name: Zapotec, Santo Domingo Albarradas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Videos. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Since 1979 Santo Domingo users have shown increasing preference for Zapotec, but in Santa María reportedly diminishing use. Some immigrant Mixe have learned local Zapotec, but few Zapotec learn Mixe. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Maia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions: 1988–2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Miani [pla].

name: Toku-No-Shima
Language Use: Adults only. Younger generation has passive understanding but cannot speak it (Okamura 2010). Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Biao
Language Development: There is an effort to use more standard Mandarin in schools in the Biaoarea. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use YueChinese [yue], specifically a local dialect, when communicating with Chinese-speaking Han andZhuang people.

name: Gimi (Eastern Highlands)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Lasgerdi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 72%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Lelak
Language Use: Shifted to Central Berawan [zbc].

name: Bassa
Writing: Bassa Vah script [Bass], used by older men. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir]. Used as L2 by Gbii [ggb].

name: Lamu-Lamu
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Keuru
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people. Also use Orokolo [oro], but decreasingly as L2.

name: Kodia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use French [fra].

name: Katawixi
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Ontong Java
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Garrwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1983–1991.
Language Use: Children have not been learning the language since 1980s (Mushin 2012). Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng]. Shifted to Kriol [rop]. Used as L2 by Yanyuwa [jao].

name: Tarok
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literacy program in progress. Grammar. NT: 1988–2007.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Pye [pai], Wãpha [juw], Ywom [gek].

name: Bau
Language Development: Bible portions: 2010.
Language Use: Most children learn Tok Pisin [tpi] first, and then learn Fulumu [bbd] whenthey’re older (2000 SIL). Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some alsouse Amele [aey], especially elderly.

name: Bavarian
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1998.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Standard German [deu], which is the language ofinstruction in school.

name: Urimo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kerak
Language Use: Those who have moved to larger urban areas no longer pass the language totheir children (2013 SIL). Used by all. Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerceand interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Some also use French [fra], as the languageof education and government (Diouf et al 2017).

name: Seko Tengah
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Panasuan [psn].

name: Nukuini
Language Use: Portuguese [por] used for 3 generations. Some older people remember some Nukuini. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Kuni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: All domains except when instructing children, arguing with family, and joking, where there is mixed use with Hiri Motu [hmo] and English [eng]. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Solomon Islands Sign Language
Language Development: Agency: Solomon Islands Deaf Association.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Kumarbhag Paharia
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Kadu
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1939.
Language Use: Vigorous in Banmauk Township (Settaw and Mawkhwin dialects), almost extinct in Indaw and Pinlebu townships (Mawteik dialect) where speakers have shifted to Burmese [mya]. All domains. Some young people, all adults. All ages in Banmauk Township; only over 80 years old in Indaw Township. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Ata
Language Use: Negative attitudes. Shifted to Cebuano [ceb].

name: Bwatoo
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Shifting to Paicî [pri]. Also useAjië [aji]. Also use French [fra].

name: Banda, Togbo-Vara
LITERACY_L2: Low in Lingala [lin] and not increasing.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low in Lingala [lin] and not increasing.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Mono [mnh]. Also use Sango [sag].

name: Glavda
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1967–2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Remun
Language Use: Strong identity centered around the Remun isolect. Some young people, all adults. Also use Bidayuh Serian [sdo]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Iban [iba]. Also use Malay [zlm].

name: Yuracare
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Wolof, Gambian
Language Development: Bible portions: 1882–1967.
Language Use: Also use English [eng], as the language of education and government. Used as L2 by Bambara [bam], Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], Jola-Fonyi [dyo], Mandinka [mnk], Mandjak [mfv], Pulaar [fuc], Serahule [snk], Serer-Sine [srr], Western Maninkakan [mlq].

name: Comorian
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].

name: Yana
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Pare
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Bible portions: 1978–1980.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Mixed Great Andamanese
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Andaman Hindi Creole [hca]. Used as L2 by Aka-Jeru [akj].

name: Ngwe
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Yemba [ybb]. A few also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Yemba [ybb].

name: Pu-Xian Chinese
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used between 1890–1950, once used in a newspaper.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate inChinese, and they use that literature. Bible: 1912.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Larteh
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka].

name: Patwin
Language Development: Grammar. The Yocha Dehe Wintun Nation has offered language classes since 2006. There are 14 youth classes and 2 adult classes taught in Yocha Dehe on a weekly basis (2018 Yocha Dehe Wintun Nation).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nimbari
Language Use: Shifted to South Fali [fal].

name: Kyaka
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1973–1987.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Draper and Draper 2002). Also use Melpa [med] (Draper and Draper 2002). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Draper and Draper 2002).

name: Keapara
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Aushiri
Language Use: Shifted to Napo Quichua [qvo].

name: Ndo
Language Use: Most also use Alur [alz]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh].

name: Kanan
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Tapei
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Kassell et al2017).

name: Mixtec, Ixtayutla
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013–2023.
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Also use Amoltepec Mixtec [mbz]. Also use Jamiltepec Mixtec [mxt], proficiently and preferred over Spanish. Also use Spanish [spa], but it is not preferred, except in the municipal capital, Ixtayutla.

name: Ketum
Language Use: Home, community.

name: Wergaia
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Vili
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Kol (Cameroon)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra]. Some also use Bulu [bum]. Some also useKoonzime [ozm]. Some also use Makaa [mcp].

name: Jimi (Cameroon)
Language Development: Bible portions: 2006–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Gude[gde] (Brye 2002). Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use French [fra].

name: Muduga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25% (31% men and 17% women) (1991 census). One of the least literate communities in Kerala, but 73% of survey respondents claim to be literate in Malayalam [mal]. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous, children learn it first. Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal]. Education often determines the extent of bilingualism in it, but even some higher educated Muduga are not adequately bilingual. Used as L2 by Attapady Kurumba [pkr], Kannada Kurumba [kfi].

name: Isirawa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Vigorous, but losing its trade language status to Indonesian [ind]; children are beginning to prefer Indonesian (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Samarokena [tmj].

name: Katua
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Jwira-Pepesa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Also use Nzema [nzi], in the south. Also use Wasa [wss], especially Pepesadialect speakers and in the north.

name: Skou
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Indonesian [ind]. Literacy motivation high, program in progress. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Dumo [vam]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Wutung [wut].

name: Batui
Language Use: Home, cultural events. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Greek, Ancient (to 1453)
Writing: Cypriot syllabary [Cprt]. Greek script [Grek]. Linear B script [Linb].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used as a religious language by the Greek Orthodox Church. The language ofthe text of the Christian New Testament.

name: Mauritian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Society for the Welfare of the Deaf (SWDEAF).
Language Use: Deaf schools. Used by all.

name: Paunaka
Language Use: Many shifted to Chiquitano [cax]. Many shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Mongo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1930.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin], increasingly. Used as L2 by Bolia [bli], Lalia [lal].

name: Zhoa
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Malimba
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Duala [dua]. Most also use French [fra].

name: Makian, West
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kalkutungu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Turkish Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Turkish National Federation of the Deaf.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Turkish [tur]. Used as L2 by Mardin Sign Language [dsz].

name: Angal
Language Development: Bible portions: 1990.
Language Use: Also use Enga [enq]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Wunambal
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: People generally speak Kriol [rop]. Children may know some of the language, but most speak Kriol or English [eng]. Shifted to English [eng]. Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Karekare
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2022.

name: Bahamas Creole English
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Masela, West
Language Use: Possibly endangered (Florey 2005). Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Shifting to Ambonese Malay [abs]. Also use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.

name: Girirra
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Borana-Arsi-Guji Oromo [gax](Mekonnen 2015). Most also use Somali [som] (Mekonnen 2015).

name: Lingarak
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Guanche
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Atruahí
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Portuguese [por], especially males (Crevels2007).

name: Frisian, Eastern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Standard German [deu]. Used as L2 bySaterfriesisch [stq].

name: Chinantec, Tlacoatzintepec
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1991–2008.
Language Use: In Tlacoatzintepec and environs, the children are still growing up speakingChinantec. (2011 SIL). Used by all.

name: Wahgi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1989.

name: Luguru
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng].

name: Kemezung
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy program started in 2011. Schooling is inEnglish. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2014–2019.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cameroon Pidgin[wes]. Also use Chung [cnq]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kom [bkm]. Also use Lamnsoʼ [lns].Also use Limbum [lmp]. Also use Naami [bzv]. Also use Nchane [ncr]. Also use Sari [asj]. Alsouse Tigon Mbembe [nza]. Used as L2 by Chung [cnq], Naami [bzv], Nchane [ncr], Sari [asj].

name: Amarakaeri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 1986–2008.
Language Use: Still spoken by the children in some communities (2012). Also use Spanish[spa].

name: Biloxi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Igala
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 1970.
Language Use: Agatu, Idoma, and Bassa people use Igala to attend Ika Bible School. Alldomains. Used as L2 by Basa [bzw].

name: Naaba
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lhomi [lhm], especially inhabitants of Pharang and Dangok.

name: Bété, Daloa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Huave, Santa María Del Mar
Language Use: Children do not grow up speaking Huave. But when they become adults theyall learn it in order to function in the culture (2011 J. Williams). Adults only, and somesemi-fluent children as L2 speakers. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Umotína
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Bisaya, Sabah
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 70% in Standard Malay [zsm].Videos. Bible portions: 1938. Agency: Sabah Bisaya Cultural Association.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work, Education. Some young people, alladults. Positive attitudes. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Many also use Brunei [kxd]. Also useTatana [txx]. Used as L2 by Klias River Kadazan [kqt], Papar [dpp], Tatana [txx].

name: Dahalik
Language Use: Also use Afar [aar]. Also use Standard Arabic [arb].

name: Amarag
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Zaramo
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Swahili [swh], with many shifting.

name: Nanga Dama Dogon
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Jamsay Dogon [djm]. Most also use Tommo So Dogon [dto].

name: Fataluku
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Makuva [lva].

name: Karaim
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Crimea. Latin script [Latn], used inLithuania.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. OT: 1842.
Language Use: Shifted to Lithuanian [lit].

name: Tolowa
Language Development: All L2 speakers are literate. Dictionary. Some successful language revival efforts (Golla 2011).
Language Use: One fully fluent L2 speaker in his 40s but growing numbers of younger emerging speakers with limited competence (Golla 2007). Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kamberau
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Wayoró
Language Use: Low ethnolinguistic vitality. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Chilisso
Language Use: Socially integrated with the Kohistani Shina [plk]. Most also use KohistaniShina [plk].

name: Gresi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Maltese Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Maltese Deaf People’s Association.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Maltese [mlt].

name: Majhwar
Language Use: Shifting to English [eng].

name: Tulai
Language Use: All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker and Araokanmi 2022). Some also use English [eng] (Decker and Araokanmi 2022).

name: Mbato
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Anyin [any]. Also use Attié [ati]. Used as L2 by Beti [eot].

name: Guajajára
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Taught as subject inprimary schools. Bible: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Portuguese [por], as a lingua franca (Crevels2007).

name: Keerray-Woorroong
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Litzlitz
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Shifted to Neve’ei [vnm]. Shifted to Uripiv-Wala-Rano-Atchin [upv].

name: Nusa Laut
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Enga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: Low. Dictionary. Texts. NT:1979–1988.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012). Usedas L2 by Angal [age], Angal Enen [aoe], Angal Heneng [akh], Ipili [ipi], Lembena [leq], Nete[net], Pinai-Hagahai [pnn], Umbu-Ungu [ubu].

name: Thaiphum Chin
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya]. Also use Hakha Chin [cnh], especially the older generation. Also use Matu Chin [hlt].

name: Mandaic
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Ethnic group of 5,000 in Khuzestan, Iran, speak Iranian Persian [pes] (1994 H. Mutzafi). Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Most shifted to Iranian Persian [pes]. Most shifted to Mesopotamian Arabic [acm].

name: Téén
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Bible portions: 1985–1995.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, market, religion. Used by all. Many also use French [fra], including all school children. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Lobi [lob]. Used as L2 by Loma [loi].

name: Budu
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Some also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Used as L2 byLika [lik].

name: Langbashe
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All also use Sango [sag].

name: Konda-Dora
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 35%–44% for Vizianagaram, Srikakulam and E. Godavaridistricts; 29% among Kubi in Odisha (2001 census). Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006–2020.
Language Use: Many ethnic Porja have adopted Telugu [tel] as L1. Also use English [eng].Also use Odia [ory].

name: Hawai'i Pidgin Sign Language
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Some people remember and use HSL signs mixed with ASL. Original HSL isalmost extinct, and CHSL is dying out. Most elderly deaf use CHSL and may not recognize how muchASL vocabulary has been incorporated in their signing (2020 J. Woodward). Elderly only. Shiftedto American Sign Language [ase].

name: Kuwaataay
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Those who have moved to larger urban areas no longer pass the language totheir children (2013 SIL). Used by all. Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerceand interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Some also use French [fra], as the languageof education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Also use Jola-Fonyi [dyo]. Also use Jola-Kasa[csk].

name: Inupiatun, Northwest Alaska
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997–2010.
Language Use: Immersion schools. Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Lawa, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy in Thai [tha] is common. Grammar. Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: Very high language vitality. All domains, except government and education (which are in Thai [tha]). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Proud of Lawa history and culture and want to maintain language. All also use Northern Thai [nod], especially for government and school. Many also use Thai [tha], with outsiders.

name: Arifama-Miniafia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Bauwaki
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Magi [mgu]. Alsouse Suau [swp].

name: Cholón
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Huamalíes-Dos de Mayo Quechua [qvh].

name: Pileni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Äiwoo [nfl]. Also use Pijin [pis]. Used as L2 by Äiwoo [nfl].

name: Arabela
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 1986–2008.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Yukaghir, Southern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus]. Also use Even [eve], especially older adults. Also use Yakut [sah], especially younger.

name: Sharwa
Language Use: Some of all ages. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Quechua, Chiquián Ancash
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Home, work, community. Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Bolivian Sign Language
Language Development: Agency: Federación Boliviana de Sordos (FEDOS, Bolivian Federation of theDeaf).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Parbate, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Young adults and older. Also use Nepali[npi].

name: Weri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. NT: 1984.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mobwa Karen
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya], with some youth shifting. Also use S’gaw Karen [ksw], with some youth shifting.

name: Réunion Creole French
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: 25% are white, poor, live in the mountainous interior, and speak archaic highland varieties. 25% are Indian, live in coastal lowlands, and speak the basilect. 45% are African or mixed race, live in coastal lowlands, and speak the basilect. Positive attitudes, which are increasing. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Tamil [tam].

name: Kwerisa
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. Shifted to Kaiy [tcq].

name: Hitu
Language Use: Moderate to vigorous.

name: Maraghei
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Romani, Kalo Finnish
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–100%. Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Bible portions: 1970–1971.
Language Use: Also use Finnish [fin].

name: Lahanan
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Gabri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%–5%. NT: 2023.

name: Estonian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2021. Agency: Estonian Associationof the Deaf.
Language Use: First deaf school 1866. Deaf associations. Used by all. Also use RussianSign Language [rsl].

name: Yau (Morobe Province)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Sarvasy 2014).

name: Gadaba, Pottangi Ollar
Writing: Oriya (Odia) script [Orya], used in Odisha. Telugu script [Telu], used inAndhra Pradesh.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 7%. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Desiya [dso], as main L2. Also use Telugu[tel], but with low proficiency.

name: Sonia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. In 1993 children went to school in Kaluli areas.
Language Use: Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Bedamuni [beo] (Aiton 2019). Also use English [eng] (Aiton 2019). Also use Kaluli [bco] (Aiton 2016).

name: Khetrani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Also use Saraiki [skr].

name: Gbe, Defi
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gun [guw]. Alsouse Yoruba [yor].

name: Chehalis, Lower
Language Development: Lower Chehalis people are attempting to merge what remains of theirlanguage with Quinault [qun].
Language Use: A few people may have passive knowledge of some words and phrases (Golla2007). Shifted to English [eng].

name: Abun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2004.

name: Mlomp
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Some also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Also use Jola-Fonyi [dyo]. Also use Mandinka [mnk]. Also use Pulaar [fuc].

name: Watut, South
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, neutral to positive. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Carter et al 2014).

name: Dano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1989.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Tokano [zuh].

name: Yapunda
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wilson 2017).

name: Topoiyo
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Work, Religion, Education. Older adults only. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Budong-Budong [bdx].

name: Kuk
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Somealso use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Nanubae
Language Use: Most domains. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi](Kassell et al 2017).

name: Namat
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Kanja [pep]. Some also use Wára [tci]. A few also use Motu [meu], especially elderly.

name: Jofotek-Bromnya
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Alsouse Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Ngurimi
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009–2023.
Language Use: All domains, unless speakers of other languages present. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Yawijibaya
Language Use: Moribund (McGregor and Rumsey 2009). Shifted to English [eng].

name: Chulym
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Yindjibarndi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1983.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Banyjima [pnw].

name: Nooksack
Language Development: The Lhéchalosem Teacher Training Language Immersion Project offers language and cultural training with both a two-year and a four-year program. Those completing the four-year program become certified language teachers. The aim is to revive the use of the language in all aspects of daily life (2010 Foothills Gazette).
Language Use: 2 or 3 older adults each know fewer than 30–40 words (1998). Shifted to English [eng].

name: Muskum
Language Use: Shifted to Musgu [mug].

name: Taromi, Upper
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Virgin Islands Creole English
Writing: Latin script [Latn], informal use on social media (wikipedia).
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Arabic, Judeo-Tripolitanian
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Hebrew [heb].

name: Tangoa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Code-switching with Bislama [bis] occurs. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Soro-n Raki [akr].

name: Kurumba, Alu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Some also use Kannada [kan], or southern nonstandard Kannada. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Matlatzinca, San Francisco
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: About half of the village is away at work in Mexico City and other places most of the time (2011 J. Williams). Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Mbulungish
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Bit
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Gabi-Gabi
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ngundi
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lingala [lin] (Leitch 2005).

name: Che
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1924–1931.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religious settings, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Kofei
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifting to Barapasi [brp].

name: Kei
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 100 can read, 10 can write. Literacy rate in L2:50%–75%. 100 can read, 10 can write. Dictionary.
Language Use: Fairly vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useBanda [bnd]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Banda [bnd], Kur [kuv].

name: Finnish Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1989. Agencies: Finnish Associationof the Deaf (FAD); Finnish Museum of the Deaf.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by deaf people whose families speak Finnish [fin] and whoattended schools that used Finnish as the language of instruction (Hoyer 2004). Used by all.Also use Finnish [fin]. Used as L2 by Finland-Swedish Sign Language [fss].

name: Mo'da
Language Use: Shifting to Beli [blm]. Also use Jur Modo [bex].

name: Nangikurrunggurr
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Kriol [rop].

name: Talaud
Language Development: Bible: 2003.
Language Use: Adults only. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Manado Malay [xmm].

name: Rennell-Belona
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Yorta Yorta
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Biage
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, traditional domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Manyalso use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Hiley et al 2015).

name: Libyan Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Libyan General Federation of Deaf Societies (LGFDS).
Language Use: Deaf associations.

name: Adang
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adang is becoming more restricted in domains and is decreasing inpopulation due to urbanization (Haan 2001). Some young people, all adults. Losing child speakers(Haan 2001). Also use Indonesian [ind] (Hamilton et al 2013).

name: Yi, Eastern Lalu
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Motu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1973.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng] (Wu 2020). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wu 2020). Used as L2 by Koita [kqi], Nama [nmx], Namat [nkm], Nambo [ncm], Namo [mxw], Neme [nex], Opao [opo], Purari [iar], Sinaugoro [snc], Toaripi [tqo], Toura [don], Uare [ksj].

name: Manyika
Language Use: Used as L2 by Barwe [bwg].

name: Nicaraguan Sign Language
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Asociación Nacional de Sordos de Nicaragua (ANSNIC).
Language Use: Vigorous. Increasing use among hearing people. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Banda, West Central
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Sansi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Not being passed on to the next generation. Much mixing of Hindi [hin], Eastern Punjabi [pan], or Gujarati [guj] (Gusain 2002). Home only. Adults only. Some shifting to Eastern Punjabi [pan]. Some shifting to Gujarati [guj]. Some shifting to Hindi [hin].

name: Makuri Naga
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya]. Used as L2 by Long Phuri Naga [lpn].

name: Simba
Language Use: Shifted to French [fra].

name: Mada (Nigeria)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. A few also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Baan
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Yi, Western (Xishanba Lalo)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: In many areas it is extinct or severely endangered; vital in some areas where parents teach their children and use it in most domains. Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially young people.

name: Hixkaryána
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Hixkaryanaliteracy no longer taught in schools. Mother tongue literacy only taught by some parents inhome. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1976.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por]. Many also use Waiwai[waw]. Used as L2 by Kaxuiâna [kbb].

name: Iwam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Paulsen 2003).

name: Mur Pano
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Carter et al 2012).

name: Ndyuka-Trio Pidgin
Language Use: Used until 1960s by Ndyuka, Trio and Wayana peoples for trading. Increasing travel to the coast cut back on that trade, and also gave some opportunity to use Sranan Tongo [srn] in contact with the Ndyuka. Few Ndyuka men, even older ones, now know it. Used rarely now.

name: Zapotec, Lachixío
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Romani, Baltic
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Belarus, Russian Federation, and Ukraine. Latin script [Latn], used in Latvia, Lithuania and Poland.
Language Development: Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Polish [pol].

name: Babar, Southeast
Language Use: Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Leti (Cameroon)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in French [fra].
Language Use: The Mengisa people reportedly speak 2 languages: Mengisa [mct], and Leti. However the linguistic context is rather complex and a very thorough sociolinguistic survey needs to be done. Most of the Mengisa people speak Mengisa; a percentage of them use Leti as a ‘secret language´, so that their Ewondo and Eton neighbors cannot understand them. There is also a smaller population of the Mengisa who speak Leti as their mother tongue (2014 SIL). Shifting to Eton [etn]. Most also use French [fra]. Also use Mengisa [mct]. Also use Tuki [bag]. Used as L2 by Mengisa [mct].

name: Ngoni (Tanzania)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Brokpake
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Guarequena
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Southern Betsimisaraka Malagasy
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains, except education, religion, and government. Used by all.Positive attitudes.

name: Popoloca, Mezontla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Grammar.
Language Use: Less than 20% of the people can understand the language; 10% can speak it some and only 10 individuals speak it well, according to the village president (1994 SIL). Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Sangkong
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Most also use Hani [hni], particularly the Yani variety of Haya dialect. Also use Lahu [lhu]. Also use Lü [khb]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Koki Naga
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Tangkhul Naga [ntx], especially the older generation.

name: Gata'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Odisha (2001 census). Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Desiya [dso]. Also use English[eng]. Also use Odia [ory].

name: Asuriní, Xingú
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Portuguese [por], especiallythose under 40 (Crevels 2007).

name: Aguacateco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 29%. Texts. NT: 1971–2011.Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Katla
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Use of Julud is decreasing. Some young people, all adults. The Juluddialect not spoken by children and youth.

name: Kenzi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Coptic script [Copt], Old Nubian variant. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1912. There have been revitalization efforts by individual speakers at Nubian clubs (Jaeger 2008). More recently activities in the cities have been organized by the efforts of the the Centre of Nubian Culture and Kenzi Heritage. Agency: The Centre of Nubian Culture and Kenzi Heritage.
Language Use: Speaker population has declined since their resettlement from their homeland to the Kom Ombo area in 1963–1964. Home, Special cultural events. Adults only. Neutral attitudes. All shifting to Egyptian Arabic [arz]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Iwam, Sepik
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1989.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Ambai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT:2010.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind], especially children.

name: Lamkang
LITERACY_L2: 40% in Meitei [mni]: 10 to 40 year olds (2000 S.
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], used in Myanmar.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Meitei [mni]: 10 to 40 year olds (2000 S. Towar). Only 2% can read Latin script. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous, but each successive generation not as knowledgeable about their folksongs and folktales. Used by all. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Meitei [mni], at least passively.

name: Kolom
Language Use: Children learn Tok Pisin [tpi] first (Gray et al 2015). Traditional events, arguing at home, joking, sports. Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Gray et al 2015).

name: Hatam
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2009.

name: Naga, Tarao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75% in Meitei [mni], English [eng]. Literacy program in progress. Older people can read Meitei in Bengali script. Young people prefer Latin script. Most villages have primary and junior schools; attendance is irregular. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni].

name: Monumbo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Oroha
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Saꞌa [apb] (Wurm 2007).

name: Numee
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Zapotec, Guevea De Humboldt
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–30%. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nokuku
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–40%, only older adults. Literacy rate in L2: 60%–70%. The only literacy program was a church-sponsored one in Bislama [bis] in the past (2023 B. Pala). Bible portions: 1906–1918.
Language Use: Community, Work; Mixed: Home, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. A few also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Oa [tmt], Tavanlav [vlp].

name: Zizilivakan
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Most also use Fali Muchella [fli], passively especially Madzarin dialect; older men use all 4 Fali dialects.

name: Ngen
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some ethnic Ngen do not speak the Ngenlanguage anymore. Most also use Baoulé [bci], specifically the Ando dialect. Many also use Jula[dyu].

name: Karao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%–90%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–90%. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ibaloi [ibl]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Also use Kalanguya [kak].

name: Mpinda
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mpinda children learn Portuguese [por] even before they enter school. Adults often use Portuguese when speaking with children or age peers and at church, while they use Mpinda with parents and elders and perhaps with their spouses (2018 L. Jordan). Mixed attitudes. All also use Portuguese [por].

name: Tomadino
Language Use: Shifted to Bungku [bkz].

name: Matal
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Many also use Zulgo-Gemzek [gnd]. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Some also use Mada [mxu]. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Wuzlam [udl]. Used as L2 by Mada [mxu].

name: Kapin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: Possibly 10% are fluent readers, 25% halting. Bible portions: 2015–2020.
Language Use: In villages closer to the road, children learn Tok Pisin [tpi] as their first language. Further away from the road, children learn the vernacular first (2011 SIL). Mixed use in church with Tok Pisin [tpi], English [eng], and Yabem [jae] (2011 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kumalu [ksl]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Yabem [jae].

name: Blablanga
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Cheke Holo [mrn]. Used as L2 by Zazao [jaj].

name: Miwa
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Gade
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, alladults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. A few also use Gbagyi [gbr].

name: Ambele
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Denya [anv]. Some also use English [eng]. Somealso use Manta [myg]. Some also use Menka [mea].

name: Agwagwune
Language Development: Bible portions: 1894.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Argobba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 16% in Amharic [amh]. Taught as subject in someprimary schools. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: The ethnic group near Ankober mainly speaks Amharic [amh]; the group nearHarar mainly speaks Oromo [hae]. Some young people, all adults. Only children in one village(T’allaha) learn Argobba; in all other areas, used only by older people. Positive attitudes. Allalso use Amharic [amh] (Mohammed et al 2015). Some also use Eastern Oromo [hae] (Mohammed et al2015). A few also use Afar [aar] (Mohammed et al 2015).

name: Fataleka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use Kwara’ae [kwf]. Also use Lau [llu]. Also usePijin [pis].

name: Mixtec, San Miguel Piedras
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Damal
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Children are beginning to prefer Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Nduga [ndx].

name: Marithiel
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop]. Most also use English [eng].

name: Alune
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–65%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–55%. Dictionary. NT:2012.
Language Use: People in the interior, the majority, use it daily. Coastal village usageless vigorous. Shifting to Ambonese Malay [abs]. Many also use Ambonese Malay [abs] (Florey2005). Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Fanamaket
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Nduga
Language Use: Also use Damal [uhn]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Moni [mnz].

name: Dahalo
Language Use: Shifted to Swahili [swh] (Sommer 1992).

name: Kalanadi
Language Development: Younger generation reportedly literate in Malayalam [mal].
Language Use: Continued vitality doubtful, due to small population, no separate settlements, living with Malayalis, and similarity to Malayalam [mal]. Home. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal].

name: Horned Miao
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, market. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Tibea
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra], especially young people.

name: Ruwila
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Konongo [kcz]. Some also use Nyamwezi [nym]. Also use Swahili [swh], but at least half of the children do not know Swahili [swh], the national language, when they start school.

name: Krongo
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 1963.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Yali, Angguruk
Language Development: Bible: 2019.

name: Manggarai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2013.

name: Yugoslavian Sign Language
Language Development: School for the Deaf Ljubljana, established 1900, is the central institution, offering programs in primary and secondary (vocational) levels. Other institutions are oral or provide mainstream education with interpreters. TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Slovenian Association of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing (ZDGNS).
Language Use: Deaf schools. Deaf associations. Used by all. Also use Slovene [slv], in written form, which is taught in deaf schools.

name: Kim
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–15%. Bible: 2014.

name: Mangala
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Language learning materials are available through Wangka Maya Pilbara Aboriginal Language Centre.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Chorote, Iyo'wujwa
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Karen, Pwo Eastern
Writing: Leke (Chicken-Scratch) script [Leke], developed between 1830–1860, used by adherents to the Leke Millenarian sect. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], primary usage, a variety of orthographies are in use. Thai script [Thai], developed by expatriates around 2000, used in Thailand by West Central Thailand Pwo Karen community, limited usage.
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1883–1926.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Used as L2 by S’gaw Karen [ksw].

name: Kariyarra
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Totoro
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Dungra Bhil
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%–5%. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Emberá-Catío
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions:1975–2012.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Pero
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1936–2008.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Hõne [juh].

name: Kung-Ekoka
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1980.

name: Talise
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Sapé
Language Use: Shifted to Pemon [aoc].

name: German, Pennsylvania
Language Development: Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Plain community not shifting to English [eng], but maintains stable bilingualism (1987 M. Louden). All domains. Some of all ages. Most also use English [eng].

name: Bintauna
Language Use: Mixed: Home, Community, Work. Adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifting toManado Malay [xmm]. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Central Berawan
Language Use: Home, village. Older adults only. Shifted to Malay [zlm]. Used as L2 by Lelak [llk].

name: Pele-Ata
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Tok Pisin [tpi] andEnglish [eng]. Some adult literacy classes. Dictionary. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also useTok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mokilese
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Pohnpeian [pon].

name: Menominee
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Language teachers are being trained and educational videos prepared (Golla 2007). Agency: Menominee Language Institute.
Language Use: Religious and ceremonial functions, restricted communication among elders, educational settings. Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Wik-Mungkan
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1985.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Children are learning it (2011). Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Kugu-Muminh [xmh], Wik Ngathan [wig], Wikalkan [wik], Wik-Iiyanh [wij], Wikngenchera [wua].

name: Mankiyali
Language Use: Home, community. Some of all ages. Most also use Northern Pashto [pbu] (Anjum 2016). Most also use Urdu [urd] (Anjum 2016). Some also use English [eng] (Anjum 2016). Also use Northern Hindko [hno], with many youth shifting.

name: Pémono
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Teribe
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Lobala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: Some, in Lingala [lin] and French [fra]. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Parents in the forest and some along the Ubangi River pass on Lobala to children. Literacy classes, religious services, oral use in commerce. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Lingala [lin], especially along the Ubangi River. A few also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Bomboli [bml].

name: Chimariko
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Chimariko descendants consider both Hupa [hup] andChimariko to be heritage languages but emphasize Hupa for cultural revitalization (Golla 2007).

name: Nahuatl, Northern Puebla
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1979.

name: Una
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Dictionary. NT: 2007.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Maii
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Actively used but shifting to Namakura [nmk] and North Efate [llp] (Lynch and Crowley 2001). Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Paraujano
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Pomo, Eastern
Language Development: Grammar. The California Indian Museum and Cultural Center (CIMCC) has developed an Eastern Pomo Language Curriculum and also offers a free language learning app.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mono (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low in Lingala [lin], women below 10%. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Ngbaka [nga]. Also use Sango [sag]. Used as L2 by Fulu [fuu], Gbanziri [gbg], Gobu [gox], Mid-Southern Banda [bjo], South Central Banda [lnl], Togbo-Vara Banda [tor].

name: Awa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Texts.NT: 1974–2002.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Laki
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Iranian Persian [pes]. Most also use Northern Luri [lrc]. Used as L2 by Northern Luri [lrc], Southern Kurdish [sdh].

name: Andoa
Language Use: Shifted to Southern Pastaza Quechua [qup].

name: Kamara
Language Use: Vigorous. Some ethnic Kamara also use Safaliba [saf] as L1. Kamara inLarabanga speak Kamara. All domains. Used by all. Also use Safaliba [saf].

name: Huba
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 2008, in development.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Nearly all villages have primary schools; somehave secondary schools. Literacy program in progress. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Usedas L2 by Hwana [hwo].

name: Wayana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1979.
Language Use: Actively spoken in geographically distant and isolated villages (Crevels 2007). Also use Sranan Tongo [srn], especially in trade relations (Crevels 2007).

name: Fore
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1970–1974.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Beasley 2009).

name: Mekwei
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Bembe
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1991.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French[fra].

name: Citak
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Cha'ari
Language Use: Home. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau](Decker and Araokanmi 2022). Many also use English [eng], mostly children and young adults(Decker and Araokanmi 2022).

name: Franco-Provençal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 100% in French [fra]. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.Bible portions: 1830.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to French [fra].

name: Dibole
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains (Leitch 2004). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French[fra]. Also use Lingala [lin], especially with non-Babole.

name: Mirning, Mirniny
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kissi, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in French [fra]. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk]. Also use French [fra].

name: Haruai
Language Use: Speeches and sermons by outsiders always translated into Haruai. Used by all. Also use Kobon [kpw]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Pinai-Hagahai [pnn].

name: Totonac, Xicotepec De Juárez
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Adults only. Negative attitudes. Shifting to Spanish [spa], with older adults using Totonac more than Spanish, while others use Spanish more than Totonac. Some also use Tepehua, Nahuatl, Otomi.

name: Bandi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir]. Used as L2 by Kuwaa [blh].

name: Mono (Cameroon)
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Ndonde Hamba
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Makhuwa-Meetto [mgh]. Also use Swahili [swh], with some youth using it as L1.

name: Krumen, Plapo
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Pye Krumen [pye]. Also use Tepo Krumen [ted].

name: Tiwa, Southern
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1981–1987. Attempt to reestablish use of Southern Tiwa at Sandia Pueblo and Ysleta del Sur, El Paso, Texas.
Language Use: Vigorous in a few families. Diminishing vigor at Isleta except among older adults. Commerce on tribal land, traditional ceremonial life. Some young people, all adults. Only middle-aged or elderly are fluent but some younger people use the language and at least a few children acquire it (Golla 2007). Positive attitudes. People are apprehensive about losing their culture if the language is not revived. All also use English [eng].

name: Nek
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Prep schools in Nek. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1999–2018.
Language Use: Home, prep schools, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Zapotec, El Alto
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Itene
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Caló
Language Development: Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Grammar. Bible portions: 1837–1872.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Naga, Chokri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Greater than 40% (2001 census). NT: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Angami Naga [njm]. Also use English [eng].

name: Samatao
Writing: Yi script [Yiii], experimental use in the late 1990’s.
Language Development: Some language heritage activities underway in the village school (Bradley 2007a).
Language Use: Older adults only. No fluent speakers under 50 (Bradley 2007a). Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Selayar
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bugis [bug]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Laiyolo [lji].

name: Lala-Bisa
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1947–2000.
Language Use: Home, traditional ceremonies, community.

name: Golpa
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Rampi
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous in some villages. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Uma [ppk].

name: Bisorio
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kaningdon-Nindem
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home, market, work, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Hausa [hau]. Some also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm].

name: Dumpas
Language Use: Due to the emphasis on Standard Malay [zsm] in the educational system,those born after the 1990s are not fluent in the language, although they can still understand.Home, Friends, some Religion, Work. Adults only. Mixed attitudes. Shifting to Sabah Malay [msi].Also use Tombonuo [txa].

name: Tetserret
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home, religion. Some young people, all adults. Also use Tayart Tamajeq [thz], with some youth shifting.

name: Koli, Kachi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Gujarati script [Gujr], used by olderpeople.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Taught as subject in some primary andsecondary schools. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Izora
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Tokano
Language Development: Bible portions: 1979.
Language Use: Also use Alekano [gah]. Also use Dano [aso]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Todrah
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Naga, Wancho
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Latin script [Latn]. Wancho script [Wcho].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25% (2001 census). Bible: 2012.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Bada (Nigeria)
LITERACY_L2: Many under 40 are literate in Hausa [hau] and English[eng].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Many under 40 are literate in Hausa [hau] and English[eng]. Used in some schools.
Language Use: Home, village, market, school. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Grebo, Barclayville
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Cara
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Hausa [hau]. Also use English [eng].

name: Matumbi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh], but with low comprehension.

name: Itneg, Adasen
Language Use: Young people tend to prefer Ilocano [ilo] (Wurm 2007). Some domains. Some young people, all adults, especially young adults and older. Positive attitudes. Also use Ilocano [ilo], with high proficiency especially among the young in most key domains.

name: Tommo So Dogon
Language Development: Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Dogul Dom Dogon [dbg], Nanga Dama Dogon [nzz],Yanda Dom Dogon [dym].

name: Warlmanpa
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Karirí-Xocó
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Kayardild
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. The Kaiadilt community and Mirndiyan GununaAboriginal Corporation are running a Kayardild language revival program.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Jandavra
Language Development: No literates.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sindhi [snd]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Nabak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Fabian et al 1998). Used as L2 by Musom [msu], Numanggang [nop].

name: Meriam
Language Development: Bible portions: 1879–1994.
Language Use: Some children give preference to Torres Strait Creole [tcs] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng]. Also use Torres Strait Creole [tcs].

name: Barbareño
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Chumash descendants interested in restoring traditionalculture and language. Chumash Living Language Revitalization Project established in 1999.
Language Use: All shifted to English [eng].

name: Otomi, Mezquital
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1970.

name: Judeo-Berber
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Hebrew [heb].

name: Mangseng
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Nakanai [nak]. A few also use Lote [uvl]. A few also use Mamusi [kdf]. Used as L2 by Amio-Gelimi [let].

name: Kok-Nar
Language Development: Texts.

name: Xaragure
Language Development: Some experimental use in primary school at Borindi. Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra].

name: Ratagnon
Language Use: Shifted to Tagalog [tgl].

name: Koryak
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2006.
Language Use: Few domains. Some young people, all adults. Used by a few children, but situation varies according to location (Salminen 2007). Mixed attitudes, from neutral to mildly positive. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Even [eve].

name: Kwakiutl
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1882–1900.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mochica
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Gbanu
Language Development: Bible portions: 1932–1939.
Language Use: All also use Sango [sag].

name: Tikopia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1989.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: E'ma Buyang
Language Use: Most shifted to Guibian Zhuang [zgn], especially those ages 15–50, in a local variety. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially men and particularly in the local southwestern dialect.

name: Kyenele
Language Development: Bible portions: 1993.

name: Tumtum
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Khanty
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used between 1920–1940,experimental usage.
Language Development: Russian used in schools. Taught as subject in a few primary and secondaryschools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2000–2018.
Language Use: 20%–60% of the ethnic group speaks Khanty. In Eastern Khanty, some childspeakers but many shift to Russian [rus] at school age. Surgut and Vakh-Vasyugan are still usedin the home but boarding school system often forces a shift to Russian among youngergenerations. In Southern Khanty, transmission of the language to children stopped long ago.Assimilated to Siberian Tatar [tat] and Russian. Few domains. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Salvadoran Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy in written Spanish is increasing, due to education available infive national deaf schools (San Salvador, Santa Ana, San Miguel, Sonsonante, Cuscatlán), whichin 2021 enrolled 351 students (2022 MINEDUCYT). Dictionary. Texts. Agencies: AsociaciónSalvadoreña de Sordos (ASS); Asociación pro Desarrollo Integral de la Comunidad SordaSalvadoreña (ASDICSSA); Fundación Pro Educación de El Salvador (FUNPRES); Fundación para elDesarrollo Integral de la Persona Sorda (FUDIPES); Equipo de Investigaciones Lingüísticas deLESSA (EIL-LESSA).
Language Use: LESSA is in use in families with generational deafness, in public deafeducation, within deaf associations, at churches with interpreted services, for distributinginformation on the internet, and for official interpretation for the government of El Salvador.The growth and spread of deaf education using LESSA suggests that the percentage of LESSA userswill increase. Multigenerational deaf families all use LESSA (Ciupek-Reed 2012). Five activeinterpreters (2008 WFD). Some also use American Sign Language [ase], especially in San Salvadorand San Miguel, often mixed with LESSA. A few also use Costa Rican Sign Language [csr],previously in the eastern region, mixed with LESSA. Also use Spanish [spa], with positiveattitude toward developing Spanish reading and writing skills (Ciupek-Reed 2012). Used as L2 bySalvadoran ASL [ase].

name: Pijin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Many L1 speakers in the capital city, Honiara, are younger people, some of them well educated, who have developed their own way of speaking Pijin that is very fluid (2020 C. Jourdan). Creolization in progress. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Äiwoo [nfl], Amba [utp], ’Are’are [alu], Asumboa [aua], Bilua [blb], Bughotu [bgt], Cheke Holo [mrn], Dughore [nke], Engdewu [ngr], Fataleka [far], Hoava [hoa], Kusaghe [ksg], Kwara’ae [kwf], Lovono [vnk], Nalögo [nlz], Natügu [ntu], Noipä [npx], Savosavo [svs], Sikaiana [sky], Tanema [tnx], Teanu [tkw], To’abaita [mlu], Touo [tqu], Vaeakau-Taumako [piv].

name: Huave, San Francisco Del Mar
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa], especially youth.

name: Quinault
Language Development: Language program continues at the Taholah Elementary School. Four Quinault language teachers are tribally and state certified. Dictionary. Revitalization efforts underway. Language program continues at a local elementary school. Four Quinault language teachers are tribally and state certified. Quinault Language activities also occur during the summer (2016 C. Terry-itewaste).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Samba Daka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1933.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Nyong[muo].

name: Kao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Ethnic group membership expressed by knowing the language. Older adultsonly. Shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Naga, Liangmai
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Bible: 2001.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Ngawun
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Beli (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2004).

name: Huitoto, Murui
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1978–2008.
Language Use: Only some youth eventually learn to speak the language as young teens oryoung adults. Adults only. Most shifting to Spanish [spa] (Wojtylak 2021). Used as L2 by Ocaina[oca].

name: Kantosi
Language Use: Shifting to languages where they settled: those in Funsi now speak Pasaale [sig], those near Wa now speak Wali [wlx]. Home. Some of all ages. Also use Buli [bwu], especially in Sandema.

name: Westphalien
Language Development: Bible portions: 2003.
Language Use: Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Malimpung
Language Use: Mixed: Home, Community, Work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Indonesian [ind]. Most also use Bugis [bug].

name: Zimbabwe Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Agencies: Zimbabwe National Association of the Deaf (ZIMNAD); Association of the Deaf (ASSOD); King George VI School and Centre, Open Society Initiative for Southern Africa (OSISA).
Language Use: Primary schools for deaf children since 1940s. Also secondary schools (2008 WFD). Deaf associations. Used by all. Also use English [eng], in written form, but literacy in it is generally limited. Also use Shona [sna], especially those from Masvingo, but with limited literacy.

name: Suba-Simbiti
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Pimbwe
Language Development: Bible portions: 2018–2022.
Language Use: Home, farming, local contexts. Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Rungwa [rnw].

name: Benyadu'
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1952.
Language Use: Also use Kendayan [knx].

name: Bainouk-Gunyaamolo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2003.
Language Use: All also use Mandinka [mnk]. Many also use French [fra], as the language ofeducation and government (Diouf et al 2017). Some also use Wolof [wol], as the language ofcommerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012).

name: Mehek
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar.
Language Use: Mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] by adults in the home and community (Hatfield 2016). Some young people, all adults. Tok Pisin [tpi] is the dominant language used by speakers under 20 years old (Hatfield 2016). Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Hatfield 2016).

name: Kpatili
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag]. Also use Nzakara [nzk] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).

name: Vai
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Vai script [Vaii], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Also use Gola [gol]. Also use Liberian English [lir]. Also use Mende [men].

name: Potawatomi
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools at the Hannahville (Michigan) Indian School; many other communities have language and cultural centers where language classes are available. Grammar. Bible portions: 1844. The Prairie Band Potawatomi Language and Cultural Department is instrumental in the revitalization of the Potawatomi language and culture. Agency: Citizen Potawatomi Cultural Center.
Language Use: Ceremonial and religious activities. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Hidatsa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Curriculum for language program under development. Used conversationally bymost elderly, rarely used in public settings. Adults only, but a few children have passiveknowledge (Golla 2007). Most shifting to English [eng].

name: New Zealand Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. All ages, but decreasing especially in younger age groups (McKee and McKee 2016). Some also use English [eng].

name: Nigerian Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Zapotec, San Vicente Coatlán
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Bhalay
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Alsouse Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Nyungwe
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Phimbi [phm].

name: Lenje
Language Development: Bible: 2004.
Language Use: Home, community, traditional ceremonies. Used by all. Also use Tonga [toi].

name: Gamo-Ningi
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Yaka (Central African Republic)
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1938–2007.
Language Use: As speakers come out of the forest, they are shifting to Sango [sag]. Mostalso use Sango [sag].

name: Pipil
Language Development: Videos. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Some young adults now teach their children Nahuat. Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Tiang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 77%. Literacy rate in L2: 83% in English [eng]. Bible portions: 2006–2011.
Language Use: Home, Community, Education, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Mostly positive attitudes; a small group have negative attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Jabutí
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Portuguese [por].

name: Mashi (Zambia)
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013–2023.
Language Use: Home, community.

name: Thu Lao
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Songe
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Temoq
Language Use: Shifted to Malay [zlm].

name: Kanite
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Vernacular literacy schools have been established and very well supported in 2 of the major 3 geographical areas of the Kanite community (2023 T. Cirre). NT: 1980–2002.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Lokaa
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Lenyima [ldg], Robambami [ibm].

name: Nimboran
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1982–1985.
Language Use: Older adults only. Children learn Papuan Malay [pmy] exclusively. Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Bulu (Cameroon)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1940–2004.
Language Use: Most also use Ewondo [ewo]. Most also use French [fra], mostly for officialpurposes in the Centre, East, and South Regions. Many also use Eton [etn]. A few also useCameroon Pidgin [wes]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use Iyasa [yko]. Used as L2 byBatanga [bnm], Gyele [gyi], Iyasa [yko], Kol [biw], Kwasio [nmg], Nulibie [ekm], Numala [mmu],Swo [sox], Yangben [yav].

name: Philippine Sign Language
Language Use: Total communication used in deaf schools, with teachers both speaking and signing. Used by all. Many also use American Sign Language [ase].

name: Namla
Language Use: Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Tofanma [tlg].

name: As
Language Development: The generation below the remaining speakers are very keen to produce legacymaterials of their language, in particular a dictionary, before it becomes completely extinct(Arnold 2020).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy] (Arnold 2020). A few also useMoi Kelim [mxn], only older adults (Arnold 2020).

name: Barikewa
Language Use: Home, legal, traditional events, prayer. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Most also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Bullock 2015). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bullock 2015).

name: Abureni
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.

name: Isanzu
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home. Used as L2 by Hadza [hts].

name: Warlpiri
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Anmatyerr [amx].

name: Birifor, Malba
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Lobi[lob]. Also use Moore [mos].

name: Kyenga
Language Development: Literacy materials are available (2015 R. Jones). Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifting to Hausa [hau], Dendi [ddn], Bisã [bqp], Boko [bqc], or Zarma [dje] depending on location. Some of all ages. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Bisã [bqp]. Also use Boko [bqc]. Also use Dendi [ddn]. Also use Zarma [dje].

name: Kyerung
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Yoke
Language Use: Religious services. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Warembori [wsa]. Used as L2 by Warembori [wsa].

name: Asumboa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Shifted to Amba [utp] (Wurm 2007). Also use Pijin [pis]. Also use Tanibili[tbe].

name: Malay, Bacanese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Shifted to North Moluccan Malay [max].

name: Negeri Sembilan Malay
Language Use: Also use Malay [zlm], with some shifting.

name: Pashayi, Southwest
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Northern Pashto [pbu].

name: Ejamat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Beginning literacyclasses offered in some Protestant churches. Videos. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Shifting to Guinea-Bissau Creole occurring among those whose parentsmigrated to the capital Bissau for further education and/or economic opportunity (2022 T.Bachmann). Home, friends, religion, and work. Used also in radio and texting. Some young people,all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language ofinterethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Many also use Portuguese [por], as the languageof education and communication with foreigners. Used as L2 by Jola Bayote [bda].

name: Bamako Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Agency: Association malienne pour les sourds (AMASOURD,Malian Deaf Association).
