Language Use: Mostly older urban signers, rural signers and those with no access toformal education or LSAF. Shifting to ASL [ase] (LSAF) in Bamako (Nyst et al 2012). In Bamako,primarily used by men (Nyst 2015). Many also use American Sign Language [ase], specifically, theASL-derived variety sometimes called Langue des signes franco-africaine (LSAF) as it is used inMali (Nyst 2015). A few also use French Sign Language [fsl], which was used for a brief periodin education, before being replaced by ASL [ase] in about 2001 (Nyst 2015). A few also useQuebec Sign Language [fcs], which was taught for one year in 2009 (Nyst 2015). Also useBamanankan [bam]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Langue des signes de l’Afriquefrancophone [ase].

name: Bonggo
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Home. Shifted to Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Javanese, New Caledonian
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to French [fra].

name: Bimoba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. Bible:2004–2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Mampruli [maw].

name: Vano
Language Use: Shifted to Pijin [pis]. Shifted to Teanu [tkw].

name: Pumé
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2007).

name: Yi, Eshan-Xinping (Northern Nisu)
Language Use: The language is active in areas with high concentrations of Nisu. However, there is increasing borrowing of lexical items from Chinese. Code switching between Nisu and Chinese is common. Many men and women spend part of the year working in predominantly Chinese towns or cities. Home, village, work. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Eastern Nisu [nos]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Eastern Nisu [nos].

name: Ahtena
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Chinantec, Chiltepec
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Marimanindji
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Phuza
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Caddo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Jordanian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Holy-Land Institute for the Deaf.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Puoc
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Nauru
Language Development: School attendance required from age 6 to 17. Literacy is high. Grammar. Bible: 1918.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Children tend not to learn it anymore (Wurm 2007). All also use English [eng] (Wurm 2007).

name: Arapaso
Language Use: Shifted to Tucano [tuo].

name: Lumbu
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1933–1966.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra].

name: Khmer, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 1,000 can read Northern Khmer, 100 can write it. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2003.
Language Use: Vigorous in towns; replaced by Northeastern Thai [tts] and Thai [tha] in cities. A few Chinese shopkeepers speak it. Education, media, religious services, commerce. Positive attitudes. Also use Northeastern Thai [tts]. Also use Thai [tha] (Ungsitipoonporn and Laparporn 2019). Used as L2 by Kuay [kdt].

name: Aasáx
Language Use: Shifted to Maasai [mas] (Petrollino and Mous 2010). Shifted to Swahili[swh] (Petrollino and Mous 2010).

name: Nasal
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Yupik, Sirenik
Language Use: Shifted to Saint Lawrence Island Yupik [ess].

name: Kriol
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2007.
Language Use: Preschool children may not be bilingual in another language. Some also use English [eng], or Aboriginal languages. Used as L2 by Alawa [alh], Ami [amy], Antikarinya [ant], Bardi [bcj], Bunuba [bck], Dalabon [ngk], Djamindjung [djd], Djauan [djn], Garrwa [wrk], Gooniyandi [gni], Gurindji [gue], Jaru [ddj], Jingulu [jig], Kaytetye [gbb], Kija [gia], Kunbarlang [wlg], Kunjen [kjn], Malak Malak [mpb], Mangala [mem], Mangarrayi [mpc], Maridan [zmd], Maridjabin [zmj], Marimanindji [zmm], Maringarr [zmt], Mariyedi [zmy], Marra [mec], Marrithiyel [mfr], Martu Wangka [mpj], Miriwoong [mep], Murrinh-Patha [mwf], Ngan’gityemerri [nam], Ngarinyin [ung], Ngarinyman [nbj], Nunggubuyu [nuy], Nyikina [nyh], Rembarrnga [rmb], Ritharrngu [rit], Wadjiginy [wdj], Wagiman [waq], Walmajarri [wmt], Wambaya [wmb], Wandarang [wnd], Wardaman [wrr], Warlmanpa [wrl], Warumungu [wrm], Worrorra [wro], Wunambal [wub], Yangman [jng], Yanyuwa [jao].

name: Pana (Burkina Faso)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 15% in Jula [dyu]. Texts.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events, Technology and media. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Jula [dyu]. Some also use Western Niger Fulfulde [fuh]. A few also use Samo [smq]. Also use Marka [rkm], which young people are free to use in the home.

name: Mixtec, Tidaá
Language Development: Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Few children speak it. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Yonaguni
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Maya, Yucatán
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1992.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Yucatec Maya Sign Language [msd].

name: Hu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Roria
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 90%.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Varsaf [nrg]. Some also use Bislama [bis]. Used as L2 by Atin [plb], Varsaf [nrg].

name: Darlong
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 45%. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Amami-Oshima, Southern
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Orokolo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. NT: 1963.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Brown 1986). Used as L2 by Kaki Ae [tbd], Keoru-Ahia [xeu], Opao [opo], Tairuma [uar].

name: Dumbea
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Tama (Chad)
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use Masalit [mls].

name: Patep
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mazatec, San Jerónimo Tecóatl
Language Development: Some initiatives to teach Mazatec in primary school. Materials being prepared for adult education in Mazatec. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Shekhawati
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], with widespread bilingualism, but the educated are more proficient.

name: Gbaya-Bossangoa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Kwara'ae
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1961–2019.
Language Use: Largest indigenous vernacular in the Solomons. Used by all. Most also use Pijin [pis]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Fataleka [far].

name: Austrian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Austrian Deaf Association (ÖGLB).
Language Use: Vigorous. In deaf schools outside of the classroom. Deaf associations. Usedby all.

name: Polabian
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Hmong, Chonganjiang
Writing: Bopomofo script [Bopo], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1937.
Language Use: All domains.

name: Ronga
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 1923.

name: Bomboma
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Abipon
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Nalca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 1% semiliterate. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Koiali, Mountain
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Dutton 2010). Also use English [eng] (Dutton 2010). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Dutton 2010).

name: Apache (Lipan)
Language Development: Texts. Language preservation classes offered in San Antonio focusing onJicarilla Apache [apj] and incorporating Lipan Apache (2015).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Austral
Language Use: Shifting to Tahitian [tah].

name: Karen, Geko
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use S’gawKaren [ksw]. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Nakara
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Ethnic group members generally speak Burarra [bvr] or Djeebbana [djj]. Shifted to Burarra [bvr]. Shifted to Djeebbana [djj]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Wiru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1990.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Franklin and Kerr 2020). Used as L2 by East Kewapi [kjs], Imbongu [imo].

name: Khvarshi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults, 50%–60% of children speak Khvarshi. Positiveattitudes. Also use Avar [ava], as a literary language. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Mbandja
Language Development: Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Ngbaka [nga]. Used as L2 by Gilima [gix], Mid-Southern Banda [bjo], Yango [yng].

name: Golin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1980.
Language Use: Also use Kuman [kue].

name: Dayi
Language Use: Vitality adversely affected by the scattering of children, who now speakother languages (Wurm 2007). Shifting to English [eng]. Also use Dhuwal [dwu]. Also useDjambarrpuyngu [djr]. Also use Gumatj [gnn].

name: Loarki
LITERACY_L2: 25% boys, some older men, no girls or women in Sindhi [snd], some Urdu [urd].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25% boys, some older men, no girls or women in Sindhi [snd], some Urdu [urd].
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Sindhi [snd]. Also use Urdu [urd], especially educated individuals.

name: Nakama
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to positive. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Numanggang [nop].

name: Tela-Masbuar
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Used by all. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], except for cultural domains; children learn the local Malay variety first. Also use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.

name: Gowlan
Language Use: Home. Mixed attitudes. Positive attitudes toward Gowlan and Hindi [hin].Only some want their children to learn Marathi [mar]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi[hin], but with low bilingualism in Chikli area.

name: Bainouk-Gunyuño
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, friends, work, radio. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language of interethnic unity, communication, andcommerce. Many also use Mandinka [mnk]. Some also use Portuguese [por], as the language ofeducation and communication with foreigners.

name: Nkoya
Language Development: Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Home, traditional ceremonies, community. Also use Lozi [loz].

name: Bera
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1930.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], but not among older adults.

name: Tunebo, Angosturas
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Suruí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Bible portions: 1991–2002.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Portuguese [por].

name: Yi, Southern Lolopho
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Dusun Witu
Language Use: Also use Bakumpai [bkr].

name: Gurdjar
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions: 1991–2020.
Language Use: Okro dialect not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Lele [lle]. Used as L2 by Lele [lle].

name: Sami, Ter
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Opuuo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 36%. Literacy development and education underway, but no standardization (2018 J. Smolders). Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use Anuak [anu], as common L2. Also use Nuer [nus]. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Madi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Taught as subject in some primary schoolsthrough grade 2. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes, increasing due to vernacular literacyprograms. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Yote [wab].

name: Wichí Lhamtés Vejoz
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Leti (Indonesia)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar.
Language Use: No longer spoken by younger generations (Hajek 2006). Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Luang [lex].

name: Bauzi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–25%. 230 can read and write it. Texts. NT:2008–2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some Aliki speak Bauzi [bvz] due to intermarriage and trading.All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Eritai [ert]. Also use Indonesian [ind].Used as L2 by Eritai [ert].

name: Zapotec, Coatecas Altas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%–30%. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ngando (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Sango, Riverain
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Aribwatsa
Language Use: Shifted to Bugawac [buk].

name: Kami (Tanzania)
Language Use: Traditional religious ceremonies and conflict mediation through thetraditional chief. Shifting to Swahili [swh] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).

name: Sholaga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 31% for Tamil Nadu. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Sauk
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Domains: Home, community; Mixed use: church. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pennington 2018).

name: Woleaian
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Woleai script [Wole], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].

name: Yarawata
Language Use: Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Guayabero
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20% in Spanish [spa](2007 Nadya L.). Taught as subject in most primary schools. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish[spa].

name: Hoava
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Marovo [mvo] (Davis 2003). Also use Pijin [pis](Davis 2003).

name: Jalkunan
Language Development: Government literacy program in Jula.
Language Use: Home. Shifting to Jula [dyu].

name: Avá-Canoeiro
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: All the Avá-Canoeiros of the Araguaia speak or at least understand thelanguage. All the people of the Rio Tocantins also speak Avá-Canoeiro and Portuguese [por](Rodrigues 2021). Some of all ages. Some also use Karajá [kpj] (Instituto Socioambiental 2020).Some also use Portuguese [por] (Instituto Socioambiental 2020).

name: Aeka
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except church, where there is mixed use withHunjara-Kaina Ke [hkk], Orokaiva [okv], English [eng], Tok Pisin [tpi], and Ewage Notu [nou] invarying amounts, depending on the village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use TokPisin [tpi]. A few also use Orokaiva [okv]. Also use Binandere [bhg]. Also use English [eng].Also use Ewage-Notu [nou]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Hunjara-Kaina Ke [hkk]. Used as L2by Binandere [bhg], Orokaiva [okv].

name: Madhi Madhi
Language Development: Texts. In 2015, Dr. Luise Hercus, a leading chronicler of endangeredAustralian Aboriginal languages, gathered Madhi Madhi and other indigenous groups together tohear recordings of their heritage languages with the goal of helping the groups ‘maintain andteach their languages to future generations’.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nyaheun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Lao [lao] (Schliesinger 2003b).

name: Ese Ejja
Language Development: Taught as subject in most primary schools, yet with very little interest inL1 literacy resulting in extremely low literacy rate. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1984–2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Cabécar
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1993–2014.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sekani
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1969.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Senoufo, Djimini
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Tonjon [tjn].

name: El Molo
Language Development: Some revitalization may be taking place.
Language Use: Shifted to Samburu [saq].

name: Minyag, Eastern
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Most also use MandarinChinese [cmn].

name: Eggon
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, alladults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Akye [aik].

name: Ani Phowa
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home, village, market. Used by all.

name: Wemba Wemba
Language Development: Dictionary. Revitalization efforts initiated by Dr. Luise Hercus in 2015.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Abé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. Bibleportions: 1967–1980.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Attié [ati], Krobu [kxb].

name: Pacahuara
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Chácobo [cao] (Tallman 2018).

name: Waray (Australia)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Budong-Budong
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some intermarriage and bilingualism with Topoiyo [toy] is pressuringvitality (Wurm 2007). Mixed in Home, Communty and Work. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes.All also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Topoiyo [toy]. Some also use Mamuju [mqx]. A fewalso use Mandar [mdr].

name: Ndau
Language Use: Used as L2 by Sena [seh].

name: Ma'di, Southern
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014–2022.
Language Use: Home, work, markets. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Lugbara [lgg].

name: Principense
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use, unified alphabet (ALUSTP) developed for use by all native languages of São Tomé e Principe officially recognized by government in 2010 (2020 M. Bouchard). No published literature.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Most L1 users are over the age of 60, and have varying levels of competency (Agostinho and Araujo 2021). Elderly only. All shifted to Portuguese [por]. Some also use Kabuverdianu [kea]. Some also use Sãotomense [cri].

name: Yaygir
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Kaco'
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Khmer [khm]. Younger people are having more contact with Khmer [khm] through schooling. Some also use Jarai [jra]. Some also use Lao [lao]. Some also use Tampuan [tpu]. A few also use Krung [krr]. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Kapriman
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Sumbuk 2006). Used as L2 byKaningra [knr].

name: Inapang
Language Development: Bible portions: 2007–2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Aka
Language Use: Most shifted to Berta [wti]. Most shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Nonuya
Language Development: Efforts are being made to transcribe audio recordings made of 4 speakers between 1973 and 2007 (2020 J. A. Echeverri).
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa]. Also use Andoque [ano]. Also use Muinane [bmr]. Also use Nipode Witoto [hux].

name: Moksha
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: The Tengushen are Erzya ethnically, but speak Moksha. Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language but usually only use it with elderly relatives (Salminen 2007). Also use Russian [rus].

name: Wik-Ngathana
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Wik-Mungkan [wim] (Wurm 2007). Many also use English [eng].

name: Yokuts
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Some revival activity in Chukchansi and Tachi communities and several Yowlumne speakers and learners have participated in master-apprentice teaching (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mbangwe
Language Use: Most also use French [fra].

name: Bungku
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: LWC before independence. Some of all ages. Neutral attitudes. All also useIndonesian [ind]. Many also use Mori Bawah [xmz]. Some also use Bugis [bug]. Used as L2 byKoroni [xkq], Tomadino [tdi].

name: Nubri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 10%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Speakers have minimal proficiency in Tibetan. Also use Nepali [npi]. Minimal proficiency in Nepali, which is used with outsiders. Used as L2 by Kuke [ght].

name: Korku
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy program in some villages in Chikaldarafield. 50 literates reported. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also useMarathi [mar]. Used as L2 by Nihali [nll].

name: Tamang, Eastern Gorkha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 10%.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Ghari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible: 1998.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Yue Chinese (Cantonese)
Writing: Braille script [Brai], used in Hong Kong. Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant [Hant], official usage in Hong Kong and Macau, also used elsewhere. Latin script [Latn], used since mid-19th century.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Speakers are highly literate in Chinese. Fully developed. Bible: 1894–1981.
Language Use: Second only to Mandarin [cmn] in use. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], which many understand, speaking it only with difficulty. Used as L2 by Biao [byk], Chadong [cdy], E [eee], Iu Mien [ium], Lianshan Zhuang [zln], Min Nan Chinese [nan], Vietnamese [vie], Yang Zhuang [zyg], Yongnan Zhuang [zyn], Zuojiang Zhuang [zzj].

name: Orok
Language Development: A project to create a literary norm in Cyrillic script and teach the language at elementary schools has recently been launched in cooperation with Japanese scholars (Salminen 2007). Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 A. Kibrik). Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Makalero
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home, religion. Used by all. Most also use Indonesian [ind] (Huber 2011). Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Huber 2011).

name: Southern Sami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Bible portions: 1993–2013.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used by few children. All also use Swedish [swe] (Ylikoski 2022).

name: Kuvi
LITERACY_L2: 34%—42% in for Vishakhapatnam, Vizianagaram, Srikakulam districts (2001 census).
Writing: Latin script [Latn], experimental usage in 1916. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya], used in Odisha. Telugu script [Telu], used in Andhra Pradesh.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 34%—42% in for Vishakhapatnam, Vizianagaram, Srikakulam districts (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1987–2020.
Language Use: Dongria and Kuvi subgroups speak Kuvi as L1. Also use English [eng].

name: Tamahaq, Tahaggart
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng], called Shifinagh in Niger.
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1948–1965.
Language Use: Most still speak the language.

name: Iraya
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Many also use Filipino [fil], in the home.

name: Paama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1944–2015.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Lamenu [lmu].

name: Oksapmin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012). Some also use Bimin [bhl] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012). Used as L2 by Bimin [bhl], Hewa [ham].

name: Dyangadi
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Language classes for adults offered at Djigay Centre atKempsey TAFE (Technical and Further Education) and in Bellbrook; Thunghutti Tidda’s AboriginalCorporation was producing a K–6 language teaching kit in 2007.

name: Belhariya
Language Development: About 5 speakers are literate in their mother tongue. Dictionary.
Language Use: Many parents only use Nepali [npi] with their children, citing advantagesfor economic and social success. Religion; mixed use: Home, friends, work. Some young people,all adults. Adults and elderly. Some use among children and adolescents. Negative attitudes.Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Arára (Mato Grosso)
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Tho
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Imbongu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English[eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use West Kewapi [kew]. Also use Witu [wiu]. Used as L2 byEast Kewapi [kjs].

name: Neapolitan
Language Development: Bible portions: 1861–1862.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Italian [ita].

name: Konai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: All domains except in church and interactions with outsiders, where there is mixed use. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Aekyom [awi], especially older adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Manyawa
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lomwe [ngl].

name: Chinantec, Usila
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Dictionary. Texts. NT:1983.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nyong
Language Use: Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use French [fra].

name: Maidu, Northwest (Konkow)
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Revitalization efforts led by the Konkow Language Preservation Group.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mixtec, Mitlatongo
Language Development: Bible portions: 2012.
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], which is learned by children to a limited extent.

name: Thai, Southern
Language Development: Read Thai [tha]. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2000.
Language Use: 81% use Southern Thai in the home, Muslim Tai (Thai Malay) speak only Southern Thai. Used by all. Also use Thai [tha]. Used as L2 by Kensiu [kns], Kintaq [knq], Ten’edn [tnz], Urak Lawoi’ [urk].

name: Beneraf, Bonerif, Edwas
Language Use: Home. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy], especially children.

name: Abanyom
Language Development: English [eng] used in school. Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Also useEkajuk [eka]. Also use Nde-Nsele-Nta [ndd]. Also use Nkem-Nkum [isi]. Also use Nnam [nbp]. Usedas L2 by Nde-Nsele-Nta [ndd].

name: Gbari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions:1925–2018.
Language Use: All non-formal contexts. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 byKoro Nulu [vkn], Koro Zuba [vkz].

name: Liabuku
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Muna [mnb]. Many also use Wolio [wlo].

name: Adonara
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Negerhollands
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1781–1833.

name: Yurutí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–40% in Spanish [spa]. 10% can write Wajiara. Bible portions: 1985–1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa], in schools and government contexts. Also use Tucano [tuo], especially along the Pacá and Caño Yi rivers. Used as L2 by Waimaha [bao].

name: Kalkoti
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Gawri [gwc] (Liljegren 2013). Most shifting to Northern Pashto [pbu] (Liljegren 2013). Many also use Urdu [urd], especially the educated and those who migrate to Punjab province each winter for employment.

name: Mbula-Bwazza
Language Use: Hausa [hau] also used at home, English [eng] used in schools and by the young. Mbula Pastors’ Forum promoting the use of Mbula in the churches. Home, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Bacama [bcy]. Also use Bata [bta]. Also use Dera [kna]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kaan [ldl]. Also use Longuda [lnu]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Kaan [ldl].

name: Paiute, Northern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1985–2012. Language programs in several communities but no immersion schools. Have increased awareness but made no new fluent speakers (Golla 2007). Informal language programs in Owens Valley Paiute, language classes, written materials for Gidutikad band.
Language Use: Greatest use in McDermitt. Older adults only, with 20%–30% of the children acquiring it as L1 at Fort McDermitt (Golla 2007). Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Asaro'o
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Taught as subject in a few primary schools through grade 2. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Forak [frq].

name: Baluan-Pam
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Schokkin 2020). Some also useEnglish [eng] (Schokkin 2020). Some also use Titan [ttv] (Schokkin 2020). A few also use Lou[loj], especially elderly (Schokkin 2020). Used as L2 by Lou [loj].

name: Tawala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT: 1985.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Dobu [dob] (Ezard 1997). Also use English [eng] (Ezard 1997). Also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Ezard 1997). Also use Suau [swp] (Ezard 1997). Also use Wedau [wed] (Ezard 1997). Used as L2 by ’Auhelawa [kud], Buhutu [bxh], Bwanabwana [tte], Haigwai [hgw], Maiwala [mum], Oya’oya [oyy], Taupota [tpa], Wa’ema [wag], Wagawaga [wgb], Yaleba [ylb].

name: Tehuelche
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Have assimilated with the Mapuche [arn] (Mapudungun). Shifted to Mapudungun [arn].

name: Kolbila
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1982–1985.
Language Use: Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use French [fra].

name: Bine
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Videos. NT:1993.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng] (Döhler 2019). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi](Döhler 2019).

name: Tembo (Motembo)
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Dusner
Language Use: Shifted to Wamesa [wad].

name: Ventureño
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bathari
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Omani Arabic [acx].

name: Chiru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 56% in English [eng] and Meitei [mni] (2000 A.Khorong). Grammar. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Educated youth more interested in developing L1 and preserving culture thanelders. Community. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni].

name: Martu Wangka
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1981–1999.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Also use Kriol [rop]. Also use Kukatja [kux]. Also use Walmajarri [wmt]. Used as L2 by Kukatja [kux].

name: Miriti
Language Use: Shifted to Tucano [tuo].

name: Tangkhul Naga (Myanmar)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], based on the Somra village dialect.
Language Development: Bible: 1989.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Used as L2 by Akyaung Ari Naga [nqy], Kokak Naga [nxk].

name: Wanman
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Ethnic group members generally speak Kriol [rop], English [eng], Martu Wangka [mpj], or Nyangumarta [nna]. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ohlone (Northern)
Language Development: Revitalization work in progress: all ages attend workshops in the language.Many consider themselves speakers because they can converse in the language.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Arem
Language Use: Shifted to Vietnamese [vie].

name: Saep
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Bible portions: 1997.
Language Use: Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Dumun [dui].

name: Kulere
Language Use: Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Muniru et al 2016). Some also use English [eng] (Muniru et al 2016). Used as L2 by Bo-Rukul [mae].

name: Omi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 65% in Bangala [bxg], 30% in French [fra]. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg]. Also use French [fra].

name: Fa d'Ambu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Spanish [spa].Grammar. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous use in Annobón and Malabo. All domains except government andeducation where Spanish [spa] is used. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish[spa]. Many on Bioko learn it, but less so on Annobón; women on Annobón seem uncomfortable usingit. Many also use Equatorial Guinean Pidgin [fpe], especially those who live on Bioko island. Afew also use Fang [fan]. Also use Portuguese [por], as a liturgical language by local Catholics.

name: Barok
Language Use: Private conversations among fluent speakers (Du 2010). Some young people,all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Du 2010). Many also use English[eng], especially young people (Du 2010).

name: Guhu-Samane
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. NT:1975–1983.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin[tpi] (Handman 2017).

name: Yalahatan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1990.
Language Use: Adults only. Many shifting to Ambonese Malay [abs]. Also use Indonesian[ind].

name: Nyiyaparli
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Wangka Maya Pilbara Aboriginal Language Centre has Nyiyaparli language learning materials; in 2016, Wangka Maya started offering a Certificate III in Aboriginal Languages, and some of the first students were Nyiyaparli.
Language Use: Ethnic group members generally use Aboriginal English [eng] or Nyangumarta [nna]. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Wahgi, North
Language Development: Bible portions: 2006–2018.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Jukun Takum
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 1980–1994.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English[eng], as language of public education. Used as L2 by Akum [aku], Beezen [bnz], Bikya [byb],Bishuo [bwh], Kutep [kub], Naki [mff], Yukuben [ybl].

name: Javindo
Language Use: Shifted to Javanese [jav].

name: Chinook jargon
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1912. Language revitalization began inthe 2000s, especially after the release of ‘Chinuk Wawa—As our elders teach us to speak it’. Itis reported that some members of the tribe are now fluent speakers.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Fali, North
Language Use: Rapidly shifting to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde[fub]. Used as L2 by Gidar [gid].

name: Nyangbo
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Éwé [ewe].

name: Kaamba
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Kituba [mkw]. 90% of adults speak Kituba.

name: Unami
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Lenape Language Project involved with revitalization.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bondei
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1887–1895.
Language Use: Also use Swahili [swh], with some shifting.

name: Chicomuceltec
Language Use: Extinct in recent Mayanist literature. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Wom (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Chinantec, Quiotepec
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 1983.

name: Gugu Badhun
Language Development: Texts. Revitalization attempts underway (Wurm 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Dura
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Nepali [npi].

name: Chipaya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. 400 children in school. Have a high school.Taught as subject in some primary schools. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1978–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Primary L2 is shifting from Central Aymara [ayr] to Spanish[spa]. Religious services. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Aymara [ayr]. Also use Spanish[spa].

name: Xiri
Language Use: A few isolated speakers (2000). Shifted to Khoekhoe [naq].

name: Ngandi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. The Ngukurr Community Education Centre has been running a Ngandi language program since 2006. The last fluent speaker, Cherry Wulumirr Daniels, and her grandnephew, Grant Mathumba Thompson have been working with the organization on revitalization of Ngandi and some other endangered regional languages. In 2017, the Ngukurr Language Centre was running 30 minute Ngandi lessons on a weekly basis in primary schools.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mundurukú
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1980.
Language Use: Sai Cinza village and others villages on the Cururu river mostly monolingual in Mundurukú (2020 F. Gerardi). Some young people, all adults. Many also use Portuguese [por], especially in those communities where children use it as their L1 (Mangue, Praia do Índio, Terra Indígena Coatá-Laranjal, Amazonas). Portuguese is also used by many in Jacareacanga (with high proficiency), by men (more than women) in Sai Cinza, by those at the Roman Catholic mission on the Cururu, and by men in villages along the Cururu (for trade). Many women know daily greetings. Used as L2 by Apiaká [api], Apinagé [apn].

name: Gronings
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1987.
Language Use: L1 of many rural people. Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Toma
Language Development: Was taught in school under the First Republic (before 1984). NT: 1981.
Language Use: Many also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk]. Many also use Manya [mzj]. Used as L2 by Manya [mzj], Zialo [zil].

name: Sangir
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2008–2009.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Manado Malay [xmm].

name: Beng
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Baoulé [bci]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Allar
Language Use: All domains. Adults only. Shifting to Malayalam [mal].

name: Erave
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Lamba
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1959.
Language Use: Home, community.

name: Ngarinyin
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Most children speak Kriol [rop] as L1. Adults only. No longer passed on to children (2011 ELDP). Shifting to English [eng]. Shifting to Kriol [rop].

name: Gerai
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Work, education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Indonesian [ind]. Most also use Kendayan [knx].

name: Nahali
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Merei
Language Development: Bible portions: 2011–2014.
Language Use: Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Bislama [bis], especially men and school children.

name: Slavey, North
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Deline still has strong language use including young people. Decreasing use in other communities. Over half actively use it in the home. Some young people, all adults. All also use English [eng].

name: Ukit
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 65%.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events, Technology and media. Used by all. Many also use Malay [zlm]. Some also use Iban [iba].

name: Malaccan Creole Portuguese
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1884.
Language Use: English [eng] is rapidly becoming the dominant language among the younger generation. Some young people, all adults. Mainly adults 50 and older, about one-third of young adults, some children (Bradley 2007a). Most also use Malay [zlm], especially local varieties. Some also use English [eng], especially older women.

name: Wyandot
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. There are audio and video resources available for learning Wyandot and also online course materials at a dedicated website, along with games and keyboards. A series of 40 Wyandot narratives have been published in four different versions, as well as shorter texts, such as children’s stories. Wyandot is taught in on-going online classes for adults, and a high school-level course has been developed (2021 M. Lukaniec).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mapoyo
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Bekwil
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lingala [lin] (Leitch 2005).

name: Kahe
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Zapotec, Loxicha
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2009–2015.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa], especially those in town centers.

name: Lewotobi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Arop-Sissano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible portions:1988–2018.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Wu Chinese
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans], used since 1981. Han script, Traditional variant [Hant]. Latin script [Latn], used since mid/late 19th century.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Fully developed. Bible: 1908–1914.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Leco
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Yil
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bakula 2022).

name: Navajo
Language Development: High literacy. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1985–2000. Immersion program in several schools; formally taught at several universities (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Vigorous in some families. L1 speakers among first graders are 30% versus 90% in 1968 (1998). Wide range of functions. Most also use English [eng].

name: Nyishi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 37%—46% (2001 census). Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Miji [sjl]. Used as L2 by Miji [sjl], Puroik [suv].

name: Kuna, San Blas
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Aizi, Tiagbamrin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Adioukrou [adj], especially by older adults. Also use French[fra], learned by youth in school.

name: Kinnauri
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longerin use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 37%: men 52%, women 22%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2017.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also useHindi [hin] (Negi 2012). Used as L2 by Chitkuli Kinnauri [cik].

name: Berik
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1993.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 byMander [mqr].

name: Ruga
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Garo [grt].

name: Totonac, Yecuatla
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Ubykh
Language Use: A century ago, there were 50,000 speakers in the Caucasus valleys east of the Black Sea. Shifted to Adyghe [ady].

name: Pontic
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], rarely used. Greek script [Grek], primary usage, used in Greece. Latin script [Latn], sporadic use on social media, used in Turkey.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Youth may speak standard Greek as L1. Speakers in North America reportedly maintain the use of Pontic more zealously than those in Greece.

name: Rahambuu
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Bugis [bug] (Wurm 2007). Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Mortlockese
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Chuukese [chk].

name: Erromintxela
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to French [fra].

name: Mala (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions: 1982–1988.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b).

name: Waigeo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home only. Adults only. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Shekkacho
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 39%. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Taught as a major at the university level. Dictionary. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Shabo [sbf].

name: Akuntsu
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Punan Batu 1
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Some young people, all adults.

name: Adioukrou
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT:1999.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Abidji [abi], Mobumrin Aizi [ahm],Tiagbamrin Aizi [ahi].

name: Rungwa
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Swahili [swh]. A few also use Pimbwe [piw].

name: Arrarnta, Western
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1997.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng].

name: Bidyogo
Language Development: Incipient L1 literacy thru the regular reading of L1 scripture in somechurches. Grammar. NT: 1975.
Language Use: On many islands people are more comfortable using Bijago rather thanCrioulo [pov] (2009 F. Sabio). Home, friends, religion, work. Also used in radio and texting.Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language ofinterethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Some also use Portuguese [por], as the languageof education and communication with foreigners.

name: Beba
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Manyalso use English [eng].

name: Aruá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Hiw
Language Development: Bible portions: 1894–1900.
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Used by entire ethnic group. Most key domains.Used by all, all children speak Hiw. Positive attitudes.

name: Mouwase
Language Use: Home, legal, traditional events, prayer, sporting events. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Most also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Bullock 2015). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi](Bullock 2015). Used as L2 by Minanibai [mcv].

name: Sinaugoro
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Motu [meu]. Used as L2 by Uare [ksj].

name: Yine
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–80%. Desire higher education. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1960–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Written form and many songs used in religious services. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Asháninka [cni], in Miaria, Bufeo Pozo, and Senza. Also use Matsigenka [mcb], in Senza and Miaria. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Klamath-Modoc
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Revitalization efforts include lessons in Head Start program, classes in local primary school, weekly community meetings (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Okolie
Language Use: All domains, some use in schools, churches, and government offices. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Dongotono [ddd]. Also use English [eng], mostly used in church and schools. Also use Juba Arabic [pga].

name: Chepya
Language Use: Shifting to Akha [ahk] (Bradley 2007b).

name: Lala
Language Development: Bible portions: 2015.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng] (Kassell and Potter 2009). Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially adults (Kassell and Potter 2009). Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth (Kassell and Potter 2009). A few also use Waima [rro] (Kassell and Potter 2009).

name: Kwoma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. No known use of vernacular literature. Dictionary. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people (Lambert-Brétière 2018). Also use Yalaku [ylg] (Aikhenvald 2018). Used as L2 by Yalaku [ylg].

name: Sakata
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Bible portions: 1932–1951.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Most also use Lingala [lin].

name: Tuamotuan
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2008–2011. Agency: Karuru Vanaga (Académie paꞌumotu).
Language Use: Many shifting to Tahitian [tah]. Some of all ages. Also use Tahitian [tah], but possibly with less proficiency on Napuka and Reao.

name: Yupik, Pacific Gulf
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], no longer in use. Cyrillic script, Old ChurchSlavonic variant [Cyrs], used in the 19th century, experimental usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1848.
Language Use: Immersion camp at Nuuciq every summer and efforts are underway to developimmersion schools (2014 N. Novik). Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Tadyawan
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 2005, limited usage.
Language Development: Bible portions: 2005.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Many also use Bangon [bnj].

name: Spanish Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2007–2021. Agency: National Confederation of Deaf People (CNSE).
Language Use: Deaf schools, plus many deaf children integrated in hearing schools, with widespread oralist emphasis. Many young adults arrive at deaf associations not knowing how to sign. Deaf who have travelled tend to understand the other sign languages in Spain but use their own. (2017 S. Parkhurst). Some young people, all adults. Some young people, more widespread among deaf adults. Some also use Spanish [spa].

name: Wichí Lhamtés Nocten
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: The 1994 Indigenous census shows an increase in language use among younger people compared to the elders (Crevels 2007). Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Umon
Language Development: Bible portions: 1895.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. All also use Efik [efi]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Igbo [ibo].

name: Kru'ng 2
Language Development: Bible portions: 2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Khmer [khm]. Also use Lao [lao]. Used as L2 by Kachok [xkk].

name: Naga, Khoibu
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Bubi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use French [fra]. Also use Tsogo[tsv].

name: Gambera
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Fungwa
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021k). Some also use English [eng], among young adults (Decker et al 2021k).

name: Nambya
Language Use: All also use Ndebele [nde] (Hachipola 1998). Also use Dombe [dov]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Shona [sna]. Also use Tonga [toi]. Used as L2 by Dombe [dov].

name: Sawi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% semiliterate. NT: 1973–1994.
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Atohwaim [aqm].

name: Danu
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Grangali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Nangalami may have no remaining speakers. Some of all ages. Also use Dari [prs].

name: Sawai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. 5,000 can read it, 1,000 can write it. Bible portions: 1994–2005.
Language Use: Some domains, local commerce. Some young people, all adults. Youth are taught Indonesian [ind] first; then learn to understand Sawai. Positive attitudes. Also use Buli [bzq]. Also use Gane [gzn]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Maba [mqa]. Also use North Moluccan Malay [max]. Also use Patani [ptn]. Also use Ternate [tft]. Also use Tidore [tvo]. Also use Tobelo [tlb].

name: Chinantec, Valle Nacional
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Tacana
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1981–2009.
Language Use: Adults only. Hardly spoken by children under 10 over a decade ago (Crevels 2007). Shifting to Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2007).

name: Sakirabiá
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Selee
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Texts. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Éwé [ewe], but diminishing contact with the language.

name: Quechua, Panao Huánuco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dzao Min
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Cambodian Sign Language
Language Development: Starting in about 2020, the five government schools started teachingCambodian Sign Language [csx] to new students, rather than Krousar Thmey Sign Language.
Language Use: Vigorous. Previously used in schools for adults operated by the MaryknollDeaf Development Programme. Formal education (the five government schools) previously usedKrousar Thmey Sign Language, but since about 2020 they have started to teach Cambodian SignLanguage (2020 J. Woodward, 2023 C. Wallace). There is a formal register (used for publicannouncements) that is somewhat different from what deaf people use among themselves in informalsettings. Used by all.

name: Mel-Khaonh
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most of the children do not learn thelanguage (2017 P. Lambrecht). Also use Khmer [khm], with many youth shifting.

name: Dolgan
Language Development: Several publications in Dolgan. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions:1996–2002.
Language Use: Low vitality. Family, friends. Some young people, all adults, with asubstantial number of child speakers (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Russian[rus]. Used as L2 by Nganasan [nio].

name: Otank
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Abanglekuo [bzy].

name: Tabla
Language Development: Bible portions: 1986–1991.
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Hupla
Language Development: Bible: 2014.

name: Amanayé
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Yalarnnga
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Holoholo
Language Development: Bible portions: 1948.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French[fra].

name: Tanimbili
Language Use: Shifted to Amba [utp]. Used as L2 by Asumboa [aua].

name: Piya-Kwonci
Language Development: Bible portions: 1950.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Kulung [bbu]. Also use Tangale [tan].

name: Lama (Togo)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1993–1995.
Language Use: Home, neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Kabiyè [kbp]. Also use Tem [kdh]. Used as L2 by Miyobe [soy], Nawdm [nmz].

name: Ngbaka
Language Development: Possibly 150,000 read Ngbaka; 100,000 can write it. Bible: 1995.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Lingala [lin]. A few also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Gilima [gix], Mbandja [zmz], Mono [mnh].

name: Mochi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Ngasa [nsg].

name: Serua
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Coahuilteco
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Gbaya-Mbodomo
Language Development: No literacy programs. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1980.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains except church and with outsiders. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Ewondo[ewo]. Also use Northwest Gbaya [gya], especially in the Lutheran Church. Used as L2 by Kako[kkj], Pol [pmm].

name: Menya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Mixed use: home, church. Some young people, all adults. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Whitehead 2004). Used as L2 by Kamasa [klp].

name: Umbindhamu
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Lianshan Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Use: Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Yue Chinese [yue].

name: Suyá
Language Development: Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Panará [kre].

name: Jinuo, Youle
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 83%. Videos. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Some alsouse Mandarin Chinese [cmn], which is used in education. Also use Lü [khb].

name: Torona
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Shifted to Tira [tic].

name: Kufr Qassem Sign Language (KQSL)
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: KQSL is used in informal and local settings - deaf club, in deaf homes, also used by some hearing people who have deaf relatives. A deaf community center was opened in Kafr Qasim in 1995, serving as a cornerstone for the deaf community to come together and share experiences, knowledge and enjoyment (2020 R. Stamp). Home and local contexts. Used by all. Recent studies have shown a shift among younger users toward bilingualism in Israeli Sign Language (ISL) [isr], with a more subtle shift among older monolingual users toward ISL (2020 R. Stamp). Also use Israeli Sign Language [isr], especially those born since 1980.

name: Koya
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Latin script [Latn], reportedly preferred by Koyaleaders. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya]. Telugu script [Telu].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 7%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997–2016.
Language Use: Some also use Telugu [tel], but proficiency is low. Also use English [eng].

name: Cavineña
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1985–2012.
Language Use: Cavineña highly conserved in the communities, except in Riberalta wherechildren are not learning it (Crevels 2007). Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish[spa], increasingly.

name: Zimba
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Most speak Binja dialect. Semulu dialect is spoken in the northeast, Semalinga in the west. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Yangum Mon
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Bragat [aof].

name: Sikiana
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por]. Also use Waiwai [waw] (Crevels 2007).

name: Crow
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1980–2007. Increasing efforts toward language preservation(Golla 2007).
Language Use: Most younger people are semispeakers (Golla 2007). Some young people, alladults. Most also use English [eng].

name: Lacandon
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Chol [ctu]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kewa, West
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1973–2004.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Franklin 2017). Used as L2 by Imbongu [imo].

name: Ruund
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2008–2009.

name: Ulithian
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Nungali
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Lao Naga
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Lainong Naga [lzn].

name: Kinnauri, Harijan
Language Development: Bible portions: 2017.

name: Halkomelem
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Language preservation activities in all dialects.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Kutenai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Kutenai is offered as L2 course (1991). Retention efforts underway in most locations (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Makonde
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Gadjerawang
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mixtec, Pinotepa Nacional
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1980.
Language Use: Used with other Mixtecs. Home, friends, work. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mullukmulluk
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Popoluca, Sayula
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1969.

name: Zan Gula
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–15%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Bété, Gagnoa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Djambarrpuyngu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Dayi [dax], Dhangu-Djangu [dhg], Dhuwal [dwu], Djinang [dji],Djinba [djb], Gupapuyngu [guf], Yan-nhangu [jay], Yolngu Sign Language [ygs].

name: Lithuanian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2018. Agency: Lithuanian Deaf Association (Lietuvos kurčiųjų draugija, LKD).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Lithuanian [lit].

name: Maung
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1960.
Language Use: Language still being acquired by children (2011). Most also use English [eng]. Also use Gunwinggu [gup]. Used as L2 by Kunbarlang [wlg].

name: Pawnee
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Pawnee Nation is developing teaching materials for the local high school and adult education (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Wiradhuri
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Revitalization attempts (Wurm 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Lehar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% in French [fra], 35% in Wolof [wol]. Culturalassociation works on language development. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Children learn Laalaa first. Youth being lost to cities causing decrease inL1 speakers. Shifting to Wolof [wol]. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many alsouse Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw2012). Some also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al2017). Used as L2 by Ndut [ndv].

name: Tamazight, Tidikelt
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Algerian Arabic [arq].

name: Mer
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Naga, Mao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: High. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2001.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni].

name: Helong
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Helong Darat shifting to Kupang Malay [mkn] (Florey 2005). Funai dialectendangered through intermarriage and urban contact. Home, community, traditional ceremonies.Some of all ages. Also use Bilba [bpz]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kupang Malay [mkn].Also use Uab Meto [aoz].

name: Sokoro
Language Development: 2002 literacy classes. Bible portions: 2001–2022.
Language Use: Most also use Chadian Arabic [shu], especially men (Boyd 1989).

name: Dogon, Bondum Dom
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jamsay Dogon [djm].

name: Besoa
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: 70% are speakers. Behoa is passed on to more than 60% of the children.Younger generation now prefers Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Home, Community; Mixed: Religion.Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Wala
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Indian Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 2%. Male literacy rate in L2 is higher thanfemale as boys are more likely to attend school. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: IndianSign Language Research and Training Centre at Indira Gandhi National Open University.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use American Sign Language [ase],especially in Bangalore (Panda 2012).

name: Onondaga
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Elderly only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Aghu
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Bodo (Central African Republic)
Language Use: Shifted to Sango [sag].

name: Ubaghara
Language Development: Bible portions: 1984–1991.

name: Berom
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1917, 3 orthographies unified in 1973.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Children and adults are less likely to speak it in the city. In the villageall ages speak it consistently. Shifting to Hausa [hau]. Used by all. Also use Hausa [hau]. Usedas L2 by Firan [fir], Ibaas [cen], Iguta [nar].

name: Jeri Kuo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Jula [dyu]. Also use French [fra].

name: Korupun-Sela
Language Use: Religious services. Also use Nipsan [nps].

name: Tenharim
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. NT: 1996.
Language Use: On the Igarapé Preto and the Sepoti rivers, the indigenous language has almost disappeared and now is being revived. On the Marmelos river, Tenharim is spoken within the group and Portuguese [por] with those outside (Peggion 2018). Some of all ages. All also use Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007). Used as L2 by Karipuna [kuq].

name: Sarudu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Mixtec, Southwestern Tlaxiaco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nyanga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%–30%.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Kamano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 1977–2014.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Benabena [bef]. Also use Tok Pisin[tpi]. Used as L2 by Wagama [abg].

name: Oneida
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1942.
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Bouni
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013–2014.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Miller 2017).

name: Kamula
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use English [eng]. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Doso [dol] (Suter and Usher 2017). Also use Gogodala [ggw]. Used as L2 by Dibiyaso [dby], Doso [dol], Eibela [ail], Kasua [khs], Odoodee [kkc].

name: Ndaka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–40%.
Language Use: Some also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Beeke [bkf].

name: Lengo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Maria (India)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Men 5%, women below 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. High interest in literacy. Grammar. Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: All domains. Some also use Halbi [hlb], especially men who may also use a Muria variety. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Arabic (Hadrami)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], limited usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Standard Arabic [arb]. Used as L2 by Bathari [bhm], Mehri [gdq].

name: Kaiku
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools.

name: Lisela
Language Use: Shifting to Ambonese Malay [abs]. Used as L2 by Kayeli [kzl].

name: Lomavren
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Armenian [hye].

name: Wagawaga
Language Development: 2 schools.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Suau [swp]. Many also use Tawala [tbo], especially speakers of Wagawaga Inland. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth. A few also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Malay, Ambonese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1877–2022.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Alune [alp], Amahai [amq], Aputai[apx], Benggoi [bgy], Buru [mhs], Central Masela [mxz], Dai [dij], Dawera-Daweloor [ddw], Dobel[kvo], East Masela [vme], Emplawas [emw], Fordata [frd], Galolen [gal], Haruku [hrk], Ili’uun[ilu], Imroing [imr], Kaibobo [kzb], Kamarian [kzx], Kayeli [kzl], Laha [lhh], Lisabata-Nuniali[lcs], Lisela [lcl], Lola [lcd], Loun [lox], Luang [lex], Luhu [lcq], Nila [nil], North Babar[bcd], Nusa Laut [nul], Paulohi [plh], Perai [wet], Saparua [spr], Seit-Kaitetu [hik], Serili[sve], Serua [srw], Southeast Babar [vbb], Tela-Masbuar [tvm], Te’un [tve], Tugun [tzn], Tulehu[tlu], Ujir [udj], Wemale [weo], West Masela [mss], West Tarangan [txn], Yalahatan [jal],Yamdena [jmd].

name: Carrier
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught assubject in primary and secondary schools. Taught as subject at the University of NorthernBritish Columbia, the College of New Caledonia, and the University of British Columbia.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1995–2019.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to English [eng].

name: Bom
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Mende [men].

name: Kaba Na
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used as L2 by Gula [glu], Kulfa [kxj].

name: Gera
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022c). Some also useEnglish [eng] (Decker et al 2022c). Some also use Standard Arabic [arb] (Decker et al 2022c).Used as L2 by Deno [dbb], Jimi [jmi], Shiki [gua].

name: Lule Sami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. NT: 1903–2003.
Language Use: Language use has recently been activated to some extent. Younger speakers may nevertheless prefer Swedish [swe] (Salminen 2007). Some young people, all adults. Used by few children. Also use Swedish [swe].

name: Reyesano
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Chin, Chinbon
Writing: Latin script [Latn], recently developed, has a small user community.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Djauan
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Some also use Dalabon [ngk] (Wurm2007). Some also use English [eng] (Wurm 2007).

name: Gwahatike
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 19%–55%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–85%. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kaxuiâna
Language Use: In the 1960s, the number of speakers of the language fell to less than 100,due to disease and contact with the non-indigenous population colonizing their region. In 1968,the Kaxuiâna were moved to the Parque do Tumucumaque IT in Pará, an area where Trió [tri] wasthe dominant language, and they began to be assimilated into Trió. So since the 1970s until2010, the Kaxuiâna children grew up speaking, reading and writing predominantly Trió with thelanguage on the verge of extinction (Grupioni 2018). However, since 2010 the Kaxuianas have madea comeback, creating 8 new villages of their own on the river system where they were originallyfrom. About half of the Kaxuiana children now grow up speaking Kaxuiana, while the other halfspeak Trió or Hixkaryana [hix] as their mother tongue. Some young people, all adults. Many alsouse Trió [tri], but only in some of the villages where the Kaxuiana live with the Tirio. Inother villages this shift is no longer occurring. Many also use Hixkaryána [hix]. Some Kaxuianachildren raised in Hixkaryana villages are L1 speakers of Hixkaryana. Some also use Apalaí[apy]. Some also use Portuguese [por], mostly men. Some also use Waiwai [waw].

name: Iku-Gora-Ankwa
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Dzùùngoo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in French [fra]. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bibleportions: 2002.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula[dyu].

name: Dadibi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2001–2002.
Language Use: Also use Folopa [ppo]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bobo Madaré, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% or below. Dictionary.
Language Use: Home. Also use French [fra], especially the educated. Also use Jula [dyu],especially most men with good proficiency and some women for common topics, government, andtrade.

name: Zigula
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some also use Swahili [swh], a nonstandard street variety.

name: Arutani
Language Use: Most have intermarried with the Ninam, some with the Pemon (Arecuna) and afew with the Sapi and do not speak Arutani fluently. Shifted to Ninam [shb].

name: Bolon
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Banda-Mbrès
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Miyobe
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Some of all ages. All also use Kabiyè [kbp]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Lama [las].

name: Cemuhî
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Teke-Tege
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra], mostly for official purposes; younger people sometimes mix French with Teke-Tege.

name: Nengone
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1903.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes.

name: Emerillon
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use French [fra], especially educated persons. Alsouse Guianese French Creole [gcr]. Also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Wayampi [oym].

name: Bunu, Wunai
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Syriac, Classical
Language Use: Was used in Turkey, Iraq, and Syria. Became extinct in the 10th to 12th centuries. Still used, but rarely, as a secular literary language among followers of the churches listed.

name: Mwaghavul
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1991–2007.
Language Use: Most also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Belning [glb], Cakfem-Mushere [cky], Rom [tdk], Ron [cla].

name: Kara (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Tigak [tgc].

name: Xamtanga
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used since 1996, revised in 2012.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 7%. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Most Xamir speak Xamtanga. Xamtanga speakers association in Weldiya. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use Tigrigna [tir].

name: Yukuben
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Jukun Takum [jbu]. Also use Kutep [kub].

name: Zapotec, Yatee
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sulka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Mengen [mee]. Some also use Tomoip [tqp].

name: Huichol
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Oral and written use in religious services, oral usein local commerce, administration, oral literature, songs. Letter writing. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use El Nayar Cora [crn]. Also use Spanish [spa], in schools and clinics.

name: Tauya
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (MacDonald 2013).

name: Gyalsumdo
