Language Use: Shifting to Nepali [npi].

name: Cuba Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Asociación Nacional de Sordos de Cuba (ANSOC), CentroNacional de Superación y Desarrollo del Sordo (CENDSOR).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Àhàn
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion, Special cultural events. Some young people, alladults. Most also use Yoruba [yor]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Batak Karo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1987–1995.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Community, Work, Religion. Some young people, all adults.All also use Indonesian [ind], some youth are shifting, especially in urban and migrant areas.

name: Andai
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi](Kassell et al 2017).

name: Mango
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–12%. Primer, literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. NT: 2019. Agency: Mango Language Committee.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Njen
Language Use: Home, community, work; Mixed: market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Ngamambo [nbv], specifically the Moghamo dialect (Flora and Brye 2006). Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Mundani [mnf], specifically Bamumbo dialect (Flora and Brye 2006).

name: Arabic (North Mesopotamian)
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bajelani [bjm], Macho [hac], Shabak [sdb], South Azerbaijani[azb].

name: Attapady Kurumba
LITERACY_L2: 32% in Attapady; or 23% (27% men, 15% women), including other Kurumba in Wayanad District (1991 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 32% in Attapady; or 23% (27% men, 15% women), including other Kurumba in Wayanad District (1991 census). NT: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Muduga [udg]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Irula [iru]. Also use Malayalam [mal]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Saaroa
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Bunun [bnn].

name: Kuruáya
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Hunde
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Grammar. NT: 1987.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Also use French [fra].

name: Warembori
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% in Indonesian [ind]. Dictionary.
Language Use: Home. Adults only. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Yoke [yki]. Used as L2 by Yoke [yki].

name: Paranan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Videos. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Home, community meetings, some churches. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Terik
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Nandi [niq]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Ukwuani-Aboh-Ndoni
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Awad Bing
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 61%. Literacy rate in L2: 61%. 700 can read and writeit. Grammar. Bible portions: 1992–2000.
Language Use: Vigorous. A few Ngaing [nnf] speak it for trade. All domains. Used by all.Positive attitudes. A few also use Gedaged [gdd], the church language. Also use English [eng].Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Matukar Panau [mjk], Yote [wab].

name: Mushungulu
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Maay [ymm]. Also use Somali [som].

name: Bwa
Language Development: Bible portions: 1938.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Boone and Olson 2004).

name: Bebeli
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin[tpi] (Bullock et al 2013). Some also use Bola [bnp], especially elderly (Bullock et al 2013).Some also use Nakanai [nak], especially elderly (Bullock et al 2013).

name: Hewa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 2%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. 25 or fewer canread it, 10 or fewer can write it. Bible portions: 1985–2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Use of Hewa is the norm (2014 SIL). All domains except church,where there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] (2014 SIL). Used by all. Some also use Duna [duc].Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ipili [ipi]. Also use Oksapmin[opm].

name: Haryanvi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 55% in Hindi [hin]. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].Also use Hindi [hin], with proficiency higher among the educated.

name: Biyo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Observed functional literacy in Chinese is low.Official literacy rate for the Hani Nationality is registered much higher. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Sylheti
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Latin script [Latn]. Syloti Nagri script [Sylo].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 35%. Educated can read Bengali [ben]. Few women are educated. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Bengali [ben], primarily men. Bengali used in education and media. Used as L2 by Meitei [mni], War-Jaintia [aml].

name: Ninggerum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Faiwol [fai]. Also use Telefol [tlf]. Also use Yongkom [yon].

name: Waiwai
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: Some also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Hixkaryána [hix], Kaxuiâna [kbb], Mapidian [mpw], Sikiana [sik].

name: Abui
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also practice a variety of Late Vernacular Acquisition with most childrennot speaking the vernacular until late adolescence or young adulthood (Saad 2020). Used as L2 byKamang [woi].

name: Eleme
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 60% in English [eng]. NT:2001.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. All also use English [eng]. Also use Gokana [gkn].

name: Hong Kong Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%–80% in written Chinese. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also useEnglish [eng]. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Tunebo, Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1987–2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Salar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Schooling in Mandarin Chinese [cmn] in Qinghai, and Uyghur [uig] in Xinjiang. Domestic, informal domains. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Many also use Amdo Tibetan [adx], especially men. Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially men using northwestern variety and mainly in Qinghai. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Uyghur [uig], mostly in Xinjiang.

name: Torau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Use has declined. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Naasioi [nas], Papapana [ppn].

name: Mafea
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Bislama [bis].

name: Monzombo
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Serer
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Most also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Used as L2 by Saafi-Saafi [sav].

name: Kadar
LITERACY_L2: 51% in Kerala, 56% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 51% in Kerala, 56% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).Grammar.
Language Use: Some language shift to Malayalam [mal] observed in Kerala. Home, village,religious services. Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam[mal]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Yaqay
Language Use: Home, religious services. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Pam
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Pali
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr]. Sinhala script [Sinh]. Thai script [Thai].
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1835.
Language Use: Classical and liturgical language of the Theravada Buddhist canon. Positive attitudes.

name: Taznatit
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Yugur, East
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85% (2000 census, Yugur nationality). Written Chinese is in use. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Yupik, Naukan
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Dzalakha
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Blagar
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Blagar still transmitted to next generation, but Indonesian[ind] has produced decreased speaking competence and increased use of Indonesian in youngerspeakers of Blagar (Steinhauer 2014). Most also use Indonesian [ind] (Steinhauer 2014).

name: Noipx
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Pijin [pis].

name: Kumbainggar
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Language revitalization efforts underway.
Language Use: Growing number of younger adult speakers who are now passing on thelanguage to their children. Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng].

name: Nzanyi
Language Development: Schools in almost all villages, but enrollment often low. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Gude [gde], Ngwaba [ngw].

name: Emplawas
Language Use: Elderly only. All shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs], or a variety of it, inalmost all domains. Some also use Indonesian [ind]. in government and Christian religiousdomains.

name: Muyang
LITERACY_L2: High in French [fra] among young educated men, and some in Fulfulde [fub].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in French [fra] among young educated men, and some in Fulfulde [fub]. Classes in some areas, mostly among women and children. Taught as subject in some primary schools. NT: 2013.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use French [fra], especially young educated men. Also use Wuzlam [udl].

name: Pokangá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por]. Also use Tucano [tuo]. Also use Waimaha [bao].

name: Yuki
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: No revitalization activities reported (Golla 2007). All shifted to English [eng].

name: Kesawai
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Use of Tok Pisin [tpi] increasing with children, adults continue to speak Koromu [xes] (Priestley 2020). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people (Priestley 2020).

name: Salas
Language Use: Shifted to Masiwang [bnf] (Wurm 2007).

name: Maklew
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home, friends. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind], with many youth shifting.

name: Ninam
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1970.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por], especially children. Used as L2 by Arutani [atx].

name: Sika
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Emberá-Tadó
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sonsorol
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Young Sonsorolese are reported to speak their native language with many English [eng] admixtures. Consequently, their speech is very different from the Sonsorolese of the elder generation, in which there are currently less than 20 speakers over 60 years old. Some of all ages. Most also use Palauan [pau]. Also use English [eng].

name: Yelmek
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind] (Evans et al 2018).

name: Ashtiani
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Mixtec (Western Juxtlahuaca)
Language Development: Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], but very little and withlittle comprehension.

name: Cuba, Tsucuba
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Imotong
Language Use: All domains, some use in schools, churches, and government offices. Used byall. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], mostly used in church and schools. Also useJuba Arabic [pga]. Also use Lango [lgo].

name: Dobu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 90%. Dictionary. Texts.Bible: 1928.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Used as L2 by Anuki[aui], ’Auhelawa [kud], Boselewa [bwf], Bunama [bdd], Bwaidoka [bwd], Bwanabwana [tte], Duau[dva], Galeya [gar], Gumawana [gvs], Iamalele [yml], Iduna [viv], Kaninuwa [wat], Kilivila[kij], Koluwawa [klx], Maiadomu [mzz], Minaveha [mvn], Molima [mox], Muyuw [myw], Mwatebu [mwa],Sewa Bay [sew], Tawala [tbo], West Goodenough [ddi].

name: Guragone
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Children are still learning it (2011). Some young people, all adults. Allalso use Burarra [bvr]. All also use Gunwinggu [gup]. Most also use English [eng].

name: Oko-Eni-Osayen
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Apache (Mescalero-Chiricahua)
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: A few Chiricahua semispeakers in Oklahoma (Golla 2007). Older adults only.Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Tujia, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 88% in Chinese (2000 census, Tujia nationality). Grammar.
Language Use: Regularly used but increasingly the young prefer to speak Chinese and are encouraged by their parents. In most areas children acquire a passive knowledge only. No longer used in southeastern Sichuan, northeastern Guizhou and southwestern Hubei provinces. No longer used or moribund in northwestern Hunan and severely endangered in the remaining areas (Bradley 2007a). All domains. Adults only. Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Written Chinese in use and used in schools. Also use Hmong Njua [hnj].

name: Giiwo
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022c). Many also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Decker et al 2022c). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022c).

name: Mailu
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1936–1979.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bauwaki [bwk], Binahari [bxz], Domu [dof], Magori [zgr], Morawa [mze].

name: Tanggu
Language Development: Bible portions: 1993–2011.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Lotterman and Mackenzie 2005).

name: Nkutu
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1937–1940.
Language Use: Also use Tetela [tll].

name: Dogon, Tebul Ure
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Jamsay Dogon [djm]. Used as L2 by Ana TingaDogon [dti], Yanda Dom Dogon [dym].

name: Daungwurrung
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Revitalization program since 2004. Agency:Daungwurrung Language Program.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Saniyo-Hiyewe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Conrad and Lewis 1988). Used as L2 by Yawiyo [ybx].

name: Alamblak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT:2003–2014.
Language Use: Mixed use: home, church. Some young people, all adults. A few also useEnglish [eng] (Coulter 2007). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Coulter 2007). Used as L2 by Sumariup[siv].

name: Makah
Language Development: Grammar. Since late 1970s Makah Cultural and Research Center has sponsored language education at Neah Bay (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Beaver
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1886–1989.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Wiyot
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Language revival program underway at Table Bluff (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kwaza
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Turoyo
Writing: Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Syriac script [Syrc].
Language Use: Mixed Turoyo, outside Tur ’Abdin, the language’s original location, is increasingly used mainly by youth throughout the Jacobite diaspora. All also use Turkish [tur], or local lingua francas.

name: Honi
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], no longer in use, used in ritualtexts and folk literature.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Observed functional literacy in Chinese is low.Official literacy rate for the Hani nationality is registered much higher. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Muria, Far Western
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Alsouse Chhattisgarhi [hne]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Totonac, Papantla
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1979.

name: Doutai
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Kalapuya
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yi, Azhe
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Atohwaim
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kayagar [kyt]. Also use Sawi [saw].About half are trilingual.

name: Osatu
Language Development: Literacy is in English.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].

name: Gagauz
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used between 1957–1991. Greek script [Grek], useduntil 1957. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006.
Language Use: 89% speak it as L1.

name: Kachama-Ganjule
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. All members of the Kachama community regard Kachama as theirfirst language (Brenzinger 1999). Also use Wolaytta [wal].

name: Limilngan
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Albarradas Sign Language
Language Use: LSAlb is used in many places in Santa Catarina Albarradas, wherever deaf and hearing people congregate, including the local evangelical church and a store run by a deaf family. Used by all. A few also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Santa Catarina Albarradas Zapotec [ztn].

name: Tiyaa
Language Development: Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau], which is used for most functions in the churches and for most teaching in the schools. Most also use English [eng], which is used in the churches and in education.

name: Dutch Sign Language
LITERACY_L2: Although word identification skills of deaf childrenwere comparable to hearing peers, overall reading comprehension averaged at the first gradelevel in a sample of approximately 500 deaf students ages 6–20 (Wauters 2005).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Although word identification skills of deaf childrenwere comparable to hearing peers, overall reading comprehension averaged at the first gradelevel in a sample of approximately 500 deaf students ages 6–20 (Wauters 2005). TV. Theater.Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Deaf Association of the Netherlands.
Language Use: Vigorous. Deaf schools. Deaf associations. Used by all. Also use Dutch[nld].

name: Botlikh
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Few domains. Some young people, all adults. Used by many children (Salminen2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava], a literary language, in school and for widergroup communication (Salminen 2007). Also use Russian [rus], in school and for wider groupcommunication (Salminen 2007).

name: Semnam
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Enets, Tundra
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Under 10% of ethnic group speaks Enets. Few domains. Older adults only.Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Russian [rus] (Salminen 2007). Also use Nganasan [nio].

name: Siamou
LITERACY_L2: A few in Jula [dyu], some in French [fra].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: A few in Jula [dyu], some in French [fra]. Grammar. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Lamogai
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kashaya
Language Development: Small-scale language education program started (Golla 2007). Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Touo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Marovo [mvo]. Also use Pijin [pis]. Also use Roviana [rug].

name: Kisi, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Gbe, Maxi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Tchumbuli [bqa].

name: Choni
Language Development: Tibetan vernaculars are not written, but education in written Tibetan isavailable where Choni speakers live. Teachers probably speak either Choni or Amdo [adx].
Language Use: Shifting to Amdo Tibetan [adx].

name: Tuparí
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Arikapú [ark].

name: Haji
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useIndonesian [ind], in education, religious, and civic domains.

name: Mulam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 94% (2000 census, Mulao nationality). Radio.
Language Use: Most domains, Daoist and Buddhist services. 87% speak Mulam at home; 57% speak it outside the home. 82% speak Mulam to their children. (2005 GXLOUS). Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], commonly in writing.

name: Umbuygamu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Muthuvan
LITERACY_L2: 24% (31% males, 17% females) (1991 census); 40% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 24% (31% males, 17% females) (1991 census); 40% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census). NT: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal], especially youth. Also use Tamil [tam], especially older people.

name: Nend
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible portions:2004.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. All also useTok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2015).

name: Batuley
Language Use: Adults only.

name: Dohoi
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1998.

name: Gorovu
Language Use: Moribund (2000 S. Wurm). Home. Elderly only. Shifted to Waran [byz] (Wurm2007).

name: Achumawi
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Torres Strait Creole
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kala Lagaw Ya [mwp], Koko-Bera [kkp], Kunjen [kjn], Kuuku-Ya’u [kuy], Meriam Mir [ulk], Umpila [ump].

name: Kplang
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka].

name: Ho-Chunk
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1907. Agency: Ho-Chunk Culture Committee.
Language Use: Language maintenance efforts underway since 1990 (Golla 2007). Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Yahang
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2004).

name: Cumanagoto
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: So (Cameroon)
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2010.
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra], in schools and government offices; it is increasingly learned by children. Also use Bulu [bum].

name: Amdang
Language Development: Attitudes towards education and literacy in French and Arabic positive.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes. Most also use Chadian Arabic [shu] (Sommer1992).

name: Purisimeño
Language Development: Chumash Living Language Revitalization Project established in 1999. Although only Ineseño [inz] descendants are organized as a recognized tribe, there is interest among all Chumash descendants in restoring their traditional culture and language (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Dhundari
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market, religion. Positive attitudes. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], but the educated are more fluent.

name: Imroing
Language Use: Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Many shifting to AmboneseMalay [abs], in all domains, except for ceremonies. Children are taught this variety. Some alsouse Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.

name: Nyali
Language Use: A few also use Bangala [bxg]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Grebo, Gboloo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Ibani
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1870–1985.

name: Thai, Northeastern
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2016.
Language Use: 88% use Isan dialect in the home, 1% use Central Thai, 11% use both. Used by all. Also use Thai [tha]. Used as L2 by Kuay [kdt], Northern Khmer [kxm], Nyahkur [cbn], Nyaw [nyw], Nyeu [nyl], Phu Thai [pht], Yoy [yoy].

name: Lakurumau
Language Use: Used informally for family groupings, for social occasions, and occasionally for customary events when outsiders are not present (2020 C. Volker). Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with the younger generation shifting.

name: Gogodala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Texts. NT:1981.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. They expect all who live in their area tolearn their language. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Dundon 2007). Used as L2 by Ari [aac], Dibiyaso[dby], Doso [dol], Kamula [xla], Kasua [khs], Mubami [tsx], Tabo [knv], Waruna [wrv].

name: Bamenyam
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many alsouse English [eng]. Also use French [fra].

name: Aheri Gondi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1962.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Jebero
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1959.
Language Use: Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Salish, Straits
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 100%. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ojibwa, Severn
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used in some books and in educational settings. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Concerted effort via language teaching in public schools and other efforts to reverse decline. Grammar. Bible portions: 1974–1986.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Batyala
Language Development: Dictionary. The Butchulla Language Program has been vibrant thanks to young people in the community using story telling, oral histories, games, song, and dance to teach and revive their language; the Butchulla Language Program has also produced bilingual teaching books.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kaili, Da'a
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 45%. Texts. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most children know little Indonesian [ind] when entering school. All domains. Oral use in local administration, commerce, school. Some oral and written use in church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], especially in church.

name: Ezaa
Language Development: Bible: 2014.

name: Au
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Tracer 2003).

name: Maru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Jingpho [kac].

name: Abidji
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Adioukrou [adj]. Also use Baoulé [bci]. Also useFrench [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Wayampi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2003–2013.
Language Use: All still speak their native language but knowledge of Portuguese [por] is growing (Crevels 2007). Many also use Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007). Also use Apalaí [apy]. Used as L2 by Apalaí [apy].

name: Mayogo
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg], especially the older generation. Also use Lingala [lin], especially youth, increasingly. Used as L2 by Ngbee [jgb].

name: Yaur
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Arapesh, Bumbita
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Weril and Weriruse different materials for beginning literacy. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Young people mainly use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, alladults. Mostly middle-aged and older, youth in 2 villages (Wurm 2007). All also use Tok Pisin[tpi] (Dobrin 2014).

name: Gundi
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Many also use Sango [sag].

name: Ibu
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to North Moluccan Malay [max].

name: Ambrak
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Inupiatun, North Alaskan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1969–2012.
Language Use: Immersion schools. Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Hlepho Phowa
Language Use: Dialects spoken in Wenshan County are most endangered. Home, village, market. Some young people, all adults.

name: Yei
Language Use: Home. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Some also use Marind [mrz].

name: Bernde
Language Use: The Bolong now use Kenga [kyq] as their mother tongue. Tar Bolong ismoribund with less than 10 speakers in 2002.

name: Awyu (Edera)
Language Use: All domains.

name: Bannoni
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Dawera-Daweloor
Language Use: Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Many shifting to AmboneseMalay [abs], in all domains, except for ceremonies; children are taught Ambonese Malay. Somealso use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religious domains.

name: Tauade
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–30%. No known use of vernacular literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Fuyug [fuy].

name: Ndolo
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Popoluca, Texistepec
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Chinese Sign Language
Language Development: In 2006, school-age deaf children enrollment rate was approximately 82%(China Disabled Persons’ Federation). TV. Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Classmates and factory coworkers are channels of dissemination. Nowspecialized deaf colleges use CSL. Official CSL is primarily used in formal situations:Education, Media. Unofficial varieties: Home, Community. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese[cmn]. Used as L2 by Tibetan Sign Language [lsn].

name: Mixtec, Yucuañe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Possibly 40% in Spanish [spa].
Language Use: Home. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Umatilla
Language Development: Language classes at Umatilla (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tembo (Kitembo)
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra], mostly in education.

name: Mala Malasar
LITERACY_L2: 17% in Kerala, 15% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 17% in Kerala, 15% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Alsouse English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal].

name: Afro-Seminole Creole
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Maricopa
Language Use: Language program at Lehi on the Salt River Reservation (Golla 2007). Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Kansa
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. The Kaw Nation started offering online language learning for Kansa second language speakers in 2012.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Somyev
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Nigeria Mambila [mzk].

name: Tajio
Language Development: Bible portions: 2020.
Language Use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Taje [pee], Tomini [txm].

name: Kajali
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Yalunka
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2009.

name: Uab Meto
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2000.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Helong [heg].

name: Djeebbana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%–65%. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religious settings, Special cultural events. Some youngpeople, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng]. Many also use Gunwinggu[gup], or another Burarran language. Used as L2 by Kunbarlang [wlg], Na-kara [nck].

name: Garasia, Rajput
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Gujarati [guj]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Tillamook
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bareli, Pauri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 10%. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except education. Positive attitudes. Also useAhirani [ahr]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar]. Also useNimadi [noe].

name: Nyamwanga
Language Development: Texts. Bible: 1982.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Quechua, Chincha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Adults only. Many shifting to Spanish [spa]. Some shifting to Jaqaru [jqr].

name: Kanjobal, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2016. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Taiap
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Positive attitudes. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi](Kulick and Terrill 2019).

name: Matlatzinca, Atzingo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Fernando Po Creole English
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Virtually none. Literacy rate in L2: 75% in Spanish[spa]. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: All domains except government. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All alsouse Spanish [spa]. Some also use English [eng], which is growing in importance for jobopportunities. Also use Bube [bvb]. Used as L2 by Bube [bvb], Fa d’Ambu [fab], Fang [fan], Kombe[nui], Kwasio [nmg].

name: Bikya
Language Use: Shifted to Jukun Takum [jbu].

name: Baikeno
Language Development: Bible portions: 2004.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind], but for manyonly with difficulty. Also use Portuguese [por], but less than 1% can perform job-relatedfunctions in it. Also use Tetun Dili [tdt], but only those who have acquired it for study orwork.

name: Macanese
Language Use: A small number of older adult women in Macau use as L1 (1996). Elderly only. Shifted to Yue Chinese [yue].

name: Ngad'a
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Nisga'a
Language Development: Schools try to teach oral and written Nisga’a. Taught as subject in primary schools since 1976 (Golla 2007). Taught as subject at local community college and University of Northern British Columbia (Golla 2007). Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1890–1897.
Language Use: Taught in public school since 1976 and at local community college and the University of Northern British Columbia (Golla 2007). Adults only. Shifting to English [eng]. Some also use Tsimshian [tsi], especially older people. Used as L2 by Gitxsan [git].

name: Vute
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vute de Banyo is still used daily, but seems heavily influenced by Fulfulde [fub]. Used by all. Many also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Wawa [www].

name: Usarufa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 1980.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bird 2010).

name: Giziga, North
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also useAdamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Watam
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Mixed use: education, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Paris 2015). Used as L2 by Kopar [xop].

name: Kaibobo
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Alawa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Kupia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% (1991 census). Texts. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also useTelugu [tel], particularly in the market and for work and travel.

name: Dieri
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1897. The Dieri Aboriginal Corporationstarted preparing Dieri language material for schools in 2009. The Mobile Language Team (MLT)worked with the Dieri Aboriginal Corporation to complete a Dieri language learner’s guide in2017.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mota
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1912.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Formerly lingua franca. Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Tanna, Southwest
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Home. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Kwamera [tnk].

name: Olrat
Language Use: Active use probably ceased around 1950s. Shifted to Lakon [lkn].

name: Pular
Writing: Adlam script [Adlm], used since 1989. Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab].Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk]. Also use Susu [sus]. Used as L2 byKakabe [kke].

name: Khunsari
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Isekiri
Language Development: Bible: 2010.

name: Extremaduran
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90%. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Agatu
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events.Used by all. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Ajiri [afo].

name: Mambila, Nigeria
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Njerep [njr], Somyev [kgt].

name: Bozo, Tiéyaxo
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], in development. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Grammar. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Some ethnic Marka and Somono live among them and speak Tieyaxo as L1. Usedby all. Also use Bamanankan [bam]. Also use Maasina Fulfulde [ffm]. Use of Bambara or Fulfuldedepends on region.

name: Quapaw
Language Development: Dictionary. A Quapaw Tribal Youth Language and Cultural Preservation Camp teaches the language to children, and the Quapaw Tribal Museum offers classes for adults (2015 Joplin Globe).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yilan Creole
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn], including all those born after 1980 (Sanada and Chien 2012).

name: Monom
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Altai (Northern)
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Home, community, media. Some young people, all adults. Little transmissionof language to children (Salminen 2007). Also use Russian [rus].

name: Ahom
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Not spoken in daily life; used in religious chants and literary materials.Attempts to revive the spoken language are underway, with assistance of scholars from the Aiton[aio] and Phake [phk] communities (2007).

name: Kilmeri
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1980.
Language Use: Adults only. Negative attitudes. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi](Gerstner-Link 2018).

name: Watakataui
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Ndumu
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra].

name: Bongili
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Leitch 2005).

name: Amo
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Akaselem
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tem [kdh] (Sama2018). Also use Anii [blo] (Sama 2018). Also use French [fra]. Also use Ntcham [bud]. Used as L2by Anii [blo].

name: Jah Hut
Language Development: Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Kalabari
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2018.

name: Nambo
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1974.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. A few also use Motu [meu], especially elderly. Also use Nen [nqn] (Kashima 2020). Used as L2 by Nen [nqn].

name: Njebi
Language Development: Older church members can read Njebi, and a few do. Dictionary. NT: 1968–1978.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Duma [dma].

name: Logol
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Yugambal
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Kwato
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Kassell et al 2009).

name: Toraja-Sa'dan
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1960–1995.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Panasuan [psn].

name: Tyap
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Less use in towns and cities. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also useHausa [hau].

name: Noiri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1% in Marathi [mar]. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village. Positive attitudes. Positive attitudes to the west. Less positive to the east. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Efate, North
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Texts. Bible: 1972.
Language Use: Livara dialect is extinct. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Emae [mmw], Eton [etn], Lelepa [lpa].

name: Pemon
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1990.
Language Use: Some adults are still monolingual but younger generation is becomingbilingual in Spanish [spa] or English [eng] (Crevels 2007). Some young people, all adults. Alsouse English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Ninam [shb], Sapé [spc].

name: Nhanda
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. The Irra Wangga Language Centre has been working with the Nhanda people to create resources for the Nhanda people to learn and reawaken their language.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Terei
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary.Texts. Bible portions: 1973–2007.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Evans and Palmer 2011). Used as L2by Naasioi [nas], Papapana [ppn].

name: Chaldean Neo-Aramaic
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Northern Kurdish [kmr].

name: Votic
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], developed in 1920. Latin script [Latn], used since 2004, primary usage.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Wiaki
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Cen
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Berom [bom]. Also use Izere [izr]. Used as L2 byIzere [izr].

name: Male (Ethiopia)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Non-formal literacy classes. Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Chin, Asho
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], primary usage.
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Makolkol
Language Use: Shifted to Meramera [mxm]. Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bongu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Sam [snx].

name: Naskapi
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], used by Western Naskapi.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Western Naskapi: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Ongoing community language program in Western Naskapi. All children in kindergarten through grade 6 can read and write in the language (2017 N. Jancewicz). Taught as subject in primary schools (Golla 2007). Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous in both dialects. Slowly shifting to English [eng]. Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use French [fra]. Also use Innu [moe].

name: Eman
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also useIpulo [ass]. Used as L2 by Ipulo [ass].

name: Ndemli
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Tunen [tvu].

name: Tai Hongjin
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Romanian Sign Language
Language Development: Romanian literacy for access to mainstream society and employment is valued. (Eberle et al 2015). TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Associatia Nationala a Surzilor din Romania (ANSR).
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Many also use Romanian [ron], with widely varying degrees of bilingualism (spoken and written). Some also use Hungarian Sign Language [hsh]. Used as L2 by Hungarian Sign Language [hsh].

name: Barama
Language Use: Many also use French [fra].

name: Bima
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2001.

name: Chaima
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Urum
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Greek script [Grek], limited usage.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only, few child speakers (Salminen 2007). Shifting to Ukrainian [ukr].

name: Brazilian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Federação Nacional De Educação eIntegração Dos Surdos (FENEIS).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Portuguese [por].

name: Yareba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. NT: 1973–1987.
Language Use: Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Used as L2 by Aneme Wake [aby], Bariji [bjc], Nawaru [nwr].

name: Nez Perce
Language Development: A class in Nez Perce is taught on Umatilla Reservation. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1845–1876. Conversational Nez Perce taught in Nespelem, Washington. There is a formal program of Nez Perce language instruction at Lewis-Clark State College in Lewiston, Idaho as well as an independent program run by the tribe itself on the Idaho reservation, in Lapwai, Kamiah, and Orofino, Idaho.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Lohar, Gade
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% (1981 census). Grammar.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Tunebo, Barro Negro
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Cahuilla
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tondi Songway Kiini
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Bankan Tey Dogon [dbw].

name: Gungabula
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Kwaja
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English[eng], as language of public education.

name: Sajalong
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 39%, males 48%, females 29% (2001 census). NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Educated speak it more fluently, but all speakers know some. Also use Hruso [hru]. Also use Nyishi [njz]. Used as L2 by Hruso [hru], Nyishi [njz].

name: Mbule
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: The younger genearations are learning and using the language as long as they stay in the village (2014 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to positive. Most also use Basaa [bas]. Most also use French [fra]. Most also use Yangben [yav].

name: Bella Coola
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Nuxalk College has occasional language classes.There are immersion camps and other revitalization programs (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Meyah
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kulung (Nigeria)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1926–1950.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau] (Blench2019). Used as L2 by Dadiya [dbd], Piya-Kwonci [piy].

name: Ndun
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau].

name: Dime
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Aari [aiw].

name: Humla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%–15% Tibetan [bod]. Some schools using English[eng] medium, some Tibetan [bod] instruction. Texts.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few alsouse Central Tibetan [bod]. A few also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi], mostly for trade.

name: Hijuk
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra]. Also use Basaa[bas]. Also use Yangben [yav].

name: Vlaamse Gebarentaal
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Federation of Flemish Deaf Organisations (Fevlado).
Language Use: Vigorous. 7 schools for the deaf in Flanders but only a few use VGT for instruction. As of 2008, deaf children increasingly attend mainstream schools, with occasional interpreting into VGT. Used by all. Many also use Dutch [nld], in classrooms for writing (Van Herreweghe and Vermeerbergen 2003).

name: Jiamao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 88% (2000 census, Li nationality). Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Guriaso
Language Use: Declining in some villages. Some of all ages. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].Used as L2 by Ak [akq].

name: Zapotec, Totomachapan
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Kalami
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Apparently few remaining speakers of Dashwa dialect. Some of all ages. Mostalso use Northern Pashto [pbu], with some youth shifting. Many also use Urdu [urd], butuneducated people have low proficiency. Used as L2 by Kalkoti [xka], Khowar [khw].

name: Tjurruru
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Laeko-Libuat
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kwese
LITERACY_L2: All read and write in Kituba [ktu].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: All read and write in Kituba [ktu]. Grammar. Bible portions: 1929.
Language Use: Work; Mixed: Home, Community. Used by all. Most also use Kituba [ktu]. Many also use Lingala [lin], especially among the young people. Used as L2 by Mbala [mdp].

name: Suau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Dictionary. NT: 1956–1998.
Language Use: All also use English [eng] (Demian 2000). Also use Buhutu [bxh], especially Sinaki dialect speakers. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults (Demian 2000). Used as L2 by Bauwaki [bwk], Binahari [bxz], Buhutu [bxh], Bwanabwana [tte], Domu [dof], Haigwai [hgw], Magori [zgr], Maiwala [mum], Morawa [mze], Oya’oya [oyy], Saliba [sbe], Tawala [tbo], Wagawaga [wgb], Yaleba [ylb].

name: Uni
Language Development: Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bauni [bpe] (Miller 2017). Also use English [eng] (Corris 2005). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Corris 2005). Used as L2 by Bauni [bpe].

name: Twana
Language Development: Dictionary. The position for manager of the Twana Language Revitalization Project became available in 2017.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Paku Karen
Language Development: The Paku Karen use S’gaw Karen [ksw] literature and consider it to be theirown. S’gaw Karen literacy classes in some Christian communities through the churches.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use S’gawKaren [ksw]. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Zapotec, San Agustín Mixtepec
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Gundungurra
Language Development: The Gundungurra Language Awakening Group has been active since 2003.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kaiwá
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Portuguese [por].Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Home, community, religious settings, special cultural events. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Most also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug]. Most also use Portuguese [por]. Usedas L2 by Ofayé [opy].

name: Kayan, Busang
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Nindi
Language Use: Shifting to Swahili [swh].

name: Kaike
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion, work; mixed use: Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], especially for trade and commerce with the Dolpo. Also use Dolpo [dre]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Angkamuthi
Language Development: Revitalization program has begun in 2015 by the Pama Language Centre for agroup of closely related languages including Angkamuthi, Atambaya [amz], Uradhi [urf], andYadhaykanu (a dialect of Uradhi).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Maisin
Language Development: Literacy varies from 20%–80%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2004–2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng] (Frampton 2014). Some also use Baruga [bjz], especially Kosirava dialect speakers (Frampton 2014). Some also use Korafe-Yegha [kpr] (Frampton 2014). Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young men (Frampton 2014). Some also use Ubir [ubr] (Frampton 2014).

name: Ojibwa, Northwestern
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Concerted effort via language teaching in public schools and other efforts to reverse decline. Taught as subject in primary schools. NT: 1988.
Language Use: All shifting to English [eng].

name: Gros Ventre
Language Development: White Clay Immersion School on the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation had 26students studying the language in 2012.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mofu, North
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Used as L2 by Mafa [maf], Merey [meq].

name: Rotuman
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1999.

name: Narak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Transfer primer from Tok Pisin. 10% can write Narak. Dictionary. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng] (Hainsworth et al 2019). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Hainsworth et al 2019).

name: Berbice Creole Dutch
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Popoluca, Oluta
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Kurnai
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Serili
Language Use: Under pressure from Masela and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Otomi, Ixtenco
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Mander
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Home. Elderly only. Shifted to Berik [bkl].

name: Asháninka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 68% (including Ashéninkalanguages). Dictionary. NT: 1972–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Caquinte [cot],Nomatsigenga [not], Yine [pib].

name: Mandan
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. The language is taught at Fort Berthold Community College (2016).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Agta, Alabat Island
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Used by a few children. Neutral attitudes. Shiftedto Manide [abd]. Shifted to Tagalog [tgl].

name: Coptic
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Coptic script [Copt], used in Churchliterature. Greek script [Grek].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1716–1924.
Language Use: Bohairic dialect is liturgical language of the Coptic Church. Ceased dailyuse in the 16th century.

name: Indri
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Also use Feroge [fer].

name: Inuit Sign Language
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to American Sign Language [ase] (Schuit 2012).Some also use English [eng] (Schuit 2012). Some also use Inuinnaqtun [ikt] (Schuit et al 2011).

name: Kwaya
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2023.
Language Use: People moving to the area learn Kwaya. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Sorkhei
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 86%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Naga, Maring
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 53% (2001 census). Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Moni
Language Use: Used as L2 by Nduga [ndx], Wano [wno].

name: Eipomek
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2014–2018.

name: Judeo-Persian
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1909.
Language Use: Shifting to Hebrew [heb].

name: Ganza
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Komo [xom]. Used asL2 by Uduk [udu].

name: Wanda
Language Development: Swahili [swh] is the national language, so educated people are able to read and write it.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. All also use Swahili [swh]. Some also use Nyamwanga [mwn].

name: Dii
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Many also useFrench [fra]. Some also use Mbum [mdd].

name: Damakawa
Language Use: Still used in traditional rituals (2008 S. McGill). Ceremonies. Shifted toC’Lela [dri].

name: Soqotri
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Bible portions: 1902.
Language Use: The language is used socially especially among women but also in the market if both people involved are L1 speakers (2020 S. Warwick). Some of all ages. The language is used in each generational group, but the language is losing users, and L1 speakers are less proficient in their language than they used to be (2020 S. Warwick).

name: Borei
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Simbari
Language Development: Bible portions: 2006–2010.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Andoque
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1976.
Language Use: Elderly only. Most shifted to Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Nonuya [noj].

name: Hiri Motu
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1994.
Language Use: Most of the remaining L1 speakers are adults. Used as L2 by Abadi [kbt],Aeka [aez], Aneme Wake [aby], Aramba [stk], Are [mwc], Bamu [bcf], Bariji [bjc], Barikewa [jbk],Baruga [bjz], Bauwaki [bwk], Binahari [bxz], Boselewa [bwf], Buhutu [bxh], Dawawa [dww],Dibiyaso [dby], Dima [jma], Dobu [dob], Domu [dof], Doromu-Koki [kqc], Ese [mcq], Fuyug [fuy],Ginuman [gnm], Gweda [grw], Haigwai [hgw], Humene [huf], Ikobi [meb], Ipiko [ipo], Kakabai[kqf], Kaki Ae [tbd], Kanasi [soq], Kaninuwa [wat], Kasua [khs], Keoru-Ahia [xeu], Kerewo [kxz],Kibiri [prm], Kilivila [kij], Koiari [kbk], Koita [kqi], Korafe-Yegha [kpr], Kuni [kse], Lala[nrz], Magori [zgr], Maiadomu [mzz], Maiwa [mti], Maiwala [mum], Mapena [mnm], Maria [mds],Miniafia Oyan [aai], Moikodi [mkp], Morawa [mze], Mountain Koiali [kpx], Mouwase [jmw], Mubami[tsx], Nawaru [nwr], Nen [nqn], Ninggerum [nxr], Northeast Kiwai [kiw], Ömie [aom], Orokaiva[okv], Rema [bow], Rumu [klq], Samo [smq], Sinaugoro [snc], Suau [swp], Suki [sui], Tairuma[uar], Tawala [tbo], Turaka [trh], Wa’ema [wag], Wagawaga [wgb], Waima [rro], Wipi [gdr], Yaleba[ylb], Yareba [yrb], Yongkom [yon], Zia [zia].

name: Moraid
Language Use: Religious services.

name: Kakabe
Language Development: Some are literate in Pular (Arabic script) or French [fra]. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: The language is being abandoned by the younger generation in most of the area, with the exception of the Kankalabe subprefecture. Also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk]. Also use Pular [fuf].

name: Avestan
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Avestan script [Avst], used until 7thcentury. Gujarati script [Gujr].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: The sacred language of Zoroastrian scriptures.

name: Zapotec, Zaachila
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Rudbari
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Kapingamarangi
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. 75% are bilingual; bilingualism increasing. Home, community, church. Used by all.

name: Uru
Language Use: Shifted to Central Aymara [ayr] (Crevels 2007).

name: Chilean Sign Language
Language Development: First residential school for the deaf opened in 1852 in Santiago. Oralisteducation predominated from 1889 to the 1980s, when schools began incorporating signing, chieflyTotal Communication, but sometimes a bilingual-bicultural approach. Three deaf schools inSantiago, but most deaf students attend mainstream schools. Almost 60% of Chilean deaf have noeducation beyond primary school; only 3% have graduated from high school (González et al 2019).37 deaf teachers of Chilean sign language (2006 V. Castillo Martínez). Approximately 15 signlanguage interpreters (2008 WFD). TV. Dictionary. Texts. Agency: Asociación de Sordos de Chile(ASOCH).
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Favor use by both deaf andhearing people. Also use Spanish [spa], with varying degrees of bilingualism in speech andwriting. Literacy for access to mainstream society and employment is valued.

name: Bakairí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Most also use Portuguese [por].

name: Sarasira
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 52%.
Language Use: Apparent declining use, possible late language acquisition. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use Adzera [adz], especially older generations. Some also use Sukurum [zsu].

name: Purepecha, Western Highland
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1968–2012.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Menka
Language Use: Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Used as L2 by Ambele [ael].

name: Kuy
Writing: Khmer script [Khmr], used in Cambodia. Lao script [Laoo], used in Laos.Thai script [Thai].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1978–2020.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Have affection for Kuayand want to keep it. All also use Lao [lao]. All also use Northeastern Thai [tts]. Most also useThai [tha]. Some also use Northern Khmer [kxm], especially older adults.

name: Lafofa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Some, in Arabic [arb].
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kashubian
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: No remaining speakers of Slovincian. Some young people, all adults. Manychild speakers (Salminen 2007).

name: Sengseng
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Just over half the children learning the language (Wurm 2007). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Chowning 1983). Used as L2 by Ambul [apo].

name: Mamvu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1931.
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg].

name: Bicolano, Northern Catanduanes
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Bolo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% in Portuguese [por]. Radio.
Language Use: Home, church, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Kimbundu[kmb]. Also use Portuguese [por].

name: Ujir
Language Use: Use declining in Ujir because Malay [abs] used increasingly by outsiders. Use reportedly less in Samang than in Ujir. Shifting to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Tzotzil, Venustiano Carranza
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1997–2001.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tajuasohn
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Imonda
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Seiler 1985).

name: Hmong Njua
Writing: Lao script [Laoo]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Pahawh Hmong script[Hmng]. Thai script [Thai], used in Thailand.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Nepalese Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Periodicals. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: National Deaf Federation Nepal (NDFN, also known as The Nepali Federation of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, NFDH).
Language Use: Has been used on the floor of the national legislature by a deaf member. All domains. Used by all. Some also use Nepali [npi], passively by those who have become literate, especially in urban areas. Used as L2 by Ghandruk Sign Language [gds].

name: Achagua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–25%. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible portions: 1986–2013.
Language Use: Still very viable. Home. Some young people, all adults. Also use Piapoco[pio]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Otomi, Tilapa
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Urhobo
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1977.

name: Japanese Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1993–2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Over 95% of the deaf understand Japanese Sign Language. 107 deafschools. The first school opened in Kyoto in 1878. Used by all. Also use Japanese [jpn].

name: Yetfa
Language Development: Bible portions: 2023.
Language Use: Home, market, religious services. Used as L2 by Murkim [rmh], Towei [ttn].

name: Cun
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also useMandarin Chinese [cmn]. A few also use Hlai [lic].

name: Southern Bontok
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Safeyoka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT:1989.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Yabem [jae].

name: Lavi
Language Use: Seriously endangered (Sidwell 2003). Older adults only. Shifted to Lao [lao]. Many also use Alak [alk] (Asian Minorities Outreach 1999b). Many also use Talieng [tdf] (Asian Minorities Outreach 1999b).

name: Bafaw-Balong
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. English is the language of education andgovernment for the Bafaw-Balong who live in the South West Region. Many also use French [fra].Some also use Duala [dua]. Used as L2 by Oroko [bdu].

name: Tonsea
Language Development: Bible portions: 2005–2006.
Language Use: Under pressure from Manado Malay [xmm]. Some young people, all adults. Also use Manado Malay [xmm].

name: Ngiti
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Maninka, Konyanka
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Kono [knu]. Many also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk], especially in larger market towns because of travel.

name: Batak
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1972.
Language Use: Heavy influence from Palawano and Tagbanwa (Wurm 2007). Few domains.Positive attitudes. Shifting to Tagalog [tgl].

name: Tagargrent
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Some parents choose to speak Algerian Arabic [arq] with their children to give them a good start in their education. However, other children speak Tagargrent in the streets with their families. Positive attitudes. Also use Algerian Arabic [arq].

name: Tchitchege
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra].

name: Nyeu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Northeastern Thai [tts] (Suwannaraj 1980). Also use Thai [tha] (Suwannaraj 1980).

name: Epie
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Izon [ijc], especially Atisa dialect speakers.

name: Ma'anyan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Also use Bakumpai [bkr]. Used as L2 by Paku [pku].

name: Pinai-Hagahai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Very few read fluently. Little access to schools. Bible portions: 2002–2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Enga [enq]. A few also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Haruai [tmd].

name: Popoloca, San Felipe Otlaltepec
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible portions: 1955–1996.
Language Use: Local administration, commerce, religious services. Adults only. Mixed attitudes. Older people want to use Popoloca, but it has low prestige among younger people. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Lower Southern Aranda
Language Development: Arrente in Schools (AIS) program: primary and secondary schools in AliceSprings (2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Duna
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1976.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (San Roque 2015). Some also useEnglish [eng] (San Roque 2015). Some also use Huli [hui] (San Roque 2015). Used as L2 by Bogaya[boq], Hewa [ham], Huli [hui].

name: Musan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–65%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%–65% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Most children literate. NT: 1977–2013.
Language Use: All domains, except with outsiders. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Amto [amt], especially adult men. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially most young people. Used as L2 by Amto [amt].

name: Njalgulgule
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Latundê
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Bareli, Rathwi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 10%. Bible portions: 1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except education. Positive attitudes. Also useAhirani [ahr]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar]. Also useNimadi [noe].

name: Telefol
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Jorgensen 2006). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Jorgensen 2006). Used as L2 by Asaba [seo], Mian [mpt], Ninggerum [nxr], Tifal [tif].

name: Lavukaleve
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Awar
Language Use: Some of all ages. About 30 children are able to speak Awar. Adults use Awarsparingly, and some adults do not speak Awar. Only elderly consistently use Awar. Positiveattitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Paris 2015).

name: Saam
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Nepali [npi].

name: Baruya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bonnemère 2016).

name: Huli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. Bible:2002.
Language Use: Huli is a dominant language in the area. Most domains. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012). Also use AngalHeneng [akh] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012). Also use Duna [duc] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012).Used as L2 by Angal Heneng [akh], Duna [duc], Edolo [etr], Kasua [khs], Onobasulu [onn].

name: Lakkia
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some speakers of other languages use Lakkia for trade. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Iu Mien [ium]. Also use Liuqian Zhuang [zlq]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Jiongnai Bunu [pnu].

name: Bamwe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%–50% in Lingala [lin].
Language Use: Most also use Lingala [lin], except oldest women. Many women speak onlymarket Lingala.

name: Wangaaybuwan-Ngiyambaa
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Daro-Matu
Language Use: Home, Community, Religious settings. Some of all ages. Many also use Malay[zlm]. Some also use Iban [iba].

name: Bughotu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. NT:1914–2009.
Language Use: Home, village, church. Used by all. Also use Gao [gga]. Also use Pijin[pis], with other Santa Isabel speakers who do not speak Bughotu. Used as L2 by Cheke Holo[mrn], Gao [gga].

name: Wè Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Fanagalo
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used widely in towns and gold, diamond, coal, and copper mining areas.

name: Wendat
Language Development: Dictionary. Wendat is taught to adults at the adult education centre at Wendake, and to children at the primary school on the reserve, École Wahta’ (2021 M. Lukaniec).
Language Use: Shifted to French [fra].

name: Bih
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Rade [rad].

name: Ngam
Language Use: Also use Sar [mwm], particularly the Sara Madjingay dialect. Used as L2 by Horo [hor].

name: Katso
Language Development: High literacy in Chinese. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults.

name: Mwan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Also use French [fra], especially the educated. Also use Guro [goa]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Wan [wan].

name: Adynyamathanha
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Texts. The Department of Education and Children’sServices developed a teaching framework and language learning material for Adnyamathanha between2004 and 2005. By 2009, over 1,000 students were studying Adnyamathanha in 9 primary schools.Online educational resources available for students online (2018).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng] (Wurm 2007).

name: Lodhi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 22% in Odisha (2001 census). NT: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Odia [ory].

name: Mozambican Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Mozambique National Association of the Deaf (ASUMO).
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Quichua, Tena Lowland
Language Development: Children learn to read and write in standard Ecuadorian Quichua, which is referred to as ‘Quichua Unificado’, Unified Quichua. Dictionary. NT: 1972.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Spanish [spa] (Grzech 2016). Used as L2 by Waorani [auc].

name: Merwari
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially educated people, with very good proficiency.

name: Arbore
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 14%. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Konso [kxc]. Used as L2 by Daasanach [dsh].

name: Arabic (Omani)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bathari [bhm], Harsusi [hss].

name: Gazi
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Yangum Gel
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Garlali
Language Development: Texts.

name: Karakalpak
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Also use Northern Uzbek [uzn]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Saek
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Most also use Lao [lao] (Asian Minorities Outreach 1999b). Used as L2 by Arem [aem].

name: Odiai
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Yale [nce], and have maintained long-term tradeand cultural relationships with Yale speakers (Foley 2018a). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Araweté
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Portuguese [por], especially those under 20(Crevels 2007).

name: Urali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 73% (2001 census).
Language Use: Shifted to Malayalam [mal].

name: Loniu
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Also use Koro [kxr]. Also use Lele [lle]. Used as L2 by Koro [kxr].

name: Kunjen
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Torres Strait Creole [tcs]. Also use Kriol [rop], or other Aboriginal languages. Used as L2 by Koko-Bera [kkp].

name: Keyagana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1997–2003.

name: Indo-Portuguese
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 1826–1852.
