Language Use: It is mostly, if not entirely, spoken by multilingual speakers (Cardoso2006). Some communities in India have no remaining speakers. Few remaining speakers inCannanore; last speaker in Cochin, Mr. William Rozario, died on Vypeen Island (2010). Some youngpeople, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Gujarati [guj]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Alsouse Marathi [mar]. Also use Portuguese [por], extensively (Cardoso 2006).

name: Hung
Language Use: Shifting to Lao [lao].

name: Rangkas
Language Use: Shifted to Kumaoni [kfy].

name: Shabo
Language Use: Most domains. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Majang [mpe]. Also use Shekkacho [moy].

name: Sekpele
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. All also use Éwé [ewe] (Ameka 2007). Also use Akan [aka].

name: Ugong
Language Development: Revival activities underway in Kok Chiang village in Suphanburi Province (Bradley 2007a).
Language Use: Extinct in traditional territory in western Kanchanaburi Province, moribund (youngest fluent speakers over 40) in Kok Chiang village in Suphanburi Province, endangered in Khok Khwai village in Uthai Thani Province, where they have recently lost their land and dispersed into the surrounding forests (Bradley 2007a). Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Thai [tha]. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Balti
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used since the 17th century. Arabicscript, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used since the 17th century, primary usage. Balti script[Qaab], no longer in use. Tibetan script [Tibt], used between 8th and 17th century, recentefforts to revive usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%–5% in Urdu [urd]. Dictionary. Texts. Bibleportions: 1903–1940.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Shina [scl]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Warao
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1974–2004.
Language Use: Extensively documented and taught at the university level (Crevels 2007). Used by all.

name: Buriat, China
Language Development: Written Mongolian is the literary language. Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Peripheral Mongolian [mvf].

name: Sursurunga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Benroi et al 2018).

name: Tübatulabal
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Language preservation classes held around Lake Isabella (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sumau
Language Development: Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Dubli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 48% in Gujarat (2001 census). NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Buang, Mapos
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1978–2003.
Language Use: Vigorous use in villages. Urban residents mainly use Tok Pisin [tpi] withchildren (2001 UNESCO). All domains in villages except church, where there is mixed use withother languages (2001 UNESCO). Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with some young people living in urban areas shifting.Also use Yabem [jae]. Used as L2 by Vehes [val].

name: Dondo
Language Use: Children receive their education in Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Someyoung people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Naga, Northern Rengma
Language Development: Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Tidore
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use North Moluccan Malay [max]. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].

name: Zoque, Tabasco
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Ede Nago, Manigri-Kambolé
Language Development: Literacy classes using Yoruba materials started in 1977. Post literacy activities began in 1995.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra].

name: Mazahua, Michoacán
Language Development: Bible portions: 1987.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ayta, Ambala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Filipino [fil].

name: Yale, Kosarek
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Negative attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Bobongko
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Wané
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Bakwé [bjw]. Also use French [fra].

name: Baygo
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Spokane
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Language revival program is expanding to provide instruction at all grade levels in the reservation school (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Huilliche
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Few domains. Elderly only. All shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Zangskari
LITERACY_L2: Speakers in Ladakh region have highest rate.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Speakers in Ladakh region have highest rate. Bible portions: 1945–1951.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Ladakhi [lbj].

name: Inuktitut (Eastern Canadian)
Writing: Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], uses eastern finals.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1826–2012.
Language Use: Vigorous except in Labrador, where less than half are speakers. In Labradoraverage speaker age over 20 years old; possibly a few children at Nain. Some young people, alladults. Also use English [eng].

name: Bulu (Papua New Guinea)
Language Use: Also use Bola [bnp].

name: Popoloca, Santa Inés Ahuatempan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 55%. 300 readers. Bible portions: 1994–1996.
Language Use: All domains among older adults; half of the time in local commerce, administration. Adults only. Negative attitudes. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Antakarinya
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007).

name: Legbo
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng] (Decker et al2023). Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm] (Decker et al 2023). Some also use Efik [efi] (Deckeret al 2023). A few also use Cross River Mbembe [mfn] (Decker et al 2023). A few also use Igbo[ibo] (Decker et al 2023).

name: Vehes
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon); endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Mapos Buang [bzh], Mangga Buang [mmo] and Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Also use Central Buang [bzh] (Wurm 2007). Also use Mangga Buang [mmo] (Wurm 2007).

name: Ntomba
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1936–1947.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Meeuwis 1998). Used as L2 by Bolia [bli].

name: Naro
LITERACY_L2: 15–29 years: 70% in Setswana [tsn], 15% in English [eng]; 30–54 years: 10% in Setswana 2% in English; 55 and older: 2% in Setswana, 0% in English.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15–29 years: 70% in Setswana [tsn], 15% in English [eng]; 30–54 years: 10% in Setswana 2% in English; 55 and older: 2% in Setswana, 0% in English. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2012. Agency: Naro Language Project.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by ǀGwi [gwj], ǁGana [gnk], Juǀ’hoansi [ktz], Taa [nmn].

name: Jacalteco, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–52%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2016. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Wandji
Language Use: Many also use French [fra].

name: Popoloca, Coyotepec
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Malay, North Moluccan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: A few communities use it as L1. Used orally between speakers of different languages. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Bacanese Malay [btj], Ibu [ibu], Sawai [szw], Tabaru [tby], Tidore [tvo], Tobelo [tlb].

name: Bwisi
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Heiltsuk
Language Development: Local teaching program in Bella Bella. Dictionary.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Toga
Language Development: Bible portions: 1900.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Alak
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao]. Used as L2 by Lavi [lvi], Talieng [tdf].

name: Tula
Language Development: Videos. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Dadiya [dbd].

name: Aninka
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Boikin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Texts. Bibleportions: 1971–2003.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Khana
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 1968.
Language Use: Khana is the largest language of the Ogonoid group and therefore Gokana [gkn], Baan [bjv], and Tee [tkq] tend to learn it. Used by all. Also use Gokana [gkn]. Also use Ibibio [ibb].

name: Seke (Nepal)
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lhowa [loy]. Also use Nepali [npi], with the Gurung people.

name: Bua
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Boor [bvf].

name: Ahirani
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar].Used as L2 by Palya Bareli [bpx], Pauri Bareli [bfb], Rathwi Bareli [bgd].

name: Ampari Dogon
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Bujhyal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15% in Nepali [npi]. Grammar.
Language Use: Home; mixed use: Work, education. Older adults only. Positive attitudes.Shifted to Nepali [npi] (Van Driem 2007). Used as L2 by Sunwar [suz].

name: Yi, Wuding-Luquan
Writing: Miao (Pollard) script [Plrd], used at least since 1923, primary usage among Christians. Yi script [Yiii], traditional, dating from Han dynasty, limited usage.
Language Development: Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Wageman
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Kpan
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: The Bissaula dialect is extinct.

name: Kanasi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1997.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Some also use Dawawa [dww]. Some also use English [eng], especially young people. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults. Some also use Wedau [wed], especially older adults.

name: Duruwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Madiya [mrr] speak Duruwa to communicate with the Dhurwa people. Some young people, all adults. Also use Bhatri [bgw], especially the younger generation. Also use English [eng]. Also use Halbi [hlb], especially the younger generation. Also use Hindi [hin], especially the younger generation. Also use Odia [ory], especially the younger generation.

name: Laven
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Itawit
Language Use: Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Singpho
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 40%. Bible portions: 1907.
Language Use: Home only. Most also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Tangsa Naga [nst], Turung [try].

name: Mandara
Language Use: Home, community; Mixed use: church, school. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially adult men.

name: Arabic (Judeo-Yemeni)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Sanaani Arabic [ayn].

name: Olekha
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Lamu
Language Use: Intermarried with Lipo [lpo] (Bradley 2007a). Home, village. Shifted to Lipo [lpo]. Also use Lolopo [ycl].

name: Tamasheq
Language Development: The government is actively promoting the language through adult literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Grammar. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Koyra Chiini Songhay [khq], Koyraboro Senni Songhay [ses], Tadaksahak [dsq].

name: Kadai
Language Use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Nasarian
Language Use: Some key domains. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Letemboi [nms] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Nahavaq [sns] (Wurm 2007).

name: Noone
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 65%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Limbum [lmp]. A few also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Bum [bmv]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Kom [bkm]. Also use Lamnsoʼ [lns]. Also use Nchane [ncr]. Also use Oku [oku]. Used as L2 by Bum [bmv], Limbum [lmp], Nchane [ncr], Oku [oku], Sari [asj].

name: Ute-Southern Paiute
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2006. Tribally sponsored language programs in Ute. No language programs in Southern Paiute. Arizona Chemehuevis have started revitalization program but few materials and no agreement on orthography (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mainly adults but children in San Juan are still acquiring Southern Paiute as L1 (Golla 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Kaska
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Grammar. Texts. Taught at schools in Watson Lake and Ross River, Lower Post and Good Hope Lake. Yukon Native Language Centre conducts annual Literacy Workshops and produces teaching and learning materials (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Adults only. Ross River may have younger users. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Malaysian Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%–80% in Standard Malay [zsm], 30%–40% in English [eng]. Dictionary.
Language Use: BIM is considered a natural sign language and is widely used by deaf people. Since 1978, the Ministry of Education has developed KTBM (Kod Tangan Bahasa Malaysia, or Manual Coded Bahasa Malaysia) to be used in public schools. Deaf children must learn KTBM, and BIM is not allowed to be used in schools. Deaf children from deaf families, and those from hearing families who enter early intervention programs, know and use BIM at an early age. Some hearing parents send their deaf children straight to public schools, and these children generally learn KTBM in schools. However, many who have completed schooling and joined deaf social groups quickly adopt BIM. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Standard Malay [zsm], in written form. Some also use English [eng], in written form. Used as L2 by Penang Sign Language [psg], Selangor Sign Language [kgi].

name: Masela, Central
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Ndamba
Language Use: Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Pa-Hng
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Hmong Njua [hnj] (Bradley 2007b). Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn] (Bradley 2007b). Also use Northern Dong [doc] (Bradley 2007b).

name: Isconahua
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Shipibo-Conibo [shp].

name: Ohlone (Southern)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Revitalization work in progress; all agesattend workshops in the language. Many consider themselves speakers because they can converse inthe language.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ingrian
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Heavily influenced by Finnish [fin] and Russian [rus] (Salminen 2007). Fewdomains. Elderly only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Hupa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Adult classes and language immersion camps(2016).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Purik
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Tibetan script [Tibt], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 61% (2001 census). Bible portions: 1938–1940.
Language Use: Dominant language in Kargil District. Many Purik have shifted to Balti [bft]. Some of all ages. Many also use Balti [bft]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Balti [bft], Shina [scl].

name: Ili'uun
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Jeh and Juru have no remaining speakers. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Wakawaka
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sighu
Language Use: Shifted to French [fra].

name: Malecite-Passamaquoddy
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1870. School and community-based classes. Taught at the University of New Brunswick.
Language Use: Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Increasing interest in the language in some places. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Latvian Sign Language
Language Development: Literature. TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Latvijas Nedzirdīgo savienība (Latvian Association of the Deaf, LNS).
Language Use: Deaf associations. Deaf boarding schools in Riga and Valmiera. Used by all.

name: Iwal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1984.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Cobb and Wroge 1990).

name: Yukaghir, Northern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: In Andryushkino there may be a few younger speakers (Salminen 2007). Home. Older adults only. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to mildly positive. No sense of shared ethnic identity between the two Yukaghir varieties, Southern Yukaghir [yux] and Northern Yukaghir [ykg]. Shifted to Russian [rus]. Also use Chukchi [ckt]. Also use Even [eve], especially reindeer herdsmen and some others. Also use Yakut [sah]. Used as L2 by Chukchi [ckt].

name: Mapia
Language Use: Shifted to Biak [bhw] (Wurm 2007).

name: Taman (Myanmar)
Language Use: Many shifted to Burmese [mya]. Many shifted to Tai Laing [tjl].

name: Yuyu
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Segeju
Language Use: Shifted to Swahili [swh].

name: Albanian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Albanian National Association of the Deaf (ANAD).
Language Use: Residential deaf school in Tirana established 1963 with an oralist philosophy, but deaf people did not gather on a regular basis until Communism collapsed in 1990 (Hoyer 2007). Sign language began to be taught in 2005. Deaf associations. Used by all. Also use English [eng], especially among youth in school and on the internet (Dimoshi 2013).

name: Brunca Sign Language
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Boruca [brn].

name: Kowaki
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Mauwake [mhl] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Mauwake [mhl]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b).

name: Kumak
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Bumang
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Tai Dam [blt]. Also use Tai Dón [twh].

name: Pa'a
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1%. Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022b). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Siri [sir] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Warji [wji] (Decker et al 2022b). Used as L2 by Kariya [kil], Siri [sir].

name: Muruwari
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Wonganurra Aboriginal Project has been running the Murrawari Language Project (2007); Murdi Paaki Regional Enterprise Corporation had funding to teach Muruwari to students and community members for the 2008–2009 financial year.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Walla Walla
Language Development: Language classes at Umatilla (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Krahn, Western
Language Development: Côte d’Ivoire orthography differs from Liberia. NT: 1992–1995.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Samre
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Khmer [khm].

name: Subiya
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Fwe [fwe], Yeyi [yey].

name: Katukína, Panoan
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. All the Katukina speak their own language when talking among themselves (Lima 2018). Some also use Portuguese [por], for communication with outsiders (Crevels 2007).

name: Dagba
Language Use: Many also use Sango [sag].

name: Mixtec, Cacaloxtepec
Language Development: Bible portions: 1969.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Nyangumarta
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1996.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Nyamal [nly].

name: Aizi, Mobumrin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra]. Also use Adioukrou [adj], especially among olderadults.

name: Romani, Tavringer
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Swedish [swe], and to Para-Romani, a variety consisting of Swedish grammar with a partial Romani lexicon.

name: Irántxe
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Weak use. Munku group intermarries with other groups. Shifted to Portuguese[por].

name: Kuamasi
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kuri
Language Use: Home. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Digaro-Mishmi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% for Mishmi (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Miju-Mishmi [mxj].

name: Juwal
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Tobo
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013–2020.
Language Use: A few also use Somba-Siawari [bmu].

name: Diri
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Special cultural events. Elderly only. All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Deckeret al 2022b). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Warji [wji](Decker et al 2022b).

name: Djinba
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng]. Also useDjambarrpuyngu [djr]. Also use Djinang [dji]. Used as L2 by Djinang [dji], Ritharrngu [rit].

name: Ushojo
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Northern Pashto [pbu], with many school-going children shifting, particularly in the homeland. Most also use Torwali [trw], with some children shifting, particularly in the homeland. Many also use Urdu [urd], with many children shifting, particularly in large urban centers.

name: Budukh
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Used by 30%–50% of children.Positive attitudes. Also use North Azerbaijani [azj], as a literary language.

name: Xiriâna
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Akhvakh
Language Development: Russian [rus] is a language of education. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults, with many children speaking it(Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. All also use Russian [rus], the language of education. Alsouse Avar [ava], as the literary language and for communication between different Akhvakhdialects.

name: Bai, Southern
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from 9th century, limiteduse in folk songs and ritual texts, favoured by older people. Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based,used since 1993, experimental, small-scale use in education, administration, and literature.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Nahuatl, Santa María La Alta
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Tumzabt
LITERACY_L2: 100% in Standard Arabic [arb]; 35%–65% in Algerian Arabic [arq].
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 100% in Standard Arabic [arb]; 35%–65% in Algerian Arabic [arq]. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1950.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, workplace. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. All also use Algerian Arabic [arq]. Most also use Standard Arabic [arb].

name: Whitesands
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–3 in Narak dialect. NT: 1924–2014.
Language Use: Shifting to English [eng]. Used as L2 by Kwamera [tnk].

name: Nanti
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 0%. Bible portions: 2000.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Matsigenka [mcb]. Also use Spanish[spa].

name: Arabic (Algerian)
Language Development: Textbooks often in modern Standard Arabic [arb]; teacher pupil interactionin Algerian Arabic. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1965.
Language Use: The Ouled Nail of Biskra speak Algerian Arabic [arq], but are ethnicallydifferent. Home, street. Standard Arabic [arb] often used in government communication. Used asL2 by Chenoua [cnu], Tagargrent [oua], Tarifit [rif], Temacine Tamazight [tjo], TidikeltTamazight [tia], Tumzabt [mzb].

name: Mannan
LITERACY_L2: 50% for Kerala, 84% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% for Kerala, 84% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census). NT: 2018.
Language Use: Home, village, religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Interest in language development. Also use Malayalam [mal], with many youth shifting, especially the educated and those having contact with outsiders (Shaw 2008).

name: Sardinian, Sassarese
Language Development: Growing movement to recognize Sardinian as part of linguistic and cultural heritage. Bible portions: 1863–1866.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language but often stop using it at school age (Salminen 2007).

name: Marba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 6%. Literacy classes. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1999.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Marfa [mvu].

name: Ama (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1990–2009.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Yawuno Teneyo [itr].

name: Naga, Poumei
Language Development: Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Kare (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.

name: Opao
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tairuma [uar]. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Motu [meu]. Some also use Orokolo [oro]. Used as L2 by Tairuma [uar].

name: Natchez
Language Development: Dictionary. Revitalization efforts in process with Breath of Life (Natchez) language seminars at the University of Oklahoma and Vista Volunteers and Language Preservation grants (2011 H. Fields).
Language Use: Primarily ceremonial activities and prayers. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bangba
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg].

name: Mixtec, Apasco-Apoala
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Corsican
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1861–1994.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra].

name: Grebo, Southern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Nyâlayu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Kanikkaran
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 71%–80% in Kerala, 59%–68% in Tamil Nadu (2001census). Grammar.
Language Use: Almost all in Kerala are shifting to Malayalam [mal], but those in TamilNadu use L1. Some of all ages. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal]. Also use Tamil[tam].

name: Phai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literacy materials include a set of primers and lessons. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Northern Thai [nod]. Most also use Thai [tha].

name: Leinong Naga
Language Development: Some literacy classes. Bible portions: 2005–2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya], but only by the educated. Used as L2 by Lao Naga [nlq], Paungnyuan Naga [umn], Ponyo-Gongwang Naga [npg].

name: Wichita
Language Development: Grammar. Extensive efforts to document and preserve the language by Wichita Documentation Project (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tepehua, Huehuetla
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1976.

name: Urim
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1981–2003.
Language Use: Used by all. Some children are also being taught Tok Pisin [tpi] by their parents (2020 P. Akerson). All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wood 2012).

name: Truká
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Mixtec, Southern Puebla
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Hanga Hundi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 1997.
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2018).

name: Birale
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Elderly only. Negative attitudes. Shifted to Tsamai [tsb] (Dimmendaal andVoeltz 2007). Also use Borana-Arsi-Guji Oromo [gax]. Also use Hamer-Banna [amf]. Also use Konso[kxc].

name: Thai Song
Language Development: Bible portions: 1986.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Thai [tha].

name: Dimbong
Language Use: Shifted to Bafia [ksf]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Yambeta [yat].

name: Bedjond
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Palu'e
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some of all ages. All also use Indonesian [ind], with some using it as an L1 (Danerek 2019b). Some also use Li’o [ljl], on Flores island (Danerek 2019b).

name: Mohegan-Pequot
Language Development: Dictionary. The Mohegan Language Project has produced a dictionary and online learning materials.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bomitaba
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Gardner 2006).

name: Tongwe
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: In the mountains, vigorous use by all ages; in Kalya and Kashagulu, some Swahili [swh]; in other areas, speakers are over 40. Use Tongwe when speaking with Bende [bdp]. Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Swahili [swh]. A few also use Ha [haq].

name: Tring
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Manam
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Lutkehaus 1995). Used as L2 by Kaiep [kbw], Matukar Panau [mjk].

name: Oromo, Borana-Arsi-Guji
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], primaryusage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 16%. Non-formal literacy classes. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. Bible: 1967.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Ale [gwd], Girirra [gii], Ongota [bxe], Zay[zwa].

name: One, Southern
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: All domains except church. Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Xakriabá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Zapotec, Cajonos
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Santa Catarina Albarradas Zapotec [ztn].

name: Lobu, Tampias
Language Use: Also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp].

name: Anuki
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009–2015.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. A few also use Dobu [dob], only trade boatcaptains. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use Wedau [wed], only older people. Used asL2 by Dima [jma], Doga [dgg], Gapapaiwa [pwg].

name: Awjilah
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Libyan Arabic [ayl].

name: Muniche
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Mengen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2003–2018.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Meramera [mxm], Sulka [sua].

name: Vera'a
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Bislama [bis] (Schnell 2011). Many also use Vurës [msn], especially adults (Schnell 2011). A few also use English [eng], the language of education for older speakers (Schnell 2011). A few also use French [fra], the language of education for younger speakers (Schnell 2011).

name: Dhanki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 53% in Gujarat (2001 census). Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use Gujarati [guj].

name: Narrinyeri
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2019. Narungga People’s Language Project is promoting language revitalization. Several schools in the state of South Australia offer Narrinyeri as part of their Language Other than English (LOTE) program.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Malagasy, Northern Betsimisaraka
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Bantayanon
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. The majority of parents who are passing iton are in families who live outside of the town centers. In the town centers primarily, however,the speech of the young people is more and more indistinguishable from Cebuano [ceb] (Allen2022). Most also use Cebuano [ceb] (Allen 2022).

name: Nankina
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Bible portions: 1990.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Spaulding and Spaulding 1994). Used as L2 by Gamane [bmp], Yopno [yut], Yout Wam [ytw].

name: Tepehua, Pisaflores
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: Most. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ashéninka Pajonal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Dictionary. Texts. NT:2002–2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tsez
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary.
Language Use: Highland users have good language maintenance, those moving to the lowlandsshow attrition. Few domains. Some young people, all adults. More than half the children speakDido. Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava], as a literary language. Used as L2 by Hinukh[gin].

name: Wakoná
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por] (Loukotka 1968).

name: Koraga, Korra
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tulu [tcy].

name: Taloki
Language Use: Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Older adults only. Negative attitudes. Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most also use Muna [mnb] (Wurm 2007). A few also use Wolio [wlo].

name: Suabo
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Mangarayi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Dwang
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka].

name: Lishanid Noshan
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Hebrew [heb].

name: Nnam
Language Development: English [eng] used in school.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Also use Izii [izz]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Also use Nkem-Nkum [isi]. Used as L2 by Abanyom [abm], Nkem-Nkum [isi].

name: Mandari
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bari [bfa].

name: Zambian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Agencies: Zambian National Association of the Deaf (ZNAD); Association of Sign Language Interpreters of Zambia (ASLIZ).
Language Use: Some deaf schools. All domains. Used by all.

name: Pekal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Indonesian [ind].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Education, Religions, Special cultural events, Technology and media. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. A few also use Minangkabau [min].

name: Furu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Lingala [lin], but comprehension is limited.Also use Gbanziri [gbg]. Also use Mono [mnh]. Also use Sango [sag].

name: Momuna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Losing its status as a contact language; being replaced by Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults.

name: Bissa
Language Development: Used in adult literacy classes (2021 SIL). Taught as subject in someprimary schools through grade 5. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Moore [mos].

name: Romani, Welsh
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tsogo
Language Development: Older church members can read Njebi [nzb]; a few do. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Bubi [buw], Eviya [gev], Kélé [keb], Pinji [pic].

name: Ayizi
Language Use: Extinct in most places; moribund at best in Aimalong (Bradley 2007a). Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Shi
Language Development: Bible: 1997.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Havu [hav].

name: Duvle
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Wano [wno]. Used as L2 by Iau [tmu].

name: Soli
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Mahou
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Ashéninka, Ucayali-Yurúa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Dictionary. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kera
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%–15%. Thrivingliteracy program. Taught as subject in a few primary schools in grade 1 only. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra].

name: Malagasy, Tandroy-Mahafaly
Language Development: Bible portions: 2012–2014.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Langnian Buyang
Language Use: Most shifted to Guibian Zhuang [zgn], a local variety, especially those ages 15–50. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially men in the local southwest dialect.

name: Mandaya, Karaga
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, neighborhood. Used by all. Most also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use Mansaka [msk].

name: Haida, Southern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Taught at community-based immersion program(Golla 2007).
Language Use: Only at formal gatherings. Elderly only. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Karaboro, Western
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Bellari
Language Use: Shifting to Kannada [kan].

name: Hoyahoya
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Bamu [bcf] (Usher and Suter 2015).

name: Kamwe
Language Development: Primary schools. People in lowland towns have more education. Bible: 2021.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Sukur [syk].

name: Jehai
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Southern Jehai are beginning to settle down and intermarry with Temiars[tea]. Some young people, all adults. All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a). Also use Temiar[tea].

name: Wayu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Ethnic Wayu live on the hills on both sides of the Sun Kosi River but the language is only spoken in the villages listed. In 1995 many children in Mudajor were not learning Wayu but the language was alive and well in Manedihi (2002 UNESCO). A growing interest in language preservation. Religion; mixed use: Home, friends. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Many feel the language is an obstacle to progress, but a minority would like to keep speaking it. All also use Nepali [npi].

name: Are
Language Development: Bible: 1925.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially elderly. Used as L2 by Dima [jma], Gapapaiwa [pwg].

name: Zire
Language Use: There are reports of the language being revived (Wurm 2007). Shifted to French [fra].

name: Mape
Language Use: Naga and Nigac dialects may be extinct. Adults only. Shifting to Kâte [kmg] (Sifuma 1997). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Sifuma 1997).

name: Cherepon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka], specifically the Fante dialect.

name: Qau
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Sara
Language Development: Bible portions: 1986.
Language Use: Also use Kendayan [knx].

name: Tamazight, Temacine
Language Use: Shifting to Algerian Arabic [arq], in all locations except Bledit Amor.

name: Omagua
Language Use: Persons 40 years old used to understand their parents but do not speak the language themselves (Crevels 2007). Elderly only. Most shifted to Kukama-Kukamiria [cod]. Most shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Chinantec, Lealao
Language Development: 150 readers, 25 can write. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1980–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Negative attitudes. Considered inferiorto Spanish [spa], but use continues.

name: Bassa-Kontagora
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau] (Sommer 1992).

name: Katbol
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis] (Crowley 2006a).

name: Demisa
Language Use: Home, religious services. Adults only. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Nalik
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Tok Pisin [tpi] is the primary language of young people, though young people still speak the vernacular (Jenkins 2005). On the east coast, all children learn Tok Pisin [tpi] as an L1, with only some learning Nalik as an additional L1 (2020 C. Volker). Mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] in all domains among young people. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Jenkins 2005). Most also use English [eng] (Jenkins 2005).

name: Swabian
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Harsusi
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Omani Arabic [acx]. Also use Mehri [gdq], with increasingfrequency and proficiency.

name: Reli
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Oki-No-Erabu
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Guinea-Bissau Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Dictionary. Agency: Associação de Surdos da Guiné-Bissau (AS-GB).
Language Use: Used in the deaf school in Bissau.

name: Kota (Gabon)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1938–1948.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra].

name: Saweru
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Befang
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Pakistan Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used in urban centers. The National Institute of Special Education encourages a total communication approach, including the teaching of PSL. Used by all.

name: Zapotec, Southeastern Ixtlán
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Macuna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. NT: 1989–2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Barasana-Eduria [bsn], Tanimuca-Letuama [tnc], Waimaha [bao], Yahuna [ynu].

name: Nanticoke
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Miya
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2012–2023.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022b). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022b). Used as L2 by Siri [sir], Zibinju [jmb].

name: Azerbaijani, South
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in Iraq and Iran. Arabic script,Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in Iran.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High, in Persian [pes]. Fully developed. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Iranian Persian[pes]. Used as L2 by Alviri-Vidari [avd], Armenian [hye], Iranian Persian [pes], Karingani[kgn], Kho’ini [xkc], Muslim Tat [ttt].

name: Colognian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 99%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1992.
Language Use: Theaters, literature. An academy teaches it. Used by all. Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Ulumanda'
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; Mixed: Religion, Education. Some young people, all adults. Children in villages of Ulumanda communities who are close to cities are shifting to Indonesian [ind] and are no longer speaking the language with their parents (2022 R. Saupia). Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Mamasa [mqj]. Many also use Mandar [mdr]. A few also use Mamuju [mqx].

name: Ghadamès
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Mom Jango
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Palawano, Brooke's Point
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Filipino [fil] (2007 SIL). Dictionary. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Also use Filipino [fil], but with low comprehension.

name: Pwaamei
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Children beginning to not learn the language (Wurm 2007). Shifting to French [fra]. Also use Jawe [jaz].

name: Kosena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 1980.

name: Yi, Dongshanba Lalo
Language Use: Extinct, moribund or severely endangered in many areas, and not many children using it; in some areas less so (Bradley 2007a).

name: Awyi
Language Use: Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Quechua, Huamalíes-Dos de Mayo Huánuco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Most also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Cholón [cht].

name: Bada (Indonesia)
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Taivoan
Language Development: Bible portions: 1661. Revitalization efforts.
Language Use: Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Roma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Narua
LITERACY_L2: Most under age 40 literate in Mandarin Chinese [cmn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Most under age 40 literate in Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Frequent. Home, village, friends. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], in speaking (a local dialect) and in writing. Also use Northern Pumi [pmi]. Also use Nuosu [iii]. Used as L2 by Central Tibetan [bod], Northern Pumi [pmi], Nuosu [iii].

name: Wayanad Chetti
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Malayalam [mal]. Also use English [eng].

name: Hinukh
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, community. Some young people, all adults, few child speakers.Positive attitudes. Most also use Russian [rus], with limited proficiency for older women(Forker 2019). Some also use Bezhta [kap] (Forker 2019). Some also use Dido [ddo] (Forker 2019).Also use Avar [ava], especially among older speakers and almost exclusively used for oralcommunication with Avar people (Forker 2019).

name: East Berawan
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults.

name: Tai
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng] (Pawley et al 2011). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pawley et al 2011).

name: Taino
Language Development: There are revitalization efforts in several places, including language classes, particularly in Puerto Rico.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: El Hugeirat
Language Use: Few domains. Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Defaka
Language Use: Shifted to Nkoroo [nkx].

name: Swiss-Italian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agencies: Swiss Federation of the Deaf (SGB-FSS); Regionalkomitee Italienische Schweiz.
Language Use: Deaf school has closed (Boyes Braem and Rathmann 2010). Deaf association. Status of signing is increasing. Used by all. Also use American Sign Language [ase], and other signed and written languages in Switzerland and surrounding countries (Boyes Braem and Rathmann 2010).

name: Ekajuk
Language Development: English [eng] used in schools. NT: 1971–2012.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Used as L2 byAbanyom [abm], Efutop [ofu], Nkem-Nkum [isi].

name: Hadza
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. A few also use Datooga [tcc] (Brenzinger2013b). A few also use Isanzu [isn] (Brenzinger 2013b). A few also use Sukuma [suk] (Brenzinger2013b).

name: Nuu-chah-nulth
Language Development: Some dialects of the language are taught in local community schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: The language is almost completely replaced by English in both formal and informal domains of use, though significant passive knowledge of the language survives. Ceremonial use. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Gule
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Chala
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka], especially with outsiders and with lower proficiency.Also use Gikyode [acd].

name: Kpelle, Guinea
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk].

name: Dhuwal
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use English [eng]. Also use Djambarrpuyngu [djr]. Usedas L2 by Dayi [dax], Djinang [dji].

name: Loup A
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Lakha
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Hungana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: Very high. Grammar.Bible portions: 1920–1935.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Some of all ages. Manyalso use Kituba [ktu]. Some also use French [fra]. Some also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 byLonzo [lnz].

name: Turkana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Bible: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh], and this is increasing. Also use Daasanach [dsh]. Also use Pökoot [pko].

name: Phende
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Dictionary. Bible: 1996.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion; Mixed: Work, Education. Used by all. Many also use Kituba [ktu]. Many also use Lingala [lin].

name: Pahi
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Nugunu (Australia)
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Kuku-Muminh
Language Use: Shifted to Wik-Mungkan [wim] (Wurm 2007).

name: Bankan Tey Dogon
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jamsay Dogon [djm]. Also use Maasina Fulfulde [ffm].Also use Tondi Songway Kiini [tst].

name: Nukuoro
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Dictionary. Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, church. Used by all. Many also use Pohnpeian [pon], especially older speakers.

name: Arandai
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Lese
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some also use Bangala [bxg]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Zapotec, Yareni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%–75%. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Bazigar
Language Use: Shifting to Eastern Punjabi [pan]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Tucano
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988–2015.
Language Use: Many also use Portuguese [por]. Also use Cubeo [cub]. Used as L2 by Arapaso [arj], Desano [des], Hupdë [jup], Koripako [kpc], Miriti [mmv], Nhengatu [yrl], Piratapuyo [pir], Pokangá [pok], Siriano [sri], Tuyuca [tue], Waimaha [bao], Yuhup [yab].

name: West Berawan
Language Development: Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Home, church, village. Some young people, all adults.

name: Eton (Cameroon)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some urban youth speak French as L1. Used by all. Most also use Ewondo[ewo]. Most also use French [fra]. Many also use Bulu [bjl]. Some also use English [eng]. Usedas L2 by Ewondo [ewo], Mengisa [mct].

name: Ineseño
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Although only Ineseño descendants are organized as arecognized tribe, there is interest among all Chumash descendants in restoring their traditionalculture and language. Chumash Living Language Revitalization Project established in 1999.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Qiang, Southern
Language Development: Those under 35 are functionally literate in Chinese. Dictionary.
Language Use: Parents encourage children’s excellence at school which means learning Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Some families still use Qiang at home. Home. Some of all ages. Negative attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Bantik
LITERACY_L2: More than 90% in the age group born after 1950s.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: More than 90% in the age group born after 1950s.Texts.
Language Use: Under pressure from Manado Malay [xmm]. Older adults only. Positiveattitudes. Shifted to Manado Malay [xmm]. Most also use Indonesian [ind], in formal andreligious registers.

name: Miami
Language Development: Grammar. Miami University of Ohio with support of the Miami Tribe of Oklahoma has developed the Myaamia Center for study of Miami culture and language. Courses are offered there and the Miami Tribe has been developing youth programs since 2005 (2013 D. Baldwin).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Erre
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Senhaja De Srair
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Uri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1984.
Language Use: Spoken by all ages in every village except one, where only adults use it. Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with few children shifting. Used as L2 by Mungkip [mpv].

name: Tutong 2
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used with other ethnic groups. Some young people, all adults. Parents in mixed marriages tend to use Brunei Malay [kxd] with their children. Positive attitudes.

name: Fijian, Western
Language Development: Bible portions: 2016.

name: Gumatj
Language Development: Texts. NT: 1985.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Also use Gupapuyngu [guf]. Used as L2 by Dayi[dax], Gupapuyngu [guf].

name: Nagarchal
Language Use: Many shifted to Hindi [hin]. Many shifted to Northern Gondi [gno].

name: Kayeli
Language Use: Many shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs] (Wurm 2007). Many shifted to Lisela [lcl] (Wurm 2007).

name: Kimbu
Language Development: Swahili [swh] is the national language, so educated people are able to readand write it.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some youngpeople, all adults. Negative attitudes. Low prestige such that in some areas, speakers identifythemselves to outsiders as being from other ethnic groups. All also use Swahili [swh]. A fewalso use Nyamwezi [nym].

name: Udmurt
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: The Besermyan are Udmurt-speaking Tatar. Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language but only those living in remote rural areas continue to use it actively (Salminen 2007). Also use Russian [rus].

name: Amahai
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Urubú-Kaapor Sign Language
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Used as L2 by Kaapor [urb].

name: Nafri
Language Use: Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Bolia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 65%. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community, Work, Special cultural events; Mixed: Religion. Used byall. Most also use Lingala [lin]. Many also use French [fra]. Many also use Mongo-Nkundu [lol].Many also use Ntomba [nto]. Many also use Sengele [szg].

name: Aimele
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng] (Aiton 2016).Also use Kaluli [bco] (Aiton 2016). Also use Kamula [xla], especially young people (Aiton 2016).Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people (Aiton 2016). Used as L2 by Kasua [khs].

name: Baga Manduri
Language Use: Home, village. Most also use Susu [sus].

name: Mixifore
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2021.

name: Odual
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1981.

name: Kiput
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Iban [iba].

name: Hmong, Eastern Qiandong
Writing: Bopomofo script [Bopo], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Wathawurrung
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Dhao
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2012.

name: Mbo-Ung
Language Use: Also use Melpa [med]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Rumsey et al 2020).

name: Kanamarí
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Dogon, Ana Tinga
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some also use Maasina Fulfulde [ffm]. Alsouse Jamsay Dogon [djm]. Also use Tebul Ure Dogon [dtu].

name: Kayah, Eastern
Writing: Kayah Li script [Kali], used in Myanmar. Thai script [Thai], used inThailand.
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use S’gawKaren [ksw]. Also use Burmese [mya], specifically among Buddhists and Roman Catholics. Also useShan [shn]. Also use Thai [tha], in education of Kayah in permanent villages. Also use WesternKayah [kyu], in education in refugee camps.

name: Senaya
Language Use: Shifted to Assyrian Neo-Aramaic [aii].

name: Pengo
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Odia [ory].

name: Chácobo
Language Development: Spanish [spa] bilingual schools have about 180 students, 4 teachers, 5grades. 3 of the teachers are Chácobo. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1979–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous in remote areas (Crevels 2007). Some of all ages. Many also useSpanish [spa], especially those living in Riberalta where youth are using it as their L1(Tallman 2018). Used as L2 by Pacahuara [pcp].

name: Nuni, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 5% in French [fra]. High motivation for literacy. Government coordinated literacy program in Sanguié and Sissili provinces. Grammar. NT: 1999–2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Lyélé [lee].

name: Subtiaba
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Nayi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 7%.
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Amharic [amh]. Most shifting to Kafa [kbr].

name: Kurichiya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 68% (2001 census).
Language Use: Shifting to Malayalam [mal], more in Kunnam than in Wayanad dialect. Allalso use Malayalam [mal], but less than half with good proficiency. Also use English [eng].

name: Twendi
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Kwanja [knp].

name: Seki
Language Use: Many also use French [fra].

name: Angal Enen
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Enga [enq]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Te'un
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Popoloca, San Luís Temalacayuca
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Polish Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Board of the Polish Association of the Deaf (Polskiego Związku Głuchych).
Language Use: Vigorous. Primary schools for deaf children since 1817. Committee for the unification of Polish Sign Language. Interpreters required in court, provided for some college students and in important public events. Used by all. Also use Polish [pol].

name: Nahuatl, Coatepec
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Nahuatl, Morelos
Language Development: Bible portions: 2005–2018.
Language Use: Cuentepec most vigorous use. Used by all.

name: Kulina Pano
Language Use: Weak use. Most live in urban area. Older adults only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Pashto, Central
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Saraiki [skr]. Used as L2 by Ormuri [oru], Savi [sdg], Western Punjabi [pnb].

name: Kutu
Language Use: Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Wedau
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1927–1980.
Language Use: Understood some in Oro Province. All domains. Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Anuki [aui], Dawawa [dww], Dima [jma], Gapapaiwa [pwg], Ghayavi [bmk], Gweda [grw], Haigwai [hgw], Kakabai [kqf], Kanasi [soq], Taupota [tpa], Tawala [tbo], Wa’ema [wag].

name: Maba (Indonesia)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].

name: Taiwan Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%–70%. 4 elementary, 3 high schools. Taught in primary and secondary schools.
Language Use: Decreasing, but not likely to die out, as many deaf are not candidates for cochlear implants or hearing aids. Schools, sporting events, some homes, churches for the deaf. Some young people, all adults. 5 to old age. Neutral attitudes. Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], in written form or use gestures.

name: Laragia
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sere
Language Use: Shifted to Zande [zne].

name: Higaonon
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2009. Schools for Indigenous Knowledge and Traditions (SIKAT) is an an educational program that promotes the Higaonon language and culture.
Language Use: At home and in public, children respond to parents or elders mostly in Cebuano [ceb] (2023 B. Bado). Home, Community, Work, Religion, often mixed with L2. Used by all. Most also use Cebuano [ceb]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Chorote, Iyojwa'ja
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Tilung
Language Use: Mixed use: Religion. Adults only, but mostly elderly. Shifting to Nepali [npi].

name: Albanian (Arbëreshë Dialect)
Writing: Greek script [Grek], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Some literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1868–1970.
Language Use: Strong position in some districts. Taught in some schools. No officialstatus. Home, Community. Some young people, all adults. In some places there may be childrenlearning the language but many stop using it at school age (Salminen 2007). All also use Italian[ita]. All also use regional Italian varieties.

name: Gorowa
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Iraqw [irk]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Hanoi Sign Language
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Some also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Balo
Language Development: Literacy is in English.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].

name: Nsari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Literacy program started in 2011. Schooling is inEnglish. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2014–2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A fewalso use English [eng]. Also use Kemedzung [dmo]. Also use Limbum [lmp]. Also use Naami [bzv].Also use Nchane [ncr]. Also use Noone [nhu]. Also use Tigon Mbembe [nza]. Used as L2 byKemedzung [dmo], Mbororo Fulfulde [fuv], Naami [bzv], Nchane [ncr].

name: Papar
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Adults only. Neutral attitudes.Shifting to Brunei [kxd]. Some also use Sabah Bisaya [bsy]. Some also use Standard Malay [zsm].Some also use Tatana [txx]. Some also use West Coast Bajau [bdr].

name: Maco
Language Use: Also use Piaroa [pid]. Also use Spanish [spa], especially about half the men.

name: Ak
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Muno [grx].

name: Ami
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007).

name: Northern Tidung
Language Development: Standard Malay [zsm] used in school and formal settings.
Language Use: Home, Work, Market and other informal domains. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Sabah Malay [msi]. Some also use Kalabakan Murut [kve]. Used as L2 by Kalabakan Murut [kve], Sembakung Murut [sbr].

name: Maslam
Writing: Latin script [Latn], developed in 1997, experimental usage.
Language Use: In rapid decline (Tourneux 2004). Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Gula (Central African Republic)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Many also use Sango [sag].

name: Awak
Language Development: L1 literacy in early stages (2012). Bible portions: 2008.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Kayan, Murik
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Malay [zlm].

name: Pije
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Fwai [fwa] and French [fra] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to French [fra].

name: Ditidaht
Language Development: The language is taught in the local K-12 community school, but is not usedas the language of instruction. Dictionary. Texts. Agency: First Voices.
Language Use: Ceremonial use. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Gaddang
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Ipulo
Language Development: Bible portions: 1998.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English[eng]. Also use Caka [ckx]. Also use Eman [emn]. Used as L2 by Eman [emn].

name: Kudu-Camo
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Ket
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Older adults only, very few child speakers (Salminen 2007). Mixedattitudes, from negative to mildly positive. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Anu
Language Development: Anu and Khongso have separate literature efforts. Some literacy classes.NT: 2022.
Language Use: Fairly strong vitality in Anu and Khongso majority villages. But in mixedvillages and intermarried families, Khumi [cnk] and Asang dialect of Eastern Khumi [cek] are nowused. Most domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Rakhine[rki]. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Eastern Khumi Chin [cek]. Also use Khumi Chin [cnk].Used as L2 by Eastern Khumi Chin [cek].

name: Mbugwe
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All ages, although villages increasingly mixed (ethnically), and children tend to learn Swahili [swh] alongside or even before Mbugwe.

name: Myanmar Sign Language
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: Vigorous. 4 deaf schools (2 in Yangon, 1 each in Kale and Mandalay). Deaf associations. Used by all.

name: Dogon, Toro Tegu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Phuie
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1% in French [fra]. Motivation for literacy is high. Dictionary. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Northern Dagara [dgi].

name: Sedoa
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kajakse
Language Use: Strongest in Kajakse canton.

name: Day
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–6%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1989–1999.

name: Salt-Yui
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Kamasunga 2014). Also use Kuman [kue].

name: !Xóõ
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use ǀGwi [gwj]. Also use Herero [her]. Also use Kgalagadi [xkv]. Also use Naro [nhr]. Also use Setswana [tsn]. Second languages used by people older than 10 who have been to school or have lived with speakers of the other languages.

name: Orowe
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra]. Also use Ajië [aji].

name: Murrinh-Patha
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1982–1990.
Language Use: Children learn it as L1 (Wurm 2007). Many also use English [eng], many over the age of 40, and among young people, women have a greater command than men (Mansfield 2019). A few also use Kriol [rop] (Mansfield 2019). Used as L2 by Marriammu [xru], Marti Ke [zmg].

name: Teke-Kukuya
Language Development: Bible portions: 1971–1979.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Valencian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Federación de Personas Sordas de la Comunidad Valenciana (FESORD).
Language Use: Deaf schools, plus many deaf children integrated in hearing schools, with widespread oralist emphasis. Many young adults arrive at deaf associations not knowing how to sign. Deaf who have travelled tend to understand the other sign languages in Spain but use their own (2017 S. Parkhurst). Some young people, all adults. Some young people, more widespread among deaf adults. Some also use Spanish [spa].

name: Wasembo
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mor (Mor Islands)
Language Use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Baré
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Nhengatu [yrl]. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Kawaiisu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Muyuw
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. 30% of the children are in government schools. Dictionary. NT: 1976–1993.
Language Use: Also use Dobu [dob]. Also use Kilivila [kij]. Also use Misima-Panaeati [mpx]. Used as L2 by Budibud [btp].

name: Mahongwe
Language Use: Threatened and undocumented (2000 B. Connell). Shifted to French [fra].

name: Eshtehardi
Language Use: Shifting to Takestani [tks].

name: Wasu
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Twents
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Waja
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1926–2013.
Language Use: Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Dadiya [dbd], Longuda [lnu].

name: Kenyah, Tutoh
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kurrama
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Assiniboine
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kandas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Immigration brings pressure from Tok Pisin [tpi], and both Kandas and Tok Pisin are used in home domains. Most domains. Tok Pisin [tpi] is used in many domains as well. Some young people, all adults. In Semalu village, children do not acquire Kandas as their first language, though some acquire it later. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Ramoaaina [rai]. A few also use Kuanua [ksd]. A few also use Siar-Lak [sjr]. Used as L2 by Label [lbb].

name: Tangko
Language Use: Most domains. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Manx
Language Development: Taught at one primary school as the language of instruction; offered assubject only beginning at age 7 through secondary school. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible:1773.
Language Use: Supplanted by Manx vernacular English, which in turn is supplanted by othervarieties of English [eng]. Some peopole are using Manx with their children. There is a strongsense of ethnic identity associated with the language (2013 N. Rees). Some public functions.Shifted to English [eng].

name: Labir
Language Use: Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Gimi (West New Britain)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some alsouse English [eng].

name: Ogea
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 65%. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Jamaican Country Sign Language
Language Development: English literacy is very low because many adults have had no formaleducation. Texts.
Language Use: Formerly used by everyone in the area, deaf and hearing (Adone et al 2012,Cumberbatch 2012b). In the mid-1980s (Dolman 1986) there were about 200 deaf, and only 10 whowere bilingual in KS and Jamaican Sign Language [jls]. Adults only. Shifting to Jamaican SignLanguage [jls], especially middle-aged people (Cumberbatch 2012b). Also use Jamaican EnglishCreole [jam], especially hearing people (Cumberbatch 2012b). Used as L2 by Jamaican SignLanguage [jls].

name: Kâte
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1978.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Asa’a [kyy], Borong [ksr], Dedua [ded], Finongan [fag], Gitua [ggt], Komba [kpf], Kube [kgf], Mape [mlh], Mesem [mci], Migabac [mpp], Momare [msz], Numanggang [nop], Ono [ons], Selepet [spl], Sialum [slw], Sio [xsi], Somba-Siawari [bmu], Timbe [tim], Tuma-Irumu [iou], Yopno [yut].

name: Mixtec, Ocotepec
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1977.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Magɨ (Madang Province)
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2016b).

name: Hobyót
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Mehri [gdq] (Simeone-Senelle 2010).

name: Bagri
Language Development: Most Bagri live in rural areas and are illiterate. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, school, market, religion. Positive attitudes. Mostalso use Hindi [hin]. Educated people and men have greater proficiency. Many also use English[eng].

name: Kla-Dan
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Arabic (Tajiki)
Language Use: Only a few speak Arabic. Shifting to Tajiki [tgk]. No diglossia with ModernStandard Arabic [arb]. Also use Tajik [tgk].

name: Kwegu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 0%.
Language Use: Diminishing among adults. Some of all ages. Also use Me’en [mym], particularly the Bodi dialect. Also use Mursi [muz].

name: Hulaulá
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Hebrew [heb]. Also use Central Kurdish [ckb],especially older people.

name: Dakka
Language Use: Dakka is spoken in a mixed language area including Mandar [mdr], Bugis[bug] and other immigrants. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Indonesian [ind],especially young people. Many also use Mandar [mdr].

name: Dari, Zoroastrian
Language Development: Literate in Persian [pes]. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Used by Persian Zoroastrians in personal communications as a privatelanguage. Shifted to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Yaouré
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Also use Baoulé [bci]. Also use Guro [goa]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Toura (Côte d'Ivoire)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 1986–2005.
Language Use: Also use Dan [dnj]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Wè Northern [wob].

name: Tringgus
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Madagascar Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Agency: Federation of the Deaf in Madagascar (FMM).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Otomi, Querétaro
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2003.

name: Karok
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. School-based programs at primary and secondary levels. Summer immersion camps. Language Committee coordinates several preservation activities (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Elderly only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Asu (Tanzania)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Dictionary. NT: 1922–1967.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English[eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Gweno [gwe], Mbugu [mhd].

name: Bomu
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Bible: 2005–2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Konabéré [bbo].

name: Banda-Bambari
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Chin, Zotung
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Niuafo'ou
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Used in private when no Tongans present. Not used in church. Some young people, all adults. Used by all ages on Niuafo’ou and ’Eua islands. Only the older people speak it on Niuafo’ouin Vava’u, Tongatapu and Ha’apai Islands (2019 S. Tuilautala). All also use Tongan [ton].

name: Kare (Central African Republic)
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1947.
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Kavalan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Min Nan Chinese [nan](Tsukida and Tsuchida 2007). Also use Amis [ami].

name: Caquinte
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 33%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. 100 readers andwriters. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Grammar. NT: 2005–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. State bilingual school in Tsoroja (Crevels 2007). Some borrowingfrom Asháninka [cni] and Matsigenka [mcb]. Religious services. Mostly spoken in the localcommunity. Letter-writing between villages. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also useSpanish [spa]. Also use Asháninka [cni]. Also use Matsigenka [mcb].

name: Pahari
Language Development: Grammar. Agency: Nepal Pahari Bikash Sangh (Nepal Pahari Development Association).
Language Use: Home, community. Adults only. Children no longer speak it. All shifting to Nepali [npi]. Many also use Newar [new], especially men.

name: Zapotec, Mazaltepec
Language Development: Bible portions: 2000.
Language Use: Approximately 58% are speakers. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Gadang
Language Use: Shifting to Bagirmi [bmi].

name: Malay, Kedah
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Thai [tha].

name: Khalaj, Turkic
Language Development: Literate in Persian [pes]. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Bangubangu
