Language Use: A form of Late Vernacular Acquisition is practiced (Prolonged VernacularAcquisition), where children speak a little of the vernacular in early childhood but proficiencygradually increases over time up to adulthood. Home, Community, Religion, Special culturalevents. Used by all. All also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Many also use French [fra]. Some also useLingala [lin].

name: Bullom So
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1816.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Themne [tem], with many youthshifting.

name: Mixtec, San Juan Teita
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Possibly 40% in Spanish [spa]. Bible portions: 1998–2022.
Language Use: Mainly used by older teens and adults. Most prefer Mixtec for family and informal usage. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Swiss-French Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Bilingual education with French [fra] in Geneva, Fribourg, and Lausanne (Boyes Braem and Rathmann 2010). TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Agencies: Swiss Federation of the Deaf (SGB-FSS); Regionalkomitee Romandie.
Language Use: Taught in deaf schools. Deaf associations. Used by all. Positive attitudes, which are increasing. Also use American Sign Language [ase], and other signed and written languages in Switzerland and surrounding countries. Also use French [fra] (Boyes Braem and Rathmann 2010). Also use International Sign [ils].

name: Aranadan
LITERACY_L2: 36%–41% in Kerala, 65% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 36%–41% in Kerala, 65% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Use: Vitality in Malappuram District questionable due to small population, noseparate settlements, living with Malayalis. Low education level helps keep language stable.Mixed use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Most also useMalayalam [mal]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Saxon, Upper
Language Development: Bible portions: 1996.
Language Use: Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Arabic, Tunisian Spoken
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn], informal use onsocial media (Akin 2014).
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1847–2011.

name: Ben Tey Dogon
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Jamsay Dogon [djm].

name: Tatuyo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. NT: 1987–2019.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Barasana-Eduria [bsn], Waimaha [bao].

name: Kaansa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Lobi[lob].

name: Singapore Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70% estimated in English [eng] and (or) Chinese. It is difficult for the deaf to learn to read and maintain their reading skills. Agency: Singapore Association for the Deaf.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, church, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng].

name: Kelo
Language Use: Still has speaker population (1997 M. Bender). Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Bunu, Bu-Nao
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used at least since 1988.
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Bouyei [pcc].Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Mandarin Chinese used in schools.

name: Ghale, Northern
Language Use: Home, friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Positiveattitudes. Also use Nepali [npi], but speakers in Philim, Lho, and Bihi have no more than basicbilingual proficiency.

name: Moi (Congo)
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Ngulu
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Rwa
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Arapaho
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1903. Bilingual educationefforts begun on Wind River Reservation in the 1980s. Arapaho Language Lodge established in1993, a successful immersion program (Golla 2007).
Language Use: No L1 speakers in Oklahoma (Golla 2007). Older adults only. All shifted toEnglish [eng].

name: Bunu, Jiongnai
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous in most families. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Hmong Njua [hnj]. Also use Iu Mien [ium]. Also use Lakkia [lbc]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Warumungu
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007).

name: Tima
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Seriously endangered as a result of the encroaching role of Sudanese Arabic [apd] (Alamin 2012, Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Manta
Language Use: Used as L2 by Ambele [ael].

name: Nakanai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Chowning and Goodenough 2016). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Chowning and Goodenough 2016). Used as L2 by Bebeli [bek], Mangseng [mbh].

name: Hmong, Northeastern Dian
Writing: Latin script [Latn], 1909–1917, 1951–1956, 1958–1966, and from 1982. Miao(Pollard) script [Plrd], used since 1905, primary usage. Pahawh Hmong script [Hmng].
Language Development: High level of literacy among the older generation in original Pollardscript. Texts. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, market.

name: Quichua, Northern Pastaza
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Spanish [spa]. Any teaching done in Quichua uses Unified Quichua rather than the L1. NT: 1992–2009.
Language Use: Home, community, religion. Some of all ages. Negative attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Achuar-Shiwiar [acu], Waorani [auc], Záparo [zro].

name: Carapana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 1992–2012.
Language Use: Due to intermarriage with neighboring groups, almost all Tatuyo [tav] andWaimaha [bao] also use Carapana. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Barasana-Eduria [bsn],Waimaha [bao].

name: Kpasam
Language Development: There are village primary schools. Parents want school for their children. 1 junior secondary school.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Bacama [bcy]. Some also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Camsá
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1990–2009.Language preservation efforts taking place (Crevels 2007).
Language Use: Also use Inga [inb]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2% or more (2021 SIL). Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1981–1993.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra], especially the educated.Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Toura [neb].

name: Tojolabal
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1972–1994.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Tzeltal [tzh].

name: Beeke
Language Use: Most shifted to Ndaka [ndk]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Shua
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1978. Agency: Toraa Dao Association.
Language Use: All shifting to Setswana [tsn].

name: Lotud
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1992. Agency: Pertubuhan PelestarianBahasa Suang Lotud Sabah (PELESTARIAN), Persatuan Suang Lotud Sabah (PERADATAN), KadazandusunLanguage Foundation (KLF), Dewan Bahasa dan Pustaka Cawangan Sabah (DBP, Sabah).
Language Use: Some use in Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Some of all ages. Positiveattitudes. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use KadazanDusun [dtp]. Many also use West Coast Bajau [bdr]. Some also use Hakka Chinese [hak]. Some alsouse Standard Malay [zsm].

name: Ralte
Language Development: Though literacy is high, formal education level is low (in Tripura).
Language Use: Shifted to Mizo [lus].

name: Momare
Language Use: Not used in daily life. Elderly only. Shifted to Kâte [kmg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Barombi
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Mostalso use Duala [dua]. Most also use French [fra].

name: Bandjalang
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bangala
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1953–1995.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Alur [alz], Avokaya [avu], Baka [bdh], Bangba [bbe], Bendi[bct], Dongo [doo], Kakwa [keo], Kaliko [kbo], Lese [les], Lika [lik], Logo [log], Lugbara[lgg], Mamvu [mdi], Mangbetu [mdj], Mangbutu [mdk], Mayogo [mdm], Mündü [muh], Ndo [ndp], Nyali[nlj], Nyanga-li [nyc], Omi [omi], Zande [zne].

name: Sanie
Language Use: Closer to Kunming, spoken only by elderly; further away, only by adults; furthest away, a few children speak L1, which is being replaced by Chinese and Nasu (Bradley 2007a). Older adults only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Mariyedi
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Gbe, Gbesi
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Alsouse Gen [gej]. Also use Saxwe Gbe [sxw].

name: Kabalai
Language Use: Used as L2 by Goundo [goy].

name: Hunzib
Language Development: No literacy in Hunzib. Avar [ava] is literary language. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Avar [ava] and Russian [rus] are used in school and for wider communication(Salminen 2007). Home. Some young people, all adults, few child speakers. Positive attitudes.Also use Avar [ava]. Also use Bezhta [kap]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Lusengo
Language Development: Bible portions: 1898–1920.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Meeuwis 1998).

name: German Sign Language
Language Development: Standard German [deu] is used for writing. Some schools are teachingEnglish for written use, using British Sign Language [bfi] or American Sign Language [ase]. TV.Theater. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1998. Agencies: German Society for theHearing-impaired; German Association of the Deaf (DGB).
Language Use: Vigorous. 80 deaf schools with 11,000 students. Also schools that integratedeaf with hearing students (Müller 2012). Deaf associations. Used by all. Some also use English[eng] (Müller 2012). Some also use Standard German [deu] (Müller 2012).

name: Zapotec, Santiago Lapaguía
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Matsés
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1993–2021.
Language Use: Vigorous. Schools taught by Matsés teachers. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Halbi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 74% for Chhattisgarh plains (2001 census). Governmentliteracy program uses Hindi [hin] primers. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use Bhatri [bgw]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially educated men, fortrading and common topics. Used as L2 by Bhatri [bgw], Duruwa [pci], Eastern Muria [emu], Maria[mrr], Mirgan [zrg].

name: Etulo
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014.

name: Tewa (USA)
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1969–1984. Language preservation project focusing on computer technology (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Some young people, all adults, 50% below 18 years, 70% above 18 (1980 census); most adults. Many younger ones prefer English [eng]; some do not speak Tewa. Some children acquiring the language in Hano (Golla 2007). Also use English [eng], with many youth shifting.

name: Lufu
Language Use: Culture and religion similar to the Jukun Kapya. Language reportedly similar to Bete [byf]. Arufu near Wukari have lost the language. Older adults only. Shifted to Jukun Takum [jbu].

name: Zapotec, Yalálag
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Laari
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Laari has become an informal trade language among youth in Brazzaville, spoken by many non-ethnic Laari in the city (2014 SIL). Used by all. Also use Kituba [mkw]. Used as L2 by Teke-Wuumu [ifm].

name: Andajin
Language Use: All shifted to English [eng].

name: Arára, Pará
Language Development: Nearly all literates read and write in Portuguese [por]. Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Portuguese [por], especially adolescents.

name: Kara (Tanzania)
Language Use: Shifting to Jita [jit]. Also use Swahili [swh], especially youth and a few adults.

name: Wano
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1979–1989.
Language Use: Under pressure from Western Dani [dnw] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Religious services, home, field, community, oral. Some of all ages. Negative attitudes. Little interest in language revival, low prestige, considered inferior to Western Dani [dnw] and Indonesian [ind]. Also use Dem [dem]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Moni [mnz]. Also use Western Dani [dnw]. Used as L2 by Duvle [duv].

name: Guianese Creole French
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: L1 for over 30% of the population in the capital. Most important rurallanguage. Educated people speak it, but avoid it. Low status. Not taught in schools. Somedecreolization taking place. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Carib [car], Palikúr [plu],Tekó [eme], Wayampi [oym].

name: Trinidadian Creole English
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Urban, some rural speakers’ speech may be more similar to Tobagonian Creole. Used as L2 by Sarnami Hindustani [hns].

name: Anamgura
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also useTok Pisin [tpi] (Ingram 2001). Used as L2 by Anam [pda].

name: Masana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 8%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2003.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Kendem
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Denya [anv]. Also use Kenyang [ken].

name: Chatino, Nopala
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2000–2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Watut, North
Language Use: Used by all. Mixed attitudes, neutral to positive. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Carter et al 2014).

name: Zapotec, Xanaguía
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Bible portions: 1996–2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. A few users of other languages have married into and speak it. Home, local administration, commerce, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Spanish [spa], especially those in San José.

name: Gobu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low in Lingala [lin].
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Mono [mnh]. Also useSango [sag].

name: Sindhi Bhil
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Dhatki [mki]. Also use Sindhi [snd]. Used as L2 by Kabutra [kbu].

name: Kpessi
Language Use: Home, formal village functions, prayer, church. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gen [gej]. Also use Ifè [ife].Also use Kabiyè [kbp]. Also use Tem [kdh].

name: Wewaw
Language Use: Shifted to S’gaw Karen [ksw].

name: Zapotec, Yautepec
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Tsakonian
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Monolinguals existed in 1927. Few use Northern dialect. Most use Southern Tsakonian. Propontis Tsakonian has had no remaining speakers since 1970. Older adults only. Shifted to Greek [ell].

name: Lawu
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Weyto
Language Use: Shifted to Amharic [amh].

name: Tuxá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Grenadian Creole English
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Carriacou is an English creole (1996 R. Kephart). The creole predominatesin Grenada (Holm 1989:458). All informal domains. Used by all. Used as L2 by Lesser AntilleanFrench Creole [acf].

name: Iatmul
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Texts.NT: 1975.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin[tpi], especially young people (Jendraschek 2012). Some also use English [eng], especiallyadults (Jendraschek 2012). Used as L2 by Sengo [spk].

name: Yupik, Central Siberian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Gadaba, Mudhili
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 34%–42% (2001 census). Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Telugu [tel], but with lowproficiency.

name: Cowlitz
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tunisian Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low (2008 WFD). Dictionary. Agencies: Voice of the Deaf Association of Tunisia (WFD); ICHARA; Tunisian Association for Assistance to the Deaf.
Language Use: Approximately 70 deaf schools (Total Communication, 2008 WFD). Used by all.

name: Yandruwandha
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Naga, Chang
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: Also use Ao Naga [njo]. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Yangkam
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Hausa [hau], but retain Bashar identity.

name: Pidgin, Cameroon
Language Development: Very negative attitudes towards its possible use in schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Growing number of L1 speakers. Most also use English [eng], especially since English is the language of education and government in the entire anglophone region, where Cameroon Pidgin is widely used. Used as L2 by Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], Aghem [agq], Ajumbu [muc], Akoose [bss], Akum [aku], Atong [ato], Awing [azo], Babanki [bbk], Bafut [bfd], Bakole [kme], Balo [bqo], Bambili-Bambui [baw], Bamun [bax], Bankon [abb], Barombi [bbi], Basaa [bas], Bassossi [bsi], Beba [bfp], Beezen [bnz], Befang [bby], Bubia [bbx], Bulu [bum], Bum [bmv], Busam [bxs], Caka [ckx], Cameroon Mambila [mcu], Chopechop [bbq], Chrambo [bmo], Chufie’ [bfj], Chung [cnq], Denya [anv], Duala [dua], Ejagham [etu], Eman [emn], Esimbi [ags], Evant [bzz], Fang [fak], Fe’fe’ [fmp], Ghomálá’ [bbj], Iceve-Maci [bec], Ipulo [ass], Isu [isu], Isubu [szv], Iyasa [yko], Iyive [uiv], Jukun Takum [jbu], Kemedzung [dmo], Kendem [kvm], Kenswei Nsei [ndb], Kenyang [ken], Kom [bkm], Koshin [kid], Kuk [kfn], Kung [kfl], Kutep [kub], Kwaja [kdz], Laimbue [lmx], Lamnsoʼ [lns], Lidzonka [add], Limbum [lmp], Mankong [bqt], Mbessa [emz], Mbo [mbo], Mbo’ [mtk], Mbororo Fulfulde [fuv], Mbuk [bpc], Medumba [byv], Mendankwe-Nkwen [mfd], Mendenkye [bgj], Mengaka [xmg], Mengambo [bce], Menka [mea], Mesaka [iyo], Meta’ [mgo], Mfumte [nfu], Mokpwe [bri], Mubako [muo], Mundabli [boe], Mungaka [mhk], Mungbam [mij], Naami [bzv], Naki [mff], Nchane [ncr], Ngamambo [nbv], Ngemba [nge], Ngie [ngj], Ngiemboon [nnh], Ngiemekohke [bvm], Ngomba [jgo], Ngombale [nla], Ngwe [nwe], Njen [njj], Noone [nhu], Northwest Gbaya [gya], Oku [oku], Oroko [bdu], Osatu [ost], Pere [pfe], Pinyin [pny], Sari [asj], Supapya [bbw], Tigon Mbembe [nza], Tuotomb [ttf], Vengo [bav], Weh [weh], Wushi [bse], Yamba [yam], Yemba [ybb], Yukuben [ybl], Zhoa [zhw].

name: Ipili
Language Development: Low motivation for literacy. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin[tpi]. Some also use Enga [enq]. Used as L2 by Hewa [ham].

name: Ngwo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use French [fra].

name: Lushootseed
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Numerous programs beginning to teach Lushootseed, in which children, parents, and elders take part; also being introduced as a language available at local colleges.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Wantoat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. NT: 1975–2001.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also use Kutong [skm]. A few also use Yopno [yut]. Used as L2 by Awara [awx], Kutong [skm], Tayatuk [smc], Yopno [yut].

name: Grebo, Northern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1989.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Pinigura
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mayangna
Language Development: Literary development in Tawahka dialect. Dictionary. Bible: 1999.
Language Use: Also use Mískito [miq]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Malay, Balinese
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Education, Religion, Special cultural events, Technology and media. Some of all ages. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. A few also use Bali [ban].

name: Korandje
Language Use: Shifting to Algerian Saharan Arabic [aao].

name: Anal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 74% (2001 census). Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni]. Used as L2 by MoyonNaga [nmo].

name: Rema
Language Use: Shifted to Blafe [bfh]. Many also use Indonesian [ind]. A few also use TokPisin [tpi]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Shahrudi
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Bokyi
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1985.
Language Use: Important district language. Home, Community, Workplace, Special culturalevents. Used by all. All also use English [eng]. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm].

name: Fortsenal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%.
Language Use: Community, Work; Mixed: Home, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Many also use French [fra]. Some also use Bislama [bis]. Some also use Moiso [wlr].

name: Ghomara
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Possible slow shift to Moroccan Spoken Arabic [ary]. Used by all. Also useMoroccan Arabic [ary], especially men.

name: Kelon
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Salish, Southern Puget Sound
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: ut-Hun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Literacy rate in L2: 3%. Dictionary. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Tsuvadi [tvd].

name: Peruvian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Asociación de Sordos del Peru (ASP).
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Baga Sobané
Language Use: Shifted to Susu [sus].

name: Keder
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Older adults only. Young people seldom speak thelanguage. Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Also use Anus [auq].

name: Cuyonon
Language Use: A few also use Calamian Tagbanwa [tbk], especially Cuyonon married to orwho live near Tagbanwas. Used as L2 by Agutaynen [agn], Central Tagbanwa [tgt], Kagayanen [cgc].

name: Mixtec, Tlazoyaltepec
Language Use: They prefer Mixtec over Spanish [spa]. Used by all.

name: Andaqui
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Uare
Language Development: Bible portions: 1994–2005.
Language Use: Vigorous, but much influence from Motu [meu] and English [eng]. All domains except church, where there is mixed use with Motu [meu], English [eng], and Sinaugoro [snc]. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Motu [meu]. Many also use Sinaugoro [snc]. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mirandese
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary schools. Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Officially recognized since 1999, has gained some presence in education, media and public life since then (2007). All also use Portuguese [por], as the language of education, government, business, and upward mobility.

name: Kwa'
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to French [fra].

name: Olulumo-Ikom
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Manyalso use Ejagham [etu].

name: Yevanic
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Greek [ell].

name: Talodi
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Used as L2 by Tocho [taz].

name: Pame, Northern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Northern Pame has more bilingualism than Central Pame [pbs] or Southern Pame [pmz], and only three or four villages where there are monolingual Pame-speaking children. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Notsi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–100%. Bible portions: 1995–2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Vafsi
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Gbe, Eastern Xwla
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Alsouse Gun [guw].

name: Drents
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1981.
Language Use: Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Nkhumbi
Language Development: Bible portions: 1985–1987.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Oshiwambo [kua].

name: Urarina
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006–2008.
Language Use: Bilingual education program but in almost all bilingual schools Spanish [spa] is used exclusively because the teachers are not native Urarina speakers (Crevels 2007). Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], especially men, with varied but generally good proficiency.

name: Aulua
Language Development: Bible portions: 1894–1925.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most domains. Used by all. Positiveattitudes.

name: Yuqui
Language Development: Bible portions: 2000.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Urat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Young people understand Urat [urt], but rarely speak it. Tok Pisin [tpi] is the main language of most speakers (Arminen et al 2017). Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with most young people shifting (Arminen et al 2017).

name: Otomi, Temoaya
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Acipa (Western)
Language Development: Videos. Grammar.
Language Use: Fewer children speak Cicipu in Niger State and in Kebbi State. Home,village. Positive attitudes. Also use C’Lela [dri]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Tsuvadi[tvd].

name: Chontal, Lowland Oaxaca
LITERACY_L2: Most children and young adults in Spanish [spa].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Most children and young adults in Spanish [spa].Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1955.
Language Use: Endangered. Simple greetings, ritual speech. Elderly only. Shifted toSpanish [spa].

name: Bhunjia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 24% in Odisha (2001 census). NT: 2022.
Language Use: Also use Chhattisgarhi [hne]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Bangwinji
Language Development: Bible portions: 2008.

name: Bieria
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Bible portions: 1898.
Language Use: Some domains. Adults only. No one under 20 regarded as a good speaker (2007R. Early). Positive attitudes. Desire for maintenance and revival. Shifting to Baki [bki], butuse as L2 is declining.

name: Curripaco
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1959–1984.

name: Tanimuca-Retuarã
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Grammar. Bible portions: 1993–2019.
Language Use: No longer spoken in the communities near the non-indigenous villages (Crevels 2007). All domains. Also use Macuna [myy]. Also use Yucuna [ycn]. Used as L2 by Yucuna [ycn].

name: Subi
Language Use: Still used in everyday life when Subi speakers are present. However, at church, hospitals, government offices, and schools Swahili [swh] is mostly used (2018 SIL). Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Swahili [swh].

name: Trinitario
Language Use: Rapid loss of language among the youth (Crevels 2007). Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Mundabli
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Good etal 2011). Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Numana-Nunku-Gbantu-Numbu
Language Use: Numbu children speak Hausa [hau] unless speaking with parents. Home. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Bina [byj].

name: Chin, Paite
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75% (2005 BI). Literacy rate in L2: 79% (2001 census). Taught as subject at Manipur University. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1971–2005.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Also use Mizo [lus].

name: Irish Sign Language
Language Development: Literature. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Irish Deaf Society(IDS).
Language Use: Several deaf schools. Government policy recommends bilingual education(National Council for Special Education 2011). Deaf associations. Committee on national signlanguage, and organization for sign language teachers. All domains. Used by all. Some also useEnglish [eng].

name: Abom
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Bitur [mcc]. Shifted to Makayam [aup]. Shifted toWipi [gdr].

name: Mixtec, Sindihui
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Arabic (Algerian Saharan)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Korandje [kcy].

name: Churahi
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Eastern Punjabi [pan]. Also use English [eng]. Alsouse Hindi [hin]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Kola
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible portions: 2004–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. Outsiders want to learn it. Home, garden. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Tonkawa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Hmong, Western Mashan
Language Use: Home, community, market.

name: Njerep
Language Use: Shifted to Nigeria Mambila [mzk].

name: Miani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions: 1982–1988.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Maia [sks] (Sullivan et al 2003). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Sullivan et al 2003). Used as L2 by Mawak [mjj].

name: Icelandic Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Theater. Dictionary. Agency: Icelandic Association of the Deaf.
Language Use: Used natively by hearing children of deaf parents and as L2 by many otherhearing people (2014 R. Sverrisdóttir). The language is taught as a subject within one school inthe language area. The language of introduction is Icelandic [isl] mixed with ÍTM. Home, school(mixed language use), media, community. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Icelandic[isl], especially for writing.

name: Yanyuwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1980–1990.
Language Use: Intermarry with Garrwa [wrk] or Marra [mec]. Wives learn the husband’slanguage but use their own with members of their own group. Children usually speak the mother’slanguage, but boys at puberty learn and then speak the father’s language. Losing young speakers(Wurm 2007). Shifting to English [eng]. Also use Garrwa [wrk]. Also use Kriol [rop].

name: Latin
Language Development: Bible: 300–1979. Revival effort underway. The Vatican Latin Foundation established in 1976.
Language Use: Used in Roman Catholic liturgy and publication of all official documents in gazette.

name: Kaimbé
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Karas
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Iha [ihp] andIndonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Karipuná
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por]. Also use Tenharim [pah].

name: Mambwe-Lungu
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Home, community, market. Positive attitudes.

name: Osage
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Revitalization program since the 1970s (Golla 2007) The Osage Language Program was created in 2003, and its website has both audio and video learning materials. Geoffrey Standing Bear, the Osage Nation Chief, announced early in 2015 that he would make Osage language immersion a priority.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Chung
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy program started 2011. Schooling is inEnglish [eng]. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Bum [bmv].Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use English [eng]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Hausa[hau]. Also use Kemedzung [dmo]. Also use Kom [bkm]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used asL2 by Bum [bmv], Kemedzung [dmo], Kom [bkm], Nchane [ncr].

name: Sagalla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–40%. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Home, social gatherings, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Kombai
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Vumbu
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra].

name: Swiss-German Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Agencies: Swiss Federation of the Deaf (SGB-FSS); Regionalkomitee Deutschschweiz und Liechtenstein.
Language Use: First deaf school 1777 in Zurich. Strong oralist tradition in schools in German area; some classes taught in sign language. Deaf associations. Status of signing is improving. Used by all. Also use American Sign Language [ase]. Also use International Sign [ils]. Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Busam
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Manyalso use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Longgu
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kunza
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2007).

name: Makhuwa-Marrevone
Language Use: Used as L2 by Nathembo [nte].

name: Perai
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Bati (Indonesia)
Language Use: Also use Geser-Gorom [ges].

name: Munkip
Language Development: Literacy is in Tok Pisin [tpi]; primary instruction in Uri [uvh].
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Retsema et al 2009). Shifted to Uri [uvh].

name: Thompson
Language Development: No standard orthography. Dictionary. Grammar. Language preservation efforts not strong although Nlakapmx Tribal Council in Lytton started a language education program and is developing a teaching curriculum (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Taveta
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literacy for children in Kiswahili. NT: 1906.
Language Use: Home, social gatherings, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], in schools and official domains. Also use Swahili [swh], especially youth.

name: Ratahan
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Under pressure from Manado Malay [xmm]. Elderly only. Shifted to Manado Malay [xmm]. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Quechua, Jauja Wanca
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Guana (Paraguay)
Language Use: Shifted to Paraguayan Guaraní [gug]. Some also use Spanish [spa] (Crevels2012).

name: Yekhee
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1997.

name: Sahu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Comanche
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1958. Courses in Comanche havebeen taught at University of Oklahoma (Golla 2007). Agency: Comanche Language and CulturalPreservation Committee.
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Ede Nago, Kura
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Lukpa [dop]. Also use Tem [kdh].

name: Sonaga
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Ticuna
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1986–2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Heiban
Language Use: Shifting to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Pakaásnovos
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Strong vitality. A few also use Portuguese [por], isolated on govenment reserve. Used as L2 by Oro Win [orw].

name: Andaandi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Coptic script [Copt], Old Nubianvariant. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Revitalization efforts mainly involve cultural eventsusing the Andaandi language organized by the Dongola Association For Nubian Culture andHeritage, which also offers some literacy courses. The University of Africa in Khartoum hasjoined them in this effort (Jaeger 2008). Agency: Dongola Association For Nubian Culture andHeritage.
Language Use: Home, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Neutral attitudes. Allalso use Sudanese Arabic [apd], with many shifting.

name: Iraqw
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, except government and education. Used by all. Mostalso use Swahili [swh] (Mous 2007). Used as L2 by Datooga [tcc], Gorowa [gow].

name: Bunun
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1964–1983.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kanakanabu [xnb], Saaroa [sxr].

name: Erzya
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1827–2006.
Language Use: Many children learn the language but most of them use it only with elderly relatives. Vitality higher in Eastern diaspora areas than in the Republic (Salminen 2007). Also use Russian [rus].

name: Suruí Do Pará
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Most of the ethnic group still speak their native language (Crevels 2007). Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Kokata
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bunu, Younuo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Gor
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Primer, literacy classes. NT: 2014.
Language Use: There is a Gor Language Committee.

name: Fali
Language Development: English [eng] and Hausa [hau] used in schools.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. A few also use French [fra], especially women.Also use English [eng]. Also use Gude [gde]. Also use Hausa [hau], especially the middle-agedand the youth. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv], especially the middle-aged and the youth. Usedas L2 by Zizilivakan [ziz].

name: Arabic (Najdi)
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2013.

name: Kalispel-Pend d'Oreille
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Flathead dialect classes in some reservation schoolsand at the tribal college. Language camp in the summer. Kalispel Tribe has begun documentationand revitalization program (Golla 2007).
Language Use: General communication among fluent elders with extensive code-switching toEnglish [eng], prayers. Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Totonac, Ozumatlán
Language Development: Bible portions: 2015.
Language Use: Home, work, play. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ngoshie
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use French [fra].

name: Yagua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. 8 bilingual schools. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1994–2008.
Language Use: Children who live near big mixed villages usually no longer acquire Yagua, but those that live in more isolated areas still do (Crevels 2007). Most along main rivers prefer that children learn Spanish [spa]. All domains. Some use in religious ceremonies and services. Mixed attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Chinantec, Sochiapan
Language Development: 20% can read, 10% can write–all in San Pedro Sochiapam. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also useEnglish [eng].

name: Ghulfan
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. Those under 30 speak only Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Shifting toSudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Ura (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Kuanua [ksd], which they passively understand, but do not speak. Used as L2 by Kairak [ckr], Simbali [smg].

name: West Bengal Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Nahuatl, Isthmus-Mecayapan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Zapotec, Coatlán
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Lika
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2019.
Language Use: A few also use Bangala [bxg]. Also use Budu [buu]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc], especially in south Wamba zone. Also use Mangbetu [mdj], particularly the Meje dialect.

name: Mgbolizhia
Language Development: Bible portions: 1980–2008.

name: Bobo Madaré, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Jula [dyu]. Syabéré in Bobo Dioulasso region isthe prestige dialect, and is used for literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2004.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra], especially educated people. Also useJula [dyu].

name: Selkup
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools through grade 4 in northern dialect. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: In Ratta and Purovskaya Tolka almost everybody knows Selkup, including children and other ethnicities. Some of all ages. Northern dialect spoken by 90% of people, but not mastered by young adults and children. Southern dialect spoken by 30%; 10–15 adults, all over 70, speak fluently. Most children are monolingual Russian [rus] speakers (Salminen 2007). Mixed attitudes. Attitudes are positive among Northern Selkups, neutral among Central and Southern Selkups. Also use Russian [rus], in most key domains, except perhaps among family.

name: Fars, Southwestern
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Finnish-Swedish Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agencies: Finnish Association of the Deaf (FAD); Finnish Museumof the Deaf.
Language Use: Mostly deaf people from southern and western coastal areas, whose familiesspeak Swedish and who attended the deaf school in Porvoo (Hoyer 2004). The first deaf school inFinland, in Porvoo, where FinSSL developed, was founded in 1846 and closed in 1993. Privatespheres only. Older adults only. Many shifted to Finnish Sign Language [fse]. Used mainly bydeaf people in Finland who attended the deaf school in Porvoo, now closed (Takkinen et al 2015).

name: Longto
Language Use: Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Guajá
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. A few also use Portuguese [por], but with low proficiency.

name: Masimasi
Language Use: Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Mator
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Kanashi
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Ura (Vanuatu)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Sie [erg] (Wurm 2007).

name: Panamint
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90%. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Only used among the oldest with each other. Younger speakers attempting to revive interest in Timbisha among the younger generations, but with little success (Golla 2007). Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bugun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 24% (1981 census), 35% for men, 12% for women. NT:2018.
Language Use: Home, village, religion. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].Younger people use more Hindi. Also use Hruso [hru]. Also use Kalaktang Monpa [kkf]. Also useNefamese [nef]. Also use Sherdukpen [sdp]. Older people use more Sherdukpen.

name: Tai Ya
Writing: Tai Tham (Lanna) script [Lana], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1922.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Gimnime
Language Use: Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Butuanon
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Cebuano [ceb].

name: Nahuatl, Huaxcaleca
Language Use: 12 municipalities no longer have speakers. Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Matagalpa
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Cora, Santa Teresa
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Chuka
Language Development: Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Gikuyu [kik].Also use Kamba [kam]. Also use Kimîîru [mer]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Nakwi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1%.

name: Songhay, Humburi Senni
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Mangerr
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Balanta-Kentohe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. L1 literacy materialsused in church and in government social programs. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Shifting to Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov] occurring among those whose parentsmigrated to the capital, Bissau, for further education and/or economic opportunity. Home,friends, work, religion. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Guinea-BissauCreole [pov], as the language of interethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Many also usePortuguese [por], as the language of education and communication with foreigners. Used as L2 byMandjak [mfv], Mankanya [knf], Mansoanka [msw], Papel [pbo].

name: Banggarla
Language Development: Dictionary. Professor Ghil’ad Zuckermann, chair of Linguistics andEndangered Languages at the University of Adelaide, is working with the Barngarla people toreclaim their language (2014).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Hangaza
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1938.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Kahua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Ekari
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1963–1985.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Tolomako
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% in Bislama [bis]. Bible portions: 1904–1909.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Work, Religion, Education for Palanen speakers. Mixed in all domains for Paleano speakers (2023 M. Majamaja). Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Bislama [bis], including all of the Palanen dialect. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use French [fra], particularly in the Paleano dialect. A few also use Tiale [mnl], particularly in the Palanen dialect.

name: Hehe
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes.

name: Bonerate
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Kalao [kly].

name: Kuo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Savi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Over 50% in Southern Pashto [pbt].
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Southern Pashto [pbt].

name: Masmaje
Language Development: 3 primary schools in 87 villages in Masmedie Canton.
Language Use: Most also use Chadian Arabic [shu], especially for literacy and education.

name: Koti
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], plans for future development usingthis script. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Portuguese [por]. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2021.
Language Use: Home, market, trading. Used by all. Also use Makhuwa [vmw]. Also usePortuguese [por]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Nathembo [nte].

name: Grebo, Central
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Dakaka
Language Development: Videos. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Bislama [bis], specifically in contexts where speakers of otherlanguages are present (for example, in court).

name: Bati (Cameroon)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in French [fra]. Grammar.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Many also use French [fra]. Some also use Bakoko [bkh].Some also use Nubaca [baf]. Some also use Yangben [yav]. Also use Basaa [bas], especially inchurch.

name: Sicilian
Language Development: Bible portions: 1860.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Italian [ita].

name: Moi (Indonesia)
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by As [asz], Duriankere [dbn].

name: Rembarunga
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults, but few children. Most also use English [eng]. Also use Dalabon [ngk]. Also use Gunwinggu [gup]. Also use Kriol [rop]. Used as L2 by Dalabon [ngk].

name: Notre
Language Use: Most domains except church. Some young people, all adults. Most also useBiali [beh]. Most also use Waama [wwa]. Also use French [fra].

name: Kung
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Good etal 2011). Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Otomi, Estado de México
Language Use: The vast majority of monolinguals are over 50. But in the Morelos Municipality, a small percentage of children go to school not knowing Spanish [spa] (2011 SIL).

name: Wikngenchera
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Wik-Mungkan [wim] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Musey
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 8%–10%. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: Kera [ker] and other nearby groups are bilingual in Musey. Also use French [fra].

name: Akyaung Ari Naga
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tangkhul Naga [ntx].

name: Mbere
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Leitch 2005).

name: Sipacapense
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Grammar. Bible portions: 1992–1998. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. In a survey of 80 people in 2000, many children actively used it. Neutral attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Yuchi
Language Development: Grammar. Preschool language immersion daycare center, after-school children’s classes, and annual language and culture camps. Agency: Euchee (Yuchi) Language Project.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Panamanian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nyamal
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Wangka Maya Pilbara Aboriginal Language Center has worked with the Nyamal to produce language learning material.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to English [eng] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Nyangumarta [nna] (Wurm 2007).

name: Mohawk
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1880–2004. Immersion school at St. Regis (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mainly adults but a few children are native speakers (Golla 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Lachi, White
Language Use: Shifting to Vietnamese [vie].

name: Zapotec, Zoogocho
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sivia Sign Language
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Threatened by the officially-recognized Peruvian Sign Language [prl], which is the only sign language used in education, though no signed language is currently used in Sivia schools (2018 B. Clark). All domains. Some young people, all adults.

name: Gbe, Ci
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra].

name: Bonjo
Language Use: Shifting to Lingala [lin].

name: Ashéninka, Pichis
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 1996–2008.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Spanish [spa].

name: Lele (Chad)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 8%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Karen, Pwo Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Also use Thai [tha], but little knowledge of it in the area delimited by Hot and Mae Sarieng.

name: Korwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 26% for Chhattisgarh (2001 census). NT: 2022.
Language Use: Some Pahadi Korwa are shifting to Sadri [sck]. Dihari Korwa of Jashpurspeak a local variety of Sadri as mother tongue. Some Korwa speak Chhattisgarhi [hne] as mothertongue. Some of all ages. Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck].

name: Sáliba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary.
Language Use: In the Orocué area the language is only conserved to a high degree among elderly women; others understand Sáliba but no longer express themselves in the language (Crevels 2007). Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Krahn, Eastern
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Tsishingini
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20% in Hausa [hau]. Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Daju, Dar Sila
Language Use: Shifting to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Aleut
Writing: Cyrillic script, Old Church Slavonic variant [Cyrs], introduced in 1829.Latin script [Latn], introduced in 1870.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1840–1903.
Language Use: Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Wapishana
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Amariba dialect may have no remaining speakers. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Atorada [aox], Taruma [tdm].

name: Chiapanec
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Ghandruk Sign Language
Language Development: Deaf children attend Phokara Deaf School (Hofer 2024). Agency: AnnapurnaDeaf Association (affiliated with National Federation of the Deaf Nepal).
Language Use: Despite the influence of Nepalese Sign Language there is no mention thatnumbers of users are decreasing or that some children are not learning the language. However,the language is called ‘endangered’ (Hofer 2024). All domains. Some also use Nepalese SignLanguage [nsp]. Growing influence of Nepalese Sign Language due to increased use in education,video communication, social media, and travel (Hofer 2024). Also use Gurung [gvr]. Hearingsigners speak Gurung [gvr], the main language of Ghandruk village (Hofer 2024). Also use Nepali[npi]. Most hearing signers fluent in Nepali [npi] (Hofer 2024).

name: Pana (Central African Republic)
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Hunsrik
Language Use: Officially minimized until the 2000s when it began to be recognized as alanguage and written with a standardized Latin alphabet. Home, market. Positive attitudes.Shifting to Portuguese [por].

name: Tukang Besi South
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all, even in communities away from the main islands. Alsouse Cia-Cia [cia]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Indonesian Bajau [bdl]. Also use Kamaru[kgx]. Also use Lasalimu [llm]. Used as L2 by Indonesian Bajau [bdl], Kumbewaha [xks].

name: Chin, Tawr
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Hakha Chin [cnh] (Khun 2019). Also use Burmese [mya] (Khun 2019).

name: Tawandê
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Mixtec, Santa María Zacatepec
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Grammar. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some Spanish-speaking merchants can understand Mixtec. All domains. Oral use in local administration, commerce. Some use in primary schools, churches. Used by all. Negative attitudes. A few also use English [eng].

name: Malagasy, Bara
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Piedmontese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 100% in Italian [ita]. NT: 1834.
Language Use: Use has diminished drastically among the young and in towns (Salminen 2007). Less than 27% of the informants in a 2012 census report use, within their family, a regional language of Northwestern Italy, including Piedmontese. All shifting to Italian [ita]. Used as L2 by Arpitan [frp], Occitan [oci], Walser [wae].

name: Ayta, Abenlen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Less than 25%. Literacy rate in L2: Less than 25%.Teachers are not speakers of the language and when they do teach Abellen, they are often usingmaterials not reviewed by elders (so there are errors). NT: 2020.
Language Use: In some remote areas, children still learn it first. Otherwise, speakersgenerally acquire and use L2’s at home, community, or school, trying to negotiate multiplelinguistic identities. Also used in poetry, songs, oral stories. Mixed: Home, community. Some ofall ages. Neutral attitudes. All also use Ilocano [ilo]. Most also use Kapampangan [pam]. Somealso use Tagalog [tgl]. A few also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Botolan Sambal [sbl],Ilocano [ilo].

name: Buruwai
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Rendille
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literacy activities in some churches. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Samburu [saq]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Mende (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except church, where there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Vaiphei
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% in Manipur (2001 census). Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Ekpeye
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Wali (Sudan)
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Many also use Sudanese Arabic [apd] (Krell 2012). Also use English [eng], especially young people (Krell 2012) (Krell 2012).

name: Manda (India)
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Wampar
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1984.
Language Use: In some places, children learn Tok Pisin [tpi] first (Beer and Bender 2015). Fluent use by most children throughout language area. Writing used for unofficial purposes such as writing letters. Some use in education (2020 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Fischer and Beer 2021).

name: Xaasongaxango
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT:2008.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Putai
Language Use: Shifted to Yerwa Kanuri [knc].

name: Bura-Pabir
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%. Grammar. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some youngpeople, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Dera[kna], Kibaku [ckl].

name: Kaulong
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Ambul [apo].

name: Raute
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Used mostly by younger children, older adults, and elderly. Some use among adolescents and young adults. Some also use Hindi [hin], especially youth. Some also use Nepali [npi], especially settled Raute, youth.

name: Mpur
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1998–2013.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Romani, Vlax
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used by Kalderash dialect. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Grammar. Bible: 2008–2020.
Language Use: Some children are not learning the language. Some young people, all adults.

name: Kalinga, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%. Literacy rate in L2: 65%. Texts. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Written use in religious services. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Awiyaana
Language Development: Texts. NT: 1984.

name: Agta, Isarog
Language Use: Home. Negative attitudes. Shifted to Central Bikol [bcl].

name: Aja (Sudan)
Language Use: Shifted to Gbaya [krs].

name: Jilbe
Language Use: Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Efutop
Language Development: English [eng] used in school. Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Also use Efik [efi]. Also use Ekajuk [eka]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Also use Nkem-Nkum [isi]. Used as L2 by Nde-Nsele-Nta [ndd].

name: Umbugarla
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Koresh-e Rostam
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Kanjobal, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 26%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1989. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Uma
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Use vigorous in the Uma homeland. Kantewu is prestige dialect. Among those living outside (e.g., in Palu, Palolo, Gimpu), use is vigorous among adults. For those who move away as adults, Uma remains language of the home. For those who move away as children, half retain Uma as home language. Daily work, local administration, religious services. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Ledo Kaili [lew]. Also use Rampi [lje]. Also use Seko Padang [skx].

name: Mapun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%–70%. Literacy rate in L2: 30% in English [eng], 60% in Tausug [tsg]. Many older women are illiterate. Used some at school. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Home, neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tausug [tsg]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Molbog [pwm], Southern Sama [ssb].

name: Malagasy, Tsimihety
Language Development: Bible portions: 1924.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Papua New Guinean Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: PNG Deaf Association.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Chiquitano
Language Development: Taught as subject in all primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT:1980–2012.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Paunaka [pnk],Saraveca [sar].

name: Dyirbal
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bhattiyali
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Eastern Punjabi [pan]. Also use English [eng]. Alsouse Hindi [hin]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Puerto Rican Sign Language
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Horo
Language Use: Shifted to Ngam [nmc], the Kle dialect.

name: Bahonsuai
Language Use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind] (Mead 1999).

name: Itonama
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1967–1969.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Niwer Mil
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Loloda
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Texts. Bible portions: 1915.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Omaha-Ponca
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Omaha language program at Umonhon Nation Public School Culture Center in Walthill. Taught at tribal college and at the University of Nebraska at Lincoln. Ponca language program at Red Rock high school (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Formally for prayers, especially at funerals, for songs, powwow announcements, but usually translated into English [eng] for nonspeakers present. Older adults only. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Mina (Cameroon)
Language Development: Positive attitudes towards literacy. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Some also use Mazagway-Hidi [dkx]. Alsouse Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Daba [dbq], but most not generally bilingual in it. Alsouse French [fra], especially educated people. Used as L2 by Mazagway-Hidi [dkx], Mbudum [xmd].

name: Embu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. There are government literacy materials inKiembu. Texts. Bible: 2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also useGikuyu [kik], due to previous teaching in schools, but limited in rural areas. Also use Kimîîru[mer], but with limited comprehension. Also use Swahili [swh], and up to 70% have lowproficiency in it.

name: Iowa-Oto
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Language preservation activities taking place inOklahoma (Golla 2007).
Language Use: In 1999, only 4 passive speakers remained, none fluent (Golla 2007).Shifted to English [eng].

name: Duduela
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Kassell et al2008). Some also use Marik [dad] (Kassell et al 2008).

name: Dhungaloo
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Zoque, Rayón
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1982.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Zapotec, Ocotlán
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Matís
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por], especially men from 15–40 years of age, and some of the younger women.

name: Mpi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Children not speaking the language much. In one village only very old people spoke the language and in the other it was reported that only people over 40 spoke the language. Home. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Northern Thai [nod] (Bradley 1997). Also use Thai [tha] (Nahhas 2007).

name: Basay
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Long Phuri Naga
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Makuri Naga [jmn], especially older generation. Also use Burmese [mya], especially youth.

name: Naga, Monsang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% (1988). Many read and write Meitei (Singh 1998b). Literacy program in progress by government and church. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Meitei [mni]. Also use Nagamese [nag]. Used as L2 by Moyon Naga [nmo].

name: Kgalagadi
LITERACY_L2: Ages 15–29: 85% in Setswana [tsn], 55% in English [eng]; ages 30–54: 50% in Setswana, 15% in English; ages 55 and older: 20% in Setswana, 2% in English.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Ages 15–29: 85% in Setswana [tsn], 55% in English [eng]; ages 30–54: 50% in Setswana, 15% in English; ages 55 and older: 20% in Setswana, 2% in English. Grammar. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Afrikaans [afr]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Setswana [tsn]. Used as L2 by ǂ’Amkhoe [huc], Taa [nmn].

name: Gula (Chad)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use SaraKaba Naa [kwv]. Used as L2 by Gula Iro [glj].

name: Turumsa
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Dibiyaso [dby].

name: Rombo
Language Use: Vigorous in home area. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Kwere
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used as L2 by Doe [doe].

name: Lauje
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Taje [pee], Tomini [txm].

name: Bushoong
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1927–1932.

name: Mbuk
Language Use: Home, community, market. Many also use Bum [bmv]. Many also use CameroonPidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Ranglong
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Not all children learn the language. Also use English [eng].

name: Sheni
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Kon Keu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 77%.
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Jaru
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Children speak Kriol [rop] or Aboriginal English [eng] (Wurm 2007). Adultsonly. Shifting to English [eng]. Shifting to Kriol [rop].

name: Michif
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Taught for decades at Turtle Mountain CommunityCollege in Belcourt, North Dakota (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Port Sandwich
Language Use: Shifted to Bislama [bis].

name: Yeni
Language Use: Shifted to Cameroon Mambila [mcu], the Langa dialect.

name: Ocaina
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1964–1972.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa]. Also use Bora [boa]. Also use Murui Witoto [huu]. Used as L2 by Resígaro [rgr].

name: Pauserna
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Mesmes
Language Use: While it appears that the language is no longer spoken, the Mesmes ethnic and cultural identity is strong and remains important across the community (2018 M. Ahland). Shifted to Hadiyya [hdy].

name: Pendau
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2002–2005.
Language Use: Pendau is the everyday language in their settlements, but Indonesian [ind] is used with speakers of neighboring languages and with outside officials. Children’s education is in Indonesian (Quick 2007). Home, community. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Indonesian [ind] (Quick 2007). Also use Manado Malay [xmm] (Quick 2007).

name: Songlai Chin
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Gilyak; Nivkh
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage. Latin script [Latn], used between 1931–1953.
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools through grade 2. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 A. Kubrik). Forced resettlement weakened use. Some scattered without regular contact with other speakers. No younger speakers in Amur region and very few on Sakhalin (Salminen 2007). Home. Older adults only. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to mildly positive. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Petjo
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Marind, Bian
Language Use: Home. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Tsou
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Many speak Tsou in daily life. Youth speak Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Some young people, all adults.

name: Pankararé
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Wanyi
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tembé
Language Use: The youth in the main village are speaking a mixed language - Portuguese [por] grammar and verbs mixed wth Tembé nouns. Youth in other villages only speak Portuguese. Adults only. Only in the main village. In all other villages there are no L1 speakers. Shifting to Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Turiwára [twt].

name: Tiene
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Ogbah
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Bible portions: 1999.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Igbo [ibo]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm].

name: Pomo, Southern
Language Development: Grammar. Since 2011, the Dry Creek Rancheria Band of Pomo Indians has held weekly language classes (Walker 2012).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Baeggu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Laghu
Language Use: Shifted to Zabana [kji].

name: Kwandu
Language Development: Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Most also use Kuvale [olu]. Most also use Nyaneka [nyk].

name: Malo
LITERACY_L1: 60% in Tamambo; very low in Alehuta.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60% in Tamambo; very low in Alehuta. Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Bislama [bis]; 55% in English [eng]. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1954.
Language Use: Mixed in all domains. Some of all ages. Used by all adults only in the Tamambo area (2023 J. Mape). Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. Many also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra].

name: Abure
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Many also use Anyin [any]. Used as L2 by Beti [eot].

name: Chin, Bualkhaw
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Chin, Lai
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1978–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by LautuChin [clt], Matu Chin [hlt], Senthang Chin [sez], Tawr Chin [tcp], Thaiphum Chin [cth], ZypheChin [zyp].

name: Mauwake
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Most children learn Tok Pisin [tpi] as their first language (Berghäll 2010). Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Berghäll 2010). Used as L2 by Hember Avu [mmi], Kowaki [xow].

name: Achang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 86% (2000 census). Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Many Han people in Longchuan county use Achang in informal situations. Alldomains. Adults only. Many shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn], except for speakers of theLongchan dialect which remains stable. Some also use Jingpho [kac].

name: Gooniyandi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Kriol [rop]. Most also use English [eng].

name: Obispeño
Language Development: Although only Ineseño [inz] descendants are organized as a recognized tribe, there is interest among all Chumash descendants in restoring their traditional culture and language. Chumash Living Language Revitalization Project established in 1999 (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nzadi
Language Development: Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work. Used by all. Many also use Kituba [ktu]. Some also use Lingala [lin].

name: Seze
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Home. Adults only. Shifting to West Central Oromo [gaz], especially as education contributes to increased assimilation to Oromo, encouraged by local government (Küspert 2015). Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use Hozo [hoz], especially in areas where speakers of Seze live intermixed with speakers of Hozo [hoz]. Frequent intermarriage between speakers of Hozo and Seze. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd], with restricted use. Used as L2 by Hozo [hoz].

name: Wumbvu
Language Use: Many also use French [fra].

name: Arabic, Saidi Spoken
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Egyptian Arabic [arz], particularly Cairene dialect, some speakersas L2. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd], but do not prefer it. Used as L2 by Nobiin [fia].

name: Ai-Cham
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Koshin
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Good etal 2011). Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Puluwatese
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Kag-Fer-Jiir-Koor-Ror-Us-Zuksun
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Kuwaa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. NT: 1989.
Language Use: Also use Bandi [bza]. Also use Liberia Kpelle [xpe]. Also use LiberianEnglish [lir]. Also use Loma [lom].

name: Chukwa
Language Use: Religion; mixed use: Home. Elderly only. Many shifted to English [eng].Many shifted to Nepali [npi].

name: Bozo, Jenaama
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], in development. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2008.
Language Use: Nononke and Somono who live in the same area speak Jenaama as L1. Used byall. Positive attitudes. Also use Bamanankan [bam], particularly northern-dialect speakers withsome proficiency in a Songai or Fulfulde variety and southern-dialect speakers in a Bambaravariety. Used as L2 by Bangime [dba].

name: Kenyah, Western
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Ladji Ladji
Language Development: In 2015, Dr. Luise Hercus, a leading chronicler of endangered Australian Aboriginal languages, gathered Ladji Ladji and other indigenous groups together to hear recordings of their heritage languages with the goal of helping the groups ‘maintain and teach their languages to future generations’.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Asilulu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Banda-Yangere
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Worrorra
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1930–1943.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Naga, Pochuri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 39% (Singh 1994b). Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Mlahsö
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Mlahsö was still spoken by a handful of people in 1970s. One nearly deaf woman still knew Mlahsö well, but had no one to speak it to (1999).

name: Kaure
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Bible portions: 1990–1996.
Language Use: Religious services. Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Abai Sungai
Language Use: Neutral attitudes. Shifting to Sabah Malay [msi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Patamona
Language Development: People in Paramakatoi village are literate in English and Patamona. Some in other villages only literate in English. NT: 1974–2019.

name: Dela-Oenale
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Makuráp
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Oromo, Eastern
