Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%. Non-formal literacy classes. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use StandardArabic [arb], widely used for religious purposes. Used as L2 by Amharic [amh], Argobba [agj],Dirasha [gdl], Gumuz [guk], Mawes Aasse [myf].

name: Salinan
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Powari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 72% for Powari-speaking districts (2001 census). NT: 2022.
Language Use: Powari use is decreasing in the Bhoyar and Vyneganga dialect areas. Half the children learn Hindi [hin] or Marathi [mar] first. Home. Neutral attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Lumba-Yakkha
Language Use: Language retained among some youth (Hansson 1991). Home. Some young people, all adults.

name: Oy
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Sabüm
Language Use: Shifted to Malay [zlm].

name: Nchumbulu
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka].

name: Kallahan, Keley-I
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 4,000–5,000 can read and write. Literacy rate in L2:70%–75%. Dictionary. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English[eng]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Also use Tuwali Ifugao [ifk].

name: Kenyan Sign Language
Language Development: Schools under the Kenya Institute of Education use Kenyan version of (American) Signed Exact English, including 1 at Machakos. KSL used at Nyangoma School at Bondo, a primary and boys’ technical school (Sakwa), and in 1 girl’s school. Taught in primary and secondary schools. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2010–2013. Agencies: Kenya National Association of the Deaf (KNAD); Kenyan Sign Language Research Project (KSLRP) at the University of Nairobi; Kenyan Sign Language Interpreters Association (KSLIA); Kenyan Interpreters and Translators Association (KITA).
Language Use: Church, government, courts. Mainly those in schools and over 15 years old. Neutral attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Fuliiru
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Used as L2 by Kiviila [job].

name: Chuwabu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1978–2003.
Language Use: All domains except education. Used by all. Some also use Portuguese [por],mostly in urban areas (Guérois 2015).

name: Nganasan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Limited use in the home. Older adults only. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to mildly positive. Ethnic pride expressed and status enhanced by knowledge of Nganasan. Shifted to Russian [rus] (Leisiö 2006). Also use Dolgan [dlg]. Used as L2 by Tundra Enets [enh].

name: Alviri-Vidari
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to South Azerbaijani [azb].

name: Kaidipang
Language Use: Younger generation is using more Manado Malay [xmm] (2019 J. Lobel). Mixed use: Home, Community, Work. Adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifting to Manado Malay [xmm]. Some also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Ncane
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Literacy program started 2011. Schooling is in English [eng]. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Younger people tend to leave village for larger towns for school or work. Home, market, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bum [bmv]. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Chung [cnq]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Kemedzung [dmo]. Also use Limbum [lmp]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Noone [nhu]. Also use Sari [asj]. Used as L2 by Bum [bmv], Hausa [hau], Kemedzung [dmo], Mbororo Fulfulde [fuv], Noone [nhu], Sari [asj].

name: Tobagonian Creole English
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Politics. Used by all.

name: Arabic (Sanaani)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Standard Arabic [arb]. Used as L2 by Judeo-Yemeni Arabic [jye],Rāziḥī [rzh].

name: Teke, Ibali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 65%–85%. Bible portions: 1889–1905.
Language Use: Also use Kituba [ktu]. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Djamindjung
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Also use Kriol [rop]. Also use Ngarinyman [nbj].

name: Logba
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Éwé [ewe].

name: Kibet
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Pacoh
Writing: Lao script [Laoo], in development for Ka’do. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 15%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Mbunda
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2006.

name: Panytyima
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Also use Yindjibarndi [yij].

name: Ngungwel
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Andaman Creole Hindi
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], especiallywith outsiders. A situation of diglossia. Used as L2 by Mixed Great Andamanese [gac].

name: Atsam
Language Development: Bible portions: 1923–1932.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Kiwai, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1960.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. They consider it superior to related languages.

name: Tuotomb
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in French [fra].
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use French [fra]. Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use Tunen [tvu]. Some also use Yambeta [yat].

name: Tahltan
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kuria
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Swahili [swh] used for official functions and when non-Kuria speakers are present. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Dani, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% semiliterate. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Wano [wno].

name: Wajarri
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Used as L2 by Badimaya [bia].

name: Korana
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1933.
Language Use: Shifted to Khoekhoe [naq].

name: Kurumba, Mullu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Favorable motivation toward literacy. Grammar.
Language Use: Use is declining. Home, village, religious services. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal].

name: Quichua, Imbabura Highland
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1994.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Quebec Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Societé Culturelle Québécoise des Sourds(SCQS).
Language Use: Vigorous. Some use Signed French. Segregated deaf education by sex resultedin some lexical differences between the sexes; female use more influenced by ASL [ase], male bySigned French and LSF [fsl]. Rare for a deaf child to learn both LSQ and ASL. A few adults haveworking knowledge of both. Used by all. Some also use American Sign Language [ase], especiallyadults and a few children.

name: Wersing
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Sawila [swt].

name: Koli, Wadiyara
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Gujarati script [Gujr].
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Pardhan
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], in Madhya Pradesh. Also use Marathi [mar], in Maharashtra.

name: Gela
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. NT: 1923–2015.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Baiso
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Have resisted extinction for at least 1,000 years (Brenzinger et al 1991).Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Gamo [gmv]. Also use Wolaytta [wal].Youth have greater proficiency in second languages than other age groups.

name: Bali (Nigeria)
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most alsouse English [eng]. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use Bacama [bcy]. Some also use NigerianFulfulde [fuv].

name: Wambon
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2015.
Language Use: Home.

name: Nyambo
Language Development: Swahili [swh] is the national language, so educated people are able to read and write it. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. All also use Kinyarwanda [kin]. All also use Swahili [swh].

name: Pathiya
Language Use: Continued vitality doubtful, due to small population, no separate settlements, living with Malayalis, and similarity to Malayalam [mal]. Home. Also use Malayalam [mal].

name: Dyaabugay
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. In the 1980s, a revival of the language was undertakenand it has since been in daily use among members of the ethnic group as a symbol of theiridentity (Wurm 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Zapotec, Isthmus
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1972–2002.
Language Use: In some communities all children speak Zapotec, while in others shift has begun. In the latter there is a history of late vernacular acquisition, with some children only beginning to speak Zapotec after the age of 6. Some of all ages. Most also use Spanish [spa] (Augsburger 2004).

name: Lijili
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Wali (Ghana)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. The Chakali [cli] are bilingual in Wali. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Chakali [cli], Paasaal [sig], Vagla [vag].

name: Ghomálá'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught as subject in some primary schools.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra]. A few also use Bamun [bax]. A few also useCameroon Pidgin [wes]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use Medumba [byv]. Used as L2 byFe’fe’ [fmp].

name: Cree (Plains)
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],uses western finals, dot after, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1861–1908.
Language Use: Vigorous in many communities mainly in the north. Used by all. All also useEnglish [eng]. Used as L2 by Blackfoot [bla].

name: Malalamai
Language Use: Mixed use in home, community, church with Tok Pisin [tpi] (Carter et al 2011). Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Carter et al 2011). A few also use Sio [xsi], especially older men (Carter et al 2011).

name: Kpagua
Language Use: All also use Sango [sag].

name: Barein
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–60%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subjectin some primary schools. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Oblo
Language Use: May not have any remaining speakers. Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Dengka
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 2004.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Lari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Persian [pes]. Taught as subject in some secondary schools. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Farsi [pes] is the language of education for children beginning at age 7 (2019 M. Ourang). Home. Some young people, all adults. Media and education in Persian [pes] is causing a shift away from teaching Lari to children (2019 M. Ourang). Negative attitudes. Also use Gulf Arabic [afb]. Also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Mba
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. Children have difficulty with Congo Swahili [swc]. Many also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Ixil, San Juan Cotzal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 2001–2016. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Bozo, Hainyaxo
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Bamanankan [bam].

name: Nyaturu
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Datooga [tcc].

name: Angolar
Writing: Latin script [Latn], unified alphabet (ALUSTP) developed for use by allnative languages of São Tomé e Principe officially recognized by government in 2010 (2020 M.Bouchard). Writing only used for unpublished church music. No published literature (2019 D.Eberhard).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Portuguese [por]. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Late vernacular aquisition has been practiced for several generations wherechildren do not speak their traditional language until adolescence or early adulthood.Increasing language shift to Portuguese [por], particularly among those who migrate to thecapital (Eberhard 2019). Home, traditional economy, music. Some of all ages. All also usePortuguese [por]. Many also use Sãotomense [cri]. Used as L2 by Sãotomense [cri].

name: Pinji
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra]. Also use Tsogo [tsv].

name: Unggumi
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mixtec, Soyaltepec
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mostly elderly, except in Guadalupe Gabilera, where children still speak the language (2006). Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kpelle, Liberia
Writing: Kpelle script [Kpel], limited usage except for correspondence. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir]. Used as L2 by Kuwaa [blh].

name: Nahuatl, Orizaba
Language Development: Bible portions: 1995–2009.

name: Bube
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Almost none. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Spanish[spa]. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Equatorial Guinean Pidgin[fpe]. Most also use Spanish [spa]. A few also use Fang [fan]. Used as L2 by Equatorial GuineanPidgin [fpe].

name: Gbe, Weme
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra].

name: Yanesha'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1978–2008.
Language Use: There is a bilingual education program but in some areas (Lower Palcazú)children no longer acquire the language (Crevels 2007). Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Paku
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Negative attitudes. Shifted to Ma’anyan [mhy].

name: Taungyo
Writing: Unwritten [Qaax], informal and non-standardized use of Myanmar script.
Language Use: Vigorous. All except formal domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Totonac, Highland
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1959–2000.
Language Use: Some also use a Nahuatl language.

name: Geji
Language Development: L1 literacy in very early stages (2012). Bible portions: 2013–2023.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Urak Lawoi'
Language Development: Various Thai script and romanized literacy materials (Bradley 2007b). Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Often replaced by Thai [tha] or Malay or both when members of the group settle down (Bradley 2007b). Adults only. Shifting to Southern Thai [sou]. Most also use Thai [tha] (Bradley 2007b).

name: Ömie
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Hmong Shua
Writing: Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, favoured by the educated. Miao (Pollard)script [Plrd], favoured by peasants.
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, market.

name: Rotokas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1982.
Language Use: In the more remote villages all children speak the language, but in villages and around Wakunai Station, not all children speak it (Robinson, S. 2011). Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Robinson, S. 2011). Some also use English [eng] (Robinson, S. 2011). Used as L2 by Papapana [ppn].

name: Sanapaná
Language Development: Bible portions: 1994–2010.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many youth speak only Guaraní. Most also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug] (Crevels 2012). Also use Enlhet [enl]. Also use Enxet [enx].

name: Laz
Writing: Georgian (Mkhedruli and Mtavruli) script [Geor], used in Georgia. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2020.
Language Use: Rapid language shift to Turkish [tur] (Salminen 2007). Adults only. All shifting to Turkish [tur].

name: Ossetian
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Russia since 1844 and in Georgia since 1954. Georgian (Mkhedruli and Mtavruli) script [Geor], used in Georgia until 1954. Latin script [Latn], used in Russia during the 1920s–1930s.
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary and secondary schools for 3 hours per week in North Ossetia-Alania republic. Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Most also use Russian [rus].

name: Baatonum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–30%. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades1 and 2, in 5 schools (2014 SIL). Dictionary. Bible: 1996.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Boko [bqc], Ditammari [tbz], Mokole[mkl], Nateni [ntm], Waama [wwa], Yom [pil].

name: Northwestern Nisu
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kyan-Karyaw Naga
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Kaptiau
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm, 2000 D. Tryon). Private domains, public prayer.Older adults only. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Wirangu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Pre-school educational program and language camps for older children at Scotdesco Aboriginal Community.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mono (Solomon Islands)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Khandesi
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. A group of Kukna [kex] in Dhule District also use Khandesi.Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kukna [kex]. Also use Marathi [mar]. Usedas L2 by Kukna [kex].

name: Kwinsu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Children seldom speak it. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Malay, Baba
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1913–2007.
Language Use: Mainly in the home. Older adults only. Shifted to Malay [zlm]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Min Nan Chinese [nan]. Also use Yue Chinese [yue].

name: Tiranige Diga Dogon
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Mai Brat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 2004–2007.
Language Use: Religious services. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind], especially incities and among the highly educated. Used as L2 by Tehit [kps].

name: Fasu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1976–1995.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Lefort 2017). Also use Kasua [khs] (Lefort 2017).Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Lefort 2017). Used as L2 by Kasua [khs].

name: Huachipaeri
Language Use: Still spoken by the children in some communities (2012). Some young people,all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Armenian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Hayastani Khuleri Miavorman (Armenian DeafAssociation): committees for sign language research, interpreting, and education (2008 WFD).
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community; Mixed use: Education, Work. Used by all. Somealso use Armenian [hye], primarily written. Some also use Russian [rus], primarily written. Somealso use Russian Sign Language [rsl]. RSL taught in at least one school. Used as L2 by RussianSign Language [rsl].

name: Reshe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Hausa [hau]. Bible portions: 1970–2009.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Malfaxal
Language Development: Bible portions: 1919.

name: Kais
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Citak, Tamnim
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Bagvalal
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Positive attitudes. All also use Russian [rus]. Also use Avar [ava], as a literary language. Also use Tindi [tin].

name: So (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Trumaí
Language Use: Very low language vitality. Shifted to Portuguese [por]. Many also use Kamayurá [kay], or other languages in the area.

name: Yanomamö
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1984–2011.

name: Pataxó-Hãhaãi
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Natioro
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Lamenu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Texts. Bible portions: 1987–2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. Kindergarten, oral and some written use in church, oral use in commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis], bilingually with speakers of Lewo [lww]. Many also use Lewo [lww], especially adults (Early 2002). Also use Paama [pma]. Used as L2 by Lewo [lww].

name: Hmwaveke
Language Development: Bible portions: 1990.
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Paicî [pri] and French [fra] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults, almost no children (Wurm 2007).

name: Ilue
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Ebughu [ebg]. Shifting to Efik [efi].

name: Murik
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Not being learned by children. Young speakers prefer Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Adults only. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use English [eng].

name: Ainbai
Language Use: Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kouya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Guro [goa].

name: Samo, Matya
Language Development: Motivation to read French is high. A literacy center near Tougan teaches Jula. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Moore [mos].

name: Berakou
Language Use: Shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Arta
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Most shifted to Casiguran DumagatAgta [dgc]. Most shifted to Ilocano [ilo].

name: Duano'
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace. Some of all ages. Most also use Malay [zlm],Riau Mainland dialect.

name: Niellim
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Tchini dialect is extinct. Used as L2 by Boor [bvf], Tunia [tug].

name: Takestani
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Most shifting to Iranian Persian [pes]. Used as L2 by Eshtehardi [esh].

name: Qila Muji
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Babatana
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Ririo [rri].

name: Jarawa (India)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Waropen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Grammar.
Language Use: Children have a passive understanding (2012 Y. Sawaki). Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Woria [wor].

name: Gwak
Language Development: Bible portions: 1940–2023.
Language Use: Some pressure to shift to Hausa [hau], especially in Bununu Kasa. Used byall. Also use Hausa [hau] (Blench 2019). Used as L2 by Shall-Zwall [sha].

name: Eviya
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, village. Adults only. Children communicate in French [fra] althoughthey still understand the language. Most shifting to French [fra]. Most shifting to Sira [swj].Many also use Tsogo [tsv].

name: Bribri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 70% in Spanish [spa].Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2007–2010.
Language Use: Home, commerce among themselves, church. Also use Spanish [spa], withextensive stable bilingualism.

name: Kilivila
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng] (Senft 2010).Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially elderly (Senft 2010). Also use Dobu [dob]. Used as L2by Gumawana [gvs], Muyuw [myw].

name: Ga'anda
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Most also useHausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 byHwana [hwo], Lala-Roba [lla], Mboi [moi].

name: Kim Mun
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1983, experimental, used in China.
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Kadiwéu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Welaun
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. All also use Tetun [tet]. Some also use Kemak [kem]. Some also use Tetun Dili [tdt].

name: Awetí
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. A few also use Portuguese [por], mostly men(Crevels 2007). Also use Kamayurá [kay].

name: Muzi
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Kove
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from negative to neutral. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people and adults (Sato 2013). Some also use English [eng] (Sato 2013). Used as L2 by Anem [anz], Bariai [bch], Lusi [khl].

name: Beezen
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also useEnglish [eng], the language of instruction in school. Also use Jukun Takum [jbu], but with lowproficiency.

name: Zemba
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Fongoro
Language Use: Older adult speakers may remain living in isolated places. No remainingspeakers in Sudan. Shifted to Fur [fvr].

name: Garre
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Maay [ymm].

name: Hamer-Banna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1%. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Ongota [bxe], Tsamai[tsb].

name: Záparo
Language Development: Classes in 2 schools. Language revival effort (Crevels 2007).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Northern Pastaza Quichua [qvz].

name: Dewas Rai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15% in Nepali [npi]. Dictionary. Bible portions:1976–2019.
Language Use: Use decreasing among children in some areas (2017 SIL). Home, friends;Mixed use: work, religion, community. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Mostalso use Nepali [npi].

name: Mnong, Eastern
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1977.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Lamaholot
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: The area around Larantuka is multiethnic and some people have shifted to Kupang Malay [mkn] (Florey 2005). Used as language of wider communication. Used as L2 by Adonara [adr], Alor [aol], Ile Ape [ila], Labalekan-Mingar [lmj], Lamalera [lmr], Lamatuka [lmq], Levuka [lvu], Lewoeleng [lwe], Lewotobi [lwt], Painara [lmf].

name: Önge
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Blackfoot
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],no longer in use.
Language Development: Efforts in some reserve schools to promote knowledge and use of Blackfoot.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1890–1980.
Language Use: Some traditional ceremonies. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting toEnglish [eng]. Also use Plains Cree [crk].

name: Yonggom
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. NT: 2004.
Language Use: All domains except in church, where there is mixed use with other languages. Used by all. Some also use English [eng], especially young people. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Ninggerum [nxr].

name: Bayungu
Language Development: Dictionary. Hazel Walgar and Bernie Ryder have worked with the Wangka MayaPilbara Aboriginal Language Centre to produce Bayungu language materials, including a Bayungulanguage course for year 9 students.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nyika (Malawi and Zambia)
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Low German; Low Saxon
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1478–1534.
Language Use: Officially recognized as a regional (separate) language in 8 states of Germany. Recognized as a regional (separate) language by the European Charter on Languages. Adults only. Shifting to Standard German [deu]. Used as L2 by Northern Frisian [frr].

name: Kiorr
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Miwok, Southern Sierra
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Oro
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Efik [efi]. Also use Ibibio [ibb].

name: Kugbo
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Lambya
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2016.

name: Tsum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% or less. Taught as subject in a few primary schools.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Nepali [npi], as language of education and with those who do not understand Tsum. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], in religious domain.

name: Karata
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava], as a literary language. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Nupe-Nupe-Tako
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1953–1989.
Language Use: Regionally important language. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Asu [aum], Basa [bzw].

name: Luang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kisar [kje]. Also use Leti [lti].

name: Nkongho
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use English [eng], especially for the Nkongho who live in South West Region. Some also use French [fra], especially for the Nkongho who live in Littoral Region.

name: Timucua
Writing: Latin script [Latn], dating from 17th century, developed by Franciscan missionaries, mostly for religious purposes.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Sierra Leone Sign Language
Language Development: Agency: Salone Deaf Pipul Dem Association (Sierra Leone Association of the Deaf).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Tremembé
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Dong, Northern
Writing: Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, used since 1981, experimental,small-scale use in education and literature.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 55%. Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Also use Mandarin Chinese[cmn]. Used as L2 by Pa-Hng [pha], Southern Dong [kmc].

name: Hõne
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15% in Hausa [hau] or English [eng]. Motivation toread is high. Grammar.
Language Use: In remote settlements, some children may still learn the language as L1(Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). Home. Adults only. Negative attitudes. Shifting to Hausa [hau].Also use Bole [bol]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Jiba [juo]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde[fuv]. Also use Pero [pip]. Also use Tangale [tan]. Used as L2 by Jiba [juo].

name: Kagoro
Language Use: Being replaced by Bambara. Kagoro now spoken only in a few corners of Kaarta. Also use Bamanankan [bam]. Also use Soninke [snk].

name: Louisiana Creole French
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Ongoing revitalization through online programs and resources producing a handful of competent L2 speakers (2021 N. Wendte).
Language Use: Those over 60 prefer Creole, and those under 30 prefer English [eng]. Older adults only. Many shifted to English [eng].

name: Basa (Nigeria)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Also use Igala [igl]. Also use Nupe-Nupe-Tako [nup].

name: Namibian Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Dictionary. Agency: Centre for Communication and Deaf Studies, Namibian National Association of the Deaf.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng] (Mwondela 2005). Some also use Oshiwambo [kua] (Mwondela 2005).

name: Kungardutyi
Language Development: In 2017, Gunganndji/Kungardutyi and other language groups sentrepresentatives to the Indigenous Languages Residency, which provided the groups with resourcesto revive their languages.

name: Aleut, Mednyj
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Bodo Parja
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15% (2001 census). NT: 2020.
Language Use: Most also use Adivasi Oriya [ort], in the market. Also use English [eng],especially the youth.

name: Laal
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Bagirmi [bmi]. Used as L2 by Boor [bvf].

name: Nefamese
Language Use: Formerly a lingua franca of Arunachal Pradesh. Shifted to Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Apatani [apt], Bugun [bgg], Zakhring [zkr].

name: Memoni
Language Development: Most are highly educated.
Language Use: Adults only. Many shifting to Gujarati [guj]. Many shifting to Sindhi [snd]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Ottawa
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1841–1844.
Language Use: Dying out in many areas. Still vigorous on Manitoulin Island. Adults only. Most shifting to English [eng].

name: Lobi
Language Development: Used in adult literacy classes (2021 SIL). Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1965–1985.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Kaansa [gna], Malba Birifor [bfo], Téén [lor].

name: Bauni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. Bible portions: 2013–2018.
Language Use: People are very conscious of retaining the language and culture, as aresult of the 1998 tsunami (Corris 2005). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English[eng] (Corris 2005). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], in town and with outsiders (Corris 2005). Alsouse Uni [uni] (Miller 2017). Used as L2 by Uni [uni].

name: Wandarang
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Jibu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–3%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–7%. Few finishsecondary school. Texts. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Romani, Carpathian
Language Development: Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Slovak [slk].

name: Byep
Language Use: Most also use French [fra].

name: Pear
Language Use: All ethnic Pear learn Khmer [khm] first, while most learn to speak some Pear by the time they become adults (2011 E. Pawley). Older adults only. All shifted to Khmer [khm].

name: Karawa
Language Use: Pouye [bye] speakers consider Karawa [xrw] part of their language. Elderly only. Shifted to Pouye [bye]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bilua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT:1995.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Pijin [pis] (Obata 2003). Some also use Roviana[rug], especially older adults (Obata 2003). Also use English [eng].

name: Slovakian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Agency: Slovak Association of the Deaf (ANEPS).
Language Use: Deaf schools, associations, athletic clubs, theater group. Used by all.

name: Bishuo
Language Use: Shifted to Jukun Takum [jbu].

name: Soo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Negative attitudes. Most shifted to Ng’akarimojong [kdj]. Some shifted to Pökoot [pko].

name: Aekyom
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 1987.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Konai [kxw].

name: Kenyah, Sebob
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Sanga (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.

name: Yurok
Writing: Latin script [Latn], Unifon style has been widely employed in classroom teaching, but other orthographies are also in use (Golla 2007).
Language Development: Local school programs since the 1970s at the primary and secondary levels (Golla 2007). Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Yurok is taught in public schools in Humboldt and Del Norte counties, including five high schools (2013 L. Romney).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mang
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Ndwewe
Language Use: Home, community, business, traditional ceremonies. Some of all ages. Also use Ngindo [nnq]. Also use Pogolo [poy]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Achuar-Shiwiar
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:1981–2019.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Many also use Northern Pastaza Quichua [qvz]. Also useShuar [jiv]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Wè Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 1984–2010.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Nyabwa [nwb], Toura [neb].

name: Southwestern Bontok
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Ilocano [ilo]. Many also use Central Bontok [lbk]. Many also use Kankanaey [kne].

name: Boon
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Maay [ymm].

name: Puyuma
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], experimental usage.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1990.
Language Use: All domains. Older adults only. Mixed attitudes. The younger people have a negative attitude towards the language, while the older people have a much more positive attitude (Huteson 2005). Most shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Many also use Min Nan Chinese [nan] (Huteson 2005). Some also use Japanese [jpn], mostly older people (Teng 2008). Used as L2 by Rukai [dru].

name: Domaaki
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. Many shifted to Burushaski [bsk]. Many shifted to Shina[scl]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Mara
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Ngukurr Community Education Centre was running a language program in 2006. Mara is being taught at the Ngukurr Language Centre to children at the Early Learning Centre up to Grade 6 (2016).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Kisar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Luang [lex], Oirata [oia].

name: Gamilaraay
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Attempts are being made to restore an approximation to the original form (Wurm 2007). Extremely active revitalization movement in place. Language courses and an increasing flow of publications are evident (2015 I. Tupper).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Goo
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Lungga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Texts. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Kurudu
Language Use: Religious services. Some young people, all adults.

name: Mazatec, Huautla
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1961–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Mazatec is needed and used locally, but use Spanish [spa] for prestige. All domains. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], increasingly in Huautla de Jiménez city.

name: Idu-Mishmi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 55% (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, community, religion. Some young people, all adults. Positiveattitudes. Also use Assamese [asm], especially older people. Also use English [eng], especiallyeducated individuals. Also use Hindi [hin], especially younger people. Used as L2 by Khamba[kbg].

name: Aneme Wake
Language Use: Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Yareba [yrb].

name: Duguri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%.
Language Use: Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Hausa [hau] (Blench 2019).Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Biak
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1990.
Language Use: Only minor differences between dialects (van den Heuvel 2006). All also usePapuan Malay [pmy] (van den Heuvel 2006). Some also use Indonesian [ind] (van den Heuvel 2006).Used as L2 by Mapia [mpy].

name: Kinnauri, Chitkuli
Language Use: Home, cultural events. Used by all. All also use Hindi [hin] (Martinez2019). Most also use Kinnauri [kfk] (Martinez 2019).

name: Gureng Gureng
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Suena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Grammar. NT: 1978–2011.
Language Use: Yarawi reportedly spoke Suena from 1910 to 1978, but today may speak a dialect of Binandere [bhg] as L1 (2000). Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Yekora [ykr].

name: Buli (Indonesia)
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].

name: Koiari, Grass
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (Dutton 2003). Some young people, all adults. Alsouse English [eng] (Dutton 2003). Also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Dutton 2003). Also use Tok Pisin[tpi] (Dutton 2003).

name: Cishingini
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Dictionary. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 byBisã [bqp].

name: Yauma
Writing: Latin script [Latn], plans for future development using this script.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1978.

name: Baniwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1965–1985.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Argentine Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Confederación Argentina de Sordos(CAS).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. A few also use Spanish [spa]. Most deaf aremonolingual in LSA, having basic familiarity with Spanish but functionally illiterate (Massone1995).

name: Thao
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Cocopa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1972.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Trinidad and Tobago Sign Language
Language Use: Used by all. Also use American Sign Language [ase].

name: Mixe, Quetzaltepec
Language Development: Bible: 2013.

name: Takelma
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Molengue
Writing: Unwritten [Qaax], projected development of Latin orthography in 2012.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 0%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults, decreasing in younger generation (2011 SIL).Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa]. Also use Fang [fan].

name: Miwok, Central Sierra
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Dugwor
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, traditional ceremonies, church, market. Used byall. Positive attitudes. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use French [fra].

name: Duupa
Writing: Latin script [Latn], status of usage uncertain.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1982.
Language Use: Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Sumbwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Rawat
Language Development: Younger generation taking interest in literacy.
Language Use: All speakers use a highly mixed variety. Due to poor socio-economic status,miniscule number of speakers, fewer domains of language use, attitude of the dominant group andlack of initiative from the state, Rawat is quickly assimilating into Kumaoni [kfy] (Rastogi2006). Home, religion. Negative attitudes. Shifting to Kumaoni [kfy] (Rastogi 2006).

name: Aiklep
Language Use: Used as L2 by Ambul [apo].

name: Boma
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Tlapanec, Azoyú
Language Use: Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Callawalla
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Ostensibly a specialized language used by successors to the herb doctors ofInca emperors. Probably extinct. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Napu
Language Development: High interest in Napu literature. Dictionary. NT: 2000–2016.
Language Use: 60% of parents pass it on to the children. Young people tend to use Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Some domains, hymns, work announcements. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).

name: Savosavo
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1978, limited usage.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Declining use among younger generation, shifting to Pijin [pis] and English [eng] (Wurm 2007). Used by all. Also use Pijin [pis].

name: Carijona
Language Development: Some interest in literacy. Texts.
Language Use: Intermarry with other tribes. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Ngayawung
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Inga, Jungle
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tiri
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra].

name: Seget
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Indonesian [ind], as the language of instruction at school, church, and other formal settings.

name: Lau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1929–1992.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Fataleka [far].

name: Sou
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Mazahua Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 35%. Dictionary. NT: 1970–2007.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Korubo
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Portuguese [por].

name: Wangkumara
Language Development: Dictionary. Revitalization program is underway.

name: Sea Island Creole English
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Governmentbilingual education program begun. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng].

name: Anjam
Language Development: Vernacular literacy is not widespread. NT: 2000–2014.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Wampanoag
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1663–1685. Wôpanâak Language Reclamation Project has certified 12 adult L2 speakers as language teachers who teach a year-round language class for 20 preschool and kindergarten students as well as enrichment activities in local elementary schools and a credit-bearing class at the local public high school. In Mashpee, WLRP offers elders-only classes twice a week and a weekly community class (2019 WLRP). Agency: Wôpanâak Language Reclamation Project (WLRP).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ganggalida
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tingui-Boto
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Lembak
Language Development: Literacy valued in Indonesian.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Musi [mui]. Some also use Central Malay [pse].

name: Pamosu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: Low in Tok Pisin [tpi] andEnglish [eng] (Tupper 2012). Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, church, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Mostalso use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Tupper 2012). Some also use Pal [abw], especially the older generation(Tupper 2012). A few also use English [eng] (Tupper 2012).

name: Bankagooma
Language Use: Bankagooma no longer spoken in several towns, where the people now speakBambara [bam]. A few villages are still stable. Used by all. Also use Bamanankan [bam].

name: Arabic, Judeo-Iraqi
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Hebrew [heb].

name: Caluyanun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 67%. Literacy rate in L2: 67%. Occasional use inprimary and secondary schools. NT: 1990–2018.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Hiligaynon[hil]. All also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Yabarana
Language Use: The ethnic group has been partially assimilated by the Piaroa [pid] (Crevels 2007). Shifted to Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Piaroa [pid].

name: Yagomi
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Muratayak [asx]. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Sikule
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Indonesian [ind], with some youth using it as an L1 in Leukon dialect.

name: Tengger
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Many also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Javanese [jav].

name: Phong-Kniang
Language Development: Many are educated.
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Tavoyan
Writing: Unwritten [Qaax], informal and non-standardized use of Myanmar script.
Language Use: Vigorous. All except formal domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Norwegian Sign Language
Language Development: British Sign Language [bfi], English [eng] and Norwegian [nor] taught as foreign languages starting in 1997 (2005 P. Pritchard). TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2004. Agency: Norwegian Association of the Deaf (NDF).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used since 1815. First deaf school in 1825; first deaf club in 1878. Interpreters required in court, provided some for college students, and mental health programs. Instruction provided for parents of deaf children. Many classes for hearing people. Committee on national sign language. Deaf associations. Used by all.

name: Djinang
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1985–1987.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng]. Also useBurarra [bvr], especially by Wulaki dialect speakers. Also use Dhuwal [dwu]. Also useDjambarrpuyngu [djr]. Also use Djinba [djb]. Also use Gupapuyngu [guf]. Used as L2 by Djinba[djb].

name: Nyulnyul
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Liv(onian)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1942. Agency: Mazirbe Livonian Society.
Language Use: Shifted to Standard Latvian [lvs].

name: Bajau, Indonesian
Language Development: Radio. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous in north Maluku and Southeast Sulawesi. Some of all ages. Also useBalantak [blz]. Also use Bugis [bug]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Tukang Besi North[khc]. Also use Tukang Besi South [bhq]. Also use Wawonii [wow]. Used as L2 by Tukang Besi North[khc], Tukang Besi South [bhq].

name: Batek
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Malay [zlm]. Also use Temiar [tea](Bradley 2007a). Used as L2 by Mintil [mzt].

name: Semaq Beri
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Lonwolwol
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1899–1949.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Bislama [bis].

name: Holiya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Kannada [kan]. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan].

name: Tanaina
Language Development: Orthography developed in the 1970s. Dictionary.
Language Use: Kenai dialect nearly extinct (Golla 2007). Adults only. Most shifting to English [eng].

name: Kusunda
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Nepali [npi].

name: Arhö
Language Use: Shifted to Ajië [aji].

name: Miriwung
Language Development: Grammar. Mirima Dawang Woorlab-Gerring Language and Culture Centre has The Miriwoong Language Nest program for teaching children the language and Miriwoong Language Classes for the Community.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007).

name: A'tong
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, village. Some of all ages. Also use Garo [grt] (Van Breugel 2014).Also use Bengali [ben], with good proficiency. Used as L2 by Megam [mef].

name: Penang Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Up to 50% in English [eng].
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Malaysian Sign Language [xml]. Many also use English [eng], in written form. Used as L2 by Selangor Sign Language [kgi].

name: Haiphong Sign Language
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Alutor
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. Middle-aged adults are passive bilinguals; younger than35 use only Russian [rus] (1997). Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Futuna-Aniwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1898.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Moere
Language Use: Shifting to Brem [buq] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Teke-Tyee
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 2010–2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Nicobarese, Central
LITERACY_L2: 46% for Scheduled Tribes in Nicobar District.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 46% for Scheduled Tribes in Nicobar District. 72% for Nicobar (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1884–1890.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Tuscarora
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: No revitalization activities reported (Golla 2007). Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Karen, Yinbaw
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Udihe
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus] (Salminen 2007).

name: Kimaragang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 85% in Standard Malay [zsm]. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1996. Agency: Persatuan Kimaragang Sabah Bersatu, Pertubuhan Kimaragang Malaysia.
Language Use: Children don’t learn it in many areas, at least not well. Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Some young people, all adults. Some children and adults; all elderly. Mixed attitudes. Most also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Rungus [drg]. Used as L2 by Kota Marudu Talantang [grm], Rungus [drg], Tombonuo [txa].

name: Matukar
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Only about 25 speakers, all older adults, use Matukar Panau [mjk] regularly; all other speakers primarily use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Barth et al 2020). Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use Awad Bing [bcu] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use Bargam [mlp] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use English [eng] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use Gedaged [gdd] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use Manam [mva] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use Takia [tbc] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use Waskia [wsk] (Barth et al 2020). Some also use Yoidik [ydk] (Barth et al 2020). Used as L2 by Bargam [mlp].

name: Mombum
Language Use: Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Nahuatl, Michoacán
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10% (mainly children). Literacy rate in L2: 35%. Not preferred for written communication. Texts. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Mixed attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Poke
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1923.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Baelelea
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Pomo, Southeastern
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Uvean, West
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1903.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Iaai [iai].

name: Agta, Villa Viciosa
Language Use: Shifted to Ilocano [ilo].

name: Tanguat
Language Development: Bible portions: 2015–2019.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Naga, Thangal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Meitei [mni], English [eng]. Dictionary. NT: 2004–2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni].

name: Sanga (Nigeria)
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Lemoro [ldj].

name: Anus
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Influence from Kwesten [kwt] on the oppositecoast and from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Most domains. Many shifting to Indonesian [ind].Many shifting to Kwesten [kwt]. Used as L2 by Fedan [pdn], Keijar [kdy].

name: Mainfränkisch
Language Development: Bible portions: 1992.
Language Use: Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Venezuelan Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Agencies: Asociación de Sordomudos de Caracas; Federación Venezolana de Sordos.
Language Use: Schools for the deaf since 1937 which use sign language. Deaf people attend college with a sign language interpreter. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], due to national bilingual education program.

name: Kande
Language Use: Shifted to French [fra].

name: Nyam
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Guruntum-Mbaaru
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Yotti
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mumuye [mzm]. Also use Yendang [ynq].

name: Chaudangsi
Language Development: Hindi [hin] used for written communication.
Language Use: Home, community. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Alsouse Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Kumaoni [kfy].Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Kambera
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1995.

name: Júma
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 2004.

name: Karo (Ethiopia)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Nyangatom [nnj].

name: Namuyi
Language Development: Generally better educated than Yi or Tibetan peoples. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Adults born before 1955 use Namuyi with each other. Younger people appear to know Namuyi well, but prefer to converse in Nuosu [iii] or Chinese. Positive attitudes. Some also use Lipo [lpo]. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Some also use Northern Pumi [pmi]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Ersu [ers].

name: Chinantec, Lalana
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1974–2012.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Karey
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Yi, Central (Lolopo)
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Lamu [llh].

name: Awera
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Unubahe
Language Use: Elderly only. All shifted to Haigwai [hgw]. Also use English [eng].

name: Dagaari Dioula
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some also use Moore [mos], particularly in some western areas. Also useJula [dyu], especially some men (and women, but with lower proficiency) west of the Mouhounriver.

name: Ngarinman
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Middle-aged speakers generally code-switch between Bilinarra and Kriol [rop] (Meakins and Nordlinger 2014). Shifted to English [eng]. Also use Kriol [rop]. Used as L2 by Djamindjung [djd].

name: Karagas
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Kanauji
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% (2001 census). NT: 1821.
Language Use: Shifting to Hindi [hin]. In urban areas, almost replaced by Hindi [hin],while in rural areas, Kanauji is still functional (Dwivedi and Kar 2016). Various domains. Someyoung people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Most also use Hindi [hin], the less-educatedhaving lower proficiency. Also use English [eng].

name: Ukhwejo
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Piu
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon; 2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from surrounding Mumeng languages and Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Frisian, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Few read Frisian. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bibleportions: 1954.
Language Use: Home. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Standard German [deu].Also use English [eng]. Also use Low Saxon [nds].

name: Zapotec, Choapan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1986–2010.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Gbagyi
LITERACY_L2: 60% or higher, depending on the L2.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% or higher, depending on the L2. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1956.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events, Technologyand media. Some of all ages. All also use English [eng]. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm].Many also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Gade [ged], Koro Zuba [vkz], Rjili [uji].

name: Mal Paharia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 13% male, 3% female, average 8% (1981). Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Positive attitudes. Some also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng].

name: Dida, Lakota
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Ega [ega], Gban [ggu].

name: Nahuatl, Tenango
Language Use: Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Younger population less positive in some villages. Most also use Spanish [spa], but more comfortable in Nahuatl.

name: Burji
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 29%. Taught as subject in some primary schools ingrades 1–4. Offered at Teacher Training College as a major. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1993.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Many in Ethiopia are older adults. Also use Amharic[amh].

name: Zapotec, Quiavicuzas
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sepen
Language Development: Bible portions: 2003–2010.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Some also use Aruamu [msy] (Weatherhead 2020). Some also use Kire [geb] (Weatherhead 2020).

name: Pitjantjatjara
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–70%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%–15%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Pintiini [pti], Yankunytjatjara [kdd].

name: Asuriní
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions:1973–1979.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Portuguese [por], adults fluently; children almostexclusively (Crevels 2007).

name: Okanagan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Substantial revitalization efforts (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Adults only. Many shifting to English [eng].

name: Tawbuid, Western
Language Development: Bible: 2021.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Filipino [fil].

name: Tuyuca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2004–2011.
Language Use: Some of all ages. All also use Spanish [spa], especially in schools. All also use Tucano [tuo]. All also use Waimaha [bao]. Used as L2 by Waimaha [bao].

name: Xiang Chinese
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant[Hant].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate inChinese, and they use that literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Wasco-Wishram
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. A revitalization project was started at Warm Springs in 1992, and it was still active as of 2012 (2012 R. Moore).
Language Use: Kathlamet and Clackamas dialects were last spoken in the 1930s (Mithun 1999). All shifted to English [eng].

name: Tutchone, Northern
Language Development: Dictionary. Literacy workshops since 1984. School language programs in Mayo, Pelly Crossing and Carmacks since 1990 (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mayaguduna
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Banda, South Central
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Angor
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Declining within Samanai dialect. Some young people, all adults. Also useTok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Amanab [amn].

name: Bhaya
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Pévé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1986.

name: Burarra
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Djinang [dji], Gurr-goni [gge],Na-kara [nck], Yan-nhangu [jay].

name: Lutos
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag]. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu], particularly among the Ndokoa speakers (Moéhama 2021).

name: Dijim-Bwilim
Language Development: Bible portions: 2008.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Centúúm [cet].

name: Banda-Ndélé
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Dení
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1982.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Sangu (Gabon)
Language Development: Bible portions: 1943–1959.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kélé [keb].

name: Rerep
Language Development: Bible portions: 1892–1913.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Banda-Banda
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All also use Sango [sag].

name: Zoque, Copainalá
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1967.

name: Burate
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Ap Ma
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1990–2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Pondi [lnm], Ulwa[yla].

name: Marovo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Bible: 1956.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Dughore [nke], Hoava [hoa], Touo [tqu], Vangunu [mpr].

name: Bushi
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Hema
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Katkari
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Also use English [eng]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Chinantec, Palantla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1973.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Ozumacín Chinantec [chz].

name: Musasa
Language Use: Also use Nepali [npi], with high proficiency.

name: Karingani
Language Use: Shifting to South Azerbaijani [azb].

name: Dhuwaya
Language Development: Dhuwaya is used as the language of instruction up to grade 4 in thebilingual program at Yirrkala School (Amery 1993:61). Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Dhuwaya has evolved as the Yirrkala communilect or common language spokenby all of the younger generation irrespective of clan membership (Amery 1993). Most also useEnglish [eng].

name: Phola
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Lishán Didán
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1986–1988.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Hebrew [heb], some due to intermarriage.

name: Horpa
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Many alsouse Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. A few also use Central Tibetan [bod].

name: Tuma-Irumu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. NT: 1997–2011.
Language Use: Also use Kâte [kmg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Tause
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Indonesian [ind]. Orthography and literacy materials, but no native authored texts. Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Home, Community, Education, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Some also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Fayu [fau].

name: Chayahuita
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Texts.NT: 1978–2011.
Language Use: Bilingual education in some communities (Crevels 2007). Used by all. Alsouse Spanish [spa].

name: Kaur
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Workplace, Education, Religion, Special cultural events, Technology and media. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Namakura
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible portions: 2005.

name: Nda'nda'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Fe’fe’ [fmp], Medumba [byv].

name: Saterland Frisian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in German [deu]. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Adults only, mostly middle-aged or older (Salminen 2007). Shifting to Standard German [deu]. Also use East Frisian Low Saxon [frs].

name: Konkani, Goan
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], official usage. Kannada script [Knda]. Latinscript [Latn].
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Konkani [knn].

name: Bankon
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra]. Some also useCameroon Pidgin [wes]. A few also use Duala [dua]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Tanana, Upper
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1970–1982.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to English [eng]. Used as L2 by Tanacross [tcb].

name: Awabakal
Language Development: Bible portions: 1891. Long extinct, but there are attempts at revival (Wurm2007). Awabakal Cultural Resource Association is doing revival work, and Many Rivers AboriginalLanguage Center is running the Awabakal and Wonnarua (HRLM) Language Revitalization program(2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tsakwambo
Language Use: Home.

name: Bidyara
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Gbanziri
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All also use Sango [sag].

name: Ghera
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Sindhi [snd].
Language Use: Also use Sindhi [snd]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Biri
Language Development: Revitalization efforts (Wurm 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ona
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Now speak Spanish [spa].

name: Nahuatl, Guerrero
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. NT: 1987–2016.

name: Guiqiong
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Only in the village with their own people. Some young people, all adults.Children rarely use it. Negative attitudes. All also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Kw'adza
Language Use: Shifted to Gogo [gog].

name: Trió
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1979.
Language Use: All domains, except education. Used by all. Very positive attitudes though not considered appropriate as subject in school. Also use Dutch [nld]. Used as L2 by Akurio [ako], Mawayana [mzx], Sikiana [sik], Waiwai [waw].

name: Gagu
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1970.
Language Use: Also use Bete [byf]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Guro [goa]. Also useJula [dyu]. Also use Lakota Dida [dic].

name: Naga, Mzieme
Language Development: Bible: 1992.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Goundo
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Kabalai [kvf]. Also use Nancere [nnc].

name: Musgu
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Some also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Some also use Giziga [giz]. Some also use Tupuri [tui]. A few also use Afade [aal]. A few also use Yerwa Kanuri [knc]. Used as L2 by Masana [mcn], Tupuri [tui].

name: Wanggom
Language Use: Home.

name: Yidiny
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ong
Language Use: Shifting to Lao [lao].

name: French Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2011. Agency:National Federation for the Deaf of France (FNSF).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use French [fra].

name: Arabic (Moroccan)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1932–2023.
Language Use: Some also use French [fra]. Some also use Spanish [spa], in the north. Usedas L2 by Central Atlas Tamazight [tzm], Ghomara [gho], Judeo-Moroccan Arabic [aju], Spanish[spa], Tachelhit [shi], Tarifit [rif], Taznatit [grr].

name: Molale
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Iquito
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1963–2002.Moribund, but revitalization efforts in progress (2015 L. Michael).
Language Use: Elderly only. Negative attitudes. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Mintil
Language Use: Many shifted to Batek [btq]. Many shifted to Malay [zlm].

name: Ngaing
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 60% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Bible portions: 2004–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], increasingly. Also use Gedaged [gdd]. Also use Rempi [rmp]. Also use Wagi [fad].

name: Israeli Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2020. Agency: The Institute for theAdvancement of Deaf Persons in Israel.
Language Use: Vigorous. Interpreters provided in courts, and free for up to 45 hours peryear. Some interpretation for college students. ISL instruction for deaf immigrants, parents ofdeaf children, other hearing people. Organization for sign language teachers. Used by all. Alsouse Hebrew [heb] (Meir and Sandler 2008). Used as L2 by Algerian Jewish Sign Language [ajs],Al-Sayyid Bedouin Sign Language [syy], Kufr Qassem Sign Language [sqx], Russian Sign Language[rsl].

name: Lachi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Continue to use the language. Also use Yue Chinese [yue].

name: Awyu (Central)
Language Development: Bible portions: 1985.
Language Use: Most domains. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Sikaritai
Language Development: Bible portions: 1992.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Giangan
Language Use: Shifting to Cebuano [ceb], but with marginal bilingual ability.

name: Vitou
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Kélé
Language Development: Bible portions: 1855–1879.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra]. Also use Sangu [snq]. Also use Sira [swj]. Alsouse Tsogo [tsv].

name: Tii
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kupang Malay [mkn].

name: Birgit
Language Use: Strong in its central village Abgué, decreasing in Agrab and Tilegeye(Eastern Birgit). Probably strong in Duguri due to geographical isolation.

name: Bete-Bendi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also useNigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Used as L2 by Abanglekuo [bzy], Bukpe [ukp], Elege [alf], Ubang [uba].

name: Degema
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Pahanan Agta
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Home, church, village meetings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Filipino [fil]. Some also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Cree (Woods)
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],uses western finals.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar.
Language Use: All also use English [eng].

name: Masela, East
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Mongondow
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Mixed in Home, Community and Work. Some of all ages. Neutral attitudes. All also use Manado Malay [xmm]. Some also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Lolak [llq].

name: Ignaciano
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1980.
Language Use: Rapid loss of language among the youth (Crevels 2007). Most domains, townmeetings. Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa], the language of instruction in schools.

name: Bru, Western
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2007–2015.
Language Use: Most also use Lao [lao].

name: Burmeso
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Not spoken by outsiders. All domains. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Pogolo
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Ndwewe [nww].

name: Olkol
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. The Olkola Aboriginal Corporation started the Olkol Language Revival Project with assistance from the Pama Language Centre in 2016.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Titan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Lenkau [ler], Lou [loj], Neherneh [ncn], Paluai [blq], Penchal [pek], Tulu-Bohuai [rak].

name: Quileute
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Language education program was begun in the 1970s (Golla 2007). In 2007, the Quileute tribal council set up a two-year Quileute Revitalization Project.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mangbetu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2006–2007.
