Language Use: Many also use Bangala [bxg], but a few have low proficiency. Also use Congo Swahili [swc], especially Popoi and Aberu dialect speakers. Used as L2 by Asoa [asv], Lika [lik], Ngbee [jgb].

name: Thurawal
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Revitalization efforts taking place.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Zapotec, Amatlán
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. A few Spanish speakers who live there can speak it. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Fluency in Spanish [spa] has increased, but Zapotec is preferred. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Oirata
Language Use: Shifting to Kisar [kje], on Kisar island.

name: Ojibwa, Eastern
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Concerted effort via language teaching in public schools and other efforts to reverse decline.
Language Use: Dying out in many areas. All also use English [eng].

name: Chatino, Zenzontepec
Language Development: Videos. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Western Highland Chatino [ctp].

name: Zari
Language Development: The Oral Bible Storying (OBS) project has been key to revitalization efforts in the Zakshi dialect (2021 L. Rose).
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Shanenawa
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Xetá
Language Use: Shifted to Kaingang [kgp].

name: Tiruray
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 49%. Literacy rate in L2: 49%. Dictionary. NT: 1983–2002.
Language Use: Also use Cotabato Manobo [mta].

name: Sarli
Language Use: Shifting to Central Kurdish [ckb].

name: Shasta
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Revitalization efforts are underway.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ndambomo
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra].

name: Siwi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Egyptian Arabic [arz].

name: Tebul Sign Language
Language Use: Family and community members in Koro and Douentza Cercles use signing to communicate with the deaf.

name: Turks And Caicos Creole English
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Creole forms a continuum with English, which is in the process of decreolization.

name: Tiwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 62% for Assam (2001 census). Literacy rate higher in the plains. In the hills, equally low among men and women. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Quite a few in Brahmaputra valley adopted Assamese [asm] as L1. Resurgent interest to learn the mother tongue; approved by the state in 2004 to be taught as a subject up to class 4. Home, market. Some of all ages. Many also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng].

name: Slavey, South
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1891.
Language Use: Older people still use South Slavey in smaller, isolated communities; serious attrition among children and young people. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Seychelles Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Tunia
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Perim dialect is extinct. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Niellim [nie]. Also use Sar [mwm].

name: Malay, Jambi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: As with many Malay varieties, gradually becoming more like Indonesian[ind]. Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kaduo
Writing: Miao (Pollard) script [Plrd], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Some in Chinese. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Most also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Kunigami
Language Use: Those under 20 are mainly monolingual in Japanese (1989 T. Fukuda). Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Boguru
Language Use: Shifted to Zande [zne].

name: Galoli
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Hozo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Orthography and comprehensive dictionary underdevelopment; first reading books in provisional orthography (2023 K. Küspert). Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Adults only. Shifting to West Central Oromo [gaz], especially aseducation contributes to increased assimilation to Oromo, encouraged by local government(Küspert 2015). Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use Seze [sze], especially in areas where speakersof Hozo live intermixed with speakers of Seze [sze]. Frequent intermarriage between speakers ofHozo and Seze. Also use Standard Arabic [arb], with restricted use. Used as L2 by Seze [sze].

name: Tiv
Language Development: Taught as subject in most primary and secondary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1964–2017.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Abanglekuo [bzy], Yace [ekr].

name: Qimant
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%. Grammar. Bible portions: 1885.
Language Use: Qwara dialect has no remaining speakers. 170,747 ethnic Qimant aremonolingual in Amharic [amh]. All shifted to Amharic [amh]. Also use Hebrew [heb], a few wordsin prayer.

name: Gbiri-Niragu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Hausa [hau], 50% in English [eng]. Bibleportions: 2019.
Language Use: Youth increasingly use Hausa [hau]. Home, neighborhood. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Also use English [eng].

name: Chehalis, Upper
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kua-nsi
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Cupeño
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Resources for revitalization are being developed throughlinguistic research by the Limu Project (2017).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sehwi
Language Development: Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka].

name: Tairora, South
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. NT: 1994–2000.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Vincent and Kaave 2010).

name: Yi, Limi
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Balaesang
Language Use: Endangered in all communities (Florey 2005). Shifting to Indonesian [ind],which is the preference of the younger generation (Wurm 2007).

name: Mbo (Cameroon)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Grammar.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra]. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use Duala [dua]. A few also use Fe’fe’ [fmp]. A few also use Yemba [ybb]. Used as L2 by Akoose [bss], Fe’fe’ [fmp].

name: Nahuatl, Tetelcingo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1980.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Palikúr
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Dictionary. NT: 1982–2014.
Language Use: Strong vitality. Most also use Portuguese [por], especially the majority of educated youth (Crevels 2007). Many also use Karipuna French Creole [kmv] (Crevels 2007).

name: Palor
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% in French [fra], 10% in Wolof [wol]. Literacyactivities. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Wolof [wol], ininterethnic situations but a number also among themselves. Some villages north of the nationalroad have shifted to Wolof (Thornell et al 2017). Many also use Saafi-Saafi [sav] (Thornell etal 2017). Also use French [fra], mainly in official domains (Thornell et al 2017). Used as L2 bySaafi-Saafi [sav].

name: Moklen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Thai [tha]. Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Most also use Thai [tha], except some adults (Larish 2005).

name: Orang Kanaq
Language Use: Shifted to Malay [zlm].

name: Lucumi
Language Use: Secret language used for ritual by Santeria religion.

name: Paluan
Language Use: Also use Tahol Murut [mvv]. Used as L2 by Keningau Murut [kxi].

name: Macushi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Most still speak the language (Crevels 2007). Most also use Portuguese [por], increasingly.

name: Quechua, Lambayeque
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005–2008.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Laimbue
Language Use: Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use Aghem [agq], especially those in Wum Central Subdivision. Also use Kom [bkm].

name: Naga, Yimchungru
Language Development: Bible: 2007.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Amami Koniya Sign Language
Language Use: Centered around one family with several deaf members, with their friends,neighbors, and associates (2020 Y. Osugi). Older adults only.

name: Tepehua, Tlachichilco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Grammar. NT: 2003–2009.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tanna, North
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught as subject in some primary schools in grades 1–3. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Also use Bislama [bis], but many women and some men do not understand it.

name: Mali
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Stebbins andTayul 2012). Used as L2 by Simbali [smg].

name: Taita
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–70% in Kiswahili[swh]. Kiswahili [swh] used as language of instruction. Grammar. Bible: 1998.
Language Use: Home, social gatherings, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Alsouse Swahili [swh].

name: Qiang, Northern
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1990, revised in 1991 and 1993.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 100%. Men are more literate than women. Those under 30are fairly literate in Chinese. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Parents encourage children to excel in school, which means learningMandarin Chinese [cmn] well. Some use Qiang at home. Home. Adults only. Negative attitudes.Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Written Chinese used. Used as L2 by Jiarong [jya].

name: Nkonya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2010–2017.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka]. Also use Éwé [ewe].

name: Ullatan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 72–82% (2001 census).
Language Use: Shifted to Malayalam [mal].

name: Yakamul
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Aruek [aur].

name: Gavião Do Jiparaná
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1988.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Portuguese [por].

name: Mufian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Filifita 15%–25%; Mufian: 15%–25%. Literacy rate inL2: Filifita 50%–75%; Mufian 50%–75%. Texts. NT: 1988–1998.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Dobrin 2014).

name: Tsaangi
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Dyarim
Language Use: Home, community; Mixed use: cultural events. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker and Araokanmi 2022). Many also use Nigerian Fulfulde[fuv] (Decker and Araokanmi 2022). Some also use English [eng] (Decker and Araokanmi 2022).

name: Nyemba
Language Development: Bible portions: 1955.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Northwestern !Kung [vaj].

name: Adamorobe Sign Language
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used in most village contexts by both deaf and hearing, but beginning to bereplaced by Ghanaian SL [gse] in some domains, e.g. in church services (2019 M Edward). Used byall, deaf and many hearing. Also use Akan [aka], spoken by hearing people (Nyst 2007). Also useGhanaian Sign Language [gse], as primary language among younger deaf, learned in a deaf boardingschool (Nyst 2007). Used as L2 by Akan [aka].

name: Nen
Language Use: Those marrying into the village usually learn Nen (Evans 2015). Used by all. Most also use Idi [idi] (Evans 2015). Most also use Nambo [ncm] (Evans 2015). Many also use English [eng], especially young people and middle-aged adults (Evans 2015). Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially elderly (Evans 2015). A few also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Evans 2015). Used as L2 by Idi [idi], Nambo [ncm].

name: Kairiru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Plains Indian Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by deaf people with family and friends as a primary sign language, more elaborate than its use as a lingua franca (an ‘alternative sign language’) (McKay-Cody 1996). Elderly only. Those who use it are widely scattered. Shifted to American Sign Language [ase].

name: Kayagar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% somewhat literate in Indonesian [ind].
Language Use: Home, work. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Atohwaim [aqm].

name: Yitha Yitha
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bumthangkha
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1938.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Khengkha [xkf].

name: Ndengereko
Language Use: Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Thaypan
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Gudanji
Language Use: Shifted to Wambaya [wmb].

name: Roglai, Southern
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Potentially endangered by Vietnamese [vie] (Bradley 2007a). Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Tlapanec, Acatepec
Language Development: Community resistance to use of primary school materials in L1. Many bilingual school teachers from Malinaltepec. Bible portions: 2015–2023.

name: Githabul
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. In 2013, the Condamine Alliance Languages Project wassupporting language revival for Githabul and other language groups found near the CondamineRiver.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yaleba
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Suau [swp], especially people in Gwaugulina village who are shifting to it. Some also use Tawala [tbo]. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also use Buhutu [bxh]. A few also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially elderly.

name: Kituba (Congo)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Beembe [beq], Bwisi [bwz], Doondo [dde], Kaamba [xku], Kunyi [njx], Laari [ldi], Lumbu [lup], Punu [puu], Suundi [sdj], Teke-Laali [lli], Teke-Tsaayi [tyi], Teke-Tyee [tyx], Tsaangi [tsa], Vili [vif], Yaka [iyx], Yombe [yom].

name: Gupapuyngu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1967.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Gumatj [gnn], or otherAboriginal languages. Also use Djambarrpuyngu [djr], which is learned by children. Used as L2 byDjinang [dji], Gumatj [gnn], Yan-nhangu [jay].

name: Quichua, Loja Highland
Language Development: Only standardized or Unified Quichua is taught formally.
Language Use: Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Guarayu
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT:1985–2011.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Tee
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Gokana [gkn].

name: Emberá-Chamí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mambila, Cameroon
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education in NorthWest Region. Some also use French [fra], as language of education in Adamawa Region. Used as L2 by Yeni [yei].

name: Cacua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5% in Spanish [spa].Taught as subject in most primary schools. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2004–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Cubeo [cub]. Also use Desano [des]. Alsouse Spanish [spa]. Also use Wanano [gvc].

name: Tsimané
Writing: Latin script [Latn], not in use by Mosetén.
Language Development: Videos. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Young people and adults. Also use Spanish[spa], especially children who attend school in one of the highland communities. Other childrendo not acquire it until they are 15 years of age. Women and older people speak very little of it(Crevels 2007).

name: Ashéninka Perené
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 55%. Grammar. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sanglechi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Dari [prs], exclusively in education, administration, media, travel, and trade, but only men have access to these domains.

name: Surbakhal
Language Use: Also use Maba [mde]. Also use Masalit [mls].

name: Tawoyan
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1985.

name: Chachi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Elders and preschool-aged children are mostly monolingual (Crevels 2007).Also use Spanish [spa], but women, older adults, and those living in the isolated headwaters ofthe river are less bilingual in it.

name: Ngelima
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Boone and Olson 2004).

name: Quichua, Cañar Highland
Language Development: Texts. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Strong use of Quichua away from the road.

name: Jhankot Sign Language
Language Use: Reportedly used by deaf and hearing alike throughout the village.

name: Matengo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Little comprehension of other languages. Used by all. Used as L2 by Mpoto [mpa].

name: Label
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–70%. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Some of all ages, some children of immigrants do not learn Label, but learn Tok Pisin [tpi]. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Most also use Kandas [kqw]. Many also use Siar-Lak [sjr].

name: Sandawe
Language Development: Some literacy classes, but Sandawe is difficult to write; people prefer Swahili [swh]. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2006–2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes, but think Sandawe too difficult to read or write. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Pokomchí, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 21%–35%. Grammar. Bible: 2009. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Qꞌeqchiꞌ [kek]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nding
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Luimbi
Language Development: Bible portions: 1935.

name: Wolani
Language Development: Bible portions: 1984–1995.

name: Ngalakan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Kunda
Language Use: Most also use Shona [sna] (Hachipola 1998).

name: Miship
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religious settings, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau], used alongside Miship [mjs] in most domains (Decker et al 2021f). Many also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2021f). Used as L2 by Belning [glb], Jakattoe [jrt].

name: Fas
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1983.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, community, religion. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Honeyman 2016).

name: Buru (Indonesia)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1904–1998.
Language Use: Vigorous in most areas. Fogi dialect speakers apparently shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs]. All domains. Some of all ages. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs]. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Betaf
Language Use: Children more frequently use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Most domains. Some youngpeople, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Suwawa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Mixed: Home, Community, Work. Adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifting to Indonesian [ind], with some elements of Manado Malay [xmm]. Many also use Gorontalo [gor].

name: Balinese
Writing: Balinese script [Bali]. Javanese script [Java], no longer in use. Latinscript [Latn], used since early 20th century.
Language Development: Taught as subject in most primary schools through grade 6. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 1990.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Used as L2 by Balinese Malay [mhp], Kata Kolok[bqy].

name: Owa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Pwapwa
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Jawe [jaz], Yuanga [nua] and French [fra] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to French [fra].

name: Nyenkha
Language Use: Used as L2 by Khengkha [xkf].

name: Wusi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Bislama [bis].
Language Use: Home, Work; Mixed: Community, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Bislama [bis]. A few also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Oa [tmt].

name: Seneca
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1829–2011.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Parecís
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Most also use Portuguese [por].

name: Dendi (Central African Republic)
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: She
LITERACY_L2: 88% in any language for She nationality (2000 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 88% in any language for She nationality (2000 census). Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifting to Hakka Chinese [hak] (Bradley 2007a). Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Min Nan Chinese [nan].

name: Bamun
Writing: Bamum script [Bamu], taught in schools until 1930s. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Grammar. Texts. Bible:1988.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra], especially among the Bamun who live in theCentre and West Regions. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A few also use English [eng],especially among the Bamun who live in the NorthWest Region. A few also use Standard Arabic[arb]. Used as L2 by Ghomálá’ [bbj], Medumba [byv], Mengaka [xmg], Tikar [tik].

name: Pakanha
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ghanaian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2011–2014. Agency: Ghana National Associationof the Deaf.
Language Use: 9 deaf schools. Primary schools for deaf children since 1957. Sign languageinterpreters required in court. Used by all. Used as L2 by Adamorobe Sign Language [ads].

name: Ikizu
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2009–2021.
Language Use: Many shifting to Swahili [swh]. Home, field work, local gatherings (L1 ischoice when only Ikizu speakers present). Used by all.

name: Sechelt
Language Development: A few are literate. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Strong desire to revive the language. Taught in the local school (Golla 2007). Elderly only. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Kwerba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Bible portions: 1986–2001.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Samarokena [tmj].

name: Baga Koga
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Susu [sus].

name: Bebe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy program started in 2011. Schooling is inEnglish. Bible portions: 2014–2019.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cameroon Pidgin[wes]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Kemedzung [dmo]. Also use NigerianFulfulde [fuv]. Also use Sari [asj]. Also use Tigon Mbembe [nza]. Used as L2 by Kemedzung [dmo],Sari [asj], Tigon Mbembe [nza].

name: Pamona
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1933–2006.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Buang, Mangga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most speakers over 25 years old. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with most young people shifting. Used as L2 by Vehes [val].

name: Ashéninka, South Ucayali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%. NT: 2008–2015.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Akurio
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Trió [tri] (Crevels 2012).

name: Kwesten
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Anus [auq].

name: Narungga
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. In 2017, one primary school and three R-12 schools in South Australia were listed as offering a Narungga language program. Organizations involved in revitalization efforts include the Narungga Aboriginal Progress Association (NAPA), The Narungga Heritage Committee, the Narungga Language Retraining Program, and the Department of Education and Children’s Services (DECS). Agency: Narungga Aboriginal Progress Association.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Maragus
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Uripiv-Wala-Rano-Atchin [upv].

name: Alor
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Chewong
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Increasing exposure to Standard Malay [zsm], schooling in Standard Malayfor the children. Some young people, all adults. All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Mbangi
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: E
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], specifically the Guiliu dialect. Also useYue Chinese [yue].

name: Nande
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1980–1996.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bhele [bhy], Mvuba [mxh].

name: Maku'a
Language Use: Shifted to Fataluku [ddg] (Wurm 2007).

name: Bali Sign Language
Language Development: Starting 2007, a local elementary school uses Kata Kolok as a language ofinstruction in special math and literacy sections for deaf students (de Vos 2012). Taught inprimary schools. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous, by both deaf and hearing. All domains. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Many also use Bali [ban], especially in the village and among hearing native signers,who are fully bilingual (Marsaja 2008). Some also use Indonesian Sign Language [inl], which hasbeen acquired in boarding schools in Singaraja and Jimbaran by about 8 deaf teenagers (de Vos2016).

name: Pomo, Northern
Language Development: The California Indian Museum and Cultural Center (CIMCC) has a Northern Pomo Language Curriculum developed by a consultant available, as well as a language learning app that can be downloaded for free.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Hausa Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Varying levels of proficiency inHausa (Schmaling 2015). Some also use American Sign Language [ase]. ASL vocabulary taught inschools (Schmaling 2015). Some also use English [eng]. Schools use English with a TotalCommunication policy (Schmaling 2015).

name: Bakole
Language Use: Most shifted to Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Asobo 1989). Most shifted to French [fra]. Some also use Efik [efi] (Asobo 1989). Some also use Igbo [ibo] (Asobo 1989). Some also use Oroko [bdu] (Asobo 1989).

name: Lefa
Language Development: Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use French [fra], but rarely among themselves in the village setting. Most village children do not know French before entering school.

name: Ulch
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Traditional culture (funerals), oral ethnic storytelling, family. Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Tindi
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, community. Some young people, all adults, few child speakers (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava], as a literary language. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Bagvalal [kva].

name: Tariano
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Periquitos has strongest language use. Older adults only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Bakumpai
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Dusun Deyah [dun], Dusun Witu [duw], Lawangan [lbx], Ma’anyan[mhy].

name: Krahô
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Portuguese [por], all men and a growing number of women (Crevels 2007).

name: Ngamo
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2013.

name: Tsuvadi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Interest expressed in L1 literacy. Bible portions: 1997–2001.
Language Use: Used more in northern, more traditional part of language area. All domains except mosque. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use C’Lela [dri]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use ut-Hun [uth]. Used as L2 by Cicipu [awc].

name: Kpeego
Language Use: Highly bilingual in local languages and trade languages. Some young people,all adults. Children do not always grow up speaking Kpeego (2012 S. Showalter). Used as L2 byTurka [tuz].

name: Margany
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Atong
Language Use: Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Siane
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1991–1997.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Duli
Language Use: Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Besisi
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Most children are monolingual when they enter preschool at age four (Kruspe 2010). All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Guató
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Lega-Mwenga
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1957.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools.

name: Aushi
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Pattapu
Language Use: Home, workplace. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Pagi
Language Use: All domains except in church and with outsiders. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Dera (Nigeria)
Language Development: Many are educated. Most villages have primary schools. Grammar. Bible portions: 1937.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Bura-Pabir [bwr]. Also use Lala-Roba [lla]. Also use Longuda [lnu]. Used as L2 by Bena [yun], Kaan [ldl], Longuda [lnu], Mbula-Bwazza [mbu].

name: Tehit
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1998.
Language Use: Vigorous. Parents in villages in the interior pass Tehit on to children. In villages bordering towns, Indonesian [ind] used with children. Users of neighboring languages learn Tehit. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Indonesian [ind], particularly in schools and as LWC. Also use Mai Brat [ayz].

name: Waurá
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Bible portions: 1997–2003.
Language Use: A few also use Portuguese [por], isolated in a protected government reserve.

name: Akwa
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Leitch 2005).

name: Nteng
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Cakfem-Mushere [cky]. Also use English [eng], especially among the younger generation. Also use Kofyar [kwl], Bwol dialect.

name: Lyélé
LITERACY_L2: 18% mainly in French [fra], some in Mòoré [mos].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 18% mainly in French [fra], some in Mòoré [mos]. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3 or grade 5. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. About 50% age 15 or under. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Moore [mos]. Used as L2 by Northern Nuni [nuv].

name: Kwini
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Musom
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon, 2000 S. Wurm). Much intermarriage with speakers of other languages, strong presence of Tok Pisin [tpi] and Yabem [jae], education of children in English [eng], long absences of adult males for work all contribute to the detriment of the language. Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Holzknecht 1997). Many also use Aribwaung [ylu] (Holzknecht 1997). Many also use Duwet [gve] (Holzknecht 1997). Some also use Mesem [mci] (Holzknecht 1997). Some also use Nabak [naf] (Holzknecht 1997). Some also use Yabem [jae], especially elderly (Holzknecht 1997).

name: Min Bei Chinese
Writing: Latin script [Latn], from 1896 to some time after last publication in 1922.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate in Chinese and they use that literature. NT: 1934.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Eten
Language Development: Literacy program in progress (Blench 2019). NT: 2018.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Firan [fir].

name: Minigir
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Kuanua [ksd]. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use English [eng], especially adults.

name: Amele
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100% in Tok Pisin[tpi]. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Some villages markedly shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi], especially those withmore access to Madang town. Some young people, all adults. Mainly adults and older. All also useTok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Fulumu [bbd], Wagi [fad].

name: Rukai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Some also use Japanese [jpn],especially older adults. Some also use Min Nan Chinese [nan]. Also use Puyuma [pyu].

name: Mabire
Language Use: All shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Maiani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions: 1982–1988.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Hember Avu [mmi].

name: Laka (Chad)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 12%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. NT: 1960.

name: Gbe, Kotafon
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Some also use Saxwe Gbe [sxw]. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gen [gej]. Also use Gun [guw]. Used as L2 by Saxwe Gbe [sxw].

name: Kimré
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Prefer literacy in Kimre to French [fra] or Chadian Arabic [shu]. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Mulgi [mvh].

name: Gweno
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Asu [asa]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Miju-Mishmi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% for Mishmi (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng]. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use Digaro-Mishmi [mhu]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Warluwara
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Nuaulu, South
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1991–2004.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Sepa [spb].

name: Mumuye
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught as subject in tertiary schools. Grammar. NT: 1994–2018.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Nyong [muo], Yendang [ynq], Yotti [yot].

name: Karen, Pwo Western
Language Development: Summer and church literacy classes in many communities; used and taught in Bible schools. Dictionary. Bible: 1883–1926.
Language Use: Vigorous in villages; lessening in towns. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Used as L2 by S’gaw Karen [ksw].

name: Ewage-Notu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. NT: 1987.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Aeka [aez], Baruga [bjz], Binandere [bhg], Orokaiva [okv].

name: Waffa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. NT: 1975–1987.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some North Tairora [tbg] traders also use Waffa. All domains. Oral and written use in church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Western Neo-Aramaic
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Syriac script, Western variant [Syrj].
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, and as literary and religious language. Shifting to Levantine Arabic[apc].

name: Kirike
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2018.

name: Mazatec, Mazatlán
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Andegerebinha
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ikposo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Igo [ahl].

name: Mbe'
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use Tikar [tik], particularly outside the home. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Nahuatl, Tlamacazapa
Language Development: Bible portions: 2004–2012.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Ginyanga
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gen [gej].Also use Tem [kdh].

name: Dom
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Tida 2006). Many also use Kuman[kue] (Tida 2006).

name: Munda
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Devanagari script [Deva]. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya].
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck]. Used as L2 by Birhor [biy], Mahali [mjx].

name: Surgujia
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].

name: Gedaged
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–100%. Dictionary.NT: 1960.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Awad Bing [bcu], Matukar Panau [mjk], Ngaing [nnf], Nobonob[gaw], Siroi [ssd], Wagi [fad], Yote [wab].

name: Karachay-Balkar
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Nogai [nog].

name: Zapotec, Sierra de Juárez
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1970.

name: Ndunga
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Meeuwis 1998).

name: Nung (Burma)
Language Development: Some community literacy classes. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Majority are indifferent that Anong is disappearing (Sun 2005). Shifted to Lisu [lis]. Some also use Rawang [raw].

name: Lasi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.

name: Longuda
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Hausa [hau]. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Also use Dera [kna]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Waja [wja]. Used as L2 by Dera [kna], Mbula-Bwazza [mbu].

name: Lere
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Kabutra
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Urdu [urd].
Language Use: Also use Sindhi Bhil [sbn]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Mak (China)
Language Use: Shifting to Bouyei [pcc].

name: Angloromani
Language Development: Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Bible portions: 1874–1995.
Language Use: Spoken in the United Kingdom for 500 years. The Romanichal population must be considered as being more actively determined to retain the ethnic language than some other British minorities (Hancock 1990b).

name: Guinean Sign Language
Language Use: Used in the deaf school in Conakry. Used by all.

name: Tumbuka
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1957–2017.

name: Luchazi
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 1963.
Language Use: Home, church, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Northwestern !Kung [vaj].

name: Kalaktang Monpa
LITERACY_L2: 62% for West Kameng District, males 71%, females 49% (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 62% for West Kameng District, males 71%, females 49% (2001 census).
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Bugun [bgg].

name: Bafia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High rate in French [fra]. Written Bafia is little used, but there are members of the community who are trying to revise the orthography and get literacy programs started. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra]. A few also use Nugunu [yas]. A few also use Tuki [bag]. Used as L2 by Dimbong [dii].

name: Thayore
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1981.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Children are learning it (2011). Most also use English [eng].

name: Mbugu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Swahili [swh]. Also use Asu [asa]. Also use Shambala [ksb].

name: Amara
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: One village shifting to Bariai [bch] and another village shifting toMaleu-Kilenge [mgl]. Vigorous use in only one village (Paris et al 2012a). In one village, alldomains except church and prayer. In a second village, mixed use in all domains with Tok Pisin[tpi] and Bariai [bch]. In a third village, only used when interacting with residents of theother two villages (Paris et al 2012a). Some of all ages. Mixed attitudes, from positive toneutral. Most also use Bariai [bch] (Paris et al 2012a). Many also use Maleu-Kilenge [mgl](Paris et al 2012a). Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Paris et al 2012a). Used as L2 by Anem[anz], Maleu-Kilenge [mgl].

name: Atakapa
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Naga, Kharam
LITERACY_L2: 30% in Meitei [mni], in English [eng], or in Hindi[hin].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% in Meitei [mni], in English [eng], or in Hindi[hin]. Most 5- to 20-year-olds have learned to read in school. Older people would like to learnto read. Grammar. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni]. Also use Purum[pub].

name: Samtao
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, community affairs. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Shan [shn].

name: Bunganditj
Language Development: Grammar. There is an ongoing language program at Mount Gambier’s Burrandies Aboriginal Corporation and Penola Primary School (2016).

name: Balkan Gagauz Turkish
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Turkish [tur].

name: Myene
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1927.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra]. A few also use Fang [fan]. Used as L2 by Fang [fan].

name: Nahuatl, Tabasco
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Kutep
Language Development: Literacy program in progress. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Grammar. NT: 1985–2017.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Jukun Takum [jbu]. Used as L2 by Yukuben [ybl].

name: Narom
Language Use: Also use Iban [iba].

name: Sasak
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2007.

name: Kambiwá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Huave, San Dionisio Del Mar
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Yaqui
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1977–2011.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Vinmavis
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Litzlitz [lzl].

name: Reel
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary.Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use South CentralDinka [dib].

name: Iteri
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Bo [bpw] (Brooks 2020). Manyalso use Tok Pisin [tpi], with some young people shifting (Brooks 2020). Some also use Sawiyanu[amm] (Brooks 2020).

name: Tapieté
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Mixed attitudes. Reservations about use of their language outside their culture area. Most also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug] (Crevels 2012). Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Adele
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1996–2001.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Éwé [ewe]. Used as L2 by Delo [ntr].

name: Nii
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Zul
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022a). Most also use English [eng] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022a).

name: Naki
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Good et al 2011). Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use Jukun Takum [jbu].

name: Avatime
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use Éwé [ewe], but contact with it is diminishing.

name: Sami, Pite
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%.
Language Use: Shifted to Swedish [swe].

name: Banaro
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Gorovu [grq].

name: Quechua, Cajatambo North Lima
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Texts.
Language Use: Family, community. Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Uamué
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por] (Grünewald 2018).

name: Keiyo
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Lomwe
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Manyawa [mny].

name: Dhalandji
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Taught as Language Other Than English (LOTE) at OnslowSchool (2008).
Language Use: Only a few speakers remain (Wurm 2007). Elderly only. Shifted to English[eng].

name: South African Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Agency: Deaf Federation of South Africa (DEAFSA).
Language Use: Vigorous. Understood to some degree by most deaf people. Some interpreters provided in courts. Used by all.

name: Kaili, Ledo
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Largest and most prestigious of Kaili varieties in Sulawesi. Used as L2 by Taje [pee], Uma [ppk].

name: Logir
Language Use: All domains, some use in schools, churches, and government offices. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Dongotono [ddd]. Also use English [eng], mostly used in church and schools. Also use Juba Arabic [pga]. Also use Lango [lgo].

name: Kayan, Baram
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1990.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Washo
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Washoe Tribe sponsors language retention project and successful immersion school where Washo is medium of instruction K-8 (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Chin, Siyin
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2004–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Cochimi
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Saisiyat
Language Development: Grammar. The Saisiyat people have initiated a revitalization movement under governmental initiatives (Zeitoun et al 2015).
Language Use: Adults only. Very few under 45 can speak the language fluently (Zeitoun et al 2015). Positive attitudes. All shifting to Atayal [tay], from northern dialect (Wurm 2007). Many shifting to Hakka Chinese [hak], from southern dialect (Wurm 2007).

name: Ghanaian Pidgin English
Writing: Unwritten [Qaax], Latin script is sometimes used in comics.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Informal settings: playgrounds, on campus, in bars and dorms, in familyhomes among younger generations. Educated urban males under age 50 are likely to use it ininformal settings.

name: Kanakanabu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 8%. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Bunun [bnn]. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Shifted to Min Nan Chinese [nan].

name: Male (Papua New Guinea)
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2016a). Used as L2 by Sam [snx].

name: Malaryan
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Malayalam [mal], in Kerala state.

name: Cocama-Cocamilla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible portions: 1961–1967.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Charapa Spanish [spq]. Used as L2 by Omagua[omg].

name: Tol
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 1993–2010.
Language Use: Most shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Lamboya
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind], used in education and religion (Verdizade 2019). Some also use Wanukaka [wnk] (Verdizade 2019). Some also use Wejewa [wew] (Verdizade 2019). Used as L2 by Wanukaka [wnk].

name: Batak Toba
Writing: Batak script [Batk], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible:1894–1989.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Community, Work, Religion, Education. Some young people,all adults. All also use Indonesian [ind], which is becoming the L1 of the youth in urban andmigrant areas.

name: Tregami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Northern Pashto [pbu], especially men.

name: Tchumbuli
Language Development: No Tchumbuli literacy initiative has been successful (2023 D. Roberts).
Language Use: Used most in Gbédé and least in Edaningbe (Faton and Tupper 2017). Culturalevents: Mixed: Home. Older adults only. . Only in Gbédé village do the under 20s use Tchumbuli,and even then it is alongside Ede Cabe [cbj] (2023 D. Roberts). Mixed attitudes. Most shifted toEde Cabe [cbj], especially in Okounfo where some youth are using it as their L1 (Iroko 1995).Most shifted to Maxi Gbe [mxl], especially in Edaningbe where youth are using it as their L1(Iroko 1995). Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Yoruba [yor], mostly in church(Faton and Tupper 2017).

name: Toaripi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Bible: 1983.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Motu [meu]. Also use Tairuma [uar]. Used as L2 by Kaki Ae [tbd], Tairuma [uar].

name: Comorian, Ndzwani
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Bible portions: 2011.

name: Anindilyakwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1976–1995.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng], especially young people.

name: Kadaru
Language Use: Shifting to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Tanzanian Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary schools for deaf children since 1963. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2011–2014. Agency: Tanzania Association of the Deaf.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Pande
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Arikapú
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Tuparí [tpr].

name: Greek Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Hellenic Federation of the Deaf(HFD).
Language Use: School. Deaf associations. 12,000 children and 30,000 active adult users(1996).

name: Kube
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2007.
Language Use: With people who do not know Kube, they switch to a common language. Alldomains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Kâte [kmg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Ambulas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT:1974–1996.
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2018).

name: Ukrainian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Ukrainian Society of the Deaf (USD, UTOG).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Some also use Ukrainian [ukr], primarily written.

name: Kang
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Razajerdi
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Sardinian, Campidanese
Language Development: Growing movement to recognize Sardinian as part of linguistic and cultural heritage. Bible portions: 1860–1900.
Language Use: In general use in the south. Many children learn the language but often stop at school age (Salminen 2007). Some young people, all adults.

name: Thai Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 10%. The first deaf school began in 1951, with help from Gallaudet University. Educated deaf people have limited Thai [tha] literacy skills. Taught in primary schools. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Total communication (simultaneous speech and signing) in schools, thus different from what is used by deaf adults outside. Reported high mobility among most deaf people today. Used by all. Also use Thai [tha]. Used as L2 by Ban Khor Sign Language [bfk], Chiangmai Sign Language [csd].

name: Barai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–60%. Grammar. Texts. NT:1994–2006.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Wayuu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2002–2010.
Language Use: One of the most vigorously spoken indigenous languages in South America(Crevels 2007). Positive attitudes. Many also use Spanish [spa], especially younger generations(Crevels 2007).

name: Waigali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Northern Pashto [pbu].

name: Tarpia
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon; 2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Sentani [set] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Private domains. Older adults only. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Arabic (Chadian)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Amdang [amj], Assangori [sjg], Bagirmi [bmi], Barein [bva], Berakou [bxv], Besme [bes], Bidiyo [bid], Bolgo [bvo], Bon Gula [glc], Boor [bvf], Bua [bub], Buduma [bdm], Buso [bso], Dangaléat [daa], Dar Daju Daju [djc], Dar Sila Daju [dau], Dazaga [dzg], Fania [fni], Gula [glu], Gula Iro [glj], Jaya [jyy], Kanembu [kbl], Kenga [kyq], Kibet [kie], Koke [kou], Kulfa [kxj], Lagwan [kot], Maba [mde], Mabire [muj], Mararit [mgb], Marfa [mvu], Masalit [mls], Maslam [msv], Masmaje [mes], Massalat [mdg], Mawa [mcw], Mbara [mpk], Migaama [mmy], Mogum [mou], Mser [kqx], Mubi [mub], Mukulu [moz], Naba [mne], Runga [rou], Saba [saa], Sinyar [sys], Sokoro [sok], Tama [tma], Tamki [tax], Tedaga [tuq], Toram [trj], Tunia [tug], Zaghawa [zag], Zan Gula [zna], Zerenkel [zrn].

name: Kikai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Siuslaw
Language Development: Texts. Confederated Tribes of Coos, Lower Umpqua and Siuslaw have a language program (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Birri
Language Use: Shifted to Zande [zne].

name: Romblomanon
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Filipino [fil]. Used as L2 by Bantoanon [bno].

name: Taruma
Language Use: Shifted to Wapishana [wap].

name: Zay
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Use of Zay is decreasing due to migration from the islands (the traditionalhomeland) to the lakeshore, where they become Oromo [orm] speakers. Oromo is also taught inisland schools. Speaker number decrease also attributed to dominant role of Amharic [amh](Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). Some young people, all adults. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also useBorana-Arsi-Guji Oromo [gax], especially lakeshore children.

name: Huizhou Chinese
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant[Hant].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate inChinese and they use that literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Nyigina
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to English [eng] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Also use Walmajarri [wmt].

name: Sabu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2000.

name: Chonyi
Language Development: Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Kigiryama[nyf], or other Mijikenda varieties. Most also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Kigiryama [nyf].

name: Peere
Language Development: Active literacy program (2023 M. Kuhn). Taught as subject in secondary schools. Pere is taught in schools in the Pere area up to a BEPC certification level (2023 M. Kuhn). Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1986–2017.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Many also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Many also use French [fra]. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].

name: Dera (Indonesia)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1997, limited usage.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy] (de Sousa 2006). Many alsouse English [eng] (de Sousa 2006). Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (de Sousa 2006).

name: Kokola
Language Use: Also use Chichewa [nya].

name: Manobo, Western Bukidnon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 45%. Literacy rate in L2: 45%. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Home, church, and community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb].

name: Tjupany
Language Development: Funding was received for the year 2011 to 2012 to begin work on the recording, analysis and preservation of the language through creation of recordings, a dictionary and a sketch grammar (2018 J. Murdoch).
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kari
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Zande [zne].

name: Aghu-Tharnggala
Language Development: Texts.

name: Mbunga
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Rwandan Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Rwanda National Union of the Deaf (RNUD).
Language Use: Some also use Kinyarwanda [kin].

name: Siar-Lak
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2007–2012.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Rowe 2005). Some also use English [eng] (Rowe 2005). Used as L2 by Kandas [kqw], Konomala [koa], Label [lbb].

name: Apatani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 71% (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Alsouse Nefamese [nef].

name: Wagaya
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Malgana
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Gbaya, Northwest
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1995–2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Martuyhunira
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Unserdeutsch
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Descendant of pidginized Standard German [deu] which originated in Gazelle Peninsula of New Britain during German colonial times among Catholic mixed-race (Vunapope) community. With increased mobility and intermarriage, it is disappearing. Older adults only, but still some younger people who can understand it (Wurm 2007). All shifted to English [eng]. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Cuiba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 45%. Literacy rate in L2: 45%. Grammar. Texts. NT:1988–2022.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nahuatl, Isthmus-Pajapan
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1990–2009.
Language Use: Some young families use Nahuatl, others do not teach it to their children. All domains for older speakers. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Some also use Spanish [spa]. ; a few also speak a Popoluca language.

name: Ikoma
Language Use: Strong Swahili [swh] use among Nata dialect speakers. Many Nata children learn Swahili as L1. All domains, if no speakers of other languages are present. Some young people, all adults.

name: Samarokena
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Airoran [air]. Also use Isirawa [srl]. Also use Kwerba [kwe].

name: Emae
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar.
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use North Efate [llp], specifically the Tongoa variety.

name: Mari, Western
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Only a few child speakers. Also use Meadow Mari [mhr]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Duriankere
Language Use: Shifted to Moi Kelim [mxn].

name: Fayu
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Home, Community, Religion, Specialcultural events; in the village, all domains, in town, domains in contact with the outside worldwill use Indonesian [ind] or Papuan Malay [pmy] (2023 S. Johnston). Used by all. Most also useIndonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Kirikiri [kiy], Tause [tad].

name: Tsotsitaal
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: The language is appears to be growing in popularity among men as a pidginlanguage, and it is uncertain whether it will stabilize as a creole at this point (Makhudu 2002,McCormick 2009).

name: Gaikundi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Bible portions: 1978.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Burui [bry].

name: Engenni
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1977.

name: Yangman
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Molo
Language Use: Most shifted to Berta [wti]. Most shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Zapotec, Güilá
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Lambichhong
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Nepali [npi].

name: Kawacha
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Yagwoia [ygw] (Wurm 2007).

name: Pijao
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Fe'fe'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught assubject in most primary and secondary schools. Grammar. Bible portions: 1960.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra]. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A fewalso use English [eng]. A few also use Ghomálá’ [bbj]. A few also use Mbo [mbo]. A few also useNda’nda’ [nnz]. Used as L2 by Mbo [mbo].

name: Alatil
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Aruop [lsr]. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Chichimeca-Jonaz
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Bateri
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Kohistani Shina [plk].

name: Bende
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2018–2023.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Salampasu
Language Development: Bible portions: 1938.

name: Makhuwa-Saka
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Melanau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Above 50%. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Malay [zlm]. Used as L2 by Sibu Melanau [sdx], Vaie [bny].

name: Woun Meu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988–2011.
Language Use: Most also use Spanish [spa], except the elderly (Crevels 2007). Used as L2 by Epena [sja].

name: Lokoya
Language Use: All also use Otuho [lot].

name: Kwambi
Language Development: Texts. NT: 1951.

name: Shambala
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1908.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Mbugu [mhd].

name: Ngbaka Ma'bo
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Pongu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Hausa [hau]. Many children and adults are literate in Hausa [hau] or English [eng]. Videos. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Bauchi [bsf].

name: Tiwa, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. A rule of secrecy is adhered to by all members of the Taos Pueblo never to reveal anything to outsiders that is intrinsic to Taos culture. As a result, any language education and retention efforts are not publicly known (Golla 2007). Bible portions: 1976–1992.
Language Use: Adults only. Older adults at Picuris. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Hamtai
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1974–2013.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng] (Moretti 2006). Alsouse Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people (Moretti 2006).

name: Tereno
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Bilingual intercultural education has been implemented successfully in all municipal schools in the Terena region (Crevels 2007). Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Shifting to Portuguese [por].

name: Makwe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Motivation for literacy is high. Grammar.
Language Use: Some also use Mwani [wmw], especially men. Some also use Portuguese [por], especially those with schooling, for reading. Some also use Swahili [swh], especially men. Those with schooling can read Swahili. Also use Makonde [kde].

name: Zapotec, Tejalapan
Language Use: Total L1 speakers in 1998 was 30, all over the age of 70. Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Ngwaba
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau]. Also use Gudu [gdu]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Nzanyi [nja].

name: Kuman
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%–40%. Used in first 3 grades in school. 20,000 can read and write Kuman. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous in villages farther from highways and towns, while vitality is lower in the villages closer to the highways and towns (2015 SIL). In all villages, there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] in church. All domains except church in some villages, mixed use in all domains with Tok Pisin [tpi] in other villages (2015 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Hardie 2003). Some also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Chuave [cjv], Dom [doa], Golin [gvf], Kandawo [gam], Nomane [nof], Sinasina [sst], Yui [sll].

name: Khinalugh
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Some child speakers (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Also use North Azerbaijani [azj], as a literary language.

name: Acipa, Eastern
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Chamicuro
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Yan-nhaŋu Sign Language
Language Development: Videos.
Language Use: Elderly only.

name: Kisi
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 2019–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous in heartland area. Some of all ages. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Nguluwan
Language Use: Shifted to Yapese [yap].

name: Selangor Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in English [eng].
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Some shifted to Malaysian SignLanguage [xml]. Many also use English [eng], in written form. Some also use Standard Malay[zsm], in written form. A few also use Penang Sign Language [psg]. Older deaf from Selangorstudied at the school in Penang (Hurlbut 2003).

name: Irula
Writing: Malayalam script [Mlym], used in Kerala. Tamil script [Taml], used in TamilNadu.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% among adults, 50% among younger generation.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2001–2013.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes. Many shifting to Kannada [kan]. Manyshifting to Tamil [tam]. Also use Badaga [bfq]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam[mal]. Used as L2 by Attapady Kurumba [pkr].

name: Prasuni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Dari [prs], traditionally with bilingualism. Also use Southern Pashto [pbt], with increasing bilingualism.

name: Wolane
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Amharic [amh], especially those below the age of 30 (Meyer 2006).

name: Xavánte
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50% (most men, few women). Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Portuguese [por]. About 3,000 speak it some, but with Brazilians only.

name: Ngbandi, Southern
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Babar, North
Language Use: Home, gardens, ceremonies. Some young people, all adults. Many also useAmbonese Malay [abs], especially those youth who use it as an L1. Also use Indonesian [ind],primarily in government and Christian religious ceremonies.

name: Apiacá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por]. Many also use Kayabí [kyz], due to mixedmarriages. Many also use Mundurukú [myu], due to mixed marriages.

name: Ko
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Koitabu
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Young speakers tend to prefer Tok Pisin [tpi] or English [eng] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng] (Wu 2020). Most also use Motu [meu] (Wu 2020). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wu 2020). A few also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Wu 2020).

name: Nukak Makú
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 0%. Literacy projects in place. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tobelo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use North Moluccan Malay [max]. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].

name: Kembra
Language Use: Moribund (2000 S. Wurm). Home. Older adults only. Used by a few children. Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Kamviri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Outside of language area, shifting towards majority language. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Northern Pashto [pbu].

name: Kuni-Boazi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–50%. English used in primary and secondary school. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Few use Kuni-Boazi as L2. Home, church, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Zapotec, Tilquiapan
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Sociolinguistic differences with nearest Zapotec. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kala Lagaw Ya
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Also use Torres Strait Creole [tcs], especially those younger than 30 when outside the language area.

name: Ankave
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bonnemère 2008).

name: Kerinci
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Kwinti
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Saramaccan [srm]. Also use Sranan Tongo [srn].

name: Yanomámi
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Portuguese [por].

name: Inari Sami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught as subject in a few primary and secondary schools. Bible portions: 1903–1980. Few children used to learn it before the founding of the first Inari Saami language nest in 1997. Now a substantial portion of youth are growing as functional bilinguals (Salminen 2007).
Language Use: Also use Finnish [fin], especially in instruction in schools.

name: Tujia, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 88% in Chinese (2000 census, Tujia nationality).
Language Use: In Boluozhai, all speak the language; in Puzhu, some children can speak it; in Xiaqieji, only adults speak it (Bradley 2007a). Home, village. Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Gebe
Language Use: Mining operations started in the area which led to more schooling ofchildren and increasing use of Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). All domains. Also use Indonesian[ind].

name: Yirrk-Mel
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: War
LITERACY_L2: 40% in Bengali [ben]; many are literate in standardKhasi [kha].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Bengali [ben]; many are literate in standardKhasi [kha]. Using Latin script for War-Jaintia produces some pronunciation problems but easestransition into Khasi. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village. Used by all. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Khasi [kha]. Also use Sylheti [syl]. Used as L2 by Bengali [ben], Pnar[pbv].

name: Nde-Nsele-Nta
Language Development: English [eng] used in school. Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Also use Abanyom [abm]. Also use Efik [efi]. Also use Efutop [ofu]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Used as L2 by Abanyom [abm].

name: Orya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Some adult literacy classes. NT: 2005. Agency: Yayasan Sïp (Tunas) Irian Jaya.
Language Use: Children learn Orya in most cases. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Sause [sao].

name: Maridan
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007).

name: Dampelas
Language Use: Spoken in 8 villages but in 7 there are strong migrant communities and theeveryday public language is Indonesian [ind]. Indonesian used increasingly in families who wantchildren to have higher education (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Patpatar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997–2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Mori Bawah
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 1948.
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Bungku [bkz].

name: Ika
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Esan [ish].

name: Manambu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 1979.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, community, church. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2008). Some also use English [eng] (Aikhenvald 2008). Used as L2 by Yalaku [ylg].

name: Gorontalo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Noted shift to Indonesian [ind] in youth. Home, Community. Some of allages. Neutral attitudes. All also use Manado Malay [xmm]. Some also use Indonesian [ind]. A fewalso use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Suwawa [swu].

name: Ginuman
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Umanakaina [gdn], especiallymen. Many also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Baga Kaloum
Language Use: Shifted to Susu [sus].

name: Walmajarri
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1978–1989.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Kukatja [kux], Martu Wangka [mpj], Nyikina [nyh].

name: Kamarian
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Ngbinda
Language Use: Shifted to Lingala [lin].

name: Aralle-Tabulahan
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kacipo-Balesi
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Phuan
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: It is likely that Phuan speakers are transitioning to Thai [tha]. Home, Community, Special cultural events, But Thai [tha] is used also and usually more than Phuan. Adults only. All shifting to Thai [tha].

name: Sikkimese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 68% for Bhutia in Sikkim (2001 census). Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Nepali [npi], for education and trade (Yliniemi 2019). Some also use Central Tibetan [bod], which is viewed as appropriate for religion. Also use English [eng] (Yliniemi 2019). Also use Hindi [hin] (Yliniemi 2019).

name: Teop
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–85%. Literacy rate in L2: High. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1958–1966.
Language Use: Some dislike borrowed words entering Teop. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Mosel 2015). Used as L2 by Papapana [ppn].

name: Koreguaje
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–40%. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 1991–2009.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Macaguaje [mcl].

name: Chitimacha
Language Development: Dictionary. Rosetta Stone software has been created and distributed toevery member of the tribe, a dictionary is being prepared, and language classes are being taughton the reservation (2015).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Naba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Grammar.
Language Use: Some also use Chadian Arabic [shu], especially the Kuka ethnic group, who live near Oum Hadjer.

name: Triqui, Chicahuaxtla
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1968.

name: Moken
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Mixtec, Magdalena Peñasco
Language Development: Most people aged 50 and under are literate in Spanish [spa]. NT: 2012.
Language Use: The language is almost never used for written communication. Some young people, all adults. Older teens are only young speakers. Positive attitudes. Many also use Spanish [spa], with their children.

name: Anuta
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Karadjeri
