Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Inonhan
Language Use: Also use Hiligaynon [hil]. Used as L2 by Bantoanon [bno].

name: Keres, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Laguna dialect is taught as L2 at Laguna elementary school. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1966–1997. The pueblo sponsors a language preservation project (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to English [eng].

name: Svan
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Georgian (Mkhedruli and Mtavruli) script [Geor], primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Most domains except Education and Government. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Georgian [kat].

name: Loko
Language Development: Texts. NT: 1983.

name: Zapotec, Santa Catarina Albarradas
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some also use Albarradas Sign Language [lsc], to varying degrees of proficiency. Also use Cajonos Zapotec [zad], about half, passively, due to trade.

name: Lamma
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Batak Simalungun
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1976.
Language Use: All also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Anguthimri
Language Development: Revitalization program has begun in 2016 by the Pama Language Centre withthe goal of producing a bilingual children’s book of simple phrases.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Chug
LITERACY_L2: 22% for Hindi [hin] for the villages in the Chugvalley (Bodt 2020:41), based on 2011 census.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 22% for Hindi [hin] for the villages in the Chugvalley (Bodt 2020:41), based on 2011 census. Grammar.
Language Use: Currently relatively vigorous but low speaker population and rapidsocio-economic developments in the region pose severe threats to the long-term survival of thelanguage (Bodt 2020: 50–51). Some also use Brokpake [sgt] (Bodt 2020). A few also use English[eng], mostly younger people (Bodt 2020). Also use Central Tibetan [bod], used by religiouslyeducated people (Bodt 2020). Also use Hindi [hin], mostly younger generation with other speakers(Bodt 2020). Also use Tawang Monpa [twm] (Bodt 2020). Also use Tshangla [tsj], mostly adultsover 40 years of age (Bodt 2020).

name: West Flemish
Language Development: Bible portions: 1980–2003.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use English [eng]. Also use French [fra].

name: Mosimo
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifting to Garus [gyb] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Woiwurrung
Language Development: Woiwurrung is being taught in Thornbury Primary School and Healesville High School; language apps and audio books in Woiwurrung are also available.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Chin, Ngawn
Language Development: Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Bozaba
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin], mainly in the market.

name: Totonac, Coyutla
Language Use: Used as L2 by Filomena Mata-Coahuitlán Totonac [tlp].

name: Koli, Parkari
LITERACY_L2: Below 5%, mostly in Sindhi [snd], a few in Urdu [urd], very few in Gujarati [guj].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%, mostly in Sindhi [snd], a few in Urdu [urd], very few in Gujarati [guj]. Taught as subject in some primary and secondary schools. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Gujarati [guj]. Also use Sindhi [snd]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Miyako
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Japanese [jpn].

name: Saponi
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Shifted to Rasawa [rac].

name: Chukot
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2004–2020.
Language Use: 60% of the population. Few domains but extensive use in reindeer herdingbrigades. Some young people, all adults. Very few children speak it (Salminen 2007). Positiveattitudes. Also use Even [eve]. Also use Northern Yukaghir [ykg]. Also use Russian [rus]. Lessthan 50 speakers of Russian with varying proficiency, but nomadic groups resist Russian languageand culture. Also use Yakut [sah]. Used as L2 by Kerek [krk], Northern Yukaghir [ykg].

name: Langam
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Barlow 2020a). Also use Angoram [aog] (Barlow 2020a). Also use Ap Ma [kbx] (Barlow 2020a).

name: Zapotec, Asunción Mixtepec
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Kanoé
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Godwari
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home, village, market, religion. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Alsouse English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], with very good proficiency among the educated.

name: Geez
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 400–1918.
Language Use: Liturgical language of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church. Ancient language ofthe Aksumites.

name: Coos
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Language program run by Confederated Tribes of Coos, LowerUmpqua and Siuslaw (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Taulil
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Most also use Kuanua [ksd] (Meng 2018). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Meng 2018).

name: Tukang Besi North
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed use: Religion, Education. Some young people, alladults. All also use Indonesian [ind]. Some also use Indonesian Bajau [bdl]. A few also useCia-Cia [cia]. A few also use Kamaru [kgx]. A few also use Lasalimu [llm]. Used as L2 byIndonesian Bajau [bdl], Kumbewaha [xks].

name: Con
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Wumboko
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng].

name: Samo, Maya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 2%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 20% French [fra], below 10% Mòoré [mos]. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra], in primary and secondary schools. Also use Jula [dyu], in the west. Also use Moore [mos], which is learned well by young people in the east. Used as L2 by Kalamsé [knz].

name: Mam, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–37%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1993. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by K’iche’ [quc].

name: Ghodoberi
Language Development: Russian [rus] used in education. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only, few child speakers (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Mostshifting to Avar [ava]. Most shifting to Russian [rus].

name: Nimi
Language Use: All domains in most villages, mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] in some villages. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Teke-Fuumu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Laari [ldi]. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Taje
Language Use: Except for one elderly man, most speakers do not know the language well. Most have been resettled (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Also use Lauje [law]. Also use Ledo Kaili [lew]. Also use Tajio [tdj].

name: Kuku-Yalanji
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 14%. 100 can read; 30 can write it. Taught as subjectin primary schools, with limited oral use. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1985.
Language Use: Traditional religion, oral and some written use in religious services. Oraltradition. Some young people, all adults. Children are learning it. Positive attitudes. All alsouse English [eng].

name: Sentani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 16%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. About 5,000. Schools are beginning to use Sentani grades 1 to 6. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Vigorous use in most families. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Popoloca, San Juan Atzingo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. 2,000 L1 readers, 200 can write. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1982–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. Onyx and sugarcane workers have team leaders who speak Spanish for them. Some, more among the young, migrate temporarily for jobs, but retain the language. All domains. Oral use in local administration, commerce, religious services. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Spanish [spa], especially men. Many women who cannot speak Spanish speak Nahuatl for trading in San Gabriel Chilac. Some Nahuatl in Chilac also use some Popoloca.

name: Sakha
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Cyrillic script, Old Church Slavonic variant [Cyrs], in the 19th century, experimental usage. Latin script [Latn], 1929–1939.
Language Development: Russian used in higher education. Taught as subject in many primary and secondary schools in the Sakha (Yakutia) republic. Grammar. NT: 2004–2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Chukchi [ckt], Even [eve], Evenki [evn], Northern Yukaghir [ykg], Southern Yukaghir [yux].

name: Skolt Sami
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in 1894. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1878–1988.
Language Use: Very few children learn the language (Salminen 2007). Adults only. Shifting to Finnish [fin].

name: Miwok, Lake
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Naga, Tutsa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Very few with higher education. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Eruwa
Language Use: Home, traditional meetings, church. Adults only. Positive attitudes.Shifting to Isoko [iso] (Ekiugbo and Diffre-Odiete 2018). Also use English [eng] (Ekiugbo andDiffre-Odiete 2018).

name: Isu (Fako Division)
Language Development: Bible portions: 1843–1852.
Language Use: Adults only. To align with EGIDS level which was more recent info than the previous speaker age range data. Many shifting to Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some shifting to English [eng]. Most also use French [fra]. Also use Duala [dua]. Also use Mokpwe [bri].

name: Patani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].

name: Holikachuk
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Karenggapa
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Obokuitai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Bible portions: 1994.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Children influenced by Indonesian[ind] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults.

name: Bohtan Neo-Aramaic
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Georgian [kat]. Many shifting to Russian[rus].

name: Urningangg
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Nhirrpi
Language Development: Texts.

name: Besme
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use Nancere [nnc].

name: Maleu-Kilenge
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: All or nearly the whole Kilenge group speaks Kilenge. Used by all, especially in the Kilenge dialect. A few also use Amara [aie] (Paris et al 2012a). Used as L2 by Amara [aie], Anem [anz], Bariai [bch].

name: Senoufo, Tagwana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Chuave
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1992–1994.
Language Use: Also use Kuman [kue].

name: Nimo
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Danish Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2013. Agency: Danish DeafAssociation (DDL).
Language Use: Vigorous. First deaf school began in 1807. Used in all 6 state primaryschools for the deaf. Interpreters are required in court, and may be used at important publicevents, in job training, social services, and mental health programs. Used by all. Also useDanish [dan].

name: Nunggubuyu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Children understand it, but speak Kriol [rop]. Most also use Kriol [rop]. The younger generation speaks Kriol. Used as L2 by Ritharrngu [rit].

name: Lusi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng]. Also use Kove [kvc]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].Used as L2 by Anem [anz], Bariai [bch].

name: Andio
Language Use: Much influence from Indonesian [ind] and neighboring languages, Saluan[loe] and Balantak [blz] (Wurm 2007). Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Manado Malay[xmm]. Also use Balantak [blz]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Saluan [loe].

name: Kabatei
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Tonga (Thailand)
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Southern Thai [sou].

name: Lamalera
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Yessan-Mayo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT: 1980–2004.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2018).

name: Kumbewaha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%.
Language Use: Mixed in all domains. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Most also use Cia-Cia [cia]. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Lasalimu [llm]. Also use Tukang Besi North [khc]. Also use Tukang Besi South [bhq].

name: Kolami, Southeastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Siroi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Grammar. NT: 1975–2000.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, including local commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Gedaged [gdd], the former church language. Also use English [eng], in schools. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially in schools. Used as L2 by Taupi [awm].

name: Stieng, Budeh
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Tyaraity
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kela (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Texts. Bibleportions: 2019.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with manyyoung people shifting (Schreyer 2017).

name: Tonsawang
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Manado Malay [xmm]. Some also use Indonesian [ind], in some formal contexts or with people from other parts of Indonesia.

name: Tagin
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, cultural activities, market. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].

name: Kaingáng
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1977–2005.
Language Use: Language use varies: in some communities all speak Kaingang as L1, but notin others. Growing interest in revitalization (Golla 2007). Some of all ages. There are somevillages where everyone speaks Kaingang, while in other villages the majority speak Portuguese[por], and only the elderly speak Kaingang (Tommasino and Fernandes 2018). Most also usePortuguese [por], in some vilages (Crevels 2007). Used as L2 by Xetá [xet].

name: Chipewyan
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1881.
Language Use: Very few readers of Dëne. In La Loche some children still learn Dëne.Proportion of speakers much higher in some remote areas where some children are more fluent inDëne than English [eng]. All also use English [eng].

name: Dhargari
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kanyok
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2008.

name: Senoufo, Nyarafolo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Paleni
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Teanu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Pijin [pis] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Lovono [vnk], Tanema [tnx].

name: Bekati'
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1986.
Language Use: Also use Kendayan [knx].

name: Yami
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most young people consider Yami to be their L2 and Mandarin Chinese [cmn] their L1. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Wutunhua
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Amdo Tibetan [adx] (Sandman 2016). Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially among young people (Sandman 2016).

name: Gavião, Pará
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Ceremonies, songs, speeches. Adults only. Positive attitudes. All shiftingto Portuguese [por], increasingly, a particular regional variety, and especially in schools.

name: Inuktitut (Western Canadian)
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible portions: 1920–2021.
Language Use: Vigorous in Caribou and Netsilik. Some young people, all adults. In Commerand west, used by parent and grandparent generations (1995 M. Krauss). Also use English [eng].Used as L2 by Inuit Sign Language [iks].

name: Pomo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Most also use French [fra]. A few also use Gbaya-Mbodomo [gmm]. Used as L2 by Kwakum [kwu].

name: Kamasa
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. Shifted to Menya [mcr] (Wurm 2007).

name: Malay, Makassar
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Limola [ley], Makasar [mak], Wotu [wtw].

name: Limba, East
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Semelai
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Burak
Language Development: Bible portions: 2008.

name: Galeya
Language Use: All domains except church, where there is mixed use with Dobu [dob] andEnglish [eng] (Lambrecht et al 2015). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Dobu [dob](Lambrecht et al 2015). Most also use English [eng] (Lambrecht et al 2015). Used as L2 byBoselewa [bwf], Gumawana [gvs], Maiadomu [mzz].

name: Ulwa
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Mískito [miq] (Salazar 2008). Most also use Spanish [spa] (Salazar 2008). Some also use Nicaragua English Creole [bzk] (Salazar 2008).

name: Comox
Language Development: Grammar. Community-based language projects (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Siwai
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1977.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Evans and Palmer 2011). Used as L2 by Naasioi [nas], Papapana [ppn].

name: Krumen, Tepo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Plapo Krumen [ktj].

name: Sarsi
Language Development: School program taught by a semi-speaker. Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kadazan, Klias River
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some children and adults; all elderly. Positive attitudes. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Most also use Brunei [kxd]. Most also use Sabah Bisaya [bsy]. Most also use Tatana [txx].

name: Logo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg].

name: Bwamu, Láá Láá
LITERACY_L1: 1%–2% are fluent readers of Ouarkoye Buamu.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–2% are fluent readers of Ouarkoye Buamu. Literacyrate in L2: 1%–2% are fluent readers of French [fra] or Jula [dyu]. Literacy program. Grammar.NT: 2023.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Wardaman
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Chong
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Thai [tha]. Also use Lao [lao] (Choosri 2002).

name: Tinigua
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Sukur
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng]. A few also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Kamwe [hig]. Also use Psikye [kvj].

name: Sardinian, Gallurese
Language Development: Growing movement to recognize Sardinian as part of linguistic and cultural heritage. Bible portions: 1861–1862.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language but often stop using it at school age (Salminen 2007).

name: Kurdish, Southern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in Iran.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1894–1900.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Also use Central Kurdish [ckb]. Contact area extends from Qasr-e Shirin to Qorve and Bijar (Belelli 2023). Also use Iranian Persian [pes]. Also use Laki [lki]. The line of language contact is roughly along the border of Kermanshah and Lorestan provinces (Belelli 2023). Also use Mesopotamian Arabic [acm], which is primarily in Ilam province (Belelli 2023). Also use Northern Luri [lrc]. Main contact area is along the border of Ilam and Lorestan provinces. Secondary contact area in Kermanshah Province, east of Kangavar (Belelli 2023). Used as L2 by Gurani [hac].

name: Kele (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1918–1958.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Abua
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Waneci
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Also use Southern Pashto [pbt].

name: Doyayo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. A few also use French [fra]. Also use AdamawaFulfulde [fub]. Up to 20% of the men have proficiency in it for trading and everydayconversation.

name: Honduras Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Asociación Nacional de Sordos de Honduras (ANSH).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all except elderly deaf; in 2010 research it was rare tofind any LESHO user who was born before 1970. Older deaf were reported to sign differently butit was not clear what system they used or if there was any consistency. Some children learnLESHO in primary schools, others don’t learn LESHO until their teens (Williams 2010:6, 14, 16).Some also use American Sign Language [ase] (Williams 2010). Some also use Spanish [spa](Williams 2010).

name: Mok
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Shan [shn].

name: Warrwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Mogholi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Dari [prs].

name: Maranunggu
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Narragansett
Language Development: Dictionary. Dr. Frank Waabu O’Brien has compiled documentation and instruction materials on Narragansett. There is also a Facebook page containing the alphabet and some vocabulary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Paiwan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1993.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kumbaran
LITERACY_L2: Below 50% for older adults in Kerala.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 50% for older adults in Kerala.
Language Use: Fairly vigorous in Wayanad District although Malayalam [mal] is used some in home and village. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes, especially in Wayanad District. Also use English [eng].

name: Dakota
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in 4 schools, 3 in Minnesota and 1 inSouth Dakota. Taught as subject in tertiary schools in 7 post-secondary programs. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1879. Teaching programs at every level, preschool through university(Golla 2007). Immersion program offered at the Bdote Early Learning Center in Minneapolis, MN(2023 N. Anderson).
Language Use: Older adults only. Most youth prefer English [eng] or do not speak thelanguage (Golla 2007). Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Inga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1996–2009.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Camsá [kbh].

name: Rejang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 45%. Taught as subject in many primary schools. Dictionary. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], but with low bilingualism.

name: Manna-Dora
Language Use: It is uncertain if they are speaking Telugu [tel] or a closely related language of their own. Shifted to Telugu [tel].

name: Nkami
Language Use: There is a sizable majority of Akan [aka] speakers in towns where Nkamis live. Also use Akan [aka], in interaction between Nkamis and Akans.

name: American Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy is almost always based on English rather than ASL. Deaf people’sEnglish varies from highly literate to illiterate, but the average deaf student graduates fromhigh school with a third or fourth grade reading level. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible:2020.
Language Use: Interpreters required for many legal and civic situations. Lingua franca ofthe deaf world, used widely as L2 in many countries other than those listed here. Used by all.Many also use English [eng]. Fluency in English varies widely, from native (hearing children ofDeaf parents), or near-native in reading/writing (many Deaf professionals), to ability only toread individual English words. Used as L2 by Hawai‘i Sign Language [hps], Plains Indian SignLanguage [psd].

name: Tubarão
Language Development: Literacy is in Portuguese [por].
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Portuguese [por], in most situations.

name: Mehri
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1902.
Language Use: Shifting to Hadrami Arabic [ayh]. Used as L2 by Hobyót [hoh].

name: Karelian
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Primer in Tver Karelian. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language but most if not all become more fluent in Russian [rus] and largely stop using the language later in life (Salminen 2007). Many also use Russian [rus], but those over 50 have trouble understanding it. Also use Finnish [fin].

name: Cafundo Creole
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Ngumbi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Very little available literature. NT: 1940–1975.
Language Use: Vigorous. All except education and government. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Spanish [spa]. Many also use French [fra]. Also use Equatorial Guinean Pidgin [fpe]. Also use Fang [fan]. Used as L2 by Bapuku [bnm].

name: Tichurong
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Sibu
Language Use: Shifting to Central Melanau [mel].

name: Kokota
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Under pressure from neighboring languages Cheke Holo [mrn] and Zabana [kji] (Palmer 2009). Also use Cheke Holo [mrn]. Also use Zabana [kji].

name: Uya
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Nukna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Grammar. Bible portions: 2014–2020.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially men (Taylor 2015). Some also use Mato [met] (Taylor 2015). Some also use Pano [mqz] (Taylor 2015). Some also use Timbe [tim] (Taylor 2015).

name: Yogad
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: 77% literacy in Isabela in 1955. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Lolak
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Children mostly or exclusively use Manado Malay [xmm] (2019 J. Lobel). Elderly only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Manado Malay [xmm]. A few also use Indonesian [ind]. A few also use Mongondow [mog].

name: Bilakura
Language Use: Under pressure from Parawen [prw] and Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Shiftedto Parawen [prw] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Ngbandi, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 8%. 20,000 read; 5,000 can write. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some speakers of other languages use it for trade in border areas. All domains. Oral use in some churches. Oral literature. Positive attitudes. Most also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 by Bolondo [bzm], Pagibete [pae], Yango [yng].

name: Shiki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% or less.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Hausa [hau]. Also use Gera [gew].

name: Malagasy, Tanosy
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Gende
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Kursav [faj].

name: Darmiya
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Learn Kumaoni [kfy] and Hindi [hin] simultaneously with their mothertongue. Code switching and code mixing very common. Uncertain whether stable bilingualism willcontinue or whether Kumaoni or Hindi will replace Darmiya. Home, community. Some young people,all adults. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], withhigh rates of bilingualism and as the medium of education at all levels. Also use Kumaoni [kfy].Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Resígaro
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Most shifted to Bora [boa], integrated by marriage into the Bora villages (Crevels 2007). Most shifted to Ocaina [oca], integrated by marriage into the Ocaina villages (Crevels 2007). Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Gunwinggu
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Many domains. Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 byDalabon [ngk], Djeebbana [djj], Gurr-goni [gge], Iwaidja [ibd], Kunbarlang [wlg], Maung [mph],Rembarrnga [rmb].

name: Banggai
Language Development: Texts. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Karen, Lahta
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya], especially among the young. Also use Kayan [pdu]. Also use Pa’o [blk].

name: Tafi
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Éwé [ewe].

name: Mansi
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used between 1920–1940, experimental usage.
Language Development: Russian [rus] used in schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1868–2016.
Language Use: Mansi spoken by 50% or less of the ethnic group; most shifted to Russian [rus]. Few domains. Some of all ages, but only within Northern Vogul. Mixed attitudes. Neutral to very positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Cayuga
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Keres, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Grammar. Bible portions: 1933–1936. Taughtat Zia elementary school. No language program in San Felipe. In Santo Domingo parents areobliged to teach the language to their children but no language classes are conducted at theschool. In Cochiti, taught at elementary school and community-based language revitalizationprogram started in 1996.
Language Use: Rates of language retention vary considerably from community to community.Some young people, all adults. All ages, but few children in Zia and Cochiti. Most also useEnglish [eng].

name: Bunak
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002). Also useTetun [tet].

name: Mori Atas
Language Use: Adults only. Most also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Nambas, Big
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar. Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Malua Bay [mll].

name: Kerewe
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1936–1946.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Jita [jit].

name: Gurmana
Language Use: Shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Koasati
Language Development: Written usage is minimal. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1981.
Language Use: More in Louisiana than Texas. Use decreased until the last decade. Fewerthan 10 primary school-age speakers. Home, religious services. Adults only. Positive attitudes.Shifting to English [eng]. Some also use Alabama [akz]. Some also use Choctaw [cho]. A few alsouse Cajun French [frc], with more proficiency than in English. Used as L2 by Alabama [akz].

name: Iwaidja
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1981.
Language Use: Some domains. Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng].Also use Gunwinggu [gup]. Used as L2 by Garig-Ilgar [ilg].

name: Arabic (Baharna)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Negative attitudes. Also use Gulf Arabic [afb].

name: Tarahumara, Northern
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Colombian Sign Language
Language Development: At least 4 deaf schools (starting in 1924), 2 in Bogotá and 2 in Medellín;3 other deaf institutions. Organization for sign language teachers. TV. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible portions: 2006. Agencies: Federación de Sordos de Colombia (FENASCOL); Instituto Nacionalpara Sordos (INSOR).
Language Use: Used by half of school-age deaf children. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kamo
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.

name: Kela (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Bible portions: 1940.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Religion, Work. Used by all. Many also use Lingala[lin]. Many also use Tetela [tll].

name: Afitti
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Nihali
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Korku [kfq]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Ngasa
Language Use: Shifted to Mochi [old], Seri dialect (Legère 2012).

name: Kwomtari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low. Two community schools. Grammar. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: All domains except in church, where there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi], and in interactions with outsiders. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Honsberger and Tupper 2008).

name: Paulohi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Dusun, Sugut
Language Use: Also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp].

name: Sherdukpen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15% (20% male, 7% female) (Muanthanga 1998).
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Tawang Monpa [twm]. Used as L2 by Bugun [bgg].

name: Meramera
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Vernacular school discontinued 2003. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Moderately vigorous. Some from neighboring groups use it. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kol [kol]. Also use Mengen [mee]. Used as L2 by Makolkol [zmh].

name: Likwala
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Kamang
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Alor Malay, the local variety of Malay. Some young people, all adults. Children and adolescents are rarely more than passive speakers of their language (Schapper 2014). Also use Abui [abz], mostly by speakers of Western Kamang, and their dialect shows substantive lexical influence from that language (Schapper 2014).

name: 'Auhelawa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 85%. Literacy rate in L2: 85%. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Many also use Bunama [bdd] (Mallett 2003). Many also use Bwanabwana [tte] (Mallett 2003). Many also use Dobu [dob] (Mallett 2003). Many also use Duau [dva] (Mallett 2003). Many also use Tawala [tbo] (Mallett 2003). Some also use English [eng], especially young people (Mallett 2003).

name: Bassossi
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].

name: Arigidi
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Maringarr
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Turi
Language Use: Shifted to Sadri [sck].

name: Bintulu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Malaysian [zlm].
Language Use: Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Adults only. Allalso use Malay [zlm]. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Iban [iba]. Many also useCentral Melanau [mel]. Also use Brunei [kxd]. Also use Rejang Kayan [ree].

name: Wojenaka
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Mazatec, Ayautla
Language Development: 40 to 50 readers, very few write. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Prestigious. Vigorous. All domains. Used by all.

name: Korean Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Agencies: Korea Association of the Deaf; National Institute of the Korean Language.
Language Use: Used since 1889. Signed interpretation required in court, used at important public events, and social services programs. Instruction for parents of deaf children. Many sign language classes for hearing people. Some also use Korean [kor].

name: Nicaragua Creole English
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used asL2 by Mískito [miq], Rama [rma], Spanish [spa], Ulwa [ulw].

name: Baki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Some key domains. Some young people, all adults. Used by 30% of thechildren. Positive attitudes. Desire for language revival. A few also use Bierebo [bnk]. Used asL2 by Bierebo [bnk], Bieria [brj].

name: Guwinmal
Language Development: Grammar. Evidence of revival efforts by members of the Dharumbal community.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ngeq
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Lao [lao] (Schliesinger 2003b).

name: Kanum, Sota
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, hunting camps. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind], as a trade language or for official purposes. Also use Morori [mok], as a trade language.

name: Arhuaco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–40%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Children aredeveloping literacy in Arhuaco at school. Taught as subject in a few primary schools. Grammar.Texts. Bible portions: 2005.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa],especially men and school-age young people, and especially in written form.

name: Nguôn
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Gelao, White
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Malol
Language Development: Bible portions: 2011–2018.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Sissano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions: 2011–2018.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Yamna
Language Development: Bible portions: 2006.
Language Use: More vigorous on mainland than on island. Older adults only. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Kuot
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–85%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–95%. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Nalik [nal], Notsi [ncf], and Tok Pisin [tpi]; children tend to prefer Tok Pisin (Wurm 2007). Adults only. Mixed attitudes, from positive to neutral. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. The shift to Tok Pisin [tpi] is almost complete in Kama and the other east coast Kuot villages (2023 C. Volker).

name: Zapotec, Santa Inés Yatzechi
Language Development: Bible portions: 1989–1991.
Language Use: Apparently no longer spoken in Santa Ana Zegache, and going out of use in Zaachila. Vigorous use among children in Santa Inés, some of whom are monolingual (1990). Some young people, all adults.

name: Itzá
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: The ethnic group retains indigenous identity. 60 bilingual non-fluentspeakers (1991 A. Hofling). The ethnic group in Belize now speaks Spanish [spa]. Older adultsonly. Most shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Old Church Slavonic
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage. Cyrillic script, Old Church Slavonicvariant [Cyrs]. Glagolitic script [Glag].
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1581–1751.
Language Use: Liturgical language of various Orthodox and Byzantine Catholic churches.

name: Arabic, Gulf Spoken
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Iñapari
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Komodo
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Sacapulteco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 16%. Bible portions: 1980. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Gola
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir]. Used as L2 by Vai [vai].

name: Kunggari
Language Development: Texts. The Australian Council for Education Research reported that Gunggarilanguage and cultural programs were offered at two schools in Queensland in 2008.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Karipúna Creole French
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary schools in grades 1–3. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Very weak language transmission. Many also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Galibi [car], Palikúr [plu].

name: Wauyai
Language Use: Dormant on Friwen Island (the original village), vigorous in the one village on the bay (2012 Y. Sawaki). Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Mbe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 35% in English [eng]. Bible portions: 1992.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng].

name: Dimir
Language Use: Some children no longer speak the language. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], in church. Also use English [eng], in church.

name: Kraol
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Khmer [khm]. Also use Central Mnong [cmo]. In Roveak village some have proficiency in Central Mnong [cmo]. Many in Roya village use Central Mnong [cmo]. Also use Lao [lao]. Some in Roveak village use Lao [lao].

name: Bierebo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also useBaki [bki]. Used as L2 by Baki [bki].

name: Drung
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 68%–73% (2000 census, Nu nationality). Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Lisu[lis]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Northern Katang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Toussian, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in French [fra], 3% in Jula [dyu]. Dictionary. NT: 2015–2019.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. All also use Jula [dyu]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Turka [tuz].

name: Igede
Language Development: Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Yace [ekr].

name: Baha Buyang
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. As of 1995, still used by all ages in Dixu district’s Yanglian village, but only older people can speak it in Bada district’s Anshe village. In Anshe, younger people shifted to Guibian Zhuang [zgn]. All also use Guibian Zhuang [zgn], especially adults. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], the local Southwest Mandarin variety.

name: Warji
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Bible portions: 2013–2023.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022b). Used as L2 by Dirya [dwa], Kariya [kil], Pa’anci [pqa], Siri [sir].

name: Pagu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Danau
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Pa’o [blk].

name: Burum-Mindik
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–90%. 7,000 can read it,6,000 can write it. Dictionary. NT: 1992–2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English[eng]. Also use Kâte [kmg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Tobo [tbv].

name: Hungu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Seeku
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Motivation for literacy is high. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Ghale, Kutang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Some Tibetan religious books translated into Kuke by priests. Home,friends; mixed use: Work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Nubri [kte]. Also useCentral Tibetan [bod]. Also use Nepali [npi], to communicate with Northern and Southern Ghalespeakers, but with minimal proficiency in Bihi village.

name: Djabwurrung
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kayan, Rejang
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Vaie [bny].

name: Eyak
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. The Eyak Preservation Council is working torevive the language, and the organization has produced a comprehensive learner’s website. TheEyak Language Revitalization Project organized the first Eyak Language Workshop in 2014 inAnchorage.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kanembu
Language Development: Written use very marginal. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many businessmen in N’Djamena are Kanembu. Also use ChadianArabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Buduma [bdm].

name: Egypt Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2014. Agency: National Association for theDeaf.
Language Use: Vigorous. Interpreters in some mosques. Used by all.

name: Jogi
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use Dhatki [mki]. Most also use Marwari[mve]. Also use Gujarati [guj], particularly for religious purposes. Also use Sindhi [snd],especially by women and children, but with very low proficiency, and by men in contact withoutsiders. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Tecpatlán Totonac
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Moderate use. Not all parents pass it on to children. Local administration, commerce, religion. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa], especially in schools. A few may also speak Nahuatl.

name: Vilela
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Remaining speakers apparently assimilated with the Toba [tob]. Losing their Indian identity in the barrios of towns and cities (1981 A. Buckwalter).

name: Kangjia
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Local commerce. Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Many shifted to Central Tibetan [bod]. Many shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Zoque, Chimalapa
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tarahumara, Southwestern
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Shan
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Used as L2 by Eastern Kayah [eky], Khün [kkh], Lahu [lhu], Lü [khb], Mok [mqt], Pa’o [blk], Parauk Wa [prk], Pyen [pyy], Riang Lai [yin], Riang Lang [ril], Ruching Palaung [pce], Rumai Palaung [rbb], Samtao [stu], Shwe Palaung [pll].

name: Umpila
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Young generation speaks Torres Strait Creole [tcs]. Only a few older people know the language well, middle generation has a varying proficiency (Wurm 2007). Elderly only. Shifted to Torres Strait Creole [tcs].

name: Mayeka
Language Use: Shifted to Lingala [lin].

name: Buhid
Writing: Buhid script [Buhd]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.

name: Marind
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, market. Some young people, all adults. Children in towns have passive ability. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Morori [mok], Yei [jei].

name: Sami, Akkala
Language Use: Shifted to Russian [rus] (Salminen 2007). Some also use Kildin Saami [sjd] (Salminen 2007).

name: Koneraw
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Kimaghima [kig]and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Kimaghima [kig].

name: Nete
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 1%. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Most also use Enga [enq]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Sweet 2014).

name: Irarutu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. Bible portions: 1992–2000.
Language Use: Home, community. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Nahuatl, Temascaltepec
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Piratapuyo
Language Development: A non-governmental organization is working in literacy. NT: 1991–2011.
Language Use: Strong use in home. Many also use Portuguese [por]. Also use Tucano [tuo].

name: Komering
Language Development: Radio. Videos.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also useIndonesian [ind]. Also use Musi [mui], in the market.

name: Gelao, Green
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Tày [tyz].

name: Zeeuws
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 99% in Dutch [nld]. Bible portions: 1980–2003.
Language Use: Home. Some of all ages. All also use Dutch [nld].

name: Kamas
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Izii
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Nnam [nbp].

name: Mendankwe-Nkwen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use French [fra].

name: Piaroa
Language Use: Because of strong ethnic identity, the language is conserved to a high degree (Crevels 2007). Also use Maquiritari [mch]. Also use Spanish [spa]. Also use Yabarana [yar]. Used as L2 by Maco [wpc].

name: Mindiri
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Tiéfo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1% in French. 90% of respondents state they would prefer to learn to read and write Tiéfo.
Language Use: Noumoudara-Koumoudara dialect is no longer used. Older adults only. Shifted to Jula [dyu].

name: Kanju
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kisankasa
Language Use: Limited comprehension of other languages. Shifting to Maasai [mas].

name: Awyu (Jair)
Language Use: Home, community.

name: Arabana
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. A 500-page teaching framework for years R-10aimed at revitalizing Arabana was produced in 2004. Augusta Park Primary School was hosting theArabana project around 2007. Mobile Language Team in cooperation with Arabana AboriginalCorporation have produced online language learning resources.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kuanua
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1983.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Tateyama 2006). Many also use English [eng], especially older adults (Martin 2013). Used as L2 by Kandas [kqw], Minigir [bxf], Qaqet [byx], Ramoaaina [rai], Simbali [smg], Tigak [tgc], Tulil [tuh], Ura [uro], Vinitiri [vmg].

name: Jangshung
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Pazeh
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Naga, Moyon
Language Development: Literacy program in progress (1988). NT: 2008.
Language Use: Most also use Meitei [mni] (Singh 1998b). Also use Anal [anm] (Singh 1998b). Also use English [eng]. Also use Monsang Naga [nmh] (Singh 1998b).

name: Varisi
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Wikalkan
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Wik-Mungkan [wim] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Larantuka Malay
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Tupinikin
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Dongotono
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Logir[lqr], Okolie [oie].

name: Gusilay
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2023.
Language Use: Those who have moved to larger urban areas no longer pass the language totheir children (2013 SIL). Used by all. Many also use French [fra], as the language of educationand government (Diouf et al 2017). Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce andinterethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Also use Jola-Fonyi [dyo]. Also use Mandinka[mnk]. Also use Pulaar [fuc].

name: Kenyi
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Prefer to use surrounding languages outside the home; seldom identify themselves as BaKenye. They shy away from their true identity for fear of being marginalized and discriminated against (Abdallah 2004). Mostly home. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Ganda [lug]. Many also use Gwere [gwr]. Many also use Soga [xog]. Some also use Ateso [teo]. Some also use Saamya-Gwe [lsm].

name: Kuijau
Language Use: Also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp]. Used as L2 by Gana [gnq], Keningau Murut[kxi].

name: Tungag
Language Development: Primary education in English [eng]. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Community. Mixed use: church, with Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Roberts 2019). Also use English [eng].

name: Boruca
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Brunca Sign Language [rnb].

name: Lakondê
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Maritime Sign Language
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to American Sign Language [ase]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Zapotec, Xadani
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Zapotec, Tlacolulita
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Vunjo
Language Development: Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous in home area. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Sop
Language Development: Bible portions: 2007–2015.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Budza
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Lingala [lin]. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 by Babango [bbm].

name: Ravula
LITERACY_L2: 40% for Kodagu District, Karnataka; 44% among Adiya in Kerala (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% for Kodagu District, Karnataka; 44% among Adiya in Kerala (2001 census). High motivation for literature, literacy. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also use Malayalam [mal].

name: Li'o
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Palu’e [ple].

name: Tesaka Malagasy
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: All domains, except education, religion, and government. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Kickapoo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 45% in English [eng]. Grammar.
Language Use: In Oklahoma, some youth prefer English [eng]; in Kansas, most or allspeakers are older adults (Golla 2007). Some young people, all adults. Most also use English[eng].

name: Aizi, Aproumu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to French [fra], learned by young people in school.

name: Mawak
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Older adults only. Shifted to Miani [pla] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Huitoto, Nüpode
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1961.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Nonuya [noj].

name: Gagadu
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Tegali
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Xokleng
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Number of speakers is dropping alarmingly due to intermarriage and countless social, political and cultural disruptions (Crevels 2007). Shifted to Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Asmat (Yaosakor)
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Intha
Writing: Unwritten [Qaax], informal and non-standardized use of Myanmar script.
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except education and formal contexts. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Sie
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1909.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Ura [uur].

name: Al-Sayyid Bedouin Sign Language
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by both deaf and many of the 3,500 hearing people in the village. Siblings and children of deaf individuals, and other members of a household (which may include several wives and their children) often become fluent signers. Hearing people there routinely assess their own proficiency, praising those with greater facility in the language. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Hebrew [heb], but usually only in writing (Kisch 2012). Many also use Levantine Arabic [apc], especially hearing signers (Kisch 2012). Some also use Israeli Sign Language [isr], especially deaf signers among themselves (reserving ABSL for interactions with hearing people); learned in school (Kisch 2012).

name: Odut
Language Use: Shifted to Efik [efi].

name: Mingrelian
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Younger generation uses the language less (Salminen 2007). All also use Georgian [kat]. Some also use Russian [rus], in Abkhazia. Also use Abkhaz [abk].

name: Gugubera
Language Use: Shifted to Torres Strait Creole [tcs] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Kunjen [kjn].

name: Chopi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Also use Tswa [tsc], with about 50% of the population understanding it.

name: Kubo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20%. Bible portions:1996–1999.
Language Use: Neutral attitudes. Also use English [eng] (Minnegal and Dwyer 2017). Alsouse Tok Pisin [tpi] (Minnegal and Dwyer 2017).

name: Gan
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant[Hant]. Latin script [Latn], from 1891 to some time after last publication in 1922.
Language Development: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions:1940.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Bidiyo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subjectin some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2021–2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Chesu
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Hlersu [hle].

name: Dhangu
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1977–1982.
Language Use: Fewer children speak the language (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng].Also use Djambarrpuyngu [djr] (Wurm 2007).

name: Dungan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2006–2015.
Language Use: Those under 50–55 speak Russian [rus] as L1. Shifting to Russian [rus].

name: Albanian (Arvanitika)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Youth migrate to Athens and assimilate as Greeks. Some cultural revivalsince the 1980s (Salminen 2007). Older adults only. Shifted to Greek [ell].

name: Kota Marudu Talantang
Language Use: Also use Kimaragang [kqr].

name: Lubu
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Enggano
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Stable presently; threatened long term ifemigration and marriage with other language communities continue. Home, village, market,ceremonies. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Indonesian [ind], incivic, religious, and educational areas.

name: Yucatec Maya Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 0%. Some deaf children from Chicán attend a nearby special education school, which makes little use of signs.
Language Use: Widely used by hearing people as well as deaf. Hearing people speak Yucatec Maya Sign Language and Spanish [spa]. Reportedly well integrated into local society, so presumably used in all domains in which deaf people participate. Used by all. Many also use Spanish [spa], namely the hearing signers (Safar 2021). Many also use Yucatec Maya [yua], namely the hearing signers (Safar 2021).

name: Zialo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Toma [tod], especially the older generation (Babaev 2010).

name: Chhulung
Language Use: Home; mixed use: Friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults.Also use Bantawa [bap].

name: Samo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–25%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1980–2007.
Language Use: Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Tombulu
Language Use: Under pressure from Manado Malay [xmm]. Shifting to Manado Malay [xmm].

name: Dhurga
Language Development: Dhurga is being taught at primary, secondary, and tertiary levels.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Algonquin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught assubject in primary and secondary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Most are bilingual with over 25% multilingual. Religious services,administration, commerce. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also useFrench [fra]. Many also use English [eng]. Also use Southern East Cree [crj].

name: Wares
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Mardin Sign Language
Language Development: Videos.
Language Use: The main factor keeping it in use is the hearing people who have noincentive to learn Turkish Sign Language [tsm]. Family celebrations, such as weddings. Elderlyonly. Most shifted to Turkish Sign Language [tsm] (Dikyuva 2012). Also use Levantine Arabic[apc], by hearing members of the family.

name: Uruguayan Sign Language
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Spanish [spa]. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agencies: Centro de Investigación y Desarrollo de la Persona Sorda (CINDE); Asociación de Sordos del Uruguay (ASUR).
Language Use: Used in schools since 1910. Interpreters required in court. Instruction for parents of deaf children. Committee on national sign language, and an organization for sign language teachers. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Zapotec, Yatzachi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 78%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1971.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mixtec, Diuxi-Tilantongo
Language Use: Spoken at home and taught to children in most Mixtec households. Home, friends, work. Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Senoufo, Cebaara
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: The Tyelibele (Tyeliri) are leather workers scattered throughout the Senoufo area, speaking as L1 the various Senoufo languages where they live. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Komba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. NT: 1980.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Also in church, songs. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kâte [kmg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], particularly in church and for songs. Used as L2 by Kumukio [kuo].

name: Yinggarda
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ngaanyatjarra
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 11%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Kukatja [kux], Pintiini [pti].

name: Kolami, Northwestern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 4%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Home, community. Also use English [eng]. Also use Marathi [mar], but withlimited proficiency. Also use Northern Gondi [gno]. Also use Telugu [tel].

name: Kalanga
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Rapidly being absorbed by Ndebele [nde], though most rural members speakKalanga. All also use Ndebele [nde] (Hachipola 1998). Also use Shona [sna]. Used as L2 bySetswana [tsn], Tsoa [hio].

name: Yahuna
Language Use: Shifted to Macuna [myy].

name: Marúbo
Language Development: Schools taught by Marubo teachers only. Taught as subject in some primary schools in grades 1–5. Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used in texting and on amateur radio. Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por], especially youth. Portuguese is used in communication with outsiders by most men, and understood by some women.

name: Quechua, South Bolivian
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1986–2015.

name: Chenchu
LITERACY_L2: 43% among Scheduled Tribes in Kurnool District; 43%among Chenchu in Odisha (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 43% among Scheduled Tribes in Kurnool District; 43%among Chenchu in Odisha (2001 census). Grammar.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Telugu [tel].

name: Lingua Franca
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Xârâcùù
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Chak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25% Bengali [ben]. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Marma [rmz], especially those living nearBandarban. Also use Bengali [ben]. Used as L2 by Marma [rmz], Tangchangya [tnv], Tippera [tpe].

name: Bole
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Daza [dzd], Hõne [juh], Juu [juu].

name: Gaɓogbo, Guébie
Language Use: With every generation of speakers, French [fra] is used more often andGuébie is becoming a language of secondary use (2015 H. Sande). Some young people, all adults.Many also use French [fra].

name: Yaul
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Even fluent speakers of Ulwa [yla] communicate almost entirely in Tok Pisin (Barlow 2018). Older adults only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Barlow 2018). Some also use Ap Ma [kbx] (Barlow 2018). Some also use Biwat [bwm] (Barlow 2018).

name: Karo (Brazil)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. The children are taught to speak Karo from the beginning. Somealso use Portuguese [por], only in contact situations (Crevels 2007).

name: Pame, Central
Language Development: Bible portions: 1953–1998.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Chochotec
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Shama-Sambuga
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Maria, Dandami
Language Development: Literacy program in progress. Grammar. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Aneityum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 1879.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Barí
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Shumashti
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Northern Pashto [pbu].

name: Tera
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Kuranko
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Ná-Meo
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Gua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka].

name: British Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2011–2022. Agencies: British DeafAssociation (BDA); Deaf EXperience (DEX).
Language Use: Previously vigorous but likely declining, since out of 52,000 deafchildren, only 4,000 are learning BSL (2022 J. Jones, DEX). Regional and national organizationsfor deaf people throughout UK. The Equality Act 2010 requires equal access to public services,so interpreters are required in courts, medical and civil services and proceedings, and privatecompanies. Organization for sign language instructors. Deaf schools established in 1760, withover 100 at the turn of the 19th century. Now there are 23 deaf schools, with 3 of them teachingin English. Schools that teach in BSL have a high number of students with additional needs; somedeaf children with other disabilities attend schools for special education. Most deaf studentsare in mainstream schools, some of which provide some instruction in BSL. Some young people, alladults, declining use in children. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Irish Sign Language[isg].

name: Candoshi-Shapra
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 1979–2010.
Language Use: Language maintenance program and bilingual education program (Crevels2007). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Cree (Swampy)
Writing: Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], uses western finals.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1976.
Language Use: All also use English [eng].

name: Kulango, Bondoukou
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1975–1995.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Abron [abr].

name: Fipa
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Mambwe-Lungu [mgr].

name: Buduma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Grammar. Bibleportions: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Most also use Kanembu [kbl], especially thoseliving near Bol. Many also use Yerwa Kanuri [knc]. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Dama
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Makayam
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Consistent use by children reported in Lewada and Suame. Used by all. Alsouse Bitur [mcc]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Abom [aob].

name: Belait
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Brunei [kxd] (Clynes 2005).

name: Kaurna
Language Development: There is a sustained revival movement, such that there are now speakers who are able to conduct a conversation in the language, and several children are being raised as at least semi-native speakers (2015 R. Amery).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Angika
Language Development: Videos. Texts. Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Use declining (Van Driem 2007). Home, community. Used by all. Negativeattitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially for trade, government, andprayer.

name: Zanaki
Language Use: Children learn Zanaki first. Home, field-work, local gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh], which is learned at an early age by children in multilingual villages.

name: Nahuatl, Central Huasteca
Language Development: Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Guanyinqiao
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Kete
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Massep
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Isirawa [srl], Samarokena [tmj] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Home, religious services. Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Ixcatec
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1950.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Zapotec, Mixtepec
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. NT: 1998.

name: Havu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Shi [shr].

name: Kofyar
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed use: Religion, Market. Used by all. Used as L2 by Jakattoe [jrt], Nteng [nqt].

name: Nukuria
Language Development: Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng] (Davletshin 2017). Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Davletshin 2017).

name: Owiniga
Language Development: Bible portions: 1991.

name: Cua
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1973.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Krikati-Timbira
Language Use: Most also use Portuguese [por].

name: Tupinambá
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used between 1575–1759, developed and utilized almost exclusively by Jesuit priests.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Australian Aborigines Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by hearing Aborigines as alternate form of communication with speakersof other languages, or when silence is required during periods of mourning or hunting. Several,perhaps all, such sign languages are also used by deaf persons in the community.

name: Krenak
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Iresim
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).

name: Lautu Chin
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use HakhaChin [cnh]. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Guduf-Gava
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 1966.

name: Arabic, Shihhi Spoken
Language Development: Some may be literate in Standard Arabic [arb].
Language Use: Not a written language. Most Shihuh speak Shihhi, but the Kumazirah Subdivision of Shihuh, eg. the Dhahuriyin tribe, speak Kumzari [zum].

name: Panasuan
Language Use: Some pressure from Kalumpang [kli], Seko Tengah [sko] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Home, Community; Mixed: Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Seko Tengah [sko]. Many also use Mamasa [mqj]. Some also use Kalumpang [kli]. Some also use Toraja-Sa’dan [sda]. Also use Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).

name: Mapidian
Language Use: Assimilating with Waiwai [way]. Shifted to Waiwai [waw].

name: Folopa
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Anderson 2018). Used as L2 by Dadibi [mps].

name: Mbay
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 4%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1980.

name: Temiar
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: The most secure Aslian language (Bradley 2007a). All domains. Used by all. All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a). Used as L2 by Batek [btq], Jehai [jhi], Lanoh [lnh], Minriq [mnq], Semai [sea].

name: Wik-Me'anha
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kayabí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Low vitality outside of Xingú Park, but high vitality inside where 80% live. Some of all ages. Most also use Portuguese [por], in Xingu Park; many living outside the park no longer speak their native language (Crevels 2007). Used as L2 by Apiaká [api].

name: Zapotec, San Juan Guelavía
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Dictionary. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Abnaki, Western
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1844. At least 3 communities, notablyAbenaki Reserve, are attempting to revive the language.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Limburgish, Limburgan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 99%–100%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2001.
Language Use: Spoken by 50%–90% of the population in Limburg Province. All domains, songs. Used by all. Also use Dutch [nld]. Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Ainu (China)
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Also use Uyghur [uig], with outsiders.

name: Chickasaw
Language Development: Dictionary. Chickasaw community languages classes offered weekly. Fourcourse levels are taught at East Central University in Ada, Oklahoma. There is a monthlylanguage club for youth meeting in Ardmore and Ada, Oklahoma (2017 The Chickasaw Nation).Agency: The Chickasaw Nation.
Language Use: The last speaker in California, Catherine Willmond, died in 2022 (2022 P.Munro). Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Aragonese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Nearly 100%. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2013.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults, few children (Salminen 2007). Most also useSpanish [spa] (Reyes et al 2017).

name: Budik
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Dictionary. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Home, village, work, church. Used by all. Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Some also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Also use Pulaar [fuc].

name: Siraya
Language Development: Grammar. Revitalization efforts since 1990s through Tainan Ping-pu SirayaCulture Association.
Language Use: Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Ngemba
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use Bafut [bfd]. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Used as L2 by Bafut [bfd], Ngamambo [nbv].

name: Vasekela Bushman
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Under 5%. No orthography, literacy, or language development. Radio.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. Many also use Luchazi [lch]. Many also use Nyemba [nba]. Many also use Oshiwambo [kua].

name: Samo, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Higher among Toma. Motivation to read French and Toma Samo is high. A literacy center in Toma teaches Toma. Grammar. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Home, religion, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra], especially users of the Toma dialect. Also use Jula [dyu], especially youth and those who do not speak the Toma dialect. Also use Moore [mos]. Also use Western Niger Fulfulde [fuh].

name: Tai Dón
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1969–1992.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Tai Dam [blt], bilingually among some of the population. Used as L2 by Tai Dam [blt].

name: Sake
Language Use: Shifted to French [fra].

name: Karen, Yintale
Language Development: Some language development activity at Wa Awng village monastery. Dictionary. NT: 2020.
