Language Use: Used in 3 villages; in other villages not used at all. Some young people, all adults. Elderly and young children, not youth. Neutral attitudes. Some also use Kawyaw [kxf], especially the older generation. Also use S’gaw Karen [ksw], especially the youth.

name: Dompo
Language Use: Shifted to Nafaanra [nfr].

name: Lengilu
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Lundayeh [lnd].

name: German, Hutterite
Language Development: Almost all adults are literate in English and Biblical German. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible portions: 2008–2009.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. All also use English [eng]. Most also use StandardGerman [deu].

name: Baramu
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use English [eng].

name: Dezfuli
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Many shifted to Bakhtiâri [bqi]. Many shifted to IranianPersian [pes].

name: Wagi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible portions:2016.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin[tpi] (Bullock et al 2011). Some also use Amele [aey] (Bullock et al 2011). Some also useGedaged [gdd] (Bullock et al 2011). Some also use Isebe [igo] (Bullock et al 2011). Some alsouse Nobonob [gaw] (Bullock et al 2011). Used as L2 by Ngaing [nnf].

name: Foi
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Some of all ages.

name: Fali, South
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Used as L2 by Nimbari [nmr].

name: Mentawai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Most also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Playero
Language Development: Interest in literacy.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Pagibete
Language Development: 400 can read, 50 can write. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous in most families. 20% of Pagibete men marry speakers of other languages, and those women are pressured to learn it. Children of women who marry men from other languages speak it when visiting Pagibete villages. All domains. Positive attitudes. Some also use Ngombe [ngc], mostly through intermarriage. Some also use Northern Ngbandi [ngb], mostly through intermarriage. Also use French [fra]. Also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 by Ngombe [ngc].

name: Yawuru
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. The Walalangga Yawuru Ngang-ga language program is a 2 year program for adults; the town of Broome has incorporated the Yawuru language into its schools; an estimated 1,000 young people were learning the language in 2016.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tepehuan, Southeastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. Learned by Durango Nahuatl [azn] speakers due to intermarriage. Their children usually speak both languages. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Eastern Durango Nahuatl [azd].

name: Islander Creole English
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Spanish [spa], 80% in English [eng]. Grammar.Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Probably L1 of a majority of native islanders who are only about one-sixthof the population. Also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by ProvidenciaSign Language [prz].

name: Yele
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 29%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. 1,100 can read, 450 can write. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1987–1997.
Language Use: Vigorous (Levinson 2015). All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng] (Levinson 2015). Many also use Misima-Panaeati [mpx] (Levinson 2006b). Many also use Sudest [tgo] (Levinson 2006b).

name: Nahuatl, Isthmus-Cosoleacaque
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Kucong
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Gao
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Children increasingly using Cheke Holo [mrn] (Wurm 2007). All domains. Usedby all. Also use Bughotu [bgt]. Also use Cheke Holo [mrn]. Used as L2 by Bughotu [bgt].

name: Bunaba
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Kriol [rop]. Most also use English [eng].

name: Maden
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Dadiya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Bible portions: 2008.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use AdamawaFulfulde [fub]. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Some also useKulung [bbu]. Some also use Tula [tul]. Some also use Waja [wja].

name: Oroch
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Rogo
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Termanu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kupang Malay [mkn].

name: Mohave
Language Development: Dictionary. Language materials, programs for children.
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Araona
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1974–1984.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa], with increasing proficiency.

name: Mbre
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Koro [kfo].

name: Enrekang
Language Use: Home, Work, Community, Religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind]. Some also use Bugis [bug].

name: Miwok, Plains
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Passive knowledge is retained by a few (Golla 2007). All shifted to English [eng].

name: Stellingwerfs
Language Development: Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Kiowa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nyabwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Wè Northern [wob]. Also use Wè Southern [gxx].

name: Cornish
Language Development: Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2019. Religious services held inCornish. Evening classes, correspondence courses, summer camps, children’s play groups,residential courses, and self-help groups. Also groups in London and Australia. There is now afull-time Cornish language nursery school being set up. Since 2009 approximately 50 childrenbetween the ages of 1 and 7 have attended the setting for significant periods of time. Agency:Cornish Language Board.
Language Use: Some people brought up as L1 speakers by language enthusiasts.

name: Canichana
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Massalat
Language Use: Shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Sarikoli
LITERACY_L2: 87% in any language for Tajik nationality (2000 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 87% in any language for Tajik nationality (2000 census). Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Kyrgyz [kir]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Uyghur [uig].

name: Ndai
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Ha
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1960–1962.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also spoken by the Jiji people in the Ujiji area. Used by all.Used as L2 by Tongwe [tny].

name: Khe
Language Use: Shifting to Jula [dyu].

name: Laha (Viet Nam)
Language Use: In one village in Son La province it is moribund, spoken only by those over 50, while in several villages in Lao Cai it is still spoken but potentially endangered (Bradley 2007a). Older adults only.

name: Thuri
Language Use: Thuri groups are nearly absorbed into Dinka groups. Shifting to Southwestern Dinka [dik] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). Also use Luwo [lwo].

name: Nomlaki
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Potiguára
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Orokaiva
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth (Bashkow 2006). Some also use English [eng] (Bashkow 2006). A few also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Bashkow 2006). Also use Aeka [aez] (Bashkow 2006). Also use Binandere [bhg] (Bashkow 2006). Also use Ewage-Notu [nou] (Bashkow 2006). Also use Hunjara-Kaina Ke [hkk] (Bashkow 2006). Used as L2 by Aeka [aez].

name: Alago
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Bible portions: 1929.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Akye [aik], Gwandara[gwn].

name: Tibetan, Khams
Language Development: Modern Literary Tibetan [bod] is the language of literature. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Shuhi [sxg], Western Minyag [wmg].

name: Dogon, Bangeri Me
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jenaama Bozo [bze].

name: Karen, Bwe
Language Development: Some S’gaw Karen [ksw] literacy classes held. Dictionary. Texts. Bibleportions: 1858–1859.
Language Use: Some shift to S’gaw Karen [ksw] or Burmese [mya]. Most domains, exceptchurch. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use S’gaw Karen [ksw],especially in church. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Bunama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 85%. Literacy rate in L2: 85%. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Also use Dobu [dob]. Used as L2 by ’Auhelawa [kud], Duau [dva].

name: Beami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Fleming 2019). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Fleming2019). Used as L2 by Edolo [etr], Odoodee [kkc], Sonia [siq].

name: Qawasqar
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Most shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Doga
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon, and 2000 S. Wurm). Potentially endangered (2000R. Cooper). Some young people, all adults. Also use Anuki [aui]. Also use Dima [jma]. Also useEnglish [eng]. Used as L2 by Dima [jma].

name: Nyamusa-Molo
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Tandia
Language Use: Shifted to Wamesa [wad].

name: Nahuatl (Highland Puebla)
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1979.
Language Use: Also use Totonac languages.

name: Naga, Southern Rengma
Language Development: Literacy in Rengma is higher among older people. Young people are learning English. Bible: 2000.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Nakai
Language Use: Home, local government. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Yimas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Young women grow up speaking Yimas and Tok Pisin, but young men are shifting to Tok Pisin (Foley 2004).

name: Zenaga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Arabic [arb]. Grammar.
Language Use: Mainly adults. Community. Shifted to Hassaniyya [mey]. Many also use Standard Arabic [arb], as the language of government, media, and religion (Ould Ahmed 2012). Also use French [fra], as the language of education, media and government.

name: Khün
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 95% among males; 50% among females. Promoted through monastery education. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1938.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Burmese [mya]. Most also use Shan [shn]. Used as L2 by Lü [khb].

name: Kaang Chin
Language Development: Literacy classes in some communities. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya]. Also use Daai Chin [dao]. Also use Müün Chin [mwq].

name: Ligbi
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka].

name: Wolio
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Former court language of Baubau Sultanate, and surrounding communities; formerly used by nobility in the region. Wolio is declining in the urban center, but being maintained at the rural periphery. Some young people, all adults. Children in villages use Wolio, but city children primarily use Indonesian. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Some also use Muna [mnb]. Some also use Pancana [pnp]. Used as L2 by Busoa [bup], Cia-Cia [cia], Kamaru [kgx], Kioko [ues], Liabuku [lix], Muna [mnb], Pancana [pnp], Taloki [tlk].

name: Croatia Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Agency: Croatian Association of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing(HSGN).
Language Use: Deaf schools. Deaf associations. Used by all.

name: Yeretuar
Language Use: Shifting to Wamesa [wad].

name: Rungtu Chin
Language Use: Also use Burmese [mya], with some shifting.

name: Qaqet
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1996.
Language Use: In one village, Tok Pisin [tpi] is becoming the main language, though thevernacular is still being used there by children with varying degrees of fluency (Hellwig 2019).All domains except church and markets, where there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used byall. Most also use Kuanua [ksd] (Hellwig 2019). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Hellwig 2019).

name: Pomo, Northeastern
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tarahumara, Southeastern
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Gane
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].

name: Guadeloupean Creole French
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Zou
Language Development: Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Naasioi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Stebbins et al 2018). Also use Askopan [eiv]. Also use Motuna [siw]. Also use Sibe [nco]. Also use Terei [buo]. Also use Torau [ttu]. Also use Uisai [uis].

name: Muduapa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–80%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught as subject in primary schools. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Home, community; Mixed use: religion, education. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (van den Berg and Bachet 2006). Also use English [eng] (van den Berg and Bachet 2006).

name: Selepet
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Also use Kâte [kmg].

name: Pima Bajo
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1994.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dogon, Yanda Dom
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Jamsay Dogon [djm]. Most also use Tebul UreDogon [dtu]. Most also use Tommo So Dogon [dto].

name: Usan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b). Used as L2 by Hember Avu [mmi].

name: Psikye
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Many also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Many also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Gavar [gou].

name: Hwana
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013–2023.
Language Use: Also use Ga’anda [gqa]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde[fuv]. Also use Nya Huba [hbb].

name: Karajá
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Portuguese [por] is the dominant language in Xambioá village (Crevels 2007). Many also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Avá-Canoeiro [avv].

name: Chinantec, Ozumacín
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 15 readers, 4 can write. Dictionary. Texts.NT: 2003.
Language Use: Half of parents pass it on to children. Most domains, local administration,commerce, some in religious services. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes.Considered inferior to Spanish [spa], but use continues. All also use Spanish [spa]. Also usePalantla Chinantec [cpa].

name: Toura (Papua New Guinea)
Language Use: Vigorous use in all villages but one, where children learn Tok Pisin [tpi]first, but then learn to speak Toura [don] later (2004 SIL). All domains in most villages exceptchurch, where there is mixed use, and mixed use in all domains with Tok Pisin [tpi] in onevillage. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to positive. Many also useEnglish [eng]. Some also use Abadi [kbt]. Some also use Motu [meu]. Some also use Tok Pisin[tpi].

name: Tulehu
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Mouk-Aria
Language Use: Used as L2 by Anem [anz].

name: Amis
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1997.
Language Use: Also use Japanese [jpn]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 byKavalan [ckv].

name: Garig-Ilgar
Language Use: Shifted to Iwaidja [ibd] (Wurm 2007).

name: Yaeyama
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Buso
Language Use: Shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Yaka (Congo)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1933.
Language Use: Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Pááfang
Language Use: Shifted to Chuukese [chk].

name: Carib, Island
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Sirionó
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. 250 can read, 50 can write. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1977.
Language Use: More and more of the children do not acquire the language (Crevels 2007). Religious services. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Spanish [spa].

name: Rikbaktsa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Worodougou
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Negidal
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Tanglang
Language Use: Most, including children, can speak the language (Bradley 2007a). Home, village, market. Some young people, all adults. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Miwok, Coast
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Tanema
Language Use: Shifted to Pijin [pis]. Shifted to Teanu [tkw].

name: Makhuwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1982–2000.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Koti [eko], Mwani [wmw].

name: Tonga (Nyasa)
Language Development: Bible: 1987.

name: Hupdë
Language Development: Little interest in L1 literacy. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Some also use Portuguese [por], but only less than20% of men. Also use Tucano [tuo], especially men (almost all) and some women.

name: Chontal, Tabasco
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1977.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Quechua, Yanahuanca Pasco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 20%. Texts.
Language Use: Home, community. Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Bauchi
Language Use: Some shifting to Hausa [hau]. Home, Community, Workplace, Special culturalevents. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021k).Some also use Pangu [png] (Decker et al 2021k). A few also use English [eng], especially youngadults (Decker et al 2021k).

name: Hlersu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Being replaced by Nisu [nos] and Chinese (Bradley 2007a). Home, village.Some young people, all adults. Also use Chesu [ych] (Bradley 2007a). Also use Eastern Nisu [nos](Bradley 2007a).

name: Sabanês
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Yace
Language Development: Bible portions: 1980.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Yala [yba]. Also use Bekwarra [bkv]. Also useIgede [ige]. Also use Tiv [tiv].

name: Cimbrian
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: A number of children still learn Cimbrian in Luserna. Some presence inschool and media. More active attempts to promote it in recent decades (Salminen 2007). Someyoung people, all adults. Middle-aged or older in Sette, all ages in Luserna. Also use Bavarian[bar]. Also use Italian [ita]. Also use Venetian [vec], specifically the Trentin variety.

name: Gorap
Language Use: Under strong pressure from the languages from which the majority of itsvocabulary seems to have originated (Wurm 2007). All domains. Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Hértevin
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Northern Kurdish [kmr].

name: Madak
Language Use: In the strongest villages, all ages speak the language, but in other areas not all children learn the language. Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Lindström 2008).

name: Benabena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–50%. Grammar. NT:1983.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 byKamano [kbq], Wagama [abg].

name: Aer
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15% in Sindhi [snd].
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Gujarati [guj]. Also use Saraiki[skr]. Also use Sindhi [snd], especially adult men for common topics. 100% of boys and 25% ofgirls attend Sindhi medium schools. Also use Western Punjabi [pnb], especially adult men ofJikrio Goth, but only for common topics.

name: Nubaca
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some indication speakers want to retain Nubaca. Some young people, alladults. Mixed attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Basaa [bas], particularly thenorthern dialects. Some also use Nugunu [yas]. A few also use Ewondo [ewo], in the CatholicChurch. Used as L2 by Bati [btc].

name: Edolo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Bibleportions: 1997–2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also useBedamuni [beo]. Some also use Huli [hui], men more than women. Some also use Onobasulu [onn].Used as L2 by Onobasulu [onn].

name: Palaung, Rumai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Jingpho [kac]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Also use Ruching Palaung [pce]. Also use Shan [shn]. Used as L2 by Parauk Wa [prk].

name: Mawan
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Batak Mandailing
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Community, Work, Religion. Some young people, all adults.All also use Indonesian [ind], many youth are shifting, especially in urban and migrant areas.

name: Wailapa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%–50% in Bislama [bis]. Only a few people attended church literacy classes offered 20 years ago (2023 J. Vanua).
Language Use: Mixed in all domains. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Bislama [bis]. All children speak it as a second L1. Some also use Akei [tsr]. Some also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Kiae [frt].

name: Muinane
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1981–2009.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa]. All also use Bora [boa]. Used as L2 by Nonuya[noj].

name: Marghi South
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.

name: Maiwa (Indonesia)
Language Use: Home, Community, Work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Bugis [bug]. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Romano-Greek
Language Use: Used only as a secret language. Shifted to Greek [ell].

name: Warwar Feni
Language Development: Bible portions: 2011–2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Darkinyung
Language Development: Many Rivers Aboriginal Language Centre is running the Darkinyung Language Revitalization program (AIATSIS).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mubi
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home, market. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Puari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Pin [wmx].

name: Sira
Language Development: Older church members can read Njebi [nzb]; a few do. Grammar. Bible portions: 1954.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra]. Also use Punu [puu]. Used as L2 by Eviya [gev], Kélé [keb].

name: Kagoma
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, alladults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Kwaio
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kaimbulawa
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; Mixed in other domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Busoa [bup].

name: Lardil
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Iha
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Mor [moq].

name: Quechua, Eastern Apurímac
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–3%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–50% (census: 65%). 40,000 nonliterate adults. 35% of adults, or 20% of total population (census). In rural areas 48% of the adults are nonliterate. Taught as subject in primary schools. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Spanish [spa].

name: Lhokpu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Nepali [npi] (Van Driem 2007).

name: Malawian Sign Language
Language Development: Four deaf elementary boarding schools, the first founded in 1968. Three are historically oralist but have begun to use signing since about 2005; one school was founded in 1994 using Total Communication (Baer 2013). Dictionary. Agency: Malawi National Association of the Deaf (MANAD).
Language Use: Vigorous. Within higher education, Malawian Sign Language is taught but mixed with American Sign Language [ase] and British Sign Language [bfi], for which better documented resources and textbooks are available (2016 M. Sorola), whereas natural Malawian Sign Language is more common in deaf schools with deaf native signers. Used by all. Some also use American Sign Language [ase] (Baer 2013). Some also use Chichewa [nya] (Baer 2013). Some also use English [eng] (Baer 2013).

name: Nancere
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 11%. Literacy rate in L2: 7%. Bilingual schools (Nancere, French) have been created in Delban and Béré, lack of personnel. Bible: 1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Besme [bes], Goundo [goy].

name: Dzando
Language Use: Most also use Lingala [lin], except the oldest women. Other women speakonly market Lingala.

name: Vamale
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Hmwaeke nearly extinct. Under pressure from Fwai [fwa], Cemuhi [cam], and French [fra] (Wurm 2007). Adults only. Shifting to French [fra].

name: Hmong, Western Xiangxi
Writing: Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, 1951–1956, 1958–1969, and from 1978, experimental usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% or more. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous, strong sense of ethnic identity. Most domains except education. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Komi-Permyak
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage. Latin script [Latn], official usage between 1932–1938. Old Permic script [Perm], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: In the Komi-Permyak area there are villages where people speak hardly any other language except Komi-Permyak. Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language, but only in rural areas do they continue to use it as adults. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Pfaelzisch
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Dawawa
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2002.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Some also use Wedau [wed], especially middle-agedand elderly. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Used as L2 by Kakabai [kqf],Kanasi [soq].

name: Dumi
Language Development: Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Pressure to shift to Nepali [npi] in education and communication withoutsiders is strong. Few parents teach Dumi to their children or encourage their children to usetheir language. Home, religion. Mixed use: Friends, work. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. Most also use Nepali [npi]. Also use Koyee [kkt]. Also use Nachiring [ncd].Also use Sampang [rav]. Also use Thulung [tdh].

name: Doondo
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Bolyu
Language Use: Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Djadjawurrung
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Bareli, Palya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 10%. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except education. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Also use Ahirani [ahr]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar].Also use Nimadi [noe].

name: Ayoreo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Spanish [spa], with more younger than olderpeople speaking it, with more men than women speaking it, and more urban dwellers than ruralspeaking it.

name: Umbundu
Language Development: Taught at teacher training colleges in the provinces of Huambo, Bié, and Benguela. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1963.

name: Abu’ Arapesh
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: In the northern villages, Abu’ is being replaced in most domains oflanguage use by Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also useTok Pisin [tpi] (Dobrin 2014).

name: Axamb
Language Development: Bible portions: 1935–2018.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: traditional events, community, religion. Some young people,all adults. Many also use Bislama [bis] (Rangelov et al 2019).

name: Morouas
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Elip
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: High degree of multilingualism among the Nulibie (2014 SIL). Positiveattitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Also use Bulu [bum], especially in the PresbyterianChurch. Also use Ewondo [ewo], especially in the Catholic Church. Also use Numala [mmu]. Alsouse Yangben [yav]. Used as L2 by Numala [mmu].

name: Bauria
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Also use Eastern Punjabi [pan].

name: Kalinga, Lower Tanudan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 82%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%–82%. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Zyphe
Language Development: Some community literacy classes. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Hakha Chin [cnh]. Also use Mara [mrh]. Also use Mizo [lus].

name: Kunimaipa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT: 1990–2002.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Miwok, Northern Sierra
Language Development: Dictionary. Sustained community interest in language revival (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Only one person is conversationally fluent (Golla 2007). All shifted to Enga [enq].

name: Centúúm
Language Use: Shifted to Cham [cfa], Dijim dialect.

name: Serrano
Language Development: Grammar. Active language program at San Miguel (Golla 2007). The San Manuel Band of Mission Indians and Cal State San Bernardino worked out a deal to have a series of Serrano language courses taught at the university during the 2013–2014 academic year, taught by San Manuel’s Serrano Language Revitalization Project staff.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Maidu, Northeast
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Much interest in revitalization (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Biangai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Literacy rate inL1 dropped due to adult reader deaths and the shift of children to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Literacyrate in L2 remains high due to the number of children attending school. NT: 1985.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Australian Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary schools. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions:1999–2002.
Language Use: Some signed interpretation in court, for college students, at importantpublic events. Used by all. Used as L2 by Australian Irish Sign Language [isg].

name: Ari
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Gogodala [ggw].

name: Mixtec, Metlatónoc
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Used by all.

name: Russian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Vserosiyskoe obshestvo gluhih (VOGh, All-Russian Society of the Deaf).
Language Use: Vigorous. Hundreds of residential schools for deaf; some vocational schools, mainly oralist. Deaf associations and athletic clubs. Some interpreters. Some sign language classes for hearing people, mostly in large cities. Organization for sign language teachers. Used by all. Some also use Russian [rus], primarily written.

name: Chhintange
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Nepali [npi]. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts.
Language Use: Home, religion, work; mixed use: Friends. Some of all ages. Neutralattitudes. All also use Nepali [npi]. Some also use Bantawa [bap].

name: Alugu
Language Use: Home, village, market. Used by all.

name: Ngalkbun
Language Development: Dictionary. Diwurruwurru-jaru Aboriginal Corporation made a teacher’s guide and video materials in the late 1990s and early 2000s. Sarah Cutfield ran the Dalabon Oral Histories Project from 2006 to 2008. There are a number of younger ‘semi-speakers’ who are actively engaged in documentary and revitalization work on their language.
Language Use: Few domains. Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng]. Also use Gunwinggu [gup]. Also use Kriol [rop]. Also use Rembarrnga [rmb]. Used as L2 by Djauan [djn], Rembarrnga [rmb].

name: Bukitan
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Chibcha
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Reawakening. The ethnic Muisca survived through theextinction of their language to the present day. In 1988 they began to push for more recognitionand the revitalization of their language and culture. Chibcha is taught to about 150 children inone public school named Jizcamox, which means ‘healing with the hands’.

name: Mwani
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%–40% in Arabic, 30%–40% in Portuguese [por]. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Home, community, religion, commerce. Also use Makhuwa [vmw]. Also use Portuguese [por]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Makwe [ymk].

name: Ndam
Language Development: Bible portions: 2001.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Mulgi [mvh].

name: Chortí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–50%. Grammar. Texts.NT: 1997–2012. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Many also use Spanish [spa].

name: U
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 77%.
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Mangayat
Language Use: Most shifted to Gbaya [krs]. Most shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Cayubaba
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Maridjabin
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007).

name: Batak Dairi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1998.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Dâw
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. The Dâw language is still vital; it is spoken by all Dâw people and learned by children (Epps and Storto 2015). Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Mulao
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Itelmen
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1996.
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to mildly positive.Shifted to Russian [rus].

name: Midob
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Mono (USA)
Language Development: North Fork: informal language classes, dictionary under development; Big Sandy: language classes, wordlists. Each of the communities has sponsored language revival programs (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sisaala, Western
Language Development: Bible portions: 1978.

name: Kintaq
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Yaaku
Language Use: Most ethnic Yaaku speak Maasai [mas] as L1. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Maasai [mas].

name: Zapotec, San Pedro Quiatoni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Education is highly valued. Bible portions: 2000–2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains among adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa]. Bilingualism high near Pan-American highway, decreasing to non-existent the farther away the settlements are. Overall rising percentage of bilingualism, due to more contact with outsiders.

name: Koy Sanjaq Surat
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Mian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: High. Literacy rate in L2: High. Grammar. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Fedden 2012). Some also use Telefol [tlf], especially older men (Fedden 2012). Also use English [eng], especially young people (Fedden and Boroditsky 2012).

name: Simbo
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Roviana [rug], decreasingly.

name: Nila
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Cuicatec, Tepeuxila
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1974.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Mbum
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1965.
Language Use: Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], with rapidly increasing bilingualism. Most also use French [fra], with rapidly increasing bilingualism. A few also use Northwest Gbaya [gya]. Used as L2 by Dii [dur], Northwest Gbaya [gya].

name: Kambaira
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Gadsup [gaj]. Also use Binumarien [bjr]. Also use Kâte [kmg]. Also use North Tairora [tbg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Abar
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Good et al 2011). Also use English [eng].

name: Ngas
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1977.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religious settings, Special cultural events.Some of all ages. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Belning[glb], Bijim [jbm], Fyer [fie], Kusur-Myet [tdl], Pye [pai], Rom [tdk], Tal [tal].

name: Kryts
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Used by 30%–50% of children, but number of child speakers decreasing (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Also use North Azerbaijani [azj], as a literary language.

name: Bebil
Language Use: Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Bebele [beb].

name: Andi
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Russian[rus], for most key domains. Also use Avar [ava], as a literary language.

name: Sonha
Language Use: Home; mixed use: Friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults.

name: Paumarí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995–2010.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Burduna
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Haisla
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Taught in Kitamaat by University of Northern British Columbia since 1994.Adults only. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Anambé
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Tewa (Indonesia)
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Lampung
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Outside of the city, home and village everyday. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Turiwára
Language Use: Shifted to Tembé [tqb] (Crevels 2007).

name: Esselen
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Chagatai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Tepehuan, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Some also use a Tarahumara variety.

name: Mairasi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kowiai [kwh].

name: Vaghri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Gujarati [guj]. Also use Sindhi [snd]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Cakchiquel-Quiché Mixed Language
Language Use: Changing to become more like South Central Kaqchikel [cak]. Adults only.Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Chatino, Eastern Highland
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sena
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Also use Chichewa [nya], in Tâte. Also use Ndau [ndc], in church and communication with outsiders in Beira region, but with limited comprehension. Also use Portuguese [por], with speakers of other languages. Also use Shona [sna], in Tâte.

name: Indonesian, Peranakan
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Indonesian [ind].

name: Arhâ
Language Use: Shifted to Ajië [aji].

name: Labo Phowa
Language Use: Dialects spoken in Kaiyuan County are most endangered. Home, village, market. Some young people, all adults.

name: Remo
Language Development: Texts.

name: Cheke Holo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%–35%. 5,500 can read and write. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. Literature could be used by Blablanga and Gao, Kokota, and Zazao. Home, work, church, commerce, kindergartens. Positive attitudes. Others recognize it and Bughotu [bgt] as the major languages of the island. Also use Bughotu [bgt]. Also use Pijin [pis] (Boswell 2018). Used as L2 by Blablanga [blp], Gao [gga], Kokota [kkk], Zabana [kji], Zazao [jaj].

name: Mattole
Language Development: Grammar. A tribal scholar of Hupa [hup] background has some interest in reviving the language (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nyang'i
Language Use: Adults only. Negative attitudes. All shifting to Ng’akarimojong [kdj].

name: T'en
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Moderately vigorous. Chinese and Bouyei [pcc] in the area also speak T’en. Religion. Some young people, all adults. All ages, but not used by children and young people as often as adults. Also use Bouyei [pcc].

name: Kuikúro-Kalapálo
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Matipuhy [mzo], Yawalapití [yaw].

name: Nyungah
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mixe, Isthmus
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nomatsiguenga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%–40%. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 1980–2008.
Language Use: All children acquire the language. Used by all. Also use Asháninka [cni]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nsenga
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1923–2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Kedang
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Indonesian Sign Language
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Used as L2 by Kata Kolok [bqy].

name: Gelao, Red
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn] (Asian Minorities Outreach 1999a). Somealso use Kim Mun [mji].

name: Dogon, Tene Kan
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Sebat Bet Gurage
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Agob
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Texts. Bibleportions: 2010.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Ririo
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Babatana [baa] (Wurm 2007).

name: Tawbuid, Eastern
Language Development: Grammar. Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Tadyawan [tdy].

name: Tututni
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Ayu
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Hausa [hau].

name: Akawaio
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2010.

name: Ngadjuri
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Mor (Bomberai Peninsula)
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Baham [bdw], Iha [ihp], and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Iha [ihp].

name: Ugandan Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2011–2014. Agencies: Ugandan National Association of the Deaf (UNAD); Uganda National Association of Sign Language Interpreters (UNASLI).
Language Use: Schools for deaf children since 1961. Eleven primary schools and two secondary schools for the deaf, plus about 40 units for deaf children in mainstream schools. Classrooms often use Signed English or Total Communication rather than full UgSL, especially by hearing teachers. Relatively few teachers are deaf. (Lutalo-Kiingi and De Clerck 2015:813) Some schools are residential; education at preschool through vocational and university levels, but not available to all deaf children (Lule and Wallin 2010). Interpreters available for university, social, medical and religious services, courts, parliament, etc. (2008 WFD). Positive attitudes towards UgSL among deaf; negative attitudes still common among hearing (Lule and Wallin 2010). Used by all. Most also use English [eng], with varying degrees of bilingualism, since it is the language of education. 40% are literate in it.

name: Wipi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2001.
Language Use: All domains except church, where it is mixed with various languages,depending on church denomination. Used by all. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especiallyelderly. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Abom [aob].

name: Rengao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1977.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Tifal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 6%. 300 can read and write it. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Preschool. Oral and written use in churches. Oral use in local commerce. Personal letters. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Faiwol [fai]. Also use Telefol [tlf]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Aputai
Language Use: Influence from Galolen [gal] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Many shiftedto Galolen [gal], especially Ilputih dialect speakers. Many shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Alsouse Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Southwest Gbaya
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag]. Used as L2 by Kako [kkj].

name: Gbe, Western Xwla
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gen [gej].

name: Bebele
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra]. Used as L2 byBebil [bxp].

name: Quechua, Yauyos
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Kabyle
Writing: Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng],symbolic use only.
Language Development: Taught as subject in some secondary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.Bible: 2011. Agency: Algerian Academy of Amazigh Language.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra], especially by menin trade and correspondence.

name: Piapoco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–40%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–40%. Dictionary. NT: 1966–2014.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Achagua [aca].

name: Sinasina
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use English [eng] (Rarrick 2017). Also use Kuman [kue] (Rarrick 2017). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with most Tabare young people and some Tabare adults shifting (Ilai 2012), and all Kere young people shifting (Rarrick 2017).

name: Moldova Sign Language
Language Development: Agency: Association of the Deaf of the Republic of Moldova.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Romanian [ron], primarily written.

name: Guanano
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1982–2008.
Language Use: Language stronger in Colombia than in Brazil. Language loss among childrenin São Gabriel da Cachoeira. Due to obligatory mixed marriages, wives speak other neighboringlanguages (such as Desano [des]). They and their children become bilingual over time, addingWanano (2020 L. Drake). Some young people, all adults. Many also use Portuguese [por],especially men. Some also use Spanish [spa], spoken by those living closest to Colombia border.

name: Yuwana
Language Development: Bible portions: 1999.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], especially the southern group, and some among the northern group.

name: Kenati
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Yagaria
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1977–2008.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible portions: 2002.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2015). Used as L2 by Anam [pda].

name: Puruborá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Central Malay
Language Development: Indonesian [ind] preferred for educational and religious materials, but L1 for cultural stories and songs. Mixed preference for health and agricultural materials. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, commerce, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Musi [mui]. Used as L2 by Col [liw].

name: Amahuaca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. Bible portions: 1963–1997.
Language Use: Group disintegrating and losing its identity due to intermarriage withothers. No bilingual education program (2007). Home, village. Adults only. Only children in themost distant communities still acquire the language (Crevels 2007). Negative attitudes. Shiftingto Spanish [spa]. Also use Sharanahua [mcd]. Also use Yaminahua [yaa].

name: Wa
LITERACY_L2: 76% in any language (2000 census, Va nationality).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 76% in any language (2000 census, Va nationality). Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Lahu [lhu]. Also use Lü [khb]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Blang [blr], Lahu [lhu].

name: Cibak
Language Development: Literacy program planned. NT: 2023.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use NigerianPidgin [pcm]. Some also use Bura-Pabir [bwr]. Some also use Marghi Central [mrt]. Some also useNigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Some also use Yerwa Kanuri [knc].

name: Kott
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Xukurú
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Paranawát
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Saposa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Adults only. Positive attitudes. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Koro (India)
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults.

name: Guramalum
Language Use: Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Traveller Norwegian
Language Use: Active use (1997). Older adults only. Shifted to Norwegian [nor].

name: Fulniô
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1968.
Language Use: Adult Fulniô still speak their mother tongue, Yatê children prefer to speakPortuguese [por] (Crevels 2007). Adults only. Shifting to Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Kurumba, Jennu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 46% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census). Attitudes favorable toward literacy.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also use Malayalam [mal]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Pawaia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Grammar. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Haeke
Language Use: Under pressure from Paici [pri] and French [fra] (Wurm 2007). Shifted toFrench [fra].

name: Machinere
Language Use: Shifting to Portuguese [por].

name: Baga Sitemu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%–40% in French [fra], 5%in Susu [sus]. Grammar. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Home, community; some market, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Most also use Susu [sus]. Some also use French [fra], mostly men, boys, and girls.

name: Dogon, Donno So
Language Development: Literacy and numeracy primers available but not in use because governmentlanguage policy only allows Toro So materials. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Dogul Dom Dogon [dbg].

name: Amanab
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: Low. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous use in some villages, while in some villages some young people areshifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (2017 SIL). Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin[tpi]. A few also use Angor [agg]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Powhatan
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yuaga
Writing: Latin script [Latn], developed in the 1930s, only used for writing songs.
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Ende
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009.

name: Northern Muji
Language Use: Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Chamalal
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Avar [ava] and Russian [rus] used in school (Salminen 2007). Home. Someyoung people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava]. Avar is literary language.Also use Russian [rus].

name: Wariyangga
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Busoa
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Adults only. Negative attitudes. Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Most alsouse Wolio [wlo]. Many also use Cia-Cia [cia]. Used as L2 by Kaimbulawa [zka].

name: Bonkeng
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra].

name: Babuza
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Quechua, San Martín
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 1,500 readers, 400 can write. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1992–2008.
Language Use: Little transmission to children. Bilingual parents want their children to learn Spanish. Used by shamans in chants. Protestants use it in singing with published hymnbook. Scattered occasional use in religious services apart from singing. Negative attitudes. Embarrassed to be heard using the language. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dzodinka
Language Development: Bible portions: 1923–1932.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use English [eng], as language of public education.Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].

name: Bagirmi
Language Development: Almost no use in written form. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions:2017.
Language Use: The language of the ancient Bagirmi kingdom. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].Used as L2 by Boor [bvf], Gadang [gdk], Kwang [kvi], Laal [gdm], Miltu [mlj], Sarua [swy].

name: Oya'oya
Language Use: All domains except singing. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Suau [swp]. A few also use Tawala [tbo].

name: Talu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Ethiopian Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Most deaf students learn both theEthiopian Manual Alphabet (based on the Amharic syllabry) and ASL fingerspelling (Tamene 2016).Addis Ababa University offers a BA in Ethiopian Sign Language and Deaf Culture, for traininginterpreters, linguists and deaf teachers in primary and secondary schools. TV. Dictionary.Bible portions: 2011–2014. Agency: Ethiopian National Association of the Deaf (ENAD).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used in mass media. Used by all. Many also use Amharic [amh](Tamene 2016). Some also use English [eng] (Tamene 2016). A few also use Dorze [doz] (Tamene2016). A few also use Gamo [gmv] (Tamene 2016).

name: Bakwé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Wané [hwa].

name: Mískito
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 52%–58%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1999.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Nicaragua English Creole [bzk]. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Mayangna [yan], Spanish [spa], Ulwa [ulw].

name: Kinnauri, Bhoti
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Feroge
Language Use: Shifting to Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Used as L2 by Indri [idr].

name: Padoe
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kitja
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1978.
Language Use: Shifting to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Many also use English [eng].

name: Ninzo
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Ubir
Language Use: Also spoken by Maisin [mbq] and Miniafia (dial. Arifama-Miniafia). Used as L2 by Maisin [mbq], Onjob [onj].

name: Mpiemo
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Some also use Sango [sag].

name: Auye
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. NT: 2016–2020.
Language Use: Influence from Ekari [ekg] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). All domains.Used by all. Most also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. A few also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Chilcotin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught as subjectin primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1993. The Chilcotin Language Committeeoversees teaching of Chilcotin in schools and encourages language and cultural awarenessactivities. Agency: Chilcotin Language Committee.
Language Use: Preferred by adults. Adolescents to elderly. Most children prefer English[eng]. Grandparents pass the language to some children. Many decry the perceived loss ofChilcotin among the younger generation. A small number of English speakers (mostly missionaries)have made attempts to learn Chilcotin. Shifting to English [eng]. Some also use Southern Carrier[caf].

name: Eastern Khumi Chin
Language Development: Literacy classes are being taught in some communities. Orthographies andprimers have been developed by many of the dialect groups. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also useRakhine [rki]. Also use Anu-Khongso Chin [anl], but only by some Asang dialect speakers. Used asL2 by Anu-Khongso Chin [anl].

name: Mahican
Writing: Latin script [Latn], limited usage in the 1660s.
Language Development: Dictionary. Language was extinct for approximately 70 years. Revitalization efforts in the 2010s have created an increasing number of adult L2 speakers and children who are learning Mahican as their L1.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kono (Sierra Leone)
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2008.

name: Gozarkhani
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Talieng
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Alak [alk]. Also use Lao [lao]. Used as L2 by Lavi [lvi].

name: Quechua, Sihuas Ancash
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 28%. Taught as subject in primary schools in 7 rural communities that have been almost isolated until recently. Bible portions: 2017–2023.
Language Use: Young high school graduates and men who have worked on the coast for a while can speak reasonably good Spanish [spa]. The majority of women over 40 in rural communities are monolingual speakers and cannot read or write. In the 3 large population centers, almost nobody speaks the language. In rural areas close to these centers, only the older people speak Quechua (2023 D. Hintz). Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Havasupai-Walapai-Yavapai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1980. Bilingual education programs in Walapai and Havasupai. Yavapai taught in reservation school in Prescott (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All ages for Walapai, Havasupai, middle-aged and older for Yavapai (Golla 2007). All also use English [eng].

name: Somrai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 4%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Bible portions: 1999–2023.

name: Alyawarr
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. Bible portions: 1994–2016.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religious settings, Special cultural events. Some of allages. Language shift has been in progress for multiple generations. Positive attitudes. All alsouse English [eng], but with low proficiency.

name: Nipsan
Language Development: Bible portions: 1982.
Language Use: Religious services. Used as L2 by Korupun-Sela [kpq].

name: Urubú-Kaapor
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 6%. Literacy rate in L2: 6%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some also use Kaapor Sign Language [uks] (Godoy 2020). Some also use Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Lole
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kupang Malay [mkn].

name: Tachawit
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], minor but increasing usage. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng].
Language Development: Bible portions: 1950.
Language Use: A widely used Berber language.

name: Neko
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Also use Nekgini [nkg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Gray et al 2015). Used as L2 by Nekgini [nkg].

name: Lowa
LITERACY_L2: 41% for whole district, includes Thakalis, Nepalis.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 41% for whole district, includes Thakalis, Nepalis. (males 57%, females 28%). Non-formal education. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Some youth totally educated outside language area and may not be able to speak Lhowa. Tibetan [bod] is used in religious domain. Home, friends. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Dolpo [dre], Seke [skj].

name: Apurinã
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Some of all ages. In a few villages, Apurinã is widely spoken (Facundes2000). Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Yoron
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Mixtec, Tututepec
Language Use: Most vigorous in Acatepec, but young people don’t use Mixtec. Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Skagit
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Zapotec, Mitla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–90%. 10% can write it. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous in some families. Shifting to Spanish [spa]. All domains among most adults. Oral use in local administration, commerce, some in media, in religious services. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Magori
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Wurm 2007). Most also use Magi [mgu] (Wurm 2007). Most also use Suau [swp] (Wurm 2007).

name: Kreen-Akarore
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Portuguese [por], passively but only a few men are fluent (Crevels 2007). Many also use Kayapó [txu] (Crevels 2007). Many also use Suyá [suy] (Crevels 2007).

name: Yolŋu Sign Language
Language Development: Videos.
Language Use: Used both by deaf and by hearing who speak a variety of Yolngu languages. Every child acquires signs from birth (Adone et al 2012). Nearly all domains by deaf; as an alternate language by hearing when at a distance, hunting, or when silence is required for ceremonies or in the proximity of sacred objects (Adone et al 2012). Shifting to Djambarrpuyngu [djr] (Adone et al 2012).

name: Wabo
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Aguna
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra], to varying degreesaccording to education level. Also use Gen [gej]. Also use Ifè [ife].

name: Orma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 30% in English [eng], Kiswahili [swh]. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. Closed community. Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Aweer [bob].

name: Kwakum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Less than 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 10% in French [fra]. Grammar.
Language Use: All home, all community, some religion, some education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Also use Kako [kkj]. Also use Koonzime [ozm]. Also use Pol [pmm].

name: Luiseno
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. San Juan Capistrano community has a language revival program for the Ajachemem dialect (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Pankararú
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Libinza
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Meeuwis 1998).

name: Makian, East
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Catawba
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Catawba Nation’s Cultural Preservation Program isengaged in a language revitalization effort (Golla 2007).
Language Use: All shifted to English [eng].

name: Lish
LITERACY_L2: 62% for West Kameng District, males 71%, females 49% (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 62% for West Kameng District, males 71%, females 49% (2001 census).
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Tshangla [tsj].

name: Pumi, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70% for Pumi nationality (2000 census). Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Bai [bca]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Lipo [lpo]. Also use Lisu [lis]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Narua [nru]. Also use Naxi [nxq]. Used as L2 by Namuyi [nmy], Narua [nru], Shuhi [sxg].

name: Canela
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1990.
Language Use: Vigorous. A few also use Portuguese [por].

name: Stoney
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Bible portions: 1970–1973.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Boghom
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Hausa [hau].

name: Persian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Some also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Eñepa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–25%. Grammar. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15–29 years: 70% Setswana [tsn], 50% English; 30–54years: 40% Tswana, 10% English. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Setswana [tsn].

name: Krisa
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Older adults only. Positive attitudes. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Donohue and San Roque 2004).

name: Rama
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Nicaragua English Creole [bzk].

name: Wamey
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Mixed attitudes, from positive among older people to more neutral among theyoung. Most also use Pulaar [fuc]. Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce andinterethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Some also use French [fra], as the language ofeducation and government (Diouf et al 2017).

name: Dadi Dadi
Language Development: In 2015, Dr. Luise Hercus, a leading chronicler of endangered AustralianAboriginal languages, gathered Dadi Dadi and other indigenous groups together to hear recordingsof their heritage languages with the goal of helping the groups ‘maintain and teach theirlanguages to future generations’.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bijori
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Hindi [hin].
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hindi [hin](Bhattacharya 2016). Most also use Sadri [sck] (Bhattacharya 2016). Also use English [eng].

name: Bakaka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra], especially youngpeople. Also use Duala [dua], especially older generations.

name: Marino
LITERACY_L1: Some men over 50 can write Marino.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Some men over 50 can write Marino. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis].

name: Enu
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Ikwo
Language Development: Bible: 2014.

name: Dameli
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], in development. Arabic script,Nastaliq variant [Aran], in development.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Northern Pashto[pbu]. Many also use Urdu [urd], especially men; a few women also use a Pashto variety.

name: Hlai
Writing: Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, used from 1958 to early 1960s and from 1985, small-scale use in literacy.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 88% (2000 census, Li nationality). Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some local Han can also speak Hlai. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Iu Mien [ium]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Cun [cuq], Tsat [huq].

name: Awyu, Asue
Language Development: Bible portions: 1985.
Language Use: All domains.

name: Magoma
Language Development: Swahili [swh] is the national language, so educated people are able to readand write it.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events.Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Swahili [swh]. Many also use Kinga [zga]. Also useEnglish [eng], especially in secondary schools.

name: Lou
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Paluai [blq]. Also use Titan [ttv]. Used as L2 by Paluai [blq].

name: Huitoto, Minica
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1985–2011.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mostly adults; also spoken by youngergenerations; many youngsters and children have only listening comprehension, with limited spokencompetence (2023 J. Echeverri). Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tairora, North
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Texts. NT: 1979–2012.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Asa’a [kyy].

name: Tayo
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra]. Used as L2 by Wallisian [wls].

name: Yug
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: One, Molmo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains except church. Some young people, all adults. Also use TokPisin [tpi].

name: Lara'
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1989.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Guambiano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 2,000 or morereaders, a few can write. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.NT: 2000–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa] (Crevels2007).

name: Pilagá
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1993.
Language Use: Vitality varies with age, education and frequency of Spanish [spa] use (Crevels 2007). Home. Some of all ages.

name: Chut
Language Use: Shifting to Vietnamese [vie].

name: Xipaya
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Phangduwali
Language Use: Many shifting to Nepali [npi].

name: Chippewa
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. NT: 1833–1854. Concertedefforts via language teaching in public schools and other efforts to reverse decline.
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to English [eng].

name: Daats'iin
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Manyalso use Gumuz [guk]. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Sagala
Language Use: Low vitality. Shifting to Swahili. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Doe
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Kwere [cwe]. Most also use Swahili[swh].

name: Sukurum
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Adzera [adz], especially older men. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Sarasira [zsa].

name: Garasia, Adiwasi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Gujarati [guj], but with low proficiency.

name: Bete
Language Use: Shifted to Jukun Takum [jbu].

name: Ersu
Writing: Ersu Shaba Picture Writing [Qaag], used until some time before 2003,limited usage, used in religious ceremonies.
Language Development: About 10 people can read the Shaba script. Videos. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Decreasing from language attrition. Adults only. Neutral attitudes.Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. A few also use Lipo [lpo]. Used as L2 by Namuyi [nmy].

name: Megam
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Atong [aot]. Also use Garo [grt], particularly the Abeng dialect, with most other Garo speakers.

name: Bezhta
Language Development: Russian [rus] used for education. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bibleportions: 1999–2005.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava], as a literarylanguage. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Hinukh [gin], Hunzib [huz].

name: Kioko
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Community and Work. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. A few also use Wolio [wlo].

name: Timbe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Texts. NT: 1987.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, including education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kâte [kmg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Nukna [klt], Weliki [klh].

name: Jinyu Chinese
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant[Hant].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate inChinese and they use that literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Daasanach
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Non-formal literacy classes. Grammar. Texts. NT:2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use Arbore [arv].

name: Kuna, Border
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1993.

name: Senoufo, Palaka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Bargam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 50%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2001.
Language Use: In the inland communties, there is vigorous use among all ages, but in the coastal communties, the children are shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Home, community in the inland villages. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. Also use Garus [gyb]. Also use Matukar Panau [mjk]. Also use Takia [tbc]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Matukar Panau [mjk].

name: Inor
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kalinga, Madukayang
Language Use: Home, community, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Mocoví
Language Development: Bilingual education in 5 schools. Grammar. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Preserved to a higher degree in Chaco Province than in Santa Fe Province; by the early 1990s already less than 50% maintained their ancestral language (Crevels 2007). Home, friends, religion. Some young people, all adults.

name: Bauro
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Bibleportions: 1922.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Koroni
Language Use: Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Also use Bungku [bkz].

name: Kanum, Smärky
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Home, hunting camps. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind], as a trade language or for official purposes. Also use Morori [mok], as a trade language.

name: Arawak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions:1850–1978.
Language Use: Lokono villages show a progressive loss of language (Crevels 2007). Home,friends; mixed use: Religion. Older adults only. Young people no longer interested in learningthe language (Crevels 2007). Mixed attitudes. Most shifted to Dutch [nld]. Most shifted toSranan Tongo [srn].

name: Ofayé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Language revival effort underway.
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por]. Also use Kaiwá [kgk].

name: Gowli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Tikar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. NT: 1989.
