Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra], as language of public education for those in francophone regions. Some also use Bamun [bax]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education for those in North West region. A few also use Kwanja [knp]. Used as L2 by Mbo’ [mtk].

name: Wappo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. The Wappo Language Project initiated Wappo language classes in November 2012.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yinhawangka
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kumalu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Kapin [tbx].

name: Bimin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012).Some also use Oksapmin [opm] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012). Used as L2 by Oksapmin [opm],Setaman [stm].

name: Kokoda
Language Use: Home.

name: Karitiâna
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1981.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Ashe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Not used in formal situations, but widely spoken in the community. Home,market, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Nyankpa [yes]. Used as L2 by KoroWachi [bqv], Nyankpa [yes].

name: Emai-Iuleha-Ora
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1908–1910.

name: Portuguese Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Portuguese Federation of Associations of the Deaf (FPAR).
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Portuguese [por], with widely varying degrees of bilingualism (spoken and written), and it is valued as a written language for access to mainstream society and employment.

name: Siwu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Community-sponsored vernacular literacymaterials are available. Grammar. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Evant
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Tsikimba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Hausa [hau].Dictionary. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Tumak
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Some also use Sar [mwm], especially speakers of Motun dialect.

name: Mawayana
Language Use: Shifted to Waiwai [waw].

name: Zapotec, Miahuatlán
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1971.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Womo
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Puare [pux] (Honeyman 2016). Shifted to Sera [sry] (Honeyman 2016). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Honeyman 2016).

name: Punu
Language Development: Older church members can read Punu; a few do. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1992.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Sira [swj].

name: Sapuan
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Kho'ini
Language Use: Shifting to South Azerbaijani [azb].

name: Xerénte
Language Development: Taught as subject in all primary schools. Grammar. NT: 2007.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. All also use Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Ngarluma
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. The Ngarluma Language Project has focused on the production of materials that promote the spoken language, using media that are widely available in the community (2010).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nimoa
Language Development: Bible portions: 1979–2016.
Language Use: Also use Misima-Panaeati [mpx]. Used as L2 by Sudest [tgo].

name: Asmat, Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 5% in Indonesian [ind]. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 1985.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Mundang
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Grammar. Bible: 1983.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Mambai [mcs].

name: Mixtec, Chazumba
Language Use: 75% scattered over a large area; most villages fewer than 15% can speak Mixtec. Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Langi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: About 50% moderately fluent in Swahili [swh]. Swahili official language for education. Langi used for explanations. L1 literacy program in place. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, local meetings. Used by all. Positive attitudes, but Swahili [swh] preferred in public settings. Most also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Alagwa [wbj], Burunge [bds].

name: Siona
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1982–2009.
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Macaguaje [mcl].

name: Muak Sa-aak
Language Development: Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, church. Used by all. Also use Burmese [mya] (Hall 2013). Also use Lü [khb] (Hall 2013). Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn] (Hall 2013). Used as L2 by Lü [khb].

name: Cora, El Nayar
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999–2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Huichol [hch].

name: Zoque, Francisco León
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1978–1985.

name: Gbayi
Language Use: At risk of being replaced by Banda (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). Most alsouse Sango [sag].

name: Omotik
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Maasai [mas].

name: Matipuhy
Language Use: Shifted to Kuikúro-Kalapálo [kui]. A few also use Portuguese [por], isolated in government protected park.

name: Yerong
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Children learn Yerong first, but acquire Zhuang in school and are fluent by adulthood. Home. Some young people, all adults. Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], with most men also using local southwest variety (Li 2006). Also use Guibian Zhuang [zgn]. Also use Yang Zhuang [zyg].

name: Malasar
LITERACY_L2: 36% in Kerala, 22% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 36% in Kerala, 22% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Use: Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal], especially in Kerala among the few with higher education. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Kasua
Language Development: Some are literate in Fasu. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Home, community. Mixed use: Church, business. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young men. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo],especially adult men. Also use Eibela [ail]. Also use English [eng], especially young people.Also use Fasu [faa]. Also use Gogodala [ggw]. Also use Huli [hui]. Also use Kaluli [bco]. Alsouse Kamula [xla]. Used as L2 by Fasu [faa].

name: Bugawac
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Tok Pisin [tpi],15%–25% in Yabem [jae]. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. Yabem [jae] decreasingly used in religious services, beingreplaced by Bugawac or Tok Pisin [tpi]. Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin[tpi]. Also use Yabem [jae], decreasingly. Used as L2 by Aribwatsa [laz].

name: Ambrym, North
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–3. Bible portions: 2019–2021.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Fanbak [fnb].

name: Yawa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%–50%. Taught as subject in some primary schools in early grades (2012 L. Jones). Dictionary. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Home, market, religious services, school.

name: Shahmirzadi
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Italian Sign Language
Language Development: Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Ente Nazionale per laprotezione e l’assistenza dei Sordi (Italian National Agency for the protection and assistanceof the Deaf, ENS).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Italian [ita], with widely varying degreesof bilingualism (spoken and written).

name: Mikasuki
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1980–1991.
Language Use: Full range of social functions, spoken by tribal leaders, in churches, and at ceremonial groups, as well as in some schools (Golla 2007). Monolinguals only among older adult women. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Muskogee [mus].

name: Dinka, Northwestern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Chadian Sign Language
Language Development: Agency: Church and Christian Mission for Deaf Persons in Chad.
Language Use: 11 deaf schools (2008 WFD).

name: Shuswap
Language Development: Standard orthography has been adopted. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Secwepemc Cultural Education Society has made efforts to revitalize the language through classes at all levels, including an immersion program (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Algerian Jewish Sign Language
Language Use: Now used only among nuclear families that have deaf members (Lanesman andMeir 2012b). Elderly only. Most shifted to Israeli Sign Language [isr] (Lanesman and Meir2012b).

name: Yora
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Bible portions: 2007–2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Pitta Pitta
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Sanumá
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Percentage of monolinguals is still relatively high (Crevels 2007). Some also use Maquiritari [mch] (Crevels 2007).

name: Ayta (Sorsogon)
Language Use: Home. Negative attitudes. Shifted to Tagalog [tgl].

name: Suki
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1981.
Language Use: All domains, except in interaction with outsiders. Used by all. Most also use English [eng] (van Tongeren 2022). Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (van Tongeren 2022). A few also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older men (van Tongeren 2022). Used as L2 by Aramba [stk], Neme [nex].

name: Wamin
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. In 2017, Wamin and other language groups sent representatives to the Indigenous Languages Residency, which provided the groups with resources to revive their languages.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Hula
Language Development: Texts. NT: 1954.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use English [eng] (Van Heekeren 2004). Also use TokPisin [tpi] (Van Heekeren 2014).

name: Beti (Côte d'Ivoire)
Language Use: The last speaker of the pure form of Beti died about 1993. Presently use avariety heavily influenced by surrounding languages. Older adults only. Shifted to Anyin [any].Also use Abure [abu]. Also use Attié [ati]. Also use Mbato [gwa]. Also use Nzema [nzi]. Also useTchaman [ebr].

name: Kunbarlang
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Kriol [rop] (Kapitonov 2019). All also use Maung [mph] (Kapitonov 2019). Most also use Gunwinggu [gup] (Kapitonov 2019). Some also use Djeebbana [djj], especially those living in Maningrida (Kapitonov 2019).

name: Buglere
Language Use: Vigorous in Bocas, but those in Chiriqui are losing the language (Adelaar 2007).

name: Bariai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 41% (adults). Literacy rate in L2: 83% (adults).Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: All domains except church and school, where there is mixed use. Used byall. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Gallagher 2008). Some also use Kove[kvc], especially elderly. Some also use Lusi [khl], especially elderly. Some also useMaleu-Kilenge [mgl], especially elderly. Used as L2 by Amara [aie], Anem [anz].

name: Takwane
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2016.

name: Isoko
Language Development: Bible: 1977.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Eruwa [erh].

name: Mudburra
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Raymond and Eleanor Dixon, a father and daughter, writeMudburra songs for children to teach Mudburra language and culture (2017).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Woria
Language Use: Moribund (2000 S. Wurm). Shifted to Waropen [wrp].

name: Hpon
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Southern dialect extinct; northern dialect moribund; some older peopleremember lexical items but none can speak it (Bradley 2007b). Shifted to Burmese [mya].

name: Karkar-Yuri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Ila
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1915–2016.
Language Use: Home, community, traditional ceremonies. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Korowai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 1% (2007 P. de Vries). Literacy rate in L2:5%–10% in Indonesian [ind]. Grammar. Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events.Used by all. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to positive. Most also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Bonan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 44% (2000 census, Baoan nationality). Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Religion, local administration, home; for Tongren, not used for religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes, except in Tongren. Also use Amdo Tibetan [adx]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Sengele
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Bible portions: 1915–1930.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Many also use Lingala [lin]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Bolia [bli].

name: Avikam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Bible portions: 1957.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Nemi
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Some Children are learning the language (Wurm 2007).

name: Malaccan Creole Malay
Language Use: Intermarriage and out-migration are shrinking the community (Mohammed2009). Shifted to Baba Malay [mbf] (Mohammed 2009). Shifted to Malay [zlm] (Mohammed 2009).

name: Kimbundu
Language Development: Taught at teacher training colleges in the provinces of Luanda, Bengo, Cuanza Norte and Malanje. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1980.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kibala [blv].

name: Alaba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 9%. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades1–4. Taught as a major at the university level. Grammar.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. All also use Amharic [amh] (Crass 2007).

name: Bulgarian Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Union of the Deaf in Bulgaria (UDB).
Language Use: Since 1920. Primary schools for deaf people since 1898. Allowed in schoolsince 1945. Interpreters are required in court; some available for college students. Used byall.

name: Hyam
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kyoli [cry], Zhire [zhi].

name: Koroshi
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Bats
Language Development: Georgian [kat] is literary language. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Modern Bats heavily influenced by Georgian [kat]. Traditional Bats perhapsknown by a few elders (Salminen 2007). Few domains. Adults only. Neutral attitudes. All shiftingto Georgian [kat].

name: Sulung
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], limited usage. Devanagari script [Deva], limited usage. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, village. Positive attitudes. All also use Nyishi [njz]. Some also use Assamese [asm]. Some also use Hindi [hin]. Also use English [eng].

name: Mbu'
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Good et al 2011).

name: Jiiddu
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Spoken by the Jiiddu clan. Ethnic Jiiddu in Bale Province, Ethiopia speakOromo as L1. Also use Maay [ymm].

name: Duma
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Njebi [nzb].

name: Toda
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 66%–79% (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1897–1910.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Bicolano, Southern Catanduanes
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2022.

name: Ngaju
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in Palangkaraya since 1988 (Masinambow and Haenen 2002). Dictionary. Bible: 1858–2005.

name: Kiliwa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: No language retention efforts reported (Golla 2007). Shifted to Paipai [ppi]. Used as L2 by Paipai [ppi].

name: Nyanga-li
Language Use: Shifted to Bangala [bxg].

name: Wintu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. The Living Tongues Institute partnered with the Winnimem Wintu Nation to revitalize Wintu (2012).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Levuka
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Algerian Sign Language
Language Development: Agency: Federation Nationale Des Sourds d’Algerie (FNSA).

name: Romani, Sinte
Language Development: Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Grammar. Bible: 2021.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. All also use Standard German [deu].

name: Aguaruna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–90%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Primaryeducation begins in Awajún. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:1973–2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also used by Spanish and Quechuas in the area. All domains. Oraland written use in commerce. Letters. Used by all. Many also use Spanish [spa].

name: Yaminahua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. 2 bilingual schools sponsored by the Ministry of Education (Crevels 2007). Grammar. NT: 2003–2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Amahuaca [amc].

name: Ilongot
Language Use: Losing speakers in more than half of the villages in Quirino and NuevaVizcaya provinces (2016 R. Gonzales). Much intermarriage with Ilocano [ilo] speakers resultingin Ilocano becoming the preferred household language (2019 L. Zubiri). Mixed: Home, Community,Religion, Work. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tagalog [tgl], especially by thosefrom Nueva Vizcaya who are close to Tagalog- speaking provinces. Many also use Ilocano [ilo],especially those from Quirino Province who are close to Ilocano speakers.

name: Laiyolo
Language Use: Vigorous in Barang-Barang dialect. Some young people, all adults. Mainly adults in Laiyolo; all ages in Barang-Barang. Many also use Selayar [sly]. A few also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kaxararí
Language Development: Most education is in Portuguese [por].
Language Use: Language is threatened, but there is a revitalization movement. Some of all ages. Also use Portuguese [por].

name: Angaatiha
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Uringa 2002). Used as L2 by Susuami[ssu].

name: Alege
Language Development: Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Bete-Bendi [btt]. Many also use Bukpe [ukp].Some also use Ubang [uba]. Used as L2 by Bukpe [ukp], Ubang [uba].

name: Bhilali
Language Use: Many also use English [eng].

name: Brokskat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 56% (2001 census). Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Ladakhi [lbj].

name: Surajpuri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low (2006 M. Toulmin). Different scripts in Nepal and India. Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Harzani
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Bisis
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Machame
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous, especially in their home area. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Gidar
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Many also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Many also use French [fra]. Some alsouse Giziga [giz]. Some also use North Fali [fll]. A few also use Daba [dbq].

name: Sãotomense
Writing: Latin script [Latn], unified alphabet (ALUSTP) for Sãotomense and allnative languages of São Tomé recognized by government in 2010 (2020 M. Bouchard). Incipient useof Sãotomense writing in advertisements and unpublished church music. No published literature.Emerging use in private messaging (2019 D. Eberhard).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Portuguese [por]. Dictionary.
Language Use: Language of national identity, although most commonly used by fishermen,fish-sellers, and agriculturalists. Also used for greetings and music by majority of population(2020 M. Bouchard). Adults only. Used as L1 by many over 50. Late vernacular acquisition hasbeen practiced for several generations where children did not speak their traditional languageuntil adolescence or young adulthood (Eberhard 2019). All shifting to Portuguese [por]. Somealso use Angolar [aoa]. Used as L2 by Angolar [aoa], Kabuverdianu [kea], Principense [pre].

name: Laghuu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Nisenan
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Language program underway at Shingle Springs, with classroom instruction (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mixtec, Itundujia
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Zapotec, Elotepec
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Anmatyerre
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Warlpiri [wbp].

name: Rer Bare
Language Use: Shifted to Somali [som].

name: Mlap
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kemtuik [kmt].

name: Lanoh
Language Use: All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a). Many also use Temiar [tea] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Worimi
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Weekly Gathang (Worimi) language classes were offered atMurrook Culture Centre in Williamtown, NSW, Australia starting in March 2017; revival effortsare being made through use of ‘books, songs, dance, storytelling and language workshops’ (WorimiConservation Lands).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Qabiao
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn] (Asian Minorities Outreach 1999a). Some also use Nung [nut] (Asian Minorities Outreach 1999a).

name: Kham, Gamale
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous in the villages. Home, friends, work; mixed use: Religion. Used byall. Positive attitudes. Also use Nepali [npi], especially the younger generation.

name: Kewa, East
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Yarapea 2006). Some also use Imbongu [imo] (Yarapea 2006). Some also use Witu [wiu] (Yarapea 2006). A few also use English [eng] (Yarapea 2006).

name: Pech
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Use Pech more in Agua Amarilla and La Laguna in El Carbón. Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Sowa
Language Development: Desire for revival, but no formal effort (2023 A. Gray).
Language Use: Shifted to Apma [app].

name: Bena (Nigeria)
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Also use Dera [kna]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Mboi [moi].

name: Minyag, Western
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Some also use Khams Tibetan [khg] (Bai 2019).

name: Kumiai
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Vaagri Booli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Very low. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Most also use Hindi [hin]. Some also use Kannada [kan]. Some also use Marathi [mar]. Some also use Tamil [tam]. Some also use Telugu [tel].

name: Ecuadorian Sign Language
Language Development: LSEC dictionary (Federación Nacional de Sordos de Ecuador). Several deafschools have developed their own LSEC teaching materials. Videos. Dictionary. Agencies:Federación Nacional de Sordos de Ecuador (FENASEC); Fundación Vivir la Sordera Ecuador.
Language Use: While LSEC is the primary language of communication for most deaf people,widely varying degrees of bilingualism (spoken and written) in Spanish [spa] are common. Spanishliteracy for access to mainstream society and employment is valued. All domains. Used by all.Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Jandai
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Ngardi
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yout Wam
Language Use: Home, traditional activities, sports, joking. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Domung [dev]. Many also use Nankina [nnk]. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Djiwarli
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Hebrew, Ancient
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. OT: 916–1488.
Language Use: Liturgical language; Jewish Bible text.

name: Talondo'
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Work, Education, Religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind], for trade and in education. Some also use Kalumpang [kli], specifically the Bone Hau dialect.

name: Campalagian
Language Use: Community, Religion, Work. Some young people, all adults. Positiveattitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Mandar [mdr]. A few also use Bugis[bug].

name: Nyika (Tanzania)
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Dirim
Language Development: Bible portions: 2000.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kamu
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Kato
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Cao Miao
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Daily communication. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn],including in singing.

name: Marquesan, South
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1858–1905.
Language Use: Most shifting to French [fra] (Cablitz 2006).

name: Quechua, North Junín
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997–2008.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Datooga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1%. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Iraqw [irk]. Also use Lambya [lai]. Also use Nyaturu [rim]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Hadza [hts].

name: Gahri
Writing: Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longer in use. Tibetan script[Tibt].
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1911–1923.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng].

name: Kubachi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Russian [rus].

name: Dogon, Jamsay
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Ana Tinga Dogon [dti], Bankan Tey Dogon [dbw],Ben Tey Dogon [dbt], Bondum Dom Dogon [dbu], Nanga Dama Dogon [nzz], Tebul Ure Dogon [dtu],Yanda Dom Dogon [dym].

name: Kháng
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Tai Dam [blt]. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Maquiritari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1970.
Language Use: Some also use Spanish [spa], mostly children (Crevels 2007). Used as L2 by Piaroa [pid], Sanumá [xsu].

name: Chetco
Language Development: Oregon’s Siletz Valley Charter School offered courses in the language forgrades 6 through 8 (2012).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Klao
Language Development: Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Nhuwala
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yugur, West
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85% (2000 census, Yugur nationality). Written Chinese is in use.
Language Use: Decreasing use. Religion, some commerce, oral literature. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Chiangmai Sign Language
Language Use: Moribund. Used only in very limited social situations (Woodward andWongchai 2015). Older adults only. Shifted to Thai Sign Language [tsq].

name: Tandaganon
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Most also use Cebuano [ceb]. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Mmaala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Numala is begining to be taught in the public schools (couple of hours per week). Dictionary. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Even in the village and at home, some children use French [fra]. Speakers do not think French will replace Numala. Religious services. Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra], from school age on. Most also use Nulibie [ekm]. Most also use Yangben [yav]. Some also use Ewondo [ewo], especially in the Catholic Church, generally in singing only. A few also use Bulu [bum], especially in the Presbyterian Church (EPC). Used as L2 by Nulibie [ekm], Yangben [yav].

name: Buraka
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Huarijio
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Veddah
Language Use: Shifted to Sinhala [sin] (Breton 1997).

name: Jurúna
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many also use Portuguese [por], especially the youngergenerations and most men in Xingu Park; about half of the women understand it; elders are lessfluent in it (2019 S. Graham).

name: Baras
Language Use: Shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Kara (Central African Republic)
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Kwaami
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.

name: Sami, Kildin
Language Development: Local literacy effort.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Akkala Saami [sia].

name: Yazgulyam
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Tajik [tgk].

name: Sô
Writing: Lao script [Laoo], used in Laos. Thai script [Thai], used in Thailand.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1980–2004.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Were
Language Development: Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].

name: Mpoto
Language Development: Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Matengo [mgv].

name: Riang (India)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Very low. School attendance is low. Periodicals. Videos. Bible: 2008.

name: Iau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. 200 or more can read and write it. Bible portions: 1985–2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. Speakers of other languages in western Lakes Plains area speak basic Iau. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use Duvle [duv], or a Dani variety. Also use Indonesian [ind], especially young to middle-aged speakers.

name: Jamamadí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Jamamadí 60%–100%; Jarawara 50%; Kitiya 1%. Literacyrate in L2: Jamamadí 75%–100%; Jarawara 5%–15%; Kitiya 5%. L1 literacy learned in the home as anorm. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Religious services, letters. Used by all. Many also usePortuguese [por].

name: Puquina
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Bo (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Yawuno Teneyo [itr].

name: Kayupulau
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon); seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Older adults only. Shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Aduge
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community, Education, Religion, Special cultural events. Some youngpeople, all adults. Most also use Yoruba [yor]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Ebira[igb].

name: Papapana
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Nearly all of the fluent speakers are above the age of thirty (Smith-Dennis 2020). All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Smith-Dennis 2020). Some also use Rotokas [roo] (Smith-Dennis 2020). Some also use Torau [ttu] (Smith-Dennis 2020). A few also use Motuna [siw] (Smith-Dennis 2020). A few also use Teop [tio] (Smith-Dennis 2020). A few also use Terei [buo] (Smith-Dennis 2020). A few also use Tinputz [tpz] (Smith-Dennis 2020).

name: Roglai, Cacgia
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Zimakani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1989.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Burton 1995). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Burton 1995).

name: Bomboli
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Lobala [loq], but only passively.

name: Yi, Axi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low in Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Those early 30s and under are highly proficient in the local Chinese dialect and Mandarin.

name: Caka
Language Use: Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Ipulo[ass].

name: Kiong
Language Use: Shifted to Efik [efi] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).

name: Maewo, Central
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1906.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Kapinawá
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Kalabakan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70% in Standard Malay [zsm].
Language Use: Some Home, Friends, and Work. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Most also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Many also use Northern Tidung [ntd]. Used as L2 by Northern Tidung [ntd].

name: Swedish Sign Language
Language Development: Written Swedish taught in the schools (Svartholm 2010). Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2001–2008. Agency: Swedish National Association of the Deaf (SDR).
Language Use: Used since 1800. First deaf school established in 1809. Deaf schools. Deaf associations. Regarded as bilingual minority. Taught and constituting a subject of research at Stockholm University. Many also use Swedish [swe].

name: Lenca
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Foau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Indonesian [ind]. Grammar. Texts. Bibleportions: 2022.
Language Use: The people want to retain and strengthen their own identity. Home,community, most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Taburta [tbp], passivelyespecially by those over age 35. Also use Indonesian [ind], in school. Used as L2 by Abinomn[bsa], Airoran [air], Taburta [tbp].

name: Afghan Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in at least 3 schools for the deaf in Afghanistan. Taught in primaryand secondary schools. Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, university, work. Used by all.

name: Arikara
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. The annual Mandan-Hidatsa-Arikara SummerInstitute (MHASI) supports Arikara language teachers and encourages new teachers to help inrevitalization efforts. Agency: Mandan-Hidatsa-Arikara Language Project.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sardinian, Logudorese
Language Development: Growing movement to recognize Sardinian as part of linguistic and cultural heritage. Bible portions: 1858–1861.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language but stop using it at school age (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Prestige is equal to Italian [ita] in some contexts, including writing. Also use Italian [ita]. Used as L2 by Catalan [cat].

name: Tenino
Language Development: Language classes at Warm Springs (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Poyanáwa
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Tanapag
Language Development: Language promotion efforts. School children are using it as L2 (2018 J. Ellis).
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Chamorro [cha].

name: Wejewa
Language Use: Used as L2 by Lamboya [lmy].

name: Lamang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions:1995.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Manyalso use English [eng]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Malayo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Kogi [kog].

name: Ajyíninka Apurucayali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Hya
Language Development: Positive attitudes toward literacy.
Language Use: All domains. Shifted to Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Some also use French [fra],as language of public education.

name: Lemerig
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Mwotlap [mlv].

name: Wotapuri-Katarqalai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Shifted to Southern Pashto [pbt].

name: Ketengban
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–40%. Dictionary. NT: 1997–2022.
Language Use: All domains. Used as L2 by Lepki [lpe].

name: Bardi
Language Development: Believe English or Bardi should be written, not Kriol. Government programin primary school. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Many in the younger generation understand Bardi but do not speak it (Wurm2007). Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng]. Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007).

name: Lukpa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–30%. Dictionary. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra], in varying degrees depending oneducation level. Also use Yom [pil]. Used as L2 by Kura Ede Nago [nqk], Yom [pil].

name: Yiddish, Western
Language Development: Bible: 1908.
Language Use: Shifted to Standard German [deu].

name: Riang (Myanmar)
Language Development: Bible portions: 1950.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Shan [shn].

name: Simte
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 67% (2001 census). Bible: 1992.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Morori
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Marind [mrz], a language group which surrounds the Morori, and from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Elderly only. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Marind [mrz] (Evans et al 2018). Used as L2 by Bädi Kanum [khd], Ngkâlmpw Kanum [kcd], Smärky Kanum [kxq], Sota Kanum [krz].

name: Wambaya
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop]. Used as L2 by Gudanji [nji].

name: Lushai
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 82%. Literacy rate in L2: 74% for Manipur (2001 census). Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools in Mizoram state. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1959–1995.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Biate [biu], Chakma [ccp], Hmar [hmr], Hrangkhol [hra], Mara [mrh], Paite Chin [pck], Pankhu [pkh], Pnar [pbv], Ralte [ral].

name: Nahuatl, Ometepec
Language Use: Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Madngele
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.

name: Semandang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Reportedly low (2004 M. Connor). Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Work, education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Most also use Kendayan [knx].

name: Manobo, Dibabawon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 23%. Literacy rate in L2: 23%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Rajah Kabunsuwan Manobo [mqk].

name: Munsee
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1818–1821.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Olo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Elkei [elk], Yis [yis].

name: Kamoro
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Palenquero
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. 10% of those under 25 speak it (1998 A. Schwegler), and younger people are increasingly learning it as L2 and marker of identity (2011 A. Schwegler). Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Bankal
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Juu [juu], Shall-Zwall [sha].

name: Aymara, Southern
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Malagasy, Antankarana
Language Development: Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Jaqaru
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Ministry of Education revitalization program inprogress.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Chincha Quechua[qxc].

name: Korop
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Many also use Efik [efi] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).

name: Aheu
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lao [lao] (Suwilai 1986). Also use Nyaw [nyw] (Suwilai 1986). Also use Thai [tha] (Suwilai 1986).

name: Basa (Cameroon)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1969.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use French [fra], particularly for official purposesand in public media in the Centre, Littoral, South, and West Regions. Some also use Duala [dua].Some also use English [eng]. A few also use Bakoko [bkh]. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].Used as L2 by Bakoko [bkh], Bati [btc], Gyele [gyi], Hijuk [hij], Mbule [mlb], Nubaca [baf].

name: Xinca
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Baima
Language Development: Schools use Chinese. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous among adults in Pingwu and Jiuzhaigou counties. All domains. Someyoung people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Amdo Tibetan [adx]. Also use MandarinChinese [cmn].

name: Duri
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Sherbro
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Sikaiana
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used between 1932–1946, limited usage.
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Pijin [pis]. Many also use English [eng].

name: International Sign
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: L2 users only.

name: Mele-Fila
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. NT: 1993.
Language Use: Also use South Efate [erk].

name: Archi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Used by many children (Salminen 2007).Positive attitudes. Also use Avar [ava], as the literary language. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Ghale, Southern
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, religion; mixed use: Friends, work. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Awtuw
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Declining vitality in Galkutua, Gutaiya, and Kamnom villages. Some young people, all adults. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth.

name: Kuku-Uwanh
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Ulau-Suain
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Nubi
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from positive toneutral, especially among youth. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Ganda [lug]. Manyalso use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Alur [alz], Aringa [luc], Kakwa [keo], Kuku [ukv], Lugbara[lgg], Ma’di [mhi].

name: Zapotec, Petapa
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Avau
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bullock andVan Cott 2015). Some also use English [eng] (Bullock and Van Cott 2015). Used as L2 byAmio-Gelimi [let].

name: Igo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 33%. 2,000 read Igo, 1,000 can write it. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Many shifting to Éwé [ewe] as L1 (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). All domains.Used by all. Also use Akan [aka]. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Ikposo[kpo]. Also use Lelemi [lef]. Also use Sekpele [lip]. Also use Tem [kdh].

name: Lala-Roba
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Also use Ga’anda [gqa]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Dera [kna].

name: Dogon, Dogul Dom
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tommo So Dogon [dto]. Some also use Donno SoDogon [dds].

name: Tsoa
LITERACY_L2: 15–29 years: 25% in Setswana [tsn], 20% in English[eng]; 30–54 years: 2% in Setswana, 2% in English; 55 and older: 0%.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15–29 years: 25% in Setswana [tsn], 20% in English[eng]; 30–54 years: 2% in Setswana, 2% in English; 55 and older: 0%. Agency: Toraa DaoAssociation.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to English [eng]. Shifting to Setswana [tsn].

name: Harari
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Ethiopic script[Ethi], primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 81%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Ngendelengo
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Kuvale [olu], especially among the youth.

name: Tontemboan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1933–2018.
Language Use: Under pressure from Manado Malay [xmm]. Adults only. Shifting to Manado Malay [xmm].

name: Kunduvadi
Language Use: Continued vitality doubtful, due to small population, no separate settlements, living with Malayalis, and similarity to Malayalam [mal]. Home. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal].

name: Catalan Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Theater. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2008–2021.Agencies: Direcció General de Política Lingüística (DGPL); Federació de Persones Sordes deCatalunya (FESOCA).
Language Use: Deaf schools, plus many deaf children integrated in hearing schools, withwidespread oralist emphasis. Many young adults arrive at deaf associations not knowing how tosign. Deaf who have travelled tend to understand the other sign languages in Spain but use theirown. (2017 S. Parkhurst). Some young people, all adults. Some young people, more widespreadamong deaf adults. Some also use Catalan [cat]. Some also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mser
Writing: Latin script [Latn], developed in 1999, experimental usage.
Language Use: In rapid decline (Tourneux 2004). Shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Siberian Tatar
Language Development: Bible portions: 2019–2022.
Language Use: Home.

name: Ngizim
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Some also use Hausa [hau].

name: Uneapa
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Marriammu
Language Use: Elderly only. Many shifted to English [eng]. Many shifted to Murrinh-Patha [mwf].

name: Béte, Guiberoua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT: 1982–2022.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Penan, Western
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Mbonga
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra].

name: Pouye
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20% in Tok Pisin [tpi].Bible portions: 1995–2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especiallymen, boys, and a few women. Used as L2 by Karawa [xrw].

name: Kwanga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Texts. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kulfa
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use Sara Kaba Naa [kwv]. Prefer Sara Kaba Náà [kwv] to Chadian Arabic [shu] as L2.

name: Ashkun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Northern Pashto[pbu].

name: Aari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 8%. Grade 1 pilot classes are in progress. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Dime[dim].

name: Brokkat
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Saparua
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Latu [ltu].

name: Sanye
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kigiryama [nyf]. Also use Kipfokomu [pkb]. Also use Kiwilwana [mlk]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Mashco Piro
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Yabaâna
Language Use: Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Jarnango
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Also use Burarra [bvr]. Also use Djambarrpuyngu[djr]. Also use Gupapuyngu [guf].

name: Mexican Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Spanish [spa].

name: Benggoi
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Lillooet
Language Development: Language courses (1991). Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Active language retention programs at Mount Currie and Lillooet. Older adults only. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Paipai
Language Use: Shifted to Kiliwa [klb]. Used as L2 by Kiliwa [klb].

name: Columbia-Wenatchi
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Colville Confederated Tribes 1995 languagepreservation program focused on documentation, not revitalization.
Language Use: Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Komi-Zyrian
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], official usage. Cyrillic script, Old Church Slavonic variant [Cyrs], in the 19th century, experimental usage. Latin script [Latn], used between 1931–1936.
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary and secondary schools in the Komi republic only. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1990.
Language Use: Komi used in Institute for Language and Literature of the Komi branch of the Academy of Science. Some young people, all adults. Many children learn the language but many stop using it later in life (Salminen 2007). Also use Nenets [yrk]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Mixtec, Coatzospan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Grammar. NT: 2003.

name: Sara Kaba
Language Use: Some also use Sango [sag].

name: To'abaita
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1923.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Pijin [pis] (Lichtenberk 2008). Many also use English [eng] (Lichtenberk 2008).

name: Upper Necaxa Totonac
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Moderate use. Not all parents pass it on to children. Local administration, commerce, religion. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa], especially in schools. A few may also speak Nahuatl.

name: Cakfem-Mushere
Language Development: Texts. Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Home, market, work. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Most also useNigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Mwaghavul [sur]. Used as L2 byNteng [nqt].

name: Sekapan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Nearly 100% in Iban [iba].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Some also use Iban [iba].

name: Daju, Dar Daju
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–50%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subjectin some primary schools. Grammar. Bible portions: 2008–2021.
Language Use: Many also use Chadian Arabic [shu], including all adult males. Used as L2by Kujarge [vkj], Sinyar [sys], Zerenkel [zrn].

name: Nilamba
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1967.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Gitonga
Language Development: Bible: 2016.

name: Chadong
Language Use: Home. Also use Iu Mien [ium]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], specificallythe Guiliu dialect. Also use Yue Chinese [yue].

name: Kukele
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 28%. Literacy rate in L2: 35% in English [eng].Literacy program in progress. NT: 1979.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English[eng].

name: Atayal
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant [Hant]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1974–2003.
Language Use: In active use in some areas. Adults only. Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Saisiyat [xsy].

name: Warrgamay
Language Development: A video with Warrgamay words for river animals is available online; Warrgamay children have alloted classroom time for language learning through stories (2013).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Marghi Central
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1987.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kibaku [ckl].

name: Gelao
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Idon
Language Development: Many read Hausa [hau] well.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 byEjuele [dbi].

name: Lelepa
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1877–1883.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Bislama [bis]. Also use English [eng]. Also use French [fra]. Also use North Efate [llp]. Also use South Efate [erk]. Used as L2 by Eton [etn].

name: Djingili
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop]. Most also use English [eng].

name: Tinputz
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Papapana [ppn].

name: Od
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Punthamara
Language Development: Texts.

name: Amami-Oshima, Northern
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Dehu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1890.
Language Use: Vigorous. Fairly widely spoken church and regional language, although thisuse decreasing with increase of French [fra]. Positive attitudes.

name: Kundal Shahi
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Northern Hindko [hno], especially among the younger generation.

name: Mefele
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], increasingly due to travel. Also use French [fra], increasingly by a few children in school. Also use Mafa [maf], especially children, who learn it at school and market. Used as L2 by Cuvok [cuv], Mafa [maf].

name: Tubar
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Kanowit
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Being absorbed by Iban [iba]. Home. Some young people, all adults. Few or no children use Kanowit dialect. Neutral attitudes.

name: Ambakich
Language Development: 41% of ethnic group (10 years and older) literate in at least 1 language(2000 census).
Language Use: Mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] in home, community. Adults only. Positiveattitudes. Interest in language retention with many parents saying they want their children toknow Ambakich; however, they often speak Tok Pisin [tpi] to them and to each other instead(Potter et al 2008). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Potter et al 2008).

name: Holu
Language Development: Bible portions: 1943–1956.

name: Tangale
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1932–1963.
Language Use: Some parents are not teaching their children to speak Tangale. Some young people, all adults. Also use Hausa [hau], especially young men (ages 18–35) and Muslims; both of these groups prefer it. Used as L2 by Hõne [juh], Piya-Kwonci [piy].

name: Byangsi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home, community. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng].Also use Hindi [hin], with high level of bilingualism and as the medium of instruction inschool. Also use Kumaoni [kfy]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Medumba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Orthography developed in 1926 by Protestantmissionaries. Taught as subject in most primary and secondary schools. Texts. Bible: 1992.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Nda’nda’ [nnz]. A few also useBamun [bax]. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A few also use English [eng]. Used as L2 byGhomálá’ [bbj], Ngomba [jgo].

name: Alabama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Extremely low. Dictionary. Grammar. Revitalizationprogram is underway (Moseley 2010).
Language Use: Home, Senior Citizen Center. Some young people, all adults. Teens toelderly; the language of choice among those 50 and older (Golla 2007). Most also use English[eng]. Some also use Koasati [cku]. Used as L2 by Koasati [cku].

name: Turka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 28% in Jula [dyu]. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2006–2008.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events, Technology and media. Used by all. Most also use Jula [dyu]. Many also use Western Niger Fulfulde [fuh]. Some also use Kpeego [cpo]. Some also use Senara Sénoufo [seq]. Some also use Southern Toussian [wib]. A few also use Northern Dagara [dgi].

name: Domari
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some children in Hatay province reportedly speak the language (2018 B. Herin). All also use Turkish [tur] (Herin 2016). Some also use Levantine Arabic [apc], among the older generation of Hatay province (Herin 2016). Some also use Northern Kurdish [kmr] (Marsh 2008). Some also use Southern Zazaki [diq] (Marsh 2008).

name: Warungu
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. There are attempts at revitalization (Wurm 2007). Tasaku Tsunoda and Mie Tsunoda have been working with community members to revive the language with evidence of success (2010).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Elseng
Language Use: Religious services. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind], but with minimal ability.

name: Solong
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bashkardi
Language Use: Shifting to Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Yir Yoront
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Most ethnic group members speak Torres Strait Creole [tcs]. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ngarla
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Yagnobi
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Russian [rus], as a literary language. Also use Tajik [tgk], as a literary language.

name: Achterhooks
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2002.
Language Use: Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Maca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Spanish [spa]. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. Older adults and preschool children monolingual. Home, village, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Strong cultural cohesion and strong language identity. Also use Spanish [spa], especially among men.

name: Edopi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Bibleportions: 1997–2003.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Kirikiri [kiy].

name: Cashinahua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–30%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1980–2008.
Language Use: All children acquire the language and learn to read and write in bilingualschools (Crevels 2007). Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], and up to 10% have routineproficiency in it.

name: Mopán Maya
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1979–2012.

name: Ngadjunmaya
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. In 2012–2013, a research fellow from AIATSIS worked with Ngajumaya speakers and community members to develop language documentation material and assist with developing language learning programs for young people.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Gurinji
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1981–2013.
Language Use: Language maintenance activities are being undertaken. Children use onlyKriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to English [eng]. Shifting to Kriol [rop].

name: Apali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Adults only. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Creek
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1886–1906. Courses taught at University of Oklahoma. Several schools introduce Creek in first primary years. Has been taught in one elementary school in Florida since 1979 (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Church services, ceremonial speeches. Adults only. Shifting to English [eng]. Also use Mikasuki [mik].

name: Tswa
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1910–1955.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Chopi [cce].

name: Umanakaina
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Ginuman [gnm], Turaka [trh].

name: Kam
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Sallands
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Obanliku
Language Development: Most middle-aged men, youth and children literate in English [eng].
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bete-Bendi [btt]. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Itang [uta]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Also use Tiv [tiv].

name: Mesqan
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Batak Alas-Kluet
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Bata
Language Use: Most Muslims shifted to Fulfulde [fub]. All domains. Used by all. Mixedattitudes. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], especially adults middle-aged and above. Also useHausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Mbula-Bwazza [mbu].

name: Nga La
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya]. Also use Hakha Chin [cnh]. Used as L2 by Thaiphum Chin [cth].

name: Dair
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Guatemalan Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Texts. Agency: Asociación de Sordos de Guatemala (ASORGUA).
Language Use: Vigorous. Many audiologically deaf people learn Guatemalan Sign Language intheir teens or later, after initial exposure to Spanish or the indigenous language of theircommunity; actual proficiency in each language varies widely. Some hearing people sign; mostsuch people have deaf parents or siblings. Used by all. Some also use American Sign Language[ase]. Some deaf visit the United States, educators and missionaries from the United Statesvisit Guatemala; ASL dictionaries available (Parks and Parks 2008). Some also use Spanish [spa](Parks and Parks 2008). A few also use Costa Rican Sign Language [csr] (Parks and Parks 2008).

name: Tabaru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use North Moluccan Malay [max].

name: Darling
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. The Paakantyi Language Circle has beenpromoting their language since 2008; their work has enabled Paakantyi language courses to beadded to several schools, and they have published four children’s stories in partnership withIndigenous Literacy. Aboriginal Educator Noe Lumby worked with some young men within theJuvenile Justice System to create Paakantyi language resources.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mombo Dogon
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Manchu
Writing: Mongolian script [Mong], Manchu style, used since 1599. Mongolian script [Mong], Old Manchu style, no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 50 read and write. Literacy rate in L2: 82%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1835.
Language Use: Long extinct among the mainly urbanized Manchu, but still studied in an ongoing scholarly tradition (Bradley 2007a). Elderly only. Positive attitudes. All shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Daur [dta].

name: Yendang
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Mumuye [mzm]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Kugama [kow], Nyong [muo], Teme [tdo], Yotti [yot].

name: Dorze
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 57%.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Ethiopian Sign Language [eth].

name: Oroko
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Home, church, market. Used by all. All also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes],especially in official settings. Many also use English [eng], in official settings. A few alsouse Bafaw-Balong [bwt]. A few also use Mokpwe [bri]. Used as L2 by Bakole [kme].

name: Dehwari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.

name: Okinawan, Central
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1855–1858.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Japanese [jpn].

name: Suundi
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Kituba [mkw]. 90% of adults speak Kituba. Some also use Lingala [lin].

name: Tsat
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Mandarin Chinese [cmn], particularly the Southwest Mandarin Chinese dialect, for school(Thurgood et al 2014). Most also use Min Nan Chinese [nan], particularly the Hainanese dialect,for school (Thurgood et al 2014). Some also use Hlai [lic] (Thurgood et al 2014).

name: Maninkakan, Kita
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Samba Leko
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Those in Donga now speak Jukun [jbu].

name: Ringgou
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kushi
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013.

name: Eravallan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 42% in Tamil [tam]. Resistant toward literacy inEravallan.
Language Use: Shifting to Tamil [tam]. Most children learn Tamil first. Some youngpeople, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Kerewo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1926–1941.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Di Rosa 2018). Also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Di Rosa 2018). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Di Rosa 2018). Used as L2 by Kibiri [prm].

name: Samay
Language Use: Most also use French [fra].

name: Alta (Northern)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Used as L2 bySouthern Alta [agy].

name: Angal Heneng
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Enga [enq] (Reithofer 2011). Also use Huli [hui](Reithofer 2011). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (San Roque and Loughnane 2012). Used as L2 by Huli[hui].

name: Malagasy, Masikoro
Language Development: Bible portions: 2008–2015.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Taushiro
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Southern Pastaza Quechua [qup] (Crevels 2007). Shifted to Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2007).

name: Ritarungo
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Kriol [rop] (Wurm 2007). Some also use Nunggubuyu [nuy], especially passively around Numbulwar. Also use Djinba [djb].

name: Kabwa
LITERACY_L2: About 75% of Kabwa areliterate in Kiswahili [swh].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: About 75% of Kabwa areliterate in Kiswahili [swh]. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Home, private domains, except if speakers of other languages are present.Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Chin, Mro
Language Development: Some literacy classes. Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All alsouse Rakhine [rki].

name: Luba-Katanga
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1951.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Language loss by some children in Lualaba province. Used as L2 by Kaonde [kqn].

name: Moroccan Sign Language
Language Development: About 95% illiterate (2008 WFD). Dictionary. Agency: National Deaf Federation of Morocco.
Language Use: Deaf schools (mostly day schools); most teachers are hearing and have limited command of a sign language. Deaf adults, ages 15–40 (as of 2014), have the strongest command of a sign language and are using it over the internet in video chats with deaf in other cities or countries. Used by all. A few also use Standard Arabic [arb].

name: Mocho
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home only. Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Bhele
Language Development: Bible portions: 1939–1987.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Also use Nande [nnb].

name: Gongduk
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Lakota
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2006. Teaching programs at every level, preschool through university. Substantial Lakota language program developed at Sinte Gleska College on the Rosebud Reservation. Courses offered in several American colleges and universities (Golla 2007). Agency: Lakota Language Consortium (LLC).
Language Use: Revitalization is quite active, so even though absolute numbers may still be decreasing, there is increasing use among the young L2 speakers (2016 W. Meya). Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Wuvulu-Aua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: All domains except in interactions with outsiders. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Hafford 2014). Some also use English [eng] (Hafford 2014).

name: Ili Turki
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Kazakh [kaz] (Salminen 2007). Shifted toUyghur [uig] (Salminen 2007).

name: Noy
Language Use: Shifted to Sar [mwm] (Boyd 1989).

name: Apinayé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. NT:1999–2010.
Language Use: Most also use Portuguese [por], especially men. All women understandPortuguese even if they don’t speak it (Crevels 2007). Also use Mundurukú [myu].

name: Ngindo
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Ndwewe [nww].

name: Hungarian Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2018. Agency: Hungarian Association of the Deafand Hard of Hearing (SINOSZ).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Hungarian [hun].

name: Mbo (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools.

name: Faifi
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Ladin
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some children learn it but stop using it at school age (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Also use Bavarian [bar]. Also use Italian [ita].

name: Lishana Deni
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1983.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Hebrew [heb].

name: Semimi
Language Use: Many children do not speak it (1991 L. Peckham). Shifting to Papuan Malay[pmy].

name: Phula
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie], with many shifting.

name: Atsugewi
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: No revitalization effort underway (Golla 2007). All shifted to English[eng].

name: Jiba
Language Development: Bible portions: 1927–1950.
Language Use: Shifted to Hõne [juh]. Used as L2 by Hõne [juh], Kugama [kow].

name: Kajaman
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Iban [iba], but with limitedcomprehension.

name: Seko Padang
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Uma [ppk].

name: Jaunsari
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Latin script [Latn], no longer in use. Takri(Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 26%. Hindi preferred for education. Dictionary. Texts.Bible portions: 1895–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, private prayer. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Also use Hindi [hin], with proficiency higher among the educated. Used as L2 by Gujari [gju].

name: Kagate
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Few. Literates in Nepali [npi] have very little trouble reading Syuba in Devanagari script. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1977–2023.
Language Use: Home, friends; mixed use: Religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Some also use Nepali [npi], at home.

name: Karen, Zayein
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Kayan [pdu]. Also use Pa’o [blk].

name: Pumi, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70% for Pumi nationality (2000 census).
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Bai [bca]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Lipo [lpo]. Also use Lisu [lis]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Naxi [nxq]. Used as L2 by Shuhi [sxg].

name: Uripiv-Wala-Rano-Atchin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Litzlitz [lzl], Maragus [mrs].

name: Roviana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Bilua [blb], Dughore [nke], Fagani [faf], Kusaghe [ksg], Simbo [sbb], Touo [tqu], Ughele [uge].

name: Pintupi-Luritja
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Kukatja [kux].

name: Deccan
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage. Devanagari script [Deva].
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Movima
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1967. Strong movement to revitalize the language (Crevels 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Holma
Language Use: Shifted to Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Kendeje
Language Use: Many shifting to Maba [mde]. Many shifting to Masalit [mls].

name: Sobei
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some shifting to Indonesian [ind], especially by children, who are bilingual and tend to prefer it. Some shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Guaraní, Western Bolivian
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1984–2012.

name: Pirahã
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1987.
Language Use: Vigorous use of the Pirahã dialect. No remaining L1 speakers of Múra dialect (Crevels 2012). Some of all ages. Some also use Portuguese [por]. Many have shifted to it. Of those who have not, men understand it, but women understand very little and never use it to express themselves (Crevels 2007).

name: Panim
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Anderson and Harrison 2014).

name: Malavedan
LITERACY_L2: 67%–78% for Kerala, 56% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 67%–78% for Kerala, 56% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census). Grammar.
Language Use: Shifting to Malayalam [mal] in Kerala state, especially in Idukki district. Home, village in Pathanamthitta district. Some of all ages. Negative attitudes, especially in Kerala state. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal], especially in Kerala.

name: Bai
Language Use: Shifting to Ndogo [ndz].

name: Shawnee
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1842–1929.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Akum
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Aghem[agq]. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Most also use Jukun Takum [jbu] (Akumbu and Brye2005). A few also use English [eng].

name: Siriano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 1998–2009.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Spanish [spa], and at least one other Tucanoan language.

name: Plautdietsch
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 95%. Bible: 2003.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng]. Many also use Standard German [deu].

name: Yámana
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1881–1886. There are irregular language workshops (2013 Y. Meroz).

name: Likuba
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Bible portions: 1916.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Lorung, Southern
Language Use: Home, religion, work; mixed use: Friends. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Agta, Remontado
Language Use: Shifted to Tagalog [tgl].

name: Rathawi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 37% for Gujarat (2001 census). Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Chantyal
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Home, villages (Noonan 1996). Not used for singing. Some young people, alladults. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Nhengatu
Language Use: Used as L1 by several ethnic groups in the upper Rio Negro region. In Nhengatu-speaking communities along the Içana and Xié rivers, all children speak it. In communities along the Rio Negro and Vaupes rivers some children speak it (2020 M. Luz). Some young people, all adults. All also use Tucano [tuo], especially those in the Vaupes region where it is replacing Nhengatu [yrl]. Many also use Baniwa [bwi]. Many also use Portuguese [por], especially in communities along the Rio Negro and Vaupes rivers where some youth are using it as their L1. A few also use Spanish [spa], along the Colombia border. Used as L2 by Baniwa [bwi], Baré [bae], Koripako [kpc], Siriano [sri], Warekena [gae].

name: Guntai
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use English [eng], especially older adults (Quinn2014). A few also use Indonesian [ind] (Quinn 2014). A few also use Tok Pisin [tpi].
