name: Mambae
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 2023.
Language Use: Second most widely spoken language of East Timor. Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Lega-Shabunda
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2003.
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Dai
Language Use: Home, gardens, village, ceremonies, religion. Some young people, alladults. Positive attitudes. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], specifically a regional variety, inthe home, garden, ceremonies; children are taught this variety first and later become proficientin the vernacular. Also use Indonesian [ind], primarily in government and Christian religiousdomains.

name: Gusii
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in some primary schools.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1988.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].Also use Kuria [kuj]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Kuria [kuj].

name: Ndoola
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Limassa
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Ngundi [ndn].

name: Assangori
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Chadian Arabic [shu], although at low proficiency level.

name: Babine
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible portions: 1978.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to English [eng].

name: Bitur
Language Development: Bible portions: 2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Abom [aob], Makayam [aup].

name: Chimila
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–2%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Grammar. Texts. Bibleportions: 2009.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Very few children speak Chimila. Also useSpanish [spa].

name: Neyo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Binumarien
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. L1 literacy ishigh among older and elderly adults, but very low among young people. NT: 1983–2018.
Language Use: Home, community, church. Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Manyalso use Gadsup [gaj] (van Dasselaar 2019). Used as L2 by Asa’a [kyy].

name: Batak Angkola
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1991.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Hemba
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.

name: Parya
Language Use: Despite small population, it is spoken more vigorously amongst themselves than larger language groups. Uzbek and Tajiki men who marry Parya women learn Parya and become assimilated into the community. Home. Also use Tajik [tgk].

name: Even
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], two orthographical standards, limited usage.Cyrillic script, Old Church Slavonic variant [Cyrs], in the 19th century, experimental usage.
Language Development: Some literature available. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions:1880–2001.
Language Use: Strongest in Sakha (Beryozovka, Sebyan-Kyuly) and Northern Magadan Oblast(Seymchan). Evens learn the language of ethnicities around them, and switch to that languagewhen a non-Even is present. Few domains. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Russian[rus]. Also use Koryak [kpy]. Also use Yakut [sah]. Used as L2 by Chukchi [ckt], NorthernYukaghir [ykg], Southern Yukaghir [yux].

name: Valman
Language Use: Home. Adults only. Most adults over the age of 30 understand the language; most children under the age of 20 do not (2014 M. Dryer). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Juang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 21% (2001 census). Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Some also use Odia [ory], especially men and educated.Also use English [eng].

name: Manusela
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Sou Nama [tlt].

name: Yinchia
Language Use: Endangered. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Shan [shn], particularly a southern dialect. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Ganang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Hausa [hau].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some youngpeople, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Also use English [eng].

name: Ijo, Southeast
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1956.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Bukiyip
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. NT:1994–2003.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use English [eng],especially young people.

name: Palawano, Southwest
Language Use: Also use Filipino [fil], but with low comprehension.

name: Karuwali
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Mazatec, Ixcatlán
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kire
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Akukem [spm].

name: Sapo
Language Development: Bible portions: 1956.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Yabem
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1924–1980.
Language Use: Used as a church language by Lutherans in the Huon Peninsula region since1890. Served as medium of instruction for 30,000 students following World War II (Streicher1982), but now eclipsed by Tok Pisin in use as a lingua franca. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi],especially young people (Ross 2002a). Used as L2 by Bugawac [buk], Central Buang [bzh], Kapin[tbx], Karnai [bbv], Mesem [mci], Musom [msu], Numbami [sij], Safeyoka [apz], Sio [xsi], Tami[tmy].

name: Aimol
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%–70%. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Home, church. Most also use Meitei [mni]. Also use English [eng].

name: Squamish
Language Development: Many literates. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Band-sponsored language program has offered K-12 classes in public schools for 25 years (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Ceremonial contexts, community gatherings. Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Guguyimidjir
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1940.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng].

name: Tsuvan
Language Use: Home, friends, work, ceremonies. Some young people, all adults. Interviewees stated that the youth from both villages speak Fulfulde more than Tsuvan (Brye 2001). Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], with diglossia. Also use French [fra], as medium of instruction in school.

name: Atorada
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Wapishana [wap].

name: Kuuku-Ya'u
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Most children speak Torres Strait Creole [tcs] as L1 (Wurm 2007). Shifted to Torres Strait Creole [tcs]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Dani, Lower Grand Valley
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1988–1994.

name: Kenga
LITERACY_L2: Men: 15% or below in French [fra], 1% in Arabic [arb]; women: below 1%.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: Men: 15% or below in French [fra], 1% in Arabic [arb]; women: below 1%. Roman Catholic songbook and prayer book. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Less than ten Bolong dialect speakers used Kenga as L1 in 2002. Positive attitudes. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Mawa [mcw], Tamki [tax].

name: Waskia
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1985–2014.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Ross 2004a). Used as L2 by Matukar Panau [mjk].

name: Ishkashimi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Most children now become literate in Dari[prs] because they attend school. Grammar.
Language Use: Some parents used Dari [prs] with their children to provide them withbetter chances in school. Only now do the people realize that this might cause the language tobecome endangered. About half the households use Ishkashimi with the younger generation. Home,village. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Dari [prs].

name: Bokobaru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Literacy materials available. Low motivation.Dictionary. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baatonum [bba]. Also use English[eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Yoruba [yor].

name: Lombi
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools.

name: Sar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Gulay [gvl], Kwang [kvi], Ngam [nmc], Noy [noy], Tumak [tmc], Tunia [tug].

name: Burundian Sign Language
Language Development: Taught in primary schools. Agency: Association Nationale des Sourds du Burundi (ANSB).
Language Use: Four deaf schools (2020 F. Hamissi).

name: Fwe
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Many also use English [eng] (Gunnink 2018). Alsouse Afrikaans [afr], especially among older generations (Gunnink 2018). Also use Kuhane [sbs](Gunnink 2018). Also use Lozi [loz] (Gunnink 2018). Also use Totela [ttl] (Gunnink 2018). Alsouse Yeyi [yey] (Gunnink 2018).

name: Zauzou
LITERACY_L2: 68% in any language (2000 census, Nu nationality).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 68% in any language (2000 census, Nu nationality). Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Used less by young people and children. Positive attitudes. Some also use Lisu [lis]. Also use Central Bai [bca]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Haveke
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Paici [pri] and French[fra] (Wurm 2007). Shifting to Paicî [pri].

name: Subanen, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 86%. Literacy rate in L2: 86%. Few local grade schools. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Home, church, community, group discussion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cebuano [ceb], acquired through intermarriage, community, school, travel, and some homes and churches.

name: Zhaba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low. Many in elder generation illiterate. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Most use Chinese or Tibetan varieties even when they speak with other Zhaba people. Personal communication among themselves. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Regarded as useless; users strongly desire to better learn Chinese varieties.

name: Dominican Sign Language
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: There are regional sign variations across the Dominican Republic. However,the sign language is most standardized along the center of the country from Santo Domingo toPuerto Plata. There are deaf schools, clubs, associations, and churches that use Dominican SignLanguage. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dalmatian
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used between 13th and 19th centuries.
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Arabic (Cypriot)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Greek script [Grek],no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], revitalization efforts in one town.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Revitalization effort producing written materials.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Greek [ell] (Walter 2020). Also use StandardArabic [arb]. Also use Turkish [tur].

name: Czech Sign Language
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Czech Republic Union of Deaf and Hard ofHearing (UDHH).
Language Use: Used since 1786 when deaf schools began. Dialect used in schools differsfrom adult use outside. Interpreters required in court; some provided for college students andimportant public events. Used by all.

name: Miu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Parkwa
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Wuzlam [udl].

name: Haruku
Language Use: Shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Ngombe (Central African Republic)
Language Use: Some also use Sango [sag].

name: Waboda
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Bible portions: 2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Sian
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Some young people, all adults. Few to half the children speak Sihan.

name: Parenga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 17% (2001 census).
Language Use: Shifted to Adivasi Oriya [ort].

name: Bora
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Bilingual primaryand secondary schools but classes generally taught in Spanish [spa]. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:1982–2008.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa]. Also use Murui Witoto [huu]. Usedas L2 by Murui Witoto [huu], Ocaina [oca], Resígaro [rgr].

name: Tlapanec, Tlacoapa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Odoodee
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Literacy increasing as more children learn to read. Bible portions: 2002–2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Kamula [xla]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Kaluli [bco]. A few also use Bedamuni [beo]. A few also use Gebusi [goi]. A few also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Wadi Wadi
Language Development: In 2015, Dr. Luise Hercus, a leading chronicler of endangered Australian Aboriginal languages, gathered Wadi Wadi and other indigenous groups together to hear recordings of their heritage languages with the goal of helping the groups ‘maintain and teach their languages to future generations’.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Nukumanu
Language Development: Videos. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Feinberg 2009). Also use English [eng] (Feinberg 2009).

name: Costa Rican Sign Language
Language Development: Dictionary. Agency: Asociación Nacional de Sordos (ANASCOR).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Seediq
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Many also use Min Nan Chinese [nan]. Some also use Japanese [jpn], especially elderly individuals.

name: Mixtec, Santa Lucía Monteverde
Language Development: Bible portions: 2012.
Language Use: Children learn Mixtec and Spanish [spa] in Agua del Toro and Ocotlán. In most other villages Spanish is becoming the main language of use. Home, friends, work. Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa], but writing skills are marginal.

name: Comorian, Ngazidja
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Bible portions: 1976–2007.

name: Tibetan Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Adults only. Mostly those too old to have attended the Lhasa Special School, which opened in 2000, or other deaf schools which teach Chinese Sign Language [csl] (Hofer 2024). Shifting to Chinese Sign Language [csl].

name: Bunoge Dogon
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Fulfulde [ffm] is replacing Bunoge among younger generations (2012 J.Heath). Some young people, all adults. Most also use Maasina Fulfulde [ffm]. Many also useBamanankan [bam].

name: Bussa
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], trial orthography since 2017, not yet officiallyapproved.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 14%. Grammar.
Language Use: Still used in the homestead in many communities but more frequently by theolder generation. Is threatened by other infiltrating languages, particularly Zayse [zay] andAmharic [amh]. Also use Amharic [amh], with the younger generations shifting. Also use Dirasha[gdl]. Also use Gamo [gmv]. Also use Konso [kxc]. Also use Zayse [zay], with the youngergenerations shifting. Used as L2 by Dirasha [gdl].

name: Maa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Mpuono
Language Development: Bible portions: 1935–1951.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work. Some of all ages. Shift happening in many villages, on major and secondary roads, as well as town of Idiofa. In villages away from towns or main roads, transmission is secure (2023 M. Gibson). Most also use Kituba [ktu]. Many also use Lingala [lin], increasing, especially among young people. Some also use French [fra].

name: Chatino, Zacatepec
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Spoken in Zacatepec. Virtually extinct in Juquila with 2 older adult menspeakers. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Wandala
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: 200–300 read Wandala. Grammar. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Vame [mlr], Wuzlam [udl], Yerwa Kanuri [knc].

name: Nanggu
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Mixed use: All domains, with Pijin [pis]. Shifting to Pijin [pis]. Also use Äiwoo [nfl] (Vaa 2013). Also use Nalögo [nlz]. Also use Natügu [ntu].

name: Monimbo
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Selaru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Grammar. Bible portions: 1997–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Badeshi
Language Use: Shifted to Torwali [trw].

name: Parachi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Dari [prs].

name: Tjungundji
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Noon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 70% in French [fra], 10% in Wolof [wol]. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Children learn Noon first. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Most also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012).

name: Kanum, Ngkâlmpw
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, hunting camps. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian[ind], as a trade language or for official purposes. Also use Morori [mok], as a trade language.

name: Mwimbi-Muthambi
Language Development: Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kimîîru [mer]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Miyakubo Sign Language
Language Use: Home, market, social events, fishing boats. Used by all. Used by all deafpeople in the community.

name: Kota (India)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75% (2001 census). Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Positive attitudes. Also use Badaga [bfq]. Alsouse English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also use Tamil [tam], with outsiders. It is themedium of instruction in school, so most children are bilingual in it.

name: Hanunoo
Writing: Hanunoo script [Hano], used in love songs and correspondence. Latin script[Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Awa (China)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 76% (2000 census).
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Saraveca
Language Use: Shifted to Chiquitano [cax].

name: Chinantec, Ojitlán
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1968–2003.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kwadi
Language Use: Used regularly (Westphal 1971); no remaining speakers (Winter 1981).

name: Zapotec, Chichicapan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%–50%. NT: 1990.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Istriot
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Young speakers in Bale and middle-agedspeakers in Galižana; elsewhere speakers are elderly (Salminen 2007).

name: Pashayi, Northwest
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Northern Pashto [pbu].

name: Kitsai
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sri Lankan Sign Language
Language Use: 14 deaf schools. Several sign languages used by different schools.

name: Yulu
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Many also use Sango [sag]. Also use Gbaya [krs].

name: Jurchen
Writing: Jurchen script [Jurc], developed in 1120, last inscription dated 1526.
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Umiida
Language Use: Moribund (McGregor and Rumsey 2009). Shifted to English [eng].

name: Para Naga
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Apache (Jicarilla)
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1965.
Language Use: More than 300 semi-speakers (Golla 2007). Most shifting to English [eng],which is preferred by children and most young adults.

name: Mobilian
Language Development: Dictionary.

name: Yagwoia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5% among Iwalaqamalje. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. NT: 2009.
Language Use: All domains. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], as trade language with outsiders. Used as L2 by Kawacha [kcb].

name: Juray
Language Development: Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Home, community. Older adults only. Many shifted to Odia [ory] (Andersonand Gomango 2016). Many shifted to Sora [srb] (Anderson and Gomango 2016).

name: Pahlavani
Language Use: Shifted to Dari [prs].

name: Ban Khor Sign Language
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Nyaw [nyw], especiallyhearing individuals (Nonaka 2009). Many also use Thai Sign Language [tsq], especially deafchildren, who learn it at residential deaf schools.

name: Barzani Jewish Neo-Aramaic
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Hebrew [heb]. Some also speak other Neo-Aramaiclanguages.

name: Lipo
Writing: Lisu (Fraser) script [Lisu], no longer in use. Miao (Pollard) script [Plrd], used from about 1910, primary usage among Christians.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: High in Chinese. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], even between speakers of different dialects of Lipo. Used as L2 by Ersu [ers], Hani [hni], Lamu [llh], Namuyi [nmy], Northern Pumi [pmi], Southern Pumi [pmj].

name: South West Bay
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 1905.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Some children not learning the language. Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Nasarian [nvh].

name: Manda (Tanzania)
Language Use: Vigorous. Low domains and to discuss high domains. For high domains, Swahili [swh] is used or mixed with Manda. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Mese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Over 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Also use Kâte [kmg]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Yabem [jae]. Used as L2 by Musom [msu].

name: Mixtec, San Miguel El Grande
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1951–2010.

name: Punan Bah-Biau
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Dharuk
Language Development: Darug Custodian Aboriginal Corporation is working on the establishment of community language centre in order to run language classes and support the Primary School and High School (2007 AIATSIS).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Zia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Binandere [bhg]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Binandere [bhg], Yekora [ykr].

name: Karaboro, Eastern
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 1994–2020.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Ambrym, Southeast
Language Development: Dictionary. NT: 2015.

name: Nar Phu
Language Development: Many men are literate in Classical Tibetan. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: If work is locally oriented, then Nar-Phu used; Tibetan [bod] is the liturgical language, but one can hear Nar-Phu in certain contexts during religious festivals. Used by all. Many also use Central Tibetan [bod], especially men.

name: Miltu
Language Use: Shifted to Bagirmi [bmi].

name: Nottoway
Language Development: Language revival efforts underway.
Language Use: Ethnic group members now speak English [eng]. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Umbu-Ungu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. NT: 1995–1998.
Language Use: Home; Mixed Use: Community. Used by all. Mixed attitudes, from positive to negative. Also use Enga [enq] (Malone 2004). Also use Melpa [med] (Malone 2004). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Malone 2004).

name: Hmong, Luopohe
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, community, market. Used by all.

name: Bwaidoka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%. Literacy rate in L2: 65%–75%. Texts. Bibleportions: 1934–2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Main language used in church, along with Dobu [dob].Oral and written use in local commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Dobu [dob].Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Iamalele [yml], Kaninuwa [wat], Koluwawa [klx], Minaveha[mvn], West Goodenough [ddi].

name: Larike-Wakasihu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous use in Larike and Wakasihu, weak in Allang. Only older adults inAllang, Allang Asaude, Uraur, and Urusana still know Allang, but apparently do not use it. Someyoung people, all adults. Younger generation prefers regional or national language. Also useIndonesian [ind].

name: Dhaiso
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Swahili [swh].

name: Arabic (Uzbeki)
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Few ethnic group members speak Arabic. No diglossia with Standard Arabic[arb]. Shifted to Northern Uzbek [uzn].

name: Pashayi, Northeast
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Northern Pashto [pbu].

name: Jaya
Language Use: Shifting to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Bugan
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All ethnic Bugan speak Bugan. Used by all. Many also use MandarinChinese [cmn], especially adults but few middle aged and older people and children who have notattended school. Also use Chuanqiandian Cluster Miao [cqd]. Also use Nong Zhuang [zhn].

name: Judeo-Italian
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Very few speakers are fluent (Salminen 2007). More commonly spoken 2generations ago. Used in Passover song. Perhaps 4,000 occasionally use elements of it in theirspeech, about 10% of Italy’s 40,000 Jews. Shifted to Italian [ita].

name: Ali
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: All also use Sango [sag].

name: Gepo
Language Development: Bible portions: 1913.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Setaman
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Bimin [bhl] (Bullock and Van Cott 2010). Some also use Faiwol [fai] (Bullock and Van Cott 2010). Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bullock and Van Cott 2010).

name: Wadjiginy
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Kriol [rop].

name: Cahuarano
Language Use: Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Galela
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Nyahkur
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Most men and the youngergeneration are literate in Thai [tha]. Literacy in Thai [tha] transfers easily to Nyah Kur.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1996.
Language Use: Few children can speak Nyah Kur. Nearly extinct in Phetchabun and NakhonRatchasima provinces (2007 SIL). Home. Adults only. Mixed attitudes. Some have strong identitylinks to their language, others prefer to identify themselves as Thai [tha] (2002 P. Suwilai,2007 SIL). Shifting to Thai [tha]. Some also use Northeastern Thai [tts] (Statezni et al 2007).Also use Lao [lao].

name: Chol, Tumbalá
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1977–2009.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Used as L2 by Lacandon [lac], Tzeltal [tzh].

name: Gogo
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible: 1962–2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. Church meetings. Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh], in churchmeetings. Used as L2 by Kw’adza [wka].

name: Clallam, Klallam
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Taught as a heritage language K-12 at a handful ofschools on the Olympic Peninsula of Washington state, including at Port Angeles High School.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Geme
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Gadsup
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Videos. Texts. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Asa’a [kyy],Binumarien [bjr].

name: Khengkha
Writing: Tibetan script [Tibt], Uchen style, unofficial usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Dzongkha [dzo]. Bible portions: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, commerce, local politics, traditional religion, but not allowed in school. Used by all. Negative attitudes, especially toward Gonphu village speaking style. Lower Kheng considered most backward; Middle Kheng most prestigious. Also use Bumthangkha [kjz], especially those who travel or have intermarried. Also use Dzongkha [dzo], but only by educated people and some older men. Also use English [eng], especially some (10%) of the educated young people. Also use Kurtokha [xkz], especially those who travel or have intermarried. Also use Nepali [npi], especially some (20%) of those who live near the road. Also use Nyenkha [neh], especially those who travel or have intermarried. Also use Tshangla [tsj], especially those who travel east of Kheng area.

name: Wangganguru
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Barasana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 45%. Literacy rate in L2: High, in Spanish [spa].Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2001–2010.
Language Use: Home, Community, Work, Education, Religion, Special cultural events. Usedby all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Carapana [cbc]. Many also use Macuna [myy]. Many alsouse Spanish [spa]. Many also use Tatuyo [tav]. Many also use Tucano [tuo]. Used as L2 byCabiyarí [cbb], Waimaha [bao].

name: Miriwoong Sign Language
Language Development: Videos.
Language Use: Older adults only.

name: Oro Win
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Pakaásnovos [pav].

name: Aruamu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Akukem [spm].

name: Mal
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Bedoanas
Language Use: Adults only. Children do not use the language anymore (Wurm 2007). Shiftingto Indonesian [ind].

name: Asmat, Casuarina Coast
Language Use: Home, community.

name: Alladian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Kalabra
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Religious services.

name: Paraguayan Sign Language
Language Development: Literature. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Deaf associations and religious meetings use LSPY in their formal proceedings and deaf people use LSPY in their casual interactions. Used by all. Also use Brazilian Sign Language [bzs], especially some living near the Brazilian border, as L2.

name: Quechua, Santa Ana de Tusi Pasco
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Salumá
Language Use: Shifted to Trió [tri]. A few also use Portuguese [por].

name: Maninkakan, Eastern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. N’Ko script[Nkoo], used in Guinea.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1932–1966.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Guinea Kpelle [gkp], Kakabe [kke], Kono [knu], Konyanka[mku], Kuranko [knk], Lele [llc], Mano [mev], Manya [mzj], Northern Kissi [kqs], Pular [fuf],Toma [tod].

name: Runga
Language Use: Neutral attitudes. Many also use Chadian Arabic [shu], especially men (Boyd 1989).

name: Banda (Indonesia)
Language Use: All domains. Shifting to Kei [kei]. Used as L2 by Kei [kei].

name: Jamaican Sign Language
Language Development: Videos. Texts. Agency: Jamaica Association for the Deaf (JAD).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used as primary means of instruction in schools run by theJamaican Association of the Deaf (Cumberbatch 2012a). Used by all. Some also use American SignLanguage [ase]. A few also use Konchri Sain [jcs]. Younger deaf in the Top Hill area, St.Elizabeth Parish, use Jamaican SL as L1 and Konchri Sain as L2 (Cumberbatch 2012b). Used as L2by Konchri Sain [jcs].

name: Serui-Laut
Language Use: Shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Yankunytjatjara
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Also use Pitjantjatjara [pjt].

name: Koraku
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 26% in Chhattisgarh (2001 census). NT: 2022.
Language Use: Kodaku in Jharkhand shifting to a local variety of Sadri [sck]. Kodaku in Chhattisgarh retaining their mother tongue more. In Chhattisgarh most use Kodaku in home and village and it is used by children with each other. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Kurux [kru]. Also use Sadri [sck].

name: Kandawo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Many also use Kuman [kue], especially olderadults. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Shoshoni
Language Development: Idaho State University offers a 2-year language program (Golla 2007). Literacy is increasing. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1986. Strong interest in revitalization but efforts are scattered with little coordination (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mostly adults 50 and older but a few children learn the language as L1 in Duck Valley and Gusiute communities (Golla 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Wandamen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1937–1994.
Language Use: Most also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Dusner [dsn], Tandia [tni], Yeretuar [gop].

name: Bhatri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 38% in Chhattisgarh [hne] (2001 census). NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, religion. Positive attitudes. Some also use Hindi [hin], inMadhya Pradesh. Also use Halbi [hlb]. Also use Odia [ory], in Odisha. Used as L2 by Duruwa[pci], Halbi [hlb].

name: Pangwa
Language Development: Grammar. Bible portions: 2016–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. Low domains and often to discuss high domains. Swahili [swh] used in high domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh], but not much.

name: Nyokon
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra].

name: Sami, Ume
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Bible: 1811.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Swedish [swe].

name: Anfillo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to West Central Oromo [gaz] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).

name: Saluan, Coastal
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some children only use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Andio [bzb].

name: Yeyi
LITERACY_L2: Age 15–29: 95% Setswana, 68% English; age 30–54: 33% Setswana, 20% English; age 55 and older: 33% Setswana, 6% English.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Age 15–29: 95% Setswana, 68% English; age 30–54: 33% Setswana, 20% English; age 55 and older: 33% Setswana, 6% English. High motivation for literacy. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: 43% who learned Yeyi from their parents said they speak Yeyi best, 57% said they speak Setswana [tsn] best. 12% of respondents said they speak only Yeyi to their children, 9% speak Yeyi and Setswana to their children. Some young people, all adults. In some villages, children speak Yeyi. In many villages used only by those over 40. All also use Setswana [tsn]. Also use English [eng], especially young people who have attended secondary school.

name: Palawano, Central
Language Use: Also use Filipino [fil], but with low comprehension.

name: Kalam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1992–2009.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Pawley et al 2011). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pawley et al 2011).

name: Gunditjmara
Language Development: The Victorian Aboriginal Corporation for Languages had released apps in theApple App Store with stories and language learning materials in Gunditjmara.

name: Warnang
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Mekeo
Language Development: Grammar. Texts. NT: 1998.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng]. A few also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bahinemo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Dye and Dye 2012).

name: Cree (Moose)
Writing: Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans], uses eastern finals.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1876.
Language Use: Language in decline at Moose Factory; many young adults have little or noknowledge of it (Golla 2007). All also use English [eng].

name: Mbara (Chad)
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Lashi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Grammar. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Jingpho [kac].

name: Kerek
Language Use: Shifted to Chukchi [ckt].

name: Quechua, Pacaraos
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Mongolian Sign Language
Language Development: Agency: Mongolian Sign Language Center (MSLC).
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Some also use Halh Mongolian [khk] (Geer 2012).

name: Mwera (Chimwera)
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Alsea
Language Development: Grammar.

name: Lenakel
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1900–1902.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kwamera [tnk].

name: Machiguenga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1976–2018.
Language Use: Quechua and Spanish [spa] are replacing Matsigenka in some areas where children no longer acquire the language. Not endangered on the Manu River, where teachers from Urubamba River area are interested in implementing a formalized bilingual education program (Crevels 2007). Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Caquinte [cot], Nanti [cox], Yine [pib].

name: Awyu (South)
Language Use: All domains.

name: Desano
Language Development: Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1984–2011.
Language Use: Many also use Portuguese [por]. Also use Tucano [tuo], more often thanDesano.

name: Siliput
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bungu
Language Development: No L1 literacy, many Bungu live very remotely and education levels are low. Boys may leave school early (12 years old) to enter fishing business. Bible portions: 2022–2023.
Language Use: Home, village, farming. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Tiwi
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1979–2000.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng].

name: Tohono O'odham
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools; schools of the Tohono O’odham Nation teach the language. Taught at the University of Arizona (Golla 2007). Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Vigorous in the west and south. Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng].

name: One, Northern
Language Development: Bible portions: 2013–2018.
Language Use: All domains except church. Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Malay, Cocos Islands
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use English [eng].

name: Lom
Language Development: Dictionary.
Language Use: Lom dialect seriously endangered or moribund (2000 S. Wurm).

name: Providencia Sign Language
Language Development: No use of fingerspelling.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. As of 2019, deaf people ranged in age from below 10 to above 80 (Omardeen et al 2021: 7). Some also use English [eng], some deaf and hearing users (Omardeen et al 2021). Some also use Islander English Creole [icr], some deaf and many hearing users (Omardeen et al 2021). Some also use Spanish [spa], some deaf and many hearing users (Omardeen et al 2021).

name: Minriq
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Temiar [tea] (Bradley 2007a). Also use Malay [zlm].

name: Cruzeño
Language Development: Although only Ineseno [inz] descendants are organized as a recognizedtribe, there is interest among all Chumash descendants in restoring their traditional cultureand language. Chumash Living Language Revitalization Project was established in 1999 (Golla2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Ngom
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1910.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra].

name: Pela
Language Development: Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. All aremultilingual, speaking other languages from within the cluster natively, as well as some Chineseand a local Tai language (Bradley 2007a).

name: Mócheno
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Italian [ita].

name: Zula
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Chakali
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. In Tuasa, only older people; in othervillages children also use it. Also use Wali [wlx]. Chakali seem to accept the Wali language,but do not approve of it being used in their homes.

name: Wawa
Language Development: All Wawa are literate in Arabic [arb]. Some are literate in French [fra]. Grammar.
Language Use: Still transmitted to children, but much mixing with other languages (2014 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Many also use French [fra]. Many also use Vute [vut]. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Neku
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Ajië [aji], Tiri [cir] and French [fra] (Wurm 2007). Shifted to French [fra].

name: Judeo-Crimean Tatar
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Rarely used even by the elderly who know it (Salminen 2007). Elderly only.Shifted to Ukrainian [ukr].

name: Toram
Language Use: Shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Mann
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Also use Dan [dnj], especially outside home area of Nimba County. Also use Liberian English [lir]. Used as L2 by Dan [dnj].

name: Sakao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. No systematic adherence to one orthography. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1905–1949.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. Some also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Ngen [ssv].

name: Yarluyandi
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Orejón
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1967–1976.
Language Use: Younger generation has abandoned the language and most of the Maijuna culture (Crevels 2007). Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Iduna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Grammar. NT: 1983–2003.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng] (Kassell and Lambrecht 2012). Some also use Dobu [dob] (Kassell and Lambrecht 2012). Used as L2 by Dima [jma], Kaninuwa [wat], Koluwawa [klx].

name: Thachanadan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% (2004 survey). Literacy rate much lower than state literacy rate.
Language Use: Some use Malayalam [mal] in home and village, esp. with children. Use is less among youth. Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to positive attitudes, with youth having more negative attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal].

name: Ho Chi Minh City Sign Language
Language Development: Bible portions: 2018–2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Cineni
Language Use: Traditional ceremonies and announcements. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng], especially in local government area meetings(Hamm 2004a). Some also use Hausa [hau], especially the youth (Hamm 2004a).

name: Pannei
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Most also use Mandar [mdr].

name: Kukatja
Language Development: Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng]. Also use Martu Wangka [mpj]. Also use Ngaanyatjarra [ntj]. Also use Pintupi-Luritja [piu]. Also use Walmajarri [wmt]. Used as L2 by Martu Wangka [mpj].

name: Greek (Cappadocian)
Writing: Greek script [Grek], used primarily at a scholarly level.
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Shifted to Greek [ell].

name: Labo
Language Development: Bible portions: 1905.
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Kalmyk; Oirat
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], adopted in 1924, used in Russia and Mongolia. Mongolian script [Mong], Todo style, used in China.
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools in the Republic of Kalmykia only. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1827–2009.
Language Use: 91% speak it as L1. Some young people, all adults. A few children learn the language. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], in religious domains. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Migaama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–60%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Dictionary. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except to Arabs in market, French to teachers in school. Oral use in administration, some in church, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Chadian Arabic [shu], men with high proficiency, women with low proficiency. Some also use French [fra]. Also use Standard Arabic [arb], which is taught in school.

name: Gorakor
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Broome Pearling Lugger Pidgin
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Gitxsan
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1906.
Language Use: Small number of families in which children and young people are fluentspeakers. Taught in public schools in some communities and at the University of Northern BritishColumbia (Golla 2007). Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng]. Allalso use Nisga’a [ncg].

name: Serudung Murut
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Standard Malay [zsm].
Language Use: Home, Friends, Work; Mixed use: Religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Sabah Malay [msi]. A few also use Standard Malay [zsm].

name: Kaitag
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Russian [rus].

name: Mbembe, Cross River
Language Development: Grammar. NT: 1985–2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Legbo [agb].

name: Shixing
Language Development: Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], in temples. Also use Khams Tibetan [khg]. Also use Lahu [lhu]. Also use Naxi [nxq]. Also use Northern Pumi [pmi]. Also use Southern Pumi [pmj].

name: Borôro
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Grammar. Texts.NT: 1993–2019.
Language Use: Spoken by one-third of the ethnic group (2024 F. Gerardi). Some youngpeople, all adults. Children are actively taught Bororo in Tereza Cristina and Perigara statesonly and, even there, they do not consistently use it (2024 F. Gerardi). Also use Portuguese[por], increasingly by children and young people, especially in Meruri.

name: Jju
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literacyprogram in progress. NT: 1982–2011.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: O'du
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Vietnamese [vie].

name: Jumli
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion, work. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Someembarrassed by their own speech when speaking to standard Nepali [npi] speakers. Also use Hindi[hin]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Awara
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Children’s literacy schools. Literature. Bibleportions: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].Also use Wantoat [wnc], but mostly passively.

name: Suba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. NT: 2010. Revitalization efforts have been very effective.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Dholuo [luo]. Also use English [eng].

name: Sorbian, Lower
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1796–1824.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Standard German [deu].

name: Hindustani, Caribbean
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio.TV. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1997–2010.
Language Use: All domains, except education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useDutch [nld]. Also use Sranan Tongo [srn]. Used as L2 by Dutch [nld].

name: Kalaallisut
Language Development: Taught in some primary schools in early grades only. Taught as subject in afew tertiary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1900.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Danish [dan].

name: Rapanui
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–90% in Spanish [spa]. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2018. Agency: Academia de la Lengua Rapa Nui.
Language Use: Was vigorous, but now declining. Young generation losing interest in the language. Revival efforts are in progress (Wurm 2007). Home, education. Some young people, all adults. All also use Spanish [spa].

name: Vagla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Wali [wlx].

name: Gen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Aguna [aug], Aja [ajg], Akebu [keu], Ginyanga [ayg], Kpessi[kef], Western Xwla Gbe [xwl].

name: Chhattisgarhi
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Grammar. NT: 2005–2012.
Language Use: Nearly all domains. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also useHindi [hin], but with low proficiency. Also use Odia [ory]. Used as L2 by Bhunjia [bhu], EasternMuria [emu], Far Western Muria [fmu].

name: Uma' Lung
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Decreasing due to mixed marriage and urbanization. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Also use Mainstream Kenyah [xkl], particularly Lepo Tau’ dialect.

name: Tatana
Writing: Latin script [Latn], developed in the mid-1980s.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literature. Periodicals. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Sabah Tatana Cultural Association (STCA), KadazanDusun Cultural Association (KDCA).
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Some young people, all adults. Some children and adults; all elderly. Positive attitudes. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Many also use Brunei [kxd]. Many also use Sabah Bisaya [bsy]. Many also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp]. A few also use Hakka Chinese [hak]. Used as L2 by Brunei [kxd], Klias River Kadazan [kqt], Papar [dpp], Sabah Bisaya [bsy], West Coast Bajau [bdr].

name: Agta, Central Cagayan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 6%. Literacy rate in L2: 6%. Literature. Grammar.Texts. NT: 1992–2018.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Filipino [fil], inschool. Also use Ilocano [ilo], with all non-Agta speakers.

name: Kenyah, Wahau
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. Neutral attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], in education. Also use Mainstream Kenyah [xkl].

name: Tsakhur
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Russia. Latin script [Latn], used in Azerbaijan.
Language Development: Studied as a subject in some local schools (Sackett 2017). Literature. Newspapers. Videos. Bible portions: 2003–2012.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most children are speakers (Salminen 2007). Most also use North Azerbaijani [azj] (Sackett 2017). Many also use Russian [rus] (Sackett 2017).

name: Lingao
Language Development: Chinese characters read with Lingao pronounciation. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Other speakers in the area use it. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Min Nan Chinese [nan], especially urban residents and in secondary schools. 200,000 speak the Hainan dialect.

name: Ipiko
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous, but Ibigo dialect is nearly extinct. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. A few also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Croatian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools.Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1831–1999.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Standard German [deu].

name: Morisyen
Language Development: Taught in most primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Generally used at home while standard French [fra] is more commonly used in the workplace. Neutral attitudes. Lower prestige than French [fra] or English [eng]. Also use French [fra].

name: Waimaha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–40%. Letter writingbetween communities. Written and oral forms used in religious services. Taught as subject inprimary schools. Literature. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Passed on from fathers to children. Most domains, home, family, religion,local commerce, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Spanish [spa],especially in school and with government officials. Also use Barasana-Eduria [bsn]. Also useCarapana [cbc]. Also use Macuna [myy]. Also use Tatuyo [tav]. Also use Tucano [tuo]. Also useTuyuca [tue]. Also use Wajiara [yui]. All use 2 to 4 of the other languages due to marriagepatterns across language boundaries. Children speak the language of each parent, but identifywith the father’s language. Used as L2 by Tuyuca [tue].

name: Kuanyama
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Most adults can read it, while most youth cannot. To date, it is used as a written standard by the Mbadja people as well as the Kwanyama people (2014 SIL). Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–6 in Cunene province. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1974.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Nkumbi [khu], Northwestern !Kung [vaj].

name: Kikuyu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. 95% of thechildren are in school. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Newspapers.Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1951–1965.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, social gatherings, business. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Gichuka [cuh], Kiembu[ebu], Kitharaka [thk].

name: Betawi
Language Development: Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar.
Language Use: Two villages in the Jakarta area, Condet and Setu Babakan, show a markeddecline in the use of Betawi by adults as well as by young people, shifting to Indonesian [ind](Lauder and Lauder 2017, Nur 2021). Functions as a Low variety in a diglossic situation, but hascovert prestige when used by the upper class. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes,some young people have negative attitudes towards the language (Nur 2021). Many also useIndonesian [ind] (Nur 2021).

name: Mixtec, Tezoatlán
Language Development: Because of different efforts by SIL, government officials and Mixtec organizations, more people are learning to read and write Mixtec. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Almost all speak Mixtec to their children, except in 2 towns where Spanish [spa] is mostly used. All domains, mostly oral; written use in church. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa], especially youth.

name: Idoma
Language Development: Radio. TV. Grammar. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Adult education.

name: Rangpuri
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2008–2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Kurux [kru], Mundari [unr], Oraon Sadri [sdr], Santhali [sat], Sauria Paharia [mjt].

name: Majang
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used until 1990s. Latin script [Latn], official in Gambela Region.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 21%. Taught in primary schools in the early grades in Gambela state. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Shabo [sbf].

name: Daju, Dar Fur
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials produced. Literature.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Arrernte, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught as subject inprimary schools. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng].

name: Kelabit
Language Development: Community mother-tongue based play school started in 2007 in Bario. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1965.
Language Use: Decreasingly used by the youth. All domains in the village. Positive attitudes. Most also use Lundayeh [lnd].

name: Sudest
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–70%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–90% in Misima-Panaeati [mpx], Rifao [nmw], or English [eng]. When possible, used by community schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Also use Misima-Panaeati [mpx]. Also use Rifao [nmw]. Used as L2 by Yélî Dnye [yle].

name: Min Nan Chinese
Writing: Bopomofo script [Bopo], used since 1998, used in Taiwan. Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Katakana script [Kana], used between 1895–1945, once used in Taiwan. Latin script [Latn], used since 1850.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate in Chinese and they use that literature. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1933.
Language Use: Other speakers use it for commerce. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Yue Chinese [yue]. Used as L2 by Lingao [onb], She [shx], Tsat [huq].

name: Hausa
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], called Ajami. Braille script [Brai].Latin script [Latn], used since 1880, primary usage.
Language Development: Taught as subject in most primary and secondary schools in grades 1–9.Taught in some primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some tertiary schools.Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1932–2015.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Abishi [pcn], Adara [kad], Agatu [agc], Ahwai [nfd], Ajiri[afo], Ajiya [idc], Akye [aik], Alago [ala], Aninka [aqk], Arum [aab], Asu [aum], Atoro [tdv],Atsam [cch], Awak [awo], Ayu [ayu], Baangi [bqx], Bacama [bcy], Bade [bde], Bali [bcn], Bankal[jjr], Bassa-Kontagora [bsr], Bata [bta], Bauchi [bsf], Beele [bxq], Belning [glb], Bena [yun],Berom [bom], Bijim [jbm], Bille [bil], Bina [byj], Bisã [bqp], Boghom [bux], Boko [bqc],Bokobaru [bus], Bo-Rukul [mae], Bu [jid], Bu [zbu], Buli [uly], Bura-Pabir [bwr], Bure [bvh],Burku [bbt], Cahungwarya [nat], Cakfem-Mushere [cky], Cara [cfd], Cha’ari [cxh], Choogen [tgd],Cicipu [awc], Cineni [cie], Cishingini [asg], C’Lela [dri], Dadiya [dbd], Dass [dot], Daza[dzd], Deno [dbb], Dera [kna], Dir-Nyamzak-Mbarimi [nzr], Dirya [dwa], Duguri [dbm], Duhwa[kbz], Duya [ldb], Dyarim [dyr], Dza [jen], Eastern Acipa [acp], Ebira [igb], Eggon [ego],Ejuele [dbi], Etkywan [ich], Fali Muchella [fli], Firan [fir], Fungwa [ula], Fyer [fie], Ga’anda[gqa], Gade [ged], Galambi [glo], Gamo-Ningi [bte], Ganang [gne], Gbagyi [gbr], Gengle [geg],Gera [gew], Geruma [gea], Giiwo [kks], Goemai [ank], Gude [gde], Gurmana [gvm], Guruntum-Mbaaru[grd], Gwa [gwb], Gwak [jgk], Gwamhi-Wuri [bga], Gwandara [gwn], Gyaazi [gyz], Gyem [gye], Gyong[kdm], Hasha [ybj], Hausa Sign Language [hsl], Hõne [juh], Hwana [hwo], Iguta [nar], Ikhin-Aokho[ikh], Ikulu [ikl], Izere [izr], Izora [cbo], Jakattoe [jrt], Jara [jaf], Jibu [jib], Jimi[jmi], Juu [juu], Kaan [ldl], Kadung [dkg], Kam [kdx], Kamantan [kci], Kamuku [cdr], Kariya[kil], Kibaku [ckl], Kir-Balar [kkr], Kizamani [izm], Koenoem [kcs], Koma [kmy], Koro Nulu[vkn], Koro Wachi [bqv], Koro Zuba [vkz], Kpasham [pbn], Kuce [ruk], Kudu-Camo [kov], Kugama[kow], Kulere [kul], Kulung [bbu], Kumba [ksm], Kusur-Myet [tdl], Kutep [kub], Kyanga [tye],Kyoli [cry], Labir [jku], Laka [ksp], Lala-Roba [lla], Lamang [hia], Lere [gnh], Longuda [lnu],Lopa [lop], Mada [mda], Mama [mma], Mansi [zns], Mbat [bau], Mboi [moi], Mbula-Bwazza [mbu],Migili [mgi], Mindat [mmf], Miship [mjs], Mwaghavul [sur], Ndoola [ndr], Ngas [anc], Ngizim[ngi], Ngwaba [ngw], Nikyob-Nindem [kdp], Ninzo [nin], Nteng [nqt], Numana [nbr], Nungu [rin],Nya Huba [hbb], Nyankpa [yes], Nyong [muo], Pa’anci [pqa], Pangu [png], Pero [pip], Pesse [pze],Piapung [pcw], Piya-Kwonci [piy], Pyam [pym], Pye [pai], Reshe [res], Rigwe [iri], Rishiwa[rsw], Rjili [uji], Rom [tdk], Ron [cla], Samba Daka [ccg], Sanga [xsn], Shall-Zwall [sha],Shama-Sambuga [sqa], Shanga [sho], Sheni [scv], Shiki [gua], Shoo-Minda-Nye [bcv], Siri [sir],Sorko [bze], Sukur [syk], Sya [scw], Tal [tal], Tala [tak], Tangale [tan], Tehl [mtl], Teme[tdo], Tera [ttr], Tigon Mbembe [nza], Tiyaa [tyy], Tsikimba [kdl], Tsishingini [tsw], Tso[ldp], Tsucuba [cbq], Tsuvadi [tvd], Tugbiri-Niragu [grh], Tulai [tvi], Tunzuii [dza], Tyap[kcg], ut-Ma’in [gel], Verre [ver], Voro [vor], Vune mi [mkf], Wandala [mfi], Wãpha [juw], Warji[wji], Yangkam [bsx], Yendang [ynq], Yukuben [ybl], Ywom [gek], Zamwal [zah], Zari [zaz], Zhire[zhi], Zibinju [jmb], Zul [zlu].

name: Manya
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Many also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk]. Many also use Loma [lom]. Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Mbelime
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Ditammari [tbz]. Also use French [fra].

name: Bemba (Zambia)
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Newspapers. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1956–2003.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Newari; Nepal Bhasa
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Newa script [Newa], in common use during the Malla period and earlier, recent efforts to revive usage. Ranjana (Lantsa, Wartu) script [Ranj].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60% (1991 census). Literacy rate in L2: 60% (1991 census). Youth more literate than older; men more than women. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2015. Agencies: Nepal Bhasa Academy; Newar National Forum.
Language Use: Language shift greater among Hindus than Buddhists. Home, religion; mixed use: Friends, work, education. Used by all. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Pahari [phj].

name: Gujari
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage. Devanagari script [Deva], plans for future development using this script.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: In general, Hindu agriculturalists have not retained Gujari language andculture, whereas Muslim Gujari have. Gujars outside Jammu-Kashmir and Himachal Pradesh do notspeak Gujari, but regional languages. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Dogri [dgo].Also use English [eng]. Also use Garhwali [gbm]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Jaunsari [jns].Also use Kashmiri [kas]. Also use Kullu Pahari [kfx]. Also use Kumaoni [kfy]. Also use Urdu[urd].

name: Mokole
Language Development: Radio. Bible: 2021.
Language Use: Vigorous. For school-age children, though education is in French [fra], outside the classroom children speak Mokole. Home, school, neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baatonum [bba]. Also use Boko [bqc]. Also use Borgu Fulfulde [fue]. Also use Dendi [ddn]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Yoruba [yor].

name: Tagbanwa
Writing: Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Tagbanwa script [Tagb].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 36%. Literacy rate in L2: 36%. Literature. Texts. NT: 1992–2019.
Language Use: Used exclusively with other Tagbanwa in all situations. Used by all. Negative attitudes. Somewhat ashamed of being Tagbanwa among other Filipinos, and speak Filipino [fil] as they can. Also use Filipino [fil]. Proficiency varies; more proficiency on the East coast than the West.

name: Kalamsé
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 48% in Jyla [dyu]; 38% in Moore [mos]. Literature. Bible portions: 1978.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events, Technology and media. Used by all. Many also use Jula [dyu]. Many also use Moore [mos]. A few also use Maya Samo [sym]. A few also use Western Niger Fulfulde [fuh].

name: Fiji Hindi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85%. Taught in a few primary schools in early gradesonly. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Used by all of Indian ancestry in Fiji. Indians who arrived after theindenture system as free immigrants continue to speak their languages at home, using English[eng] as the language to communicate with others. Home. All also use English [eng]. Used as L2by Eastern Punjabi [pan], Gujarati [guj], Tamil [tam], Telugu [tel], Urdu [urd].

name: Vidunda
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Arabic (Egyptian)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], primary usage. Braille script [Brai].
Language Development: Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1932.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng], especially in academic settings. Alsouse French [fra], especially in academic settings. Used as L2 by Greek [ell], Mattokki [xnz],Nobiin [fia], Sa’idi Arabic [aec], Siwi [siz], Western Armenian [hyw].

name: Standard Malay
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Used through secondary education and in some tertiary institutions. Taught in all primary and secondary schools; taught as subject in schools using Chinese [cmn] or Tamil [tam] as the language of instruction. Taught in tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1733–2016.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Quechua, Huallaga Huánuco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mofu-Gudur
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Several schools have Multilingual Education programs, with Mofu-Gudur as the language of instruction. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Many also use French [fra]. A few also use Giziga [giz]. A few also use Mafa [maf]. Used as L2 by Cuvok [cuv], Mbudum [xmd].

name: Buli (Ghana)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Around 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 byKantosi [xkt].

name: Luo (Kenya and Tanzania)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1953–1977.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Suba [sxb].

name: Keliko
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Taught as subject in some primary schools throughgrade 3. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bari [bfa].

name: English
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Deseret Alphabet [Dsrt], limited usage only in theUnited States between 1854–1877. Duployan shorthand [Dupl]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.Shavian (Shaw) script [Shaw], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1382–2002.
Language Use: Some also use French [fra] (European Commission 2006). A few also useSpanish [spa] (European Commission 2006). A few also use Standard German [deu] (EuropeanCommission 2006).

name: Soga
Language Development: Materials inadequate for dialectal variations (2021 SIL). Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some secondary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015. Agencies: Lusoga Language Development Academy; Basoga Cultural Research Centre.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Ganda [lug]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Kenye [lke], Saamya-Gwe [lsm].

name: Tira
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–20%. Literature. Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Widely promoted in the churches. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Torona [tqr].

name: Timugon Murut
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Less than 40%. Literacy rate in L2: More than 50% in Standard Malay [zsm]. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 2014. Agency: Kadazandusun Language Foundation (KLF), Murut Language Centre.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some children and adults; all elderly. Neutral attitudes. Many also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Hakka Chinese [hak]. Some also use Standard Malay [zsm]. A few also use Tahol Murut [mvv]. Used as L2 by Keningau Murut [kxi], Tahol Murut [mvv].

name: Turkish
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Bulgaria. Greek script [Grek], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], used since 1928 or 1929, primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1827–2006.
Language Use: Karamanli are Turkish-speaking Greeks. Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). A few also use Standard German [deu] (European Commission 2006).

name: Venetian
Language Development: Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Bible portions: 1859. Agency: Academia de ła Łengua Veneta (Academy of the Venetian Language).
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Italian [ita]. Used as L2 by Cimbrian [cim].

name: Hopi
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:1972. The Hopilavayi Project is part of a comprehensive plan for revitalizing Hopi. This projectwas the result of a survey conducted by the Hopi Cultural Preservation Office in 1997 to assesslanguage use among the Hopis. Agency: Hopi Cultural Preservation Office (HCPO).
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng], especiallyyouth who prefer English [eng].

name: Dazaga
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions:2006.
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Tedaga [tuq].

name: Galician
Language Development: Academy of the Galician Language. Decades of development as literarylanguage, including poetry and essays for all levels of education. Taught in primary andsecondary schools in Galician-speaking areas. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1989–1992.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tharu, Rana
Language Development: Mother-tongue multilingual education up to grade three in Kanchanpur. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Moba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%–30%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, market, work, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Mampruli [maw], Ngangam [gng].

name: Rusyn
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used in Slovakia.
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Also use Ukrainian [ukr], for literature and signs.

name: Aukan
Writing: Afaka script [Afak], developed in early 1900s, never widely used, may be inuse by a few individuals. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature.Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. In Paramaribo some shifted to Dutch [nld], some younger ones toSranan Tongo [srn]. All domains. Also in oral and written form for religious services. Positiveattitudes. Most also use Sranan Tongo [srn], especially men. Many also use Dutch [nld].

name: Malay, Manado
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, Community, Work. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Andio [bzb], Bantik [bnq], Bintauna [bne], Bolango [bld], Buol [blf], Gorontalo [gor], Kaidipang [kzp], Lolak [llq], Mongondow [mog], Pendau [ums], Ponosakan [pns], Ratahan [rth], Sangir [sxn], Talaud [tld], Tombulu [tom], Tondano [tdn], Tonsawang [tnw], Tonsea [txs], Tontemboan [tnt].

name: Baraamu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: 49% in Nepali [npi].Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Agencies: National Foundation for the Developmentof Indigenous Nationalities; Nepal Baram Association.
Language Use: Home, religion; mixed use: Friends, work. Older adults only. Positiveattitudes. Shifted to Nepali [npi].

name: Chrau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 5,000 can readChrau, 500 can write it. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Some parents pass it on to children. Informally used in education, oral andwritten use in religious services, oral literature. Positive attitudes. Also use Vietnamese[vie].

name: Weh
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Radio. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Isu [isu]. Used as L2 by Aghem [agq], Isu [isu].

name: Chatino, Tataltepec
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Very few children speak the language (2015R. Sullivant). Used as L2 by Western Highland Chatino [ctp].

name: Danish
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Compulsory subject in primary schools on Faroe Islands. Taught in allprimary and secondary schools. Taught in some tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible:1550–1993.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Many also useStandard German [deu] (European Commission 2006). Some also use French [fra] (EuropeanCommission 2006).

name: Tebilung
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%–70% in Standard Malay [zsm]. The current spelling system is not widely known, but anyone who is literate in L2 (Standard Malay [zsm]) can read and write in Tobilung. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Stronger in villages in the interior. Half of the children are learning the language or using it at home. Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. Most also use Sabah Malay [msi].

name: Yao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 60% Chichewa [nya], 30% Arabic [arb]. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Chichewa [nya]. Also use Standard Arabic [arb].

name: Mpade
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literature. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: All ages, but intergenerational transmission is weakening. Mostly home life. Positive attitudes. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Shuwa Arabic [shu].

name: Kamayo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Cebuano [ceb]. Taught in primary schools in early grades only. Videos. Dictionary.
