Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, some in government. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Crimean Tatar
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used until 1928. Cyrillic script[Cyrl], primary usage. Latin script [Latn], official usage since 1997.
Language Development: Taught in a few schools. Two local universities have faculties of CrimeanTatar. Literature. Newspapers. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Mostly the older generations speak it, but it could be shifting up in use.

name: C'lela
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Cicipu [awc], Damakawa[dam], Gwamhi-Wuri [bga], Tsuvadi [tvd].

name: Yucuna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. 500 read Yucuna, 300 can write it. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1982–2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Oral and written use in religious services, and oral use in the traditional religion. Letter writing. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa]. Some also use Tanimuca-Letuama [tnc], because of intermarriage. Used as L2 by Tanimuca-Letuama [tnc].

name: Nogai
Language Development: Most read and write Russian [rus]. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Home, community. Some young people, all adults. Many children shift to other languages at school age (Salminen 2007). Positive attitudes. Many also use Kumyk [kum]. Also use Karachay-Balkar [krc]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Hawai'i Creole English
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 66%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 66%–75%. Taught in bushschools as an elective to native and nonnative children. Taught as subject in primary schools inHawaii. Radio. TV. Texts. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous use by 100,000 to 200,000. Native speech of a large number ofthose born or brought up in Hawaii, regardless of racial origin. Continuum of speech fromdistinct creole to standard English [eng] of Hawaii. Different speakers control different spansalong the continuum, with some only speaking creole. Some communication problems at universitylevel. Courts, literature, personal letters, local commerce, and a few songs. Used by all. Mixedattitudes. Accepted by many as a distinctive local language and important part of local culture;but looked down on by others. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Hawaiian [haw].

name: Maskelynes
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Often mix with Bislama [bis]. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis].

name: Bodo (India)
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage.Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 61% Assam (2001 census). Taught as subject in primaryand secondary schools through grade 9 in tribal areas of Assam. Literature. Periodicals. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1981.
Language Use: Vigorous Bodo language and culture. Assamese [asm] is L1 for most Bodo Mechdialect speakers in Assam (Breton 1997:24). Also use English [eng], especially the youth. Usedas L2 by Koch [kdq].

name: Naga, Lotha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: High. Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1967–2000.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Nagamese [nag]. Used as L2 by Sumi Naga [nsm].

name: Beja
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], limited usage. Latin script [Latn],used since 1990s, primary usage.
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2008–2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Sudanese Arabic[apd]. Also use Tigré [tig].

name: Sundanese
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used since 12th or 13th century, used for religious writing. Javanese script [Java], used until 17th century. Latin script [Latn], used since mid-19th century. Sundanese script [Sund], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught as subject in most primary schools. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 1891–1991.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Badui [bac].

name: Boko (Benin)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 6%. Literature. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1992–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baatonum[bba]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Yoruba [yor]. Used as L2 by Mokole[mkl].

name: Triqui, Copala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1987–2010.
Language Use: Considerable language loss among youth who grow up in the diaspora.

name: Lombard
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1859–1860.
Language Use: In towns and among younger generations the use of Lombard has diminished significantly (Salminen 2007). Also use Italian [ita].

name: Berta
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Functional women’s literacy program started in Berta in 2017 and is now being gradually expanded throughout the language community (2021 SIL). Taught in many primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Based on new curriculum (2021), it has been decided that Berta shall be used as language of instruction (LOI) for grades 1–6; work is ongoing to establish this (2021 SIL). Taught as a major at the Gilgel Beles Teacher Training College and at Assosa University (2021 SIL). Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2006.
Language Use: All domains, except for religion (which is in Arabic [arb]). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Also use West Central Oromo [gaz]. Used as L2 by Gwama [kmq], Komo [xom], Mawes Aasse [myf].

name: Yiddish, Eastern
Language Development: Periodicals. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 1821–1936.

name: Kombio
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–35%. Literature. Bible portions: 1999–2001.
Language Use: Much mixing with L1. Kombio used by adults, but only used occasionally by those under 18. Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Czech
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1380–1980.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also useRussian [rus] (European Commission 2006). Some also use Standard German [deu] (EuropeanCommission 2006).

name: Lelemi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka].

name: Rawa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20% (Rawa), below 10% (Karo). Literacy rate in L2: 10%–20% can read Tok Pisin [tpi]. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1992–2001.
Language Use: Due to migration, use of Tok Pisin [tpi] increasing. All domains with same dialect speaker. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], and are slowly shifting towards it, though it was formerly learned mostly by women through intermarriage.

name: Nafaanra
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25% in Akan [aka]. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka]. Used as L2 by Dompo [doy].

name: Nepali (individual language)
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1914–2004.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Thulung [tdh], especially lower caste speakers in Mukli VDC. A few also use Kulung [kle], especially families from the tailor caste (Damai) and blacksmith caste (Kami) in Chheskam. Also use Bahing [bhj].

name: Tamang, Western
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Tibetan script [Tibt].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–75%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1990–2003. Agency: Nepal Tamang Ghedung.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], in religious contexts in the northwestern dialect. Also use Nepali [npi], especially younger people, as it is the medium of instruction in schools.

name: Fulfulde, Maasina
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn], official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5% (2007 S. Crickmore). Literacy rate in L2: 5% inBambara [bam] (2007 S. Crickmore). Taught in some adult and youth literacy classes (2021 SIL).Taught in some primary schools in early grades only. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bamanankan [bam].Used as L2 by Ana Tinga Dogon [dti], Bankan Tey Dogon [dbw], Bunoge Dogon [dgb], Tiemacèwè Bozo[boo], Tieyaxo Bozo [boz].

name: Kulung (Nepal)
Language Development: High motivation for literacy. Literature. Periodicals. Grammar. Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion. Some young people, all adults. Also use Nepali [npi], which almost all can understand at a basic level. Used as L2 by Eastern Mewahang [emg], Khaling [klr], Nepali [npi], Western Mewahang [raf].

name: Ahanta
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Akan [aka]. Also use Nzema [nzi].

name: Ayta, Mag-Anchi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Taught in many primary schools in grades 1–3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Children in some communities shifting to Kapampangan [pam] (2020 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Also use Kapampangan [pam].

name: Persian (Dari)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in print. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 28%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools in predominantly Dari-speaking regions; taught as subject in primary schools in some other regions. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Urdu [urd].

name: Balochi, Eastern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage. Latin script [Latn], limited usage in the early 1900s.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Radio. Grammar. NT: 1906.
Language Use: Many also use Urdu [urd]. Some also use Saraiki [skr]. A few also useSindhi [snd].

name: Rabha
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Latin script [Latn], preferred by Catholics.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%–50%. High interest in language development. Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2023.
Language Use: The majority of the ethnic group speaks Assamese [asm] as L1; Rabha spoken only in Rongdani and Maituri. Home, prayer, market, other villages. Used by all. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Garo [grt]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Koch [kdq].

name: Nenets
Language Development: Most attend school and read Russian [rus]. Taught as subject in some primary and secondary schools, especially in the Yamalo-Nenets autonomous district. Used as language of instruction in a few secondary schools, especially in the Yamalo-Nenets autonomous district. Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2004–2021.
Language Use: In Siberia most young people are still fluent in the language. On the European side, very few children learn it; young people tend to prefer Russian [rus] and most speakers are middle-aged or older (Salminen 2007). Some young people, all adults, a few to half of children speak Nenets. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus], especially school-aged children in Siberia. Used as L2 by Komi-Zyrian [kpv].

name: Vasavi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low. Radio. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Marathi [mar], but with low proficiency.

name: Birifor, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 5% or more. Literature.Radio. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Gumawana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Tend not to readGumawana or Dobu but increase in English use and literacy. Literature. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Boselewa[bwf]. Also use Dobu [dob]. Also use Galeya [gar]. Also use Kilivila [kij]. Also use Maiadomu[mzz].

name: Kannada
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Kannada script [Knda], primary usage. Nandinagariscript [Nand], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Taught in primary andsecondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Karnataka state. Fully developed.Bible: 1831–2023.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Alu Kurumba [xua], Bellari [brw], Holiya [hoy], Irula [iru],Jennu Kurumba [xuj], Kannada Kurumba [kfi], Kodava [kfa], Kota [kfe], Kudiya [kfg], Lambadi[lmn], Mudu Koraga [vmd], Paniya [pcg], Ravula [yea], Tamil [tam], Tulu [tcy], Vaagri Booli[vaa].

name: Diodio
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: High. Taught in primaryschools in early grades only, in at least 5 schools. Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Bwaidoka [bwd]. Also use Dobu [dob].

name: Ibanag
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught inprimary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1911–1989.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Usedas L2 by Faire Atta [azt], Pudtol Atta [atp].

name: Chuj (San Sebastián Coatán)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Taught in primaryschools in early grades only in San Sebastián Coatán dialect. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible:1999–2007. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tektiteko
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20%. Some bilingual education in elementary schools. Literature. Radio. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2003. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: In Tectitán municipality, language use increasing. Vitality stronger than 20 years ago (2000). Some young people, all adults. In the largest villages, commonly used by children. In some areas, parents desire their children to speak only Spanish [spa]. Neutral attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Assyrian Neo-Aramaic
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Syriac script [Syrc], primary usage.
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. Bible: 1852–1919.

name: Wolaitta
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], primarily used by adults. Latin script [Latn], taught in school.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Also taught as a major at the university level. Taught in primary and secondary schools in grades 1–4 and as subject thereafter. Taught in university as a major. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2002–2003.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Baiso [bsw], Kachama-Ganjule [kcx], Tsaara [cra].

name: Esperanto
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1926.Agency: World Esperanto Association.
Language Use: L1 users learn Esperanto from birth from Esperanto-speaking parents. Home,Esperanto clubs and associations. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Araucanian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 21%. 85,000 are literate in Spanish [spa].Intercultural Bilingual Education programs prevalent, and a large amount of indigenous authoredliterature in Mapudungun has been produced, but with very few readers. Taught as subject in mostprimary schools in grades 1 to 8. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997–2011.
Language Use: Used orally in social media by the youth who still speak it. Some of allages. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Pattani
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Tibetan script [Tibt], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% for women (even young ones). Over 50% for men. Most young men under 30 can read (2002). Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 1907–1914.
Language Use: Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], in education and trade. Half of the population speak it with good proficiency. Used as L2 by Tinani [lbf].

name: Wongo
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1938–1940.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Kituba [ktu]. Some also use French [fra]. Some also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Lele [lel].

name: Yakima
Language Development: Radio. Heritage College in Toppenish offers 2 levels of Yakama language instruction. Tribal museum offers occasional classes (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Elderly only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Yupik, Central
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Still acquired by children in 17 of 68 villages. Some young people, alladults. Most also use English [eng].

name: Marachi
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Lingala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Used in church-based adult literacy programs (2021 SIL). Taught as subject in most primary and secondary schools from grade 3 in the capital, west, and northwest of the country. Taught in most primary schools through grade 3 in the northwestern third of the country. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1970–2000.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Asoa [asv], Babango [bbm], Bali [bcp], Baloi [biz], Bamwe [bmg], Bangi [bni], Bangubangu [bnx], Barambu [brm], Bindji [bpj], Boko [bkp], Bolia [bli], Boloki [bkt], Bolondo [bzm], Bomboli [bml], Bomboma [bws], Bozaba [bzo], Budja [bja], Budu [buu], Bwa [bww], Chokwe [cjk], Dengese [dez], Ding [diz], Dzando [dzn], Eboo Teke [ebo], Efe [efe], Foma [fom], Fulu [fuu], Gbanziri [gbg], Gilima [gix], Gobu [gox], Holu [hol], Hungana [hum], Ibali Teke [tek], Iyansi [yns], Kakwa [keo], Kango [kty], Kango [kzy], Kela [kel], Kele [khy], Kiyombe [yom], Komo [kmw], Kpala [kpl], Kwese [kws], Lalia [lal], Lele [lel], Libinza [liz], Ligenza [lgz], Likila [lie], Lobala [loq], Lombo [loo], Lonzo [lnz], Luba-Kasai [lua], Lunda [lun], Lusengo [lse], Ma [msj], Mayeka [myc], Mayogo [mdm], Mba [mfc], Mbala [mdp], Mbandja [zmz], Mbesa [zms], Mbole [mdq], Mbuun [zmp], Mfinu [zmf], Mid-Southern Banda [bjo], Moingi [mwz], Mongo-Nkundu [lol], Mono [mnh], Monzombo [moj], Ndaka [ndk], Ndobo [ndw], Ndolo [ndl], Ndunga [ndt], Ngando [nxd], Ngbaka [nga], Ngbaka Ma’bo [nbm], Ngbinda [nbd], Ngbundu [nuu], Ngelima [agh], Ngombe [ngc], Ngongo [noq], Ngwii [nlo], Northern Ngbandi [ngb], Ntomba [nto], Nzadi [nzd], Nzakara [nzk], Ombo [oml], Pagibete [pae], Pelende [ppp], Phende [pem], Poke [pof], Sakata [skt], Samba [smx], Sengele [szg], So [soc], Sonde [shc], Songo [soo], South Central Banda [lnl], Southern Ngbandi [nbw], Suku [sub], Tembo [tmv], Tetela [tll], Tiene [tii], Togbo-Vara Banda [tor], Wongo [won], Yaka [yaf], Yango [yng].

name: Maltese
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use, attempts at using Arabic script have failed. Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Grammar. Bible: 1932–1984.
Language Use: Vigorous. No diglossia with Standard Arabic [arb]. Most also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006).

name: Jowulu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Active literacy program. Literature. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Jula [dyu]. A few also useDuungooma [dux]. A few also use French [fra], especially educated speakers. A few also useSupyire Sénoufo [spp]. Also use Bamanankan [bam], especially men.

name: Luwo
Language Development: Literacy in progress. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2003. Agency: Luwo Literacy Organization.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, local administration, some use in schools, churches. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Thuri [thu].

name: Cham, Western
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Cham script [Cham]. Latin script[Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Khmer [khm]. Manychildren learn to read Cham using Arabic-based script in madrassah schools. In one sect, mostpeople over age 50 can read using the ancient Cham script called Kakha. Literature. Radio.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2021.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Khmer [khm].

name: Ewe
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], used since 1850s, primaryusage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught inprimary and secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Newspapers.Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1911–2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Akposo [kpo],Avatime [avn], Logba [lgq], Nawdm [nmz], Nkonya [nko], Nyagbo [nyb], Sekpele [lip], Selee [snw],Tafi [tcd], Tuwuli [bov].

name: Chiripá
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Most also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug] (Crevels 2012). Some also use Spanish [spa].

name: Hruso
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 48%: males 58%, females 39% (2001 census). Literature.
Language Use: Steady shift away from Hruso, especially among youth educated outside thearea. Some young people, all adults. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also useHindi [hin]. Also use Miji [sjl]. Used as L2 by Bugun [bgg], Miji [sjl].

name: Kinabatangan, Upper
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1984–2004. Agency: The Orang SungaiCultural Association (Sabah Association of Bangsa Sungai).
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Some young people, all adults.Speaker age range choice based on previous comment in that field. Positive attitudes. All alsouse Sabah Malay [msi]. Most also use Standard Malay [zsm]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Rusyn, Ruthenian
Language Development: Taught in primary schools, in minority-language schools. Newspapers. Radio. TV.

name: Ngumba
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1930s, revised in 2011.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 75% in French [fra]. Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 1957–2019.
Language Use: Some churches use Kwasio exclusively; some use a mixture with French [fra]. All domains. Used by all, though many youth lose proficiency to French [fra]. Positive attitudes. All also use French [fra], especially in education, politics and media. Many also use Bulu [bum]. Some also use Batanga [bnm]. Some also use Gyele [gyi]. Used as L2 by Batanga [bnm], Fang [fan], Gyele [gyi], Iyasa [yko].

name: Bote-Majhi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: None. Generally, literacy programs are conducted inNepali [npi]. Newspapers. Grammar. Bible portions: 2019–2023.
Language Use: Use is mostly local. Rapid shift to Nepali [npi] (Van Driem 2007). Mixeduse: Home, friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Elderly. Some use amongchildren, adolescents, younger and older adults. Positive attitudes, with growing languageactivism. Also use Bhojpuri [bho]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Bilin
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], unofficial usage. Latin script [Latn], used since1990s, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Females: 40%. Taught in some primary schools.Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Sudanese Arabic [apd],especially in the code-switching of the younger population. Also use Kunama [kun]. Also use Nara[nrb]. Also use Tigré [tig], by 70% of the Muslim population. Also use Tigrigna [tir], by 60% ofthe Christian population.

name: Xibe
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used between 1957–1958, experimental use in education. Latin script [Latn], used in 1939–1941 and since internet became popular, mainly used on internet and text messaging, favoured by younger people. Mongolian script [Mong], Sibe style, used in 1947–1966 and from 1974, official usage, all domains, favoured by older generations. Mongolian script [Mong], Manchu style, used from Qing dynasty to 1947.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 52%. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. All ages in rural areas. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kazakh [kaz]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Russian [rus]. Also use Uyghur [uig].

name: Gokana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 40%. Literature. Radio. Videos. NT: 1996–2011.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Mixed attitudes, from positive attitudes amongolder generation to negative attitudes among youth. Used as L2 by Eleme [elm], Khana [ogo], Tèẹ̣̀ [tkq].

name: Bandial
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 20% in French [fra].Literacy mostly directed to adults. Some for primary and secondary schools. Literature. Radio.Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Bandial is still transmittedto children in villages, but its transmission to new generations outside the traditional ruralarea has fallen drastically (Sagna 2008). Mixed attitudes. Some also use Jola-Fonyi [dyo]. Somealso use Jola-Kasa [csk]. Also use French [fra], with many youth shifting (Sagna 2008). Also useGuinea-Bissau Creole [pov]. Also use Wolof [wol], with many youth shifting (Sagna 2008).

name: Kurdish, Central
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools in Kurdish Autonomous Region.Literary standard is based on Sorani (from Suleimaniye) variety. Fully developed. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes.

name: Polish
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1561–2018.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006).

name: Mixtec, Peñoles
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Literature. Texts. NT: 1979–2002.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dobel
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literature. Bible portions: 1991–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some Chinese merchants who speak Dobo Malay dialect of Ambonese Malay [abs] and older Hokkien [nan] learn Dobel. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs], specifically the Dobo Malay dialect. Nearly all school-age speakers of Dobel are bilingual in this variety. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Manombai [woo]. Used as L2 by Lorang [lrn], Manombai [woo].

name: Irish
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Latin script, Gaelic variant [Latg]. Ogham script[Ogam], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools in the Irish-speaking areas(Gaeltacht), where Irish is the only language of instruction, and in Irish-language schools.Taught as subject in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in some tertiary schools. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1690–1981.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. A number of children learn the language butthe number is decreasing (Salminen 2007). Also use English [eng] (Salminen 2007).

name: Lobu, Lanas
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Mixed use in Home, Friends, Religion, Work and Education. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Many also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp], specifically the Dusun Tambunan dialect. Many also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Some also use Bookan Murut [bnb]. Some also use Minokok [mqq].

name: Kalumpang
Language Development: Radio. Bible portions: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Mixed in all domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Panasuan [psn], Talondo’ [tln].

name: Tulishi
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Kwanja
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Regular use in Kwanja area. Home, community. Positive attitudes, though in some places there is pressure to use Fulfulde [fub]. A few also use French [fra], especially those who work in cities outside the language area. Used as L2 by Tikar [tik], Twendi [twn].

name: Sénoufo, Sìcìté
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: 20% Jula or French. Radio. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Nai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Texts.Bible portions: 2004.
Language Use: All children, except those in Amini, learn Nai first; vitality in Amini indecline. All domains. Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kalagan, Tagakaulu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–30%. Literacy instruction continues for out-of-school youth and adults in non-public school and some church settings. Literature. Radio. Videos. Texts. Bible portions: 1964–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except church, trade. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cebuano [ceb]. Most also use Hiligaynon [hil].

name: Western Durango Nahuatl
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 16% (Durango). Community-based literacy project.Bilingual teachers assessing sociolinguistic situation (2007 SIL). Literature. Radio. Videos.Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. The Nayarit communities are more isolated and surrounded bylarger language group; there are pockets of the region where the language has fallen intodisuse. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Sri Lankan Creole Malay
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio.
Language Use: Language shift taking place. Malay communities using either English [eng], Sinhala [sin], or Tamil [tam] favor Sri Lankan Malay Creole. Clear shift to English among youth in Colombo. Kirinda is the only vital community of Sri Lanka Malays who have youth who speak it as L1. There is also a desire to acquire Standard Malay [zsm] as a useful economic tool but still preserve Malay identity. Beginning to shift to Standard Malay even in Kirinda. Home, community. Some young people, all adults. All ages only in Kirinda; being lost by youth in every other community. Also use English [eng]. Also use Sinhala [sin]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Tharaka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 45% in Kiswahili [swh] or English [eng]. L1 books in schools since 2003. Thriving mother-tongue education in schools. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio. Videos. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Older people’s dialect more prestigious due to lack of borrowings. Many now use written materials. Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], in schools and offices. Also use Gikuyu [kik]. Also use Kimîîru [mer]. Also use Swahili [swh], especially in churches, schools, jobs, and sometimes in the home.

name: Yopno
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–35%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Yopno is preferred unless non-Yopno are present; then Tok Pisin [tpi] is used. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Slotta 2015). Some also use Domung [dev] (Slotta 2012). Some also use Kutong [skm]. Some also use Nankina [nnk] (Slotta 2012). A few also use Kâte [kmg] (Slotta 2012). A few also use Wantoat [wnc]. Used as L2 by Kutong [skm], Tayatuk [smc], Wantoat [wnc].

name: Banjar
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Newspapers. TV. Dictionary.Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Naga Pidgin
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Grammar. NT: 2018.
Language Use: L1 for the Kachari in Dimapur area, a small community, and among children of interethnic marriages. Mixed attitudes, viewed by some as a threat to the indigenous languages (Longkumer 2016). Used as L2 by Angami Naga [njm], Chang Naga [nbc], Dimasa [dis], Konyak Naga [nbe], Lotha Naga [njh], Monsang Naga [nmh], Phom Naga [nph], Pochuri Naga [npo], Sakachep [sch], Sangtam Naga [nsa], Southern Rengma Naga [nre], Sumi Naga [nsm], Yimchungru Naga [yim].

name: Spanish (Castilian)
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1553–2012.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use French [fra] (European Commission 2006).

name: Ga'dang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–80%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%–80%. Literature.Texts. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Liberian English
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bandi [bza], Barclayville Grebo [gry], Bassa [bsq], Central Grebo [grv], Dan [dnj], Dewoin [dee], Eastern Krahn [kqo], Gbii [ggb], Gboloo Grebo [gec], Glaro-Twabo [glr], Glio-Oubi [oub], Gola [gol], Klao [klu], Konyanka Maninka [mku], Kuwaa [blh], Liberia Kpelle [xpe], Loma [lom], Maan [mev], Manya [mzj], Mende [men], Northern Grebo [gbo], Sapo [krn], Southern Grebo [grj], Southern Kisi [kss], Tajuasohn [tja], Tepo Krumen [ted], Vai [vai], Western Krahn [krw].

name: Dogrib
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught as subjectin primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2005–2008.
Language Use: Adults prefer to use Tlicho in most contexts. Some young people, alladults. All also use English [eng].

name: Sauria Paharia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 7%. Literacy classes. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Parauk
LITERACY_L2: 8% in Burmese [mya] (mostly males), 5% in Chinese in border areas (mostly males); 2% in Shan [shn] (males).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 8% in Burmese [mya] (mostly males), 5% in Chinese in border areas (mostly males); 2% in Shan [shn] (males). Literacy classes. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2006–2012. Agency: Wa Language and Culture Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. Females in rural areas tend to be monolingual in local Parauk varieties. Males tend to be more bilingual. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Lahu [lhu]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Rumai Palaung [rbb]. Also use Shan [shn].

name: Korafe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1984–2003.
Language Use: All domains except sports. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo], particularly those over 50 years of age. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], particularly teenagers who use it increasingly among themselves (2007 SIL). Used as L2 by Baruga [bjz], Maisin [mbq].

name: Breri
Language Development: Literacy program since 2016. Literature. Bible portions: 2017–2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Use of the language is discouraged in elementary and primaryschools (2020 A. Tousch). Home, church, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also useTok Pisin [tpi], with high proficiency. Some also use English [eng], with varying degrees ofproficiency.

name: Kuskokwim, Upper
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Bangolan
Language Development: Basic literacy materials. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English[eng].

name: Quechua, Arequipa-La Unión
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. 600 readers, 200 can write. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1993–1998.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used in some schools. Some families switched to Spanish. Other language speakers use Quechua to talk to monolinguals. Administration, commerce, labor relations, religious services. Used by all. Negative attitudes. Considered inferior to Spanish [spa]. Most also use Spanish [spa]. Also use Cusco Quechua [quz], in schools.

name: Oroqen
LITERACY_L2: 97% in any language (2000 census, Oroqen nationality).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 97% in any language (2000 census, Oroqen nationality). Radio.
Language Use: Kumarchen dialect has some child speakers; Birarchen is moribund (Salminen 2007). All domains. Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Some also use Daur [dta]. Also use Evenki [evn]. Also use Peripheral Mongolian [mvf]. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Daur [dta], Evenki [evn].

name: Biete
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 56%. Literature. Bible: 1985–2005.
Language Use: Home, village, church. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin],especially in Assam. Also use Khasi [kha], in Meghalaya. Also use Mizo [lus]. Also useWar-Jaintia [aml], in Meghalaya. Used as L2 by Sakachep [sch].

name: Koorete
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Church literature. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 24%. Offered at the university as a major. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Offered at the Teacher Training College as a major (2021 SIL). Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Marquesan, North
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Most shifting to French [fra] (Cablitz 2006).

name: Bambara
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. N’Ko script [Nkoo], used in Mali.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Taught in many adult and youth literacy classes(2021 SIL). Taught in some primary schools in early grades only. Bambara is most widely used andbest developed program (2021 SIL). Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1961–1987.
Language Use: Growing. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 byBankagooma [bxw], Bunoge Dogon [dgb], Duungooma [dux], Jenaama Bozo [bze], Jowulu [jow], Kagoro[xkg], Kelengaxo Bozo [bzx], Konabéré [bbo], Koyra Chiini Songhay [khq], Koyraboro Senni Songhay[ses], Maasina Fulfulde [ffm], Malian Sign Language [bog], Mamara Sénoufo [myk], Pana [pnq],Soninke [snk], Supyire Sénoufo [spp], Syenara Sénoufo [shz], Tieyaxo Bozo [boz].

name: Kharia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 46% (1991 census). Literature. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Many also use Sadri [sck]. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng].Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Odia [ory]. Also use Santhali [sat].

name: Moru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 85%. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Bible: 2000.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Zande [zne]. Used as L2 by Baka [bdh], Morokodo [mgc].

name: Guro
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1979.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Gban [ggu], Kouya [kyf], Mwan [moa],Yaouré [yre].

name: Ditammari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2, in 5 schools (2014 SIL). Literature. Radio. Bible: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baatonum [bba]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Yom [pil]. Used as L2 by Mbelime [mql], Waama [wwa].

name: Minaveha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 62%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. 1,100 can read, 400 can write. Taught in primary schools in early grades only. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2008–2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except in Catholic Churches, where there is mixed use with other languages (2001 UNESCO). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bwaidoka [bwd]. Also use Dobu [dob]. Also use English [eng], steadily increasingly. Also use Iamalele [yml]. Also use Koluwawa [klx]. Also use Molima [mox]. Used as L2 by Koluwawa [klx].

name: French
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Duployan shorthand [Dupl]. Latin script [Latn],primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1530–2000.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also useSpanish [spa] (European Commission 2006). A few also use Standard German [deu] (EuropeanCommission 2006).

name: Marshall
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1982.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: German, Colonia Tovar
Language Development: Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: N'Ko
Language Development: N’Ko is both a script devised in 1949 as a writing system for the Mande languages, and the name of the literary language written in the script. Newspapers. Dictionary.

name: Kirmanjki (individual language)
LITERACY_L2: School-age children to 40 years old, are literate inTurkish [tur].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: School-age children to 40 years old, are literate inTurkish [tur]. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions:2023.
Language Use: Abroad, they use Northern Zazaki for close relationships. Home, community.Some young people, all adults. Also use Turkish [tur]. Used as L2 by Northern Kurdish [kmr].

name: Marwari (Pakistan)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in Sindh Province. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in Punjab Province.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5% in Sindhi [snd] or Urdu [urd]. Newspapers. NT: 1821.
Language Use: One sweeper community of 10,000–100,000 identifies itself as Marwari, but is undergoing rapid shift to Urdu [urd]. Marwari is not usually written. Used by all. Also use Saraiki [skr]. Also use Sindhi [snd], especially educated people. Also use Urdu [urd], particularly the educated. Used as L2 by Jogi [jog], Western Punjabi [pnb].

name: Gurung, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Literature. Newspapers.Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1982–2020.
Language Use: Children and young people use Gurung less frequently than those who areolder. Passed down only a little from generation to generation (2002 UNESCO). Gurung childrenare learning Nepali before they enter school and formal education is conducted in Nepali (2015SIL). Home; mixed use: Friends, religion, work, education. Some young people, all adults. Thelanguage is decreasingly being passed on to children, and Nepali usage among even very youngchildren is increasing (2015 SIL). Positive attitudes. All also use Nepali [npi]. Also useEnglish [eng], especially by high school graduates. Also use Lhomi [lhm]. Used as L2 by GhandrukSign Language [gds].

name: Kenswei Nsei
Language Development: Basic literacy materials. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Shughni
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in Afghanistan. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Tajikistan. Latin script [Latn], used in Tajikistan.
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2015.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tajik [tgk], as a literary language. Used as L2 by Wakhi [wbl].

name: Zaiwa
Writing: Latin script [Latn], developed in 1957, modified in 1997. Lisu (Fraser)script [Lisu], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50,000 can read and write. Newspapers. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2009–2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Speakers of other languages in the area also speak Zaiwa. Alldomains. Used by all. Used less by young people and children. Positive attitudes. Intellectualsare concerned about preservation of Zaiwa. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also useCentral Bai [bca]. Also use Jingpho [kac]. Also use Lachi [lbt]. Also use Lhao Vo [mhx]. Alsouse Lisu [lis]. Used as L2 by Jingpho [kac], Lhaovo [mhx].

name: Lendu
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Spoken as L1 by people from 4 ethnic backgrounds: Lendu, Hema-North, Alur, and Okebu. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Isnag
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Literature. Dictionary.Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Manangba
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Fairly strong vitality. Some community involvement in language and culture preservation activities both in home area and in Kathmandu. Mixed use: Home, friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], especially in religious domains. Also use English [eng], especially in local government schools. Also use Nepali [npi], especially for business and in local government schools.

name: Kurdish, northern
LITERACY_L1: Overall about 83%, but not differentiated by L1 or L2 usage.
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in Iran, Iraq, Syria, and Lebanon. Armenian script [Armn], used between 1921–1929, used in Armenia. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Armenia, Russia, and Azerbaijan. Latin script [Latn], developed in 1932, used in Turkey and Syria.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Overall about 83%, but not differentiated by L1 or L2 usage. While overall speakers are decreasing, literates are increasing. Many literary works from 16th and 17th centuries onward. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Overall use of Northern Kurdish is beginning to decline in Turkey, even as it is used more as an LWC among immigrant populations. Home, market, political situations. Some of all ages. Many are adults above age 30. Positive attitudes. Most also use Turkish [tur]. Also use Northern Zazaki [kiu]. Also use Southern Zazaki [diq]. Used as L2 by Domari [rmt], Hértevin [hrt], Southern Zazaki [diq].

name: Lao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1932–2012.

name: Nyakyusa
Language Development: SIL has transition literacy work (Swahili to Nyakyusa). Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1993–1996.
Language Use: Vigorous. Local non-Nykyusa speakers often learn Nyakyusa. Most domains and increasingly in politics. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Semai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Literacy in Semai growing. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1951–2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Cameron Highlands dialect is used on radio and is a school language (Bradley 2007a). Home, church, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a). Some also use Temiar [tea] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Tshangla
Writing: Tibetan script [Tibt], Uchen style, used in India.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 47% (2003 SIL). Literacy rate in L2: Below 1%. Radio. Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Also use Dzongkha [dzo]. Used as L2 by Khengkha [xkf], Kurtokha [xkz].

name: Moma
Language Development: 550 Moma speakers enrolled in the literacy program (2013 A. Eastwood). Taught as subject in many primary schools, for one hour per week (2013 A. Eastwood). Literature. Bible portions: 1939–2015.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Chambeali
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longerin use.
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Eastern Punjabi [pan]. Also use English [eng]. Alsouse Hindi [hin]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Kashmiri
LITERACY_L1: 88% male; 12% female over 35 years of age (Koul andSchmidt 1983).
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage. Devanagari script [Deva]. Latin script [Latn]. Sharada script [Shrd], nolonger in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 88% male; 12% female over 35 years of age (Koul andSchmidt 1983). Literacy rate in L2: 55% for Jammu and Kashmir (2001 census). 83% would preferuse of Kashmiri rather than Urdu as medium in primary school, 48% in middle school (Koul andSchmidt 1983). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafterin Jammu and Kashmir. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible:1899–2005.
Language Use: Most also use Urdu [urd] (Koul and Schmidt 1983). Some also use English[eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Bhadrawahi [bhd], Changthang [cna], Gujari [gju],Khah [hkh], Uyghur [uig].

name: Yukpa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Inside protected areas the language is used all the time; outside those areas, it is only spoken when there are no outsiders present (Crevels 2007). Also use Spanish [spa], especially men, but only for buying and selling.

name: Bayot
Language Development: Beginning literacy classes. Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: L1 by all generations in the Nyassia municipality. Adults who have movedaway speak it when possible but their children tend to speak Wolof [wol]. Close contact with theNyassia area (2021 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also useJola-Fonyi [dyo], mostly adults who live in the Nyassia area. Many also use Wolof [wol], mostlythe younger generation and also those who have moved away from the language area. Also useFrench [fra], used by educated people in official and public situations. Also use Guinea-BissauCreole [pov].

name: Kaba
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Some also use Sango [sag].

name: Gadaba, Bodo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 9% (2000 H. Rajan). Literacy classes in progress.Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Many speak and are shifting to Desiya [dso] in home and religious domains.Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. A few also use Odia [ory], in Odisha. Also useDesiya [dso]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Telugu [tel], in Andhra Pradesh.

name: Agta, Casiguran Dumagat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Literature. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1979.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Filipino [fil]. Used as L2 by Arta [atz].

name: Lango (Uganda)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1967, revised in 2010.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some secondary schools, as ‘Lwo’, sharing materials with Acholi [ach], Alur [alz], Jopadhola [adh], and Kumam [kdi]. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1979.
Language Use: Home, market, office. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Kumam [kdi], Thur [lth].

name: Usui
Language Development: Literature. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Dendi (Benin)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–30%. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades1 and 2, in 5 schools (2014 SIL). Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Market. Also use French [fra]. Also use Yom [pil]. Used as L2 by Mokole[mkl], Yom [pil].

name: Bantoanon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%–90%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–90%. Literature. NT:2016.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].Also use Filipino [fil]. Used for politics, education, church in main towns, and withnon-Bantoanon speakers. Also use Inonhan [loc]. Also use Romblomanon [rol].

name: Solos
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Newspapers. TV.
Language Use: In all villages except one, Solos is the first language learned and used. In one village, Tok Pisin [tpi] is the first language learned and used, and children do not speak Solos well. Mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] in most domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use Petats [pex], especially adults. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Halia [hla]. Used as L2 by Petats [pex].

name: Tachoni
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Chamacoco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Literature. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Most also use Spanish [spa] (Ciucci 2016).Some also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug], but with low proficiency (Crevels 2012). Also usePortuguese [por] (Ciucci 2016).

name: Zuni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Schools in English [eng]. Taught as subject in primary schools. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1941–2007. The Zuni Tribe has collaborated with the public school district in developing a literacy program to help preserve the written language (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Some children raised to speak the language (1998). Slowly shifting to English [eng] (Golla 2007). Home, traditional tribal council meetings, all religious ceremonies, and occasionally in religious services. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng].

name: Obolo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. 90% of childrenattend school. Taught in a few primary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Grammar.Bible: 2012.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ibibio [ibb].Also use Igbo [ibo].

name: Mixtec, Ayutla
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Home, work. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dungmali
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Dictionary. Agency: Dungmali Rai Language Culture Preservation Forum.
Language Use: Home, religion. Mixed use: Friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Also use Bantawa [bap].

name: Lote
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 65% in Tok Pisin [tpi], 40% in English [eng]. Vernacular language preschools. Literature. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except church and community meetings, where there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pearson and van den Berg 2008). Some also use English [eng] (Pearson and van den Berg 2008). Used as L2 by Amio-Gelimi [let], Mangseng [mbh].

name: Abau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–80%. Vernaculareducation mostly effective. Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006–2013.
Language Use: Dialect differences are such that (especially young) people from differentdialects use Tok Pisin [tpi] between them. Tok Pisin is favored if non-Abau speakers arepresent. Village gatherings; Mixed use: home, community. Used by all, but increasingly youthprefer Tok Pisin [tpi]. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Lock 2011). A few also use English [eng](Lock 2011).

name: Hindi
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Latinscript [Latn], recent informal usage, especially online on social media. Mahajani script [Mahj],no longer in use, historic usage. Newa script [Newa], no longer in use, historic usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools, more in northern India than insouthern India. Taught in tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1835–2000.

name: Uisai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only. Radio. Texts. Bible portions: 1986.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Naasioi [nas].

name: Serbian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools; taught as subject in other schools where a minority language is the language of instruction. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1804–1868.

name: Konkani (specific)
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Kannada script [Knda], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Goa state. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1997.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Goan Konkani [gom].

name: Naga, Konyak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40% (2001 census). Literacy rate in L2: 40% (2001 census). Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1992.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Bhadrawahi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Devanagari script [Deva].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70% (84% for males, 53% for females). Literature.Radio. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous in spite of high bilingualism; L1 seen as important. Home,village, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also useKashmiri [kas]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Subanen, Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Shift to Cebuano [ceb] beginning among children in some urban areas. Community, home, church, informal education. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Cebuano [ceb]. Most also use Tagalog [tgl]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Kolibugan Subanon [skn]. Some also use Southern Subanen [laa].

name: Mambai
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2011–2014.
Language Use: Men tend to be more multilingual. Most domains. Used by all. Many also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Many also use French [fra]. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Mundang [mua].

name: Tuvinian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85% in Russian [rus] (2007 SIL). Taught in most primary and secondary schools through grade 10 in the Tyva republic only. 80% of Tuvan schools are rural and feature a curriculum taught primarily in Tuvan (Chevalier 2012). Literature. Grammar. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: One of the most vital minority languages in Siberia due to geographic isolation. Home, work, government. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Halh Mongolian [khk], near the border. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Chakma
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Chakma script [Cakm]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Taught in primaryschools in grades 1 and 2. Literature. Bible: 2021.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bengali [ben],especially educated people and most men. Also use Chittagonian [ctg]. Used as L2 by Riang [ria].

name: Cebuano
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible: 1917–1981.
Language Use: Also use Bolinao [smk]. Used as L2 by Ata [atm], Bagobo-Klata [bgi],Bantayanon [bfx], Butuanon [btw], Central Sama [sml], Central Subanen [syb], Chavacano [cbk],Cotabato Manobo [mta], Davawenyo [daw], Eskayan [esy], Higaonon [mba], Ilianen Manobo [mbi],Inabaknon [abx], Kagan Kalagan [kll], Kalagan [kqe], Kamayo [kyk], Kinamiging Manobo [mkx],Kolibugan Subanon [skn], Koronadal Blaan [bpr], Maguindanaon [mdh], Mandaya [mry], Maranao[mrw], Matigsalug Manobo [mbt], Northern Subanen [stb], Obo Manobo [obo], Porohanon [prh], RajahKabunsuwan Manobo [mqk], Sangil [snl], Sangir [sxn], Sarangani Blaan [bps], Southern Subanen[laa], Surigaonon [sgd], Tagakolu [klg], Tandaganon [tgn], Western Bukidnon Manobo [mbb].

name: Lindu
Language Development: 50 Tado speakers enrolled in the literacy program (2013 A. Eastwood). Taught as subject in many primary schools in grades 1 and 2, for one hour per week (2013 A. Eastwood). Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Babanki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Used informally in education. Schooling inEnglish. Women and children dominate in learning to read and write L1. Literature. Radio.Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, church, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also useCameroon Pidgin [wes], at market and health clinic. Many also use English [eng]. A few also useKom [bkm]. Used as L2 by Kom [bkm].

name: Adzera
LITERACY_L2: 62% (age 10 and over)literate in at least 1 language, probably Tok Pisin [tpi] (2000 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 62% (age 10 and over)literate in at least 1 language, probably Tok Pisin [tpi] (2000 census). Women: 55%; men: 70%.Women and the elderly tend to be least literate. Taught in primary schools in early grades only,in more than 20 elementary schools. NT: 1976.
Language Use: Vigorous despite increased use of Tok Pisin [tpi]. Home, village, church.Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Sarasira [zsa], Sukurum[zsu], Wampur [waz].

name: Kalinga, Limos
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Literature. Radio. Videos. NT: 2004.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Also use Tagalog [tgl]. Used as L2 by Mabaka Valley Kalinga [kkg].

name: Yali, Ninia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20%. Literature. Bible: 2000.
Language Use: Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Quechua, Southern Conchucos Ancash
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. TV. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous in most but not all communities. Spanish-speaking health workers and teachers learn Quechua to communicate. All domains, local administration, written and oral interpretation of Spanish [spa] in church, oral use in commerce labor relations, and health centers. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Koi
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Dumi [dus].

name: Uzbek, Northern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], 1920–1928, symbolic use in Uzbekistan, sometimes used in China. Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], official usage in Uzbekistan between 1940–1992, continued widespread use in Uzbekistan and China. Latin script [Latn], official usage in Uzbekistan since 1992.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. Turks of Fergana and Samarkand speak Uzbek. Uzbek-speaking Roma communities in Russian central Asia. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Sio
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Clark 2012). Some also use English [eng] (Clark 2012). A few also use Kâte [kmg], especially older adults (Clark 2012). A few also use Yabem [jae], especially older adults (Clark 2012). Used as L2 by Gitua [ggt], Mala [mmt].

name: Mbala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: High. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1931–1968.
Language Use: Work; Mixed: Home, Community, Religion, Education. Some young people, all adults. Many also use Kituba [ktu]. Some also use Lingala [lin], especially among the young and in the markets. A few also use Kwese [kws]. A few also use Samba [smx]. A few also use Suku [sub]. Used as L2 by Lonzo [lnz], Suku [sub].

name: Chin, Khumi
Language Development: Some community literacy classes. Radio. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also useRakhine [rki]. Used as L2 by Anu-Khongso Chin [anl].

name: Ama (Sudan)
Language Development: Ama orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature. Bible portions: 1950.
Language Use: L1 widely used, even by children. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Standard Arabic [arb], especially in education.

name: Ngile
Language Development: Literature.

name: Occitan (post 1500)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 99%. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Grammar. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Children who learn it in school cannot communicate in Occitan with their parents (2012). Home, (rural) community. Some young people, all adults, few children. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra].

name: Hote
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–65%. Literature.Texts. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bini
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 1996.
Language Use: Adult education, history.

name: Kambaata
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 44%. Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Culina
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Portuguese [por].

name: Nusu
LITERACY_L2: 68% literate in any language (2000 census, Nu nationality).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 68% literate in any language (2000 census, Nu nationality). Literature. Bible portions: 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Intellectuals want to preserve it. Most also use Lisu [lis].

name: Romanian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], official usage in Moldova until 1991. Cyrillic script, Old Church Slavonic variant [Cyrs], 1688, experimental usage. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1688–1989.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use French [fra] (European Commission 2006).

name: Kabiyé
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], used since the 1970s, primaryusage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–25%. Taught as subject in some secondary schoolsfrom grade 7 onwards, as an optional exam subject, but only for one hour a week. Newspapers.Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1998. Agency: Académie Kabiyè (formerly, Comité de LangueNationale Kabiyè).
Language Use: Vigorous, but code-switching with French [fra] occurs especially in urbanareas (2023 D. Roberts). Home, market, neighborhood, church, non-formal education. Used by all.Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Tem [kdh]. Used as L2 by Kpessi [kef], Lama[las], Lukpa [dop], Miyobe [soy], Nawdm [nmz].

name: Panjabi; Punjabi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Gurmukhi script [Guru], primary usage. Khojki script [Khoj].
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Punjab and West Bengal states. Literature. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 1959–2017.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bauria [bge], Bazigar [bfr], Bhattiyali [bht], Bilaspuri [kfs], Chambeali [cdh], Churahi [cdj], Dogri [dgo], Kangri [xnr], Mandeali [mjl], Sansi [ssi].

name: Pohnpeian
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in Pohnpei state. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1994.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Used as L2 by Mokilese [mkj], Ngatik Men’s Creole [ngm], Nukuoro [nkr], Pingelapese [pif].

name: Kakabai
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Texts. Bible portions: 2009–2023.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Buhutu [bxh]. Also use Dawawa [dww]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Wedau [wed].

name: Tamil
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Braille script [Brai]. Tamil script [Taml], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Tamil Nadu state. Fully developed. Bible: 1727–2002.
Language Use: All also use Kannada [kan] (Gowda 1976). Used as L2 by Alu Kurumba [xua], Attapady Kurumba [pkr], Eravallan [era], Irula [iru], Jennu Kurumba [xuj], Kadar [kej], Kanikkaran [kev], Kannada Kurumba [kfi], Kota [kfe], Malankuravan [mjo], Malapandaram [mjp], Malasar [ymr], Moundadan Chetti [cty], Muthuvan [muv], Paliyan [pcf], Paniya [pcg], Sourashtra [saz], Toda [tcx], Vaagri Booli [vaa].

name: Ida'an
LITERACY_L2: 95% in Standard Malay [zsm];60% in English [eng]; 50% in Suluk [tsg].
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Standard Malay [zsm];60% in English [eng]; 50% in Suluk [tsg]. Literature. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bibleportions: 1987–2011. Agency: PEWARIS (Pertubuhan Kebajikan Idahan Pewaris Madai, Lahad Datu),Persatuan Aktivis Bahasa, Adat dan Budaya Idahan, Sabah (Idahan Language, Customs and CultureActivitist Association, Sabah), Begak Language and Culture Association.
Language Use: Home and Friends. Mixed use: Work and Education. Some young people, alladults. Positive attitudes. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Many also use Standard Malay [zsm].Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Tausug [tsg]. Also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp]. Used asL2 by Suluk [tsg].

name: Koho
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2009–2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Phalura
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], in development. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous within Ashret and Biori valleys. Reluctant to use Palula when speakers of other languages are present. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Khowar [khw]. Many also use Northern Pashto [pbu]. Many also use Urdu [urd].

name: Avaric
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Many also use Kumyk [kum]. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Akhvakh[akv], Andi [ani], Archi [aqc], Bagvalal [kva], Bezhta [kap], Botlikh [bph], Chamalal [cji],Dido [ddo], Ghodoberi [gdo], Hinukh [gin], Hunzib [huz], Karata [kpt], Khvarshi [khv], Tindi[tin], Tsakhur [tkr].

name: Nachhiring
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Degree of Nepalization is very high. Language retention among the younger generation appears to be limited to Bakachol, Rakha, and Bangdel VDCs (Hansson 1991:73; 2011 J. Rai). Religion; mixed use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Dumi [dus], Khaling [klr].

name: Albanian (Gheg)
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Newspapers.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1869–1990.
Language Use: Also use Tosk Albanian [als]. Used as L2 by Vlax Romani [rmy].

name: Blaan, Sarangani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 28%. Literacy rate in L2: 28%. Literature. Videos. NT:1981–2014.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religious settings, Special cultural events.Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use English [eng]. Also useFilipino [fil]. Also use Maguindanaon [mdh]. Also use Sangil [snl]. Also use Sangir [sxn]. Alsouse Sarangani Manobo [mbs]. Also use Tboli [tbl].

name: Oku
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught as subject in some primary and secondary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Lamnsoʼ [lns]. A few also use French [fra]. Also use Noone [nhu]. Used as L2 by Kom [bkm], Lamnsoʼ [lns], Noone [nhu].

name: Kankanay, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%–70%. Literacy rate in L2: 65%–70%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1984.

name: Tondano
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Younger generations mostly use Manado Malay [xmm]. Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Manado Malay [xmm]. Some also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Khamyang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 58% in Assamese [asm] (1981 census). Literature.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Assamese [asm].

name: Bundeli
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Grammar. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Home. Positive attitudes, especially toward Chhatapur dialect. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], but uneducated speakers have low proficiency.

name: Akei
LITERACY_L2: 100% of adults in Bislama [bis] and either English [eng] or French [fra]; between 20%–50% of children in Bislama [bis], English [eng], or French [fra] (2023 P.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 100% of adults; 20%–30% of children. Literacy rate in L2: 100% of adults in Bislama [bis] and either English [eng] or French [fra]; between 20%–50% of children in Bislama [bis], English [eng], or French [fra] (2023 P. Mangohig). Taught in a few primary schools in early grades only. Videos. Bible portions: 1909–1924.
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; Mixed: Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Bislama [bis]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use French [fra]. A few also use Tiale [mnl]. Used as L2 by Moiso [wlr].

name: Sangu (Tanzania)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low in Swahili [swh]. SIL has transition literacy work (Swahili to Sangu). Literature. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Kituba (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools through grade 2 and as subject thereafter, often in combination with Koongo [kng] in the southeast. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1990.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Chokwe [cjk], Ding [diz], Holu [hol], Hungana [hum], Ibali Teke [tek], Iyansi [yns], Kwese [kws], Lele [lel], Lonzo [lnz], Luba-Kasai [lua], Lunda [lun], Mbala [mdp], Mbuun [zmp], Ngongo [noq], Ngwii [nlo], Nzadi [nzd], Phende [pem], Samba [smx], Sonde [shc], Songo [soo], Suku [sub], Wongo [won], Yaka [yaf].

name: Paicî
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Bwatoo [bwa], Haveke [hvk].

name: Lak
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used until 1928. Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used between 1928-1938.
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1996–2023.
Language Use: Many also use Kumyk [kum].

name: Jeh
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Diriku
Language Development: Taught in many primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988.
Language Use: Administration.

name: Kui
Language Development: Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all.

name: Parbate, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Some. Literacy rate in L2: Some. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1985–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous in the villages in Rukum. Home, friends, religion, work. Used by all. Also use Nepali [npi], only when outside their homeland; young men are most proficient, older adult women least proficient in it, and most can discuss common topics in the language.

name: Badaga
Writing: Badaga script [Qabq], in development. Kannada script [Knda], no longer inuse. Latin script [Latn]. Tamil script [Taml], used since 2009.
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Irula [iru], Kota [kfe].

name: Yapese
Language Development: Taught in primary schools in Yap state public education system, but an increasing number of children attend private schools that teach English only. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2007.
Language Use: Losing speakers among the youth. Some young people, all adults. All also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Nguluwan [nuw].

name: Standard Latvian
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1689–1995.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Many also use Russian [rus].

name: Naga, Phom
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 35% adults. Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Tlingit
Language Development: Practical writing system developed in the 1960s. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1969.
