Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Attié
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio. Grammar.NT: 1995.
Language Use: Also use Abé [aba]. Also use Anyin [any]. Also use Baoulé [bci]. Also useFrench [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Tchaman [ebr]. Used as L2 by Beti [eot], Mbato[gwa].

name: Benga
LITERACY_L1: Only a few dozen read Benga (Scripture).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Only a few dozen read Benga (Scripture). All Ndowegroups use Benga hymnal. Literacy rate in L2: Almost 100%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible: 1929.
Language Use: On Corisco, all domains. Some young people, all adults. Away from Coriscoisland, used more by older generation, fewer youth. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish[spa]. All Equatorial Guinean Benga from age 6 are educated in Spanish. Many also use French[fra], due to trade with Gabon. Some also use Fang [fan]. Used as L2 by Bapuku [bnm].

name: Tsamai
Writing: Latin script [Latn], trial orthography since 2018, official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%. Literature.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Hamer-Banna [amf]. Also use Konso [kxc]. Used as L2 by Ongota [bxe].

name: Fur
Language Development: Literacy materials developed. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Sudanese Arabic[apd].

name: Malay, Sabah
Language Development: The Sabah Malay orthography has not been standardized. Reading and writing is done using the Standard Malay [zsm] orthography. Literature. Radio. Videos.
Language Use: Widely spoken in Sabah, beginning as a lingua franca for interaction with other ethnic groups for trading purposes. Since then, its function as a trade language has expanded. There is an increasing number of L1 speakers, especially children of mixed-ethnic parentage. This happens more often in urban areas than rural areas where mono-ethnic groups are concentrated. Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Used as L2 by Abai Sungai [abf], Banjar [bjn], Bonggi [bdg], Bookan Murut [bnb], Brunei [kxd], Bugis [bug], Cocos Islands Malay [coa], Dumpas [dmv], Gana [gnq], Hakka Chinese [hak], Ida’an [dbj], Iranun [ilm], Javanese [jav], Kadazan Dusun [dtp], Kalabakan Murut [kve], Keningau Murut [kxi], Kimaragang [kqr], Klias River Kadazan [kqt], Kolod Murut [kqv], Labuk-Kinabatangan Kadazan [dtb], Lanas Lobu [ruu], Lotud [dtr], Lundayeh [lnd], Mapun [sjm], Minokok [mqq], Molbog [pwm], Northern Tidung [ntd], Rungus [drg], Sabah Bisaya [bsy], Selungai Murut [slg], Sembakung Murut [sbr], Serudung Murut [srk], Southern Sama [ssb], Southern Tidung [itd], Suluk [tsg], Tahol Murut [mvv], Tatana [txx], Timugon Murut [tih], Tobilung [tgb], Tombonuo [txa], Toraja [sda], Upper Kinabatangan [dmg], West Coast Bajau [bdr].

name: Arosi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Over 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Activeliteracy program. Taught in most primary schools in early grades only. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2005.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Iaai
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1901.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Fagauvea[uve] (Lynch 2002a).

name: Akoye
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1994–2000.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to negative. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Epena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. 400 readers, 50 can write. Taught in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005–2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, religion, fiestas, ceremonies, commerce. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa]. Also use Woun Meu [noa].

name: Bassari
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2011–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Wolof[wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Somealso use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017).

name: Tonga (Tonga Islands)
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1862–1966.
Language Use: Ethnic group predominantly monolingual in Tongan (1997 J. Siegel).

name: Belanda Bor
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Belanda Viri [bvi]. Used as L2 byBelanda Viri [bvi].

name: Mamanwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 7%. Literacy rate in L2: 7%. Literature. Grammar. NT: 1982.

name: Tatar
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used prior to 1928. Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Taught as subject in tertiary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2016.
Language Use: Also used by the Karatai (different from Karata [kpt]), ethnically Erzya people who speak Tatar. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Bashkort [bak], Eastern Yiddish [ydd].

name: Pahari, Mahasu
LITERACY_L2: 80% for Shimla District, 82% for Solan (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% for Shimla District, 82% for Solan (2001 census).Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, religion. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin],with more proficiency among educated people.

name: Uzbek, Southern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in print. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Dari [prs]. L1 literacy in larger towns increasing among younger population. Taught as subject in some primary schools in grades 1–3, but without much success. The Afghanistan Ministry of Education has produced Southern Uzbek textbooks through twelfth grade. No use of these materials reported. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2004–2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Dari [prs], especially in urban areas. Many also use Urdu [urd]. Also use Southern Pashto [pbt]. Used as L2 by Turkmen [tuk].

name: Lango
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: All domains, some use in schools, churches, and government offices. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], mostly used in church and schools. Also use Juba Arabic [pga]. Used as L2 by Imotong [imt], Logir [lqr].

name: Tahitian
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1838–1913.

name: Libido
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 16%. Taught in primary schools in grades 1–3. Taught as a major at the university level.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Bulgarian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage. Cyrillicscript, Old Church Slavonic variant [Cyrs], 19th century, experimental usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools.Fully developed. Bible: 1864–1923.
Language Use: The Sopa are of Petecheneg origin and speak Bulgarian. Some also useEnglish [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use Standard German [deu] (EuropeanCommission 2006).

name: Khasi
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], usedsince about 1842.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 63% in Meghalaya (2001 census). Taught in primary andsecondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Meghalaya state. Literature.Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1891–2016.
Language Use: Government, courts, mass media in Meghalaya. Used as L2 by Biate [biu],Sakachep [sch], War-Jaintia [aml].

name: Iranun (Malaysia)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%–95% in Standard Malay[zsm]. Taught in 3 preschools. Periodicals. Dictionary. Texts. Agency: Persatuan Bahasa danKebudayaan Iranun Sabah (BKI).
Language Use: Home, Friends, Religion. Mixed use: Work, Education. Some young people, alladults, few children. All also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Many also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp],especially speakers of the Tempasuk dialect. Many also use West Coast Bajau [bdr]. Some also useStandard Malay [zsm]. A few also use Rungus [drg]. Used as L2 by Bugis [bug], Rungus [drg].

name: Varhadi-Nagpuri
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2017.

name: Gamo
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Church literature. Latin script [Latn],official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 18%. Church-based literacy program started 2007.Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Taught as amajor at the university level. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Everyday rural life. Neutral attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2by Baiso [bsw], Ethiopian Sign Language [eth], Mositacha [dox].

name: Buwal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 30% in Fulfulde [fub], 20% inFrench [fra]. L1 literacy is new. Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Some also use Gavar [gou].Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], in markets and churches. Also use French [fra], as language ofinstruction in school. Used as L2 by Gavar [gou], Mafa [maf], Mbudum [xmd].

name: Nadëb
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. Those living near Santa Isabel are reported to be partially assimilated into local Brazilian culture and may be losing their native language. Those in Riacho Escondido are all full speakers (Crevels 2007). Many also use Portuguese [por], and some are reported to be partially assimilated into local Brazilian culture and may be losing their native language.

name: Chichewa; Nyanja
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in grades 1–4. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1905–1998.
Language Use: Most Ngoni in Malawi speak the Chewa dialect or Tumbuka [tum]. Used as L2 by Kokola [kzn], Malawi Lomwe [lon], Malawian Sign Language [lws], Yao [yao].

name: Tswana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%–90%. Official language of instruction grades 1–4 in all government primary schools. Taught in all primary and secondary schools in grades 1 and 2 and as subject thereafter. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1857–1993.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used among the educated. More for spoken purposes than written. Used by all.

name: Sambal, Tinà
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 98%. Literacy rate in L2: 98%. Orthography similar to Filipino [fil]. English and Filipino taught in school. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1999–2000.
Language Use: Youth start using it at work if they do not go on to higher education; little use among children. Not used around outsiders, but they like it when outsiders learn Sambal. All domains among adults. Oral use in local commerce, occasional use in religion and political campaigning. Some letter-writing. Adults only. Shifting to Filipino [fil]. Some also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Ramoaaina
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–90%. Most adults can read it, 10% can write it. Literature. Videos. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], especially youth. Also use Kuanua [ksd], especially older adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Kandas [kqw], Konomala [koa].

name: Kenyah, Kelinyau
Language Development: Literature. NT: 1978–2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used as L2 by Uma’ Lasan [xky], Uma’ Lung [ulu], Wahau Kenyah [whk].

name: Kayah, Western
Writing: Kayah Li script [Kali], primary usage. Latin script [Latn], preferred by Catholics. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], limited usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy classes in some communities. NT: 2010–2014. Agency: Kayah Literature and Culture Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use S’gaw Karen [ksw]. Also use Burmese [mya], especially among Baptists, but among others as well. Used as L2 by Eastern Kayah [eky].

name: Sheko
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 16%. Kindergarten and adult literacy programs using Me’en [mym] as medium of instruction are piloted (2021 SIL). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, religion, community. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use Bench [bcq].

name: Yemba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Taught in a few primary schools in early grades only. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use Ngiemboon [nnh]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use Ngwe [nwe]. Used as L2 by Mbo [mbo], Ngiemboon [nnh], Ngwe [nwe].

name: Kenyang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 30% (gov’t figure). Usedinformally in education. Literature. Radio. NT: 2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Cameroon Pidgin[wes]. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Denya [anv]. Some also use Ejagham [etu]. Afew also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Akoose [bss], Denya [anv], Ejagham [etu], Kendem [kvm].

name: Dogon, Tomo Kan
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Limbum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Some literacy classes. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng], as language of public education. Some also use Lamnsoʼ [lns]. A few also use Noone [nhu]. A few also use Tigon Mbembe [nza]. A few also use Yamba [yam]. Used as L2 by Kemedzung [dmo], Lamnsoʼ [lns], Nchane [ncr], Noone [nhu], Sari [asj], Tigon Mbembe [nza], Yamba [yam].

name: Agarabi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature.Videos. NT: 2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kinaray-A
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 95%. Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Hiligaynon [hil]. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. NT: 2009. Agency: Paranublian.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Hiligaynon [hil], especially in church and school. Acquired through school, travel, and media. Used as L2 by Ati [atk].

name: Thai (Northern)
Writing: Tai Tham (Lanna) script [Lana], limited usage. Thai script [Thai].
Language Development: Newspapers. Dictionary. NT: 1914–2017.
Language Use: Most use Northern Thai in the home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Thai [tha]. Used as L2 by Akha [ahk], Bisu [bzi], Eastern Lawa [lwl], Hakka Chinese [hak], Iu Mien [ium], Lü [khb], Mlabri [mra], Mpi [mpz], Phrae Pwo Karen [kjt], Prai [prt], Tai Ya [cuu], Western Lawa [lcp], Yong [yno].

name: Gbe, Saxwe
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Radio. NT: 2022.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use Fon [fon]. Most also use Gen [gej]. Some also use Aja [ajg]. Some also use Ayizo Gbe [ayb]. Some also use Kotafon Gbe [kqk]. Also use French [fra], to extents varying with education level. Used as L2 by Ayizo Gbe [ayb], Gbesi Gbe [gbs], Kotafon Gbe [kqk], Xwela Gbe [xwe].

name: Mundari
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Devanagari script [Deva], used in India. Latin script [Latn]. Nag Mundari script [Nagm]. Ol Onal script [Onao], used in Odisha, West Bengal, and Jharkhand in India. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1910–2002.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck]. Used as L2 by Birhor [biy], Mahali [mjx].

name: Ifugao, Amganad
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 60% (2007 SIL). 17,550 readit and 14,000 write it (2007 SIL). Literature. Videos. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Many Ifugao parents raising children in non-Ifugao-speaking areas do notteach Ifugao to their children (2007 SIL). All domains as well as religious services,traditional ceremonies, administration, and commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Used as L2 by Tuwali Ifugao[ifk].

name: Ebrié
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Attié [ati], Beti [eot].

name: Mru
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Mro script [Mroo], developed in the 1980s.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Literacy materials are being developed using the Krama script. Literature. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Marma [rmz]. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use Chittagonian [ctg].

name: Quichua, Chimborazo Highland
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1989–2010.

name: Kamba (Kenya)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 10% (2007 BTL). Literacy rate in L2: 25%–60%(2007 BTL). Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. Bible: 1956.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Gichuka [cuh].

name: Kankanaey
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 78%. Taught in most primary schools in grades 1–3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1990–2016.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Southwestern Bontok [vbk].

name: Kisan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 17% (1981 census). Materials for multilingual education have been prepared in Kisan. Taught in primary schools, in 20 schools in Sambalpur district. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Odia [ory].

name: Kallahan, Kayapa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85%. Mother-tongue multilingual education has beenimplemented in primary schools. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, church, community affairs. Used by all. Positive attitudes.All also use Ilocano [ilo]. All also use Tagalog [tgl]. Used as L2 by Karao [kyj].

name: Gaddi
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longerin use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 37% for Jammu and Kashmir (2001 census). Radio. NT:2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], in shops, cities, and aslanguage of instruction in schools.

name: Sindhi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], primary usage. Devanagari script [Deva], used in India. Gurmukhi script [Guru], used in India. Khojki script [Khoj].
Language Development: Taught as subject in most primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1954.
Language Use: Also use Saraiki [skr], in northern Sind. Used as L2 by Aer [aeq], Bagri [bgq], Dhatki [mki], Eastern Balochi [bgp], Ghera [ghr], Goaria [gig], Gurgula [ggg], Jandavra [jnd], Jogi [jog], Loarki [lrk], Marwari [mve], Memoni [mby], Oadki [odk], Parkari Koli [kvx], Sansi [ssi], Sindhi Bhil [sbn], Southern Balochi [bcc], Vaghri [vgr].

name: Jarai
Writing: Khmer script [Khmr], used in Cambodia. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio.Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Burmese
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1835–2014.
Language Use: Many Mon, some Shan, some Karen are monolingual in Burmese. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Iamalele
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught in many primary schools in Prep to grade 2. Dictionary. NT: 1984–1999.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Bwaidoka [bwd]. Also use Dobu [dob]. Used as L2 by Koluwawa [klx], Minaveha [mvn].

name: Tajik
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used until 1928. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used since 1940, primary usage. Hebrew script [Hebr], used by Bukharan Jews in Uzbekistan. Latin script [Latn], used between 1928–1940.
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools. Literature. Radio. Bible: 1992–1999.
Language Use: Also use Northern Uzbek [uzn]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Dida, Yocoboué
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. TV.Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Eastern Durango Nahuatl
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 16% (Durango). Literature. Radio. Videos. Texts. Bibleportions: 2019.
Language Use: The migration of Southeastern Tepehuan [stp] speakers into the area overthe last few decades has put more pressure on Nahuatl speakers than the influence of Spanish[spa] as a lingua franca. Much intermarriage with the Tepehuan group. Some young people, alladults. Also use Southeastern Tepehuan [stp]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Meohang, Eastern
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Home, religion; mixed use: Friends, work. Some young people, all adults.Also use Kulung [kle]. Also use Lohorung [lbr]. Also use Nepali [npi], with some youth shifting.

name: Makaa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: All domains in rural areas. Many also use French [fra]. A few also use Baka [bdh]. Used as L2 by Baka [bkc], Kol [biw], Northwest Gbaya [gya].

name: Kagayanen
LITERACY_L2: 75% in Hiligaynon [hil],Filipino [fil], Cuyonon [cyo], Kinaray-a [krj], or Cebuano [ceb].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 85%. Literacy rate in L2: 75% in Hiligaynon [hil],Filipino [fil], Cuyonon [cyo], Kinaray-a [krj], or Cebuano [ceb]. Tendency to believe reading isin Filipino [fil] or English [eng]. Kagayanen used for speaking (2007 SIL). Literature.Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Texts. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Some oral use in local administration, commerce,religion, some schools. Letters, oral literature. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useCuyonon [cyo]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Hiligaynon [hil].

name: Ntcham
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 10% in French [fra].Radio. Videos. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Dispersed Ntcham speakers using Ntcham less. Home, work, with friends. Usedby all. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra]. Also use Konkomba [xon]. Also use Tem [kdh].Used as L2 by Akaselem [aks], Konkomba [xon].

name: Rawang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Older generation is more literate in Rawang; younger generation literacy rate in Rawang is declining. Newspapers. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1986. Agency: Rawang Language and Culture Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Rawang literature used mainly in church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Burmese [mya], especially young people. Also use Jingpho [kac]. Also use Lisu [lis]. Used as L2 by Anong [nun], Drung [duu], Lisu [lis].

name: Tibetan, Amdo
Language Development: Classroom teachers use it, but Modern Literary Tibetan [bod] is thelanguage of literature. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Baima [bqh], Bonan [peh], Choni [cda], Salar[slr], Wutunhua [wuh].

name: Cashibo-Cacataibo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 69%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subjectin some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1978–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All children acquire the language (Crevels 2007). All domains.Used by all. All also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mundani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Njen [njj].

name: Yala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in English [eng]. Literacy program in progress. Literature. NT: 1979.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Bekwarra [bkv], Nkem-Nkum [isi], Yace [ekr].

name: Mamasa
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Religion; Mixed use: Work, Education. Used by all. All also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Panasuan [psn], Ulumanda’ [ulm].

name: Farefare
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Radio.Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 byMampruli [maw].

name: Akha
LITERACY_L2: 70% in any language (2000census, Hani nationality); but functional literacy is low in Mandarin [cmn].
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used at least since 1950, used in China, Myanmar, andThailand. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], used in Myanmar. Thai script [Thai], used inThailand.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 70% in any language (2000census, Hani nationality); but functional literacy is low in Mandarin [cmn]. Orthographies infairly wide use, but not in public schools (Bradley 2007b). Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible: 2002.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese[cmn]. Used as L2 by Akeu [aeu].

name: Burunge
Language Development: No L1 literacy rate reported. Transitional and basic literacy taught forabout 10 years. Literature. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Formerly felt inhibited to speak Burunge in public, but now less common asmore and more publications are printed in Burunge. Home, field, some in churches. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Also use Rangi [lag]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Naga, Nocte
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 47% (2001 census). Radio. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Home, village, religion. Used by all. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Mazanderani
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: Very high in Persian [pes]. The educated can read Farsi [pes] well. Taught as subject in some secondary schools; maximum 2 hours per week on Mazandarani culture and literature. Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: Reportedly increased interest, but increasing desire for children to be educated and therefore be taught Iranian Persian [pes] as first language to better their opportunities. Home, market, work. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to positive. Also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Kamasau
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Wawonii
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind]. Some also use Kulisusu [vkl]. Some also use Tolaki [lbw]. Used as L2 by Indonesian Bajau [bdl], Muna [mnb].

name: Koongo
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools through grade 2 and as subject thereafter in the southwest of the country. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1905–1962.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kiyombe [yom].

name: Gedeo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Taught in primary and secondary schools throughgrade 4 and as subject thereafter. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Surigaonon
Writing: Latin script [Latn], informal use on social media.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3.
Language Use: Rapid shift towards Cebuano [ceb], especially in Surigao City and surrounding parts of (eastern) Surigao del Norte, where Cebuano is now the main language used (2023 R. Gonzales). Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cebuano [ceb]. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Chatino, Western Highland
Language Development: 500 readers, 50 can write. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.NT: 1992.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Oral use in local administration, commerce,religious services, some in primary and secondary education. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Also use English [eng]. Also use Tataltepec Chatino [cta]. Also use Zenzontepec Chatino [czn].

name: Yasa
LITERACY_L1: Few proficient writers in the revised orthography (Belew 2020: 105).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Few proficient writers in the revised orthography (Belew 2020: 105). Want literacy. Radio. Bible portions: 2017–2019.
Language Use: Youth moving to towns, where language proficiency decreases. All domains. Some of all ages. Many children have only limited or passive competence in Iyasa (Belew 2020: 104–105). Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Many also use Fang [fan], where the Mvae dialect of Fang is spoken, around Campo and to the south (Bikoi 2012). Some also use Bulu [bum]. Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes], around Campo beach. Some also use Gyele [gyi], around Lolabe and Nazareth (Campo neighborhood). Some also use Kwasio [nmg], where the Mabi dialect of Kwasio is used in Nlende and other Mabi settlements in the Iyasa language area. Some also use Spanish [spa], in Campo Beach and along the Ntem river. Used as L2 by Bulu [bum].

name: Karon
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 2016–2019.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Also use Jola-Fonyi [dyo]. Also use Mandinka [mnk].

name: Somali
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], used since 1972. Osmanya script [Osma], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25% in cities, 10% rural. Taught in all primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1979.
Language Use: Language of most of the people of the country. Also use Italian [ita]. Also use Standard Arabic [arb].

name: Quechua, Cajamarca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–35%. Series of basic primers and graded readers in Quechua. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2004–2008.
Language Use: Relatively strong use in 8 to 10 communities. Strong pressure from Spanish in all communities due to secondary schools and gold mining in the area. Many deny its existence (2000 D. Coombs). Home. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa], speaking a country dialect of it.

name: Shona
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 86% in English [eng] and Shona [sna]. Taught in some primary schools in grades 1–3 in areas where Shona is spoken. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1949–1980.
Language Use: Dominant African language understood by a considerable number. Primarily a written language apparently based on Karanga and Zezuru with lexical items also from Manyika and Korekore. Urban populations tend to speak school or standard Shona. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Chichewa [nya], Kalanga [kck], Kunda [kdn], Nambya [nmq], Nsenga [nse], Tonga [toi], Zimbabwe Sign Language [zib].

name: Kunama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Females: 21%. Literacy rate in L2: Low. Taught in primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2012.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Bilen [byn], Nara [nrb].

name: Idun
Language Development: A vigorous literacy program is being planned. Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 2011–2017.
Language Use: Home, market, some schools. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Hausa [hau], with some youth shifting.

name: Rapoisi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in at least 3 of 8 schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1994–2003.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], in schools.

name: Khamti
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya] (Bradley 2007a). Also use Jingpho [kac].

name: Loma (Liberia)
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Loma script [Loma], limited usage except for correspondence.
Language Development: Literature and literacy program in progress. Grammar. NT: 1971.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir]. Used as L2 by Kuwaa [blh], Manya [mzj].

name: Norwegian
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1904–1985.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng].

name: Camling
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Home, religion; mixed use: friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Puma [pum].

name: Buhutu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. About 100 locallyauthored titles, plus audio and written translated materials. Literature. Dictionary. Texts.Bible portions: 2011–2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Suau[swp]. Many also use Tawala [tbo]. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo].Used as L2 by Haigwai [hgw], Kakabai [kqf], Suau [swp], Yaleba [ylb].

name: Tombonuwo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Standard Malay [zsm]. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2002. Agency: Kota Kinabalu Tombonuo Association, Persatuan Bangsa Tombonuo Pitas, Persatuan Bangsa Tombonuo Beluran.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Family, Work, Education, Religion. Some young people, all adults. Few children, some adolescents, many adults, all elderly. Positive attitudes. A few also use Rungus [drg]. Also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp]. Also use Kimaragang [kqr]. Also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Used as L2 by Dumpas [dmv], Rungus [drg].

name: Mampruli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–10%. 48 literacy teachers; about 20 primary schools, 10 junior secondary schools, 3 secondary schools. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Bimoba [bim]. Also use Bisa [bib]. Also use Farefare [gur]. Used as L2 by Konni [kma].

name: Ladakhi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–50% (2001 census). Literacy rate in L2: 54%–65% men, 40% women. Percentage of those who can actually read with understanding is lower than census literacy rate indicates. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Brokskat [bkk], Changthang [cna], Zangskari [zau].

name: Chechen
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Cyrillic script[Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used between 1925–1938.
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in the Chechnya republic. Newspapers.Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2012.
Language Use: Largest Nakh-Daghestanian language. Used in publishing. Many also use Kumyk[kum]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Quechua, Corongo Ancash
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Literature. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2017–2018.
Language Use: Family, community. Adults only. Shifting to Spanish [spa], especially the young.

name: Sadri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1931–2016.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially in the market, with leaders, and for prayer and worship, but proficiency is low. Also use Odia [ory]. Used as L2 by Asuri [asr], Bijori [bix], Birhor [biy], Ho [hoc], Kharia [khr], Koda [cdz], Kodaku [ksz], Korwa [kfp], Kurux [kru], Mahali [mjx], Majhi [mjz], Munda [unx], Mundari [unr], Santhali [sat], Sora [srb], Turi [trd].

name: Aringa
Language Development: Literature. Radio. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market. Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Lugbara [lgg]. Some also use Swahili [swh]. Also use Nubi [kcn] (Nakao 2018). Used as L2 by Kuku [ukv].

name: Silt'e
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 17%. Literacy rate increasing. Taught in primary schools in grades 1–4. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1981–1988.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Tausug
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1985–2002. Agency: Anak-Sug Association.
Language Use: Vigorous. There are some distinctions in the variety of Tausug spoken by the youth in Zamboanga City from the original variety spoken in Jolo due to lexical borrowing from Chavacano [cbk] and other languages of Zamboanga (2023 E. Jainal). All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Balangingih Sama [sse]. Some also use Chavacano [cbk]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Tagalog [tgl]. Also use Kalagan [kqe]. Used as L2 by Balangingih Sama [sse], Central Sama [sml], Chavacano [cbk], Mapun [sjm], Pangutaran Sama [slm], Southern Sama [ssb], Western Subanon [suc], Yakan [yka].

name: Sampang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Nepali [npi], with some shifting, especially men, educated, and younger people. Valued as a language of education. Used as L2 by Dumi [dus].

name: Awadhi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Education is in Hindi [hin]. Considerableepic literature. Hindu holy book, Ramcharitmanas, by Tulsi Das. Literature. Newspapers.Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2000–2005.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Cofán
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Schools are in Spanish[spa], except for early grades which provide bilingual education. Taught as subject in someprimary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1980–2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some Siona and Secoya have learned Cofán due to intermarriage,and their children learn Cofán. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use NapoQuichua [qvo]. Also use Paicoca [sey]. Also use Siona [snn]. Also use Spanish [spa], which isthe language of instruction in school, except for early grades which provide bilingualeducation.

name: Ifugao, Batad
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 55%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 55%–60%. Literature.Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2010.

name: Bamunka
Language Development: Basic literacy materials. Radio. Bible portions: 2008–2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English[eng].

name: Amuzgo, Guerrero
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10% adults, 15% children. Literacy rate in L2: 30%adults; 80% children. 5,000 readers, 500 can write. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1973–2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains: some local adminstration, business. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa], becoming more proficient with education.

name: Hajong
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], used in Bangladesh and India. Latin script[Latn], used in India.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%–25%; 48% for Meghalaya (2001 census). Literature.Radio. TV. Bible portions: 2010–2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Assamese [asm].Educated have high fluency in Assamese. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also useGaro [grt]. Used as L2 by Koch [kdq].

name: Karen, Pa'o
Language Development: Literacy classes in some communities, especially at Buddhist monasteries.Dictionary. NT: 1961–2009. Agency: Pa’o Literature and Culture Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya]. Also use Shan [shn]. Used as L2 by Danau [dnu], Lahta [kvt], Zayein [kxk].

name: Inabaknon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 11,000 can read and write. Literacy rate in L2:90%–95%. Written form used in village health education, song books, some event programs, andreligious ceremonies. Literature. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Vigorous. New inhabitants of Capul Island tend to learn the language orleave. All domains. Used by all. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use Central Bikol [bcl]. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil].

name: Min Dong Chinese
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans], used since 1987. Han script,Traditional variant [Hant]. Latin script [Latn], developed and revised to final form during late19th century.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate inChinese, and they use that literature. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1884–1905.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kayan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Burmese [mya]; 10% in Sgaw Karen [ksw]. Literacy classes in some communities. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2009–2015.
Language Use: Vigorous in most areas, but in some larger towns, children are no longer learning it. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use S’gaw Karen [ksw]. Also use Burmese [mya]. Used as L2 by Lahta [kvt], Zayein [kxk].

name: Mewari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 38% (2001 census). Radio. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Home, village. Positive attitudes. Many also use Hindi [hin]. Also use English [eng].

name: Laro
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literature. Bible portions: 2004–2011.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Maba (Chad)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Low motivation. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains in the village; home only in the towns. All ages in the villages; mostly adults in towns. Mixed attitudes. The language is generally valued less than Arabic. Many also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Kendeje [klf], Surbakhal [sbj].

name: Malay, Pattani
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Thai script [Thai].
Language Development: Taught in some primary schools in early grades only. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Some young people don’t use the full spectrum of Pattani Malay [mfa] vocabulary anymore that their grandparents and parents use. However, young people can undertand Pattani Malay [mfa]. Young people use more Thai [tha] now in their daily life especially in primary school. Used by all. Most also use Thai [tha]. Used as L2 by Jehai [jhi].

name: Lumun
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 1998–2011.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Used as L2 by Tocho [taz].

name: Mamuju
Writing: Buginese script [Bugi], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Radio. Texts.
Language Use: Home; Mixed use: Work; Education. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Mandar [mdr]. A few also use Bugis [bug]. Used as L2 by Budong-Budong [bdx], Ulumanda’ [ulm].

name: Boro
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used until 2007. Latin script [Latn], used since2007.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25% in Amharic [amh]. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used by all children in Dibat’e and Bulenand by most children in Dangur. Spoken by a minority of children in Wenbera; most speak Oromo[hae]. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use West Central Oromo [gaz].

name: Anufo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Naga, Ao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 86% (2001 census). Literacy rate in L2: 86% (2001 census). Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1964–2004.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Chang Naga [nbc], Sangtam Naga [nsa], Sumi Naga [nsm].

name: Papiamento
Language Development: Taught in a few primary schools in grades 1 and 2. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1997.
Language Use: Importance varies by island. Use of both Papiamentu and Dutch [nld] not considered an indication of lack of education. Dutch use fosters social and political mobility. All domains. Used by all. Also use Dutch [nld]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ngombale
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Mostly women and children are literate in L1. Literature. NT: 2019.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use French [fra], especially young people. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use Ngiemboon [nnh], mostly adults. A few also use Ngomba [jgo]. Used as L2 by Ngomba [jgo].

name: Tai Nüa
LITERACY_L2: 84% literate in any language (2000 census, Dai nationality).
Writing: Tai Le script [Tale], used in the Dehong Dai and Jingpho Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province, China.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 84% literate in any language (2000 census, Dai nationality). Tai Nüa has traditional script and tradition of literacy, so percentages probably include literacy in Liek or Chinese script or both. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1931–1948.
Language Use: Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Herero
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible: 1987.

name: Sadri, Oraon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Literature. NT: 2003. Agency: Bangladesh Oraon Foundation.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Bengali [ben], quite fluently. Some also use Rangpuri [rkt], in Rangpur division.

name: Yakan
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 35%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1984.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Local administration, commerce, religion, oral traditional literature. Positive attitudes. Also use Chavacano [cbk]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Tausug [tsg].

name: Nafusi
Language Development: Radio. TV. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Jawe
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Pwaamei [pme].

name: Pökoot
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Efforts underway to develop functional literacy in Pökoot for all ages. Literature. Radio. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], especially for education and communication with outsiders. Also use Swahili [swh], especially for education and communication with outsiders. Used as L2 by Turkana [tuv].

name: Kasem
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15% in French [fra], 15% in Mòoré [mos]. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988–1997.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Moore [mos].

name: Tetun Dili
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in grades 1–6, with Portuguese [por] taught as a subject in the lower grades and gradually introduced as a language of instruction with Tetun Dili in the higher grades (2021 SIL). Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Increasing in use in urban areas. All domains. Used by all. Also use Tetun [tet], some bilingually, but many others have significant difficulty understanding it in many domains.

name: Bafut
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy programs in 20 schools and 30 churches.Taught in a few primary schools in early grades only; taught as subject in some other schools.Literature. Radio. Grammar. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Home, market, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also useCameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Ngemba [nge]. A few also useFrench [fra]. A few also use Mungaka [mhk]. Used as L2 by Ngemba [nge].

name: Giryama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible: 1901–2018.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Chichonyi-Chidzihana-Chikauma [coh]. Also use English [eng], which is learned by school children. Also use Kipfokomu [pkb]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Chichonyi-Chidzihana-Chikauma [coh], Kipfokomu [pkb], Waata [ssn].

name: Faroese
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools through grade 10 (uppersecondary school). Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1948–1961.
Language Use: Also use Danish [dan].

name: Bafanji
Language Development: Basic literacy materials. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Home, neighborhood, farm. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also useCameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Mankong [bqt].

name: Dinka, Southwestern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Extensive literacy materials available. Taught assubject in some primary schools through grade 3. The Ministry of Education, supported by donors,has started a pilot project to develop materials for teaching Dinka (all 4 varieties together)as a subject and as language of instruction up to grade 3 in some schools. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2006–2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Bongo [bot],Thuri [thu].

name: Friulian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Taught as subject in primary schools in Udine,Gorizia, and Pordenone provinces. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1972.Agency: Agjenzie Regjonâl pe Lenghe Furlane (Regional Friulian Language Agency).
Language Use: Children who stop using Friulian, after having learned it at school,normally shift to Italian [ita]. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.Most also use Italian [ita]. Used as L2 by Bavarian [bar], Italian [ita], Slovene [slv].

name: Khiamniungan Naga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Radio. Bible: 2005–2019.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Bakoko
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Radio. Grammar. NT:2023.
Language Use: Home, church, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French[fra]. Many also use Basaa [bas]. Many also use Duala [dua]. Used as L2 by Basaa [bas], Bati[btc].

name: Jingpho
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Some communityliteracy classes. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible:1927–2016.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Usedas L2 by Khamti [kht], Lacid [lsi], Lhao Vo [mhx], Lisu [lis], Rawang [raw], Rumai Palaung[rbb], Zaiwa [atb].

name: Wichí Lhamtés Güisnay
Language Development: Radio. Texts. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Biali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15–20% in French [fra].Radio. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Notre [bly].

name: Bambam
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. NT: 2004–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home; Mixed: Community, Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Mossi
Writing: Braille script [Brai], developed in 2010. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 24% (2006 census). Used in adult literacy classes (2021 SIL). Taught as subject in some primary schools through grades 3–5. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1983.
Language Use: Dominant African language of Burkina Faso. Used by all. Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Bisa [bib], Dagaari Dioula [dgd], Gourmanchéma [gux], Kalamsé [knz], Kasem [xsm], Koromfé [kfz], Lyélé [lee], Malba Birifor [bfo], Matya Samo [stj], Maya Samo [sym], Sininkere [skq], Southern Nuni [nnw], Southern Samo [sbd].

name: Judeo-Tat
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage. Hebrew script [Hebr]. Latin script[Latn], used in Azerbaijan.
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 2011.

name: Raji
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 22% (1991 census). Literacy in Nepali [npi] is increasing since parents have started sending their children to school. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Agency: Raji Shalma Samaj.
Language Use: In one village in Kailali District, Khailad VDC, speakers under 6 years of age and over 60 years old are monolingual. Religion; mixed use: Home, friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Apalaí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 60% in Portuguese [por].Taught in most primary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter. Taught non-formally inadult literacy classes. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Some also use Portuguese [por]. Some also use Trió[tri]. Some also use Wayampi [oym]. Also use Wayana [way]. Used as L2 by Kaxuiâna [kbb], Trió[tri], Wayampi [oym], Wayana [way].

name: Seri
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1982.
Language Use: All domains, except education. Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Quichua, Santiago del Estero
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1990.
Language Use: Vigorous. Increased use by media, musical groups. Chair of Quichua in the National University. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sirmauri
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], special variety used informally (Masica 1991).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% for Sirmaur District (2001 census). Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, village. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], with high proficiency among educated people, and a wide range of proficiency among uneducated people, but older, uneducated women have very limited proficiency.

name: Mixtec, Silacayoapan
Language Development: Literature. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Used by all.

name: Alemannic(specifically: Swiss German, Alsatian)
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1984–1997.
Language Use: Varieties have strong social function in maintaining borders of regions,cantons, and villages. They also distinguish between German, Swiss, and Austrian nationalities.93% of German speakers in Switzerland speak a variety of Swiss German; 66% only use Swiss Germanand no High German in the home (1990 census). 72% of Switzerland speaks Schwyzerdütsch daily(1990 census). Some in schools and churches. Also use Standard German [deu], the language ofinstruction in school. Used as L2 by Kabuverdianu [kea].

name: Sena, Malawi
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Bible: 2005.

name: Choctaw
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught assubject in tertiary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1848. Language preservation activitiesemphasize distance learning (Golla 2007). Taught in the Choctaw Tribal School System, as well asin numerous classes that are not tied to specific institutions.
Language Use: Prominent in church. Some young people, all adults. All ages inMississippi, middle-aged and older in Oklahoma. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 byKoasati [cku].

name: Aymara (Central)
Language Development: Churches active in literacy. Government schools open to use of Aymaraliterature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1987–2012.
Language Use: In spite of large user population considered potentially endangered due tolack of intergenerational transmission of the language (Crevels 2007). Some young people, alladults. Used as L2 by Chipaya [cap], North Bolivian Quechua [qul], Uru [ure].

name: Khowar
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20% men, 1% women. Taught as subject in someprimary schools. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: The most important language of Chitral. Most also use Urdu [urd],especially among the educated, and in schools. Some also use Burushaski [bsk], especially in theGilgit District. Some also use English [eng], especially among the educated. Some also use Gawri[gwc]. Some also use Northern Pashto [pbu]. Some also use Shina [scl], especially in the GilgitDistrict. Used as L2 by Burushaski [bsk], Gawarbati [gwt], Kalasha [kls], Kateviri [bsh],Komviri [xvi], Madaklashti [prs], Palula [phl], Wakhi [wbl], Yadgha [ydg].

name: Halia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Radio.Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1978–2020.
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Oppermann 2011). Used as L2 by Petats [pex],Solos [sol].

name: Ayta, Mag-Indi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Less than 50%. Literacy rate in L2: Less than 50%.Taught as subject in most primary schools in grades 1–3. Literature. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Home, community, work, education, religion. Some of all ages. Positiveattitudes. Most also use Filipino [fil]. Most also use Kapampangan [pam].

name: Alagwa
LITERACY_L2: Many are literate in Swahili [swh]; some also in Arabic [arb].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Many are literate in Swahili [swh]; some also in Arabic [arb]. Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous in most villages. Home. Some young people, all adults. Most children use Alagwa as L1. In mixed villages children tend to speak Rangi [lag] among themselves. Positive attitudes. Most also use Rangi [lag] (Sommer 1992). Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Koromfé
Language Development: Literacy program in progress. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT:2017.
Language Use: Also use Moore [mos]. Also use Western Niger Fulfulde [fuh].

name: Toba
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Speakers’ competence varies considerably according to location, age and attitude (Crevels 2007). Home, friends, work, religion. Some young people, all adults. All ages in the smaller communities; adult speakers in larger towns and cities.

name: Murle
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Very few schools due to pastoral lifestyle and inter-tribal tension. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Keningau Murut
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Young people prefer Sabah Malay [msi], Standard Malay [zsm]. Mixed use: Home, Friends. Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Sabah Malay [msi]. Most also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Some also use Bookan Murut [bnb]. Some also use Hakka Chinese [hak]. Some also use Paluan Murut [plz]. Some also use Tahol Murut [mvv]. Some also use Timugon Murut [tih]. A few also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp]. A few also use Kuijau [dkr]. Used as L2 by Gana [gnq].

name: Carolinian
Language Development: L1 taught, but English is language of instruction. Taught as subject inprimary and secondary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Videos. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Chamorro [cha],on Saipan; many speakers over age 50 speak it with a high level of proficiency. All also useEnglish [eng].

name: Naga, Tase
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous in remote areas; lessening in town areas. Shifting to Burmese [mya] in town areas. All domains in remote areas. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Stieng, Bulo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1971.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Iloko
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Tagalog script[Tglg], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. Bible: 1909–1996.
Language Use: Also use Abellen Ayta [abp]. Also use Bolinao [smk]. Also use Ibatan [ivb],especially migrants. Used as L2 by Abellen Ayta [abp], Adasen [tiu], Amganad Ifugao [ifa], Arta[atz], Balangao [blw], Binongan Itneg [itb], Bogkalot [ilk], Butbut Kalinga [kyb], CentralBontok [lbk], Central Cagayan Agta [agt], Dupaninan Agta [duo], Eastern Bontok [ebk], Gaꞌdang[gdg], Gaddang [gad], Ibanag [ibg], Ibatan [ivb], Inlaud Itneg [iti], Isinay [inn], Isnag [isd],Itawit [itv], Kalanguya [kak], Karao [kyj], Keley-i Kallahan [ify], Limos Kalinga [kmk],Lubuagan Kalinga [knb], Maeng Itneg [itt], Maguindanaon [mdh], Majukayang Kalinga [kmd],Masadiit Itneg [tis], Mayoyao Ifugao [ifu], Moyadan Itneg [ity], Northern Bontok [rbk], PahananAgta [apf], Pamplona Atta [att], Paranan [prf], Sambal [xsb], Southern Bontok [obk], SouthernKalinga [ksc], Southwestern Bontok [vbk], Tanudan Kalinga [kml], Tuwali Ifugao [ifk], UmirayDumaget Agta [due], Vanaw Kalinga [bjx], Villa Viciosa Agta [dyg], Yogad [yog].

name: Zaghawa
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Lonzo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 49%. Radio.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion, Work. Used by all. Many also use French [fra]. Many also use Kituba [ktu]. Many also use Lingala [lin]. Some also use Hungana [hum]. Some also use Mbala [mdp]. Some also use Pelende [ppp]. Some also use Suku [sub]. Some also use Yaka [yaf].

name: Wè Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–40%. Radio. TV. NT: 1982–2020.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Daho-Doo [das], Nyabwa [nwb].

name: Arabic (standard)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], primary usage. Braille script [Brai].
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in many tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1645–2008.
Language Use: Not an L1. In most Arab countries only the well-educated have adequateproficiency in Modern Standard Arabic. Education, official purposes, written materials, andformal speeches. Classical Arabic, with archaic vocabulary, is used for religion and ceremonialpurposes.

name: Nuni, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5% in French [fra]. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 5. Literature. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Moore [mos].

name: Baure
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1960–1966.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Araki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–90%. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Elderly only, in 2 families. Negative attitudes. All shifted to Tangoa[tgp]. All also use Bislama [bis]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Nuer
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. The Ministry of Education, supported by donors, has started a pilot project to develop materials for teaching Nuer as a subject and as language of instruction up to grade 3 in some schools. Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 1999.
Language Use: Used in all churches. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Southeastern Dinka [dks].

name: Naga, Zeme
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 59% in Manipur (2001 census). Radio. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Used strongly for oral communication but not much in written form. Home, village, church. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Tigre
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Ethiopic script [Ethi], used since 1889, not written in Sudan.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Females: about 30%. Taught in primary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1988.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Somewhat positive attitudes. Formerly they favored Arabic [arb]. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Also use Tigrigna [tir]. Used as L2 by Bilen [byn], Nara [nrb], Saho [ssy], Tigrigna [tir].

name: Kusaal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Daba
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 1992–2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub] (Lienhard andGiger 2009). Many also use French [fra] (Lienhard and Giger 2009). Used as L2 by Gavar [gou],Gidar [gid], Mazagway-Hidi [dkx], Mina [hna].

name: Bantawa
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Kirat Rai script [Krai], used in Sikkim.
Language Development: Nepali literacy rapidly increasing. Taught in some primary schools.Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Some shift to Nepali [npi] evident, especially among northern dialectspeakers (2003 SIL). Home, religion; mixed use: Friends, work. Some of all ages. Positiveattitudes. Most also use Nepali [npi]. Also use Bahing [bhj]. Also use Hindi [hin], especiallyamong ex-soldiers. Used as L2 by Chhiling [cur], Chhintang [ctn], Dungmali [raa], Puma [pum].

name: Buhi'non Bikol
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Bhojpuri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature.Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1998–2006.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Bajjika [vjk], Maithili [mai].

name: Dai Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains (e.g., speakers use like-sounding Chinese characters to record folk-songs). Latin script [Latn], used between 1984–1990s, experimental use in education in Wenshan, Yunnan, China.
Language Development: No orthography for L1 by government. Speakers use like-sounding Chinese characters to record folk songs, linguists use International Phonetic Alphabet to record pronunciation, so literacy is not possible at present. Literature. Videos. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous in most areas except Wenshan Municipality. Home, village, religious and traditional ceremonies. Some young people, all adults. All ages in rural areas where L1 is dominant, but only the elders in other areas. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], with bilingualism, in the local southwestern dialect. Also use Nong Zhuang [zhn].

name: Kumauni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 72% for Uttarakhand (2001 census). Motivation forliteracy not high. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1825–2020.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Central dialect is mostaccepted. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially men, a few educated women,and school-aged children in towns and markets. Used as L2 by Byangsi [bee], Chaudangsi [cdn],Darmiya [drd], Gujari [gju], Rangkas [rgk], Rawat [jnl], Rongpo [rnp].

name: Nyore
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 20%. First Oluluyia community to have a Bible school. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Bible: 2001.
Language Use: Home, social gatherings, church, school. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Seen as prestigious. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Dilling
Language Development: Some literacy materials produced. Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Few domains. Older adults only. Shifted to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Koireng
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%–80%. Older adults read Meitei, the young read English. Literature. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Purest Koireng spoken in Satu and Utonglo (2000 T. Shiekshel). Used by all. Children mix Meitei [mni] in with L1. Some also use Kom [kmm]. Also use English [eng], especially young people. Also use Meitei [mni].

name: Manobo, Cotabato
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–10%. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1988–2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Hiligaynon [hil]. Second languages acquired in school and community and used in schools, trade with non-Manobos, and government. Used as L2 by Teduray [tiy].

name: Maiwa (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%–15% in English [eng]. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except church, where there is mixed use with English [eng] (2001 SIL). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng], especially young people. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults. A few also use Daga [dgz]. Used as L2 by Dima [jma], Mapena [mnm].

name: Tetum
Language Development: Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bunak [bfn], Tetun Dili [tdt], Welaun [wlh].

name: Me'en
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used until 2009. Latin script [Latn], used since 2009, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 4%. Literates increasing. Kindergarten and adult literacy programs using Me’en as medium of instruction are piloted (2021 SIL). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Bible portions: 2008–2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh], in education and for reading the Bible. Used as L2 by Kwegu [xwg].

name: Didinga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 33%. Taught as subject in some primary schools throughgrade 3. Literature. NT: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Lambadi
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], used in Maharashtra. Kannada script [Knda], used in Karnataka. Telugu script [Telu], used in Andhra Pradesh.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 43% for Banjara of Andhra Pradesh. Many sources cite a much lower literacy rate for Banjara, 10%–20% (2001 census). Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1999–2018.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also use Marathi [mar]. Also use Telugu [tel].

name: Dinka, South Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Taught as subject in some primary schools throughgrade 3. The Ministry of Education, supported by donors, has started a pilot project to developmaterials for teaching Dinka (all 4 varieties together) as a subject and as language ofinstruction up to grade 3 in some schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions:1866–2018.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Reel [atu].

name: Tocho
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Acheron [acz]. Also use Lumun [lmd]. Also use Talodi [tlo].

name: Jola-Fonyi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Experimental pilot classes since 2002. Bulufdialect seems to have many lexical items different from Fonyi, but Buluf speakers are willing tolearn to read Fonyi. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, oral and written use in administration, informal usein education. Oral use in commerce, traditional religion, some use in other religious services.Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use French [fra], as the language of education andgovernment (Diouf et al 2017). Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce andinterethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov]. Also useMandinka [mnk]. Used as L2 by Bandial [bqj], Bayot [bda], Gusilay [gsl], Karon [krx], Kuwaataay[cwt], Mankanya [knf], Mlomp [mlo], Pulaar [fuc].

name: Ngongo
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Kituba [ktu]. Many also use Lingala [lin], especially young people. Some also use French [fra], used only in school. Used as L2 by Pelende [ppp].

name: Sinhala; Sinhalese
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Sinhala script [Sinh], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1823–1982.

name: Saint Lucian Creole French
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 36%. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1999.
Language Use: In French-influenced islands nearly all speak Creole as L1, although also alocal variety of standard French [fra]. In English influence areas, Creole has less standing,and speakers have a low literacy rate. All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use French[fra].

name: Maring
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature. Bible portions: 1974–1979.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Maclean 1991).

name: Senoufo, Supyire
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Bambara [bam]. Literature. Radio. Videos. Grammar. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Bamanankan [bam]. Used as L2 by Jowulu [jow], Syenara Sénoufo [shz].

name: Teso
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some secondary schools. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1961.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Kenye [lke], Kumam [kdi].

name: Eskayan
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Second language only. All speak Cebuano [ceb] as their L1. Religion,political events. All shifted to Cebuano [ceb]. Many also use Tagalog [tgl]. Some also useEnglish [eng].

name: Yom
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 35%. Literacy rate in L2: 25% in French [fra]. Rate higher among youth and women. Newspapers. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, work, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baatonum [bba]. Also use Dendi [ddn]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Lukpa [dop]. Also use Yoruba [yor]. Used as L2 by Borgu Fulfulde [fue], Dendi [ddn], Ditammari [tbz], Lukpa [dop].

name: Fulfulde (Adamawa)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], called Ajami. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low compared with national average. Arabic scriptliteracy is 2–3 times greater than Roman script literacy and growing. Franco-Arabic andAnglo-Arabic schools are increasing rapidly. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature.Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1983–2017.
Language Use: Clans often only permit marriage within the same clan. Adult men will speakAdamawa Fulfulde, while women and children will speak their specific clan’s dialect. Home,neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A fewalso use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra]. A few also use Hausa [hau]. A few also useStandard Arabic [arb]. Used as L2 by Bana [bcw], Bata [bta], Buwal [bhs], Cuvok [cuv], Daba[dbq], Dama [dmm], Dii [dur], Doyayo [dow], Dugun [ndu], Dugwor [dme], Duli-Gey [duz], Duupa[dae], Gavar [gou], Gbaya-Mbodomo [gmm], Gidar [gid], Gimme [kmp], Gimnime [gmn], Giziga [giz],Gude [gde], Gvoko [ngs], Hdi [xed], Hya [hya], Jimjimen [jim], Karang [kzr], Kera [ker], Kolbila[klc], Koma [kmy], Kuo [xuo], Longto [wok], Mafa [maf], Mambai [mcs], Masana [mcn], Maslam[msv], Matal [mfh], Mazagway-Hidi [dkx], Mbudum [xmd], Mbuko [mqb], Mbum [mdd], Mefele [mfj],Merey [meq], Mina [hna], Mofu-Gudur [mif], Moloko [mlw], Mom Jango [ver], Mono [mru], Mundang[mua], Musey [mse], Musgu [mug], Muyang [muy], Ndai [gke], Ndoola [ndr], Ngambay [sba], Nizaa[sgi], North Fali [fll], North Giziga [gis], North Mofu [mfk], Northwest Gbaya [gya], Nzakambay[nzy], Nzanyi [nja], Oblo [obl], Pam [pmn], Pana [pnz], Parkwa [pbi], Pere [pfe], Pévé [lme],Pol [pmm], Psikye [kvj], Sharwa [swq], South Fali [fal], Tsuvan [tsh], Tupuri [tui], Vame [mlr],Vemgo-Mabas [vem], Wandala [mfi], Wawa [www], Wuzlam [udl], Yerwa Kanuri [knc], Zizilivakan[ziz], Zulgo-Gemzek [gnd].

name: Lopit
Language Development: Orthography developed. Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Tennet [tex].

name: Mandinka
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012).
