Some also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov]. Used as L2 by Badyara [pbp], Bainouk-Gunyaamolo [bcz], Balanta-Ganja [bjt], Gusilay [gsl], Jola-Fonyi [dyo], Karon [krx], Mlomp [mlo].

name: Vietnamese
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 94%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1916–2008.

name: Bisaya, Brunei
Language Development: Radio. Bible portions: 1938.
Language Use: Also use Brunei [kxd].

name: Kadazan, Labuk-Kinabatangan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 85% in Standard Malay [zsm]. Literacy is highlyvalued. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Children learn Sabah Malay [msi] first before learning Standard Malay[zsm]. Standard Malay used in church, school, and official settings. Mixed use: home, market,village. Adults only. Shifting to Sabah Malay [msi].

name: Quechua, Margos-Yarowilca-Lauricocha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 62%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Bajau, West Coast
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% Standard Malay [zsm].Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Persatuan Bahasa dan Budaya Bajau Sama Sabah (BSBB).
Language Use: All domains except Education. Some young people, all adults. Some youthdelay using the language until their early teens, when they are driven by social expectations ofadulthood if they stay in the village (2022 M. Miller). Positive attitudes. All also use SabahMalay [msi]. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Mapun [sjm]. Also use Tatana [txx]. Used asL2 by Brunei [kxd], Bugis [bug], Iranun [ilm], Kadazan Dusun [dtp], Lotud [dtr], Mapun [sjm],Papar [dpp], Southern Sama [ssb].

name: Icelandic
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible:1584–1981.

name: Pokomam, Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 75% in Spanish [spa]. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1966–1983. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa], with many youth shifting.

name: Nama (Namibia)
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1966.
Language Use: Can be studied up to doctoral level at University of Namibia, also used in administration. Used as L2 by Hai|ǁom [hgm], Xiri [xii].

name: Quechua, Puno
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 71% (official figure for rural areas). Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1947–1971.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Spanish [spa]. People in towns and cities mostly want their children to speak Spanish.

name: Ndebele, South
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary and secondary schools from grade 4. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Grammar. Bible: 2013.

name: Chamorro
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools for compulsory classes in Chamorro languageand culture, optional at the secondary level. Taught as subject in tertiary schools. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2007.

name: Thulung
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2017. Agencies: Thulung Language Development Center; Thulung Sama.
Language Use: Language retention high compared to other Rai languages (Winter and Hansson 1991). Home, friends, religion. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Bahing [bhj]. Also use Nepali [npi], especially men, who tend to speak it with greater proficiency than women. Used as L2 by Dumi [dus], Khaling [klr], Nepali [npi].

name: Binukid
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 63%. Literacy rate in L2: 63%. Literature. Dictionary.NT: 1986–2015.

name: Rutul
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Russia. Latin script [Latn], used in Azerbaijan.
Language Development: Not a literary language. Some schools teach as a subject. Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 2005.
Language Use: 99% as L1. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Russian [rus].

name: Sakizaya
Language Development: Radio. TV.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Tami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 10%. Literacy rate in L2: Less than 10%. Literature. Texts. Bible portions: 2000–2015.
Language Use: Some also use Yabem [jae], especially the older generation.

name: Toposa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Perhaps 2,000 can read. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. The Ministry of Education, supported by donors, has started a pilot project to develop materials for teaching Toposa as a subject and as language of instruction up to grade 3 in some schools. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2002–2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Tennet [tex].

name: Nobonob
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 16% functional literacy skills. Literacy rate in L2:25%–75%. Many read, but understanding may be limited. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1990.
Language Use: Moderately vigorous. Some older Wagi [fad] may also use Nobonob. Alldomains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bagupi [bpi]. Also use Gedaged [gdd]. Alsouse Rempi [rmp]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Bagupi [bpi], Samosa [swm], Wagi [fad].

name: Ngangam
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Somealso use Anufo [cko], especially in the market place (Reimer 2022). Also use French [fra]. Alsouse Gourmanchéma [gux]. Also use Hausa [hau], especially in the market place (Reimer 2022). Alsouse Moba [mfq].

name: Bosngun
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults.Mixed attitudes, from positive to neutral. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Paris 2015).

name: Kwangali
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1987.
Language Use: All domains, including education. Used by all. Used as L2 by Hai|ǁom [hgm].

name: Morokodo
Language Development: Developed orthography and literacy materials in use. Taught as subject in a few primary schools. Literature. Bible portions: 2012–2016.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Moru [mgd]. Also use Zande [zne].

name: Mesquakie
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1986–2021.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Chavacano
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Taught as subject inmany primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in secondary schools. Literature. Radio.TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Davaweño Zamboangueño dialect may have no remaining speakers. Ermiteño isextinct; Zamboangueño, Caviteño, and Cotabateño are still used. Most domains, but youthincreasingly using more dominant languages (Cebuano [ceb], Tagalog [tgl] and English [eng])among their peers (Melchor and Blázquez-Carretero 2022). Some of all ages, beginning to losespeakers in dialects outside of Zamboanga City (Melchor and Blázquez-Carretero 2022). Positiveattitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Tagalog [tgl]. Some also use Cebuano[ceb]. A few also use Tausug [tsg]. Used as L2 by Balangingih Sama [sse], Central Sama [sml],Tausug [tsg], Western Subanon [suc], Yakan [yka].

name: Shor
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], Altai missionaries developed first alphabet in1880s. Latin script [Latn], used between 1930–1938.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Russian [rus]. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible portions: 2004–2022.
Language Use: Few domains except perhaps family. Adults only, mostly middle-aged or older(Salminen 2007). Mixed attitudes, from neutral to strongly positive. Shifting to Russian [rus].

name: Oriya (individual language)
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 64% (2001 census). Literacy rate in L2: 64% (2001 census). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Odisha state. Fully developed. Bible: 1815–2004.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bhatri [bgw], Birhor [biy], Bodo Gadaba [gbj], Chhattisgarhi [hne], Duruwa [pci], Eastern Muria [emu], Gata’ [gaq], Ho [hoc], Juang [jun], Juray [juy], Kharia [khr], Kharia Thar [ksy], Kisan [xis], Konda-Dora [kfc], Kudmali [kyw], Lodhi [lbm], Mahali [mjx], Mirgan [zrg], Pengo [peg], Sadri [sck].

name: Guyanese Creole English
Language Development: Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: The first or second language of most, but it has no official status. Home.Neutral attitudes. Used as L2 by Arawak [arw], Sarnami Hindustani [hns], Urdu [urd], Waiwai[waw], Warao [wba].

name: Magar, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Akebu
Language Development: More primary and secondary schools now (2011); many children being educatedin French [fra]. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2010–2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except government, education and with outsiders. Usedby all. Positive attitudes. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Éwé used extensively in church and at themarket. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gen [gej]. Gen used extensively in church and at themarket.

name: Russian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1876–2011.

name: Standard Estonian
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools, in about 87% of the schools;Russian [rus] is the language of instruction in the other 13%. Fully developed. Bible:1739–1995.
Language Use: Most also use Russian [rus] (European Commission 2006). Many also useEnglish [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use Standard German [deu] (EuropeanCommission 2006). Also use Finnish [fin].

name: Hadiyya
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Church literature. Latin script [Latn],official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 34%. Taught in primary and secondary schools throughgrade 4 and as subject thereafter. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Mesmes [mys].

name: Iranun (Philippines)
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals.

name: Chinantec, Tepetotutla
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kosraean
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools through grade 3 in Kosrae state. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1928.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Finnish
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools where Finnish is the majoritylanguage; taught as subject in all schools elsewhere from grade 1 or 3. Taught in most tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1642–1991.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also useStandard German [deu] (European Commission 2006). Some also use Swedish [swe] (EuropeanCommission 2006).

name: Mnong, Central
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. NT: 2001–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Mogum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Texts.
Language Use: Chadian Arabic [shu] used in cross-linguistic situations. Home, between native speakers in the village. Positive attitudes. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Ormu
Language Development: Taught in a few primary schools.
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon); potentially endangered (Wurm 2000). Adults only. Most shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Shina, Kohistani
Writing: Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], in development.
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Bateri [btv], Chilisso [clh], Gowro [gwf].

name: Khmu
Writing: Duota script [Qaaf], used in a small collection of villages well away from the rest of the language group, also used in China. Lao script [Laoo]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1918–2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Many also use Lao [lao], especially under the age of 40. Used as L2 by Samtao [stu].

name: Bench
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used until 2008. Latin script [Latn], used since2008.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 12% in Amharic [amh]. Pilot education project begun in2008. Kindergarten and adult literacy programs using Bench as medium of instruction are piloted(2021 SIL). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter.Radio. Grammar. NT: 1990.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Sheko [she].

name: Izon
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1912.
Language Use: Adult education (Kolokuma dialect). Used as L2 by Biseni [ije], Epie [epi],Okodia [okd].

name: Begbere-Ejar
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Videos. Texts.
Language Use: Youth in market towns are beginning to shift to Hausa [hau]. Home, market.Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Ashe [ahs]. Used as L2 by Zhire [zhi].

name: Lepcha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 66% in Sikkim (2001 census). Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1989.
Language Use: In Sikkim, all ages. Language use not known in other regions. Many also use Nepali [npi]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Western Farsi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in Iran.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1845–1995.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Northern Luri [lrc]. Also use South Azerbaijani [azb]. Also use Southern Luri [luz].

name: Kom (India)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 64% (2001 census). Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1996.
Language Use: Aimol [aim], Koireng [nkd], and Chiru [cdf] speakers also understand Kom. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni]. Used as L2 by Koireng [nkd].

name: Central Bontok
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 35%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Also use English [eng], bilingually by the majority of older people. Also use Ilocano [ilo], especially in high school and college contexts among youth. The great majority of older people are also bilingual in it. Also use Tagalog [tgl], especially in high school and college when youth speak among themselves; fewer older people speak it. Used as L2 by Northern Bontok [rbk], Southwestern Bontok [vbk].

name: Sabaot
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Over 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Elaborate mother-tongue education program. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, social gatherings, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bukusu [bxk]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Zabana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature could also be used for Kokota [kkk] and Zazao [jaj]. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Cheke Holo [mrn]. Used as L2 by Kokota [kkk], Laghu [lgb], Zazao [jaj].

name: Ede Idaca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Literacy program coversentire language area due to high motivation. Radio.
Language Use: Vigorous: determined to keep their language from influences from outsiders.All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Fon [fon]. Many also use French[fra] (Roberts and Walter 2021). Many also use Yoruba [yor] (Roberts and Walter 2021). Some alsouse Ifè [ife] (Roberts and Walter 2021).

name: Kekchí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 22%. Literature. Radio.TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1988–2019. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa]. Usedas L2 by K’iche’ [quc], Poqomchi’ [poh].

name: Tinani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Radio. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, village, infrequently in religion. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Pattani [lae]. Used as L2 by Kullu Pahari [kfx].

name: Itneg, Masadiit
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Nyaneka
Language Development: TV. Texts. NT: 2005–2023.
Language Use: High vitality across the whole language area (2013 SIL). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Kung-Ekoka [knw], Kwandu [xdo].

name: Tuki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 35%. Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Most also use French [fra]. Used as L2by Bafia [ksf], Leti [leo].

name: Tigrinya
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used since 13th or 14th century.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–25%. Female: above 65%. Taught in primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1956.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tigré [tig]. Used as L2 by Bilen [byn], Italian [ita], Saho [ssy], Tigré [tig].

name: Sedang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Tutchone, Southern
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Literacy workshops since 1984. Taught in schools at Kluane Lake and Haines Junction, and 3 elementary schools in Whitehorse have native language programs that include Southern Tutchone (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Namia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 1996–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, prep schools. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people. Also use English [eng].

name: Paasaal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–2%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. About 50% of children begin school; 10%–20% complete junior secondary school. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Tumulung Sisaala [sil]. Also use Wali [wlx].

name: Daga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%–60%. Literature.Grammar. NT: 1974–2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Dima[jma], Maiwa [mti], Mapena [mnm], Turaka [trh].

name: Waama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–10%. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Vigorous. Market, religion, preschools, home, neighborhood. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baatonum [bba]. Also use Ditammari [tbz]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Nateni [ntm]. Used as L2 by Notre [bly].

name: Kirya-Konzəl
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Home, friends, religious ceremonies, local market.

name: Guaraní, Paraguayan
Language Development: Used extensively in bilingual education. Taught in primary schools in earlygrades only. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1997.
Language Use: 52% of rural Paraguayans bilingual in Guaraní. Home, friends, religion;mixed use: Work, education. Used by all. Many also use Spanish [spa]. Most in urban areas arebilingual in Spanish.

name: Luvale
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1955–1970.
Language Use: Recognized for educational and administrative purposes. A dominant regional language. Home, community, traditional ceremonies. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Sora
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya]. Sora Sompeng script [Sora]. Telugu script [Telu].
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1992–2004.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck]. Used as L2 by Juray [juy].

name: Ramopa
Language Development: Literature. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Boloki
Language Development: Literature. Bible portions: 1895–1904.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lingala [lin], with many youth shifting.

name: Kumyk
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used until 1928. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used since 1937, primary usage. Latin script [Latn], used between 1927–1937 with a resurgence of use in 2015.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Higher where majority speak Kumyk. Literacy rate in L2: High in Russian [rus]. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Avar [ava], Chechen [che], Dargwa [dar], Lak [lbe], Nogai [nog].

name: Lele (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 1956.
Language Use: Mixed use: home, community. Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Boettger 2015). Some also use Nali [nss]. Also use English [eng] (Boettger 2015). Also use Ere [twp] (Boettger 2015). Also use Kele [sbc] (Boettger 2015). Used as L2 by Leipon [lek], Loniu [los], Nali [nss].

name: Minderico
Language Development: Newspapers. TV. Dictionary.
Language Use: Home, friends. Older adults only. Shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Nicobarese, Car
LITERACY_L2: 46% for Scheduled Tribes in Nicobar District.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 46% for Scheduled Tribes in Nicobar District. 72% forNicobar (2001 census). Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1969.

name: Santali
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Devanagari script [Deva], used in Nepal. Latin script [Latn], used in Bangladesh. Ol Chiki (Ol Cemet’, Ol, Santali) script [Olck]. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Jharkhand state. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1914–2005.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck]. Used as L2 by Birhor [biy], Ho [hoc], Kharia [khr], Kharia Thar [ksy], Mahali [mjx].

name: Lithuanian
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Latin script, Fraktur variant [Latf], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 99%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1735–1998.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use Russian [rus] (European Commission 2006). Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use Polish [pol] (European Commission 2006).

name: Mbukushu
LITERACY_L2: 15–29 years: 90% in Setswana [tsn], 50% in English [eng]; 30–54 years: 3% in Setswana, 10% English; 55 and older: 0%.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15–29 years: 90% in Setswana [tsn], 50% in English [eng]; 30–54 years: 3% in Setswana, 10% English; 55 and older: 0%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Gwich´in
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature.Dictionary. Bible: 1898.
Language Use: Still vigorous in a few communities. Taught in school at Old Crow since1970s (Golla 2007). Adults only. All shifting to English [eng].

name: Bukusu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30% (2007 BTL). Literacy rate in L2: 65% in English[eng] (2007 BTL). Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary.Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Growing. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also useEnglish [eng], especially children in school. Some also use Swahili [swh], especially childrenin school. Most adults also use neighboring languages. Used as L2 by Sabaot [spy].

name: Luri, Northern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Persian [pes]. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, commerce. Used by all. Also use Iranian Persian [pes]. Also use Laki [lki]. Used as L2 by Iranian Persian [pes], Laki [lki], Southern Kurdish [sdh].

name: Kanuri, Central
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn], used since 1949.
Language Development: Taught in a few primary schools in grades 1–3; taught as subject in some schools. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kibaku [ckl], Putai [mfl].

name: Kongo, San Salvador
Language Development: Taught at the teacher training college in Luanda. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1916–1926.

name: Waray (Philippines)
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1937–1984.

name: Melpa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1965–2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng], especially young people. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people. Used as L2 by Bo-Ung [mux], Kyaka [kyc], Umbu-Ungu [ubu].

name: Dagbani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Taught in primary andsecondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Dongxiang
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], informal usage. Latin script [Latn], experimental usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 12%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, religion, local commerce, oral tradition. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Written Chinese in common use.

name: Gbaya (Sudan)
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Gula [kcm], Yulu [yul].

name: Cia-Cia
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Hangul script[Hang], developed in 2009 (Cho 2012), limited usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Videos.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All alsouse Indonesian [ind]. Some also use Wolio [wlo]. Used as L2 by Busoa [bup], Kumbewaha [xks],Tukang Besi North [khc], Tukang Besi South [bhq].

name: Hmar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90%. Taught in primary schools in Assam, Manipur andMizoram states. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1968–2004.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni].Also use Mizo [lus]. Used as L2 by Sakachep [sch].

name: Lahu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 63%. Literacy rate in L2: Low in Chinese. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1989.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Blang [blr]. Also use Hani [hni]. Also use Lü [khb]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Vo Wa [wbm]. Used as L2 by Lahu Shi [lhi], Laomian [lwm], Sangkong [sgk], Shuhi [sxg], Vo Wa [wbm].

name: Jamaican Creole English
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in English. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. Dominant language and gaining in prestige. Post-Creole continuumfrom distinct Creole to provincial English of town dwellers. Not widely accepted as a literarylanguage. Positive attitudes. Most consider that they speak standard English [eng]. Also useEnglish [eng]. Used as L2 by Konchri Sain [jcs].

name: Malvi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 58% for rural Madhya Pradesh (2001 census). Government project discontinued due to low response. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1826.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hindi [hin]. Also use English [eng].

name: Majhi
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2019.
Language Use: Being replaced by Nepali [npi] (UNESCO). Religion. All also use Nepali [npi].

name: Tampulma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2000–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Ndebele, North
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 55%. Taught in some primary schools in grades 1–3 in areas where Ndebele is spoken. Dictionary. Bible: 1978.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Birwa [brl], Chichewa [nya], Kalanga [kck], Lozi [loz], Nambya [nmq], Setswana [tsn], Tsoa [hio], Venda [ven].

name: Dhanwar (Nepal)
Language Development: Although some people are writing in Danuwari, no data is available on L1literacy. Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Rapidly assimilating to Nepali [npi] (Van Driem 2007). Home, religion;mixed use: Friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use EasternTamang [taj], especially at work and with friends in Kabhre district. Also use Nepali [npi],especially at work and with friends in Kabhre district.

name: Guibian Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Development: Literature. TV. Videos.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Nong Zhuang [zhn], in northern Guangnan County (Yunnan) due to intensive contact. Used as L2 by Baha Buyang [yha], E’ma Buyang [yzg], Langnian Buyang [yln], Minz Zhuang [zgm], Yerong [yrn].

name: Falam Chin
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], used in India. Latin script [Latn], primaryusage.
Language Development: Most youth and some older people, if educated, can read Falam. Radio.Dictionary. Bible: 1991–2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Subanun, Lapuyan
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in grades 1–3. NT: 1982. Agency: Lapuyan Local Government Unit (LGU).
Language Use: Mixed: Home, Community, Work, Religion, Education. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cebuano [ceb]. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Tagalog [tgl]. A few also use Maranao [mrw]. Used as L2 by Central Subanen [syb].

name: Haitian; Haitian Creole
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools, mostly in rural areas instead ofFrench [fra]. 80% of the primary and 90% of the secondary education takes place in privateschools. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1985.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use French [fra].

name: Deori
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 71%. Literature. Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous among the Dibongya, the only subgroup that has retained thelanguage. Home, village, religion, work. Positive attitudes. Many also use Assamese [asm], butwomen, older adults and uneducated have less proficiency. Also use English [eng].

name: Dagara, Northern
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 5. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Phuie [pug], Turka [tuz].

name: Adyghe; Adygei
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Cyrillic script[Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used in Turkey.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 99% (Ministry of Education, Adygea Republic). Literacyrate in L2: 100% (Ministry of Education, Adygea Republic). Taught as subject in a few primaryand secondary schools in Adyghea Republic only. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 1991–2014.
Language Use: Adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Russian [rus].

name: Sartang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Hindi [hin]. Literature committee formed mid 2003.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Soninke
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. At Bamako university, there are now many more Soninke students who choose this language than before, and numbers are rising. The language is also used in adult education in the Soninke region, especially around Yelimané (2013 SIL). Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2001–2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bamanankan [bam]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Hassaniyya [mey]. Also use Pulaar [fuc]. Used as L2 by Kagoro [xkg].

name: Ayiwo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Orthography not standardized so few readers. Literature. Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Religious services, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Good speakers respected, Pijin borrowings disliked. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Pijin [pis]. Also use Vaeakau-Taumako [piv]. Used as L2 by Engdewu [ngr], Vaeakau-Taumako [piv].

name: Romagnol
Language Development: Literature. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1865–2005.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Italian [ita].

name: Bambalang
Language Development: Basic literacy materials, multilingual education program. Radio.Dictionary. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English[eng].

name: Wotu
Writing: Buginese script [Bugi], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. Positive attitudes. Most shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifting to Makassar Indonesian [mfp]. Most also use Bugis [bug], particularly the Luwu dialect.

name: Gulay
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Also use Sar [mwm].

name: Minokok
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Used as L2 by Lanas Lobu [ruu].

name: Udi
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1902–2018.
Language Use: Young people use a strongly Azeri-influenced variety of Udi, which could be described as‘Young People’s Udi’ (2018 DOBES). Home, community. Some young people, all adults. Used by 30%–50% of children. Neutral attitudes. Udi not seen as prestigious as Russian [rus]. Most also use North Azerbaijani [azj]. Some also use Judeo-Tat [jdt]. Also use Armenian [hye]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Valpei
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%–70% in Bislama [bis]. Literature.
Language Use: Community; Mixed: Home, Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Tanokuku [nkk]. A few also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Tapesena [vnp].

name: Burun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Orthography and literacy materials in use.Literature. Radio. Bible portions: 2006–2011.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Uduk [udu].

name: Rumu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1965–1993.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Gaam
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Maninkakan, Western
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 1997–2003.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Many also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Some also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017).

name: Komo (Sudan)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], plans for future development in Ethiopia.
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1960–1963.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Ganza [gza], Uduk [udu].

name: Tupuri
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use French [fra]. Some also use Masana [mcn]. Some also use Mundang [mua]. Some also use Musgu [mug]. A few also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Used as L2 by Masana [mcn], Mundang [mua], Musgu [mug].

name: Kadara
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Half those aged 17–50 read Hausa [hau]. More youththan middle-aged are literate. Radio.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau].Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Ejuele [dbi], Rjili [uji].

name: Tabassaran
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2010.

name: Molima
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Adults 30%; children 7–12 yrs. 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Literature. NT: 2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Dobu [dob], especially men, church and community leaders, traders, and travelers. Used as L2 by Boselewa [bwf], Minaveha [mvn].

name: Mansoanka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 48%. Radio. Videos. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion, work. Some of all ages. Growing shift towards Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], particularly among children of mixed marriages, and those from families who moved to the capital of Bissau for education and economic opportunity (2022 A. Yndibe). Positive attitudes. Most also use Balanta [ble]. Most also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language of interethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Many also use Mandinka [mnk]. A few also use Portuguese [por], as the language of education and communication with foreigners.

name: Munji
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], in development. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Speakers view it as their secret language, and they perceive it as an advantage to have a language that is not commonly understood by outsiders. Home, community, at school. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Dari [prs], especially adults (nearly all).

name: Kudmali
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], used in West Bengal. Chisoi script [Chis], used in West Bengal, Odisha, and Jharkhand. Devanagari script [Deva], used in Jharkhand. Oriya (Odia) script [Orya], used in Odisha.
Language Development: There are Pre-degree, Degree, and Masters level programs in Kudmali. Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous, but most young people in Odisha speak Odia [ory] among themselves rather than Kudmali. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Odia [ory].

name: Javanese, Caribbean
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary.Texts. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: All domains, except education. Used by all. Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Irigwe
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use English [eng]. All also useHausa [hau], especially in urban areas; Irigwe is more active in the village.

name: Sakechep
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Radio. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use Biate [biu]. Also use Dimasa [dis]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Hmar [hmr]. Also use Hrangkhol [hra]. Also use Karbi [mjw]. Also use Khasi [kha]. Also use Nagamese [nag]. Also use Thado Chin [tcz].

name: Iu Mien
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from before Yuan dynasty,used in folk domains and text messaging. Lao script [Laoo], used in Laos. Latin script [Latn],used at least since 1930s, used in China, Thailand, United States, France, Canada. Thai script[Thai], used in Thailand.
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use YueChinese [yue], especially adults. Used as L2 by Chadong [cdy], Hlai [lic], Jiongnai Bunu [pnu],Lakkia [lbc].

name: Shilluk
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2012.
Language Use: Taught in churches. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Logooli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Bible: 1951.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Kachchi
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Most also use Gujarati [guj]. Also use English [eng].

name: Temi
Language Development: Prevalence of Swahili literacy leads to low interest in L1 literacy. Literature. Bible portions: 2007–2012.
Language Use: Home, market, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Swahili [swh]. Swahili used in education.

name: Yongbei Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity. Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, used since 1982, official, mainly used in official domains.
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Ifugao, Tuwali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25,000 can read and write. Literacy rate in L2: 60%.Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by other language speakers in trading and in exogamousmarriages. High bilingualism; all are bilingual by the time they are in elementary school. Alldomains. Court, religion, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Amganad Ifugao[ifa]. All also use English [eng], especially those over 40. All also use Filipino [fil]. Allalso use Ilocano [ilo]. Used as L2 by Keley-i Kallahan [ify].

name: Yaka (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Kituba [ktu]. Some also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 by Lonzo [lnz], Suku [sub].

name: Tamang, Eastern
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Tibetan script [Tibt], Tamhig style.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–75%. Some non-formal and formal literacy materials, textbooks and classes. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011. Agencies: Tamang Language and Literature Council; Nepal Tamung Association; Tamang Dajang.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bhojpuri [bho]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], in religious contexts. Also use Lhomi [lhm]. Also use Maithili [mai]. Also use Nepali [npi], especially those who have been to school or traveled and in official contexts. Women, older adults, and children have limited proficiency. Used as L2 by Danuwar [dhw], Jirel [jul], Sunwar [suz].

name: Torwali
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: A bilingual literacy program in Torwali and Urdu [urd] for 2,000 adult women in the community was begun in 2013 with the support of USAID (Torwali 2018). Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2, as a 2-year multilingual education program that bridges children from Torwali to Urdu [urd] and also to English [eng] in 3 different locations. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Idara Baraye Taleem-o-Taraqi (Institute for Education and Development) (IBT).
Language Use: Nearly half the speakers have migrated to the largest urban areas of Pakistan, where their language is being replaced by Urdu [urd] or Pashto [pbu] (2020 Z. Torwali). Home, community. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Northern Pashto [pbu]. Most also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Badeshi [bdz], Ushojo [ush].

name: Motlav
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2005–2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Lemerig [lrz].

name: Lewo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2016–2019.
Language Use: Some use in religious domain. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. Many also use Lamenu [lmu], especially adults (Early 2002). Used as L2 by Lamenu [lmu].

name: Safwa
Language Development: SIL has transition literacy work (Swahili to Safwa). Literature. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Chin, Thado
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 57% in Manipur (2001 census). Literacy lower among older people and in villages. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1971–1994.
Language Use: Also use Meitei [mni]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Sakachep [sch].

name: Mixtec, Amoltepec
Language Development: Schools through 6th grade. Secundaria and Colegio de Bachilleres del Estado de Oaxaca in Amoltepec City. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2007–2023.
Language Use: Functionally monolingual parents pass Mixtec on to children. There are 2 or 3 villages, apparently founded by outsiders, with no Mixtec speakers. In all other villages, there are Mixtec speakers, but in some, very few children learn it; in others, most of them learn it (2011). Home, friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. Older adults want to preserve the language. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Spanish [spa], with basic proficiency in Amoltepec center. Those in outlying rancherías are quite monolingual. Communication often carried on in 2 languages; one speaking Mixtec and the other Spanish. Many children speak Spanish more than Mixtec, though they may know Mixtec. In some communities, children no longer learn to speak Mixtec. Used as L2 by Ixtayutla Mixtec [vmj].

name: Gumuz
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], used since2007, official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 6%. Mother Tongue Education and literacy has beenbased on geographical varieties (south and north); efforts are being made toward thestandardization of formal rules that can be applied across the language area (2020 K. Küspert).Functional women’s literacy program started in Gumuz in 2020 and is now being gradually expandedthroughout the language community (2021 SIL). Taught in many primary and secondary schools ingrades 1–4 and as subject thereafter. Work is ongoing to extend use as language of instructionto grade 6 (2021). Taught as a major at the Gilgel Beles Teacher Training College and AssosaUniversity. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh], with use and comprehension frequent inthe North, limited in the South. Also use Eastern Oromo [hae], with limited comprehension. Alsouse Sudanese Arabic [apd], especially Muslims near the border of Sudan. Also use West CentralOromo [gaz], which has wide use as lingua franca in Kamashi zone. Used as L2 by Daatsʼíin[dtn].

name: Guernésiais, Jèrriais
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. Bible portions: 1863. Agency: Guernsey Language Commission.
Language Use: Limited revitalization efforts. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Crioulo, Upper Guinea
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 48% in Portuguese [por]. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1999.
Language Use: Growing as an L1 in the capital city of Bissau. Home, friends, work, commerce, entertainment. Has even taken over previous domains of Portuguese [por] such as use in most churches and many functions of government. Positive attitudes. Many also use Portuguese [por], the language of education, governmental operations, industry, and business with international relations. Used as L2 by Bainouk-Gunyuño [bab], Balanta [ble], Biafada [bif], Bijagó [bjg], Fula [fuc], Futa Fula [fuf], Jola Bayote [bda], Jola-Felupe [eja], Kabuverdianu [kea], Kanjad [pbp], Kasanga [ccj], Kobiana [kcj], Mandinka [mnk], Mandjak [mfv], Mankanya [knf], Mansoanka [msw], Nalu [naj], Papel [pbo], Soninke [snk], Susu [sus].

name: Mangareva
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1908.
Language Use: Shifting to French [fra]. Some also use Tahitian [tah].

name: Garo
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Braille script [Brai], used since 1998.Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 55% for Meghalaya (2001 census). General level ofeducation is low compared to Khasi [kha]. Taught in primary and secondary schools in Meghalayastate. Taught as subject at North-Eastern Hill University. Literature. Radio. Videos.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1924–1994.
Language Use: Awe dialect, spoken in Assam, has few remaining speakers. Most use standardGaro. Used as L2 by Atong [aot], Hajong [haj], Koch [kdq], Lyngngam [lyg], Rabha [rah], Ruga[ruh].

name: Amri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%—60%. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Grammar. NT:2010.
Language Use: Many ethnic group members no longer use Amri Karbi. Much borrowing fromAssamese [asm] (in Assam) and Khasi [kha] (in Meghalaya). Some Amri Karbi villages shiftedcompletely to Assamese due to intermarriage and the perception that Assamese is preferred forchildren to do well in school. In the remote and isolated border area, the language is stillstrong. Home, village, religion. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Strong feelings ofseparateness from the dominant Karbi group in Karbi, Anglong District. Most also use Assamese[asm]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Mada (Cameroon)
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1989.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Many also use Zulgo-Gemzek [gnd]. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Some also use Matal [mfh]. Also use Wuzlam [udl]. Used as L2 by Matal [mfh], Wuzlam [udl].

name: Palauan
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools in early grades only. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1964.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Portuguese
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 83%–84%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1751–2017.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use French [fra] (European Commission 2006). A few also use Kabuverdianu [kea], with some Portuguese children learning Kabuverdianu in the schools with predominant Cape Verdean populations. A few also use Spanish [spa] (European Commission 2006).

name: Dawro
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Church literature. Latin script [Latn],official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 24%. Church-based literacy program started 2007.Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Neutral attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Tsaara [cra].

name: Afar
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Ethiopia. Latin script [Latn], used since1840, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%. Taught in primary schools. Literature. Radio.Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Also use Ta’izzi-Adeni Arabic [acq] (Bender 1971). Used as L2 by Argobba[agj].

name: Thur
Language Development: Radio. Bible portions: 2014–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Acholi [ach]. Many also use Lango [laj].

name: Baba
Language Development: Basic literacy materials. Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English[eng].

name: Nawuri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Yansi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 60%. Literacy rate in L2: About 80%. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home; Community; Mixed: Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Most also use Kituba [ktu]. A few also use Lingala [lin].

name: Bicolano, Iriga
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–3. Literature. Newspapers.Radio. Texts. NT: 2016.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Bikol [bcl].Also use English [eng]. Also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Fulfulde (Nigerian)
LITERACY_L1: Below 1% in Roman script; below 20% in Arabic script.
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used since 2011. Latin script [Latn],used since 2003.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 1% in Roman script; below 20% in Arabic script.Keen interest in younger generation learning to read and write. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 2007–2010.
Language Use: Home, some use in market. Used by all, but youth increasingly want to learnEnglish [eng]. Mixed attitudes. Though proud of their oral and written language, they now viewspeaking and writing English [eng] as more prestigious. Used as L2 by Bali [bcn], Bena [yun],Bille [bil], Bokobaru [bus], Bure [bvh], Burku [bbt], Choogen [tgd], Deno [dbb], Dera [kna],Duguri [dbm], Dyarim [dyr], Fali Muchella [fli], Ga’anda [gqa], Galambi [glo], Giiwo [kks], Gude[gde], Holma [hod], Hõne [juh], Hwana [hwo], Jara [jaf], Jibu [jib], Juu [juu], Kaan [ldl], Kam[kdx], Kariya [kil], Kibaku [ckl], Kpasham [pbn], Kugama [kow], Kumba [ksm], Laka [ksp],Lala-Roba [lla], Lamang [hia], Longuda [lnu], Mada [mda], Mboi [moi], Mbula-Bwazza [mbu], Ndoola[ndr], Ngwaba [ngw], Nigeria Mambila [mzk], Nya Huba [hbb], Nyong [muo], Pa’anci [pqa], Pere[pfe], Ron [cla], Samba Daka [ccg], Shall-Zwall [sha], Shoo-Minda-Nye [bcv], Siri [sir], Sukur[syk], Teme [tdo], Tsuvadi [tvd], Vemgo-Mabas [vem], Verre [ver], Voro [vor], Waja [wja],Yendang [ynq], Zibinju [jmb].

name: Agutaynen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Filipino [fil] orEnglish [eng]. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2004–2020.
Language Use: Mostly spoken in group. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Cuyonon[cyo]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil].

name: Saurashtra
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Saurashtra script [Saur], a modern version developed in the late 1800s, used for centuries. Tamil script [Taml], primary usage. Telugu script [Telu].
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 2023. Agency: Sourashtra Vidya Peetam.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, prayer. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Mixtec, Chayuco
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1979.

name: Guahibo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 45%. Literacy rate in L2: 45%. Taught as subject inmost primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1982–2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Maori
Language Development: Taught in some primary and secondary schools, 322 government-funded Maori language schools, including preschool. Grammar. Bible: 1858–1952.
Language Use: Until 20th century, Maori was spoken throughout New Zealand. There is a recent reluctance of the young generation to use Maori (Wurm 2007). Some of all ages. All also use English [eng] (Wurm 2007).

name: Lamnso'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in most primary and secondary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Oku [oku]. A few also use Limbum [lmp]. Used as L2 by Kemedzung [dmo], Kom [bkm], Limbum [lmp], Noone [nhu], Oku [oku], Wushi [bse].

name: Manobo, Matigsalug
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Home, neighborhood, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb].

name: Marathi
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Modi script [Modi].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 77% (2001 census). Literacy rate in L2: 77% (2001 census). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Maharashtra state. Fully developed. Bible: 1821–2002.
Language Use: The Bene Israel are a Marathi-speaking Jewish group in Mumbai. Used as L2 by Ahirani [ahr], Andh [anr], Bhalay [bhx], Far Western Muria [fmu], Gowli [gok], Indo-Portuguese [idb], Katkari [kfu], Khandesi [khn], Korku [kfq], Korlai Portuguese Creole [vkp], Lambadi [lmn], Mawchi [mke], Nihali [nll], Noiri [noi], Northern Gondi [gno], Northwestern Kolami [kfb], Palya Bareli [bpx], Pardhan [pch], Pauri Bareli [bfb], Powari [pwr], Rathwi Bareli [bgd], Saraiki [skr], Tulu [tcy], Vaagri Booli [vaa], Varli [vav], Vasavi [vas], Waddar [wbq].

name: Anaang
Language Development: Literature. TV.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Efik [efi].

name: Abaza
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used in Turkey.
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2019–2021.
Language Use: More vigorous in the Russian Federation than Turkey. L1 for about 95%. Mostalso use Russian [rus].

name: Tzutujil, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. 25% read, 5% write. Radio. Grammar. NT: 1981–2010. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by K’iche’ [quc].

name: Talinga-Bwisi
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2015–2017.
Language Use: Home, some churches, market, if both are Babwisi. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tooro [ttj]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Amba [rwm], Mvuba [mxh].

name: Mende (Sierra Leone)
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Mende Kikakui script [Mend], limited usage except for correspondence and record keeping, especially accounting.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in secondary schools in grades 7–9. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1959.
Language Use: Also use Krio [kri]. Used as L2 by Bom-Kim [bmf], Gola [gol], Northern Kissi [kqs], Vai [vai].

name: Yi, Sani
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Sama, Southern
LITERACY_L2: 40% in Tausug [tsg], 40% in Filipino [fil], 30% in Malay [zlm], 10% in English [eng].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%–70%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Tausug [tsg], 40% in Filipino [fil], 30% in Malay [zlm], 10% in English [eng]. 130,000 can read, 100,000 can write. Literature may not be acceptable to other dialect speakers due to marginal intelligibility and strong regional loyalties. Taught in primary schools in grades 1–3. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1979–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, local level official functions, religious services, commerce, and labor relations. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Sama [sml]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Malay [zlm]. Also use Mapun [sjm]. Also use Molbog [pwm]. Also use Pangutaran Sama [slm]. Also use Tausug [tsg].

name: Otomi, Eastern Highland
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1974–2009.
Language Use: Indigenous teachers teach L1 literacy. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sharanahua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–10%. Bilingual education program (Crevels 2007). Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1996–2008.
Language Use: Home on Purus River. Used by all. Some also use Spanish [spa], especially at home by those who intermarry and those with schooling. Used as L2 by Amahuaca [amc].

name: Tibetan
Writing: Marchen script [Marc]. Phags-pa script [Phag]. Tibetan script [Tibt], Uchenand Umed styles.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Motivation for literacy is high. Modern LiteraryTibetan [bod] is the language of literature for other Tibetan varieties, including Khams Tibetan[khg] and Amdo Tibetan [adx]. Taught in a few primary and secondary schools; taught as subjectin many schools. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1948.
Language Use: Vigorous. Speakers of other languages in the area can also speak Tibetan.All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Narua[nru]. Also use Naxi [nxq]. Used as L2 by Boga’er Luoba [adi], Cuona Monba [twm], Darang Deng[mhu], Geman Deng [mxj], Horpa [ero], Jiarong [jya], Kangjia [kxs], Lisu [lis], Namuyi [nmy],Naxi [nxq], Northern Pumi [pmi], Salar [slr], Shuhi [sxg], Southern Pumi [pmj], Tshangla [tsj],Tu [mjg], Yidu Luoba [clk].

name: Tarangan, West
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–70%. Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Indonesian [ind]. Literature. Bible portions: 1997–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Ambonese Malay [abs], and the Dobo Malay dialect in particular. Most also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Fordata
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 2,500 read;1,500 can write. Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Dictionary. NT:2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some villages have few young people being spoken to in Fordata.All domains, though church context limited. Positive attitudes. All also use Ambonese Malay[abs]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Bugis [bug], Geser-Gorom [ges].

name: Naga, Rongmei
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: High. Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Periodicals. Radio. Bible: 1989.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Inpui Naga [nkf].

name: Ibaloi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1978.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Karao [kyj].

name: Bajjika
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Kaithi script [Kthi], used until the turn of the 20th century.
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Many also use Hindi [hin] (Kashyap 2014). Also use Bhojpuri [bho]. Also use Maithili [mai].

name: Keiga
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials produced. Literature.
Language Use: Most domains. Some young people, all adults. About half the children speakthe language. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Yang Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], particularly the southwestern dialect. Also use Yue Chinese [yue], particularly Ping dialect. Used as L2 by Minz Zhuang [zgm], Yerong [yrn].

name: Esimbi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Literature. Radio. Bible portions: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous, but children growing up in English- or French-speaking areas donot learn L1 well. Home, neighborhood, market, work, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use Aghem [agq]. A few also use English [eng].Used as L2 by Mesaka [iyo].

name: Georgian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Georgian (Mkhedruli and Mtavruli) script [Geor],primary usage. Khutsuri (Asomtavruli and Nuskhuri) script [Geok], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible:1743–2021.
Language Use: Meskhi are ethnically Georgian, speak Georgian, are Eastern Orthodox, andlive in southwest Georgia.

name: Nahuatl, Western Huasteca
Language Development: Radio. Bible: 2005.

name: Coeur d'Alene
Language Development: Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Taught in the high school. The tribe hasofficial language program (Golla 2007).
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Fuyug
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Literature. Newspapers.Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1973–1994.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except in interactions with outsiders; Mixed use withTok Pisin [tpi], Hiri Motu [hmo], and English [eng] in one church. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. A few also use Tauade [ttd], especially elderly (Bradshaw 2007). Also use English[eng] (Bradshaw 2007). Also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Bradshaw 2007). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi](Bradshaw 2007).

name: Darai
Language Development: Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bibleportions: 2018–2023.
Language Use: Rapidly assimilating to Nepali [npi] (Van Driem 2007). Home; mixed use:Friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Nepali[npi].

name: Finnish (Kven)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Over 90% in Finnish [fin]. Taught in schools 3 hours aweek. Newspapers.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Norwegian [nor]. Also use Finnish [fin].

name: Urdu
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage. Braille script [Brai]. Devanagari script [Deva], used in India (Ahmad 2011).
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in some tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1843–1998.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Saamia
Language Development: Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, religion, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Swahili [swh]. Many also use Ganda [lug]. Some also use Soga [xog]. Used as L2 by Kenye [lke].

name: Iban
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in Sarawak only. Taught at theInstitute of Teacher Education Malaysia (for Bachelor of Teaching Primary School Iban Language)since 2014. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1988–2011.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Bukitan [bkn], Daro-Matu Melanau [dro],Kajaman [kag], Kiput [kyi], Narom [nrm], Remun [lkj], Sekapan [skp], Ukit [umi], Vaie [bny].

name: Jejueo
Language Development: Jejueo is being taught as an extra-curricular activity, although the schoolplans eventually to incorporate it into the regular curriculum. Literature. Newspapers.Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Home. Older adults only. Shifted to Korean [kor].

name: Nung (Viet Nam)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Ethnic group members preserved the language and culture more than the Tày [tyz]. Also use Vietnamese [vie]. Used as L2 by Qabiao [laq].

name: Binji
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Radio. NT: 1962.
Language Use: Community; Mixed: Home, Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. All alsouse Lingala [lin]. All also use Luba-Kasai [lua]. Many also use French [fra].

name: Pangwali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 9% men, 1% women. In 1981, 9% of the men had a 5th grade education, 1% of the women; 3% of the men had an 8th grade education, fewer than 1% of the women. Literature. Radio. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Nahuatl, Eastern Huasteca
Language Development: Taught in many primary and secondary schools, for basic courses, including mathematics and history, particularly in regions where the language continues to be dominant. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Huastec [hus].

name: Gizrra
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% (including semiliterates). Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in 3 schools. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Igbo
Language Development: Taught as subject in most primary and secondary schools in grades 1–9.Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1906–2009.
Language Use: Used for government notices. Used as L2 by Ikhin-Aokho [ikh], Ikwere [ikw],Legbo [agb], Lenyima [ldg], Obolo [ann], Ogbah [ogc], Umon [umm].

name: Huave, San Mateo Del Mar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Literature. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 1972–1996.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Hani
Writing: Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, used in 1958–1964 and from 1982,experimental, used in education, literature, and media.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some users of nearby languages also speak Hani. Taught at KunmingInstitute. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn],especially written Chinese. Also use Lipo [lpo]. Also use Lü [khb]. Used as L2 by Kucong [lkc],Lahu [lhu], Laomian [lwm], Sangkong [sgk].

name: Hiligaynon
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.Bible: 1912–2002.
Language Use: Also use Filipino [fil]. Used as L2 by Aklanon [akl], Ati [atk], Caluyanun[clu], Cotabato Manobo [mta], Inonhan [loc], Kagayanen [cgc], Kinaray-a [krj], Obo Manobo [obo],Tagakolu [klg], Tboli [tbl].

name: Kakwa
Language Development: Literacy campaign in progress. Literature. Radio. Videos. Bible: 1983.
Language Use: Home, market. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Many alsouse Kuku [ukv]. Many also use Lugbara [lgg]. Also use Nubi [kcn] (Nakao 2018).

name: Capanahua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1978–2008.
Language Use: Few child speakers: one-third have passive knowledge but generally do notacquire Capanahua (Crevels 2007). Use of Spanish [spa] between two Capanahua speakers can beinterpreted as rejecting the other person as an outsider. Adults in the home.

name: Lisu
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used in 1915–1918, 1958–1966, and from 1981. Lisu (Fraser) script [Lisu], used since 1918, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: High. Literacy rate in L2: Moderate in Chinese. Literacy taught through churches, rather than schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1968–1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. Speakers of other languages in the area use Lisu for administration, religion, and bilingual education in schools. In Drung and Nu areas, oral and written Lisu are used for Christian activities. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Bai [bca]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Jingpho [kac]. Also use Lü [khb]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially in secondary schools. Also use Naxi [nxq]. Used as L2 by Anong [nun], Central Bai [bca], Drung [duu], Northern Pumi [pmi], Nusu [nuf], Southern Pumi [pmj], Zaiwa [atb], Zauzou [zal].

name: Kinyarwanda
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in early grades only. Literature. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1954–1993.

name: Cham, Eastern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Cham script [Cham], primary usage.Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Radio. Grammar.Texts. Bible portions: 1973.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Ngombe (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Development: Radio. Videos. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1915–1956.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Pagibete [pae], for trading. Also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 by Pagibete [pae].

name: Ifugao, Mayoyao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–60%. Taught inprimary schools in grades 1–3. Literature. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Home and personal interaction; in school for bridging; some churches. Usedby all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Pahari-Potwari
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: Radio. Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Western Punjabi [pnb].

name: Chodri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 63% in Gujarat [guj] (2001 census). Radio. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Gujarati [guj].

name: Hindko, Northern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 20%. Pilot multilingual education program indevelopment. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: All domains, except education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useSaraiki [skr]. Also use Urdu [urd], especially the educated, but with varied proficiency. Alsouse Western Punjabi [pnb], with low proficiency. Used as L2 by Kundal Shahi [shd], Mankiyali[nlm], Western Punjabi [pnb].

name: Akoose
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 30% (Gov’t figure). Usedinformally in education. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. In official settings use English [eng], French [fra] or PidginEnglish [wes]. Home, church, market. Used by all. All also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Most alsouse English [eng]. Many also use French [fra]. A few also use Kenyang [ken]. A few also use Mbo[mbo].

name: Shatt
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2018.

name: Toba-Maskoy
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Most also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug], which is used in school and church. Some also use Spanish [spa], especially men, bilingually (Crevels 2012).

name: Sango
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1992–2012.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Ali [aiy], Bagirmi Fulfulde [fui], Banda-Bambari [liy], Banda-Banda [bpd], Banda-Mbrès [bqk], Banda-Ndélé [bfl], Banda-Yangere [yaj], Bhogoto [bdt], Bodo [boy], Bofi [bff], Buraka [bkg], Dagba [dgk], Dendi [deq], Fulu [fuu], Gbanu [gbv], Gbanziri [gbg], Gbaya-Bossangoa [gbp], Gbaya-Bozoum [gbq], Gbayi [gyg], Geme [geq], Gubu [gox], Gula [kcm], Gundi [gdi], Kabba [ksp], Kako [kkj], Kara [kah], Kare [kbn], Kpagua [kuw], Kpatili [kym], Laka [lap], Langbashe [lna], Luto [ndy], Mandja [mzv], Mbangi [mgn], Mbati [mdn], Mbay [myb], Mbum [mdd], Mid-Southern Banda [bjo], Monzombo [moj], Mpiemo [mcx], Ngam [nmc], Ngando [ngd], Ngbaka Ma’bo [nbm], Ngbaka Manza [ngg], Ngombe [nmj], Northwest Gbaya [gya], Nzakara [nzk], Pana [pnz], Pande [bkj], Riverain Sango [snj], Runga [rou], Sara Kaba [sbz], Sere [swf], South Central Banda [lnl], Southwest Gbaya [gso], Suma [sqm], Togbo-Vara Banda [tor], Ukhwejo [ukh], Vale [vae], West Central Banda [bbp], Yaka [axk], Yakoma [yky], Yulu [yul], Zande [zne].

name: Lezghian
Writing: Caucasian Albanian script [Aghb], no longer in use. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used since 1938 to present.
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Nara
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Female: 21%. Most literate Nara use Arabic [arb]. Taught in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Texts.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Kunama [kun], especially the Koyta. Also use Standard Arabic [arb], for intercommunication. Also use Tigré [tig], for intercommunication. Used as L2 by Bilen [byn].

name: Italian
Writing: Braille script [Brai], used since 1974. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1471–1985.
Language Use: Most Italians use varieties along a continuum from standard to regional tolocal according to what is appropriate. Possibly nearly half the population do not use standardItalian as L1. Only 3% of Italy’s population could speak standard Italian when the nationunified in 1861. Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use French[fra] (European Commission 2006). Also use Friulian [fur], in Friuli-Venezia Giulia region.

name: Mandjak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Literature. Radio. Videos. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Important politically. Thousands emigrated to France. Home, friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Growing shift towards Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], particularly among children of mixed marriages, and those from families who moved to the capital of Bissau for education and economic opportunity (2022 A. Yndibe). Positive attitudes. Most also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language of interethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Many also use Mandinka [mnk].
