Many also use Portuguese [por], as the language of education and communication with foreigners. Some also use Balanta [ble]. Some also use Pulaar [fuc]. Used as L2 by Kobiana [kcj], Mankanya [knf].

name: Adi
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Tibetan script [Tibt], used in China.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 59% (2001 census). Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible:2005–2009.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Alsouse Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Khamba [kbg], Tshangla [tsj].

name: Nambikuára, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Karko
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials produced. Interest in language development mainly among older people. Literature.
Language Use: Mixed: all domains. Adults only. Shifting to Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Tagbanwa, Central
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to Cuyonon [cyo]. Also use Filipino [fil], but with low comprehension.

name: Livvi
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Serious attempt since 1990 to revive language use. Some of all ages, but mainly older adults. A few children learn the language but most if not all become more fluent in Russian [rus] later in life (Salminen 2007). Also use Russian [rus].

name: Masbatenyo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1993.
Language Use: Home, market, work. Used by all. Used as L2 by Southern Sorsoganon [srv].

name: Baka (Sudan)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 27%. Orthography developed; literacy materials in use.Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Avokaya [avu]. Alsouse Moru [mgd]. Also use Mündü [muh]. Also use Zande [zne]. Used as L2 by Avokaya [avu], Mündü[muh].

name: Tabo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 28%. Literacy rate in L2: 33%. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: All domains unless non-Tabo speakers present. Used by all. Also use Bamu [bcf]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Gogodala [ggw].

name: Bwanabwana
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Important language at trade route center. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Dobu [dob]. Also use Duau [dva]. Also use Misima-Panaeati [mpx]. Also use Suau [swp]. Also use Tawala [tbo]. Used as L2 by ’Auhelawa [kud].

name: Alekano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1973–1986.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to English [eng] (Sifuma 1997). Shifting to Tok Pisin[tpi]. Used as L2 by Tokano [zuh].

name: Amarasi
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Texts. NT: 2015.

name: Lorung, Northern
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Lohorung is an endangered language, picking up Nepali [npi] influences (2002 T. P. Neupane). Home, religion; mixed use: Friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Nepali [npi], at least to some degree. Used as L2 by Eastern Mewahang [emg], Western Mewahang [raf].

name: Bashkir
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Cyrillic script[Cyrl].
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools from grade 5 in Bashkortostanrepublic. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2023.
Language Use: Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Tatar [tat].

name: Gofa
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Church literature. Latin script [Latn],official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 19%. Church-based literacy program started 2007.Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Offered atthe university as a major. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Neutral attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Baruga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. 100% children, 45%women, 90% men. Literature. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many non-Baruga wives of Baruga men learn it. All domains. Somein religious services. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], but thispopulation is diminishing. Also use English [eng], especially for government communications.Also use Ewage-Notu [nou]. Also use Korafe-Yegha [kpr]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 byMaisin [mbq].

name: Ukrainian
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used in the 19th century, limited usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in most tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1903–2020.

name: Gujarati
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Gujarati script [Gujr], primary usage. Khojki script[Khoj].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70% for Gujarat state (2001 census). Taught in primaryand secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Gujarat State; Dadra andNagar Haveli, Daman and Diu union territories. Fully developed. Bible: 1823–2005.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Adiwasi Garasia [gas], Chodri [cdi],Dangi [dhn], Dhodia [dho], Indo-Portuguese [idb], Kacchi [kfr], Rajput Garasia [gra], Sansi[ssi], Varli [vav].

name: Catalan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 96%. High literacy inCatalan (60%) is recent. Pallarese and Ribogorçan speakers have less education, less contactwith the standard, and live in high valleys of the Pyrenees. Some Valencian desire separateliterature. Taught in primary and secondary schools in Catalan-speaking areas. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1478–1993. Agency: Institut d’Estudis Catalans (Institute ofCatalan Studies), Acadèmia Valenciana de la Llengua (Royal Academy of the Valencian Language).
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Italian [ita].Also use Logudorese Sardinian [src]. Also use Occitan [oci]. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2by aranés [oci], Catalan Sign Language [csc].

name: Ivatan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 92%. Literary tradition of laji (old songs) andfolklore. Letters, hymnbooks. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1984–2016. Agency: Academics Foundation.
Language Use: Vigorous. Only very young and very old are monolingual. Not used inschools. Home, administration, religion, commerce, labor relations, letters. Used by all.Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng]. Most also use Filipino [fil].

name: Aghul
Language Development: Can be taught as a subject in local schools (Salminen 2007). Newspapers.Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2005.
Language Use: 98% speak it as L1. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Zulu
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Taught as subject in many primary and secondary schools from grade 4. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1883–1959.

name: Gilbertese
Language Development: Most are literate in Kiribati, but little material is available. Taught inall primary and secondary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter, transitioning toEnglish as language of instruction in grades 4 through 6. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible:1893–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use English [eng].

name: Quechua, Huaylla Wanca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2006–2010.
Language Use: Waycha dialect has few remaining speakers in Concepción. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mmen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25% (Fungom dialect). Literature. Dictionary. NT:2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.Also use French [fra]. Also use Kom [bkm]. Used as L2 by Kom [bkm].

name: Kubu
Language Development: Literature. Texts.
Language Use: For Kubu living in settled villages, L1 already replaced in all domains outside the home; for Kubu in Jambi areas (more isolated and less sedentary), the vitality is higher. Home. Some of all ages. Some people have assimilated to the Malay language and culture in the area (Persoon 1989). Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind], for education, religion, civic domains, and with other ethnic groups.

name: Suri
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used until 2009. Latin script [Latn], used since 2009, official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Kindergarten program using Suri as medium of instruction is piloted (2021 SIL). Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. After-school Suri literacy classes teach some school subjects in Suri. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2004–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Kacipo-Bale Suri [koe].

name: Tagalog
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Tagalog script [Tglg], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Fully developed. Bible: 1905.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Abellen Ayta [abp], Batak [bya], Bogkalot [ilk], Buhi’non Bikol [ubl], Calamian Tagbanwa [tbk], Caluyanun [clu], Central Bikol [bcl], Central Bontok [lbk], Central Sama [sml], Central Subanen [syb], Chavacano [cbk], Eskayan [esy], Higaonon [mba], Inagta Alabat [dul], Isinay [inn], Kalagan [kqe], Kalanguya [kak], Kamayo [kyk], Limos Kalinga [kmk], Lubuagan Kalinga [knb], Maguindanaon [mdh], Majukayang Kalinga [kmd], Manide [abd], Maranao [mrw], Northern Bontok [rbk], Ratagnon [btn], Remontado Dumagat [agv], Rinconada Bikol [bto], Sorsogon Ayta [ays], Southern Alta [agy], Southern Subanen [laa], Surigaonon [sgd], Tandaganon [tgn], Tausug [tsg], Western Subanon [suc].

name: Ngiemboon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 8%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Functional literacy started. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Many also use Yemba [ybb]. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Ngomba [jgo], Ngombale [nla], Yemba [ybb].

name: Migabac
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: All domains except church, where there is mixed use, and in interactions with outsiders. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use Dedua [ded]. Some also use Kâte [kmg]. Used as L2 by Dedua [ded].

name: Port Vato
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 70%. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1899.
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; mixed: Education; limited: Religion. Used by all.

name: Mari, Eastern
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1986–2020.
Language Use: Many children learn the language but only those in remote rural areas continue to use it actively. In eastern diaspora areas in Bashkortostan practically all children learn the language (Salminen 2007). Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Hill Mari [mrj].

name: Wuzlam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: Very low. Learned in literacy classes, or after school classes. Most older generation illiterate. Most are beginning readers. Church-based adult literacy classes started in 1999. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: All domains except education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Mada [mxu]. Also use Vame [mlr]. Also use Wandala [mfi]. Used as L2 by Mada [mxu], Matal [mfh], Muyang [muy], Parkwa [pbi], Vame [mlr].

name: Fyam
Language Development: 50% of youth read haltingly in Hausa [hau]. Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: In some villages, used by youth only in special contexts. Home, Community. Some of all ages. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Hausa [hau]. A few also use Bijim [jbm]. Used as L2 by Bijim [jbm].

name: Purepecha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1969–2012.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nobiin
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Coptic script [Copt], Old Nubianvariant. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1860–1899. The goals ofthe Nubian Language Society are to revitalize the Nubian language, teach the Nubian language toall Nubian people, and develop the Nubian language to cope with technology and modern life(Jaeger 2008). Agency: Nubian Language Society.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Manobo, Agusan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 54%. Literacy rate in L2: 55%–60%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1999–2011.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Rajah Kabunsuwan Manobo [mqk].

name: Katu, Eastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1978–2007.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Cerma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 12%. Literacy rate in L2: 15% Jula [dyu] or French[fra]. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio. Dictionary.Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Gilaki
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Persian [pes]. Taught as subject in somesecondary schools; maximum 2 hours per week on Gilaki culture and literature. Literature.Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2012.
Language Use: Home, market, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use IranianPersian [pes].

name: Pashto, Northern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], primary usage. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low. Taught as subject in all primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Rich literary tradition. The Powinda are a nomadic Pashto-speaking group. Used as L2 by Dameli [dml], Gawarbati [gwt], Gawri [gwc], Indus Kohistani [mvy], Kalkoti [xka], Kateviri [bsh], Khowar [khw], Komviri [xvi], Madaklashti [prs], Mankiyali [nlm], Palula [phl], Sarikoli [srh], Southern Hindko [hnd], Torwali [trw], Ushojo [ush], Western Punjabi [pnb].

name: Slovak
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1832–1999.

name: Montenegrin
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools. Grammar.

name: Sunwar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20% (2010 L. Rapacha). Literacy rate in L2: Males 15% in villages, 20% in Kathmandu. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2011. Agency: Kõits Bu.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Adolescents and older. Some use among children. Language is passed down to children only in village areas (Toba et al 2002). Positive attitudes. Also use Bhujel [byh]. Also use Eastern Tamang [taj]. Also use Nepali [npi], especially young people for trade and official purposes, but with low proficiency. Used as L2 by Jirel [jul].

name: Huastec, Veracruz
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 52%. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT:1970–2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Eastern Huasteca Nahuatl [nhe]. Also use Spanish[spa].

name: Akeu
Writing: Latin script [Latn], developed in 2005, used mainly in Thailand andMyanmar.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Less than 1%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Home, community, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also useAkha [ahk]. Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Some also use Lü [khb].

name: Mazatec, Chiquihuitlán
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kanuri, Manga
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn], used since 2007.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only,in 2 bilingual primary schools. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1998–2020.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Dazaga [dzg].

name: Korlai Creole Portuguese
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: L1 of Christian farming community in upper Korlai. Intense cultural pressure from surrounding Marathi-speaking [mar] population. Home. Also use English [eng]. Also use Marathi [mar], fluently with outsiders.

name: Kukna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Some literacy work being done. Radio. NT:1977–2002.
Language Use: Also use Khandesi [khn], especially a group of Kukna in Dhule District.Used as L2 by Khandesi [khn].

name: Jita
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1943–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, local gatherings. Preferred language unless speakers ofother languages are present. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Kara [reg], Kerewe[ked].

name: Ibatan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% (2007 SIL). Allschool-aged children are literate. Schooling is in Filipino [fil] or English [eng]. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: All domains as well as religious services and ceremonies, and localcommerce. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Some also use Filipino [fil]. Also use English[eng]. Also use Ilocano [ilo], with increasing numbers of people shifting. Used as L2 by Ilocano[ilo].

name: Ma'di
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1935, revised in 2002.
Language Development: Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1977.
Language Use: Home, market, work, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh]. Also use Nubi [kcn] (Nakao 2018). Used as L2 by Kuku [ukv].

name: Chin, Bawm
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 1989–2018.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Assamese [asm], with most youthshifting. Used as L2 by Pankhu [pkh].

name: Mutu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%–50% in Tok Pisin [tpi], 20%–30% in English [eng]. Increasing. Literature. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, church. Used by all. Mixed attitudes, from positive to negative. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Karnai [bbv].

name: Naga, Inpui
LITERACY_L2: 70% in English [eng] and in Meitei [mni] (Bengali script) (2000).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70% in English [eng] and in Meitei [mni] (Bengali script) (2000). Literacy high among young people in Meitei and English. Literature. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Home, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Meitei [mni]. Some also use English [eng]. Also use Rongmei Naga [nbu].

name: Aromanian
Writing: Greek script [Grek]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in tertiary schools in 1 municipality. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1889–2014.

name: Tal
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: All domains except church. Used by all. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Hausa [hau]. A few also use Ngas [anc]. Used as L2 by Belning [glb], Koenoem [kcs], Piapung [pcw], Tehl [mtl].

name: Mawchi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. NT: 1989.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Kalagan, Kagan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Perhaps 60%. Literature. Bible portions: 1982.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb].

name: Uighur
LITERACY_L2: 91% in any language (2000 census, Uyghur nationality).
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], official and primary usage in China, also used in Afghanistan. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Kazakhstan, past usage in China. Latin script [Latn], used in China and Turkey.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% in any language (2000 census, Uyghur nationality). Literacy based on Central Uyghur as spoken in the area between Yili (Ili) and Urumqi, and includes literates in Uyghur or Chinese or both. Taught in a few primary and secondary schools, though this is in decline; taught as subject in some scholols. Taught in tertiary schools. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Grammar. Bible: 1950–2022.
Language Use: Vigorous, except in Urumqi. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially young people, intellectuals, and city dwellers, but increasingly in rural areas as well. Also use Russian [rus]. Used as L2 by Ainu [aib], Ili Turki [ili], Kyrgyz [kir], Northern Uzbek [uzn], Peripheral Mongolian [mvf], Russian [rus], Salar [slr], Sarikoli [srh], Tatar [tat], Xibe [sjo].

name: Natügu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–60%. English texts. Pijin lectures. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2005–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, church, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Pijin [pis]. Used as L2 by Engdewu [ngr].

name: Duungooma
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Bamanankan [bam]. Also useFrench [fra], especially students. Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Jowulu [jow].

name: Ndonga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1954–1986.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Afrikaans
Writing: Braille script [Brai], used since 1953. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in some primary and secondary schools from grade 4; taught assubject in grades 1–3. Taught in some tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1933–2023.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng].

name: Apache (Western)
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1966–2012.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. A few children at San Carlos and Fort Apacheare L1 speakers but most younger people are passive or semi-passive (Golla 2007). Most also useEnglish [eng].

name: Yiwom
Language Development: Radio. Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religious settings, Special cultural events, Technologyand media. Used by all. Most also use Tarok [yer]. Many also use English [eng]. Many also useHausa [hau]. Many also use Jukun Takum [jbu]. Some also use Goemai [ank]. Used as L2 by Wãpha[juw].

name: Ladino
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used by Sephardic speakers in the Balkans. Hebrew script [Hebr]. Latin script [Latn], used in Turkey.
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1829.
Language Use: Not the dominant language for most. Formerly the main language of Sephardic Jewry. Used in literary and music contexts. Older adults only. The youngest speakers are over 50 years old. Shifted to Hebrew [heb].

name: Mixe, Coatlán
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1976.

name: Koyukon
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1974–1982.
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Kati
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], limited usage, in development. Arabicscript, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1%–3%. The Afghanistan Ministry of Education hasproduced Eastern Kateviri language textbooks for first through twelfth grades. But as ofNovember 2021, these books had not yet been distributed to schools. Literature. TV. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Outside of language area, shifting towards Dari [prs]. All domains. Used byall. Positive attitudes. Many also use Urdu [urd]. Also use Dari [prs], especially in the west.Also use Southern Pashto [pbt], especially in the east.

name: Ormuri
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran].
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Also use Central Pashto [pst]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Ndut
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Active cultural association involved in literacy and literature production. Radio. NT: 2020.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Most also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Also use Laalaa [cae]. Also use Saafi-Saafi [sav].

name: Khakas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50% (2007 SIL). Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Russian [rus]. Khakas books often self-published and difficult to obtain. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2009. In urban areas, marked interest in Khakas language revival. Fewer young people speak Khakas than previous generations, but more children study it in school than 20 years ago.
Language Use: Struggle to maintain culture and language. In some rural areas children learn it, but in cities Russian [rus] is typically the only language (Salminen 2007). Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes, but rural speakers want their children to learn the national language for economic advancement. Most also use Russian [rus], especially at work, school, public transport, government, and for most written communication.

name: Uspanteco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 16%. Radio. Grammar. NT: 1999–2010. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Jagoi
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Belize Kriol English
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Creoles, people of East Indian descent. Most domains. Positive attitudes.Used as L2 by Garifuna [cab], Plautdietsch [pdt].

name: Mpongmpong
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Many also use French [fra]. A few also use Ewondo [ewo]. Used as L2 by Bekwel [bkw].

name: Braj
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Grammar. NT: 1824–2013.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Ikobi-Mena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Bullock 2015). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bullock 2015). Some also use English [eng] (Bullock 2015). Used as L2 by Minanibai [mcv].

name: Kalagan
LITERACY_L2: 80% in Cebuano [ceb], 50% in Tagalog [tgl] or English [eng].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Cebuano [ceb], 50% in Tagalog [tgl] or English [eng]. Literature. Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Strong in communities that are mainly Kalagan, but in mixed communities speakers tend to use Cebuano [ceb]. Youth bilingual in Cebuano, some are losing Kalagan ability. Home, neighborhood, religion. Some young people, all adults. Youth only in solid Kalagan communities. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Sample showed high proficiency with narratives in Cebuano. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tagalog [tgl]. Used as L2 by Koronadal Blaan [bpr], Tausug [tsg].

name: Ngie
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio. NT: 2023.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. Also use French [fra]. Also use Meta’ [mgo].

name: Sibe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Literacy stopped, but revival plans exist. Literature. Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 1984.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Evans 2018). Used as L2 by Naasioi [nas].

name: Talysh
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in Iran. Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used in Azerbaijan.
Language Development: Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use North Azerbaijani [azj].

name: Dogon, Toro So
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate is 30% among Christians (2013 SIL).Taught in some adult and youth literacy classes (2021 SIL). Taught in some primary schools inearly grades only. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all.

name: Tokelau
Language Development: They read the Samoan Bible and some speak some Samoan [smo]. Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Grammar. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Lomwe, Malawi
Language Development: Approved orthography. Radio. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Chichewa [nya].

name: Konni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 16%. Literacy rate in L2: 0%. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Vigorous, with a strong sense of ethnic identity. Women from other language groups who marry Koma men learn the Konni language. All domains. Used by all. Also use Mampruli [maw]. Also use Tumulung Sisaala [sil].

name: Lozi
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1951–2009.
Language Use: Home, church, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Fwe [fwe], Khwedam [xuu], Nkoya [nka].

name: Yemsa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 24%. Taught in primary schools in grades 1 and 2 ingovernment pilot schools. Grammar. Bible portions: 2001.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Also use West Central Oromo [gaz].

name: Chinantec, Comaltepec
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–2%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. 1%–2% can read, lessthan 1% can write. Literature. Radio. Videos. Texts. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, local administration, preschool, religion. Writtenuse to record customs, traditions, history. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also useEnglish [eng].

name: Ifè
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%. Literature. Radio.Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2009–2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Alsouse Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Yoruba [yor]. Used as L2 by Aguna [aug], Anii[blo], Bago-Kusuntu [bqg], Kpessi [kef], Northern Nago [xkb].

name: Jerung
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education. Some young people, alladults. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Wambule [wme].

name: Puma
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Agency: Kirat Puma Rai Tupkhabangkhala.
Language Use: Home, religion, work; mixed use: Friends. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes, especially among younger generation. Also use Bantawa [bap]. Also use Chamling [rab]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Ebira
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%. High literacymotivation. Radio. TV. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Other language speakers use Ebira to communicate with Ebirapeople. All domains: administration, commerce, oral and written use in religious services; asubject at the College of Education. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa[hau]. Also use Yoruba [yor]. Used as L2 by Aduge [adu].

name: Ikwere
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 65%. Considerable localinterest in language and literacy. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Home, work, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Igbo[ibo]. Also use English [eng].

name: Teke-Ebo
Language Development: Small scale adult literacy program run by local group with SIL. Literature.Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2004–2009.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Ludian
Language Development: Ludian Society founded in Finland in 1998. Literary language development beginning (Salminen 2007). Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only, very few children (Salminen 2007). Shifting to Russian [rus].

name: Masaba
Language Development: Orthography guide published but inadequate for dialectal variants. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2016. Agency: Lumasaaba Language Academy.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Ganda [lug]. Many also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Bukusu [bxk].

name: Bouyei
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from late Ming/early Qing dynasty, limited use in ritual texts and folk literature. Latin script [Latn], official usage since 1985.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: 76% (2000 census). Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1904.
Language Use: Vigorous. Rare oral use in local administration, commerce, education. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Sui [swi]. Used as L2 by Bu-Nao Bunu [bwx], Mak [mkg], T’en [tct].

name: Mbuko
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 8%. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Daily life, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Used as L2 by Merey [meq].

name: Bosnian
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Cyrillic script[Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 97%. Taught in primary and secondary schools inBosnian-speaking areas. Dictionary. Bible: 2013–2021.

name: Quechua, North Bolivian
Language Development: Taught in some primary schools. Newspapers. Radio. TV. NT: 1985.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, religious services, commerce, and labor. Positive attitudes. Many also use Spanish [spa]. Also use Central Aymara [ayr].

name: Dusun, Central
LITERACY_L2: 90%–95% in StandardMalay [zsm], 10%–60% in English [eng], 60% in West Coast Bajau [bdr], less than 10% in MandarinChinese [cmn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–90%. Literacy rate in L2: 90%–95% in StandardMalay [zsm], 10%–60% in English [eng], 60% in West Coast Bajau [bdr], less than 10% in MandarinChinese [cmn]. The Bundu and Liwan dialects are used as the basis for the Kadazandusun languagetaught in schools/higher learning institutions. Coastal Kadazan has applied to the Ministry ofEducation for the teaching and learning of the language (2014 R. Lasimbang). Literature.Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2000. Agency: KadazanDusunCultural Association (KDCA), Kadazandusun Language Foundation (KLF).
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work, Education. Some young people, alladults. Some children and adults; all elderly. Mixed attitudes, from positive to neutral. Allalso use Sabah Malay [msi]. Many also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Some also use Hakka Chinese[hak]. A few also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially speakers of Tambunan and CoastalKadazan varieties. A few also use Rungus [drg]. A few also use Tahol Murut [mvv], especiallyspeakers of Tambunan variety. Also use English [eng]. Also use West Coast Bajau [bdr],especially users of Tindal variety. Used as L2 by Gana [gnq], Ida’an [dbj], Iranun [ilm],Keningau Murut [kxi], Kuijau [dkr], Lanas Lobu [ruu], Lotud [dtr], Rungus [drg], Sugut Dusun[kzs], Tahol Murut [mvv], Tampias Lobu [low], Tatana [txx], Tombonuo [txa].

name: Quichua, Salasaca Highland
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Spanish [spa]. Literature. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, community, agriculture, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Amba (Uganda)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 2009, in development.
Language Development: Literacy campaign in progress. Radio. Texts. Bible portions: 2004–2014.
Language Use: Due to intermarriage, most Amba children grow up speaking Lubwisi [tlj]. Home. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Talinga-Bwisi [tlj]. All also use Tooro [ttj]. Many also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Mvuba [mxh].

name: Petats
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Radio. Bible portions: 1934–1978.
Language Use: Many children who live on Pororan Island grow up learning Tok Pisin [tpi] as their first language before learning to speak the vernacular (Schneider 2018). Arguing. Mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi] in all other domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Most also use Solos [sol], especially adults. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Hakö [hao]. Some also use Halia [hla]. Used as L2 by Solos [sol].

name: Doromu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 24%. Literacy rate in L2: 27% in English [eng]. Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in 1 school. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous, but with influence from Hiri Motu [hmo] and English [eng]. All domains except in education and religion, where there is mixed use, and in communication with outsiders. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng] (Bradshaw 2012). Most also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults (Bradshaw 2012). Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Bradshaw 2012).

name: Chontal, Highland Oaxaca
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Older adults only. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Yombe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 30% in French [fra]. Radio. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Home; Religion; Mixed: Community, Work, Education. Used by all. Many also use French [fra]. Some also use Koongo [kng]. A few also use Lingala [lin].

name: Bagheli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 49% in Hindi [hin]. Had literature since 16th century.Radio. NT: 1821.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], using it widely but not displacing Bagheli in any domain.35% of Bagheli speakers have at least good general proficiency.

name: Chin, Mara
Language Development: Taught in most primary schools through grade 8. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1955–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Also use Mizo [lus]. Used as L2 by Zyphe Chin [zyp].

name: Altai (Southern)
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Cyrillic script, Old Church Slavonic variant[Cyrs], used in the 19th century. Mongolian script [Mong].
Language Development: Written Altai based on Southern Altai, but is rejected by Northern Altaichildren. Taught as subject in a few primary and secondary schools for 3 hours a week in theAltai Republic only. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2003–2017.
Language Use: Home, and with other Altai. Used by all. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Breton
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. An average of 15,000 students in Breton languageand bilingual schools. Taught in a few primary schools in early grades only. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1866–1985.
Language Use: Strong nationalistic movement demanding recognition, a place in theschools, media, and public life. Older adults only. Shifted to French [fra].

name: Arabic, Sudanese Creole
Language Development: Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1983–1985.
Language Use: Major language of communication in Greater Equatoria region, and south of Wau and Malakal. Most domains except very formal situations; also used in government. Used by all. Used as L2 by Banda-Banda [bpd], Banda-Mbrès [bqk], Banda-Ndélé [bfl], Imotong [imt], Lango [lgo], Logir [lqr], Mid-Southern Banda [bjo], Okolie [oie].

name: Miri
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Devanagari script [Deva]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 53% for Arunachal, 60 % for Assam (2001 census). Radio. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm].

name: Dutch
Writing: Braille script [Brai], used since 1951. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in most tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1526–2004.
Language Use: Most speakers of other languages are also fluent in Dutch. Most also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Most also use Standard German [deu] (European Commission 2006). Some also use French [fra] (European Commission 2006).

name: Chenoua
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Mainly rural village use. Some parents teach children Arabic foreducational advantage. These youth then learn Chenoua from elders at an older age. Some of allages. Also use Algerian Arabic [arq], with shift in larger towns and cities.

name: Asturian
Language Development: Leonese associations promote their language variety. Taught in most primaryand secondary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter. By 2018, 55% of primary and 20%of secondary students were opting to study Asturian.. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some children learn the language inAsturias; in other regions speakers are mostly elderly (Salminen 2007). Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Marka
LITERACY_L2: 5% haltingly in French [fra], some in Jula [dyu].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% haltingly in French [fra], some in Jula [dyu]. Literature. Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 1987.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu], but only men who travel. Used as L2 by Pana [pnq].

name: Buriat, Mongolia
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], used in 1930s. Mongolianscript [Mong], used until 1917.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Halh Mongolian [khk]. Literature. Videos.Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: All also use Halh Mongolian [khk].

name: Zande (specific)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used in Democratic Republic of Congo.
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1978.
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg]. Used as L2 by Boguru [bqu], Kari [kbj], Sere [swf].

name: Girawa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 45%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Assamese
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subjectthereafter in Assam state. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 1833–1995.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Adi [adi], Aiton [aio], Amri Karbi [ajz], Angami Naga [njm],Ao Naga [njo], Apatani [apt], Bawm Chin [bgr], Chang Naga [nbc], Deori [der], Digaro-Mishmi[mhu], Dimasa [dis], Galo Adi [adl], Hajong [haj], Hmar [hmr], Hrangkhol [hra], Hruso [hru],Idu-Mishmi [clk], Kachari [xac], Kamtapuri [rkt], Karbi [mjw], Khamti [kht], Khamyang [ksu],Koch [kdq], Kurmukar [kfv], Lyngngam [lyg], Miji [sjl], Miju-Mishmi [mxj], Mising [mrg], NocteNaga [njb], Phake [phk], Puroik [suv], Singpho [sgp], Sumi Naga [nsm], Tangsa Naga [nst], Tiwa[lax], Turung [try], Tutsa Naga [tvt], Wancho Naga [nnp].

name: Hazaragi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Possibly 10%–20%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions:2008–2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Urdu [urd]. Also use Dari [prs].

name: Kok Borok
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 74% (2001 census). Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools from grade 6. Taught as subject at 2 universities. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1998.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Kagulu
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Kamba [kam].

name: Gwere
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 2005, in development.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Newspapers. Radio.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2017. Agency: Lugwere Bible Translation and Literacy Association.
Language Use: Very vigorous. Home, village, market, work, church. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Ganda [lug]. Used as L2 by Kenye [lke].

name: Kein
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Most children learn Tok Pisin [tpi] first; then many, but not all, learnKein. All domains, except church. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Emberá, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Bible reading isprimary motivation for L1 literacy. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1991–2011.
Language Use: Home, friends, some churches. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa],where in Panama Province those under 30 may speak it as L1; to a lesser degree, those under 30in the Darien Province may also speak it.

name: Kalinga, Lubuagan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2013.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Also use Tagalog [tgl].

name: Endo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Mabaan
Language Development: Literature. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Khayo
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Kaninuwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Highly literate in English. Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in 1 school. Bible portions: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous (Kassell 2012). All domains except church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng] (Kassell 2012). Many also use Bwaidoka [bwd] (Kassell 2012). A few also use Dobu [dob], especially elderly (Kassell 2012). Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Iduna [viv].

name: Blafe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught in primaryschools in early grades only, in 4 schools.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Education, Religious settings, Special culturalevents. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Rema [bow].

name: Arabic (North Levantine)
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1940–1973.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Domari [rmt], Northern Kurdish [kmr], South Azerbaijani[azb], Turoyo [tru], Western Neo-Aramaic [amw].

name: Tai Laing
Writing: Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], historic usage with some recent revival of the script.
Language Development: Agency: Tai Laing Cultural and Literature Committee.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Burmese [mya], with some shifting is some areas. Used as L2 by Taman [tcl].

name: Fala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Nearly 100%. Literature. Periodicals. Grammar. NT:2015. Agency: Asociación Cultural a Nosa Fala.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except church, and contacts with outsiders. Used byall. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sa'a
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%–over 60%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught inmany primary schools in early grades only. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1927–2005.
Language Use: Nearly extinct on Uki Ni Masi. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used asL2 by Oroha [ora].

name: Esan
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1974.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Ika [ikk]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm].

name: Bilaspuri
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Home, community, agriculture, religion. Used by all. Also use EasternPunjabi [pan]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially for instruction inschool and politics, but middle-aged and older women have limited comprehension of it. Also useUrdu [urd], especially by middle-aged and older educated people.

name: Saraiki
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage. Devanagari script [Deva], no longer in use. Gurmukhi script [Guru], no longer in use. Khojki script [Khoj].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Radio. TV. Grammar. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Aer [aeq], Central Pashto [pst], Eastern Balochi [bgp], Khetrani [xhe], Marwari [mve], Northern Hindko [hno], Sansi [ssi], Sindhi [snd], Southern Hindko [hnd], Western Punjabi [pnb].

name: Bekwarra
Language Development: Radio. TV. Grammar. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Yala [yba]. Used as L2 byUtugwang-Irungene-Afrike [afe], Yace [ekr].

name: Chiga
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in somesecondary schools, as Runyakitaara, sharing materials with Nyankore [nyn]. Literature.Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1989.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also useEnglish [eng]. Most also use Nyankore [nyn], which is closely related. A few also use Ganda[lug]. Used as L2 by Fumbira [kin], Nyankore [nyn].

name: Sa'ban
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literature. Bible portions: 1969.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. People have been moving into urban areas for employment, and as a consequence have abandoned some of their cultural traditions. It is not clear whether young people are giving up on their ethnic language, but there is evidence that they are becoming proficient in other languages for employment opportunities.

name: Popoloca, San Marcos Tlalcoyalco
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 1983–2016.

name: Batanga
Language Development: Radio. Bible portions: 1953.
Language Use: Most parents of young children now transmit French as L1 rather thanBatanga. Children above age 6 speak French [fra] better than Batanga. Adults only. Most shiftingto French [fra]. Some also use Bulu [bum]. Some also use Kwasio [nmg]. Used as L2 by Kwasio[nmg].

name: Sanskrit
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Grantha script [Gran]. Kawi script [Kawi]. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr]. Newa script [Newa]. Sharada script [Shrd]. Siddham script [Sidd], no longer in use. Sinhala script [Sinh].
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Taught as subject in tertiary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1822.
Language Use: Used in liturgy, cultural ceremonies, and rituals.

name: Khorasani Turkish
Language Development: Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Thakali
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Religion; mixed use: Home, Community. Older adults only.

name: Sidamo
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used until 1993. Latin script [Latn], used since 1993.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Taught in university as a major. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Chepang
LITERACY_L2: 40% men, 15% women inNepali [npi]; 14% ethnic group (1991 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% men, 15% women inNepali [npi]; 14% ethnic group (1991 census). Difficulties in reading Chepang: long words,consonant clusters. Written Chepang has lower prestige than Nepali. Motivation high for Nepali.Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1993.
Language Use: Home; mixed use: Friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. Also use Nepali [npi], especially men for common topics and politicalaffairs, women for greetings and trade, and young people among themselves; often learned inschool.

name: Nyamwezi
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1909–2005.
Language Use: Vigorous in some areas. Swahili [swh] used increasingly in other areas. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Kimbu [kiv], Ruwila [rwl].

name: Tharu, Chitwania
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous within the language community. Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education. Used by all. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to negative. Also use Bhojpuri [bho]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Molbog
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 7%. Literature. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Home, at school, informal and formal community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Mapun [sjm]. Acquired through community, trade, school, and travel. Used as L2 by Southern Sama [ssb].

name: Tai Dam
Writing: Lao script [Laoo]. Latin script [Latn]. Tai Viet script [Tavt].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio.Dictionary. NT: 2013–2014.
Language Use: Also use Tai Dón [twh] (Abadie 2001). Also use Vietnamese [vie]. Used as L2by Kháng [kjm], Tai Dón [twh].

name: Dhodia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 76% in Gujarat (2001 census). Radio.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Gujarati [guj].

name: Tu
LITERACY_L2: 77% literate in any language (2000 census, Tu nationality).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 2,000 can read, 200 can write. Literacy rate in L2: 77% literate in any language (2000 census, Tu nationality). Literature. Periodicals. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Varies with location. Positive attitudes. Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod].

name: Safaliba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 8% in English [eng] or in Gonja [gjn]. Literature. Texts. Bible portions: 2003–2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Used as L2 by Kamara [jmr].

name: Nandi
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Terik [tec].

name: Borong
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community; Mixed use: education, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth. Many also use Kâte [kmg], especially elderly.

name: Ligurian
Language Development: Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1860.
Language Use: Also use Italian [ita].

name: Tanacross
Writing: Latin script [Latn], practical alphabet was established in 1973, sometimes taught in school.
Language Development: Practical alphabet established in 1973. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Only older adults in the home. Shifted to English [eng]. Also use Upper Tanana [tau].

name: Khmer
Language Development: 35% of the population over 15 cannot read or write Khmer. Taught in primaryand secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1954–2016.

name: Mixtec, Northern Tlaxiaco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Literature. Videos. Grammar. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Bilingualism increasing due to schooling and migration.

name: Nyiha
Language Development: SIL has transition literacy work (Swahili to Nyiha). Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1913–2021.
Language Use: Most domains except education, government. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Takuu
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Moyle 2011).

name: Dhatki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Taught as subject in some primary and secondary schools. Radio. Bible portions: 1999.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sindhi [snd]. Also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Jogi [jog], Sindhi Bhil [sbn].

name: Susu
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Baga Kaloum [bqf], Baga Koga [bgo], Baga Manduri [bmd], Baga Pokur [bcg], Baga Sitemu [bsp], Baga Sobané [bsv], Bullom So [buy], Nalu [naj], Pular [fuf].

name: Hassaniyya
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn], in development.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Arabic [arb], 25% in French [fra]. Literacy in Hassaniyya not encouraged by the government. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use French [fra], as the language of education, media and government. Many also use Standard Arabic [arb], as the language of government, media, and religion (Ould Ahmed 2012). Used as L2 by Bambara [bam], Pulaar [fuc], Soninke [snk], Tamasheq [taq], Wolof [wol], Zenaga [zen].

name: Fon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. 10% can read Fon, 7% can write it. Taught assubject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2, in 5 schools (2014 SIL). Literature. Newspapers.Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Administration, education, religious services, commerce, andlabor. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Aguna [aug], Ayizo Gbe [ayb], CiGbe [cib], Eastern Xwla Gbe [gbx], Ede Idaca [idd], Ede Ije [ijj], Gbesi Gbe [gbs], Gun [guw],Kotafon Gbe [kqk], Maxi Gbe [mxl], Saxwe Gbe [sxw], Tchumbuli [bqa], Tofin Gbe [tfi], Weme Gbe[wem], Western Xwla Gbe [xwl], Xwela Gbe [xwe].

name: Samburu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Samburu: 15%–25%, Chamus: 40%. Radio. Videos. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Home, social gatherings, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by El Molo [elo], Rendille [rel].

name: Divehi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 98%. Literacy rate in L2: 81%. Literacy rate is forthose 6 years and older. Taught in many primary and secondary schools in early grades and assubject thereafter. Fully developed. Bible portions: 2004–2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Urdu [urd]. Also use Arabic varieties.

name: Naga, Sumi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Assamese [asm], English [eng]. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2000–2004.
Language Use: Also use Angami Naga [njm]. Also use Ao Naga [njo]. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Lotha Naga [njh]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Pnar
LITERACY_L2: 62% for Synteng dialect in Meghalaya (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 62% for Synteng dialect in Meghalaya (2001 census). Radio.
Language Use: Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Mizo [lus].

name: Armenian
Writing: Armenian script [Armn], primary usage. Braille script [Brai].
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools, becoming the primary languageof instruction in 1990. Fully developed. Bible: 1666–2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Fulfulde, Central-Eastern Niger
Language Development: Taught in a few experimental primary schools. Radio. TV. Dictionary. NT:2015.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Quechua, Southern Pastaza
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997–2008.
Language Use: Home, work, play, church. Used by all. Some also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Andoa [anb], Taushiro [trr].

name: Ron
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. NT: 2020.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau].Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Some also use Mwaghavul [sur]. Some also use NigerianFulfulde [fuv].

name: Palaung, Shwe
Writing: Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], initial development in the 1930s with revisions in the 1980s.
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Shan [shn].

name: Koluwawa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–80%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–80%. Literature. Bible portions: 2000–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community; Mixed use: Market, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Dobu [dob], especially older adults. Most also use English [eng], especially young people. Many also use Bwaidoka [bwd]. Many also use Iamalele [yml]. Some also use Iduna [viv]. Some also use Minaveha [mvn]. Used as L2 by Minaveha [mvn].

name: Yakha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Nepali [npi]. There are attempts to teach Yakkha at school, and textbooks are published up to grade 3, but not widely used. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2023. Agency: Kirant Yakkha Chumma.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education. Some young people, all adults. Children and elderly. Some use among adolescents, young and older adults (Toba et al 2005). Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Limbu [lif].

name: Shuar
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary.Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Achuar-Shiwiar [acu], Waorani [auc].

name: Albanian (Tosk)
Writing: Elbasan script [Elba], no longer in use. Greek script [Grek], no longer inuse. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools. Fullydeveloped. NT: 1827–2007.

name: Shina
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 1929.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Balti [bft], Brokskat [bkk], Dawoodi [dmk], Khowar [khw].

name: Kamayurá
Language Development: Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. A few also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Awetí[awe], Trumai [tpy], Yawalapití [yaw].

name: Kupsabiny
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1975, revised in 2011.
Language Use: Home, markets. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Swahili [swh].

name: Indonesian
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Braille script [Brai]. Latin script[Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1974–2000.

name: Tennet
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Motivation for literacy is high. Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. NT: 2019.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Lopit [lpx]. Also use Otuho [lot]. Also use Toposa [toq].

name: Masalit
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Sudanese Arabic [apd], however, people in the central area and women have limited proficiency.

name: Songo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 85%. Literature. Radio.
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; Mixed: Religion. Some young people, all adults. Many also use French [fra]. Many also use Kituba [ktu]. Many also use Lingala [lin].

name: Beli (Sudan)
Language Development: Orthography developed; literacy materials in use. Taught as subject in afew primary schools in grade 1. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Mo’da [gbn].

name: Kaonde
Language Development: Literacy campaigns, agricultural extension services. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1975.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Anuak
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Otoro
Language Development: Literature. NT: 1966.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Balantak
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Andio [bzb], Bugis [bug], Indonesian Bajau [bdl].

name: Sama, Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%. Literature. Videos. Texts. NT: 1987–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use Chavacano [cbk]. Also use Malay [zlm]. Also use Tagalog [tgl]. Also use Tausug [tsg]. Used as L2 by Southern Sama [ssb].

name: Dimli (individual language)
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: In urban areas children still learn only L1 at home. Home, neighborhood,friends. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes, increasingly. Most also use Turkish[tur]. Some also use Northern Kurdish [kmr]. Used as L2 by Domari [rmt], Northern Kurdish [kmr].

name: Nivaclé
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1995–2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Many also use Iyo’wujwa Chorote [crq]. Manyalso use Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2012). A few also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug] (Crevels 2012).Used as L2 by Enlhet [enl], Manjui [crq].

name: Vengo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Basic literacy materials. Literature. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1993.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].

name: Bukar Sadong
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Used as L2 by Remun [lkj].

name: Muria, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2% (2003 India Church Growth Mission). Literature.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Palaung, Pale
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Strong literacy program. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2021.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Lü [khb]. Also use Shan [shn]. Used as L2 by Rumai Palaung [rbb].

name: Luganda
Language Development: Widely used for literacy. Many adults outside the language area learned to read Ganda in school (2021 SIL). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Taught as subject at 1 university. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1896–2017.
Language Use: Used in primary schools and churches especially in the south. Kooki dialect may be extinct. Home, work, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Chiga [cgg], Gwere [gwr], Kenye [lke], Kuku [ukv], Masaaba [myx], Nubi [kcn], Nyankore [nyn], Nyole [nuj], Nyoro [nyo], Ruruuli-Runyala [ruc], Saamya-Gwe [lsm], Soga [xog].

name: Yeskwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Radio. Bible portions: 2015–2017.
Language Use: Home, market, farms, village meeting. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Ashe [ahs]. Also use English [eng], especially youth. Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Ashe [ahs].

name: Kisa
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Adilabad Gondi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only. The State Education Department has recognized this language and has been active in promoting it for primary education (2015 M. Penny). Dictionary. NT: 2018.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Tsonga
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary and secondary schools from grade 4. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1907–1989.

name: Dedua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 85%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Prep schools in 4villages. Literature. NT: 2006–2016.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin[tpi], especially those over 20 years old. Also use Kâte [kmg], in 2 villages as L1. Also useMigabac [mpp]. Also use Ono [ons]. Used as L2 by Migabac [mpp].

name: Musi
Language Development: Preference is for Indonesian for educational and religious materials. Preference is for L1 for cultural stories and songs. Mixed preference for health and agricultural materials. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Home, village, market, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Central Malay [pse], Col [liw], Javanese [jav], Komering [kge].

name: Tharu, Kochila
Language Development: Mother-tongue multilingual education introduced in one school. Literacy increasing. Taught as subject in primary schools. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Maithili [mai]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Kurux [kru].

name: Mbula
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Literacy is increasing. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, church. Used by all. Mixed attitudes, from positive to negative. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Karnai [bbv].

name: German
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Latin script,Fraktur variant [Latf], used until 1940. Runic script [Runr], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Used as language ofinstruction in all secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1466–2016.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra].

name: Seimat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%–90%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3, in 5 schools. Vernacular literature in use in the schools. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Community meetings, village court; Mixed use: Home, education, church. Used by all. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to negative. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Han
Language Development: Taught in bush schools as an elective to native and nonnative children.Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Kumam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in English [eng]. Taught as subject in somesecondary schools, as ‘Lwo’, sharing materials with Acholi [ach], Alur [alz], Jopadhola [adh],and Lango [laj]. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Ateso [teo].Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Lango [laj].

name: Gawwada
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 22%. Taught in primary schools in grades 1–4. Bibleportions: 2017–2020.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Also useBorana-Arsi-Guji Oromo [gax]. Also use Konso [kxc].

name: Mixtec, Mixtepec
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1974–2019.
Language Use: About 90% of the parents speak Mixtec with their children (2011 SIL). Home, friends, work. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Limbu
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Limbu (Kiranti, Sirijonga) script [Limb], dating from early 18th century.
Language Development: Many adult speakers completed 5 years of school, and have good proficiency in Nepali [npi]. Motivation for development is high among all. Literacy programs in progress to teach Sirijonga script (Salminen 2007). Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. Limbu is not replaced in any domain, though children now speak more Nepali than Limbu (UNESCO 2002). A main group in eastern Nepal. Home, religion; mixed use: friends, work, education. Some young people, all adults, especially older adults and elderly. Some use among children, adolescents, and young adults. Positive attitudes. Panthare dialect is dominant in size, prestige, and language development. People prefer their own dialect, but are not negative toward others. Many also use Nepali [npi], especially among youth and educated. Some also use Yakkha [ybh], especially women due to intermarriage.

name: Vame
Language Development: Plans for use in primary schools. Secondary pupils come from 4 different language groups (Wuzlam, Vame, Muyang and Mada). Older population largely illiterate; schoolchildren can read French and those who have been to Vame literacy classes can read Vame, also some Pelasla adults have learned Fulfulde in the church literacy classes. Many children do not go to school; parents do not always find education important. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Pelasla men almost always marry Wuzlam women; children grow bilingual in their own home. Home, village, church, public meetings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use French [fra], especially educated youth. Also use Wandala [mfi]. Also use Wuzlam [udl]. Used as L2 by Wuzlam [udl].

name: Karen, Brek
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used by Roman Catholics and Baptists.
Language Development: Dictionary. Bible portions: 1990–2018. Agency: Kayaw Literature and Culture Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use S’gaw Karen [ksw]. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Mokpwe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature may serve Wumboko [bqm], Bubia[bbx], and Isu [szv]. Dictionary. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes] (Atindogbé 2013). Most also use English[eng]. Also use Duala [dua] (Atindogbé 2013). Used as L2 by Bubia [bbx], Isubu [szv], Oroko[bdu].

name: Hdi
Language Development: 700 adult students each year in literacy program. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Many also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Many also use French [fra]. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Gvoko [ngs]. Also use Mafa [maf]. Used as L2 by Gvoko [ngs], Mafa [maf], Vemgo-Mabas [vem].

name: Bicolano, Central
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.Bible: 1915.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Alsouse Tagalog [tgl]. Second languages acquired through schooling, media, and travel. Used as L2 byInabaknon [abx], Katubung Agta [agk], Northern Sorsoganon [bks], Rinconada Bikol [bto], SouthernSorsoganon [srv].

name: Achinese
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], called Jawi. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Prefer reading in Indonesian [ind]. Taught as subject in some primaryschools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1997.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, Community, Work, Education. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind], with some youth shifting, mostly in thecities and for education.

name: Yong
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Northern Thai [nod]. Some urban-educated Yong speakers are speaking Northern Thai [nod] to their children (Tuwakham 2005). Also use Thai [tha].

name: Konjo, Coastal
Language Development: Literature. Texts.
Language Use: Youth increasingly use Indonesian [ind]. Some young people, all adults. A few also use Makasar [mak], who live in Makassar city. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Balangingi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], plans for future development using this script. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40%–45%. Most urban men are literate. Literature. Videos. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Chavacano [cbk]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Tausug [tsg]. Used as L2 by Tausug [tsg].

name: Mengisa
Language Development: No literacy program in place. Radio. Texts.
Language Use: Children losing L1 capability, even in the village. Much intermarriage with Eton [eto], Ewondo [ewo] and certain Mbam languages. Children highly bilingual. Home, with other Mengisa, markets. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. Most also use Eton [eto]. Most also use Ewondo [ewo]. Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Leti [leo]. Used as L2 by Leti [leo].

name: Masai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1991–2018.
Language Use: The Kore dialect now speak Somali [som] as L1. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Okiek [oki], Omotik [omt], Yaaku [muu].

name: Senoufo, Syenara
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2% in Supyire [spp], 11% in Bambara [bam] (2007 M. Coulibaly). Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio.
