Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bamanankan [bam]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Supyire Sénoufo [spp].

name: Bum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Most women and childrenlearn to read and write. L1 used informally in education. English medium of education.Literature. Radio. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Bum and Cameroon Pidgin [wes] used in health centers and with outsiders.Almost all domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes], in healthcenters and with outsiders. Also use Chung [cnq]. Also use English [eng], as language of publiceducation. Also use Kom [bkm]. Also use Nchane [ncr]. Also use Noone [nhu]. Used as L2 by Chung[cnq], Kom [bkm], Mbuk [bpc], Nchane [ncr], Noone [nhu].

name: Samoan
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1855–1970.

name: Lave
Writing: Khmer script [Khmr]. Lao script [Laoo]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Texts. Bible portions: 2007–2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lao [lao].

name: CHARu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio.Dictionary. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Being replaced by Vietnamese [vie] in many domains (Bradley 2007a). Alsouse Vietnamese [vie].

name: Gude
Language Development: Literacy program in progress. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Some also useEnglish [eng]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Nzanyi [nja]. Used as L2 by FaliMuchella [fli].

name: Swahili, Congo
Language Development: Taught in most primary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter in the southeast and central-east of the country. Bible: 1960–1997.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Alur [alz], Bali [bcp], Bangubangu [bnx], Beeke [bkf], Bemba [bem], Bembe [bmb], Bendi [bct], Bhele [bhy], Bila [bip], Bira [brf], Budu [buu], Buyu [byi], Chokwe [cjk], Enya [gey], Fuliiru [flr], Hema [nix], Holoholo [hoo], Hunde [hke], Kaiku [kkq], Kakwa [keo], Kango [kzy], Kanu [khx], Kaonde [kqn], Kiviila [job], Kobo [okc], Komo [kmw], Konzo [koo], Kusu [ksv], Kwami [ktf], Lamba [lam], Lega-Mwenga [lgm], Lega-Shabunda [lea], Lendu [led], Lengola [lej], Lese [les], Lika [lik], Lombi [lmi], Lombo [loo], Luba-Kasai [lua], Lugbara [lgg], Mangbetu [mdj], Mba [mfc], Mbo [zmw], Mbole [mdq], Mituku [zmq], Mvuba [mxh], Ndaka [ndk], Ndo [ndp], Ngiti [niy], Nyali [nlj], Nyanga [nyj], Nyindu [nyg], Ombo [oml], Shi [shr], Songe [sop], Songoora [sod], Talinga-Bwisi [tlj], Tembo [tbt], Vanuma [vau], Zimba [zmb], Zula [zla].

name: Varli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 32% for Gujarat (2001 census). Radio. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Gujarati [guj]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Achí, Rabinal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75% in Spanish[spa]. Literacy rate for L2 in Cubulco Achi is 11%, in Rabinal Achi is 25%–40%; literacy ratefor L1 in Cubulco Achi is 1%–5%, in Rabinal Achi is 15%–20%. Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar. Texts.Bible: 2019. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Fewer children learning it as L1. Also useSpanish [spa]. Up to 20% can use it to discuss more than common topics.

name: Efate, South
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1889–1930.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. All also use Bislama [bis]. Also use English[eng]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Eton [etn], Lelepa [lpa], Mele-Fila [mxe].

name: Finnish (Tornedalen)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–30%. Literature. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible portions: 1993–1995. Agency: Swedish Tornedalian Association.
Language Use: Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Shifted to Swedish [swe]. Also useFinnish [fin].

name: Tuvalu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: High. Taught in primary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1987–2016.
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Pangasinan
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1915–1983.
Language Use: Some acquiring it after childhood via Late Vernacular Acquisition.

name: Thangmi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 10%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Ethnic Thangmi outside Dolakha and Sindhupalchok no longer speak Thangmi. Religion; mixed use: Home, friends. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes. Negative attitudes, but changing to more neutral and positive.

name: Karamojong
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Radio. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng].Many also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Ik [ikx], Nyang’i [nyp], Soo [teu].

name: Biatah
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 45%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Awngi
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Radio. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh],limited usage, mostly in towns; among Northern Awngi, only known by males.

name: Pinyin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Used informally in education. Literature. Radio. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use English [eng]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Mungaka [mhk]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Kyrgyz
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in China. Cyrillic script [Cyrl],not used in Afghanistan. Latin script [Latn], used in Turkey.
Language Development: Taught in many primary and secondary schools. Newspapers. Radio. TV.Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1995–2004.
Language Use: L1 for 98% of Kyrgyz. The Ichkilik are a Kyrgyz-speaking people ofnon-Kyrgyz origin. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Balochi, Southern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Curriculum is developed for a pre-primary2-year multilingual education program that bridges children from Balochi to Urdu [urd] or Sindhi[snd], and English [eng] (2021 S. Zubair). Taught as subject in some primary and secondaryschools. Taught as subject in some tertiary schools. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT:1999.
Language Use: Most also use Urdu [urd]. Approximately 75%. Some also use Sindhi [snd].

name: Mamaindé
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 1979.
Language Use: Strong language use in 3 of the 4 villages. Some young people, all adults. All also use Portuguese [por], particularly the youth in the Cabixi village who use Portuguese as their L1 (Eberhard 2009).

name: Chakavian
Writing: Glagolitic script [Glag], used until 17th century. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Newspapers. Periodicals. TV. Grammar.
Language Use: Music, poetry. Some young people, all adults.

name: Uduk
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1963–1983.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Sudanese Arabic [apd] (Killian 2015). Also use Berta [wti] (Killian 2015). Also use Burun [bdi] (Killian 2015). Also use English [eng], especially the younger generation (Killian 2015). Also use Ganza [gza] (Killian 2015). Also use Jumjum [jum] (Killian 2015). Also use Komo [xom] (Killian 2015). Also use Mabaan [mfz] (Killian 2015). Also use Opo [lgn] (Killian 2015).

name: Chumburung
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 24%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Yeji can read Chumburung material with literacy help. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka].

name: Yamba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literature. Radio. Videos. NT: 1992–2011.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English [eng], as language of public education. A few also use French [fra]. A few also use Limbum [lmp]. Used as L2 by Limbum [lmp].

name: Kodava
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: More than 95% in Kannada [kan]. Literature.Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. L1 of Airi, Male-Kudiya, Meda, Kembatti, Kapal, Maringi, Heggade,Kavadi, Kolla, Thatta, Koleya, Koyava, Banna, Golla, Kanya, Ganiga, and Malaya. Home, community,religion. Most also use Kannada [kan]. Many also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal].Used as L2 by Kudiya [kfg].

name: Mandarin Chinese
Writing: Bopomofo script [Bopo], used since 1913, revised in 1920 and 1932, mainlyused in Taiwan. Braille script [Brai]. Han script, Simplified variant [Hans], used since 1956,official in Mainland China (1956) and Singapore (1969), also used elsewhere. Han script,Traditional variant [Hant], used since mid-19th century, official in Taiwan, also usedelsewhere. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Taught in allprimary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1874–1983.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Korean[kor], in predominantly Korean-speaking provinces. Also use Russian [rus]. Also use Vietnamese[vie].

name: Maxakalí
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 37%. Literacy rate in L2: 37%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1981.
Language Use: Used by all. Young population. Some also use Portuguese [por] (Crevels 2007).

name: Kibiri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature.
Language Use: Some of all ages. In Porome-speaking villages, Porome is used by all. In Kibiri-speaking villages, only the older generation uses Kibiri (Petterson 2019). Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo], with Kibiri-speaking young people shifting (Petterson 2019). Also use Kerewo [kxz], with Kibiri-speaking young people shifting (Petterson 2019).

name: Rakhine
Writing: Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], informal and non-standardized use.
Language Development: ‘The literary (written) languages of Rakhine and standard Burmese are largely identical’ (Leider 2008:453). Rakhine pronunciation is closer to the literary language than modern spoken Burmese. Some Rakhine spell words according to Rakhine usage, but most use standard Burmese [mya] for writing. Literature. Newspapers. Videos.
Language Use: Vigorous, but some shift toward Burmese [mya], especially in south Rakhine state. All except formal domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Rohingya [rhg], in Buthidaung and Maungdaw townships. Used as L2 by Anu-Khongso Chin [anl], Bawm Chin [bgr], Chak [ckh], Chakma [ccp], Eastern Khumi Chin [cek], Khumi Chin [cnk], Laitu Chin [clj], Mro-Khimi [cmr], Mru [mro], Rohingya [rhg], Sumtu Chin [csv].

name: Mündü
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2005.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Avokaya [avu]. Also use Baka [bdh]. Also use Zande [zne]. Used as L2 by Avokaya [avu], Baka [bdh].

name: Gun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 1923.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by DefiGbe [gbh], Eastern Xwla Gbe [gbx], Kotafon Gbe [kqk], Tofin Gbe [tfi].

name: Amuzgo (San Pedro Amuzgos)
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Venda
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Fairly low. Taught as subject in a few primary and secondary schools from grade 4. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Radio. Bible: 1936.
Language Use: The Lembaa are a Venda-speaking Jewish people claiming Falasha descent.

name: Kaba Deme
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 12%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Western Armenian
Language Development: Taught in some primary and secondary schools, as private educationavailable in some larger cities. Fully developed.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Only adults speak the Hemshin dialect. Also use Turkish[tur].

name: Gangte
Language Development: Literacy high among young people and lower among older people. Newspapers.Periodicals. Grammar. Bible: 1991–2010.
Language Use: Under pressure from Meitei [mni] (Van Driem 2007). Also use English [eng].Also use Meitei [mni].

name: Ho
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], used in Bihar. Latin script [Latn]. Oriya (Odia)script [Orya], used in Odisha. Telugu script [Telu]. Warang Citi script [Wara].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literacy programin progress. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Vigorous. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].Also use Odia [ory]. Also use Sadri [sck]. Also use Santhali [sat]. Used as L2 by Birhor [biy].

name: Turkmen
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in Afghanistan and Iran. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Turkmenistan, not used in Afghanistan. Latin script [Latn], official usage in Turkmenistan since 1991.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2017.
Language Use: Also use Russian [rus].

name: Digo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3.Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Alsouse Chiduruma [dug]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Chiduruma [dug].

name: Senoufo, Mamara
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15% (2013 SIL). Literacy rate in L2: 10% in French [fra], 15% in Bambara [bam] (2013 SIL). Since literacy began in 1998, everyone wants to be called just Mamara or Minyanka. Literacy has unified this group. Taught in some primary schools in early grades only. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Bamanankan [bam].

name: Dolpo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 10%. Literacy materials have been produced andare being tested. Non-formal classes are being planned (2010). Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Lhowa [loy]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Kaike[kzq].

name: Karen, Geba
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1870, used by Roman Catholics. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], used since 2002, used by Anglicans and Baptists.
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Grammar. NT: 2021. Agency: Geba Literature and Culture Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use S’gaw Karen [ksw], especially among Baptists and Anglicans. Also use Burmese [mya], especially among Catholics, Baptists, and Anglicans.

name: Khaling
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Nepali [npi]. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2011. Agency: Khaling Uplifting Society.
Language Use: Home, religion; mixed use: Friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Nepali [npi], but older women are less bilingual and may comprehend it minimally. Also use Kulung [kle] (Jacques et al 2012). Also use Lhomi [lhm]. Also use Nachiring [ncd] (Jacques et al 2012). Also use Sherpa [xsr] (Jacques et al 2012). Also use Thulung [tdh] (Jacques et al 2012).

name: Veps
Language Development: Literary language based on central dialect. Taught as subject in a few primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used by few children, mostly older adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Naga, Maram
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 60% (2003). Literacy rate in L2: 20% (2000) or 40%–50% (2003). All young people can read Latin script. Writing system does not indicate tone. Literacy among older people is lower. Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Home, village, religion. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni], especially men (more than women).

name: Basketo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Taught in primary schools in grades 1–3. NT:2014.

name: Lunda
Language Development: Literacy campaigns, agricultural extension services. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1962–2012.
Language Use: Home, community. Positive attitudes.

name: Ghayavi
Language Development: Most are literate. Literature. Videos. Texts. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Gapapaiwa [pwg]. Also use Wedau [wed].Used as L2 by Gapapaiwa [pwg].

name: Hawaiian
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. The Hawaiian medium educationsystem operates immersion schools from pre-K through grade 12. The College of Hawaiian Languageat the University of Hawaii provides courses and programs entirely in Hawaiian, offering 2Master’s degrees and a PhD. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1868–2012.
Language Use: Young speakers are being trained in immersion courses and also very oldspeakers exist, but relatively few adult and middle-aged speakers, which results in lack ofcommunication situations for active use. All domains. Some of all ages. 500 older adults; 1,000ages up to 15; 350 ages 15 to 25 (1997 R. Henze). Also use English [eng]. Also use Hawaii Pidgin[hwc].

name: Pashto, Southern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in print. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles.
Language Development: Pashto is one of two national languages taught in schools. Low literacy rate, especially in non-urban locations and among women. Taught in all primary and secondary schools in predominantly Pashto-speaking areas; taught as subject in primary schools in some other regions. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2011–2019.
Language Use: Afghan government has worked since 1930s to standardize and publicize it. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Dari [prs], especially those who are educated or have business in Dari-speaking provinces. A few also use Urdu [urd].

name: Baka (Cameroon)
Writing: Latin script [Latn], not used in Gabon.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5% in French [fra]. Insmall, dispersed villages, which makes literacy difficult. Taught in one primary school.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: The Baka, being pygmies, are held in low esteem by the Bantus. East Regionpopulation increase among all language groups and Baka sedentism increase bilingualism. Mostdomains, including home, education, and forest. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also useFrench [fra], especially with outsiders and also in schools. Some also use Koonzime [ozm]. Somealso use Njyem [njy]. A few also use Makaa [mcp].

name: Slovenian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1584–2017.
Language Use: Many also use Croatian [hrv] (European Commission 2006). Many also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Many also use Standard German [deu] (European Commission 2006).

name: Romani, Balkan
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Bulgaria. Greek script [Grek], used in Greece. Latin script [Latn], used in Serbia.
Language Development: Printed or pre-recorded Romani language materials may not be understandable outside the country (or context of surrounding languages) in which they were produced. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2015.

name: Brunei
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used in Bandar Seri Begawan and surrounding areas, and by young people and educated older people from different language or dialect backgrounds. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Used as L2 by Belait [beg], Brunei Bisaya [bsb], Central Melanau [mel].

name: Numanggang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 35%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%–50% in Tok Pisin [tpi] or Kâte [kmg]. Literature. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. Tok Pisin [tpi] used more in towns. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Kâte [kmg], especially the older generation. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Nabak [naf]. Also use Nakame [nib].

name: Tat, Muslim
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Russia. Latin script [Latn], official usage in Azerbaijan.
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Community. Some young people, all adults, few children. Positive attitudes. Also use North Azerbaijani [azj], especially the Lahyj, as a literary language.

name: Tarifit
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng].
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religious settings, Special cultural events. Used by all. Many also use Moroccan Arabic [ary]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Adi (Galo)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. More men can read than women but more girls andwomen are learning. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Assamese [asm]. Most also useHindi [hin], especially with the military. Many also use English [eng], especially the educatedand the young.

name: Sorbian, Upper
Language Development: Taught in a few primary and secondary schools. Newspapers. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1728–1857.
Language Use: Upper Sorbian and Lower Sorbian are 2 standard languages. Authorized inlocal government and schools. Increasing literature production. Now accepted as a minoritylanguage. 40,000–45,000 others have some knowledge of it. Some young people, all adults. Mostlyolder adults. Most monolinguals are very young (Stephens 1976). Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Nehan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Used by all. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Shwai
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Yambeta
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in a few primary schools. Literature. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Dimbong [dii], Tuotomb [ttf].

name: Samogitian
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Radio. NT: 1816–1904.
Language Use: Also use Lithuanian [lit].

name: Yoruba
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], used since 1848, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 35%. Taught as subject in most primary and secondary schools in grades 1–9. Standard or Common/Koine Yoruba (as taught in Nigerian schools) is largely based on the Oyo dialect (Courtenay 1968). Taught in a few primary schools through grade 3. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1900–2005.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Aduge [adu], Àhàn [ahn], Akpes [ibe], Akuku [ayk], Ayere [aye], Bokobaru [bus], Ebira [igb], Idesa [ids], Ikhin-Aokho [ikh], Iyive [uiv], Oloma [olm], Ukaan [kcf].

name: Chuvash
Language Development: Taught in some primary schools, only those in rural areas, in the Chuvashiarepublic only. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Only a few children are likely to become active users (Salminen 1999). Someyoung people, all adults. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Agta, Dupaninan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 1%. Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2001.
Language Use: The language is no longer learned by the children in 5 of the 35 DupaninanAgta communities (Robinson, L. 2011). Some young people, all adults. All also use Ilocano [ilo](Robinson, L. 2011).

name: Ewondo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught in a few primary schools in Yaoundé;taught as subject in most other schools (2021 SIL). Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible:1962–2012.
Language Use: Most also use Eton [eto]. Most also use French [fra]. Many also use Bulu[bjl]. Some also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Bulu [bum], Eton [eto], Fang [fan],Gbaya-Mbodomo [gmm], Gyele [gyi], Kako [kkj], Koonzime [ozm], Mengisa [mct], Mpumpong [mgg],Nubaca [baf], Nulibie [ekm], Numala [mmu], Tunen [tvu], Yangben [yav].

name: Godié
Language Development: Radio. TV. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Makyan Naga
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya], especially youth. Also use Lainong Naga [lzn], especially the older generation.

name: Enxet
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Most also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug] (Crevels 2012). Also use Spanish[spa]. Used as L2 by Sanapaná [spn].

name: Arop-Lukep
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature.NT: 2013–2022.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Slavomolisano
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Efforts made to revive Slavomolisano literature use. For many bilingual speakers, it is still the dominant language in everyday use (2012 W. Breu). Adults only. Most children have not spoken Slavomolisano since 1990 (2012 W. Breu). Most shifting to Italian [ita].

name: Swati
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: High. Taught in most primary and secondary schools through grade 4 as the language of instruction and as subject thereafter. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Grammar. Bible: 1996.

name: Waris
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Daonda [dnd].

name: Fulfulde, Western Niger
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar.NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some who move into the city speak Zarma [dje]. All domains. Usedby all. Most also use Zarma [dje].

name: Suku
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. There is much motivation to see literacy efforts increased, but the orthography may need revision (2023 J. Mushunganya). Radio. Videos. Bible portions: 1973.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Most also use Kituba [ktu]. Some also use Lingala [lin], especially the young. A few also use Mbala [mdp], in the border areas. A few also use Sonde [shc], in the border areas. A few also use Yaka [yaf], in the border areas. Used as L2 by Lonzo [lnz], Mbala [mdp].

name: Malay, Kupang
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Helong [heg], Lole [llg], Termanu [twu], Tii [txq].

name: Secoya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 85%. Literacy rate in L2: 45% in Spanish [spa]. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1990–2012.
Language Use: Once used as LWC by the Spanish colonial administration. All: Home, community, religion; Some: education, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Cofán [con].

name: Filipino
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Tagalog script [Tglg], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools from grade 3; taught withEnglish [eng] as a language of instruction. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1905.
Language Use: Despite being constitutionally-mandated as the Philippine nationallanguage, Filipino is only used as a tertiary language in the Philippine public sphere (Demetrioand Liwanag 2014).

name: Dinka, Southeastern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Some literacy materials produced. Taught assubject in some primary schools through grade 3. The Ministry of Education, supported by donors,has started a pilot project to develop materials for teaching Dinka (all 4 varieties together)as a subject and as language of instruction up to grade 3 in some schools. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1940.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Nuer [nus].

name: Belarusian
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], developed in the 16th century. Braillescript [Brai], no longer in use. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], official usage. Latin script [Latn],official usage 1941–1944, modern occasional usage.
Language Development: Few schools remain in which Belarusian is used as a language ofinstruction. Taught in a few primary and secondary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible:1973–2017.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Russian [rus].

name: Bamukumbit
Language Development: Basic literacy materials. Radio. Texts. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Chopechop [bbq]. Alsouse Chufie’ [bfj]. Also use English [eng], especially those educated beyond primary level.

name: Kayapó
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. 400 readers, 100 can write. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, including initial education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use Portuguese [por]. Used as L2 by Panará [kre].

name: Fulfulde, Borgu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Among Fulfulde-speaking Gando people there areover 2,000 literates. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Home, villages, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French[fra], to an extent varying with education level. Also use Yom [pil]. Used as L2 by Mokole[mkl].

name: Kako
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High rate in French [fra]. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Used fairly widely. Home, church, some schools. Used by all. Most also use French [fra], particularly for official purposes and in public media in the East Region. Some also use Ewondo [ewo], the Beti variety of Ewondo which is used in some churches and in the market. A few also use Gbaya-Mbodomo [gmm]. Used as L2 by Kwakum [kwu], Mpiemo [mcx], Northwest Gbaya [gya].

name: Yamdena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Taught as subject inprimary and secondary schools. Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous except for some northern villages. Strong users mostly over 30years old. All domains, very limited use in religion. Some young people, all adults. Also useAmbonese Malay [abs]. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Ngäbere
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1977–2013.
Language Use: Also use Jamaican English Creole [jam]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nias
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Bible: 1911.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community; Mixed use: Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind], but with limited proficiency.

name: Maithili
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva], primary usage. Kaithi script [Kthi], used until the turn of the 20th century. Newa script [Newa], no longer in use, historic usage. Tirhuta script [Tirh], used until the turn of the 20th century.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. If they can read Nepali [npi] or Hindi [hin], they can read Maithili. The educated read Hindi, Nepali, or English books for pleasure. Some literacy work in India. Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Bihar state. Fully developed. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Used by Brahmin and other high caste or educated Hindus, who influence the culture and language, and other castes. There is a Maithili Academy. Linguistics and literature taught at Patna University and at L. N. Mithila University in Darbhanga. Home, community. Mixed attitudes. Influenced by caste, ranging from superiority to resentment; non-Brahmin speech viewed as inferior. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use Bhojpuri [bho]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Bajjika [vjk].

name: Chokwe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 30%. Taught as subject in primary schools ingrades 1–6 in the eastern provinces. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible:1970–1990.
Language Use: Home, church, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also usePortuguese [por].

name: Nugunu (Cameroon)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra], particularly for official functions and public media in the Centre Region. Used as L2 by Bafia [ksf], Nubaca [baf], Yangben [yav].

name: Japanese
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Han, Hiragana, and Katakana scripts [Jpan], primaryusage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1883–2018.

name: Naga, Khezha
Language Development: Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Also use Angami Naga [njm]. Also use English [eng].

name: Bru, Eastern
Writing: Lao script [Laoo], used in Laos. Latin script [Latn], used in Vietnam. Thaiscript [Thai].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio.Dictionary. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Lao [lao]. Used as L2 by Arem [aem], UpperTa’oih [tth].

name: (New) Greek
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Ukraine. Greekscript [Grek], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible:1840–1994.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). A few also useFrench [fra] (European Commission 2006). A few also use Standard German [deu] (EuropeanCommission 2006).

name: Haida, Northern
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1891–1899.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Itneg, Binongan
Language Development: Literature. Bible portions: 1967.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also useFilipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Cogui
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature. Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sanka [mbp]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Latgalian
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1937.
Language Use: Also use Russian [rus]. Also use Standard Latvian [lvs].

name: Anyin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Used as L2 by Abure [abu],Attié [ati], Beti [eot], Mbato [gwa].

name: Kom (Cameroon)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. First Kom alphabetdeveloped by German missionaries in 1880s. 5% can write Kom. Taught in some primary schools inearly grades only. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2004. Agency: Kom LanguageDevelopment Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Oral use in local administration, church, commerce,written use in church, letters. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Cameroon Pidgin[wes]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Lamnsoʼ [lns]. A few also use Babanki [bbk]. Afew also use Bum [bmv]. A few also use Chung [cnq]. A few also use French [fra]. A few also useMmen [bfm]. A few also use Oku [oku]. Used as L2 by Aghem [agq], Babanki [bbk], Bum [bmv], Chung[cnq], Kemedzung [dmo], Laimbue [lmx], Mmen [bfm], Noone [nhu].

name: Karang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%–20%. Literacy rates declined in recent years (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Children use the language less in urban centers. Positive attitudes. Some also use French [fra]. Less bilingualism in French due to decline in education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Sui
LITERACY_L2: 78% in any language for Shui nationality (2000 census).
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], used by folk singers aged 40–60.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 78% in any language for Shui nationality (2000 census). Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially in writing. Bilingualism is low in the main areas. Used as L2 by Bouyei [pcc].

name: Sakam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 10% in Kutong, and growing. Literature. Bible portions: 2012.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Tayatuk [smc]. Also use Wantoat [wnc]. Also use Yopno [yut]. Used as L2 by Tayatuk [smc], Wantoat [wnc], Yopno [yut].

name: Karbi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 54% in Assam (2001 census). Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1952.
Language Use: Other groups speak Karbi as L1, including some Dimasa. Also use Assamese [asm], among all age groups. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Sakachep [sch].

name: Nzima
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Bible: 1999.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka]. Used as L2 by Ahanta [aha], Jwira-Pepesa [jwi].

name: Deg
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka]. Also use English [eng].

name: Sambalpuri
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].

name: Garhwali
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 72% for Uttarakhand (2001 census). Older women lackliteracy. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Texts. NT: 1827–1994.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English[eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], in the market, and with more fluency among men, the educated, andyouth. Used as L2 by Gujari [gju], Jad [jda], Rongpo [rnp].

name: Tooro
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some secondary schools, as Runyakitaara, sharing materials with Chiga [cgg], Nyankore [nyn], and Nyoro [nyo]. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1912.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Nyoro [nyo]. Used as L2 by Amba [rwm], Konzo [koo], Nyoro [nyo], Talinga-Bwisi [tlj].

name: Anii
Language Development: Literacy efforts since 1980. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use French[fra]. Also use Southern Nago [nqg]. Also use Tem [kdh]. Varies with education level.

name: Panchpargania
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], no longer in use. Devanagari script [Deva]. Kaithi script [Kthi], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Cakchiquel, Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–39%. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2003. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many parents are choosing to speak Spanish[spa] in the home to their children so that they start school with Spanish as a strong firstlanguage (2020 J. Maxwell). Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by K’iche’ [quc].

name: Dimasa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% in Assam (2001 census). Literature. Dictionary.NT: 2005.
Language Use: Largely assimilated into Bengali [ben] and Assamese [asm] communities (VanDriem 2007). Some also use Assamese [asm], especially in Karbi Anglong and Nagaon districts(Longmailai 2012). Some also use Bengali [ben], especially in Cachar plains (Longmailai 2012).Some also use Nagamese [nag], especially in Nagaland with speakers of other languages(Longmailai 2012). Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Sakachep [sch].

name: Dogri (specific)
Writing: Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], no longer in use. Devanagari script[Deva]. Dogra script [Dogr], no longer in use. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longerin use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 18%–19%. Young people are becoming literate in Dogri.Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Jammu andKashmir state. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 1826–2017.
Language Use: Taught in government schools and as a subject in university. All domains.Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Eastern Punjabi [pan], in shops. Also use English[eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], in school and shops; many have only rudimentary knowledge of it.Also use Urdu [urd], especially middle-aged and older speakers. Used as L2 by Gujari [gju], Khah[hkh].

name: Giziga, South
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Grammar. Bible:2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. All also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Many also useFrench [fra]. A few also use Mundang [mua]. Used as L2 by Gavar [gou], Gidar [gid],Mazagway-Hidi [dkx], Mofu-Gudur [mif], Mundang [mua], Musgu [mug].

name: Quechua, Napo Lowland
Language Development: Orthography differs from that used in Ecuador. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1972–1988.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Aushiri [avs].

name: Sangisari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 89%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Positive attitudes. Also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Maonan
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant [Hant]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 93% (2000 census, Manon nationality). Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: 75% use it at home; 62% use it outside the home; 72% speak it to their children (GXLOUS 2005). Positive attitudes. Most also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], or other local languages (GXLOUS 2005).

name: Tarahumara, Lowland
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Komo (Democratic Republic of Congo)
LITERACY_L2: 50% older men (born before 1970), 30% younger men, less than 10% women.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 50% older men (born before 1970), 30% younger men, less than 10% women. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2021.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All ages except in population centers where L1 is Congo Swahili [swc], then it is 7 and older for boys. A few also use Lingala [lin], especially those around Kisangani. Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Used as L2 by Lengola [lej].

name: Wagdi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 2000–2023.
Language Use: A regional language in Vagad Desh. Positive attitudes. Some also use Hindi [hin], with proficiency adequate for market.

name: Meru
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible: 1964–2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Gichuka [cuh], Kiembu [ebu], Kitharaka [thk], Mwimbi-Muthambi [mws].

name: Marik
Language Development: Literature. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Home, community. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used asL2 by Uyajitaya [duk].

name: Waorani
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1992–2009.
Language Use: The language is considered to be endangered due to emergingHuaorani-Quichua bilingualism brought about by mixed marriages and bilingual education programstaught by Quichua teachers who do not speak Huaorani (Crevels 2007). Some of all ages. A fewalso use Napo Quichua [qvo]. A few also use Northern Pastaza Quichua [qvz]. A few also use Shuar[jiv]. A few also use Tena Lowland Quichua [quw], mostly those who are married to Quichua andtheir children. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Cherokee
LITERACY_L1: 15%–20% can read, 5% can write (1986 Cherokee HeritageCenter).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20% can read, 5% can write (1986 Cherokee HeritageCenter). Taught in primary schools. The Cherokee Immersion School (Tsalagi Tsunadeloquasdi),founded by the Cherokee Nation in 2001, teaches children from preschool through grade 6. Taughtas subject in secondary schools at Sequoyah High School in Tahlequah, Oklahoma. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. NT: 1850–1951. Cherokee is regularly taught at University of Oklahoma andNortheast Oklahoma University as well as adult language classes at Cherokee Nation and UnitedKeetoowah Band tribal headquarters and communities. Online language classes are offered toCherokee Nation citizens as are employee immersion programs and an adult immersion program.United Keetoowah Band of Cherokee Indians offer language revitalization initiatives and classesthrough their Education Center and Cherokee introductory language initiatives (2019 S. Young).
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Kuku
Language Development: Many Christian congregations use English [eng] scriptures, some use Bari [bfa] or Luganda [lug] scriptures, a few use Kiswahili [swh]. Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Some youth acquire Kuku later as young adults (2018 D. Eberhard). Home, church, music. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Swahili [swh]. Some also use Ganda [lug]. Some also use Ma’di [mhi]. A few also use Acholi [ach]. A few also use Aringa [luc]. A few also use Lugbara [lgg]. A few also use Nubi [kcn]. Used as L2 by Kakwa [keo].

name: Purari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught in someprimary schools through grade 6. Most early education (prep – grade 2) is in community-basedvernacular schools. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1920.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Motu [meu]. Also use TokPisin [tpi].

name: Tainae
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Carlson 1988).

name: Blaan, Koronadal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 35% (2007 SIL). Literacy rate in L2: 35% (2007 SIL).Ongoing non-formal literacy teaching (2007 SIL). Literature. Radio. Videos. Texts. NT: 1995.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use Kalagan[kqe]. Also use Tboli [tbl].

name: Antigua and Barbuda Creole English
Language Development: Oral materials available. Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Negative attitudes.

name: Pidgin, Nigerian
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Increasing in importance and use. A creole with native speakers; also a pidgin between Africans and Europeans, and Africans from different languages. All domains. Used as L2 by Abanglekuo [bzy], Abanyom [abm], Akuku [ayk], Bete-Bendi [btt], Bokyi [bky], Cakfem-Mushere [cky], Dadiya [dbd], Dza [jen], Efutop [ofu], Ekajuk [eka], Esan [ish], Gbagyi [gbr], Iceve-Maci [bec], Idesa [ids], Ihievbe [ihi], Ikhin-Aokho [ikh], Kibaku [ckl], Legbo [agb], Lenyima [ldg], Nde-Nsele-Nta [ndd], Ndoe [nbb], Nikyob-Nindem [kdp], Nkem-Nkum [isi], Nnam [nbp], Ogbah [ogc], Oloma [olm], Olulumo-Ikom [iko], Ron [cla], Utugwang-Irungene-Afrike [afe].

name: Karen, Manumanaw
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used by Roman Catholics. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], used since 2011.
Language Development: Grammar. Agencies: Kayah Literature and Culture Committee; Kayah-Manu Literature and Culture Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use S’gaw Karen [ksw]. Also use Burmese [mya]. Used as L2 by Yintale [kvy].

name: Kurukh
LITERACY_L1: 62% Oraon in Chhattisgarh, 25% in Bihar (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 62% Oraon in Chhattisgarh, 25% in Bihar (2001 census). Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2000.
Language Use: While there are written materials, the language is losing speakers (mostly due to urbanization). Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck]. Used as L2 by Kodaku [ksz].

name: Nateni
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 2018. Agency: Commission Nationale de Linguistique Naténi.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baatonum [bba]. Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Waama [wwa].

name: Tem
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used since 2004. Braille script[Brai], used since 1973. Latin script [Latn], used since the 1970s, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, market, work. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use French [fra]. Also use Standard Arabic [arb], at mosque. Used as L2 byAkaselem [aks], Anii [blo], Bago-Kusuntu [bqg], Ginyanga [ayg], Igo [ahl], Kabiyè [kbp], Kpessi[kef], Lama [las], Lukpa [dop], Northern Nago [xkb], Ntcham [bud].

name: Moundadan Chetty
Writing: Malayalam script [Mlym], limited usage. Tamil script [Taml], primary usage.
Language Development: Radio. TV. NT: 2018. Agency: Moundadan Chetties Association.
Language Use: Home, community, cultural ceremonies. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Mostalso use Malayalam [mal]. Most also use Tamil [tam].

name: Tolaki
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Taught as subject in a few secondary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous in many villages. Some children are not proficient in Tolaki. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. A few also use Bugis [bug]. Used as L2 by Kodeoha [vko], Muna [mnb], Waru [wru], Wawonii [wow].

name: Bolinao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Over 90%. Literacy rate in L2: Over 90% in Filipino [fil], 40% in English [eng]. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2012. Agency: Bolinao Historical Society.
Language Use: Some of all ages, especially in the islands. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], acquired in school. Also use Filipino [fil], with some shifting, acquired through intermarriage and community relations and used at home, school, and in the community. Used as L2 by Cebuano [ceb], Ilocano [ilo].

name: Gamit
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 53% (2001 census). Most have high school or collegeeducation. Radio. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Katcha-Kadugli-Miri
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials used in Katcha, Kadugli, and Miri. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Takia
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. People usually write in Tok Pisin [tpi] or English [eng]. Literature. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng] (Ross 2009). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially children, who often master it before Takia, and all others except older women. Used as L2 by Bargam [mlp], Matukar Panau [mjk].

name: Garifuna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: All domains. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. A few also use English[eng]. Also use Spanish [spa], with some shifting in some villages.

name: Mato
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Over 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 41%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in 3 schools. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). All domains, except church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Nukna [klt], Pano [mqz].

name: Manobo, Ata
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–30%. Literature.Dictionary. NT: 2000.

name: Izere
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Home, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Most also use Hausa [hau].Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Ibaas [cen]. Used as L2 by Ibaas [cen], Iguta [nar],Tunzuii [dza].

name: Buamu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Active literacy program.Literature. Radio. NT: 2012.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Walloon
Language Development: Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1934.
Language Use: Many native authors. Used in theaters. An indigenous language recognized in Belgium since 1990. Usage began decreasing in the 20th century, but Walloon is increasingly recognized as valuable for informal purposes. More rural use than urban. Not used in schools. Some young people, all adults. Most also use French [fra], particularly many of the youth who are using it as their L1.

name: Maay
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used by Maay Erte dialect.
Language Development: Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2006–2007.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Boon [bnl], Dabarre [dbr], Garre [gex], Jiiddu [jii], Mushungulu [xma], Tunni [tqq].

name: Tlapanec, Malinaltepec
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 1994–2023.
Language Use: Homes, local government, community.

name: Roglai, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1966–1973.
Language Use: Potentially shifting to Vietnamese [vie] (Bradley 2007a). Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Rade
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1997–2015.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie]. Used as L2 by Bih [ibh].

name: Bambili-Bambui
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cameroon Pidgin[wes], with speakers of other languages. Also use English [eng], in school. Also use French[fra], in school.

name: Akan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–10%. Taught inprimary and secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 1871–1964.
Language Use: A few also use Adamorobe Sign Language [ads] (Nyst 2007). Also use English[eng]. Used as L2 by Abron [abr], Adamorobe Sign Language [ads], Adele [ade], Ahanta [aha],Animere [anf], Anyin [any], Awutu [afu], Chala [cll], Cherepon [cpn], Chumburung [ncu], Deg[mzw], Delo [ntr], Dwang [nnu], Esahie [sfw], Gikyode [acd], Gua [gwx], Konkomba [xon], Kplang[kph], Krache [kye], Larteh [lar], Lelemi [lef], Ligbi [lig], Nafaanra [nfr], Nchumbulu [nlu],Nkami [nkq], Nkonya [nko], Nzema [nzi], Sekpele [lip], Tumulung Sisaala [sil], Tuwuli [bov],Wasa [wss].

name: Northern Sami
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught in a few primary and secondary schools. Bible: 1895.
Language Use: In central Finnmark Province, where North Saami has an official status, many children learn the language and are likely to continue to use it in adulthood (Salminen 2007). Used by all. All also use Norwegian [nor] (Aikio and Ylikoski 2022).

name: Tigak
Language Development: Taught in primary schools in early grades only. Grammar. Bible portions: 1912–2019.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Jenkins 2005). Some also use Kuanua [ksd], especially older adults (Jenkins 2005). Also use English [eng] (Jenkins 2005). Also use Kara [leu] (Jenkins 2005).

name: Lihir
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 95%. Literature.
Language Use: Home, school, church, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Hermer 2013).

name: Bahnar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio.Dictionary. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Mongolian, Peripheral
Writing: Mongolian script [Mong]. Phags-pa script [Phag], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 71%. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Grammar. NT: 1952–2003.
Language Use: Chinese living in the area can also speak it. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Kazakh [kaz]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Uyghur [uig]. Used as L2 by China Buriat [bxu], Daur [dta], Evenki [evn], Kalmyk-Oirat [xal], Oroqen [orh], Tuvan [tyv].

name: Tanana, Lower
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to English [eng].

name: Sisaala, Tumulung
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Konni [kma], Paasaal [sig].

name: Dhimal
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 39% (1991 census). Literature. Periodicals. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2017. Agency: Dhimal Ethnic Development Centre.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work. Some young people, all adults.Adolescents and older. Some use among children. Positive attitudes. Also use Hindi [hin]. Alsouse Nepali [npi]. Also use Rajbanshi [rjs].

name: Sambal, Botolan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 100%. Literacy rate in L2: 100%. All can read and write. Taught in most primary schools in grades 1–3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Local administration, commerce, religion, letters. Used by all. Also use Abellen Ayta [abp].

name: Enlhet
Language Development: Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible: 1995–2016.
Language Use: Many also use Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2012). Some also use ParaguayanGuaraní [gug] (Crevels 2012). Also use Nivaclé [cag]. Used as L2 by Sanapaná [spn].

name: Hano
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% at a very basic level. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1930–2020.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use Apma [app]. Used as L2 by Apma [app].

name: Bade
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also useAdamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Also use Hausa [hau], with some youth shifting to Hausa. Also use MangaKanuri [kby].

name: Papel
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Radio. Videos. NT: 1996. Agency: Instituto de Tradução e Alfabetização (ITA).
Language Use: Home, friends, religion, work. Some of all ages. The shift towards Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov] is growing, particularly among children of mixed marriages, and those from families who moved to the capital of Bissau for education and economic opportunity (2022 I. Gruitibna). Positive attitudes. All also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language of interethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Most also use Portuguese [por], as the language of education and communication with foreigners. A few also use Balanta [ble]. Used as L2 by Mankanya [knf].

name: Bislama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 35%. Literacy rate in L2: Low. Proposed vernaculareducation (2011). Taught in some primary schools in grades 1–3. The national language policy andexpectation is that teachers are supposed to use the Bislama curriculum but teach all subjectmatter in the early grades in the local language.. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio.TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1998.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use French [fra].

name: Tok Pisin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40%–45%. Taught in some primary schools in early grades only, used mostly in urban areas and other mixed cultural and linguistic communities. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1989.
Language Use: L1 of some people in mixed urban areas. Used between speakers of different languages. Most frequently used language in Parliament and commerce. Where it is L1, it is passed on to children by parents. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Cheyenne
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 100% in English [eng].Taught in Dull Knife Memorial College and at reservation schools in Montana (2018 W. Leman).Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1902–2007. Summer camps for children in Montanawhere Cheyenne taught by fluent speakers (2018 W. Leman).
Language Use: Conversation and prayer. Older adults only. Middle-aged or older. Allshifted to English [eng].

name: Ruli
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Bible portions: 2014–2023. Agency: Ruruuli-Runyara Language Association Committee.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Ganda [lug]. Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Nyoro [nyo].

name: Aghem
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Used in primary and secondary educationinformally. Mostly women and children want to learn to read and write. Literature. Radio.Grammar. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, church, market, clinic. Used by all. Most also use CameroonPidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng]. A few also use Kom [bkm]. Also use Isu [isu]. Alsouse Weh [weh]. Used as L2 by Akum [aku], Esimbi [ags], Isu [isu], Laimbue [lmx].

name: Mazatec, Jalapa De Díaz
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Literature. Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Colorado
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Spanish [spa].Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1980–2012.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2007).

name: Maléku Jaíka
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. Youth understand but do not speak it. Shifting to Spanish[spa].

name: Frisian, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Taught in some primary and secondary schools,alongside Dutch [nld], in Friesland. Taught as subject in secondary schools. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1943–1978.
Language Use: Over 70% of those in Friesland still speak Frisian. Positive attitudes.Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Páez
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 75% (2005 Departamento Administrativo Nacional de Estadística). Some attempts, mainly literacy courses, have been made to promote the language. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1980–2014.
Language Use: Many pass the language on, but some prefer to have children use only Spanish [spa] (Crevels 2007). Religious services, commerce. Most also use Spanish [spa], the predominant language of instruction in schools.

name: Koonzime
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. 8,000 can read it, 150 can write it. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1998–2003.
Language Use: Mostly in traditional occupations such as agriculture, fishing and hunting. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Ewondo [ewo]. A few also use Baka [bdh]. Used as L2 by Baka [bkc], Kol [biw], Kwakum [kwu].

name: Arabic (Sudanese)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1978.
Language Use: All domains except written. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 byAcheron [acz], Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], Afitti [aft], Aka [soh], Andaandi [dgl], Baygo [byg],Bedawiyet [bej], Dagik [dec], Dair [drb], Dar Fur Daju [daj], Dilling [dil], El Hugeirat [elh],Fur [fvr], Gaam [tbi], Ghulfan [ghl], Gula [kcm], Gule [gly], Heiban [hbn], Kadaru [kdu], Kanga[kcp], Karko [kko], Katcha-Kadugli-Miri [xtc], Keiga [kec], Kelo [xel], Koalib [kib], Krongo[kgo], Laro [lro], Logol [lof], Logorik [liu], Lumun [lmd], Masalit [mls], Midob [mei], Molo[zmo], Nding [eli], Nobiin [fia], Otoro [otr], Shwai [shw], Talodi [tlo], Tese [keg], Tima[tms], Torona [tqr], Tulishi [tey], Uduk [udu], Wali [wll], Western Sudanic Arabic [shu], Yulu[yul], Zaghawa [zag].

name: Isu (Menchum Division)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng],as language of public education. Also use Aghem [agq]. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also useWeh [weh]. Used as L2 by Aghem [agq], Weh [weh].

name: Denya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Used informally ineducation. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Home, church, market, clinic. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng]. A few also use Ejagham [etu]. A few alsouse Kenyang [ken]. Used as L2 by Ambele [ael], Ejagham [etu], Iceve-Maci [bec], Kendem [kvm],Kenyang [ken].

name: Tarahumara, Central
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. 5,000 readers, 1,000 can write. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1972.
Language Use: Parents pass the language on to children in rural areas. Some older Spanish [spa] speakers who live there speak Tarahumara for work or trade. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sherpa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 8%–9%. The Mountain Institute and the Curriculum Development Centre have published some primary education materials. Lack of language development is source of embarrassment for some. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: In villages vigorous but not in urban areas where there is some shift towards Nepali [npi]. Mixed use: Home, friends, religion, work, education. Some young people, all adults. Older adults and elderly. Some use among children, adolescents, and young adults. Positive attitudes. In schools children are teased if they use Sherpa. In Kathmandu parents use Nepali [npi] with school-age children. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Korean [kor]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Also use Standard German [deu]. Used as L2 by Jirel [jul], Khaling [klr], Tibetan [bod].

name: Dirasha
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used since 2007, used in Church literature. Latinscript [Latn], official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Less than 10%. Church-based literacy classes startedin 2006. Taught in some primary schools in grades 1–4. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2007–2013.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Alsouse Eastern Oromo [hae]. Also use Konso [kxc]. Also use Mositacha [dox]. Used as L2 by Mositacha[dox].

name: Sateré-Mawé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 12%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1986.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por], though use varies greatly depending on the area.

name: Bana
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Some also use French [fra], as languageof public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub].

name: Gungu
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 2017. Agency: Lugungu Language Committee.
Language Use: Home, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Nyoro [nyo]. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Alur [alz].

name: Bari
Language Development: Taught in some primary schools through grade 3; the Ministry of Education,supported by donors, has started a pilot project to develop the materials for teaching Bari inschools. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1979.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Kakwa [keo],Keliko [kbo], Ma’di [mhi], Mandari [mqu], Olu’bo [lul].

name: Balangao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 85%. Literature. Texts. NT:1982.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also useEnglish [eng]. Many also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Ilocano is also a languageof wider communication but not use much in literacy by the Balangao population (2022 J.Feenstra).

name: Nyole
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2016. Agency: Lunyole Language Association.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, work, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Ganda [lug], especially in church, but with low proficiency.

name: Hmong Daw
Writing: Lao script [Laoo]. Latin script [Latn], used since 1953, primary usage. Miao (Pollard) script [Plrd], no longer in use, used in China. Pahawh Hmong script [Hmng], used since 1959. Thai script [Thai], used in Thailand.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 42% in Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1997–2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Faiwol
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–40%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%–40%. Literature. NT:1995.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Ninggerum [nxr], Setaman [stm],Tifal [tif].

name: K’iche’
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–35%. 40,000 readers, 20,000 can write in K’iche’. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1995. Agency: Academy of Mayan Languages.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, interpreters required in courts, some bilingual schools, oral use in religious services. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Spanish [spa]. Some also use Kaqchikel [cak]. A few also use Mam [mam]. A few also use Qꞌeqchiꞌ [kek]. A few also use Tz’utujil [tzj].

name: Kiwai, Northeast
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1987–2023.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], increasing among younger generations and those who have travelled for work. A few also use Hiri Motu [hmo], mostly spoken by the elderly generation.

name: Aruop
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Mol [alx].

name: Jirel
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–30% adults, 60% younger people (1991 census).People literate in Nepali [npi] can read Jirel. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1992.
Language Use: Home, friends. Some young people, all adults. Also use Eastern Tamang[taj]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Also use Sherpa [xsr]. Also use Sunwar [suz].

name: Swedish
Writing: Braille script [Brai], used since 1917. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1541–1999.
Language Use: Most also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Some also use French [fra] (European Commission 2006). Some also use Standard German [deu] (European Commission 2006).

name: Saya
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2013.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Used as L2 by Juu [juu], Shall-Zwall [sha].

name: Hmong, Northern Qiandong
LITERACY_L2: Many literate in Chinese[cmn], but many older women are illiterate.
Writing: Bopomofo script [Bopo], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: Many literate in Chinese[cmn], but many older women are illiterate. Large-scale literacy programs stopped but supportiveattitude toward literacy promoters. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1934–2018.
Language Use: Most domains. Some young people, all adults. Youth move to the city andabandon much of their culture and language. Mixed attitudes. Attitudes are positive incountryside; neutral to negative in city. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially children,who learn it at school but do not use it at home.

name: Tetela
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 90%. Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Luba-Lulua [lua]. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Bible: 1966.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Many also use Luba-Kasai [lua]. Some also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 by Kela [kel], Nkutu [nkw].

name: Wanga
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Seselwa Creole French
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in grades 1 and 2. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes.

name: Enets, Forest
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Few domains. Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Shifted to Russian[rus].

name: Saramaccan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Saramaccan is being used for religious instruction in Moravian schools along the Suriname River. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1991–2009.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Dutch [nld]. Used as L2 by Kwinti [kww].

name: Olu'bo
Language Development: Interest in using Olu’bo for education. Orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Bari [bfa].

name: Magahi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 30% in Hindi [hin]. Bhojpuri [bho] can use Magahi materials. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1826–2016.
Language Use: Shifting to Hindi [hin] among formally educated Magahi users and among those who have migrated to the cities (2020 M. Bhushan). Religion. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially educated people, city-dwellers, and those who travel.

name: Atikamekw
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Taught inprimary schools in early grades only. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use French [fra]. A few also use English[eng].

name: Komso
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Church literature. Latin script [Latn], developed in the 1990s, common usage since 2014, official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50% (2018 Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus). Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Taught in primary schools in grades 1–4. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2002.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Ale [gwd], Arbore [arv], Dirasha [gdl], Mositacha [dox], Ongota [bxe], Tsamai [tsb].

name: East Cree (Northern)
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],uses eastern finals, dot first.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught as subjectin primary schools. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use French[fra].

name: Pahari, Kullu
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longerin use.
Language Development: Radio. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Alsouse Tinani [lbf]. Also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Gujari [gju].

name: Ding
LITERACY_L2: High in Kituba [ktu]and French [fra], which are taught in the schools.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: High in Kituba [ktu]and French [fra], which are taught in the schools. Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar.
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; Mixed: Religion. Used by all. Most also use Kituba[ktu]. Most also use Lingala [lin]. Many also use French [fra].

name: Chin, Mün
Language Development: Some literacy classes. Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Used as L2 by Daai Chin [dao], Kaang Chin [ckn], Rawngtu Chin [weu].

name: Duruma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 13%. Language attitudes toward Kigiryama indicate theneed for separate Chiduruma literature. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature.Radio. Videos. Dictionary. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useChidigo [dig]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Chidigo [dig].

name: Kumhali
Language Development: Newspapers. Periodicals. Videos. Dictionary. Agencies: Nepal Kumal Society; Kumal National Liberation Front.
Language Use: Religion; mixed use: Home, friends, work. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes, though not always reflected in their language choices. All also use Nepali [npi].

name: Futuna, East
