Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2010.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Wallisian [wls]. Also use French [fra].

name: Jahanka
Language Development: Radio.

name: Ibibio
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Used in university courses. Also use Efik [efi], decreasingly, as aliterary language. Used as L2 by Ekit [eke], Ibino [ibn], Iko [iki], Khana [ogo], Obolo [ann],Oro [orx].

name: Emilian
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1862.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Italian [ita].

name: Cubeo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Written form used forreligion and commerce. Taught as subject in primary schools. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 1970–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. About 5% are 7 years old or younger. Positiveattitudes. Also use Spanish [spa]. Most also use other Tucanoan languages. Used as L2 by Cacua[cbv].

name: Dyula
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. N’Ko script[Nkoo], used in Côte d’Ivoire and Burkina Faso.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in some primary schools;taught in 3 cities (Seguela, Mankono, Kong) as pilot classes. Materials are being prepared toexpand to 8 other languages. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Abidji [abi], Abron [abr], Anyin [any], Attié [ati], Beng[nhb], Cebaara Sénoufo [sef], Dan [dnj], Djimini Sénoufo [dyi], Dogoso [dgs], Gban [ggu], JeriKuo [jek], Khe [kqg], Mwan [moa], Ngen [gnj], Nyabwa [nwb], Plapo Krumen [ktj], SouthernToussian [wib], Téén [lor], Tepo Krumen [ted], Tonjon [tjn], Toura [neb], Wan [wan], Wè Southern[gxx], Wè Western [wec], Yaouré [yre].

name: Mussau-Emira
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%–95%. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–95% Tok Pisin [tpi]and English [eng]. Schooling declined for a few years from 1999 due to poor economy, andliteracy rates then declined, but are now increasing again (2015 J. Brownie). Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Spoken by nearly all. Passed on to children in the traditionalarea, and some elsewhere, except in mixed marriages. Tenis ethnic group also uses Emira dialect.Most domains, local administration, commerce, education in early grades, oral and some writtenuse in church, personal letters. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].Most also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Tenis [tns].

name: Dogosé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 3%. Literature. Dictionary.NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: French, Cajun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60% in English [eng], 0% in French [fra]. Textbooks inCajun, translations of some classics. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to English [eng]. Used as L2 by Koasati [cku].

name: Saliba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80% (2007 R. Oetzel). Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in 7 schools. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2007–2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng] (Margetts 2004). Many also use Suau [swp], especially older adults (Margetts 2004).

name: Shipibo-Conibo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1983–2012.
Language Use: Language and culture are conserved within the ethnic group (Crevels 2007). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Isconahua [isc].

name: Quechua, Northern Conchucos Ancash
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature. Radio. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, work, play. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Manobo, Obo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Cebuano [ceb]. Literacy work ongoing. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Home, market, church. Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. All also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use Hiligaynon [hil].

name: Arabic (Judeo-Moroccan)
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Youth have French [fra] as L1. Arabic used is more similar to MoroccanArabic [ary] than to Moroccan Judeo-Arabic. Adults only. Most shifting to French [fra]. Someshifting to Moroccan Arabic [ary]. Also use Hebrew [heb]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Balanta-Ganja
Language Development: Literacy classes. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Mandinka [mnk]. Some also useWolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication. A few also use French[fra], particularly those who have attended school. Also use Mandjak [mfv]. Also use Mankanya[knf].

name: Welsh
Language Development: Taught in some primary and secondary schools in Welsh-medium schoolstypically in Welsh-speaking areas of Wales. Taught as subject in primary and secondary schoolsin English-medium schools in Wales. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible:1588–2015.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng].

name: Kabuverdianu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 83%. Cape Verdeans who can read Portuguese [por] areable to read Kabuverdianu, with a little effort to adjust to a few differences between thePortuguese orthography and the official Kabuverdianu orthography. Taught as subject in tertiaryschools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.Bible portions: 2004–2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also usePortuguese [por], which is learned in school. Kabuverdianu [kea] coexists in constant contactwith Portuguese [por], so decreolization is a concern that government academics and educatorsare constantly addressing in their Kabuverdianu development efforts (Veiga 1995).

name: Mixe, Totontepec
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1989–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Dzongkha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 54%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Taught in manyprimary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter. Taught as subject in all secondaryschools. Taught as subject in some tertiary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible: 2010.

name: Morigi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Ejagham
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Ndoe [nbb], Olulumo-Ikom [iko].

name: Pulaar
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1997.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Many also use French [fra], as the language ofeducation and government (Diouf et al 2017). Some also use Wolof [wol], as the language ofcommerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Also use Jola-Fonyi [dyo]. Used asL2 by Gusilay [gsl], Ménik [tnr], Mlomp [mlo], Saafi-Saafi [sav], Soninke [snk], Wamey [cou].

name: Carib
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Many in the ethnic group speak Carib but lack intergenerationaltransmission (Crevels 2007). Home. Some young people, all adults.

name: Awa-Cuaiquer
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2002.
Language Use: Majority are monolingual in Spanish [spa] and no evidence of monolingualism in Awa Cuaiquer. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Maguindanao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%. Taught as subject in a few primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1991–2010.
Language Use: Value English [eng] proficiency as an aid to employment. Most multilingual families using Tagalog [tgl] and Maguindanaon as their language at home (2023 S. Gonsang). Home, Community, Work, Religion, Education, mixed with other languages in most domains. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. All also use Tagalog [tgl]. Some also use Cebuano [ceb]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Ilocano [ilo]. Used as L2 by Ilianen Manobo [mbi], Sarangani Blaan [bps].

name: Ndrulo, Northern Lendu
Language Development: Literature. Bible portions: 2021.
Language Use: Also use Alur [alz].

name: Unua
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1892–1950.
Language Use: Use Bislama [bis] for church and meetings. Home, local activities. Used by all. All also use Bislama [bis] (Pearce 2015).

name: Chin, Daai
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya]. Also use Müün Chin [mwq]. Used as L2 by Kaang Chin [ckn].

name: Dong, Southern
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from late Ming dynasty, used in ritual texts and folk domains. Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, used between 1958–1966 and from 1981, experimental, small-scale use in education, administration, and literature.
Language Development: Periodicals. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2006.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], for literature. Also use Northern Dong [doc].

name: Zuojiang Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], particularly the southwestern dialect. Also use Yue Chinese [yue].

name: Alur
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1936–2016.
Language Use: A few also use Bangala [bxg]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Used as L2 byNdrulo [dno].

name: Wambule
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2019. Agency: Wambule Rai Society of Nepal.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work, education. Used by all. Also use Bahing [bhj]. Also use Jerung [jee]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Rajbanshi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 38% (1991 census). Mother-tongue multilingual education and adult literacy programs have been carried out in villages throughout the Rajbanshi area. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion, work; mixed use: Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Maithili [mai]. Also use Nepali [npi]. Used as L2 by Dhimal [dhi].

name: Adangme
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught inprimary and secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Bible: 1999.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Lugbara
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1922, revised in 2010.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some secondary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1966.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, work, markets. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh]. Also use Nubi [kcn] (Nakao 2018). Used as L2 by Alur [alz], Aringa [luc], Kakwa [keo], Kuku [ukv], Southern Ma’di [snm].

name: Duala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught in primary schools. Radio. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1872–1970.
Language Use: All also use French [fra]. Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some alsouse English [eng], especially those Duala who live in the South West Region. A few also use Basa[bzw]. Used as L2 by Bafaw-Balong [bwt], Bakaka [bqz], Bakoko [bkh], Bankon [abb], Barombi[bbi], Basaa [bas], Bubia [bbx], Isubu [szv], Mbo [mbo], Mokpwe [bri], Mulimba [mzd].

name: Lakona
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools, in 2 primary schools. Literature. Texts.
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Vure dialect has about 60 speakers, Qatareu and Togla dialects have 1 speaker each. Entire ethnic group speaks Lakon. Most key domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bislama [bis]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Olrat [olr].

name: Herdé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 12%. Taught as subject in some primary schools.Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1980.

name: Montagnais
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75% in French [fra] or English [eng]. Taught in all schools (Golla 2007). Recent language of instruction in Betsiamites, and taught as a subject in other classes. Taught as L2 in 2 communities. Taught as subject in primary schools. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1990–2004.
Language Use: Vigorous except in 2 communities near cities where there is rapid language loss. Strong use in lower north shore communities and Schefferville (Golla 2007). Some of all ages. Most also use French [fra], especially in the Mashteuiatsh communities in Quebec, nearly all fluently. Some also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Naskapi [nsk].

name: Bishnupriya Manipuri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80%. Literature. Radio. Videos. Grammar. Bibleportions: 1995–2011. Agency: Bishnupuriya Language and Development Organisation.
Language Use: Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng].

name: Jur Modo
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. The Ministry ofEducation, supported by donors, has started a pilot project to develop materials for teachingJur Modo as a subject and as language of instruction up to grade 3 in some schools. Literature.Dictionary. NT: 1998. Agency: Modo Language Society.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, oral and written use in administration, commerce,written use in folk stories, keeping of family records. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used asL2 by Mo’da [gbn].

name: Northern Sotho, Pedi; Sepedi
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary and secondary schools. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Radio. TV. Grammar. Bible: 1904–2000.

name: Yangben
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Religious services. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Speakers do not think French [fra] will replace Yangben. Most also use French [fra], used in primary and secondary education. Some also use Bulu [bum], only in the Presbyterian Church. Some also use Ewondo [ewo], only in the Catholic Church. Also use Nugunu [yas]. Also use Numala [mmu]. Used as L2 by Bati [btc], Hijuk [hij], Mbule [mlb], Nulibie [ekm], Numala [mmu].

name: Hrangkhol
Language Development: Literature committee since 1960. Literature. Bible: 2006.
Language Use: Use declining in Mizoram, Manipur and even Assam; shifting to Assamese[asm] or Bengali [ben] (Van Driem 2007). Home, village. Some of all ages. Some also use English[eng]. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Mizo [lus]. Used as L2 bySakachep [sch].

name: Iyo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: High. One vernacular preschool. All other vernacular preschools stopped operating in 2010. One elementary school spends a small amount of time on vernacular literacy, but there aren’t enough vernacular literacy materials and teaching for widespread L1 literacy. Literature. Texts. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Very stable on the inland side of the Finisterres because of isolation. On the coastal side, with more cross-language interaction, there is much more admixture with Tok Pisin [tpi]. All domains except church, where there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi], and in interactions with outsiders. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially men and young people (Minter 2009).

name: Acheron
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials exist. Literature.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd]. Used as L2 by Tocho [taz].

name: Kazakh
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in China and Iran. Braille script[Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Kazakhstan and Mongolia. Latin script [Latn], used inKazakhstan and Turkey.
Language Development: Increasing education in Kazakh. Taught in most primary and secondaryschools; taught as subject in all other schools. Taught in many tertiary schools. Newspapers.Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: 98% speak Kazakh as L1. Positive attitudes. Increasing ethnic pride andfeelings of Islamic brotherhood. Also use Northern Uzbek [uzn]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Misima-Paneati
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–80%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–80%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in 35 schools. Dictionary. NT: 1947–1998.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Callister 2005). Used as L2 by Bwanabwana [tte], Muyuw [myw], Rifao [nmw], Sudest [tgo], Yélî Dnye [yle].

name: Maiadomu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–30%. Literature. Texts. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: All domains except school and church, where there is mixed use with other languages. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Dobu [dob]. Some also use English [eng]. A few also use Boselewa [bwf], especially elderly. A few also use Galeya [gar]. A few also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially elderly. Used as L2 by Boselewa [bwf], Gumawana [gvs].

name: Kxoe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%–20%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many non-Khwe learn Khwe for interaction with Khwe. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Afrikaans [afr]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Pidgin Bantu [fng]. Also use Setswana [tsn].

name: Gikyode
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–2%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–20%. Literature. NT:2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka]. Used as L2 byChala [cll].

name: Daur
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], 1916–?, 1957–1958. Han script, Simplified variant[Hans]. Latin script [Latn], used from 1920 to some time after 1928, then from 1981, primaryusage. Mongolian script [Mong], Manchu style, used since the Qing dynasty.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 97% (2000 census, Daur nationality). Some literacy inMongolian among those 30 to 50 years of age in Hala’er. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: In Hulun Buir the language is being retained well; in Heilongjiang nottransmitted to children among most groups (Bradley 2007a). All domains. Adults only. Neutralattitudes. Shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Evenki [evn]. Also use Kazakh [kaz].Also use Manchu [mnc]. Also use Oroqen [orh]. Also use Peripheral Mongolian [mvf]. Used as L2 byEvenki [evn], Oroqen [orh].

name: Songhai, Koyraboro Senni
Language Development: Actively promoted by the government through adult literacy classes and as the language of instruction at the primary level in some experimental schools. Some French literacy. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bamanankan [bam]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Tamasheq [taq]. Bilingualism is not extensive (1999 J. Heath).

name: Semnani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 93% in Persian [pes]. Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Iranian Persian [pes].

name: Korean
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Hangul and Han scripts [Kore], primary usage. Latin script [Latn], used for maps and signs.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 98% (1995). Higher adult illiteracy is reported on Jeju Island. Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1911–1993.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Rungus
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 85% in Standard Malay [zsm].Literacy rate in L1: low for those over 45; much higher for those under 30. Literacy in L2:Standard Malay [zsm] literacy higher than Rungus; school language is Standard Malay. Language ofinstruction in about 5 kindergartens. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2014.Agency: Persatuan Momogun Rungus Sabah (SAMORA), Rungus Cultural Association (RCA), Sabah RungusCultural and Heritage (SARUCHA), Persatuan Rungus Pitas (PISAAN), Pertubuhan Rungus Malaysia,Yayasan Rungus (Rungus Foundation).
Language Use: 90% L1 speakers. Mixed use: Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Some youngpeople, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Some also use StandardMalay [zsm]. A few also use Hakka Chinese [hak]. A few also use Iranun [ilm]. A few also useKadazan Dusun [dtp]. A few also use Kimaragang [kqr]. A few also use Tombonuo [txa]. Used as L2by Hakka Chinese [hak], Iranun [ilm], Kadazan Dusun [dtp], Kimaragang [kqr], Tombonuo [txa].

name: Gonja
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Taught inprimary and secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 byHanga [hag].

name: Otuho
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1969–2003.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Lokoya [lky], Tennet [tex].

name: Bamali
Language Development: Basic literacy materials. Radio. Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use English[eng]. Used as L2 by Mankong [bqt].

name: Seke (Vanuatu)
LITERACY_L2: Less than 90% at a basic level.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 90% at a basic level. Literature. Grammar. A project by a researcher in the late 2000s–early 2010s failed to deliver promised outputs and generated considerable disillusionment with language revitalization work, negatively impacting the viability of the language (2023 A. Gray).
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon), shifting to Bislama [bis]. Mixed: home, community. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Apma [app], including most adults. Also use Bislama [bis]. Few young children are fluent in any language other than Bislama [bis], though they may have passive knowledge of other languages.

name: Tonga (Zambia)
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–4. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Grammar. Bible: 1963–1996.
Language Use: Recognized for educational and administrative purposes. Home, community, market, administration. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Lenje [leh].

name: Carrier, Southern
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature adapted from Central Carrier isuseable. NT: 2002–2023.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng]. Used as L2 by Chilcotin [clc].

name: Fang (Equatorial Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Few read Fang. Literacy rate in L2: 77% in Spanish[spa]. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa].Many also use Equatorial Guinean Pidgin [fpe], a language of urban identity for the young peoplein the capital and on Bioko island. Many also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Benga [bng], Bube[bvb], Fa d’Ambu [fab], Kombe [nui], Kwasio [nmg], Molengue [bxc], Seki [syi].

name: Quechua, Huaylas Ancash
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught as subject in many primary schools. Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: People in and near the mestizo towns in the valley increasingly proficient in Spanish. Communities at higher elevations maintain use in all domains. Bilinguals working in an office will use mostly Spanish at work. Use of the language in the communities away from and above the mestizo population centers is vigorous (2011 D. Hintz). Home, friends, market, social gatherings. Some young people, all adults. Few children in lower elevation and higher population areas, all children at the higher elevations. Positive attitudes. Many also use Spanish [spa], especially men.

name: Marma
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], used in Bangladesh. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr], used in India.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools in grades 1 and 2. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Home, village. Also use Chak [ckh], especially in Khagrachari and Rangamati districts. Also use Chittagonian [ctg]. Used as L2 by Asho Chin [csh], Bawm Chin [bgr], Chak [ckh], Khumi Chin [cnk], Mru [mro], Tippera [tpe].

name: Wymysorys
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Elderly only. Shifted to Polish [pol].

name: Mongolian, Halh
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl]. Mongolian script [Mong],used prior to 1941 with a resurgence since the 1990s. Phags-pa script [Phag], no longer in use.Tibetan script [Tibt], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 98%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools.Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2003.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all.

name: Mixtec, Atatláhuca
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 1973–2010.
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Dargwa
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bibleportions: 2002–2020.
Language Use: 98% are L1 speakers. Many also use Kumyk [kum]. Also use Russian [rus].

name: Magar, Western
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1991.
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, friends, work. Some young people, all adults. Elderly. Some use among children, adolescents, young and older adults. Mixed attitudes. Rhetoric is positive but language conservation is generally not implemented. Most also use Nepali [npi].

name: Lahu Shi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Fairly high among Christians. Literature. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Many also use Lahu [lhu].

name: Ndogo
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous in most areas. All domains. Oral use in courts, commerce, personal letters. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Bai [bdj], West Central Banda [bbp].

name: Cuicatec, Teutila
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1972–2011.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Mixtec, Yosondúa
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1988–2010.
Language Use: There are only two ranch areas where the language is still spoken and where children may be learning it (2010 SIL). Some young people, all adults.

name: Tampuan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Khmer [khm]. A few also use Lao [lao]. Used as L2 by Kachok [xkk].

name: Hakka Chinese
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant[Hant]. Latin script [Latn], used since early 19th century.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality). Highly literate inChinese and they use that literature. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1916–2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by She [shx].

name: Narim
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Tippera
Language Development: Taught in primary schools in grades 1 and 2.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Bengali [ben], especially men. Many also use Marma [rmz]. Also use Chak [ckh], in Khagrachari and Rangamati districts. Also use Chittagonian [ctg].

name: Bangi
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1909–1922.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Religion, Work, Education. Some young people, alladults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Lingala [lin]. Some also use French [fra].

name: Swahili (specific)
Language Development: Language of instruction in primary school. In secondary school taught as a subject. Taught in primary and secondary schools; adopted as language of instruction in 2015. Taught in tertiary schools for some subjects. Fully developed. Bible: 1891–2017.
Language Use: It is also common for people of numerous ethnic groups to speak Swahili as L1, especially in urban and very mixed areas. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Samei
Writing: Yi script [Yiii], traditional, no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Chinese. Literature.
Language Use: Extinct in some villages close to Kunming, severely endangered to the east in northeast Guandu and Yiliang, endangered in Ala Township, which is the center of the Samei distribution and where most villages are entirely or largely Samei (Bradley 2007a). Some young people, all adults. Most also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Tamajaq, Tawallammat
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng], called Shifinagh in Niger.
Language Development: Slowly growing interest in literacy. Literature. Radio. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Some children in urban areas no longer speak Tamajaq. Home, market, commerce, some schools. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Tagdal [tda], Tasawaq [twq].

name: Hindko, Southern
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage.
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Also use Northern Pashto [pbu]. Also use Saraiki [skr]. Also use Urdu[urd]. Also use Western Punjabi [pnb]. Used as L2 by Western Punjabi [pnb].

name: Bondo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 12% (2001 census).Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 2010.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Many also use Adivasi Oriya [ort], for trade andinteractions with surrounding communities. Few Upper Bondo are bilingual. Also use English[eng], limited use with the youth.

name: Dinka, Northeastern
Language Development: Some literacy materials produced. Taught as subject in some primary schoolsthrough grade 3. The Ministry of Education, supported by donors, has started a pilot project todevelop materials for teaching Dinka (all 4 varieties together) as a subject and asclanguage ofinstruction up to grade 3 in some schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1952.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Telugu
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Telugu script [Telu], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Andhra Pradesh state, Telangana state, and Puducherry Union Territory. Fully developed. Bible: 1854–2002.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bodo Gadaba [gbj], Chenchu [cde], Koya [kff], Kupia [key], Lambadi [lmn], Manna-Dora [mju], Mudhili Gadaba [gau], Northwestern Kolami [kfb], Pottangi Ollar Gadaba [gdb], Vaagri Booli [vaa], Waddar [wbq], Yerukula [yeu].

name: Ngambay
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Taught in some primary schools in early grades only. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1993–2016.
Language Use: Largest language of the Sara-Bagirmi group.

name: Bongo
Language Development: Orthography developed and literacy materials in use. Literature. Bibleportions: 2012.
Language Use: Those in Nagero County, Western Equatoria State, now mainly use Zande[zne]. Positive attitudes. Also use Southwestern Dinka [dik]. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Tulu
LITERACY_L2: 80%–83% in Dakshina Kannada [kan] for Udupi districts.
Writing: Kannada script [Knda]. Tulu-Tigalari script [Tutg], philosophical texts and religious verses are sometimes written in this script.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80%–83% in Dakshina Kannada [kan] for Udupi districts. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1847–2000.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also use Marathi [mar]. Used as L2 by Korra Koraga [kfd], Kudiya [kfg].

name: Bukharic
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], primary usage. Hebrew script [Hebr]. Latin script[Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Shifting to Hebrew [heb].

name: Bena (Tanzania)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Swahili to Bena transitional literacy work begun(SIL). Some older Bena can read and write their language as used in early 1900’s. Literature.Radio. Grammar. NT: 1914–2022.
Language Use: Private domains, market, traditional rituals. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Used as L2 by Benamanga [egm].

name: Thai
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Thai script [Thai], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in all tertiary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1883–2011.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Dangaléat
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Preschoolliteracy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Zerenkel [zrn].

name: Kabras
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Luxembourgish; Letzeburgesch
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 99% in German [deu] and French [fra]. Taught in all primary schools in early grades only. Fully developed. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. The language of creativity for most. Modest amounts of literature. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006). Also use French [fra]. Also use Standard German [deu]. Used as L2 by Kabuverdianu [kea].

name: Wiarumus
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Used by a minority of the older generation. Some adults can understand, and a few young people understand. Interest in revitalization. Elderly only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Zayse-Zergulla
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], informal usage. Latin script [Latn], official usage since 2014.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Amharic [amh]. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. Bible portions: 2014–2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Approximately 7,000 ethnic Gamo [gmv] speak Zergulla as L1. Children up to school age speak Zayse more than any other language. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Mositacha [dox].

name: Mungaka
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1961–1970.
Language Use: All also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Most also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Bafut [bfd], Meta’ [mgo], Ngamambo [nbv], Pinyin [pny].

name: Macedonian
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools. Taught in most tertiary schools. Newspapers. Radio. Grammar. Bible: 1990–2006.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Mixtec, San Juan Colorado
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1994–2013.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Ono
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Used in church education. Literature. Texts. NT: 1991–2012.
Language Use: Home, church, government. Positive attitudes. Also use Kâte [kmg]. Used as L2 by Dedua [ded], Nomu [noh], Sialum [slw].

name: Kurti
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Radio. Bible portions: 1999–2004.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kele [sbc]. Also use Mondropolon [npn]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Andra-Hus [anx], Elu [elu], Kele [sbc], Mondropolon [npn], Ponam [ncc], Tulu-Bohuai [rak].

name: Micmac
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Micmac Hieroglyphs (Kauder ideograms) script [Qabg], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–17%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 800 or more readers of Micmac, 200 write it. Taught as subject in most primary schools. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1874–1998.
Language Use: In some communities, only older adults. Virtually extinct in 5 communities, 4 of which are in English-speaking areas (Shubenagadie, Truro, Eel River Bar, Pabineo Falls) and the 5th in French-speaking Gaspé, Quebec. In larger areas children tend to begin speaking some Micmac, except in Listuguj, where some families educate children in French. In communities such as Gesgapegiaq, use is more vigorous. Each community has a committee or group whose task is to help enhance the language and culture. Prayers, songs, readings. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra].

name: Tagbanwa, Calamian
Writing: Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Tagbanwa script [Tagb].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 40%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Tagalog [tgl]. Fluency training much needed (2007 SIL). Literature. Texts. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous, except with inter-marriage with non-Tagbanwas. Home, church, neighborhood, work sites. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Attitudes are positive among themselves, but negative around others. Also use Tagalog [tgl]. Used as L2 by Cuyonon [cyo].

name: Quechua, Ayacucho
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Perhaps 10,000 read it, 2,000 can write it. Oral and written Quechua used in some schools, some universities. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1987–2011.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Written form used in religious services. Negative attitudes. Considered inferior to Spanish [spa]. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tachelhit
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng], official usage.
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2010.
Language Use: Many also use Moroccan Arabic [ary], especially men but few women.

name: Bhili
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Literature. Radio.TV. Videos. NT: 1930.
Language Use: Spoken as L1 by the Patelia in Madhya Pradesh. Many also use English [eng].Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Arabic (Mesopotamian)
Language Development: Radio. TV. Grammar.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Judeo-Iraqi Arabic [yhd], Neo-Mandaic [mid], Southern Kurdish[sdh], Western Armenian [hyw].

name: Rapa
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2008.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Tahitian [tah]. Also use French [fra], but with limited proficiency.

name: Burushaski
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], in development. Arabic script,Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Hunza, less in Nagar. Literature. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous, but acquiring Urdu [urd] borrowings. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use Khowar [khw], especially Yasin dialect speakers. Also use Urdu [urd],especially women. Used as L2 by Dawoodi [dmk], Khowar [khw], Wakhi [wbl].

name: Moro
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Widely used and promoted in the Moro churches and cultural institutions. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Alta, Southern
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in some primary schools in grades 1–3 and as subject thereafter.Bible portions: 1970.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Northern Alta [aqn] (Abreu 2020).Also use Tagalog [tgl], particularly dialects of Bulacan and Nueva Ecija (Abreu 2020). Also useUmiray Dumaget Agta [due] (Abreu 2020).

name: Langue des signes de Belgique Francophone
Language Development: TV. Videos. Dictionary. Agency: Fédération Francophone des Sourds de Belgique (French-speaking Federation of the Deaf Belgians, FFSB).
Language Use: Vigorous. 4 schools for deaf children (Timmermans 2005). Taught in several private schools since 1980s, in vocational schools since 1992 (twelve levels), and in some deaf schools as pilot project since official government recognition in 2003. Interpreters required in court. Used by all. Also use French [fra].

name: Foodo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Radio. Bible portions: 1998.
Language Use: Used by all. Children in the diaspora are sent back to the Foodo homelandto learn the language (Plunkett 2009). Most also use Tem [kdh] (Plunkett 2009). Also use French[fra]. Also use Kabiyè [kbp].

name: Popoluca, Highland
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1977–1997.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use a Nahuatl language.

name: Meta'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Informally used in education. 5% can read and write Meta’. Literature. Radio. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Most also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra]. A few also use Mungaka [mhk]. Used as L2 by Ngamambo [nbv], Ngie [ngj].

name: Yi, Wusa (Wusa Nasu)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: Moderate in Chinese. Taught at Guizhou Institute of Nationalities. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Home, village, market. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Aluo [yna].

name: Taupota
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Texts. Bible portions: 2009.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Also use Tawala [tbo]. Also use Wedau [wed]. Used as L2 by Gweda [grw].

name: Nawdm
Language Development: Interest in L1 literacy very low, but higher outside the homeland (2021 SIL). Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous, but codeswitching with French occurs. All domains except education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Kabiyè [kbp]. Also use Lama [las].

name: Tzeltal, Oxchuc
Language Development: 50,000 readers, 40,000 can write. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. Some Tzotzil also speak Tzeltal. Some families now use Spanish [spa]. Some Ch’ol [ctu] in north border area and lowland learned Tzeltal. All domains. Oral use in administration, commerce, some oral and written use in education, religion. Minimal use in government schools. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use Tojolabal [toj]. Also use Chol [ctu]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Wanji
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. SIL has transition literacy work (Swahili to Vwanji); some pre-school basic literacy classes. Literature. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Adolescents prefer Swahili [swh]. Those who stay in the area often go back to Vwanji when they get older. Private domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Lawa, Western
Language Development: Literacy in Western Lawa more common among Christians. Literacy in Thai [tha] has become more common as education becomes more available. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains except government and education, which are in Thai [tha]. Used by all. Some also use S’gaw Karen [ksw], especially older adults. Also use Northern Thai [nod]. Also use Thai [tha].

name: Quechua, Ambo-Pasco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous in isolated communities. Home, fields, community. Some of all ages. Negative attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sukuma
Language Development: Some literacy work. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1960–2015.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Hadza [hts], Zinza [zin].

name: Harauti
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75% in Kota District (2001 census). Literature. NT:1822.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village; market, religion. Positive attitudes. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], with widespread bilingualism. 40% have very goodproficiency, with greater proficiency among the educated.

name: Waima
Language Development: Radio. NT: 2003.
Language Use: Home, traditional ceremonies, play, public meetings, religious services. Used by all. Most also use English [eng]. Many also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Lala [nrz].

name: Chin, Tedim
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Pau Cin Hau alphabet [Pauc], for liturgical purposesonly.
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1977–2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese[mya].

name: Nyoro
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some secondary schools, as Runyakitaara, sharing materials with Chiga [cgg] and Nyankore [nyn]. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1912.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Tooro [ttj], especially Rutangwenda speakers. Some also use Ganda [lug]. Used as L2 by Gungu [rub], Ruruuli-Runyala [ruc], Tooro [ttj].

name: Ik
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Very low. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible portions: 2014.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Ng’akarimojong[kdj]. Many also use Swahili [swh]. Some also use Turkana [tuv]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Songhay, Koyra Chiini
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Timbuktu has more prestige than other WestSonghoy dialects. Also use Bamanankan [bam]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Hassaniyya [mey].Also use Tamasheq [taq]. Used as L2 by Tiemacèwè Bozo [boo].

name: Goemai
Language Development: Radio. Grammar. Bible portions: 2015.
Language Use: Transmission of the language to children appears to be limited. Shifting toHausa [hau] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007). Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special culturalevents. Some young people, all adults. Many also use English [eng]. Many also use Hausa [hau].Used as L2 by Jakattoe [jrt], Tehl [mtl], Wãpha [juw], Ywom [gek].

name: Elfdalian, Övdalian
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Agency: Ulum Dalska.
Language Use: Adults only, with only 45 speakers younger than 15 years in a 2007 survey (Larsson et al 2008). Shifting to Swedish [swe].

name: Naga, Angami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 86% (2001 census). Literacy rate in L2: 86% (2001 census). Most youth read Angami. Literacy among older people is lower. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1970.
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nagamese [nag]. Used as L2 by Chokri Naga [nri], Khezha Naga [nkh], Sumi Naga [nsm].

name: Picard
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Literature. Bible portions: 1863.
Language Use: Recognized officially as an indigenous regional language in Belgium. Recognized by the European Bureau for Lesser-Used Languages. Some French government reports consider it a separate language from French [fra]. Boulonnais dialect has theater, poems, published grammar, dictionary. Home, family, friends, community. Elderly only. Shifted to French [fra].

name: Kalinga, Butbut
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 98%. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Videos. NT: 2016.
Language Use: Home, community, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Ilocano [ilo], which is acquired through school, travel, media, and use in church.

name: Gana
Language Development: Literature. Agency: Gana Cultural Association.
Language Use: People seldom use Gana. There has been considerable intermarriage betweenGana and Kuijau Dusun [dkr], a much larger group. This may explain why many of the Gana considerthemselves as Dusun rather than Murut. Mixed use: Home, Friends. Older adults only. Mixedattitudes. Shifted to Sabah Malay [msi]. Most also use Kuijau [dkr]. Many also use Kadazan Dusun[dtp]. Many also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use KeningauMurut [kxi].

name: Arabic (Libyan)
Language Development: Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Language not considered proper for official occasions, but at university,lecturers use it alongside Standard Arabic [arb]. Daily life. Used by all. Used as L2 by Awjilah[auj].

name: Evenki
LITERACY_L2: 96%, literacy in any language (2000 census, Ewenkinationality).
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used since 1937, small-scale use in Russia. Latinscript [Latn], used in Russia between 1931–1937, limited use in a few publications in China andon internet from 1983.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 96%, literacy in any language (2000 census, Ewenkinationality). Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2001–2018.
Language Use: Other speakers in the area also use Evenki. All domains. Some young people,all adults. Very few children except among the Khamnigan. Positive attitudes. Also use MandarinChinese [cmn]. Written Chinese used as literary languages. Farmers use Chinese. Also use Daur[dta]. Also use Oroqen [orh]. Also use Peripheral Mongolian [mvf]. Written Mongolian used asliterary language. Herdsmen use Mongolian as L2. Used as L2 by Daur [dta], Khamnigan Mongol[ykh], Oroqen [orh].

name: Naga, Chothe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Meitei [mni] (Bengali script) (2000). Literature. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Purest Chothe spoken in Purum Khullen. Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni].

name: Bookan
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Shifting to Sabah Malay [msi]. Used as L2 by Keningau Murut [kxi], LanasLobu [ruu].

name: Aché
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Guaraní [gug].Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2014. Agency: Kuatia Ñe’e.
Language Use: Home, friends; mixed use: Religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Mostalso use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug]. Some also use Spanish [spa].

name: Sissala
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1999.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Awing
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English[eng]. Also use French [fra].

name: Abadi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Taught in primaryschools in early grades only in more than 20 vernacular elementary schools (2021 SIL).Literature. Videos. Bible portions: 2016.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especiallyyouth. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially those over 50. Used as L2 by Toura [don].

name: Abkhazian
Writing: Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used since 1860s. Georgian (Mkhedruli and Mtavruli)script [Geor], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], used since 1984, used in Turkey.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools in Abkhazia region. Dictionary.Grammar. NT: 2015.
Language Use: 94% speak it as L1. Used as L2 by Mingrelian [xmf].

name: Krio
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 15% in English [eng]. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in secondary schools in grades 7–9. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous. More in provincial towns than villages, and for interethnic communication. Possibly half use Krio at work. Formal language for those who do not speak English [eng]. All domains, education. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Mende [men], Northern Kissi [kqs], Susu [sus], Themne [tem], Yalunka [yal].

name: Tunen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Ewondo [ewo]. Used as L2 by Ndemli [nml], Tuotomb [ttf].

name: Mugom
LITERACY_L2: Up to 22% in Nepali [npi]; men 30%, women 5%.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Up to 22% in Nepali [npi]; men 30%, women 5%. Mugu District ranks very low in literacy among Nepal districts, especially among children and women. Strong affinity felt towards Tibetan [bod] and its writing system because of high lexical similarity. Literature. Newspapers.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends; mixed use: Religion, work, education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use English [eng], especially children. Some also use Hindi [hin], especially men. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Oyda
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 19%. Radio.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kwama
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 12%. Non-formal literacy classes. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–3 in Benishangul-Gumuz region, as a pilot education program. Radio. Videos. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous in Benishangul Gumuz lowlands. Some of all ages. All also use West Central Oromo [gaz], as the dominant language in the Highland area, with some language shift taking place in Oromia region and in Tongo area (Küspert 2015). Some also use Amharic [amh], especially younger generation in Benishangul Gumuz. A few also use Standard Arabic [arb], in limited domains. Also use Berta [wti]. Used as L2 by Ganza [gza], Komo [xom].

name: Tboli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Perhaps 50%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: Perhaps 50%–60%. Literacy program in previously unreached coastal mountain range. Taught in primary schools in grades 1–3. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2007.
Language Use: Speak Tboli to each other freely in buses, surrounding towns, etc. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Hiligaynon [hil]. Used as L2 by Koronadal Blaan [bpr], Sarangani Blaan [bps].

name: Saafi-Saafi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% French [fra], 10% Arabic [arb]. Desire for Saafi-Saafi literature. 85 literacy classes of various types. Literature. Radio. Bible portions: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Children initially monolingual. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Most also use Wolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012). Also use Paloor [fap]. Also use Pulaar [fuc]. Also use Serer-Sine [srr]. Used as L2 by Ndut [ndv], Paloor [fap].

name: Pampanga
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Bible: 1917–1994.
Language Use: Dominant language in Pampanga province. Used as L2 by Abellen Ayta [abp], Mag-antsi Ayta [sgb], Mag-Indi Ayta [blx].

name: Nyindrou
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. 30% can write it. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bipi [biq]. Also use Khehek [tlx]. Also use Sori-Harengan [sbh]. Used as L2 by Likum [lib], Sori-Harengan [sbh].

name: Mixtec, Alacatlatzala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Bilingual schools are increasing; sufficient materials are lacking and desire for literacy remains somewhat limited. Dialects are orally intelligible, but differences from town to town make it difficult to use the same written materials. Adaptation of materials needed for 3–4 subdialects. Radio. Grammar. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Children of parents who have left the area understand Mixtec, but speak only Spanish [spa]. Very few other language speakers use this Mixtec language. Some use a Mixtec variety when communicating with Metlatónoc [mxv] and Xochapa [xta] speakers, though average comprehension is only around 70%, more for men, less for women. Less than 5% use a Tlapanec or Nahuatl variety due to intermarriage. Home, friends, religion, work. Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Pride in Mixtec growing slowly with interest in Mixtec literacy, but Spanish [spa] still often preferred for reading and writing.

name: Yi, Sichuan
Writing: Latin script [Latn], 1951–1957, 1958–1960, and from 1975. Yi script [Yiii],standardized, used since 1975, official (1980), primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Moderate in central Liangshan. Low elsewhere. Literacyrate in L2: Moderate. Nearly all literate Nuosu are literate in Chinese; some are also literatein Nuosu. Written Nuosu is used in rituals by priest-shamans in every community. Some educatedNuosu use standardized syllabary in academic contexts. The culture is orally oriented so mostwould not think of writing a letter or a set of procedures in Nuosu, nor would they think ofreading written instructions. The educated prefer to write in Chinese for these tasks. Taught assubject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2005–2009.
Language Use: Many Chinese loan words are appearing. All domains. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Narua [nru]. Also use Naxi [nxq]. Usedas L2 by Narua [nru].

name: Naxi
Writing: Latin script [Latn], developed in the 1950s and revised in 1984, primary usage. Lisu (Fraser) script [Lisu], experimental use in the 1920s and 1930s. Naxi Dongba script [Nkdb]. Naxi Geba script [Nkgb], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1932.
Language Use: Lijiang Old Town attitudes somewhat negative, decreasing number of young speakers. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Bai [bca]. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], in speaking and especially in writing. Used as L2 by Central Bai [bca], Central Tibetan [bod], Lisu [lis], Northern Pumi [pmi], Nuosu [iii], Shuhi [sxg], Southern Pumi [pmj].

name: Wallisian
Language Development: Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by East Futuna [fud].

name: Dotyali
Language Development: Literature. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also useNepali [npi]. A few also use Hindi [hin]. A few also use Kumaoni [kfy].

name: Fijian
Language Development: Taught in a few primary schools through grade 3. Newspapers. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1864.

name: Gondi, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. Videos.Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi[hin], especially in Madhya Pradesh, but with low proficiency. Also use Marathi [mar],especially in Maharashtra, but with low proficiency. Used as L2 by Nagarchal [nbg], NorthwesternKolami [kfb].

name: Lhomi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Bilingual literacy campaign should impact adult (and women’s) literacy rate in Lhomi and Nepali [npi]. Literature. Newspapers. Videos. Grammar. NT: 1995. Agency: Nepal Lhomi Society.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, friends, religion; mixed use: Work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use Nepali [npi], especially educated people (fluently), women (increasingly), and 90% of men for trade. Used as L2 by Eastern Tamang [taj], Gurung [gvr], Khaling [klr], Naaba [nao].

name: Ese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 1975–1999.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kabardian
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1993–2007.
Language Use: Some of all ages.

name: Papuan Malay
LITERACY_L2: 67% in Indonesian [ind] in Papua province; 94% in Indonesian [ind] in Papua Barat province (2010 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 67% in Indonesian [ind] in Papua province; 94% in Indonesian [ind] in Papua Barat province (2010 census). Officially no data on L1 literacy are available. Those literate in Indonesian [ind] can read and write Papuan Malay. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2013–2017. Agency: Yayasan Betania Indonesia.
Language Use: Growing number of L1 speakers, who express a strong preference for their Malay variety over Indonesian [ind] or other regional varieties. All domains except formal government settings or formal education. Used unofficially in many school settings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Ambel [wgo], As [asz], Auye [auu], Awera [awr], Awyi [auw], Beneraf [bnv], Berik [bkl], Betaf [bfe], Biak [bhw], Bian Marind [bpv], Biga [bhc], Bonggo [bpg], Burate [bti], Burumakok [aip], Buruwai [asi], Dabe [dbe], Demisa [dei], Dineor [mrx], Dla [kbv], Emem [enr], Fedan [pdn], Jofotek-Bromnya [jbr], Kais [kzm], Kamberau [irx], Kaptiau [kbi], Kaure [bpp], Kayagar [kyt], Kayupulau [kzu], Kembra [xkw], Kimki [sbt], Kirikiri [kiy], Kowiai [kwh], Kuri [nbn], Kwesten [kwt], Kwinsu [kuc], Liki [lio], Masimasi [ism], Massep [mvs], Mawes [mgk], Mo [wkd], Moi [daz], Moi Lemas [sbg], Mombum [mso], Morori [mok], Nafri [nxx], Nakai [nkj], Namla [naa], Nimboran [nir], Ormu [orz], Orya [ury], Salawati [xmx], Semimi [etz], Serui-Laut [seu], Skou [skv], Sobei [sob], Sowari [dmy], Sunum [ymn], Tangko [tkx], Tarpia [tpf], Tebi [dmu], Tobati [tti], Towei [ttn], Usku [ulf], Viid [snu], Vitou [vto], Wabo [wbb], Wamesa [wad], Warembori [wsa], Wares [wai], Wauyai [wuy], Yaosakor Asmat [asy], Yaur [jau], Yei [jei], Zorop [wfg].

name: Guaraní, Eastern Bolivian
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2001.
Language Use: Bilingual education implemented on a large scale (Crevels 2007). Used byall.

name: Moloko
Language Development: Literature. Bible portions: 2007.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], in the market, in outlying areas due to intermarriage with speakers of other languages, and in church (but only with interpretation).

name: Mandeali
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longer in use.
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Eastern Punjabi [pan]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Agta, Umiray Dumaget
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–10%. Taught in manyprimary schools in grades 1–3 and as subject thereafter. Texts. NT: 1977.
Language Use: Some parents passing the language on to children. All domains. Some youngpeople, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Filipino [fil]. Most also use Ilocano[ilo]. Used as L2 by Southern Alta [agy].

name: Balochi, Western
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Turkmenistan.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught as subjectin some tertiary schools. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions:1984–2005.
Language Use: Most also use Urdu [urd]. Some also use Brahui [brh]. A few also useSouthern Pashto [pbt], in Quetta and surrounding areas. Used as L2 by Brahui [brh].

name: Saho
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], official usage in Ethiopia. Latin script [Latn], official usage in Eritrea.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Females: about 30%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Taught in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1964.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Also use Afar [aar]. Also use Tigré [tig]. Also use Tigrigna [tir].

name: Mafa
Language Development: New orthography in Catholic schools. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 1989.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Some also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Some also use Buwal [bhs]. Some also use French [fra]. Some also use Mefele [mfj]. Some also use North Mofu [mfk]. A few also use Hausa [hau]. A few also use Hdi [xed]. Used as L2 by Cuvok [cuv], Gavar [gou], Hdi [xed], Mefele [mfj], Mofu-Gudur [mif], Vemgo-Mabas [vem], Zulgo-Gemzek [gnd].

name: Gourmanchéma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 58% (2006 census). Literacy rate in L2: 5%–10%.Central dialect is prestigious and used for writing. Also used in adult literacy classes (2021SIL). Taught as subject in some primary schools through grades 3–5. Newspapers. Radio. Videos.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2005.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Moore [mos]. Also use WesternNiger Fulfulde [fuh]. Also use Zarma [dje].

name: Degexit'an
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Gyele
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5% have some literacy in Gyele. Literacy rate in L2:Very few can read French [fra]. A Bipindi boarding school uses Gyele materials in elementaryschool, which produced some literacy among Bipindi area Gyele speakers. Not used in governmentschools, which more children are attending. Radio. Videos. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1981.
Language Use: Speakers often hide the fact that they have their own language. However,within the group, when no outsiders are present, they prefer Gyele. Home, with each other. Someof all ages. Most also use Kwasio [nmg]. A few also use French [fra]. Also use Basaa [bas]. Alsouse Bulu [bum]. Also use Ewondo [ewo]. Used as L2 by Iyasa [yko], Kwasio [nmg].

name: Tagal Murut
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Standard Malay [zsm]. A school for older adults has been set up to teach them to read in Murut Tahol. The primary reviewers expressed the need for primary and secondary school language subjects in Tahol Murut (like Kadazan Dusun), since this is the largest Murutic language in Sabah. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1998. Agency: Sabah Murut Cultural Association, Kadazandusun Language Foundation (KLF).
Language Use: The Tahol language seems to be widely used, even among young people. Home, Friends, Religion, Work; Mixed use: Education. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Sabah Malay [msi]. Some also use Standard Malay [zsm]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use Hakka Chinese [hak]. A few also use Kadazan Dusun [dtp]. A few also use Timugon Murut [tih]. Used as L2 by Kadazan Dusun [dtp], Keningau Murut [kxi], Kolod Murut [kqv], Paluan Murut [plz], Selungai Murut [slg], Timugon Murut [tih].

name: Kemtuik
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2008.
Language Use: Adults only. Shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Mlap [kja].

name: Lundayeh
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1982.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Lengilu [lgi].

name: East Cree (Southern)
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Unified Canadian Aboriginal Syllabics script [Cans],uses eastern finals.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught in primaryand secondary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2001.
Language Use: Most shifted to English [eng]. Some shifted to French [fra]. Used as L2 byAlgonquin [alq].

name: Dawsahak
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 0% (2007 M. Almaki). Literacy rate in L2: 0% (2007 M.Almaki). Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Tamasheq [taq],although women and children in isolated encampments understand very little.

name: Bacama
Language Development: New orthography being introduced so not many readers yet. Newspapers.Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: All also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Used as L2by Bali [bcn], Kpasham [pbn], Kwa [kwb], Mbula-Bwazza [mbu], Tso [ldp].

name: Abu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%–5% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Literature. Bible portions:2006.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use English [eng], especially educatedyoung and middle-age adults.

name: Trieng
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Jola-Kasa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also useFrench [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Many also useWolof [wol], as the language of commerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012).Also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov]. Used as L2 by Bandial [bqj], Ejamat [eja], Kuwaataay [cwt].

name: Sotho, Southern
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter, gradually phasing in English [eng] as the language of instruction in grades 6 and 7. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Grammar. Bible: 1878–1989.

name: Tagabawa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90%. Literature. Radio. Texts. NT: 2004.

name: Acoli
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in somesecondary schools, as ‘Lwo’, sharing materials with Alur [alz], Jopadhola [adh], Kumam [kdi],and Lango [laj]. Taught as ‘Lwo’ at 1 university. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos.Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1986.
Language Use: Home, market, church, office. Used by all. Most are young. Positiveattitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Kuku [ukv],Thur [lth].

name: Koalib
Language Development: Literature. NT: 1967–1994.
Language Use: Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Mazagway
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1972.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also useFrench [fra]. Some also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Some also use Daba [dbq]. Some also useGiziga [giz]. Some also use Mina [hna]. Used as L2 by Mina [hna].

name: Bonggi
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1992.
Language Use: Mixed use in Home, Friends, Religion, Work. Some young people, all adults.Positive attitudes. Also use Mapun [sjm]. Also use Molbog [pwm]. Also use Sabah Malay [msi].Also use Southern Sama [ssb]. Used as L2 by Molbog [pwm].

name: Gurani
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], used in Iran.
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Central Kurdish [ckb]. Mostalso use Iranian Persian [pes]. Also use Southern Kurdish [sdh].

name: Subanon, Western
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 39%. Literacy rate in L2: 39%. Multilingual education pilot program. Taught in a few primary and secondary schools. Literature. NT: 1996–2021.
Language Use: Shifting to Sabah Bisaya [bsy] (2023 S. Bulalang). Home, Community, Work, Religion, Education. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Many also use Sabah Bisaya [bsy]. Some also use Chavacano [cbk]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Tagalog [tgl]. Some also use Tausug [tsg].

name: Wakhi
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in Afghanistan. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], used in Tajikistan. Latin script [Latn], used in Pakistan, preferred script, not firmly established.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3%–15%. Pilot L1 literacy project ongoing (2012). Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Urdu [urd]. Some also use Dari [prs], especially men.

name: Guaraní, Mbyá
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 2004.
Language Use: Some also use Portuguese [por].

name: Maranao
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Taught as subject in all primary schools through grade 3 in Lanao del Sur and some municipalities in Lanao del Norte. Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 2013.
Language Use: Many code-switch between Maranao-Cebuano, Maranao-English, and Maranao-Filipino (2023 S. Mutia). Some of all ages, including some passive speakers among both children and adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tagalog [tgl]. Used as L2 by Southern Subanen [laa].

name: Kobon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–25%. Interest in L1 literacy increasing. Local school staff are regularly producing new material for use in the schools. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2005–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth. Used as L2 by Haruai [tmd].

name: Huambisa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Taught as subject inprimary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1975–2010.
Language Use: Most children acquire the language (Crevels 2007). All domains. Used byall. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Naga, Tangkhul
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 73% Meitei [mni], English [eng] (2001 census). Literature is based on the Ukhrul dialect. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1976–2014.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Mbembe, Tigon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. 5% can read and write. Used informally in education. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Limbum [lmp]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Naami [bzv]. Used as L2 by Kemedzung [dmo], Limbum [lmp], Naami [bzv], Sari [asj].

name: Busa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Busa and Hausa adult literacy programs.Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2005.
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cishingini [asg]. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Kyanga [tye], Laru [lan].

name: Aja (Benin)
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2, in 5 schools (2014SIL). Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 2010–2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, neighborhood, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Alsouse French [fra]. Also use Gen [gej]. Used as L2 by Saxwe Gbe [sxw].

name: Malila
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low. SIL has transition literacy work (Swahili to Malila), and some pre-school basic literacy classes. Literature. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Other language speakers moving into the area learn Malila. Most domains including church and politics. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Lagwan
Language Development: Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: All ages, but intergenerational transmission is weakening. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Used as L2 by Jina [jia].

name: Tamazight, Central Atlas
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn]. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng], developed in 2003, official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Men 25%, women 5%. Literature. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1919–1981.
Language Use: A major Berber language. Some young people, all adults. Also use Moroccan Arabic [ary], as L2.

name: Mixtec, Southeastern Nochixtlán
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%. Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1998–2020.
Language Use: Home. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa], bilingually, and generally prefer it.

name: Wushi
Language Development: Radio. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Lamnsoʼ [lns].

name: Javanese
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Javanese script[Java], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools. Fully developed. Bible: 1854–1994.
Language Use: Also use Musi [mui], especially in South Sumatra. Used as L2 by Javindo[jvd], Madura [mad], Osing [osi], Tengger [tes].

name: Zulgo-Gemzek
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1988–1997.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Many also use Merey [meq]. Some alsouse French [fra], as language of public education. Some also use Mafa [maf]. Also use AdamawaFulfulde [fub], in church, but with interpretation into Gemzek or Zulgo. Used as L2 by Mada[mxu], Matal [mfh], Merey [meq].

name: Tamajeq, Tayart
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Tifinagh (Berber) script [Tfng], called Shifinagh.
Language Development: Literature. Radio. NT: 1990–2003.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Algerian Saharan Arabic [aao], Tetserret [tez].

name: Apma
