Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Low. Literacy rate in L2: 80%–90%, at a basic level.Taught as subject in most primary schools in grades 1 and 2. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible portions: 1977.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. A few also use Hano [lml]. Used as L2 by Hano [lml], Ske [ske], Sowa [sww].

name: Dagaare, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught in primaryand secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Radio. Grammar. NT:2014.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Rarotongan
Language Development: Taught in primary schools in early grades only. Bible: 1851–1888.
Language Use: English [eng] preferred by the younger generation (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Penrhyn [pnh], Pukapuka [pkp].

name: Chuanqiandian Cluster Miao
Writing: Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, used between 1958–1960 and from 1981,experimental usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10% or less. Literacy rate in L2: 42% in MandarinChinese [cmn]. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Alsouse Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially the younger generation and urban residents. Used as L2 byBugan [bbh].

name: Helambu Sherpa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literacy motivation not high, except in English [eng]. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2000.
Language Use: Home; mixed use: Friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Also use Central Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi], viewing it as useful.

name: Konjo
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1914. Agency: Kikinzo Language and Culture Office.
Language Use: Home, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Most also use Tooro [ttj].

name: Mubami
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5% in English [eng]. Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Education, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use English [eng]. Also use Bamu [bcf]. Also use Gogodala [ggw]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Baoulé
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1998.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Abidji [abi], Attié [ati], Beng [nhb],Krobu [kxb], Ngen [gnj], Yaouré [yre].

name: Kinga
Language Development: Literature. Grammar. NT: 1961–2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Magoma [gmx].

name: Sranan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 1997–2016.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Dutch [nld]. Used as L2 by Arawak [arw], Aukan [djk], Carib [car], Dutch [nld], Hakka Chinese [hak], Kwinti [kww], Sarnami Hindustani [hns], Wayana [way], Yue Chinese [yue].

name: Bengali
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng], primary usage. Braille script [Brai]. Newascript [Newa], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in most tertiaryschools. Fully developed. Bible: 1832–2016.
Language Use: Used by all. A few also use War-Jaintia [aml]. Also use Chittagonian [ctg].

name: Makasar
Writing: Buginese script [Bugi]. Latin script [Latn]. Makasar script [Maka], no longer in use.
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1900–1999.
Language Use: Home, community, work (in rural areas). Some young people, all adults. Young people in the cities are shifting to Indonesian [ind] and Makassar Indonesian [mfp] (2019 B. Marshall). All also use Indonesian [ind]. Young people in the cities are shifting to Indonesian (2019 B. Marshall). All also use Makassar Indonesian [mfp]. Young people in the cities are shifting to Makassar Indonesian (2019 B. Marshall). Some also use Bugis [bug]. Used as L2 by Bugis [bug], Coastal Konjo [kjc].

name: Malayalam
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Braille script [Brai], used since 1998. Malayalam script [Mlym], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Kerala State, and Lakshadweep and Puducherry union territories. Fully developed. Bible: 1841–2004.
Language Use: Cochin Jews in Kerala speak Malayalam. Used as L2 by Allar [all], Aranadan [aaf], Attapady Kurumba [pkr], Irula [iru], Jennu Kurumba [xuj], Kadar [kej], Kalanadi [wkl], Kanikkaran [kev], Kodava [kfa], Kudiya [kfg], Kunduvadi [wku], Kurichiya [kfh], Mala Malasar [ima], Malapandaram [mjp], Malaryan [mjq], Malasar [ymr], Malavedan [mjr], Mannan [mjv], Moundadan Chetti [cty], Muduga [udg], Mullu Kurumba [kpb], Muthuvan [muv], Paliyan [pcf], Paniya [pcg], Pathiya [pty], Ravula [yea], Thachanadan [thn], Ullatan [ull], Urali [url], Wayanad Chetti [ctt].

name: Jumjum
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Orthography and some literacy materials produced. Literature. Dictionary.Grammar.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Uduk [udu].

name: Bakhtiari
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Persian [pes]. Literature. Dictionary.Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English[eng]. Also use Iranian Persian [pes]. Used as L2 by Dezfuli [def].

name: Ajië
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1922.
Language Use: Vigorous. Use as regional and church language decreasing with greater useof French [fra]. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Arhâ [aqr], Arhö [aok], Bwatoo [bwa], Orowe[bpk].

name: Mixtec, Juxtlahuaca
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Bola
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Literature. Grammar. NT:2011.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (van den Bergand Wiebe 2019). Some also use English [eng] (van den Berg and Wiebe 2019). Used as L2 by Bebeli[bek], Bulu [bjl].

name: Blang
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Tai Le script [Tale], used in Dehong and Lincang,Yunnan, China. Tai Tham (Lanna) script [Lana], used in Xishuangbanna, Yunnan, China. Thai script[Thai].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 77% (2000 census). Literature. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Lü [khb].Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Vo Wa [wbm]. Used as L2 by Lahu [lhu].

name: Buginese
Writing: Buginese script [Bugi], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Taught as subject in many primary schools. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar.Texts. Bible: 1900–1997.
Language Use: Vigorous. A few also use Makasar [mak], who live in Makassar city. Also useBalantak [blz]. Also use Fordata [frd], in a few villages. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2by Bungku [bkz], Enrekang [ptt], Indonesian Bajau [bdl], Kodeoha [vko], Koneq-koneq [cml],Limola [ley], Maiwa [wmm], Makasar [mak], Malimpung [mli], Mamuju [mqx], Moronene [mqn], Muna[mnb], Rahambuu [raz], Selayar [sly], Tolaki [lbw], Wotu [wtw].

name: Moronene
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary and secondary schools. Literature. Radio. NT: 2013.
Language Use: Vigorous in many villages. Occasional oral use in church, letter writing. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind], in some villages, especially some parents to their children. Also use Bugis [bug], in Poleang.

name: Aklanon
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 70%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Taught in primaryschools through grade 3. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1990–1996.
Language Use: Also use Hiligaynon [hil].

name: Koch
LITERACY_L2: Approximately 75% in any of the following languages:Assamese [asm], Bangla [ben], Garo [grt], English [eng], Hindi [hin], Rabha [rah], or Bodo[brx].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Approximately 75% in any of the following languages:Assamese [asm], Bangla [ben], Garo [grt], English [eng], Hindi [hin], Rabha [rah], or Bodo[brx]. Show a growing interest toward education (Singh 1994b). Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Non-Koch in Koch villages normally speak Koch. Only 6 of the 8endogamous groups still speak their mother tongue: Tintekiya, Wanang, Harigaya, Dasgaya, Chapra,and Koch-Rabha. Sankar and Satpariya have no known speakers. All domains. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use Boro [brx]. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Garo [grt]. Also use Hajong [haj]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali[npi]. Also use Rabha [rah].

name: Adhola
Language Development: Some NGOs are doing adult literacy (2021 SIL). Taught as subject insecondary schools, as ‘Lwo’, sharing materials with Acholi [ach], Alur [alz], Kumam [kdi], andLango [laj]. Taught as ‘Lwo’ at 1 university. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Texts.Bible: 2018.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most alsouse English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swh].

name: Hebrew
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Hebrew script [Hebr], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools in Jewish schools. Taught inmost tertiary schools. Fully developed. NT: 1537–2010. Agency: The Academy of the HebrewLanguage.
Language Use: Religious use (within the Jewish community) and everyday language.

name: Chuukese
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in Chuuk state. Dictionary. Texts. Bible:1989–2001.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Used as L2 by Mortlockese [mrl], Pááfang [pfa].

name: Nomaande
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Taught as subject in many primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Dictionary. NT: 2008.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra].

name: Kalasha
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran]. Latin script [Latn], used since 2000, primary usage.
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: In the south, Kalasha is being supplanted by Khowar [khw] or Kateviri [bsh]. Home, in-group communication in the north. Used by all. All also use Khowar [khw], in the south in the home, for in-group communication and elsewhere but with low proficiency; men in Birir do not speak it, but women there are learning the language. Many also use Urdu [urd], especially by women. Some also use Kateviri [bsh], especially in the south, in the home, and for in-group communication. Used as L2 by Kateviri [bsh].

name: Arabic (Eastern Egyptian Bedawi)
Language Development: TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.

name: Hre
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Radio.Dictionary. Texts. Bible: 2019.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Binandere
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3, in 17schools. Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1912–2021.
Language Use: Vigorous. Strong interest language preservation. All domains. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Also use Aeka [aez]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Ewage-Notu [nou]. Alsouse Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Zia [zia]. Used as L2 by Aeka [aez], Orokaiva [okv], Zia [zia].

name: Kafa
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used in Church literature. Latin script [Latn],official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 22%. Taught in primary and secondary schools throughgrade 4 and as subject thereafter. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2020.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Nayi [noz].

name: Mixtec, Jamiltepec
Language Development: Literature. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Used as L2 by Ixtayutla Mixtec [vmj].

name: Nyankole
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in some secondary schools, as Runyakitaara, sharing materials with Chiga [cgg]. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1964–1989.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Chiga [cgg]. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Ganda [lug]. Used as L2 by Chiga [cgg].

name: Delo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Texts. NT: 2006.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka]. Also use English [eng].

name: Manobo, Sarangani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 44%. Literacy rate in L2: 44%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1982.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Sarangani Blaan [bps].

name: Ndali
Language Development: SIL has transition literacy work (Swahili to Ndali). Literature. Texts. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Kurumba
Language Development: Younger generation over 50% literate, older generation less. Radio. NT:2018.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also useMuduga [udg]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Tuwuli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literature. Grammar. NT: 2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka], especially amongolder people (Harley 2005) (Harley 2005). Also use English [eng], especially among the young(Harley 2005). Also use Éwé [ewe], but decreasingly.

name: Nimadi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Radio. TV.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, except with government officials. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], in education, but generally with low proficiency. Used as L2 by Palya Bareli [bpx], Pauri Bareli [bfb], Rathwi Bareli [bgd].

name: Mualang
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Language shift reportedly taking place in the younger generation. Positive attitudes.

name: Azerbaijani (North)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used until 1920s. Braille script[Brai]. Cyrillic script [Cyrl], official usage in Dagestan. Latin script [Latn], official usagein Azerbaijan since 1992.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High. Taught in all primary and secondary schools, andalso taught as L2 in Russian [rus] language schools. Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar.Bible: 1891–2009.

name: Yale
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Literature. Texts. Bible portions: 1997–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially younger men. Used as L2 by Odiai [bhf].

name: Athpariya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2%. Taught in 5 mother-tongue multilingual educationschools since 2008. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT:2023.
Language Use: Home, religion; mixed use: Friends. Some young people, all adults. Positiveattitudes. Also use Nepali [npi], with some youth using it as an L1.

name: Oriya, Adivasi
LITERACY_L2: 34% for Scheduled Tribes in Vishakhapatnam District (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 7%. Literacy rate in L2: 34% for Scheduled Tribes in Vishakhapatnam District (2001 census). Literature. Dictionary. NT: 2011.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Bodo Parja [bdv], Bondo [bfw], Mukha-Dora [mmk], Parenga [pcj].

name: Arammba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 25%–50%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Taught in primary schools in early grades only, in 1 school. Literature. Texts. Bible portions: 2002–2003.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use English [eng]. Many also use Suki [sui]. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults. Used as L2 by Nama [nmx], Neme [nex].

name: Oriya, Desiya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 6%. Literature. Newspapers. NT: 2010–2020.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Bodo Gadaba [gbj], Gata’ [gaq], Mirgan [zrg], Pottangi OllarGadaba [gdb].

name: Panjabi, Western
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], primary usage, also called Shahmukhi. Khojki script [Khoj]. Lahnda (Landa) script [Qaaj], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Grammar. NT: 1819–1931.
Language Use: Educated younger generations living in cities opt to use Urdu [urd] and English [eng], and parents also encourage them to use Urdu or English even at home. Home, community, religious settings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Pashto [pst]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Marwari [mve]. Also use Northern Hindko [hno]. Also use Northern Pashto [pbu]. Also use Pahari-Potwari [phr]. Also use Saraiki [skr]. Also use Southern Hindko [hnd]. Also use Southern Pashto [pbt]. Also use Urdu [urd]. Used as L2 by Aer [aeq], Northern Hindko [hno], Sansi [ssi], Southern Hindko [hnd].

name: Nanai
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1884–2002.
Language Use: Severely endangered. Older adults only. Mixed attitudes, from negative tomildly positive. Motivated to use Russian [rus]. Those under 40 consider Nanai unhelpful inlife. Older generation pessimistic about possibility of preservation. Shifted to Russian [rus].Some also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], especially elderly.

name: Efik
Language Development: Literature. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1868–1985.
Language Use: The major dialect and language of the Ibibio-Efik group. Used in adulteducation, university courses. All domains. Used by all. Used as L2 by Anaang [anw],Deko-Dusanga [uya], Durop [krp], Efutop [ofu], Ekit [eke], Ibibio [ibb], Ibino [ibn], Ilue[ilv], Iyongiyong [bbs], Kiong [kkm], Legbo [agb], Lenyima [ldg], Nde-Nsele-Nta [ndd], Odut[oda], Oro [orx], Umon [umm].

name: Zarma
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Braille script [Brai]. Latin script[Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in primary schools in early grades only in Zarma-speaking areas.Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1990.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Western Niger Fulfulde [fuh].

name: Wolof
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], called Ajami. Garay script [Gara], limited usage. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1988–2010.
Language Use: Youth are shifting to Urban Wolof. All domains. Many also use French [fra], as the language of education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Used as L2 by Badyara [pbp], Bainouk-Gunyaamolo [bcz], Bainouk-Samik [bcb], Balanta-Ganja [bjt], Bambara [bam], Bandial [bqj], Bayot [bda], Casamance Creole [pov], Ejamat [eja], Gusilay [gsl], Hassaniyya [mey], Jalunga [yal], Jola-Fonyi [dyo], Jola-Kasa [csk], Kabuverdianu [kea], Karon [krx], Kerak [hhr], Krio [kri], Kuwaataay [cwt], Laalaa [cae], Mandinka [mnk], Mandjak [mfv], Mankanya [knf], Ménik [tnr], Mlomp [mlo], Ndut [ndv], Noon [snf], Oniyan [bsc], Paloor [fap], Pulaar [fuc], Pular [fuf], Saafi-Saafi [sav], Serer-Sine [srr], Soninke [snk], Wamey [cou], Western Maninkakan [mlq], Xasonga [kao], Zenaga [zen].

name: Zinza
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literature. Bible portions: 1930–2012.
Language Use: Vital language where Zinza are the majority. In other areas possible shift to Sukuma [suk]. Home. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Sukuma [suk]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Naga, Sangtam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% (2001 census). Literature. Bible: 1995.
Language Use: Also use Ao Naga [njo]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nagamese [nag].

name: Gaelic (Scots)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50% (1971 census). Sabhal Mòr Ostaig is a Gaeliccollege where students and faculty use only Scottish Gaelic. In bilingual areas Gaelic usuallyis the language of instruction for most primary subjects. Taught in a few primary and secondaryschools, in Scottish-medium education in Scotland. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio.TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1801–2016.
Language Use: Resurgence of interest in Scottish Gaelic in 1990s. A number of childrenlearn the language but there are serious problems in language maintenance even in the core areas(Salminen 2007). Reportedly only 1 L1 speaker of Perthshire Gaelic (2019 N. Rees). Home, church,community.

name: Brahui
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant[Aran], primary usage. Latin script [Latn], used in one newspaper.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1998.
Language Use: Also use Western Balochi [bgn]. Used as L2 by Western Balochi [bgn].

name: Atta (Pamplona)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–25%. Literature. NT:1996.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Used as L2 by Faire Atta [azt], PudtolAtta [atp].

name: Dagik
Language Development: Orthography available and literacy materials in use among urban diasporaspeakers. Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Minangkabau
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 1996.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Pekal [pel].

name: Luri, Southern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Persian [pes]. Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, commerce, some media. Used by all. Most also use Iranian Persian [pes]. Used as L2 by Iranian Persian [pes], Kashkay [qxq].

name: Teressa
Language Development: Radio.

name: Raeto-Romance
Language Development: Taught in primary and secondary schools in Romansh speaking area (Graubünden canton). Newspapers. Bible: 1679–1953.
Language Use: Many children learn the language but most become more fluent in German (Salminen 2007). Also use Standard German [deu].

name: Mansaka
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1975.
Language Use: Used as L2 by Mandaya [mry].

name: Iceve-Maci
Language Development: Radio. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes].Also use Denya [anv], especially older men. Also use Evant [bzz]. Used as L2 by Iyive [uiv].

name: Tese
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials developed. Literature.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Merey
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2012.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use French [fra]. Some also use Zulgo-Gemzek [gnd]. A few also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. A few also use Mbuko [mqb]. A few also use North Mofu [mfk]. Used as L2 by Zulgo-Gemzek [gnd].

name: Njyem
Language Development: 50 can read it, 10 can write it. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2002.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes. Some also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Baka [bkc].

name: Limba, West-Central
Language Development: Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in secondary schools in grades 7–9. Dictionary. NT: 1966–2011.

name: Rundi
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 55%. Taught in all primary and secondary schools in grades 1–4 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1967.
Language Use: Hima is an ethnic group speaking Rundi or Rwanda [kin]. Home, work, official. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Mbosi
Language Development: Small amount of literacy in place. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar.
Language Use: Primarily oral use. French [fra] is used for reading and writing. All domains. Some young people, all adults. Few younger users. Positive attitudes. Also use French [fra]. Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Teke-Tege [teg].

name: Mandar
Writing: Buginese script [Bugi], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Among the Mandar ethnic group. Loss of Mandar is not occuring among other groups who use it for trade. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Budong-Budong [bdx], Dakka [dkk], Koneq-koneq [cml], Mamuju [mqx], Pannei [pnc], Ulumanda’ [ulm].

name: Tày
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie]. Used as L2 by Green Gelao [giq].

name: Ingush
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], no longer in use. Cyrillic script[Cyrl], primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 2005–2021.
Language Use: Also use Russian [rus].

name: Võro
Language Development: Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1686–1905. Promotion and revival of Võro, which includes teachers, politicians, poets, geographers, and administrators, attempting to increase the usage (2008 S. Iva).
Language Use: Rapid shift to Standard Estonian [ekk]. Home, workplace. Some young people, all adults. Few children; most are elderly speakers living in rural areas.

name: Madurese
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40%. Literacy higher among Bangkalon. Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1994.
Language Use: Vigorous on Madura Island and East Java. All domains. Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Javanese [jav].

name: Päri
Language Development: Literature. NT: 2003.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Hungarian
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools. Taught in tertiary schools.Fully developed. Bible: 1590–1991.
Language Use: Some also use English [eng] (European Commission 2006).

name: Bai, Central
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from 9th century, limiteduse in folk songs and ritual texts, favoured by older people. Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based,used since 1982, revised in 1993, experimental, small-scale use in education, administration,and literature.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. 1 experimental program. Literature. Radio.Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also useMandarin Chinese [cmn]. A few also use Anong [nun]. A few also use Lisu [lis]. A few also useNaxi [nxq]. Used as L2 by Lisu [lis], Naxi [nxq], Northern Pumi [pmi], Southern Pumi [pmj],Zaiwa [atb], Zauzou [zal].

name: Quechua, Cusco
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 62%. Taught in some primary schools in early grades only. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1988–2004.
Language Use: City people generally want children to speak primarily Spanish [spa]. Used by all. Most also use Spanish [spa], especially in urban areas, but also in rural areas. Used as L2 by Arequipa-La Unión Quechua [qxu].

name: Muna
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools. Literature. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2004.
Language Use: Mixed in all domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Some also use Tolaki [lbw]. Some also use Wolio [wlo]. A few also use Bugis [bug]. A few also use Wawonii [wow]. Used as L2 by Liabuku [lix], Pancana [pnp], Taloki [tlk], Wolio [wlo].

name: Kovai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–40%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–60% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Literature. Bible portions: 1993–2008.
Language Use: Vigorous. Retained despite pressure from Tok Pisin [tpi]. Use in first 3 years of primary education and geographic isolation on an island help language maintenance. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], particularly with outsiders (health personnel, government officials, including police) and in church services along with Kovai. Used as L2 by Karnai [bbv].

name: Sama, Pangutaran
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 25%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–35%. Literature. Dictionary. NT: 1994.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Oral use in education for explanations. Market. Some written use in communications. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tausug [tsg]. Some also use Filipino [fil]. Some also use Malay [zlm], especially those who have been to Malaysia. Used as L2 by Southern Sama [ssb].

name: Meohang, Western
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: The language is nearly extinct in the village of Tamku, the largest settlement in the area, where many ex-Gurkha pensioners live. Home; mixed use: Friends, religion, work. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Kulung [kle]. Also use Lohorung [lbr]. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Yamphu
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Language passed on to children but being steadily replaced by Nepali [npi] (Toba et al 2005). Religion. Some young people, all adults. Also use Nepali [npi], bilingually.

name: Sangil
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%. Literature. Bible portions: 1981–2011.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Cebuano [ceb], with proficiency. Used as L2 by Sarangani Blaan [bps].

name: Basque
Language Development: Taught in most primary and secondary schools. Government surveyco-published by governments of 4 Spain provinces and 3 France provinces in Basque territory says94.4% of students studied Basque in 2017. Fully developed. Bible: 1865–1998.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Mukulu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2019.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu], but with low proficiency.

name: Gapapaiwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in English [eng]. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 2009.
Language Use: All domains except with outsiders, some church services. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Anuki [aui]. Many also use Are [mwc]. Many also use Ghayavi [bmk]. Some also use English [eng], especially young people. Also use Wedau [wed], especially very old adults. Used as L2 by Dima [jma], Ghayavi [bmk].

name: Scots
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 97% in English [eng]. Ulster Scots has a development group. Literature. Periodicals. Dictionary. NT: 1901–1984.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Most also use English [eng].

name: Hanga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1983.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Also use Gonja [gjn].

name: Onobasulu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 43%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. 300 can read it, 200 can write it. Literature. Bible portions: 1996–2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Oral and written use in preschool and adult literacy. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Edolo [etr]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Huli [hui]. Also use Kaluli [bco]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Edolo [etr].

name: Tsotso
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Avokaya
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools through grade 3. Literature. NT:2002.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Baka [bdh]. Also useMündü [muh], especially near Maridi. Also use Zande [zne]. Used as L2 by Baka [bdh], Mündü[muh].

name: Tunica
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. The Tunica Language Revitalization Project has received a grant that would allow 5 young adults to have the opportunity to learn to speak and teach their language. Also, full digital transcriptions of 2,000 handwritten pages from the 1930s notebooks of Mary Haas’ fieldwork with the last known Tunica speaker, Sesostrie Youchigant, have been created (2020 J. Maxwell). Agency: Tunica-Biloxi Language and Culture Revitalization Program.
Language Use: Shifted to English [eng].

name: Eastern Bontok
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 67%. Literacy rate in L2: 67%. Literature. Grammar.Bible: 2022.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Mayo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 2%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Government scholarships offered to young people who demonstrate Mayo proficiency. Older adults only. Mixed attitudes. Shifted to Spanish [spa].

name: Finongan
LITERACY_L2: 60% in Tok Pisin [tpi], lessthan 5% in English [eng].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 60% in Tok Pisin [tpi], lessthan 5% in English [eng]. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 2005–2014.
Language Use: All domains except church, where there is mixed use with Tok Pisin [tpi]and Kâte [kmg]. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also useEnglish [eng]. Some also use Kâte [kmg], especially older adults. Used as L2 by Doloman [mhf].

name: Sam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 45%. Literacy rate in L2: 35%–65% in Tok Pisin [tpi]. Literature. Bible portions: 2005–2020.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Mixed use: church and school, where Sam is mixed with Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Bongu [bpu] (Rueck and Jore 2003). Some also use Dubuporo [ynl] (Rueck and Jore 2003). Some also use Soq [mdc] (Rueck and Jore 2003).

name: Pokomo, Upper
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Advocacy to introduce L1 for lower primary school. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Literature. Videos. NT: 2003–2004.
Language Use: Home, social gatherings, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kigiryama [nyf]. Also use Swahili [swh], about 75% somewhat bilingually. Used as L2 by Kigiryama [nyf], Kiwilwana [mlk], Waata [ssn].

name: Oromo, West Central
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], used until 1990s. Latin script [Latn], used since1990s.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 22%. Taught in primary and secondary schools in grades1–10. Taught as a major at the university level. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. TV. Dictionary.Grammar. Bible: 1899–1998.
Language Use: Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Amharic [amh], Anfillo [myo], Berta[wti], Borna [bwo], Gumuz [guk], Gwama [kmq], Hozo [hoz], Komo [xom], Mawes Aasse [myf], Seze[sze], Yemsa [jnj].

name: Gayo
Language Development: Literature. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Home, neighborhood, clinic, market, ceremonies, village meetings. Someyoung people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Meitei
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], unofficial usage. Meitei Mayek script [Mtei].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 73% (2005 BI). Literacy rate in L2: 69% for Manipur (2001 census). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 5 and as subject thereafter in Manipur state. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1984–2019.
Language Use: Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Aimol [aim], Anal [anm], Chiru [cdf], Chothe Naga [nct], Gangte [gnb], Hmar [hmr], Inpui Naga [nkf], Kharam Naga [kfw], Koireng [nkd], Kom [kmm], Lamkang [lmk], Mao Naga [nbi], Maram Naga [nma], Monsang Naga [nmh], Moyon Naga [nmo], Purum [pub], Tarao Naga [tro], Thado Chin [tcz], Thangal Naga [nki].

name: Kangean
Language Development: Radio. Texts.

name: Mawa (Chad)
Language Development: Adult literacy ongoing in a few villages. Literature. Bible portions: 2022.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Most also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Some also use Kenga [kyq].

name: Cuvok
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Used informally in education. Literature. Radio.Grammar. Texts. NT: 2022.
Language Use: Home, village, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use AdamawaFulfulde [fub]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Mafa [maf]. Also use Mefele [mfj]. Also useMofu-Gudur [mif].

name: Belanda Viri
Language Development: Literature. Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Belanda Bor [bxb].Used as L2 by Belanda Bor [bxb].

name: Tharu, Dangaura
LITERACY_L2: All Tharu as an ethnic group 28% (1991 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: All Tharu as an ethnic group 28% (1991 census). Literature. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2018.
Language Use: High vitality but increasing Nepali [npi] loanwords. Home, friends, religion. Used by all. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Nepali [npi], especially educated people, men, and young people, and to a lesser extent women and older people.

name: Spiti Bhoti
Language Development: Most literates read Hindi. Some older people and Buddhist monks and nuns, read Tibetan. Literature. Radio.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Mon
LITERACY_L1: Some literacy among the older generation; very low literacy rates among those under 40.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Some literacy among the older generation; very low literacy rates among those under 40. Taught in some Buddhist monasteries in both Myanmar and Thailand. Some literacy efforts made on Thailand-Myanmar border. Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1928.
Language Use: Vigorous in some rural areas and in Three Pagodas border area. Low or no usage in urban centers; some language shift to Burmese. Many domains in some communities; only among the elderly, in the monastery, or not at all in other communities. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Burmese [mya].

name: Time
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 6%. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Taught as subject in secondary schools in grades 7–9. NT: 1868–1992.
Language Use: Primary language of central Sierra Leone. Also use English [eng]. Also use Krio [kri]. Used as L2 by Bullom So [buy].

name: Sos Kundi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%. Vernacular literature available and in use in church. Literature. Dictionary.
Language Use: Mixed use in all domains except when communicating with outsiders, where Tok Pisin [tpi] is used. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from positive to neutral. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also use Mevembet [keh] (Richardson and Tupper 2013). Used as L2 by Mevembet [keh].

name: Kangri
Writing: Devanagari script [Deva]. Takri (Tankri, Takari) script [Takr], no longer in use.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Educators promote Kangri. Acceptability of other Pahari dialects is high. Literature. Radio. Grammar. NT: 2017.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, work, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use English [eng]. Also use Eastern Punjabi [pan]. Also use Hindi [hin], for communicating with outsiders. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Kurumba, Betta
LITERACY_L2: 10%–15% in Tamil Nadu, 15%–20% in Karnataka, 40%–45% in Kerala.
Writing: Kannada script [Knda]. Malayalam script [Mlym]. Tamil script [Taml].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10%–15% in Tamil Nadu, 15%–20% in Karnataka, 40%–45% in Kerala. Favorable attitude toward literacy. Literature. Grammar.
Language Use: Central Institute of Indian Languages lists Betta Kurumba as endangered. It is being studied by Annamalai University. Home, work, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].

name: Kaluli
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%. Taught in primaryschools in early grades only, in 2 schools. Dictionary. NT: 2023.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also useEnglish [eng]. Used as L2 by Eibela [ail], Kasua [khs], Odoodee [kkc], Onobasulu [onn], Sonia[siq].

name: Logorik
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials produced. Literature.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Xhosa
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Literacy rate in L2: 20%–25%. Taught as subject in many primary and secondary schools from grade 4. Taught in primary schools through grade 3. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1859.
Language Use: Also use Southern Sotho [sot]. Also use Swati [ssw]. Also use Zulu [zul].

name: Pashayi, Southeast
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab], used in print. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], used in handwriting and for book titles.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Less than 20%. Many books for early readers have been produced by the Pashai people as part of their literacy program. The Afghanistan Ministry of Education has produced Southeast Pashai language textbooks for first through twelfth grades. But as of November 2021, these books had not yet been distributed to schools. Literature. Radio. Grammar. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, all informal settings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Northern Pashto [pbu]. Also use Southern Pashto [pbt].

name: Halang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Radio. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1970–1972.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Haya
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 2002.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Malagasy, Plateau
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Latin script [Latn], primary usage.
Language Development: Taught in all primary and secondary schools through all of primary school and as subject thereafter. Fully developed. Bible: 1835–2011.

name: Karen, S'gaw
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use. Myanmar (Burmese) script [Mymr].
Language Development: Some literacy classes. Literature. Periodicals. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1853–2004.
Language Use: Most communities vigorous; some shift toward Burmese [mya]. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Pwo Eastern Karen [kjp]. Also use Pwo Western Karen [pwo]. Used as L2 by Bwe Karen [bwe], Eastern Kayah [eky], Geba Karen [kvq], Geko Karen [ghk], Kawyaw [kxf], Kayan [pdu], Kayaw [kvl], Mobwa Karen [jkm], Paku Karen [jkp], Western Kayah [kyu], Wewaw [wea], Yintale [kvy].

name: Pyen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% In Lahu [lhu]and / or possibly Shan [shn]. Orthography revision planned in preparation for literacy classes. Literature. Grammar. Bible portions: 2011.
Language Use: Small population but vigorous use. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Lahu [lhu]. Many also use Shan [shn]. A few also use Burmese [mya]. A few also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Xinan Guanhua (Southwestern Mandarin).

name: Dizi
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], no longer in use. Latin script [Latn], used since 2009, official usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 17%. Kindergarten and adult literacy programs using Dizin as medium of instruction are piloted (2021 SIL). Taught in primary and secondary schools through grade 4 and as subject thereafter. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2024.
Language Use: Home, church, market, courts, government meetings (sometimes with interpretation). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Chittagonian
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng],primary usage. Latin script [Latn].
Language Development: Lower literacy rate than most of the country. TV. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Home, family, religion. Many also use Bengali [ben], especially educatedpeople who understand it but are not comfortable using it. Women in rural villages withoutaccess to television do not understand Bengali. Used as L2 by Bengali [ben], Chakma [ccp], Marma[rmz], Mru [mro], Rakhine [rki], Rohingya [rhg], Tippera [tpe].

name: Cinda-Regi-Tiyal
Language Development: Adult transition literacy classes. Taught as subject in a few primaryschools. Literature. Bible portions: 2017.
Language Use: Hausa [hau] and English [eng] used in schools. Home. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. All also use Hausa [hau], except some elderly women. Also use English [eng].

name: Nong Zhuang
LITERACY_L1: A few teachers and linguists can read the recent Yunnan government approved experimental orthography.
LITERACY_L2: Rapidly increasing due to free education begun in 2008, including women and girls.
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity. Latin script [Latn], used in 1984–1990s and from 2006, experimental use in education and official publications.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: A few teachers and linguists can read the recent Yunnan government approved experimental orthography. Literacy rate in L2: Rapidly increasing due to free education begun in 2008, including women and girls. In 2011, 300 Nong 7th graders received a few hours of Nong instruction. Radio. Texts. NT: 2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Used as L2 by Bugan [bbh], Dai Zhuang [zhd], Guibian Zhuang [zgn], Lachi [lbt], Qabiao [laq], Thopho [ytp], Zokhuo [yzk].

name: Jiarong
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible portions: 1932.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes, but intellectualsworry about diminishing use. Most also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. A few also use CentralTibetan [bod]. A few also use Northern Qiang [cng].

name: Muong
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–70%. Radio. Dictionary. NT: 2020.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Mixtec, Alcozauca
Language Development: Literature. Dictionary. Bible portions: 1997–2009.
Language Use: Home, friends, work. Used by all.

name: Hakö
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 75%–100%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught inprimary schools in early grades only, in 1 school. Radio. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Petats [pex].

name: Ngomba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%. Used informally in education. Literature. Radio.NT: 2017.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use French [fra].Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use Ngombale [nla]. Some also use Ngiemboon[nnh]. Also use Medumba [byv]. Used as L2 by Ngombale [nla].

name: Bisu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90%. Literacy classes held at weekend in Doi Chompu.Oral and written materials developed. Literature. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2015.
Language Use: Used by all. All children learn the language along with Northern Thai [nod]from birth, but since some pre-school age children attend daycare in Northern Thai [nod]speaking facilities, there is some concern that the children at that age will develop apreference for Northern Thai [nod] over Bisu (Person 2005). Also use Northern Thai [nod],especially younger generations.

name: Ga
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%–60%. Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%. Taught inprimary and secondary schools through grade 3 and as subject thereafter. Literature. Dictionary.Texts. Bible: 1866–1997.
Language Use: Major language of Accra. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Nawdm [nmz].

name: Yongnan Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, especially in rural homes when no outsiders are present. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], particularly the southwestern dialect. Also use Yue Chinese [yue], especially in business, education, government, market, and other domains. Many are partially or fully bilingual in one or more dialects.

name: Mankanya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 70%. A national organization promotes adult L1 literacy and language use in churches. Literature. Radio. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Home, local market, friends, work, religion, music. Some of all ages. Growing shift towards Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], particularly among children of mixed marriages, and those from families who moved to the capital of Bissau for education and economic opportunity (2022 I. Gruitibna). Neutral attitudes. Most also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language of interethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Many also use Portuguese [por], as the language of education and communication with foreigners. Some also use Balanta [ble]. Some also use Mandjak [mfv]. Some also use Papel [pbo].

name: Marama
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools. Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Niuean
Language Development: Taught in all primary schools in early grades and as subject thereafter. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1904.

name: Manobo, Ilianen
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–20%. Literature. NT: 1989. Agency: Erumanen ne Menuvu Educational and Cultural Center.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Maguindanaon [mdh].

name: Kendayan
Language Development: Radio. Dictionary. Texts.
Language Use: Widespread. Used as L2 by Bakati’ [bei], Benyadu’ [byd], Gerai [gef], Rara Bakati’ [lra], Sanggau [scg], Sara Bakati’ [sre], Semandang [sdq].

name: Kipsigis
Language Development: Radio.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Buriat, Russia
Language Development: Those on both sides of Lake Baikal are fully literate in the literaryvariety. Taught as subject in some primary and secondary schools, mostly in rural areas in theBuryatia republic only. Literature. Newspapers. Dictionary. Grammar. Bible: 1846.
Language Use: Children in rural areas usually learn Buriat, but in cities Russian [rus]is often spoken even between Buriat speakers (Salminen 2007). Home, community. Some youngpeople, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Russian [rus], especially younger people inthe cities. Used as L2 by Evenki [evn], Khamnigan Mongol [ykh].

name: Luba-Lulua
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: More than 60% among Christians. Literacy rate in L2: 90% in French [fra]. Taught in most primary and secondary schools through grade 2 and as subject thereafter in the south-central part of the country. Periodicals. Radio. TV. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. Bible: 1927–1996.
Language Use: Home, Community, Special cultural events, Technology and media; Mixed: Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Many also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Many also use French [fra]. Many also use Lingala [lin]. A few also use Kituba [ktu]. Used as L2 by Bindji [bpj], Chokwe [cjk], Lele [lel], Lunda [lun], Tetela [tll].

name: Bahing
Language Development: Bahing orthography introduced through community-based development efforts.Two books published (2009). Bahing orthography being promoted for use by the whole Bahingcommunity. Literature. Periodicals. Radio. NT: 2016. Agency: Bahing Kirat Mulukhim.
Language Use: Reportedly still used often by younger generation. Shift to Nepali [npi]relatively low (Winter and Hansson 1991); High vitality (Lee et al 2005). Home, friends,religion, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Nepali [npi] (Lee et al 2005).Used as L2 by Bantawa [bap], Nepali [npi], Thulung [tdh], Wambule [wme].

name: Marwari (India)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Literature. Newspapers. Radio. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 1820–2023.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin], especially educated people.

name: Bamu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Taught in primaryschools in early grades only, in 15 schools. Dictionary. Texts. Bible portions: 1952–2007.
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], only males over 60 and someyoung men. A few also use English [eng], but it is very basic, used for communication withoutsiders. A few also use Tok Pisin [tpi], but only those who have worked at logging camps faroutside the language area. Used as L2 by Foia Foia [ffi], Hoyahoya [hhy], Mubami [tsx], Tabo[knv].

name: Kwamera
LITERACY_L2: Most people read and write in Bislama [bis].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Most people read and write in Bislama [bis]. Elderly and very young are illiterate. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–3. Literature. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1890–2013.
Language Use: Home, Community, Religion; Mixed: Work, Education. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes, although some criticize the effects Bislama [bis] is having on their language. Most also use Bislama [bis]. Some also use Lenakel [tnl]. Some also use Whitesands [tnp]. A few also use Southwest Tanna [nwi].

name: Idakho-Isukha-Tiriki
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: About 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Taught assubject in some primary schools. Literature. Bible: 2014.
Language Use: Home, community, religious services. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Abung
Writing: Latin script [Latn], primary usage. Kaganga script [Rjng], historicalusage.
Language Development: Literature.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind],especially in education, religion, and civil domains.

name: Amharic
Writing: Braille script [Brai]. Ethiopic script [Ethi], primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 28%. Taught in primary and secondary schools in grades1–10. Taught as a major at the university level. Fully developed. Bible: 1840–2013.
Language Use: All domains. Some also use West Central Oromo [gaz]. Also use Eastern Oromo[hae]. Also use Standard Arabic [arb]. Also use Tigrigna [tir].

name: Lü
LITERACY_L1: 84% literate in any language (2000 census, Dainationality).
Writing: New Tai Lue script [Talu], used in Yunnan Province, China. Tai Tham (Lanna)script [Lana], still used by some, particularly in Buddhist monasteries in Yunnan Province,China.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 84% literate in any language (2000 census, Dainationality). Given that Tai Lü has a traditional script and tradition of literacy, the literacyfigure probably includes significant percentages literate in Lü Scripts, as well as percentageseducated in Chinese, as well as some literate in both languages. Taught as subject in someprimary schools. Taught in one university. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. TV.Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1933.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Jingpho[kac]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Some schools teach in it exclusively. Used as L2 by Akeu[aeu], Blang [blr], Buyuan Jinuo [jiy], Hani [hni], Lahu [lhu], Laomian [lwm], Lisu [lis],Ruching Palaung [pce], Sangkong [sgk], Vo Wa [wbm], Youle Jinuo [jiu].

name: Konkomba
Writing: Braille script [Brai], used since 1990. Latin script [Latn], used since 1964, primary usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. Literature. Dictionary. Bible: 1998–2009.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Oniyan [bsc].

name: Beembe
Language Development: Literature. Videos. Dictionary. Grammar. Texts. NT: 2014.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Tsimshian
Language Development: Taught in school programs and through University of Northern British Columbia (Golla 2007). Dictionary. Grammar. Bible portions: 1885–1898.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to English [eng]. Used as L2 by Nisga’a [ncg].

name: Susuami
Language Use: Home. Elderly only. All shifted to Angaataha [agm] (Wurm 2007).

name: Khua
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Dibo
Language Use: Those living among the Gbari [gby] no longer speak their own language(Blench and Zeitlyn 1990). Used as L2 by Koro Nulu [vkn], Koro Zuba [vkz].

name: Muria, Eastern
Language Development: Majority are illiterate.
Language Use: Vigorous. Religion, work; mixed use: home, village. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use Chhattisgarhi [hne]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Halbi [hlb]. Also useHindi [hin]. Also use Odia [ory].

name: Paynamar
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2015).

name: Arawum
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Siroi [ssd]. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Danaru
Language Use: Children usually learn Tok Pisin [tpi] first. Some young people, alladults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use Kobuka [urg], especially adults 30 andolder. Some also use Wia [ssj].

name: Rempi
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Ngaing [nnf], Nobonob [gaw].

name: Kafoa
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Malay (individual language)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Latin script [Latn].
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Standard Malay [zsm]. Used as L2 by Baba Malay [mbf], Batek [btq], Central Berawan [zbc], Central Melanau [mel], Cheq Wong [cwg], Daro-Matu Melanau [dro], Duano [dup], Jah Hut [jah], Jehai [jhi], Kensiu [kns], Kintaq [knq], Lanoh [lnh], Mah Meri [mhe], Malaccan Malay Creole [ccm], Malaccan Portuguese Creole [mcm], Minriq [mnq], Mintil [mzt], Murik [mxr], Negeri Sembilan Malay [zmi], Orang Kanaq [orn], Remun [lkj], Sabüm [sbo], Salako [knx], Semai [sea], Semaq Beri [szc], Semelai [sza], Southern Sama [ssb], Tamil [tam], Temiar [tea], Temoq [tmo], Toraja [sda], Ukit [umi], Vaie [bny].

name: Ta'oih, Upper
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all, in some villages. Positive attitudes. Some also use Lao [lao]. Also use Eastern Bru [bru]. Also use Pacoh [pac]. Also use Southern Katang [sct]. Used as L2 by Lower Ta’oih [tto].

name: Gbaya-Bozoum
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Yi, Eastern Nisu
Language Use: Language is active in areas with high concentrations of Nisu. Language use higher for older people, women, uneducated men, or villages further removed from main roads. Nisu living in cities or counties are generally Sinicized. Many parents teach their children the Chinese local dialect as L1 so they can do well in school. There is increasing borrowing of lexical items from Chinese. Code switching between Nisu and Chinese is common. Many men and women spend part of the year working in predominantly Chinese towns or cities. Home, in the fields, with village friends and relatives. Some of all ages. Neutral attitudes. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn], a local dialect, spoken with outsiders, non-Nisu government officials, non-Nisu markets, or elementary school teachers. Also use Northern Nisu [yiv], which village children eventually learn. Used as L2 by Hlersu [hle], Northern Nisu [yiv].

name: Nawaru
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Yareba [yrb].

name: Usku
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Under 5% in Indonesian [ind].
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Home, friends. Older adults only. Positive attitudes. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Mariri
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Tapirapé
Language Development: Taught as subject in primary schools.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Portuguese [por].

name: Kobo
Language Use: Home; limited use in church. Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Guibei Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes.

name: Lombo
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Bayono
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–10% in Indonesian [ind], semiliterate.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Some also use Indonesian [ind],especially young adults and children who use it for basic communication with neighboring groups.

name: Mukha-Dora
LITERACY_L2: 34%–42% for Scheduled Tribes in Vishakhapatnam, Srikakulam, Vizianagaram districts (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 34%–42% for Scheduled Tribes in Vishakhapatnam, Srikakulam, Vizianagaram districts (2001 census).
Language Use: Use Telugu [tel] as L1 (Singh 1994b). Also use Adivasi Oriya [ort]. Also use English [eng].

name: Wutung
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Those who marry into the community attain passive fluency in Wutung but don’t learn to speak it (Marmion 2010). Used by all. All also use English [eng] (Marmion 2010). All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Marmion 2010). Many also use Indonesian [ind] (Marmion 2010). Some also use Dumo [vam] (Marmion 2010). Some also use Skou [skv] (Marmion 2010).

name: Mixtec, Yoloxochitl
Language Use: All domains, not involving outsiders. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa], in one bilingual primary school.

name: Waruna
Language Use: Also use Gogodala [ggw].

name: Auwe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Atta (Pudtol)
Language Use: Also use Ibanag [ibg]. Also use Pamplona Atta [att].

name: Cutchi-Swahili
Language Development: All can read and write because they went to school where Swahili [swh] isused as a language of instruction.
Language Use: L1 of some Gujarati Muslims who came from Zanzibar. Asian Swahili is usedby other Asians to communicate with non-English speaking Africans and other Asians who share nocommon language. Home. Some young people, all adults. Many also use Omani Arabic [acx]. Somealso use English [eng]. Some also use Swahili [swa]. Some also use Swahili [swh].

name: Gwa
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Hamap
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Ihievbe
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm] (Decker et al 2021q).

name: Ndunda
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Ede Ica
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 30%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in French [fra].
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Standard Arabic[arb]. Also use Yoruba [yor].

name: Latu
Language Use: Many shifting to Saparua [spr].

name: Minanibai
Language Use: Vitality status highly questionable. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Ikobi [meb], or other local languages. Also use Mouwase [jmw].

name: Piamatsina
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Bislama [bis].
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Home, Community, Work; Mixed: Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. Some also use French [fra].

name: Oloma
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. All also use English [eng]. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Many also use Yoruba [yor]. Some also use Okpe [oke].

name: Pitcairn-Norfolk
Language Use: Valued for identity preservation. It is in a diglossic relationship with standard British English [eng] (Wurm 2007). Also use English [eng].

name: Kaytetye
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use English [eng]. Many also useKriol [rop].

name: Jimi (Nigeria)
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022d). A fewalso use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022d). A few also use Gera [gew] (Decker et al 2022d).

name: Romanian, Istro
Language Use: Adults only. No children and few younger speakers (Salminen 2007). All shifting to Croatian [hrv] (Salminen 2007). All shifting to Serbian [srp] (Salminen 2007).

name: Malasanga
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Mato [met], especially adult men. Used as L2 by Nukna [klt].

name: Umeda
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kauwera
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Lasalimu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Kumbewaha [xks], Tukang Besi North [khc], Tukang Besi South [bhq].

name: Kinuku
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Rishiwa [rsw].

name: Krache
Language Development: High level of school attendance. Texts.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Akan [aka].

name: Yabong
Language Use: All domains except market. Mixed use: religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Gray et al 2015).

name: Vono
Language Use: Used as L2 by Rishiwa [rsw].

name: Ndendeule
Language Use: Little comprehension of other languages. Used by all.

name: Som
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Kutong [skm]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Guérin 2017). Also use Wantoat [wnc]. Also use Yopno [yut]. Used as L2 by Kutong [skm].

name: Sinsauru
Language Use: Mixed use: Home, community, religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially youth.

name: Haigwai
Language Use: Home, Community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Tok Pisin[tpi]. Also use Buhutu [bxh]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Suau[swp]. Also use Tawala [tbo]. Also use Wedau [wed]. Used as L2 by Unubahe [unu].

name: Zapotec, Ayoquesco
Language Use: Most vigorous in Nexila where 52% speak Zapotec. Some young people, all adults. All ages in Santa Cruz Nexila. Positive attitudes. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nyindu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%.
Language Use: Home, market. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Mixtec, Northwest Oaxaca
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Tai Loi
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya], especially educated young people. Also use Lü [khb], especially adults. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Bile
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, alladults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].Some also use English [eng].

name: Las Delicias Zapotec
Language Use: Home, church.

name: Mvanip
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Voro
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Putukwam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Bekwarra [bkv].Also use English [eng]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm].

name: Fwâi
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Ts'ün-Lao
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Babango
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. All alsouse Lingala [lin], taught in primary schools. Many also use French [fra]. A few also use Budja[bja].

name: Manobo, Cinamiguin
Language Use: Also use Cebuano [ceb].

name: Khlula
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: us-Saare
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Less than 1%. Literacy rate in L2: 3%.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng].

name: Bilur
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Kuanua [ksd].

name: Punan Merah
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Nungu
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau] (Blench 2019).

name: Chinook
Language Development: Texts. Language classes at Warm Springs (Golla 2007).
Language Use: The Shoalwater dialect has been extinct since the 1930s (Mithun 1999). Allshifted to English [eng].

name: Malankuravan
LITERACY_L2: 53% for Kerala, 41% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 53% for Kerala, 41% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Shanga
Language Development: Literacy materials are available (2015 R. Jones).
Language Use: Some of all ages. All also use Hausa [hau], with some shifting to Hausa.

name: Mixtec, Tijaltepec
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Momina
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Doko-Uyanga
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most also use Efik [efi] (Decker et al 2022e). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022e). A few also use Iyongiyong [bbs] (Decker et al 2022e). A few also use Robambami [ibm] (Decker et al 2022e). Used as L2 by Robambami [ibm].

name: Yis
Language Use: Vitality declining in some villages. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Olo [ong].

name: Zakhring
Language Use: All shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Awutu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka].

name: Baetora
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.

name: Koma
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Yau (Sandaun Province)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Banda, Mid-Southern
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Tabriak
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Vávrová 2014).

name: Lembata, West
Language Use: Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Tawang Monpa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 32% (2001 census).
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Chug [cvg], Sherdukpen [sdp].

name: Sarua
Language Use: Most shifting to Bagirmi [bmi].

name: Onin
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Iha [ihp] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults.

name: Tunebo, Western
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Zazao
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Some domains. Positive attitudes.Many shifted to Blablanga [blp]. Many shifted to Cheke Holo [mrn]. Many shifted to Zabana [kji].

name: Atampaya
Language Development: Revitalization program has begun in 2015 by the Pama Language Centre for agroup of closely related languages including Atambaya, Angkamuthi [avm], Uradhi [urf], andYadhaykanu (a dialect of Uradhi).

name: Koraga, Mudu
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan].

name: Laha (Indonesia)
Language Use: Parents encourage children to speak Laha. Used by all. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Zumbun
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Allalso use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022b). Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Decker et al2022b). A few also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Vune mi [mkf] (Deckeret al 2022b).

name: Degenan
Language Use: In Seure, many children only speak Tok Pisin [tpi]. In Sel, children growup speaking Tok Pisin [tpi], but eventually learn to speak Degenang [dge]. Some young people,all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with some youth shifting.

name: Gbe, Waci
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Éwé [ewe]. Also use French [fra].

name: Wanukaka
Language Use: Many also use Lamboya [lmy], especially Rua speakers (Verdizade 2019). Used as L2 by Lamboya [lmy].

name: Kosadle
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Punan Merap
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Paliyan
LITERACY_L2: 44%–62% in Kerala, 50% for Hill Pulaya (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 44%–62% in Kerala, 50% for Hill Pulaya (2001 census).
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Malayalam [mal]. Also use Tamil [tam], with high proficiency.

name: Sanggau
Language Use: Also use Kendayan [knx].

name: Porohanon
Language Use: Also use Cebuano [ceb].

name: Akrukay
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Brooks 2018b).

name: Riantana
Language Use: Home.

name: Andra-Hus
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kurti [ktm]. Also use TokPisin [tpi].

name: Kumba
Language Development: No schools.
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Kugama [kow], Nyong [muo], Teme [tdo].

name: Samvedi
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Senoufo, Shempire
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Youjiang Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity. Latin script [Latn], pinyin-based, used since 1982, official, mainly used in official domains.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes.

name: Suga
LITERACY_L2: A few adults literate in Fulfulde [fub].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: A few adults literate in Fulfulde [fub]. Few can read Roman script.
Language Use: Home, cultural events. Some of all ages. Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Most also use French [fra]. Some also use Hausa [hau]. A few also use Standard Arabic [arb].

name: Glio-Oubi
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Kanu
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools.

name: Dongo
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg].

name: Gimme
Language Use: Also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], for church activities. Also use French [fra], but with low proficiency.

name: Wailaki
Language Development: Texts. The Round Valley Language Project has made Wailaki an option for Round Valley High School students to study for their core curriculum language requirements, and there is evidence of this program having success.

name: Katukína
Language Use: All shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Liujiang Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity. Latin script [Latn], used between 1952–1955, experimental use in education.
Language Use: All domains. Positive attitudes.

name: Torá
Language Use: All shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Malagasy, Sakalava
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Zhire
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021n). Most also use English [eng], with varying level of proficiency depending on age and education (Decker et al 2021n). A few also use Hyam [jab], with varying level of proficiency depending on age and education (Decker et al 2021n). A few also use Koro Wachi [bqv], with varying level of proficiency depending on age and education (Decker et al 2021n).

name: Chenapian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin[tpi].

name: Kawe
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Yelogu
Language Use: Some who marry into the language area do not learn the language (Aikhenvald 2018). Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2018). Many also use Kwoma [kmo] (Aikhenvald 2018). Some also use Manambu [mle], especially young people (Aikhenvald 2018). Used as L2 by Kwoma [kmo].

name: Bungain
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%. Texts.
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Ake
Language Use: Concern about language shift to Hausa [hau] in all but Gwayaka village.Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. Allalso use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021r). Most also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2021r).Some also use Alago [ala] (Decker et al 2021r). A few also use Eggon [ego] (Decker et al 2021r).

name: Sonde
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Very low. Literacy rate in L2: 80%.
Language Use: Home; Mixed: Community, Religion, Work, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Kituba [ktu]. A few also use Lingala [lin]. Used as L2 by Suku [sub].

name: Yeniche
Language Use: The L1 of some (1977 The Carrier Pidgin). Adults only.

name: Phana'
Language Use: Being replaced by Lahu [lhu] in Houayxay District, by Akha [ahk] in Namtha Province (Bradley 2007a). Also use Akha [ahk]. Also use Lahu [lhu].

name: Amundava
Language Use: Some also use Portuguese [por].

name: Tasawaq
Language Use: Most also use Hausa [hau] (Kossmann 2007). Most also use Tawallammat Tamajaq [ttq] (Kossmann 2007).

name: Abinomn
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Low level of schooling.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Foau [flh].

name: Urapmin
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Robbins 2004).

name: Doso
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Dibiyaso [dby]. Also use Gogodala[ggw]. Also use Kamula [xla]. Used as L2 by Dibiyaso [dby], Kamula [xla].

name: Kaburi
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults.

name: Chaura
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Sekar
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Sauri
Language Use: Under some pressure from Waropen [wrp] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults.

name: Somray
Language Use: Most shifted to Khmer [khm].

name: Bulgebi
Language Use: Vigorous. Concerted effort to teach children Gamane [bmp] and Nankina [nnk]before Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used by all. Many also use Nankina [nnk]. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Fanbak
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Since all Fanbak live in villages populated by North Ambrym [mmg] speakers,interaction with these speakers is in North Ambrym. Children attend North Ambrym-speakingkindergarten, and church services are held in Bislama [bis] or in North Ambrym. Home, garden,formal ceremonies. All also use North Ambrym [mmg].

name: Nume
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Used by 80% of the children. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng].

name: Bijim
