Language Use: Mixed use with Hausa [hau]: all domains. Used by all. All also use Hausa[hau]. Most also use English [eng]. Also use Kusur-Myet [tdl]. Also use Ngas [anc]. Also usePyam [pym]. Used as L2 by Pyam [pym].

name: Kudiya
LITERACY_L2: 48% for Scheduled Tribes in Karnataka; 63% for Kudiyain Kerala, 65% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 48% for Scheduled Tribes in Karnataka; 63% for Kudiyain Kerala, 65% in Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also use Kodava [kfa]. Alsouse Malayalam [mal]. Also use Tulu [tcy].

name: Fang (Cameroon)

name: Wara
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Brem

name: Taikat
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under strong pressure fromIndonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007).

name: Songoora

name: Hunjara-Kaina Ke

name: Mahali
LITERACY_L2: 12% for Jharkhand (20% male, 4% female) (1981 census); 32% for Odisha (2001 census).
Writing: Bengali (Bangla) script [Beng]. Latin script [Latn], used in Bangladesh.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 12% for Jharkhand (20% male, 4% female) (1981 census); 32% for Odisha (2001 census).
Language Use: Most in Jharkhand reported Santhali [sat], Sadri [sck] or Mundari [unr] as their mother tongue rather than Mahali. May be a threatened language. Home, village, private prayer for half the L1 speakers in Jharkhand. Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Munda [unx]. Also use Mundari [unr]. Also use Odia [ory]. Also use Sadri [sck]. Also use Santhali [sat].

name: Duhwa

name: Koda
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck].

name: Taworta

Language Development: The Woorabinda community developed an LOTE Gangulu program to be taught inprimary school.

name: Ile Ape

name: Khah

name: Mundat

name: Kamar

name: Isinai

name: Turung

name: Tarjumo

name: Mbalanhu

name: Subanon, Kolibugan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 65%. Texts.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Cebuano [ceb]. L2 acquired through public school, media and travel; L2 used in those domains. Used as L2 by Central Subanen [syb].

name: Kulisusu
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; Mixed: Religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Wawonii [wow].

name: Wik-Iiyanh
Language Use: Under pressure from Wik-Mungkan [wim] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults. Many also use English [eng]. Also use Wik-Mungkan [wim].

name: Taman (Indonesia)
Language Use: Culture still vital.

name: Bainouk-Samik
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use French [fra], as the languageof education and government (Diouf et al 2017). Some also use Wolof [wol], as the language ofcommerce and interethnic communication (Sarr and Thiaw 2012).

name: Maaka
Language Development: Texts.

name: Gnau
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Tracer 2003).

name: Malua Bay
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Nearly all.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Work, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes, especially among older people. Most also use Bislama [bis]. Many also use V’ënen Taut [nmb]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra].

name: Makasae
Language Use: Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Dubu
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Home only. Older adults only. Mostshifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Apache (Kiowa)
Language Use: No education efforts at present. A few semi-speakers (Golla 2007). Allshifted to English [eng] (Golla 2007).

name: Sumtu Chin
Writing: Latin script [Latn], preliminary orthography developed in 2010.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also useRakhine [rki].

name: Qashqa'i
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Persian [pes].
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, commerce. Used by all. Also use Iranian Persian [pes]. Also use Southern Luri [luz].

name: Baham
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Cinta Larga
Language Use: Vigorous. A few also use Portuguese [por].

name: Tso
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng]. A few also use Bacama [bcy].

name: Mixtec, Cuyamecalco
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Vunapu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Bislama [bis].
Language Use: Home, Community, Work; Mixed: Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. A few also use English [eng]. A few also use French [fra]. A few also use Tavanlav [vlp].

name: Ede Cabe
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Yoruba [yor]. Very high levelof comprehension of Yoruba. Used as L2 by Tchumbuli [bqa].

name: Yi, Naluo
Language Use: Moribund to extinct in Sichuan, potentially endangered to endangered in Yunnan (Bradley 2007a). Some young people, all adults.

name: Minz Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Use: Home, village, traditional ceremonies. Used by all. Also use Guibian Zhuang [zgn]. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Yang Zhuang [zyg].

name: Quichua, Calderón Highland
Language Use: Home. Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa], with some shifting.

name: Modole
Language Use: Positive attitudes.

name: Laitu Chin
Writing: Latin script [Latn], preliminary orthography developed in 2009.
Language Development: Literacy classes are being taught in some communities.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also useRakhine [rki].

name: Lesing-Gelimi
Language Use: Home, community; Mixed use: church, school. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Spencer et al 2013). Some also use Akolet [akt] (Spencer et al 2013). Some also use Avau [avb] (Spencer et al 2013). Some also use English [eng] (Spencer et al 2013). Some also use Lote [uvl] (Spencer et al 2013). Some also use Mangseng [mbh] (Spencer et al 2013).

name: Quechua, Chachapoyas
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%. Taught as subject in primary schools.
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Luhu
Language Use: Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Duke
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% fluently, 60% haltingly. Motivation for literacy high. Prefer to read English [eng] more than Pijin.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Marovo [mvo]. Also use Pijin [pis]. Also use Roviana [rug].

name: Kairui-Midiki
Language Use: Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Mbati
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Efe
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Lele (Guinea)
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk].

name: Mongol
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Barlow 2020b).

name: Karen, Phrae Pwo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Northern Thai [nod]. Bilingualism in Northern Thai is widespread and some are highly bilingual (Dawkins and Phillips 2009a). Many also use Thai [tha] (Dawkins and Phillips 2009a). Also use S’gaw Karen [ksw].

name: Seta
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Dass
Language Use: Dass borrows heavily from Hausa [hau] (25% of lexical entries) and, forthis reason, appears to be thriving rather than speakers switching to Hausa (Blench 2019). Alsouse Hausa [hau] (Blench 2019).

name: Cabiyarí
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Most shifting to Barasana-Eduria [bsn]. Some shifting to Spanish [spa].

name: Ngul
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Religion, Work. Used by all. All also use Kituba [ktu]. Most also use Lingala [lin], especially the young. Some also use French [fra], only those who have studied.

name: Duwet
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%. Texts.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Wampar [lbq]and Tok Pisin [tpi], which children prefer. Only when other Duwet speakers present. Some youngpeople, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Musom [msu].

name: Seluwasan
Language Use: Possibly endangered (Florey 2005). Some young people, all adults.

name: Dixon Reef
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from neighboringlanguages Avava [tmb] and Nahavaq [sns] (Wurm 2007). Most key domains. Some young people, alladults. Positive attitudes.

name: Penchal
Language Use: Also use Titan [ttv]. Used as L2 by Lenkau [ler].

name: Phunoi
Language Use: Shift beginning with loss of speakers as well as loss of some social functions. Has history of late vernacular acquisition where some youth begin to speak the language at around 10 years old. Some young people, all adults. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Kaikadi
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Yamap
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%. Sunday reading booklets are being read aloud in homes. In church, people are taking turns reading Scripture verses from these booklets (2020 S. Paoli).
Language Use: Home, community, church. Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Wogamusin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Dumpu
Language Use: Secret language when traveling to Madang town. Mixed use in all other domains with Tok Pisin [tpi], which is used more often than Watiwa. Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Camtho
Language Use: Mainly used by young people.

name: Kayong
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Karnai
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Raymond2005). Some also use Kovai [kqb], especially older adults (Raymond 2005). Some also use Mbula[mna], especially older adults (Raymond 2005). Some also use Mutu [tuc], especially older adults(Raymond 2005). Some also use Yabem [jae], especially older adults (Raymond 2005).

name: Dari (Persian)
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran].
Language Use: Little use of other languages.

name: Deno
Language Use: Special cultural events. Adults only. All shifting to Hausa [hau] (Deckeret al 2022c). Many also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022c). Some also use Gera [gew] (Deckeret al 2022c). Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Decker et al 2022c).

name: Isebe
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Wagi [fad].

name: Igana
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Gants
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2015).

name: Okpamheri
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Samosa
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Garus [gyb], Nobonob [gaw], and Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Many shifting to Garus [gyb] (Wurm 2007). Many shifting to Nobonob [gaw] (Wurm 2007). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Ikpeng
Language Use: Moderate vitality. Some also use Portuguese [por], but with low proficiency.

name: Mnong, Southern
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Mesaka
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Esimbi [ags],especially in the market. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Tiv [tiv].

name: Ega
Language Use: Ethnic group growing, but with some shift to Dida [dic] language due tointermarriage and other influences. Some count themselves as ethnic Dida in the census. Someyoung people, all adults. Most also use French [fra]. Most also use Lakota Dida [dic].

name: Tay Boi
Language Use: Developed about 1862. Spoken in French colonial households between male Vietnamese servants and their employers. Lower levels of administration, the military, and police.

name: Shuadit
Language Use: No remaining speakers as of 1977. May still be used in Passover song.

name: Jara
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Yawanawa
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1979, limited usage.
Language Use: Vigorous. Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Ayi (Papua New Guinea)
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially men.

name: Machinga
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Manem
Language Development: Significant literacy in Tok Pisin [tpi] and Bahasa Indonesia [ind].
Language Use: Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Ponam
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kurti [ktm]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Busami
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Pirlatapa
Language Use: No remaining speakers in the 1960s.

name: Southern Ping Chinese, Southern Pinghua
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant[Hant].

name: Konjo, Highland
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Mehináku
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Some also use Portuguese [por], having restricted access on government reserve.

name: Watubela
Language Use: Also use Geser-Gorom [ges].

name: Elepi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Matepi
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Iguta
Language Use: Use of Iguta is more vigorous in villages further from Jos. Use of Hausa [hau] and English [eng] more typical in villages closer to Jos (Decker et al 2021a). Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Used in most domains by most age groups in most of the villages, but in a few villages, it was reported that the parents are not teaching their children Iguta (Decker et al 2021a). Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021a). Most also use English [eng], used in education (Decker et al 2021a). A few also use Berom [bom] (Decker et al 2021a). A few also use Izere [izr] (Decker et al 2021a). A few also use Jere [jer] (Decker et al 2021a).

name: Silopi
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Mixtec, Yutanduchi
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ndobo
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Meeuwis 1998).

name: Rerau
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Gwandara
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. Some also use Alago [ala]. Used as L2 by Koro Nulu [vkn].

name: Angaité
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Paraguayan Guaraní [gug](Crevels 2012).

name: Yawiyo
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Saniyo-Hiyewe [sny].

name: Arguni
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Erokwanas
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Some young people, all adults.Children tend not to use it (Wurm 2007).

name: Carabayo
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Skepi Creole Dutch
Language Use: By 1998 had no remaining speakers.

name: Kurtokha
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Tibetan script [Tibt], Uchen style.
Language Use: Most also use Tshangla [tsj]. Many also use Dzongkha [dzo]. Used as L2 by Khengkha [xkf].

name: Lemolang
Language Use: Youth shifting to Tae’ [rob], Makassar Malay [mfp] and Bugis [bug]. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Makassar Indonesian [mfp]. All also use Tae’ [rob]. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Bugis [bug].

name: Dori'o
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Romanian, Megleno
Language Use: Some young people, all adults, with few if any child speakers (Salminen 2007).

name: Ombo
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. All also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Many also use Lingala [lin]. Some also use French [fra].

name: Teke-Laali
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Wogeo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Anderson 2011).

name: Luyana
Language Development: Texts.

name: Legenyem
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Mpotovoro
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Rohingya
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Hanifi Rohingya script [Rohg], some development in immigrant communities for all three scripts. Latin script [Latn].
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Rakhine [rki]. Also use Burmese [mya]. Educated individuals are literate in it. Used as L2 by Rakhine [rki].

name: Miluk
Language Development: Texts.

name: Asmat, North
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Rufiji
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Shabak
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use North Mesopotamian Arabic [ayp]. Some also use Central Kurdish [ckb]. A few also use Northern Kurdish [kmr].

name: Benamanga
Language Use: Home, community. Some also use Bena [bez].

name: Birhor
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Hindi [hin].
Language Use: Vigorous. No indication of language shift. Most domains. Used by all.Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], especially the school children. Also use Hindi[hin]. Also use Ho [hoc]. Also use Munda [unx]. Also use Mundari [unr]. Also use Odia [ory].Also use Sadri [sck]. Also use Santhali [sat].

name: Sila
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Lao [lao] (Badenoch and Hayashi 2017). Most also use Lü [khb] (Badenoch and Hayashi 2017).

name: Min Zhong Chinese
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 91% (2000 census, Han nationality).
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Bagupi
Language Use: Heavy influence from Nobonob [gaw] and Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Manyshifting to Nobonob [gaw]. Many shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Nobonob [gaw].

name: Akolet
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Ambul[apo], Amio-Gelimi [let].

name: Snohomish
Language Use: All shifted to English [eng].

name: Kariya
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022b). Most alsouse English [eng] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Decker et al2022b). A few also use Pa’anci [pqa] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Siri [sir] (Decker etal 2022b). A few also use Warji [wji] (Decker et al 2022b). Used as L2 by Burku [bbt].

name: Yango
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Mbandja [zmz]. Also use Northern Ngbandi [ngb].

name: Kusu
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Foma
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Maiwala
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Suau [swp]. Also use Tawala [tbo].

name: Narango
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 90%.
Language Use: Mixed in all domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Bislama [bis]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Mores [rga]. Used as L2 by Atin [plb], Mores [rga].

name: Ikulu
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most alsouse Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng].

name: Mengaka
Writing: Bagam (Eghap) script [Qabh], limited usage except for correspondence.
Language Development: Interest in language development for schools and individual literacy.
Language Use: Most also use French [fra], especially youth. Some also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education. A few also use Bamun [bax], especially older speakers.

name: Kango (Bas-Uélé District)
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Iwur
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Indonesian [ind].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Some also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Manombai
Language Use: Also use Dobel [kvo]. Used as L2 by Dobel [kvo].

name: Kol
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Yangulam
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Sam [snx].

name: Eton (Vanuatu)
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Pang Pang dialect has few remaining speakers. Used by all. Also use Bislama[bis]. Also use English [eng]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Lelepa [lpa]. Also use NorthEfate [llp]. Also use South Efate [erk].

name: Daho-Doo
Language Use: Also use Wè Southern [gxx], but the Wè Southern do not understand Daho orDoo.

name: Saruga
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Ganglau
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 byDumun [dui].

name: Masiwang
Language Use: Also use Geser-Gorom [ges]. Used as L2 by Salas [sgu].

name: Nalögo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%. Literacy rate in L2: 25–40%. Interest in vernacular increasing.
Language Use: Vital language. Home, village life. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Pijin [pis]. Used as L2 by Engdewu [ngr].

name: Kizamani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Hausa [hau] and English [eng].
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, cultural events. Used by all. All also use Hausa[hau], as the LWC in the area, also used in churches and in education (with English [eng])(Decker and Benard 2022b). Most also use English [eng], especially the young people (Decker andBenard 2022b).

name: Gbe, Tofin
Language Development: Literacy efforts underway using Fon, Gun, and Tofin.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gun [guw].

name: Silesian
Language Use: Also use Polish [pol].

name: Small Flowery Miao
Writing: Miao (Pollard) script [Plrd], no longer in use.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, market. Used by all. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Bipi
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Nyindrou [lid].

name: Lorang
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Dobel [kvo].

name: Biwat
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (McDowell 1991). Used as L2 by Ulwa [yla].

name: Japrería
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%. Literacy rate in L2: 0%.
Language Use: Threatened by exogamous marriages. Home, work. Some young people, alladults. Neutral attitudes. Most also use Spanish [spa]. Also use Yukpa [yup].

name: Kuturmi
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Sewa Bay
Language Use: Also use Dobu [dob].

name: Bepour
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Nicobarese, Southern
LITERACY_L2: 46% for Scheduled Tribes in Nicobar District.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 46% for Scheduled Tribes in Nicobar District. 72% for Nicobar (2001 census).
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Bure
Language Use: Elderly only. Most shifted to Hausa [hau] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).Many shifted to Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).

name: Garus
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Bargam [mlp], Mosimo [mqv], Samosa[swm].

name: Bokha
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Aigon
LITERACY_L2: 80% in Tok Pisin [tpi] and40% in English [eng].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 80%. Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Tok Pisin [tpi] and40% in English [eng].
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin[tpi].

name: Sausi
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Danaru [dnr].

name: Eloyi
Language Development: English [eng] is the language of education and churches. Young people havemore literacy than older adults. In Benue State, some are literate in Agatu [agc].
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Agatu [agc], by those in Benue state(Ushu-Olugwa), who are shifting to Agatu (Decker et al 2021c). Also use Hausa [hau], especiallyin the north (Decker et al 2021c).

name: Kaiy
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Kwerisa [kkb].

name: Dhudhuroa
Language Development: Reawakening. Elementary and Secondary school children in Victoria state,Australia, are learning Dhudhuroa and Murinpatha, the indigenous languages of their region.

name: Saleman
Language Use: Vigorous except in Wahai.

name: Urigina
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Danaru [dnr].

name: Teme
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low.
Language Use: Also use Gengle [geg]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Kumba [ksm]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Yendang [ynq].

name: Abaga
Language Use: Children generally grow up learning Benabena [bcf], Kamano [kbq], andWagama [abg] simultaneously. Children in Kese village that live closer to the highway use moreTok Pisin [tpi] and less Wagama, and some do not use Wagama at all. Those children who livefarther from the highway use less Tok Pisin and more Wagama. Private coversations, fights,sports, village gatherings. Mixed use in all other domains with Benabena [bcf], Kamano [kbq],and Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some young people, all adults. All also use Benabena [bef]. Most also useKamano [kbq]. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Anem
LITERACY_L2: 20%–30% for men in English [eng] and Tok Pisin [tpi].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%–30% for men in English [eng] and Tok Pisin [tpi].
Language Use: Home; Mixed use: community, school. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Allalso use Bariai [bch] (Paris et al 2012b). All also use Lusi [khl] (Paris et al 2012b). All alsouse Tok Pisin [tpi] (Paris et al 2012b). Many also use Kove [kvc] (Paris et al 2012b). Some alsouse Amara [aie] (Paris et al 2012b). Some also use Maleu-Kilenge [mgl] (Paris et al 2012b). Somealso use Mouk-Aria [mwh] (Paris et al 2012b).

name: Ma (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Pingelapese
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Pohnpeian [pon]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Kwer
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Romkun
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Northern Ping Chinese, Northern Pinghua
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant[Hant].

name: Geruma
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Hausa [hau], with some shifitng to Hausa.

name: Daonda
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Waris [wrs], which is understood by adults.

name: Pintiini
Language Use: Also use Ngaanyatjarra [ntj]. Also use Pitjantjatjara [pjt].

name: Kamantan
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Seti
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Dawik Kui
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Labu
Language Use: Children taught Tok Pisin [tpi] first, and its use is active. The culture seems in decline. Home. Negative attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Uradhi
Language Development: Revitalization program has begun in 2015 by the Pama Language Centre for a group of closely related languages including Uradhi and Yadhaykanu, Angkamuthi [avm], and Atambaya [amz].

name: Sileibi
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2015).

name: Mituku
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French [fra].

name: Majera
Language Use: In rapid decline (Tourneux 2004). Some young people, all adults. Some also use French [fra], as language of public education.

name: Sa'och
Language Use: Elderly only. Negative attitudes. All shifted to Khmer [khm].

name: Ughele
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Roviana [rug].

name: Ngbundu
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Kachari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 81% in Assam (2001 census).
Language Use: Some ethnic Kachari speak it as L1. Most speak Assamese [asm] as L1. Rapidly assimilating to Bengali [ben] or Assamese [asm] (Van Driem 2007). Some young people, all adults. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng].

name: Katu, Western
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Lamet
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Tambotalo
Language Use: Elderly only. All shifted to Bislama [bis].

name: Lisabata-Nuniali
Language Use: Vigorous, except in Kawa. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Southern Katang
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Lao [lao]. Used as L2 by Upper Ta’oih [tth].

name: Bentong
Language Use: Some youth shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Tenis
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon; 2000 S. Wurm). Very few claim to speak Tenis well. Marriages largely cross-linguistic. Elderly only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many shifted to Mussau-Emira [emi] (Wurm 2007). Most also use English [eng].

name: Uzekwe
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Mamusi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Only young people.
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 byMangseng [mbh].

name: Nyaw
Language Use: Also use Northeastern Thai [tts]. Used as L2 by Aheu [thm], Ban Khor Sign Language [bfk].

name: Biafada
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%.
Language Use: Home, friends, religion, work. Also used in radio and texting. Some of allages. Losing speakers to Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], particularly among children of mixedmarriages, and those from families who moved to the capital of Bissau for education and economicopportunity. Positive attitudes. Most also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov], as the language ofinterethnic unity, communication, and commerce. Some also use Mandinka [mnk]. Some also usePortuguese [por], as the language of education and communication with foreigners. A few also useStandard Arabic [arb].

name: Bo (Laos)
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Vishavan
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kamaru
Language Use: Home, Community, Work, Religion. Some young people, all adults. Positiveattitudes. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Many also use Wolio [wlo]. Used as L2 by Tukang BesiNorth [khc], Tukang Besi South [bhq].

name: Wa'ema
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Tawala [tbo]. Also use Wedau [wed].

name: Kango (Tshopo District)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 1%.
Language Use: Many also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Bali [bcp]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Iko
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Ibibio [ibb].

name: En
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Lawunuia
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Nyangatom
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Amharic [amh].
Language Use: Vigorous. Majority of Nyangatom monolingual. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Amharic [amh]. Used as L2 by Karo [kxh].

name: Ngbee
Language Use: Many shifted to Mangbetu [mdj]. Many shifted to Mayogo [mdm].

name: Kadung
Language Use: Home. Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau], which is used for mostfunctions in the churches and for most teaching in the schools. Many also use English [eng],also used in the church and in education.

name: One, Kwamtim
Language Use: All domains except church. Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Utarmbung
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mwatebu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low.
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon); endangered or potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Some young people, all adults. Also use Dobu [dob]. Also use Duau [dva].

name: Tamki
Language Use: Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. They consider themselves ethnically Sokoro, but their attitudes are not more positive toward Sokoro [sok] than toward other neighboring languages. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use Kenga [kyq]. Also use Saba [saa].

name: Southwestern Nisu
Language Use: Use higher for older people, women, uneducated men, or villages further removed from main roads. Nisu living in cities or counties are generally Sinicized. Some young people, all adults. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Hmong, Southern Guiyang
Language Use: Home, community, market.

name: Phuong
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Rakahanga-Manihiki
Language Use: Most shifting to English [eng].

name: Yambes
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Language loss concerns adults. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Ngoni (Mozambique)
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Portuguese [por].

name: Sawila
Language Use: Most also use Kula [tpg]. Most also use Wersing [kvw].

name: Tobati
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon); seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Mainly assimilated to Indonesian [ind] language and culture. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Many also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Mfinu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: About 100%.
Language Use: Adults only. No-one born after 1986 speaks the language (2018 M. Belanga Botikala). All shifting to Lingala [lin]. Also use French [fra].

name: Muratayak
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Forak [frq],Tandɨ [ygm].

name: Wakde
Language Use: Mo is often mixed with Indonesian [ind] and Papuan Malay [pmy]. Home, community. Adults only, seldom used by children. Most shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Wan
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu]. Also use Mwan [moa].

name: Waddar
Language Development: Some literate in Telugu [tel]or Marathi [mar].
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Marathi [mar]. Also use Telugu [tel].

name: Biga
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Papuan Malay [pmy] (Arnold2020). Also use Matbat [xmt], which is mostly used by older people (Arnold 2020). Also use Ma’ya[slz], used by many older people who speak the Misool dialect (Arnold 2020).

name: Ede Nago
Language Use: Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Yoruba [yor]. Used as L2 by Anii [blo].

name: Ternate
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Former trade language, now shifting to North Moluccan Malay [max]; weaker in core area, stronger in periphery (2012 J. Bowden). Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Sawai [szw].

name: Tulu-Bohuai
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Ere [twp]. Also use Kurti [ktm]. Also use Titan [ttv]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Mondropolon [npn].

name: Bagusa
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Eritai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 10%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Bauzi [bvz]. Used as L2 by Bauzi [bvz].

name: Yakaikeke
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Tanahmerah
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Khirwar
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Repanbitip
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from related neighboring languages and from Bislama [bis] (Wurm 2007). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Khuen
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Beginci
Language Use: Home, community, work, religion. Used by all. There is some mixing withIndonesian [ind] by younger schooled children (2019 R. Wallhoff). Positive attitudes. Most alsouse Indonesian [ind].

name: Simbali
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Kuanua [ksd]. Also use Mali [gcc]. Also use Ura [uro].

name: Selungai Murut
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kapya
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Gowro
Writing: Arabic script, Nastaliq variant [Aran], in development.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Kohistani Shina [plk].

name: Wára
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use English [eng] (Döhler 2018). Used as L2 by Namat [nkm], Namo [mxw].

name: Ibino
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Efik [efi]. Also use Ibibio [ibb].

name: Marfa
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use Marba [mpg].

name: Asuri
Language Use: Also use Bengali [ben]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Sadri [sck].

name: Loma (Côte d'Ivoire)
Language Use: Also use Téén [lor].

name: Yi, Poluo (Pholo)
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Navut
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%.
Language Use: Community; Mixed: Home, Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Bislama [bis]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Dao
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 50%.
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Most also use Indonesian [ind]. Also usePapuan Malay [pmy].

name: Kehu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Tai Daeng
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Rawo
Language Use: Adults only. No longer spoken in Rawo village, moribund in Onip village. Speakers live in Poko, but primarily use Tok Pisin (McPherson and Dryer 2021). All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi] (McPherson and Dryer 2021).

name: Seit-Kaitetu
Language Use: Vigorous. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Bun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.

name: Waima'a
Language Use: Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Tai Pao
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Mboko
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Leitch 2005).

name: Kham, Sheshi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Nepali [npi].

name: Vaghua
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Nekgini
Language Use: Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Also use Neko [nej]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Gray et al 2015). Used as L2 by Neko [nej].

name: Spanish, Loreto-Ucayali
Language Use: Used as L2 by Kukama-Kukamiria [cod].

name: Gula Iro
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: A few also use Gula [glu]. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Kumzari
Language Use: Also use Gulf Arabic [afb].

name: Pomo, Central
Language Development: Revitalization efforts underway with a number of language learners.
Language Use: Intermittent teaching at Hopland. All shifted to English [eng].

name: Malapandaram
LITERACY_L2: 48% for Kerala, 59% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 48% for Kerala, 59% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Use: Home, community. Negative attitudes. Also use Malayalam [mal], with many shifting in Kerala. Also use Tamil [tam], with most shifting in Tamil Nadu.

name: Nalu
Language Use: Also use Susu [sus].

name: Yaben
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b).

name: Papuma
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Ansus [and], with many youth shifting.

name: Ere
Language Use: Also use Kele [sbc]. Used as L2 by Kele [sbc], Lele [lle], Tulu-Bohuai [rak].

name: Bogaya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Duna [duc], as a more prestigiousvariety, which is acquired as a result of significant intermarriage. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Krumen, Pye
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use French [fra]. Used as L2 by Plapo Krumen [ktj].

name: Koro (Vanuatu)
Language Use: Used by entire ethnic group. Most key domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Dorig [wwo].

name: Malas
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b).

name: Dia
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mamaa
Language Use: Elderly only. All shifted to Finongan [fag]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Dewoin
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Zapotec, Lachiguiri
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Bali (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–2%. Literacy rate in L2: 30%–40% in Congo Swahili[swc].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events, Technology and media.Used by all. All also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Most also use Lingala [lin]. A few also useFrench [fra], primarily those with secondary school education. Used as L2 by Kango [kzy].

name: Maninka, Sankaran
Language Use: Some of all ages.

name: Gurgula
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Urdu [urd].
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Sindhi [snd].Many also use Urdu [urd]. Also use Gujarati [guj].

name: Kowiai
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm) but also not endangered. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Mairasi [zrs].

name: Baloi
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lingala [lin] (Meeuwis 1998).

name: Standard Moroccan Tamazight
Language Development: Agency: Being developed by the Royal Institute of Amazigh Culture (IRCAM) by combining features of the major Berber languages in Morocco.
Language Use: Not used as an L1.

name: Zapotec, San Baltazar Loxicha
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Kurmukar
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Puragi
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Andh
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Marathi [mar].

name: Simeulue
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Dibiyaso
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–50%.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains, home, social events, cultural events. Used by all.Also use Doso [dol]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Gogodala [ggw]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].Also use Kamula [xla]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Doso [dol], Turumsa [tqm].

name: Turaka
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Daga [dgz] (Wurm 2007). Older adults only. All shifted to Daga [dgz]. All shifted to Mapena [mnm]. All also use Umanakaina [gdn]. Some also use English [eng], especially young people. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially adults. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially adults.

name: Lamatuka
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Ronji
Language Use: Children mainly grow up speaking Tok Pisin [tpi], but eventually learn to speak Uma [roe]. Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Polonombauk
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 80% in Bislama [bis].
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Butmastur [bnr] (Wurm 2007). Mixed: Home, Community, Work, Education. Some young people, all adults. Very few children learn the language (Wurm 2007). Positive attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. Most also use Mores [rga]. Many also use Varsaf [nrg].

name: Idi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 50%.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Nen [nqn] (Evans 2012). Used as L2 by Nen [nqn].

name: Sori-Harengan
Language Use: Also use Nyindrou [lid]. Used as L2 by Nyindrou [lid].

name: Ponosakan
Language Use: Many shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Many shifted to Manado Malay [xmm].

name: Joba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 65%. Literacy rate in L2: Many, in Congo Swahili[swc].
Language Use: Home, community, church, cultural events. Some of all ages. Positiveattitudes. All also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Some also use Fuliiru [flr].

name: Dombe
Language Use: Also use Nambya [nmq]. Used as L2 by Nambya [nmq].

name: Shark Bay
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Bislama [bis].

name: Yahadian
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Geser-Gorom

Language Use: Also use Fordata [frd], in a few villages. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Usedas L2 by Bati [bvt], Masiwang [bnf], Watubela [wah].

name: Itik
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Under pressure from Indonesian [ind](Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults.

name: Vangunu
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Marovo [mvo].

name: Tombelala
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Guya
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Elkei
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Most also use Olo [ong].

name: Mboi
Language Development: All major villages have primary schools. They desire education.
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion. Some of all ages. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Gudu [gdu]. Also use Bena [yun]. Also use Ga’anda [gqa]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Merlav
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use.

name: Zenag
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Namo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Kanja [pep]. Some also use Wára [tci]. A few also use Motu [meu], especially elderly.

name: Lembata, South
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Indonesian [ind] (Krausse 2016). Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Abnaki (Eastern)
Language Development: Texts. Attempts to reintroduce the language in the elementary school (2011)and to publish the first Penobscot dictionary (2013).
Language Use: All shifted to English [eng].

name: Itneg, Moyadan
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useFilipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo]. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ngete
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 1991, limited usage.

name: Pei
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Walio [wla].

name: Tugutil
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Kaan

Language Use: Also use Dera [kna]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Mbula-Bwazza [mbu]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Used as L2 by Mbula-Bwazza [mbu].

name: Gwamhi-Wuri
Language Use: Many Gwamfawa assimilating to Lela culture and language, while the Wurawaassimilating to Hausa [hau]. Many shifted to C’Lela [dri]. Many shifted to Hausa [hau].

name: Lamja-Dengsa-Tola
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low.
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Liuqian Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Use: All domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Lakkia [lbc].

name: Pe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Hausa [hau].

name: Goaria
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 1% in Sindhi [snd].

name: Nathembo
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Makhuwa-Marrevone [xmc]. Many shifting to Koti [eko]. A few also use Portuguese [por].

name: Gobasi

name: Bonkiman
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Pelende
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Most.

name: Ponyo-Gongwang Naga

name: Binahari
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Magi [mgu]. Alsouse Suau [swp].

name: Aiome
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Ojibwa, Central
Language Use: All also use English [eng].

name: Ghotuo

name: Hmong Dô

name: Ciwogai

name: Mantsi

name: Pancana

name: Ojibwa, Western

name: Tepehuan, Southwestern
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nomu

Some also use Ono [ons], especially older adults.

name: Weliki

name: Loo

name: Owenia
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Swahili (generic)
Language Use: Used as L2 by Cutchi-Swahili [ccl].

name: Eastern Hongshuihe Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
