name: Queyu
Language Use: Use Tibetan [bod] as a liturgical language (Bradley 2007a). Some young people, all adults.

name: Simaa
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Okodia
Language Use: Also use Izon [ijc].

name: Boselewa
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Many also use English [eng]. Somealso use Galeya [gar]. Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Some also use Maiadomu [mzz]. Some alsouse Molima [mox]. Also use Dobu [dob] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Gumawana [gvs], Maiadomu [mzz].

name: Mburku
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022b). All also use Kariya [kil](Decker et al 2022b). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use NigerianFulfulde [fuv] (Decker et al 2022b). A few also use Standard Arabic [arb] (Decker et al 2022b).

name: Suoy
Language Use: Religion. Older adults only. All shifted to Khmer [khm].

name: Nauete
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Eitiep
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with most youthshifting. Used as L2 by Bragat [aof].

name: Fagani
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Some children shifting to Roviana [rug] (Wurm 2007). Most also use Roviana[rug] (Wurm 2007).

name: Maleng
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Lao [lao] (Schliesinger 2003b).

name: Okiek
Language Use: Some languages associated with Okiek have few remaining speakers. Akiek in northern Tanzania now speak Maasai [mas]. Those of Kinare in Kenya now speak Gikuyu [kik]. Those in Tanzania and Kenya are not in contact with each other. Sogoo dialect may be extinct. Home, social gatherings. Many shifted to Maasai [mas] (Sommer 1992). Many shifted to Swahili [swh] (Sommer 1992). Also use English [eng].

name: Tai Thanh
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Baibai
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mapena
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Daga [dgz]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Maiwa [mti]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Turaka [trh].

name: Lehali
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Lopa
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Bakpinka
Language Use: All shifting to Efik [efi] (Decker et al 2022e). Most also use English[eng]. Used as L2 by Deko-Dusanga [uya].

name: Yi, Mili
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Changthang
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 37% (2001 census).
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Kashmiri [kas]. Alsouse Ladakhi [lbj]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Kaian
Language Use: All domains. Mixed use: education, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes.Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Paris 2015).

name: Pyapun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 35% in Hausa [hau].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Most also use Hausa [hau], youth and adults, with varying degrees of proficiency. Many also use Koenoem [kcs]. Many also use Tal [tal]. Also use English [eng]. Used as L2 by Koenoem [kcs], Tehl [mtl].

name: Manobo, Rajah Kabunsuwan
Language Use: Also use Agusan Manobo [msm]. Also use Cebuano [ceb], but with low bilingualism. Also use Dibabawon Manobo [mbd].

name: Kusaghe
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Pijin [pis] (Davis 2003). Also use Roviana [rug] (Davis 2003).

name: Tugun
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, local commerce, oral tradition. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs]. Also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Vale
Language Use: Many also use Sango [sag].

name: Kui (Indonesia)
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Sialum
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use Ono [ons], especially older adults. Some also use Kâte [kmg], especially older adults.

name: Birao
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Gbe, Xwela
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Gen [gej]. Also use Saxwe Gbe [sxw]. Second languages used in non-formal education, government offices, churches. Gen and Saxwe Gbe are used for adult literacy in some villages. French is used in schools.

name: Akpes
Language Use: Also use Yoruba [yor].

name: Elu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Kele[sbc]. Also use Koro [kxr]. Also use Kurti [ktm].

name: Gurindji Kriol
Language Use: Gurindji Kriol is spreading outside the traditional Gurinji-speaking area(Meakins 2013). Used by all. Most also use English [eng].

name: Keak
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sos Kundi [sdk] (Richardson andTupper 2013). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Richardson and Tupper 2013). Used as L2 by Sos Kundi[sdk].

name: Gweda
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Taupota [tpa]. Also use English [eng].Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Wedau [wed].

name: Nzakara
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag]. Used as L2 by Kpatili [kym].

name: Zirenkel
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use Dangaléat [daa]. Also use Dar Daju Daju [djc].

name: Macaguán
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Leipon
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most children passively understand Leipon but few speak it fluently (2020 Z. O’Leary). Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], more often than Leipon by children, and interchangeably with Leipon by adults in most domains (2020 Z. O’Leary). Also use Lele [lle].

name: Wasa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka], less in rural areas. Used as L2 by Jwira-Pepesa [jwi].

name: Hoia Hoia
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Foia Foia [ffi].

name: Naga, Puimei
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Punan Aput
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Khamnigan Mongol
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Most also use Evenki [evn], specifically the Khamnigan Evenki dialect (Janhunen 2003). Also use Halh Mongolian [khk] (Janhunen 2003).

name: Kravet
Language Use: Also use Brao [brb]. Also use Khmer [khm]. Also use Lao [lao].

name: Yi, Awu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Agta, Mt. Iriga
Language Use: Also use Filipino [fil].

name: Mari (East Sepik Province)
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Home only. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Toyoda 1998).

name: Yi, Miqie
Language Use: No remaining speakers in Jinning and Anning counties; declining elsewhere. Home. Neutral attitudes. Most shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Laru
Language Use: Also use Bisã [bqp], with some youth shifting.

name: Kepo'
Language Development: Texts.

name: Tefaro
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults.

name: Abron
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%. Literacy work started in several villages(2004).
Language Use: Also use Akan [aka]. Also use English [eng].

name: Baga Binari
Language Use: Most also use Susu [sus]. Some also use French [fra].

name: Welaung
Language Development: Literacy rate in Burmese [mya] highest; very low literacy rate in Müün [mwq].
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Burmese [mya]. Also use Müün Chin [mwq].

name: Jere
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Used as L2 by Iguta [nar], Tunzuii [dza].

name: Shall-Zwall
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022b). Many also use Gwak [jgk] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022b). Some also use Bankal [jjr] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022b). Some also use English [eng] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022b). Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022b). Some also use Saya [say] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022b).

name: Bokoto
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Surubu
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Bina [byj], Rishiwa [rsw].

name: Mixtec, Sinicahua
Language Development: Primary and secondary schools.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Watut, Middle
Language Use: Home, village. Used by all. Mixed attitudes, neutral to positive. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Carter et al 2014).

name: Senggi
Language Use: Endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Frequently mix Viid with Indonesian [ind], Papuan Malay [pmy]. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Gudu
Language Use: Used as L2 by Mboi [moi], Ngwaba [ngw].

name: Burui
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Most also use Gaikundi [gbf], especially adults.

name: Kathu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kanuri, Tumari
Language Use: Also use Dazaga [dzg]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Dazaga [dzg].

name: Numbami
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Bugawac [buk] and Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults. Also use Yabem [jae], decreasingly in religious services.

name: Tomini
Language Use: Also use Boano [bzl] (Himmelmann 2001). Also use Lauje [law] (Himmelmann 2001). Also use Tajio [tdj] (Himmelmann 2001).

name: Jonkor Bourmataguil
Language Use: A large number have shifted to Chadian Arabic [shu]. Some young people, alladults. Used by children in 2 villages.

name: Lame
Language Use: No speakers of Ruhu or Mbaru as of 1987 (R. Blench).

name: Kir-Balar
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022d). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022d). A few also use Zamwal [zah] (Decker et al 2022d). Used as L2 by Zamwal [zah].

name: Mararit
Language Use: Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Nkem-Nkum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Literacy rate in L2: 35% in English [eng]. English[eng] used in school.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. A few also use Yala [yba].Also use Ekajuk [eka]. Also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Also use Nnam [nbp]. Used as L2 byAbanyom [abm], Efutop [ofu], Nnam [nbp].

name: Tareng
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Ukuriguma
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b).

name: Sepa (Papua New Guinea)
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Under pressure from Manam [mva] (Wurm 2007). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bariji
Language Use: Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Moikodi [mkp]. Also use Yareba [yrb].

name: Nkoroo
Language Use: Used as L2 by Defaka [afn].

name: Tambas
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau]. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Fyer [fie] (Decker et al 2021p). Some also use Ngas [anc], with varying level of proficiency depending on age and education (Decker et al 2021p). A few also use Mwaghavul [sur] (Decker et al 2021p).

name: Matambwe
Language Use: Home, market. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Kalao
Language Use: Under pressure from Bonerate [bna] and Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Most shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Many shifting to Bonerate [bna].

name: Bolgo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Tangchangya
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Chak [ckh], in Khagrachari and Rangamati districts.

name: Phake
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng].

name: Khao
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Literary Chinese
Writing: Han script, Simplified variant [Hans]. Han script, Traditional variant [Hant].
Language Development: Most Chinese people with at least a middle school education are able to read basic Classical Chinese. The ability to read (but not write) Classical Chinese is part of the Chinese middle school and high school curricula and is part of the college entrance examination. Texts.
Language Use: Today, pure Classical Chinese is occasionally used in formal or ceremonial occasions.

name: Gbii
Language Use: Also use Bassa [bsq]. Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Kaki Ae
Language Use: Some who marry in do not learn to speak Kaki Ae [tbd] (Potter et al 2015). Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people (Potter et al 2015). Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo], especially older adults (Potter et al 2015). Some also use Tairuma [uar] (Potter et al 2015). Some also use Toaripi [tqo] (Potter et al 2015). A few also use English [eng] (Potter et al 2015). A few also use Orokolo [oro] (Potter et al 2015).

name: Rajong
Language Development: Texts.

name: Moingi
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Ir
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Pasi
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Baimak
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Yoidik
Language Use: Used as L2 by Matukar Panau [mjk].

name: Ghanongga
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Khehek
Language Use: All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Nyindrou [lid].

name: Yangum Dey
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Tanjijili
Language Use: Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022a). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022a). A few also use Adara [kad] (Decker et al 2022a). A few also use Gbagyi [gbr] (Decker et al 2022a).

name: Aribwaung
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Musom [msu].

name: Kaningra
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Vigorous (Sumbuk 2006). Used by all. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Sumbuk 2006). Many also use Kapriman [dju], especially older adults (Sumbuk 2006).

name: Daza
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 90% in Hausa [hau].
Language Use: Elderly only. All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022c). Most shiftedto Bole [bol] (Decker et al 2022c).

name: Yaroamë
Language Use: Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Tagish
Language Development: There is some community interest in relearning the language (Golla 2007).
Language Use: All shifted to English [eng]. All shifted to Tlingit [tli].

name: Maria (Papua New Guinea)
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mangbutu
Language Use: Also use Bangala [bxg].

name: Bofi
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Aramaic, Talmudic
Language Use: Used widely in Jewish culture and life.

name: Southern Tidung
Language Development: Videos.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, work, market, traditional ceremonies and other informaldomains. Also use Indonesian [ind], especially in the company of non-Tidung users.

name: Nage
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools.

name: Sorsogon, Waray
Language Use: Also use Central Bikol [bcl]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Masbatenyo [msb].

name: Lehalurup
Language Use: Used by entire ethnic group, but under pressure from Vatrata [vra] (Wurm 2007). Most key domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Fyer
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Religious settings, Special cultural events,Technology and media. Used by all. Many also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng]. Somealso use Ngas [anc]. Used as L2 by Rom [tdk].

name: Chinantec, Tepinapa
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Spanish [spa].

name: Ternateño
Language Use: The Jakarta variety of creole Portuguese survived in Tugu until recent times (Wurm and Hattori 1981). Varieties also spoken in Larantuka, Flores; Adonara (Vure), Solor; as well as Sumatra, Kalimantan, Sulawesi, and Maluku. Varieties of creole Portuguese were also spoken in Banda and Ambon.

name: Wanambre
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b).

name: Atta (Faire)
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. Also use Ibanag[ibg]. Also use Pamplona Atta [att].

name: Lavatbura-Lamusong
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Gitua
Language Use: Strong desire to preserve language and culture, as well as learn both TokPisin [tpi] and English [eng]. Most domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use TokPisin [tpi]. Some also use Kâte [kmg], especially older adults and elderly. Some also use Sio[xsi], especially older adults and elderly.

name: Alo Phola
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Aruek
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Kap [ykm].

name: Kimki
Language Use: Most domains. Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy]. Used as L2 by Murkim [rmh].

name: Foia Foia
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], at Kamusi. Alsouse Bamu [bcf]. Used as L2 by Hoia Hoia [hhi].

name: Lemoro
Language Use: Used as L2 by Sanga [xsn].

name: Ngala
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Aikhenvald 2018).

name: Mari (Madang Province)
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Lengola
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc]. Also use Komo [kmw].

name: Boor
Language Use: Used by all. Used by children in the village. All also use Bagirmi [bmi].All also use Bua [bub]. All also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. All also use Laal [gdm]. Many alsouse Niellim [nie].

name: Letemboi
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Nasarian [nvh].

name: Tairuma
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since 2002, in development.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15% (SIL).
Language Use: Home, cultural events; Mixed use: School with English [eng] and Tok Pisin [tpi]; church with English [eng], Tok Pisin [tpi], Orokolo [oro], Motu [meu], Hiri Motu [hmo]. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people (Rueck et al 2010). Many also use English [eng], especially young people (Rueck et al 2010). Some also use Hiri Motu [hmo] (Rueck et al 2010). Some also use Orokolo [oro], especially older adults (Rueck et al 2010). Some also use Toaripi [tqo], especially older adults (Rueck et al 2010). A few also use Opao [opo] (Rueck et al 2010). Used as L2 by Kaki Ae [tbd], Opao [opo], Toaripi [tqo].

name: Pulabu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Mbowe
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Kasanga
Language Development: Revitalization project utilizing WhatsApp.
Language Use: No speakers left in most communities where it is being replaced by Mandinka[mnk], but still used by all ages in the most distant rural areas (2022 C. Nhuta). Home,friends, work. Some of all ages. Most also use Guinea-Bissau Creole [pov]. Most also useMandinka [mnk]. Some also use Portuguese [por].

name: Korak
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Pick 2020b).

name: Lang'e
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Teke-Tsaayi
Language Use: Also use Kituba [mkw].

name: Mosina
Language Use: Vigorous. Most key domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Bislama [bis], especially at church and with outsiders (Malau 2016). Used as L2 by Vera’a [vra].

name: Dza
Language Development: Over 100 people have been taught to read and write Jenjo.
Language Use: Home, market, work, community. Some young people, all adults. Positiveattitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Used as L2 byShoo-Minda-Nye [bcv].

name: Mawes
Language Use: Home; with friends. Some young people, all adults. Under pressure from Indonesian [ind] (Hammarström 2010). Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Ke'o
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20% in Indonesian [ind]. Literacy program by government for adults and in schools.
Language Use: All domains, ceremonies, personal letter-writing. Used by all.

name: Murkim
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Also use Kimki [sbt]. Also use Yetfa [yet].

name: Saba
Language Development: Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools.
Language Use: Children speak the language, (but not all). Some young people, all adults. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu], but with low proficiency (Boyd 1989). Used as L2 by Tamki [tax].

name: Kodeoha
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Bugis [bug]. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Tolaki [lbw], specifically the Mekongga dialect.

name: Nomane
Language Use: Home, community, market. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Kuman [kue].

name: Puebla Mazatec
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Spanish [spa]. Spanish proficiency is considered more important.

name: Ekai Chin
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Used by all. Also use Burmese [mya].

name: Itneg, Inlaod
Language Development: Materials for mother-tongue multilingual education have been developed forthe Inlaud Itneg communities in the provinces of Ilocos Sur and Ilocos Norte since 2018 (2020SIL).
Language Use: Vigorous in some communities. The language is still spoken by allgenerations but not all children and adults speak it in communities in the Ilocos region thatare heavily populated by Ilocanos (2020 SIL). Home, community. Some young people, all adults. InIlocos region, there are now more children who are speaking Ilocano [ilo] as L1. The lowproficiency of the children in the language was revealed by the result of L1 materialsfield-testing (2020 SIL). Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano[ilo].

name: Totonac, Filomena Mata-Coahuitlán
Language Use: Also use Coyutla Totonac [toc].

name: Bwile
Language Use: Home, community. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Kanga
Language Development: Orthography and literacy materials produced.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sudanese Arabic [apd].

name: Dir-Nyamzak-Mbarimi
Language Use: Home, community, cultural events; Mixed use: education, religion. Some young people, all adults, particularly in the Mbarimi and Nyamzak dialects (Decker and Aregbesola 2022). All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022a). Some also use English [eng], mostly young adults (Decker and Aregbesola 2022a).

name: Forak
Language Use: Children grow up learning Tok Pisin [tpi] and Forak [frq] at the same time,but mainly use Tok Pisin [tpi] when they’re younger. As they get older, they use Forak [frq] astheir main language. Some young people, all adults. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also useMuratayak [asx]. Also use Asaro’o [mtv].

name: Ndoe
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Many also use Ejagham [etu].

name: Wampur
LITERACY_L2: 30% age 10+ in at least Tok Pisin [tpi] (2000 census).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% age 10+ in at least Tok Pisin [tpi] (2000 census). Literacy rate: men 43%, women 15%.
Language Use: Not endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Adzera [adz]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Maremgi
Language Use: Only eleven families live in Tarawasi-Maremgi village, the only place Dineor (Marenggi) language is spoken. Home. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Azha
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Ngbaka Manza
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Phupa
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Minjungbal
Language Use: Elderly only.

name: Parawen
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Karian [bql].

name: Humene
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo].

name: Halang Doan
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Caac
Language Development: Caac taught a few hours a month at a junior high in Pouébo.

name: Anam
Language Use: Some villages shifting to Anamuxra [imi], Mum [kqa], or Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some young people, all adults. Mixed attitudes, from neutral to negative. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Many also use Anamuxra [imi]. Some also use Mum [kqa].

name: Yoy
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Negative attitudes. Also use Thai [tha]. Use of Yoy is discouraged in the school system in favor of Thai [tha] (Phakkahn 2017). Also use Lao [lao] (Phakkahn 2017). Also use Northeastern Thai [tts].

name: Lola
Language Use: Most vigorous in Warabal. Some young people, all adults. Also use Ambonese Malay [abs].

name: Awbono
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Gusan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kwang
Language Use: Also use Bagirmi [bmi], especially the Muslim Aloa, with full bilingualism. Also use Sar [mwm], especially the Ngam, as L2.

name: Budibud
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Some young people, all adults. Alsouse Muyuw [myw].

name: Emumu
Language Use: Home, community. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Alsouse Indonesian [ind]. Also use Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Quechan
Language Use: No systematic attempt to teach in schools. Older adults only, but there are a number of young semispeakers (Golla 2007). Most shifted to English [eng].

name: Bajelani
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use North Mesopotamian Arabic[ayp]. A few also use Central Kurdish [ckb]. A few also use Northern Kurdish [kmr]. Also useStandard Arabic [arb], as the language of instruction in schools.

name: Bo-Rukul
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% of youth read Hausa [hau] haltingly.
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Kulere [kul].

name: Bumaji
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Berinomo
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Sengo
Language Use: Also use Iatmul [ian].

name: Jilim
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2016a).

name: Sininkere
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Moore [mos]. Also use Western Niger Fulfulde [fuh].

name: Mewati
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25% (2006 SIL).
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, market, religion. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Standard Arabic [arb]. Also use Urdu [urd].

name: Biem
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kalinga, Mabaka Valley
Language Use: Also use Limos Kalinga [kmk].

name: Samaritan
Writing: Arabic script, Naskh variant [Arab]. Hebrew script [Hebr], no longer in use. Samaritan script [Samr].
Language Use: Religion.

name: Yekora
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Suena [sue]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Zia [zia].

name: Boano (Sulawesi)
Language Use: Children are educated in Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Community. Someyoung people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Tomini [txm].

name: Sénoufo, Senara
Language Use: Used by all. Used as L2 by Turka [tuz].

name: Teluti
Language Use: Used as L2 by Liana-Seti [ste], Sou Upaa [wha].

name: Himarimã
Language Use: Contact in 2007 with a mixed group may have included Himarimã speakers.Used by all. Also use Portuguese [por].

name: Kula
Language Use: Used as L2 by Sawila [swt].

name: Nake
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Okobo
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Hmong Don
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Bolondo
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin], which is used widely in main market towns among‘Water People’, but rarely in other villages where comprehension is lower. Also use NorthernNgbandi [ngb].

name: Habu
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Potentially endangered because of size and location. Some young people, alladults. Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Mbole
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Used by all. Most also use Lingala [lin], taught in primary schools. Some also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Bon Gula
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Kimaama
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Koneraw [kdw].

name: Kwerba Mamberamo
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Kwa
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Bacama [bcy].

name: Bangandu
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use French [fra].

name: Ta'oih, Lower
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all, in some villages. Positive attitudes. A few also use Lao [lao]. Also use Upper Ta’oih [tth].

name: Angoram
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Pondi [lnm].

name: Lewo Eleng
Language Use: Also use Lamaholot [slp].

name: Kunja
Language Use: Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Namat [nkm], Namo [mxw].

name: Koke
Language Use: Most shifting to Chadian Arabic [shu]. Most shifting to Fania [fni].

name: Hmong, Northern Huishui
Language Use: Home, community, market.

name: Paniya
LITERACY_L2: 41% for Kerala, 26% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Writing: Kannada script [Knda], used in Karnataka. Malayalam script [Mlym], used in Kerala. Tamil script [Taml], used in Tamil Nadu.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 41% for Kerala, 26% for Tamil Nadu (2001 census).
Language Use: Home, religion. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kannada [kan]. Also use Malayalam [mal]. Also use Tamil [tam].

name: Nafi
Language Use: Under pressure from Wampar [lbq] and Tok Pisin [tpi], which the children prefer (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Zapotec, Santiago Xanica
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Lembena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 3%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. 2% can write. No vernacular schools in area.
Language Use: Vigorous. All domains. Some oral and written use in church, oral use in local commerce. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Enga [enq]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Haroi
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home, Religious settings. Adults only. Most also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Kharia Thar
Language Use: Spoken by some Hill Kharia. Ethnic Hill Kharia in Odisha speak Odia [ory] as L1. Many in Jharkhand and West Bengal speak Bengali [ben] as L1. Home, village, private prayer. Most also use Bengali [ben], in outside domains. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Odia [ory]. Also use Santhali [sat].

name: Ayere
Language Use: Some of all ages. All also use Yoruba [yor]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Loncong
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Demta
Language Use: Seldom used. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay[pmy].

name: Buksa
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Hindi [hin], especially those who are educated, go on to higher studies or jobs in other areas. Also use English [eng].

name: Jina
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Some also use French [fra], as language ofpublic education. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Also use Lagwan [kot].

name: Lakalei
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Mirgan
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Odia [ory].
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use Desiya [dso], in Odisha. Also use English [eng]. Also use Halbi [hlb], in Madhya Pradesh. Also use Hindi [hin], in Madhya Pradesh. Also use Odia [ory], in Odisha, but with low proficiency.

name: Asoa
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Mangbetu [mdj].

name: Sowanda
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Agariya
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Many also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Nama (Papua New Guinea)
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng]. Some also use Aramba [stk]. A few also use Motu [meu], especially elderly.

name: Mangas
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022d). Some also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022d). A few also use Zamwal [zah] (Decker et al 2022d).

name: Mfumte
Language Development: Literacy classes in 1 village (2011).
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Some also use English [eng], as language of public education.

name: Kasiguranin
Language Use: Also use Filipino [fil].

name: Gawar-Bati
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Many also use Urdu [urd]. Also use Southern Pashto[pbt].

name: Nahuatl, Central Puebla
Language Development: Schools in most towns.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Rishiwa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Hausa [hau] and English [eng]. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1–3.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, cultural events. Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau], as the LWC in the area, also used in churches and in education (with English [eng]) (Decker and Benard 2022b). Most also use English [eng] (Decker and Benard 2022b). Also use Kinuku [kkd] (Decker and Benard 2022b). Also use Vono [kch] (Decker and Benard 2022b). Also use Vori [sde] (Decker and Benard 2022b).

name: Kanum, Bädi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%.
Language Use: Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Morori [mok].

name: Guana (Brazil)
Language Use: All shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Phupha
Language Use: 4 villages linguistically vital, 1 is shifting to Nisu [nsd]. Some young people, all adults.

name: Chinese Pidgin English
Language Use: Beginning to be superseded by English [eng]. Commercial use, mainly inChinese-run trade stores and restaurants.

name: Baangi
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021j). Some alsouse English [eng], young adults proficiently (Decker et al 2021j).

name: Hmong, Eastern Huishui
Language Use: Home, community, market.

name: Dem
Language Use: Used as L2 by Wano [wno].

name: Musar
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Maiani [tnh]. Also use Mauwake [mhl]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Also use Usan [wnu].

name: Mlabri
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%. Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Thai [tha].
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Many also use Thai [tha]. Some also use Hmong Daw [mww], mostly older men. A few also use Northern Thai [nod].

name: Idesa
Language Use: Elderly only. Most shifted to Nigerian Pidgin [pcm]. Many also use English[eng]. Many also use Okpe [oke]. Some also use Ghotuo [aaa]. Some also use Yoruba [yor].

name: Sinyar
Language Use: Vigorous. Most also use Chadian Arabic [shu]. Most also use Fur [fvr]. Also use Dar Daju Daju [djc]. Also use Masalit [mls].

name: Dabarre
Language Use: Also use Maay [ymm].

name: Onjob
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. All also use Ubir [ubr], with many youth shifting (Bonshek 2005). Many also use English [eng], especially women (Bonshek 2017). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with some youth shifting (Bonshek 2005).

name: Uru-Pa-In
Language Use: A few also use Portuguese [por], isolated in a protected government reserve.

name: Nisa
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Tonjon
Language Use: Many shifted to Djimini Sénoufo [dyi]. Many shifted to Jula [dyu].

name: Teke-Nzikou
Language Development: Small scale adult literacy program run by local group and SIL.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Likila
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin] (Meeuwis 1998).

name: Laomian
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70%.
Language Use: Use of Chinese [cmn] is increasing and leading to language shift. Home, village. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Lahu [lhu]. Many also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Hani [hni]. Also use Lü [khb].

name: Uruangnirin
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Domu
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Magi [mgu]. Alsouse Suau [swp].

name: Atemble
Language Use: Heavy influence from Nend [anh] and Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007). Elderlyonly. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Daniels 2015).

name: Liana-Seti
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Sou Nama [tlt], especially Seti dialect speakers.

name: Pesse
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community, cultural events; Mixed use: education, religion. Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker and Aregbesola 2022a). Some also use English [eng], mostly in education (Decker and Aregbesola 2022a).

name: Toussian, Northern
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in French [fra], 3% in Jula [dyu].
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Podena
Language Use: Adults only. Most shifting to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifting to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Anus [auq].

name: Phu Thai
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75%–100%.
Language Use: Also use Northeastern Thai [tts]. Also use Thai [tha].

name: Nuk
Language Use: Nuk is the dominant language in the Northern Nuk dialect area, and Tok Pisin [tpi] is the dominant language in the Southern Nuk and Wabangan dialect areas (2000 SIL). Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Most also use Tok Pisin [tpi], with some youth shifting.

name: Northern Bontok
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to Ilocano [ilo]. Most shifted to Tagalog [tgl]. Some also use Central Bontok [lbk].

name: Southern Nisu
Language Use: Use active in areas with high concentrations of Nisu. However, increasing lexical borrowing from Chinese. Code switching common between Nisu and Chinese. Many men and women spend part of the year working in predominantly Chinese towns or cities. Home, village. Older adults only. Neutral attitudes. Many shifted to Mandarin Chinese [cmn], with their children so they can do well in school, and also with outsiders, government officials who are not Nisu, non-Nisu people in township markets, elementary school teachers.

name: Margu
Language Development: Texts.

name: Koro (Côte d'Ivoire)
Language Use: Used as L2 by Mbre [mka].

name: Montol
Language Use: Home, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng]. A few also use Goemai [ank]. A few also use Piapung [pcw]. A few also use Tal [tal].

name: Boano (Maluku)
Language Use: Vigorous in north Boano. South Boano may have no remaining speakers. Someof all ages.

name: Purum
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30%–40% (2000).
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Meitei [mni], with speakers of other languages. Used as L2 by Kharam Naga [kfw].

name: Dema
Language Use: Strong pressure to assimilate to Nyungwe [nyu].

name: Glaro-Twabo
Language Use: Also use Liberian English [lir].

name: Aluo
Writing: Miao (Pollard) script [Plrd], no longer in use.
Language Use: Being replaced by Chinese or varieties of closely related Nasu or both. Severely endangered in all 3 villages in Miyi County, endangered in most other places (Bradley 2007a). Many shifting to Wusa Nasu [yig]. Some shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Tutuba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 75% in Bislama [bis].
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Some children are not learning the language. Mixed in all domains. Some young people, all adults. Neutral attitudes. All also use Bislama [bis]. A few also use English [eng].

name: Iyive
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Also use Iceve-Maci [bec]. Also use Tiv [tiv].

name: Malakote
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%. Orthography under development.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Kipfokomu [pkb]. Also use Swahili [swh]. Used as L2 by Waata [ssn].

name: Gayil
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], unofficial usage. Latin script [Latn], unofficialusage.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, market, church. Used by all.

name: Ede Ije
Language Development: Basic literacy program using Yoruba expanded to include post-literacy.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Alsouse Standard Arabic [arb]. Also use Yoruba [yor].

name: Dyan
Language Use: Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Gbe, Ayizo
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Fon [fon]. Also use French [fra]. Also use Saxwe Gbe[sxw]. Used as L2 by Saxwe Gbe [sxw].

name: Pak-Tong
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Parakanã
Language Use: Vigorous. Many also use Portuguese [por].

name: Pankhu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Bengali [ben], as the medium of education.

name: Tunggare
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Mixtec, Tacahua
Language Use: Some young people, all adults, 70% of monolinguals are older adults, none under 35.

name: Walungge
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 43%–72% in Nepali [npi]. Taught as subject in primary schools, in one school for teaching the Tibetan writing system starting from Class 1.
Language Use: Many school age children are shifting to Nepali [npi] when they are educated outside their homeland. There is widespread growing bilingualism, but it may not be a stable Diglossia (2019 SIL). Home, Community, and Religion. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Also use Nepali [npi].

name: Konda
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Wãpha
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some young people, alladults. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021o). Most also use English[eng] (Decker et al 2021o). Some also use Tarok [yer] (Decker et al 2021o). A few also useGoemai [ank] (Decker et al 2021o). A few also use Ywom [gek] (Decker et al 2021o).

name: Totoli
Language Use: Many shifting to Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 by Buol [blf].

name: Gabrielino-Fernandeño
Language Development: Linguist Pam Munro has spearheaded classes and conversations on social media in an attempt to revive the language by using it in everyday conversation and ceremonial contexts (2014 L. Marquez). Agency: Gabrielino-Tongva Language Committee.

name: Tedaga
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Most also use Dazaga [dzg], at low level of proficiency. Also use Chadian Arabic [shu].

name: Liki
Language Use: Older adults only. Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy].

name: Ningera
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Seba
Language Use: Massive shift away from the L1 occurring in certain mining areas. Nospeakers reported in the town of Kipushi, the outskirts of Lubumbashi, and parts of the northcentral and south central regions of the language area.

name: Kaera
Language Use: Home, traditional ceremonies, oral literature and songs. Sometime used inchurch sermons.

name: Hmong, Southwestern Guiyang
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Home, community, market.

name: Veluws
Language Use: Also use Dutch [nld].

name: Ayta (Bataan)
Language Use: A few key domains. Some of all ages. 50% of population, young and old, arepassive bilinguals, able to understand but not speak Magbukun Ayta. Positive attitudes. Also useFilipino [fil].

name: Tamagario
Language Use: Home, community.

name: Idaté
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al 2002).

name: Stod Bhoti
Language Development: Desire for literacy in Stod Bhoti.
Language Use: Home, community, religion. Positive attitudes. Many also use Hindi [hin], for trade and education. Many speak Hindi but are less proficient than those in other Lahul communities. Also use English [eng].

name: Kono (Guinea)
Language Use: Also use Eastern Maninkakan [emk]. Used as L2 by Konyanka [mku].

name: Towei
Language Use: Most shifted to Indonesian [ind]. Most shifted to Papuan Malay [pmy]. Also use Yetfa [yet].

name: Songomeno
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Rasawa
Language Use: Home. Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Saponi [spi].

name: Tai Long
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao].

name: Apalik
Language Use: Mixed use in home, community, church. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Allalso use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Van Cott et al 2011). Most also use Aiklep [mwg] (Van Cott et al2011). Many also use Akolet [akt] (Van Cott et al 2011). Many also use English [eng] (Van Cottet al 2011). Some also use Sengseng [ssz] (Van Cott et al 2011). A few also use Kaulong [pss](Van Cott et al 2011).

name: Matbat
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Biga [bhc].

name: Boni
LITERACY_L2: 40% or less inKiswahili [swh] or English [eng] (2007 BTL).
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1% (2007 BTL). Literacy rate in L2: 40% or less inKiswahili [swh] or English [eng] (2007 BTL). Many suspicious of literacy as colonizing force.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, community. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also useEnglish [eng]. Also use Orma [orc]. Also use Somali [som]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Koro Zuba
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 45% in Hausa [hau].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau], with younger people having more proficiency since it is used in education. Some also use Dibo [dio], mostly elderly with good proficiency. Some also use Gbagyi [gbr], mostly elderly with good proficiency. Some also use Gbari [gby], mostly elderly with good proficiency. Also use English [eng], with younger people having more proficiency since it is used in education.

name: Prussian
Language Development: Current reconstruction and revival efforts.

name: Kpala
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Tugen, North
Language Use: Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng], mainly in schools and all official places. Also use Swahili [swh], mainly in schools and all official places.

name: Vanimo
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Lahe-Deklin and Si 2014). Also use English [eng], especially young people (Lahe-Deklin and Si 2014). Also use Indonesian [ind] (Lahe-Deklin and Si 2014). Used as L2 by Wutung [wut].

name: Koenoem
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50% in Hausa [hau].
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.All also use Hausa [hau], except for young children; young people speak it best (2019 SIL). Mostalso use English [eng], especially the youth. Most also use Piapung [pcw]. Most also use Tal[tal]. Used as L2 by Jakattoe [jrt], Piapung [pcw].

name: Moji
Language Use: Many shifting to Phula [phh]. Some shifting to Mandarin Chinese [cmn].

name: Agta, Camarines Norte
Language Use: Young people tend to prefer Tagalog [tgl] (Wurm 2007). Home. Some youngpeople, all adults. Positive attitudes. Many also use Tagalog [tgl] (Wurm 2007). Used as L2 byInagta Alabat [dul].

name: Shoo-Minda-Nye
Language Use: Also use Dza [jen]. Also use Hausa [hau]. Also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv].

name: Mama
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Special cultural events. Some of all ages. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Many also use English [eng].

name: Enya
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use French[fra].

name: Diuwe
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Konomala
Language Use: Kapsipau village shifting to Siar-Lak [sjr]. Laket dialect shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. All also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Some also use Ramoaaina [rai]. Some also use Siar-Lak [sjr].

name: Tunni
Language Use: Also use Maay [ymm].

name: Bago-Kusuntu
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5% in Tem [kdh], 5% in French [fra].
Language Use: Home, neighborhood. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Ifè [ife].Also use Tem [kdh].

name: Mbedam
Language Development: French [fra] is the language of instruction, and reportedly children speak only French during class time, although teachers sometimes give explanation in Mbudum (2003 M. Lamberty).
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub], particularly the men (Ndokobai 2014). Some also use Buwal [bhs]. Some also use Mina [hna]. Some also use Mofu-Gudur [mif] (Ndokobai 2014). Also use French [fra], especially educated people. Used as L2 by Gavar [gou].

name: Kereho-Uheng
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Hasha
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 40% in Hausa [hau].
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau], which all speak proficiently, except for some children and elderly (Decker et al 2021i). Many also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2021i).

name: Kodi
Language Development: Taught as subject in some primary schools.

name: Pyu
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Kimki [sbt]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Bubia
Language Use: Adults only. Negative attitudes. Many shifting to Cameroon Pidgin [wes].Some shifting to English [eng]. Many also use Duala [dua]. Many also use Mokpwe [bri].

name: Horom
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Badimaya
Language Development: Since the 1990s, fluent Badimaya speaker and elder Alex ‘Ollie’ George hashelped produce language materials and resources for revitalization and has taught the languageat Mount Magnet school.
Language Use: Many shifted to English [eng]. Many shifted to Wajarri [wbv].

name: Central Hongshuihe Zhuang
Writing: Han (Hanzi, Kanji, Hanja) script [Hani], dating from Han dynasty, mainly used in non-official domains, gaining popularity.
Language Use: All domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Alumu-Tesu
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021g). Many also useEnglish [eng] (Decker et al 2021g). Used as L2 by Atoro [tdv].

name: Lenkau
Language Use: Vigorous. Most domains. Used by all. Also use Penchal [pek]. Also use Titan [ttv].

name: Sumariup
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Alamblak [amp] (Coulter 2007). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Gibanawa
Language Use: The largest group in Jega LGA. A contact language.

name: Tama (Colombia)
Language Use: Orteguaza River dwellers have integrated with the Koreguaje.

name: Dogoso
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Kistane
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 22%. Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh].

name: Wanap
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Macaguaje
Language Use: Many shifted to Koreguaje [coe]. Many shifted to Siona [snn].

name: Huaulu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Ati
Language Use: Home, community. Also use Hiligaynon [hil], especially for school, contactwith outsiders, outside culture topics, jobs, and religion. Also use Kinaray-a [krj].

name: Doka
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022g). Most also use English [eng](Decker et al 2022g). Some also use Adara [kad] (Decker et al 2022g). Some also use Ajiya [idc](Decker et al 2022g).

name: Ukpe-Bayobiri
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Elege [alf]. Some also use Bete-Bendi [btt]. Some also use Ubang [uba]. Used as L2 by Elege [alf], Ubang [uba].

name: Mbesa
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Bendi
Language Use: Some also use Bangala [bxg]. Also use Congo Swahili [swc].

name: Sorsogon, Masbate
Language Use: Also use Central Bikol [bcl]. Also use Filipino [fil].

name: Amblong
Language Use: Most domains. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes.

name: Kugama
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv]. Also use Gengle [geg]. Also use Jiba [juo]. Also use Kumba [ksm]. Also use Yendang [ynq].

name: Kuan
Language Use: Also use Lao [lao]. Used as L2 by Samtao [stu].

name: Waru
Language Use: Under pressure from larger neighboring languages and from Indonesian [ind] (Wurm 2007). Some young people, all adults. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Also use Tolaki [lbw].

name: Basap
Language Use: Parents use Indonesian [ind] with children to help prepare them for school(2012 A. Guerrerio). Home, community, religion.

name: Dambi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–25%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–50%.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Tala
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022d). A few also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022d). Used as L2 by Zamwal [zah].

name: Galice
Language Development: Texts.

name: Hinduri
Language Use: Home, village. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Hindi[hin].

name: Rongpo
Language Development: Hindi used for all written communication.
Language Use: Rongpo speakers learn Garhwali simultaneously with Rongpo. Code switching and code mixing are very common. It is uncertain whether stable bilingualism will continue or whether Rongpo will be replaced by Garhwali or Hindi. Home, community. Used by all. Also use English [eng]. Also use Garhwali [gbm]. Also use Hindi [hin]. Also use Kumaoni [kfy].

name: Kulango, Bouna
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 15%–25%.
Language Use: Also use French [fra].

name: Larevat
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes.

name: Niksek
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.

name: Ekit
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Efik [efi]. Also use Ibibio [ibb].

name: Askopan
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Naasioi [nas].

name: Loun
Language Use: Many shifted to Ambonese Malay [abs]. Many shifted to Indonesian [ind].

name: Bambassi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 5%. Taught as subject in some primary schools in grades 1–3.
Language Use: Used by all. Mixed attitudes. Children in some areas (e.g. Wamba) are no longer learning the language. Most also use West Central Oromo [gaz], learning it as children and using it in many domains. A few also use Amharic [amh], especially some adults in Bambassi area. Also use Berta [wti]. Also use Eastern Oromo [hae].

name: Tày Sa Pa
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Kreye
Language Use: All shifted to Portuguese [por].

name: Kujarge
Language Use: Many shifting to Dar Daju Daju [djc]. Many shifting to Fur [fvr].

name: Kemak
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Tetun Dili [tdt] (Williams-van Klinken et al2002). Used as L2 by Welaun [wlh].

name: Nyala, East
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Over 15%. Literacy rate in L2: Over 50% in Kiswahili [swh] or English [eng].
Language Use: Home, social gatherings. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Swahili [swh].

name: Itneg, Banao
Language Use: Moderate vitality. Home, community, education. Used by all. Positiveattitudes. Also use English [eng]. Also use Filipino [fil]. Also use Ilocano [ilo].

name: Ju
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022d). A fewalso use Bankal [jjr] (Decker et al 2022d). A few also use Bole [bol] (Decker et al 2022d). Afew also use Nigerian Fulfulde [fuv] (Decker et al 2022d). A few also use Saya [say] (Decker etal 2022d).

name: Mvuba
Language Use: Also use Congo Swahili [swc], taught in primary schools. Also use Nande [nnb], the language of the dominant ethnolinguistic community.

name: Penrhyn
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 95% in Rarotongan [rar].
Language Use: Youngest speakers are young adults. The language is rapidly disappearing (Wurm 2007). Most shifting to English [eng]. Many shifting to Cook Islands Maori [rar].

name: Zangwal
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022d). Many also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2022d). Some also use Kir-Balar [kkr] (Decker et al 2022d). Some also use Tala [tak] (Decker et al 2022d). Used as L2 by Kir-Balar [kkr], Mansi [zns].

name: Gengle
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Kugama [kow], Teme [tdo].

name: Koro Nulu
Language Use: Home, community, work. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use Hausa [hau], with younger people having more proficiency since it is used in education. Some also use Dibo [dio], mostly adults and some elderly. Some also use Gbari [gby], mostly adults and older. Some also use Gwandara [gwn], mostly adults and some elderly. Also use English [eng], with younger people having more proficiency since it is used in education.

name: Awun
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Firan
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Most also use English [eng],though comprehension levels vary. Young adults are most proficient in English. Most also useHausa [hau], except for children. Many also use Iten [etx], except for children. Some also useBerom [bom], especially the middle-aged and older generation.

name: Davawenyo
Language Use: Also use Cebuano [ceb], particularly by Lowland Davawenyo, whereas HighlandDavawenyo have only low comprehension of it.

name: Sala
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Nauna
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon); endangered or potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Some young people, all adults. Also use Titan [ttv].

name: Bwamu, Cwi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 3% in Jula [dyu]. Unable to use other Bwamuliterature. Motivation for literacy is high.
Language Use: Home. Used by all. Also use French [fra]. Also use Jula [dyu].

name: Kalou
Language Use: Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Sa
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 60%–80%. Taught as subject in primary schools in grades 1 and 2.
Language Use: Home, Community; Mixed: Work, Religion, Education. Used by all. Positive attitudes.

name: Trimuris
Language Use: Vigorous. Used by all.

name: Tuwari
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Below 1%.
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Conrad and Lewis 1988).

name: Ubi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 15%–20%. Preschool literacy classes. Taught as subject in some primary schools.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Na
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% (Singh 1995a).
Language Use: Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Kairak
Language Use: Used by all. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], especially young people. Alsouse Ura [uro].

name: Papi
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2%–3%.
Language Use: Vigorous (Hammarström 2010). Used by all. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi] (Wurm 2007).

name: Ubang
Language Use: Used by all. Many also use Bukpe [ukp]. Many also use Elege [alf]. Some also use Bete-Bendi [btt]. Used as L2 by Bukpe [ukp], Elege [alf].

name: Mursi
Writing: Ethiopic script [Ethi], limited usage. Latin script [Latn], limited usage.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2% in Amharic [amh].
Language Use: Home, daily life. Used by all. Also use Amharic [amh], but only in situations of contact with other people groups, such as trading and tourism. Used as L2 by Kwegu [xwg].

name: Pom
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Gavar
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 85%.
Language Use: Home, village, market, church. Some young people, all adults. Positiveattitudes. Most also use Buwal [bhs]. Many also use Adamawa Fulfulde [fub]. Some also use Giziga[giz]. Some also use Hausa [hau]. Some also use Mbudum [xmd]. Some also use Psikye [kvj]. A fewalso use Daba [dbq]. A few also use French [fra]. A few also use Mafa [maf]. Used as L2 by Buwal[bhs].

name: Yerukula
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 26% (1991 census).
Language Use: Vigorous language use. In Andhra Pradesh: home, community, religion; in Rayalseema and Telengana regions, wider use. Positive attitudes. Some also use Telugu [tel], with higher proficiency in Andhra Pradesh and among educated adults. Also use English [eng].

name: Malango
Language Use: Used by all.

name: Kensiu
Writing: Latin script [Latn], no longer in use, never widely used. Thai script [Thai], no longer in use, never widely used.
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Numerous other extinct dialects further west (Bradley 2007a). Used by all. Also use Malay [zlm] (Bradley 2007a).

name: Bu (Bauchi State)
Language Use: Home, community. Used by all. Also use Hausa [hau].

name: Lalia
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Lingala [lin], in church. Also use Mongo-Nkundu [lol], in church.

name: Suma
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Hungworo
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary schools.
Language Use: Approximately 3% live in towns where it is mainly spoken by adults only. Used by all. Most also use Hausa [hau] (Blench 2019).

name: Zo'é
Language Use: In 1997, all Zo’e speakers were still monolingual (Crevels 2007). Used by all. A few also use Portuguese [por], isolated and protected by government reserve.

name: Ngatik Men's Creole
Language Use: Women and children understand it. Older adults only. All also use Pohnpeian [pon], the Sapwahfik dialect (Wurm 2007).

name: Yuhup
Language Development: Schooling in Portuguese [por] is desired but some teaching is done in Yuhup.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Portuguese [por], especially about half of the men. Also use Tucano [tuo], especially men.

name: Krobu
Language Use: Also use Abé [aba]. Also use Baoulé [bci].

name: Tae'
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 20%–30%. About 10%–20% write.
Language Use: Vigorous. Written use for ancestral stories. All domains. Positive attitudes. Also use Indonesian [ind]. Used as L2 by Limola [ley].

name: Ma (Papua New Guinea)
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 20%.
Language Use: Vigorous. Home. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Yawalapití
Language Use: Elderly only. Many shifted to Kamayurá [kay], due to mixed marriages with Kamayura (Instituto Socioambiental 2020). Many shifted to Kuikúro-Kalapálo [kui], due to mixed marriages with Kuikuro (Instituto Socioambiental 2020). A few also use Portuguese [por], being isolated on a government protected reserve.

name: Tomoip
Language Use: Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Sulka [sua].

name: Mwera (Nyasa)
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Chinali
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Kungarakany
Language Development: Texts.

name: Doghoro
Language Use: All domains.

name: Nahuatl, Central
Language Use: Most also use Spanish [spa], where in San Miguel Canoa northeast of Puebla City, most are monolingual.

name: Akpa
Language Use: Home, Community, Religious settings, Special cultural events, Technologyand media. Used by all. Some also use English [eng].

name: Lepki
Language Use: Home, religious services, market. Some also use Ketengban [xte], at Luban.

name: Ngamambo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Many also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. Many also use Meta’ [mgo]. Some also use English [eng]. Some also use Mungaka [mhk]. A few also use French [fra]. A few also use Ngemba [nge]. Used as L2 by Njen [njj].

name: Romam
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Tobian
Language Use: Some of all ages. Also use Palauan [pau].

name: Zapotec, Zaniza
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Nahari
Language Use: Also use English [eng].

name: Ontenu
Language Use: Adults only. All shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Warkay-Bipim
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Many also use Indonesian [ind].

name: Tumleo
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.

name: Likum
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 D. Tryon, 2000 S. Wurm). Some young people, all adults. Also use Nyindrou [lid].

name: Traveller Scottish
Language Use: Most also use English [eng].

name: Sera
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 50%–75%.
Language Use: Seriously endangered (2000 D. Tryon; 2000 S. Wurm). Most shifting to English [eng]. Many shifting to Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 by Pin [wmx].

name: Norn
Writing: Latin script [Latn], used since the 17th century. Runic script [Runr], used as early as the 10th century.
Language Development: There have been attempts to revive Norn.

name: Bukat
Language Use: Vigorous.

name: Morawa
Language Use: Also use English [eng]. Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Also use Magi [mgu]. Also use Suau [swp].

name: Fembe
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: Below 5%.
Language Use: Also use English [eng] (Minnegal and Dwyer 2017). Also use Tok Pisin [tpi](Minnegal and Dwyer 2017).

name: Mbessa
Language Development: Taught as subject in a few primary schools. Agency: Mbessa LanguageCommittee (MBELAC).
Language Use: All domains except education. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Some alsouse English [eng], as language of public education. A few also use Cameroon Pidgin [wes]. A fewalso use French [fra].

name: Bharia
Language Use: Many also use English [eng].

name: Razihi
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Many also use Sanaani Arabic [ayn].

name: Lawangan
Language Use: Also use Bakumpai [bkr].

name: Beele
Language Use: All shifted to Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2022c).

name: Hmong, Central Mashan
Language Use: All domains.

name: Jad
Language Development: Hindi used for all written communication.
Language Use: Garhwali [gbm] learned together with Jad. Code switching and code mixingcommon. Uncertain whether stable bilingualism will continue or whether Jad will be replaced byGarhwali [gbm] or Hindi [hin]. Home, community. Used by all. Negative attitudes. Also useCentral Tibetan [bod]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Garhwali [gbm]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Amuzgo (Ipalapa)
Language Development: Bilingual primary schools with Mixtec teachers.
Language Use: Rarely used in public gatherings or in the town centers. Some young people,all adults, very few youth. Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Silesian, Lower
Language Use: Literature by Gerhard Hauptmann. Also use Polish [pol].

name: Pukapuka
Language Use: While it is spoken by almost everyone on the island including children and non-native spouses, it has few written resources and is in a diglossic relationship with Cook Islands Maori, the national language. Positive attitudes. All also use Cook Islands Maori [rar], in church and village meetings, in diglossic situations, and is taught in school. Most also use English [eng], only when communicating with outsiders and in written communication (emails, documents) in some government work situations.

name: Yidgha
Language Use: Home. Some of all ages. Positive attitudes. All also use Khowar [khw], some shifting. Most also use Urdu [urd], especially the educated.

name: Tai Do
Writing: Latin script [Latn]. Tai Yo script [Tayo], limited usage.
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Tiale
Language Use: Most key domains. Some young people, all adults. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Akei [tsr], Tolomako [tlm].

name: Okpe (Southwestern Edo)
Language Use: Used as L2 by Idesa [ids], Oloma [olm].

name: Takua
Language Use: Also use Vietnamese [vie].

name: Anakalangu
Language Development: Texts.

name: Agoi
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all.Most also use Lokaa [yaz] (Decker et al 2022e). Many also use English [eng] (Decker et al2022e). A few also use Deko-Dusanga [uya] (Decker et al 2022e). Used as L2 by Deko-Dusanga[uya].

name: Ebughu
Language Use: Used as L2 by Ilue [ilv].

name: Wetamut
Language Use: Endangered (2000 D. Tryon). Used by entire ethnic group. Under pressure from Lakon [lkn] and Nume [tgs]. Most key domains. Used by all. Positive attitudes. Used as L2 by Koro [krf].

name: Konongo
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Used as L2 by Ruwila [rwl].

name: Gyem
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau].

name: Amto
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% in Tok Pisin [tpi].
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Siawi [mmp]. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi]. Used as L2 bySiawi [mmp].

name: Duau
Language Development: Many schools, but low literacy rate.
Language Use: Used by all. Most also use Dobu [dob]. Many also use Bunama [bdd]. Manyalso use English [eng], especially young people. Used as L2 by ’Auhelawa [kud], Bwanabwana[tte], Mwatebu [mwa].

name: Ligenza
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: High in Lingala [lin].
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin].

name: Bu
Language Use: Nkadan dialect shifting to Hausa [hau]. Used by all. Most also use Hausa[hau].

name: Sur
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 30% in Hausa [hau].
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Some young people, all adults. Most also use Hausa [hau], except the elderly. Most also use Ngas [anc]. Also use English [eng], especially youth and adults. Used as L2 by Bijim [jbm].

name: One, Kabore
Language Use: All domains except church. Some young people, all adults. Also use Tok Pisin [tpi].

name: Kayan, Wahau
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Gilima
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: Low.
Language Use: Also use Lingala [lin]. Also use Mbandja [zmz]. Also use Ngbaka [nga]. Alsouse Ngbaka Ma’bo [nbm].

name: Ukaan
Language Use: Also use Yoruba [yor].

name: Lyngngam
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% (Singh 1994b).
Language Use: Also use Assamese [asm]. Also use English [eng]. Also use Garo [grt]. Also use Hindi [hin].

name: Cori
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Hausa [hau]. All also use Hyam [jab]. Some alsouse English [eng], especially young, educated people.

name: Kopar
Language Use: Older adults only. All shifted to Tok Pisin [tpi] (Foley 2004). Many shifted to Marangis [wax], especially young people (Foley 2004).

name: Kompane
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Phimbi
Language Use: Also use Chichewa [nya]. Also use Nyungwe [nyu].

name: Dengese
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Used by all. All also use Lingala [lin]. Many also use French [fra].

name: Ngando (Central African Republic)
Language Use: Most also use Sango [sag].

name: Toro
Language Use: Home, Community, Workplace, Religion, Special cultural events. Used by all. Positive attitudes. All also use Hausa [hau] (Decker et al 2021g). Most also use English [eng] (Decker et al 2021g). Some also use Arum [aab] (Decker et al 2021g).

name: Koyo
Language Development: Texts.
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lingala [lin] (Leitch 2005).

name: Mixtec, Huitepec
Language Use: Most homes in Huitepec; more in rural areas. Used by all.

name: Tofanma
Language Use: Potentially endangered (2000 S. Wurm). Home, religion. Used by all. Used as L2 by Namla [naa].

name: Moikodi
Language Use: Also use Hiri Motu [hmo]. Used as L2 by Bariji [bjc].

name: Mixtec, Chigmecatitlán
Language Use: Also use Spanish [spa].

name: Bozo, Tièma Cièwè
Language Use: Used by all. Also use Koyra Chiini Songhay [khq]. Also use Maasina Fulfulde[ffm].

name: Hmong, Northern Guiyang
Language Use: Home, community, market.

name: Thopho
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Mandarin Chinese [cmn]. Also use Nong Zhuang [zhn].

name: Terebu
Language Use: Some young people, all adults.

name: Asu (Nigeria)
Language Use: Used as primary language by all ages in 3 villages, but nearly extinct inthe 7 others. Some of all ages. All also use Hausa [hau]. Asu use has shifted to Hausa in 7 ofthe 10 villages (Decker et al 2021e). Most also use Nupe-Nupe-Tako [nup] (Decker et al 2021e).

name: Taliabu
Language Use: Positive attitudes.
